KSIMU residents and NASA supporters burned banners congratulating President Uhuru Kenyatta's on his win at the 8 August poll. Police intervened with teargas.

Hundreds of demonstrators protested to show discontent at fake Somalia currency circulating in the region and burned unspecified amount of the currency. They requested Somali Federal Government to end this phenomenon and tackle those making the currency in Galkacyo and Adaado.
Residents in Maili Saba, in Dandora, protested against the high levels of banditry attacks in the area.
A Christian group protests against homosexuality in Kampala on 26/08. Details limited.
NRM supporters hold demonstration in Lira to support removal of presidential age limit
AM, Bariire, Lower Shabelle: civilians protested against the 25 August killing of civilians by joint security forces.

Traders shut down their shops in protest against Kampala Capital City Authority-KCCA for allegedly selling off the market to unidentified investor. Carrying placards, the angry vendors poured into the main road. Anti- riot police had to fire bullets and teargas to disperse them.
NRM supporters hold demonstration in Kabale town to support removal of presidential age limit.
A Makerere University student is arrested following an anti-age limit protest during a presidential speech.
Nairobi train workers protested, causing the train service to be suspended.
Protests erupted after Eid al Adha prayers against the extradition of ONLF official Qalbi Dagax. Five female organisers arrested by JSF Police. No reported violence from the protesters.
Peaceful protests in NASA's stronghold Kisii over President Uhuru Kenyatta's remarks on Justice David Maraga
Second day of peaceful protests in NASA's stronghold Kisii over President Uhuru Kenyatta's remarks on Justice David Maraga
Residents of Bonyamatutu village in Nyamira County, the home of Chief Justice Maraga, protest against Kenyatta's verbal attacks on the judiciary.
Police in Budaka District on Monday arrested three Members of Parliament who reportedly staged a demonstration over the sorry state of Mbale-Tirinyi-Nakalama road.
Civilians stage protest against extradition of Qalbi Dagax. Protests remained peaceful.

Hundreds of Moi Market traders in Thika Town have demonstrated over the allocation of a leisure garden located in the town centre to hawkers who flooded the town since Kiambu Governor Ferdinand Waititu was declared the Jubilee Party prior to the August 8 election
Refugees in the Dadaab Camp held a demonstration to protest against the renditioning of refugees to Ethiopia.

All markets in Qardho were closed in protest to the increasing rate of Somali Shilling to the US dollar. Police conducted security operations where they detained 10 forex dealers. The forex dealers were taken to Qardho Police Station.

Approximately 100 locals conducted a peaceful demonstration on the road linking the Airport and Botan in protest to the inflated exchange rate of Somali Shilling to the US dollar. The demonstration ended peacefully without any incident.
Protests in Ceelasha Biyaha and Afgooye after AMISOM forces shot and killed a farmer.
Protests in Ceelasha Biyaha and Afgooye after AMISOM forces shot and killed a farmer.

Employees of Berbera port boycotted from work in protest of the new safety measures imposed by a commercial company on all staff, contractors and agents when accessing the port. The safety measures included possession of a metal helmet, a safety vest and safety shoes.

Hundreds of protesters demonstrated on the streets of Cel-Buh village (c. 111 km South East of Cerigabo) in protest against the denial of the Somali shillings by local traders. The demonstration ended peacefully.

Striking nurses protest outside Afya House in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) on September 11, 2017. On the same day, taxi drivers working for Uber, Little, Taxify and Mondo began an indefinite strike in protest of the rates at which they are currently being paid. Tens of drivers gathered outside City Hall in Nairobi, hooting and making their plight known to passers-by.

Residents of eastern Hararghe towns staged protest demonstrations against Liyu violence in Dedere, Qobo, Awoday and Chelenko on 12/09. Two protesters were injured by police in Dedere. Possibly related to the protest, a mob attacked a group of ethnic Somali traders in Aweday, killing more than 30.

Residents of eastern Hararghe towns staged protest demonstrations against Liyu violence in Dedere, Qobo, Awoday and Chelenko on 12/09. Two protesters were injured by police in Dedere. Possibly related to the protest, a mob attacked a group of ethnic Somali traders in Aweday, killing more than 30.

Protests against the TPLF take place in several Oromia Region towns (not named). Protesters are demonstrating against the killing of Oromo persons by Somali region militia members, politicians and activists believe the Somali region militias are backed by the ruling party in Ethiopia which is Tigrayan People's Liberation Front (TPLF).

Residents of eastern Hararghe towns staged protest demonstrations against Liyu Police paramilitary violence in Dedere, Qobo, Awoday and Chelenko on 12/09. Two protesters were injured by Liyu Police in Dedere. Possibly related to the protest, a mob attacked a group of ethnic Somali traders in Aweday, killing more than 30.

People in Chinaksan village demonstrated against continued violence perpetrated by the Liyu police. They also complained that the government was disarming locals but not doing anything to stop the Liyu police. Similar protests took place in Dedere, Qobo, Awoday and Chelenko.

Residents of eastern Hararghe towns staged protest demonstrations against Liyu violence in Dedere, Qobo, Awoday and Chelenko on 12/09. Two protesters were injured by police in Dedere. Possibly related to the protest, a mob attacked a group of ethnic Somali traders in Aweday, killing more than 30.
Conductors subscribing to the Kampala Operational Taxi Stages Association (KOTSA) matched on the streets of Kampala supporting the move to uplift the age limit.
Kenyan nurses held demonstrations across the country.
On 13/09 protests were held in Boreda and Karamille towns of Western Haraghe zone. One person was killed by security officers, reasons not known.
Afternoon, Makka al Mukarama road, Mogadishu: peaceful pro-government protests were witnessed. The nature of the protest is not known.
There was a pro-government demonstration between KM1-KM3 is Mogadishu. Disruption was minimal.

In East Hararge, Goro gutu woreda, Karra Mille, a demonstration was held against continued incursions by the Liyu police. It is not clear if the protesters were violent. Federal troops intervened; one man was killed and 6 others injured.
Police arrested demonstrators in Keroka town in Nyamira County. The demonstrators were protesting against President Kenyatta's verbal attacks against the judiciary.
Civilians protest at Ethiopian consulate following killing of Somali nationals in the Ethiopian Oromo region.
Civilians spontaneously organised protests against the green-on-green skirmish that opposed Mogadishu Stabilization Force to Army in Hodan. Protests remained peaceful.

Khat dealers in Lascanod protested as a result of a decision made by the government to increase the tax on khat coming from Kenya to Lascanod. SLP in Lacanod denied for the entry of khat into the town. Community elders at Lacanod intervened and managed the situation. Transportation of khat proceeded to the town.

A few school teachers in Cerigabo demonstrated in front of the Office of the Ministry of Education in Cerigabo in protest over the teacher's examination results. This came after the Ministry of Education demoted several tutors after failing to achieve the pass scores for the examination. The demonstration ended peacefully.
Ugandan police have detained a lawmaker and 10 others who were arrested while protesting against a plan that they charge would enable the country's long-term president to rule for life.
Supporters of President Kenyatta protest against the Supreme Court's decision to annul the elections in the strongholds of Nakuru, Kikuyu, Nyeri and Eldoret towns

Supporters of President Kenyatta protest against the Supreme Court's decision to annul the elections in the strongholds of Nakuru, Kikuyu, Nyeri and Eldoret towns. Jubilee supporters in Nyeri town demanded the Supreme Court to order recount of votes of the presidential elections. The demo was held as Kenyans await the full judgment of the court.
Supporters of President Kenyatta protest against the Supreme Court's decision to annul the elections in the strongholds of Nakuru, Kikuyu, Nyeri and Eldoret towns
Protesters outside the Supreme Court waved placards against Chief Justice David Maraga whom they accuse of slowing the country's development after nullification of President Uhuru Kenyatta's victory

Residents in Faluja neighbourhood peacefully demonstrated against Somaliland Army whom they accused of grabbing land adjacent to SLA headquarters that was given to residents by the local government. Somaliland police dispersed the demonstrators. There were no reports of arrests.
NASA protesters and police outside the Supreme Court (Nairobi - Starehe) were on Wednesday attacked by a swarm of bees and forced to flee amidst the issuing of the full ruling by Supreme Court Judges

South-West Administration soldiers clashed at Diinsoor town (c. 90 km South West of Baidoa). There was an exchange of gunfire. There were no reports of casualties. The ISWA soldiers belong to Geelid and Dabare clans who disputed over the killing of ISWA soldier from Geelidle clan by ISWA soldier from Dabare clan on 18/09. ISWA soldiers from Geelidle clan were isolated from the rest of the ISWA forces and amassed at area in the town in protest of the incident.
Jubilee supporters who gathered in Bungoma were chased away by NASA supporters. No evidence of violence.
Police fired tear gas to disperse protestors and arrested opposition politicians who protested the age limit bill in Kampala.

Hundreds of students at the country's main Makerere University in Kampala waved branches and chanted 'K'ogikwatako!' -- meaning 'Don't dare touch it!' in the local Luganda language -- in reference to the constitutional clause on age limits. Armed officers -- including military police -- fired volleys of teargas forcing the students to flee to their residence halls and hostels.
In the northern town of Lira, demonstrators left a mock coffin at a central road junction with 'The removal of the presidential age limit is the death of our country' painted on the side.

Hundreds of protesters took to the streets of Galkayo to show their support for Galmudug's president Ahmed Duale Gelle (Haf) over his decision on the Gulf crisis. The protesters waved placards showing support for the Galmudug leader, and condemning the decision by his deputy and the regional parliament to oppose his stance.
Police have fired bullets and tear gas to disperse students who have gone on strike demanding the immediate release of their colleagues who are currently detained at Wandageya Police Station.
In Bale zone, Beltu (laga hidha) woreda and in Robe people demonstrated against the government and Somali Regional President over ongoing violence happening in Eastern parts of the country.
In Bale zone, Beltu (laga hidha) woreda and in Robe people demonstrated against the government and Somali Regional President over ongoing violence happening in Eastern parts of the country.

On 23 September 2017, a peaceful demonstration was conducted by supporters of the President of Galmudug Interim Administration (GIA) and Vice President of GIA in Cadado town. The protest may have occurred the previous day.

A civilian man was shot and killed by a traffic police officer at Geed Jacayl area in Wardhigley district. The man and the police officer had a verbal altercation over tax issues before the police officer killed him. The perpetrator escaped from the scene. Residents in the area protested against the killing of the civilian man. Government security forces in the area dispersed the crowd.
Students of a school in Makueni county marched to the sub-county headquarters in Kibwezi town on Monday in protest against their deputy principal.
Over 100 residents of Kahunyira Cell, Rwamucucu Sub County in Rukiga district stormed offices of the Kabale District State Attorney, protesting the release of people who had been arrested for murder.

Students protesting new academic rules surrounded the Vice Chancellor Prof. Celestine Obua's office. Some students however snuck through the neighboring regional referral hospital gates and poured onto the main road which forced police to unleash teargas.

Kamuli Municipality was on Monday rocked by gunfire for over three hours as police battled anti-age limit protesters led by opposition Democratic Party [DP] National Youth Chairman Moses Bigirwa. Police intervened to disperse anti-age limit protesters loyal to the Democratic Party (DP) in Kumuli.
Migori county MCA allied to the opposition led county residents in peaceful demonstrations for free and fair elections.

On 26 September 2017, NASA supporters in Kisumu marched to the IEBC to demand the resignation of the Commission's top officials. Dozens of heavily armed police officers stood and watched in the town's sweltering heat as protesters marched through the streets.

President Uhuru Kenyatta's supporters hold anti-opposition demonstrations in Murang'a town. President Uhuru Kenyatta said the government will not allow the IEBC officials to be removed from office unconstitutionally.

Security operatives forced some legislators out of the Chambers as they refused to leave the room to protest their suspension after disagreements over the debate to lift the presidential age limit of 75 years.
Police dispersed a demonstration against the anti age bill in Kabale university.
Police in Masaka District arrested six members of Forum for Democratic Change (FDC), who staged a march to protest the impending removal of the presidential age limit from the Constitution.
People protested against the anti age bill in Mbale. Several arrested by police.
Anti age limi protests in Mukono. An unidentified police officer undressed the Municipal speaker as they tried to arrest her for participating in the protests.
NASA supporters protested at the IEBC offices in Mombasa.
A protest took place in Borama on 27/09. The protest is related to a land-based clash in the area. Police reportedly made arrests in the days that followed.
24 people were arrested in Ankole and Teso sub regions for holding unlawful assemblies to protest the anti age limit bill.
24 people were arrested in Ankole and Teso sub regions for holding unlawful assemblies to protest the anti age limit bill.
Babu Owino's supporters protested outside the Milimani court (Nairobi - Westlands), demanding his release after a second night in cell over apparent insults to the President

In East Hararghe, Golo Oda woreda, several young men were arrested and beaten for demonstrating against the violence occurring in Eastern Ethiopia. Locals surrounded the police station in opposition to the arrests. Policemen fired their weapons, accidentally hitting the city administrator. The current status of the administrator is not known.

On 28 September 2017, University of Nairobi students protested the arrest of Embakasi East MP Babu Owino (Nairobi - Starehe). 27 students and staff at the University of Nairobi were reportedly injured when police used tear gas, beat them with wooden clubs, robbed them and threatened them with sexual violence.
Peaceful anti-government protest occur in Hodan. The reason for the protest is not known.

An Oromo festival on 01/10 turned into a anti government protest. Over a million people gathered at Horra Harsede, a meeting place for Irreecha celebration in the central town of Bushoftu, 50 kilometres (31 miles) south of the capital, Addis Ababa.
Anti-IEBC protests in Kitui
There were anti-IEBC demonstrations in Bungoma
There were anti-IEBC demonstrations in Kajiado
There were anti-IEBC demonstrations in Kilifi
There were anti-IEBC demonstrations in Kisii
Anti-IEBC protests in Garissa
Students march for the reunification of Gaalkacyo.
Peaceful protest by NASA supporters in Mombasa
In East Shewa , Awaday town, people took part in a demonstration denouncing the jailing of various Oromo political figures.
In Mombasa, Nasa supporters held their anti-IEBC demos peacefully.
On 7 October 2017, Kenyan conservationists participated in the Global March for elephants, rhinos and lions to raise awareness on threats facing the iconic wildlife species.
Students at Moi university in Eldoret protested after a student is raped by a security guard.
Oromo Opposition media is accusing federal soldiers of shooting and killing a high school student during a protest in west Hararge zone, Mieso woreda, in a place called Muso.
In Vihiga, MPs Alfred Agoi (Sabatia) and Ernest Kagesi (Vihiga) led protests. They asked voters not to take part in the October 26 poll if reforms demanded by Nasa are not effected
More than 200 anti-IEBC demonstrators converged at a petrol station on the turn-off to Voi town and marched peacefully to the Scripture Mission Centre
In Lamu, hundreds of protesters at the Milano area in Lamu town marched to the IEBC offices declaring 'Chiloba must go'
In West Hararge, Guraawa woreda, Dira town, People demonstrated to oppose the jailing of various Oromo political figures. Note: Girawa woreda is in East Hararge Zone.

Demonstrations for the release of political prisoners were held in Fadis, east Hararge zone. According to opposition media, a young man by the name of Jamal Kile was killed by Ethiopian military forces during the demonstration.
Police disperse anti-IEBC protests in Saiya. No report of violence from demonstrators.
On 9 October 2017, NASA held anti-IEBC demonstrations in Kakamega.
On 9 October 2017, a small group of NASA supporters protest in Mombasa.
On 9 October 2017, three people were wounded during NASA demonstrations in Nairobi. A man in a car shot one person and injured tow other protesters before driving away.

Over hundreds of IDPs staged a peaceful demonstration in Ainabo in protest of 'unfair distribution of food aid provided by the Somaliland government and Aid organizations to IDPs' in town. The protestors accused the mayor and the other local councillors of unequally distributing the aid to the IDPs. The protestors marched through streets in Ainabo chanting against authority officials.
There were protests against the IEBC in Kisii.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protest in Wollega for the release of political prisoners.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.

Protests reported in Ambo after rumours spread that a mineral water factory was to move to another town. The initial protest led to a wider anti-government protest. Date unknown; reported by the source in conjunction with a series of anti-government protests which occurred on 11/10.
Protests in Shashamane continue. No incidents reported.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Protests in Wollega continue for a second day. Protesters blocked the Moyale-Addis road.
Anti-government protests occur in Tulu Bolo, Sululta, Gimbi, Qelem and Agarfa on 11/10 and 12/10. No reported incidents.
Anti-government protests reported in Bule Hora.
Anti-government protests reported in Gimbi.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
Protests in Wollega continue for a third day. Protesters blocked the Moyale-Addis road.
Anti-government protests reported in several towns in Oromia.
On 13 October 2017, NASA supporters held a peaceful demonstration in Kakamega.
On 13 October 2017, police shot at protesters who had coverged to march in Homa Bay.
On 13 October 2017, police shot at protesters who had coverged to march in Siaya.
Police lob teargas canisters against election protesters along Moi avenue (Nairobi - Starehe) on 13/10.

Residents of Garbaharrey town held a peaceful demonstration against regional states presidents who held a meeting Kismayo during that week. The demonstration was conducted peacefully with no report of violence. The demo may have occurred the previous day.
15 October, evening - anti-al Shabaab protests are reported in Boondheere.
Anti-al Shabaab protest occurred at the site of the large hotel bombing on 14/10.
Anti-IEBC protest along Moi avenue (Nairobi - Starehe).
In Isiolo Town, Nasa supporters marched peacefully and converged outside Isiolo North Constituency IEBC offices calling for electoral reforms. The protest was led by Ms Nasibo Sora Abdirahaman.
On 16 October in Siaya, business premises were closed as hundreds of residents demonstrated in streets. Protesters marched to IEBC offices to present their petition.
On 16 October in Vihiga [western Kenya], residents stormed streets carrying twigs and placards, demanding IEBC reforms. They called for resignation of IEBC Chief Executive Officer Ezra Chiloba.
Anti-government protests reported in Jima, Debre Selam, Sulultra and Metu following the shooting and killing of two civilians by government forces.
Anti-government protests reported in Jima, Debre Selam, Sulultra and Metu following the shooting and killing of two civilians by government forces.
Anti-government protests reported in Jima, Debre Selam, Sulultra and Metu following the shooting and killing of two civilians by government forces.
Anti-government protests reported in Jima, Debre Selam, Sulultra and Metu following the shooting and killing of two civilians by government forces.

A large group of Somali citizens gathered at Xaawo Taako statue to protest on the deadly explosion that occurred at KM 5. The demonstrators chanted anti-al Shabaab slogans and encouraged Somali people to unite in solidarity to counter al Shabaab attacks.
On 16 October in Migori, shops, offices and hotels were closed as Nasa demonstrators took to the streets. Police watched them from a distance and did not interfere with the demos.
On 16 October in Kakamega, former Senator Boni Khalwale and Lurambi MP Titus Khamala led a group of opposition supporters in anti-IEBC protests.
On 16 October 2017, rallies were held at Kalerwe and Bwaise against a proposed presidential age limit removal.
On 16 October 2017, rallies were held at Kalerwe and Bwaise against a proposed presidential age limit removal.
NASA protesters engage police. Live bullets allegedly used. No reports of protester violence or injuries.
In Mombasa, police dispersed NASA demonstrators who were assembling with an aim of storming the CBD. Police arrested a few protesters, and several others were injured in the process.
Teargas bombs were thrown on striking daladala operators to disperse them in Tanga City. They were protesting against traffic police fines and bullying. No one was injured.
Anti-government protests reported in Sulultra the day following the killing of two residents by government forces.
Anti-government protests reported in Muke Turi the day following the killing of two residents by government forces. The protests became violent the following day.
Anti-government protests reported in Chanho the day following the killing of two residents by government forces.

Hundreds of pro-ODM youth holding anti-IEBC protests in Kisii County on 17 October were forced to run for safety after anti-riot police lobbed tear gas canisters to disperse them. The youth were protesting the harassment of Woman Representative Janet Ong'era.
Civilians take the streets for anti-al Shabaab protests in Cadaado and Kismayo. The protest comes following the hotel attacks in Mogadishu on 14/10.
Civilians take the streets for anti-al Shabaab protests in Cadaado and Kismayo. The protest comes following the hotel attacks in Mogadishu on 14/10.
Residents in Lasanod marched peacefully along the street of Lasanod in solidarity with Somalis who lost their loved ones at the bombing incident at Zoobe Junction in Mogadishu on 14 October 2017.
Anti-government protests reported in Gebre Guracha the day following the killing of two residents by government forces. The protests became violent the following day.

On 17 October 2017, Ugandan police fired teargas and rubber bullets at opposition supporters in Kasubi, Rubaga Division, in Kampala protesting plans to remove presidential age limits. Two people were rushed to hospital.
Civilians stage peaceful protest against al Shabaab following 14 OCT bombing.

Anti-government protests occurred in Melketuri, Ejerie, Chanco, Bedelle, Metu. The source reports 'protests continued' in these areas, indicating some may have occurred on 17/10 as well - this was not confirmed. Violence not reported, however, the source states 'a dozen' protesters have been killed since last week.' The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

Anti-government protests occurred in Melketuri, Ejerie, Chanco, Bedelle, Metu. The source reports 'protests continued' in these areas, indicating some may have occurred on 17/10 as well - this was not confirmed. Violence not reported, however, the source states 'a dozen' protesters have been killed since last week.' The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.

Anti-government protests occurred in Melketuri, Ejerie, Chanco, Bedelle, Metu. The source reports 'protests continued' in these areas, indicating some may have occurred on 17/10 as well - this was not confirmed. Violence not reported, however, the source states 'a dozen' protesters have been killed since last week.' The dates and locations of these reported deaths are not known, and may have occurred in other towns reporting protests from other sources. Fatalities divided among town with reported violence.
Two people were taken to hospital after police used teargas and live bullets to dispersed a consultative rally on age limit in Kasubi, Rubaga Division, in Kampala.

A large crowd of residents in Mogadishu gathered at Stadium Koonis in Abdulaziz district for a demonstration attended by top government officials. This took place after protesters against the VBIED incident that occurred on 14 October 2017 were dispersed by police.

Hundreds of people from all parts of the community of Baidoa staged a demonstration against the VBIED attack in Mogadishu and in support of the victims of the attack. The demonstration was organized by the local authorities and South West administration. Officials from the local authorities and South West state attended the rally. The demonstration ended peacefully.

Hundreds of people in Beletweyne demonstrated against the killing of civilians during the VBIED attack that occurred in Mogadishu on 14 October 2017. Local businesses were closed and vehicle movements were restricted during the demonstration. The demonstration ended peacefully.
About 50 locals conducted a peaceful demonstration at Gaaca area of Bossaso to express grief and sorrow for the bombing incident that occurred in Mogadishu on 14 October 2017.

Hundreds of people demonstrated in various locations including Dhusamareb, Guriel, Abudwak and South Galkayo. The protesters chanted slogans against the deadly terror attacks which occurred at Mogadishu on 14 October 2017. The demonstrators urged the FGS and all nationals to conduct operations against al Shabaab fighters to eliminate the terror group in Somalia.

Hundreds of people demonstrated in various locations including Dhusamareb, Guriel, Abudwak and South Galkayo. The protesters chanted slogans against the deadly terror attacks which occurred at Mogadishu on 14 October 2017. The demonstrators urged the FGS and all nationals to conduct operations against al Shabaab fighters to eliminate the terror group in Somalia.

Hundreds of people demonstrated in various locations including Dhusamareb, Guriel, Abudwak and South Galkayo. The protesters chanted slogans against the deadly terror attacks which occurred at Mogadishu on 14 October 2017. The demonstrators urged the FGS and all nationals to conduct operations against al Shabaab fighters to eliminate the terror group in Somalia.

Residents in Garbaharrey held a peaceful demonstration against the VBIED attack that took place on 14 October 2017 in Mogadishu. Protesters showed solidarity and support to the affected families and those that were killed and injured in the explosions. The demonstration ended peacefully.

Hundreds of people demonstrated in various locations including Dhusamareb, Guriel, Abudwak and South Galkayo. The protesters chanted slogans against the deadly terror attacks which occurred at Mogadishu on 14 October 2017. The demonstrators urged the FGS and all nationals to conduct operations against al Shabaab fighters to eliminate the terror group in Somalia.

A number of demonstrations took place around the city which has led to reported gunfire in the vicinity of KM4. While details from locals remain unclear it is understood the crowd assaulted an AMISOM soldier which resulted in his death after he shot and wounded a demonstrator. The reason of the protest is not known, however, several demonstrations have been occurring following the large-scale hotel attack on 14/10.
Hundreds of locals conducted a peaceful demonstration in Qardho to condemn the VBIED incident in Mogadishu. They pledged to support the government and the Somali people in fight against al Shabaab.
In Kyengera town in Busiro East constituency, bullets and tear gas were reported during an age limit consultative meeting.

Police fired tear gas and live bullets to disperse protesters opposed to the amendment of the constitution to remove the age limit cap at Nateete, Rubaga South in Kampala. Stick-wielding goons were also seen working with police officers.

A group of teachers in Cerigabo demonstrated in front of Cerigabo Ministry of Education against the Regional Education Officer accused of favouritism and corruption. The demonstrators demanded for the removal of Regional Education Officer. It was reported that the teachers were among those who failed the MoE exams and were disqualified. Police dispersed the protestors.

Kenyan police fired rifles and tear gas in Nairobi's Freedom Park (Nairobi - Westlands) on 19 October to disperse demonstrators preparing to protest police killings of opposition supporters ahead of a fresh presidential election. Injuries reported.
Regime security forces shot and killed two anti-government protesters in Gundo Maskal town of North Shewa. It is not known if the protesters were violent.
Regime security forces shot and killed two anti-government protesters in Bedele. It is not known if the protesters were violent.

Protest in Mbale Town against the Constitutional Amendment that seeks among others to remove presidential age limits from the 1995 Constitution. Police fired teargas and live bullets to disperse the protestors. Secretary General for Forum for Democratic Change (FDC) was arrested.
Civilians stage peaceful protest against al Shabaab following 14 OCT bombing. Religious protest, led by religious leaders after prayers.
Nairobi's Eastleigh hold protest against Mogadishu bombing.

In Ilu Abba Bora, Buno Badale woreda, Ethiopian federal army troopers who were reportedly wearing Oromiya forces uniforms shot at demonstrators as they were protesting in the town. Opposition groups have accused the government of attempting to turn peaceful protests violent as an excuse to clamp down. Casualties not known.

The protest against the constitutional ammendment for the age limit of the candidates for the presidentials was called by Mbale Municipality MP Jack Wamanga and went peacefully from the start at 3pm until 4pm. Then, the opposition leader Winfred Kiiza arrived. At the interval, police ordered protesters to stop the demonstration since meetings attended by politicians and officers from other constituencies were banned. The police started firing bullets and tear-gas at protesters when the crowd did not disperse.

22 Oct: Pro-Puntland Dhulbahante supporters and politicians demonstrated at Buhodle against the peace accord arrived at by the Presidents of Khatumo and Somaliland at Ainabo on 20 October. The demonstrators marched along the streets chanting anti- Somaliland/Khatumo slangs. The rally ended peacefully.
There were demonstrations in Ukunda to protest police brutality.
Students of Adama Science and Technology University conducted an anti-government demonstration.

Opposition protesters belonging to the FDS storm the police office of Nagalama to demand the release of the party's former president - Dr. Kizza Besingye - and other party leaders who have been held there for days without a trial.
Multiplex company workers are protesting over poor conditions. They are demanding higher pay and better conditions.
Confrontation between police in Migori and NASA supporters started on Tuesday night and extended to the 25th, with businesses being closed and roads blocked. Scores injured.
A group called Kisii County IDPs held peaceful demonstrations in the streets of Kisii calling on residents not to participate in unlawful activities before the elections.

Pro-Somaliland Dhulbahante supporters and politicians gathered at Buhodle in support of the peace accord arrived at by the Presidents of Khatumo and Somaliland in Ainabo on 20 October 2017. The rally ended peacefully.
At least three people were injured by the police in Kisumu when protesting against the electoral commission.
Two days before the presidential elections, protesters demonstrate in Nairobi. Kenyan police used teargas and shot fires in the air to disperse the crowd.
A group of women protested for a peaceful election in Langata. The protest was peaceful.
NASA activists protest outside IEBC offices

Protesters angered at Besingye's re-arrest protest outside the police station in Rukungiri. Police used tear gas in order to disperse the crowd. Eyewitnesses confirm that two aides of Mr. Besingye were beaten.
Police shot one person during protests in Siaya. They used live bullets, teargas and batons.

Hundreds of fishermen conducted a peaceful demonstration in front of Narch Fish at Bossaso Seaport. The protestors marched through the streets in protest to the five-day fishing ban due to the ongoing seaport construction. The demonstration concluded peacefully without any incident.
Residents kept off polling stations, choosing instead to protest an attack on Kisima Primary School polling station by a senior administration officer last Wednesday.
Young people pretending to be voters disturb the voting polls in Narok.

In Kondele, one of Kisumu's slums, youth protest against the elections by barricating roads with huge stones, preventing police from approaching. Police later used water canons to disperse the protesters.
A student is killed during protests in Kombewa
Two people shot dead in Baba Dogo, no mention of violence by the protesters.
At least seven people have been injured after Badhan police opened fire on demonstrators protesting against the Hargeisa administration.
Angry protesters took to the streets, blocking roads to protest the decision to redo the elections on Saturday in certain counties.
Protesters took to the streets again to show their opposition to holding elections on Saturday. Outside Kisumu's morgue, 30 women stood weeping with signs saying 'Stop killing our sons'.

In East Hararge zone, Mayo Muluke woreda, security forces killed one Oromo young man. The forces fired bullets to disperse a crowd of people gathered to oppose security forces from taking Chat from Oromia region to areas controlled by the Liyu police force in Somali region.

300 residents from the Rubaare Town held a protest, accusing their legislator, Deputy Attorney General Mwesigwa Rukutana, of locking them out of the age limit consultative meeting. As 220 NRM members convened in Rubaare to discuss the amendment, they were blocked from entering the meeting and participating in the vote. With red bandanas tied around their heads, the demonstrators, who included youth and women, took to the streets.

Approximately 300 local civilians stage a protest against the tenure of Somaliland elections in Baran. Unidentified gunmen opened fire, injuring nine. Puntland forces were subsequently deployed to the area.
Kenyan police have used tear gas in an attempt to disperse crowds of opposition supporters in the Nairobi slum of Kawangware.
Civilians protest against the Aynabo Peace Agreement. Demonstration instigated by pro-Puntland politicians. Event remained peaceful.
In the slums of Kibra, in Nyamira, youth lit bonfires to protest against the election of Kenyatta.
Police dispersed Jubilee supporters in Mumias.

The altercation between the police and protesters at the Majengo bus stage began when a car belonging to a local businessman was allegedly found with marked presidential election ballot papers. One person was shot and at least 11 others were injured. Among those beaten up was a police in civilian uniform who ran to the scene.

One person has been reported as killed and five injured when Puntland security force opened fire on protestors who had assembled over reasons surrounding inflation in the city and the closure of the now P&O owned port. The protesters were reportedly peaceful.
Residents protest after the town of Bwelet Weyne changed currencies to the US dollar.

State Minister, Hajj Abdul Nadduli, faced an angry crowd in Mikono during the weekend. He was meeting NRM leaders from the districts of Buvuma, Mukono, Buikwe and Kayunga on the invitation of Sam Bbemba, a party member. The attendants to the meeting became rowdy and denounced the age limit Bill after they were denied allowances. The protesters entered the house and tried to burn files and party cards before the anti-riot police stopped them.

Police in Kabale on Sunday afternoon dispersed a group of students from Kanungu district (The Kanungu Kabale Students Association (KAKASA)) that had convened to protest the way Dr. Chris Baryomunsi, the Kinkiizi East legislator has been conducting his consultations on the proposed amendment of Presidential age limit.

Police in Mbale Town under the command of the District Police Commander fired live bullets and teargas to disperse the opposition leaders and supporters who had gathered at scene to welcome FDC presidential candidate, Patrick Amuriat Oboi. The police also arrested Mr. Amuriat Oboi on allegations of holding an illegal assembly and inciting violence. He was injured during the arrest. Pressure was also created by FDC leaders who camped outside the police station demanding his immediate release. During the arrest, some police officers were seen kicking Mr Amuriat who was already on ground helpless.

A group of students in Wadamagoo secondary schools staged a demonstration against the arrest of their school principal by police after being accused of getting USD 5,000 from Wadani opposition party as compensation for lack of three months' salary.
SLP arrested seven youngsters involved in a 'public disturbance' in Halane neighbourhood, Borama. No reported violence.
SLP arrested eight youngsters involved in public disturbance in Mohamud Haibe, Hargeysa. No reported violence.

Police fired live bullets and teargas to disperse supporters of the opposition figure who had gathered at Arrow Square in Soroti. Police also arrested former Presidential candidate Dr Kizza Besigye, who led a group of Forum for Democratic Change leaders to a campaign rally in the municipality. Besigye, who was in company of the FDC Presidential candidate Patrick Amuriat Oboi was arrested as the situation worsened and detained at Soroti Police station. The police also mentioned that they dispersed the raly because it was taking place illegally. According to the Daily Nation, supporters of Besigye engaged with police in battle for almost 6hours. Some people were injured and others hospitalised.

Police in Lira district indiscriminately fired tear gas canisters at supporters of former Forum for Democratic Change [FDC] presidential candidate Dr Kizza Besigye, leaving two people seriously injured. It started with the police ordering the protesters to leave the Lira mayor's gardens, after which the protesters disobeyance led the police to start firing tear gas canisters. Police on Thursday apologised to 'innocent' people in Lira town who were affected by the tear gas and rowdy Tuesday atmosphere. One person was shot by a stray bullet.
Residents of Narok protested against the rising insecurity.

Armed riot police officers deployed at the venue of a protest fired teargas canisters to disperse a crowd of youth who wore red ribbons as they cheered the opposition politicians who had just arrived at the venue. Police also lobbed tear gas canisters under the cars of the opposition politicians to have them come out of their vehicles and abandon the venue but in vain. Mr. Besigye, who was attending, locked himself in his car, refusing to Mr Wanyama, Aswa Regional Police Commander. The presidential contender was been held static in his car for nearly three hours since 3:00pm by armed riot police officers who also double shielded his car with a police firefighting truck and police patrol pickup. Mr. Besigye managed to escape without being arrested.
University dons tried to hold a peaceful demonstration in Nairobi, but were threatened by the police, who confiscated their megaphones and blocked the road so that the march could not pass.
Students of Metu University in Illubabor staged a protest rally. The students were chanting slogans denouncing the ethnic and divisive policies of the TPLF government.
Eritrean refugees and opposition groups staged a protest against their government, specifically against political and religious persecution. The protesters numbered 200.
Students in Bule Hora University demonstrated against national security forces on campus.

Embakasi East MP Babu Owino, his Rauaraka counterpart TJ Kajwang and Starehe politician Steve Mbogo were arrested Thursday as Opposition leaders engaged police in a cat-and-mouse game. The leaders were apprehended on Ngong' Road (Nairobi - Westlands) as they attempted to enter Kibra's Kamkunji ground where NASA had scheduled a rally that had been banned by the police.
Locals of Shakiso protest a contract extension of a 'billionaire' mining gold in the area.

On Saturday 18th, the Rubabo County MP Mary Paula Turyahikayo was forced to stop an age consultation meeting after a group of rowdy youth disrupted it. The incident happened at Kayanga Primary School in Kisiizi and the group prevented the MP from continuing her address, forcing her to leave in order to avoid chaos.
Residents of Adola protest a local mining business deal which they believe will be economically ineffective. The date of the Adola protest is not known - source dated 20/11.
NTV and other leading TV stations also broadcast footage of large crowds in President Uhuru Kenyatta's strongholds in Rift Valley regions celebrating the Supreme Court ruling.
Residents of Dima protest a local mining business deal which they believe will be economically ineffective.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.

Hundreds of local residents conducted a peaceful demonstration in the area between Gaaca and Bossaso main market in protest to a construction company. The demonstration ended peacefully at 1140 hrs.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.

Police lobbed teargas to disperse protesters at Uhuru Park (Nairobi - Westlands) on Wednesday. Reto Women Association was holding a peaceful demonstration to decry alleged police killing of over 300 livestock belonging to pastoralist communities who had invaded private ranches in Laikipia County.
Women in Garissa held a peaceful march to demonstrate their commitment to preventing gender based violence.
In West Hararge zone, Mieso woreda, students demonstrated against the Liyu police after a student was wounded.

A group of women demonstrated in front of Borama local government office to protest the increase in price of water imposed by the local government. The demonstrators demanded that the local government review the new prices of the communal water.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.

Teargas fired at opposition leader Raila Odinga and his supporters as they attempted to rally in Nairobi. At least two people were shot dead in clashes with police. Odinga's supporters engaged in running battles with police as they attempted to gather for a 'memorial rally' to honour nearly 60 people killed, mostly by police, in over four months of political upheaval. Two people were shot dead in Soweto (in Nairobi) as police manned Jacaranda grounds to prevent NASA's memorial service.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.

Security forces use live bullets to disperse anti-TPLF government forces in several Misraq Harerge towns. Any sustained causalities were not reported. Date(s) of violence not entirely known (other sources cite protests between 28/11 and 30/11 in several areas of Misraq (and Mirab) - source dated 29/11.

Security forces use live bullets to disperse anti-TPLF government forces in several Misraq Harerge towns. Any sustained causalities were not reported. Date(s) of violence not entirely known (other sources cite protests between 28/11 and 30/11 in several areas of Misraq (and Mirab) - source dated 29/11.

Security forces use live bullets to disperse anti-TPLF government forces in several Misraq Harerge towns. Any sustained causalities were not reported. Date(s) of violence not entirely known (other sources cite protests between 28/11 and 30/11 in several areas of Misraq (and Mirab) - source dated 29/11.
State forces kill six anti-TPLF protesters in Gursum. No violence reported from protesters.

Security forces use live bullets to disperse anti-TPLF government forces in several Misraq Harerge towns. Any sustained causalities were not reported. Date(s) of violence not entirely known (other sources cite protests between 28/11 and 30/11 in several areas of Misraq (and Mirab) - source dated 29/11.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.
Protest in Kumbi against the TPLF government. Protests against the government have been occurring in several unnamed areas of East and West Hararghe since 28/11.
Protest in Boreda against the TPLF government. Protests against the government have been occurring in several unnamed areas of East and West Hararghe since 28/11.
Anti-TPLF government protest in several locations in East and West Hararghe. The protests lasted three days between 28/11 and 30/11.
Ethiopian security forces used tear gas to disperse students peacefully demonstrating at Bule Hora University. Many were later arrested. No reported injury.
Civilians stage a protest against the sale of the Ceel Afweyn Intermediate School grounds to Telsom. Police dispersed the crowds. 10 arrested.

On 7 December 2017, around 40 people took part in a peaceful protest organised by the Pan-African Pyramid, a non-partisan organization who ideal is to revive 'intellectual' discourse on Pan-Africanism. The protesters demonstrated in front of the Lybian embassy against the reports of slave trade in the country, demanding to know whether the reports were true or false, and asking for the government to formally recognise the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) and allow it fully carry out its mandate.
Students are protesting against what they term as poor management at the institution. Daystar University was on Friday closed due to student unrest that has rocked the institution since November.
Protests in Mogadishu following the US announcement to recognise Jerusalem as Israeli capital.

Hundreds of non-locals in Lamu town took to the streets to protest against increased attacks and killings. The protests were precipitated by the killing of a 35-year-old man who was attacked with machetes and knives at Bombay area on Lamu Island on Saturday night.

Following the attacks of students at Nekemt and Debre Tabor Universities, protests against the act occur in Wurgessa, Wuchale, Ambo and in Guji towns. Additionally, 13 universities were 'disrupted' - names not provided.

Following the attacks of students at Nekemt and Debre Tabor Universities, protests against the act occur in Wurgessa, Wuchale, Ambo and in Guji towns. Additionally, 13 universities were 'disrupted' - names not provided.

Ethiopian security forces killed at least 9 protesting civilians and wounded more in Chelenko town, Meta woreda, east Hararge zone. A secondary source, published later in the week accounts for 18 dead. The attack spurred a number of area protests.

Anti-government protests continue for three days at the University of Bahir Dar. Students from Bahir Dar University, like the other universities, started protesting after the killing of a student in Adigrat University.

During a march from Ugandan Democratic Party members in Kampala, on the way to the Parliament, on December 12th, police arrested the party president general - Norbert Mao - and 11 other party members. The group was marching to Parliament to protest against the proposed scrapping of the presidential age limit. The 12 are being held on tentative charges of holding an unlawful procession.

Anti-government protests continue for three days at the University of Bahir Dar. Students from Bahir Dar University, like the other universities, started protesting immediately after the killing of a student in Adigrat University.

People in different parts of Oromia region (exact locations not named) demonstrated following a number of security forces actions against area civilians in Chelenko. The protesters requested that Ethiopian security forces leave the Oromia region.

Anti-government protests at the University of Debre Tabor.
Anti-government protests at the University of Weldiya.
Anti-government protests at the University of Gonder.
Anti government protests in Metu, Nekempte, Dembi Dolo, Wadera, Shakiso following killing of civilians in Chelenqo.

Regime security forces killed 7 civilians on Monday as they protested the killing of protesters in Chelenko on 11/12. The number of fatalities was spread among two cities, Yabello and Moyale.
Regime security forces killed 7 civilians on Monday as they protested the killing of protesters in Chelenko on 11/12. The number of fatalities was spread among two cities, Yabello and Moyale.
Anti government protests in Metu, Nekempte, Dembi Dolo, Wadera, Shakiso following killing of civilians in Chelenqo.
As of 25/12 anti-government protests at Dire Dawa University (among other not named universities) 'continue.' The date(s) of the initial protest at Dure Dawa (not others) not known.

On 29/12 reports that anti-TPLF protests have 'continued' in Arba Minch, Adigrat, Wolkite and Asosa Universities. It is not known when each protest began.

On 29/12 reports that anti-TPLF protests have 'continued' in Arba Minch, Adigrat, Wolkite and Asosa Universities. It is not known when each protest began.

A group of staff working for Cerigabo Hospital staged a demonstration in front of Cerigabo General Hospital. The protesters reportedly accused a local NGO that manages Cerigabo Hospital and Somaliland Development Fund of excluding them from the list of the local NGO staff. They also accused Cerigabo authorities of nepotism and favouritism.

Commercial sex workers in Kisii Town on Friday protested against the killing of their colleague on Wednesday. They matched though Kisii Town streets, calling for justice, wearing red T-Shirts inscribed 'Stop Violence against Commercial Sex Workers'.
On 29/12 reports that anti-TPLF protests have 'continued' in Arba Minch, Adigrat, Wolkite and Asosa Universities. It is not known when each protest began.
On 29/12 reports that anti-TPLF protests have 'continued' in Arba Minch, Adigrat, Wolkite and Asosa Universities. It is not known when each protest began.
Anti government protests in Kellem, Wollega on or before 29/12.
Security forces killed two people in Horogudru-Shambu, West Wollega during an anti-government protest.
On 29/12 reports that anti-TPLF protests have 'continued' in Arba Minch, Adigrat, Wolkite and Asosa Universities. It is not known when each protest began.
On 29/12 reports that anti-TPLF protests have 'continued' in Arba Minch, Adigrat, Wolkite and Asosa Universities. It is not known when each protest began.
Anti-government protests 'continue' in Shambu 01/01. It is not known when the protest began, or if it had continued for consecutive days.
Security forces enter Gelila in an effort quell an anti-government protest in Gelila. It is not known if the forces stopped the protest.

On 2 January 2018, Puntland Darawish Forces took control of the custom office/check point located at North Galkayo entrance near a UN Compound (c. 400m south west of the UN Compound). Initial reports indicated that the security forces demonstrated over unpaid salaries. The forces blocked the main tarmac road linking the custom check point and Galkayo town. The issue was resolved after the involvement of government officials.

NRM Protesters took to the street in front of the Civil Division of the High Court in Kampala protesting litigations against Parliament Speaker Rebecca Kadaga. The group claims that Kadaga is being targeted over presiding the proceedings that led to the passing of the age limit law. The protesters argued that Kadaga had nothing to answer to in regards to the bill having passed, which they claim happened in the right manner.

In Adama, Goro High School students took to the streets protesting the arrest and detention of 18 students of Adama University (Nazreth). Eighteen students of the Adma University were arrested on 02/01 and taken to undisclosed location. Students believe they were targeted because they are ethnic Oromos and ethnic Amhara. It is not known if the students were protesting at the time of their arrest.

More than 800 employees on Friday protested at the Satellite section in Mai Mahiu. Ongoing construction of the Nairobi-Naivasha phase of the Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) has been suspended in the last three days as workers protest low pay and harsh working conditions.

Hundreds of residents of October neighbourhood staged a demonstration near October neighbourhood in Burao against road constructions that was temporarily halted by the new administration. Protesters marched to the streets peacefully. SLP in Burao arrived at the scene and dispersed the protestors.

A group of people, mostly youth, staged a peaceful demonstration at Cerigabo liberty garden against the arrest of Aidarus Salah, the regional sports coordinator of Somlaliland, on accusation of collaborating with FGS of the SLP in Hargeisa. The demonstrators demanded for his release.

On 7 January 2018, a group of people, mostly youth, staged a peaceful demonstration at Laascaanood in support of the visit of the President of Federal Government of Somalia in Garowe. The demonstration ended peacefully. There were reports of arrests.

One person has been shot dead in Bonyunyu, Nyamira County as villagers protested the planned construction of a controversial dam. Police also arrested three people among them two women even as villagers said they are not ready for the project.

On 9 January 2018, a group of Congolese refugees held a protest in Nyarugusu camp after a group of bandits robbed a Congolese refugee household. The police fired tear gas and live ammunition to disperse protesters.

On 11 January 2018, Kapenguria boys high school students demonstrated by marching to the office of the county director of education in Kapenguria (West Pokot, West Pokot), against the transfer of their head teacher. The school closed indefinitely.

On 11 January 2018, about 80 Kisukioni secondary school students demonstrated by marching to the office of the governor in Machakos (Machakos, Machakos), against the underperformance and mismanagement of the institution by the principal. The Police talked to the students and transported them back to school.

On 11 January 2018, a group, including students, demonstrated at the St. Joseph's girls school, Kibwezi (Kibwezi West, Makueni), against the transfer of the school principal. 6 people tried to stop current Principal from entering the school by surrounding her; Police intervened and arrested them.

On 12 January 2018, hundreds of civilians from Bantu origin gathered in front of Kismayo General Hospital for a peaceful demonstration against the killing a civilian of Bantu origin in Kismayo town. The protestors established roadblocks at the main Kismayo city centre tarmac road demanding justice from the government. Security forces arrived and dispersed the crowd. There were no reports of security incidents.
Youngsters gathered to protest against the arrests of three people for Saturday's events.

Several people, mostly elders and fishermen in Maydh (c. 50 km north of Cerigabo), staged a peaceful demonstration against the decision of the Minister of Livestock and Fisheries of Somaliland to revoke all fishing licenses. The elders stated that people living in the area depended on fishing for food to sustain their families.

A group of Tanzanian Muslims held since 2013 in prison on charges of terrorism stripped naked to demand the start of their trial. Out of the 60 persons, 19 took part in the protest. They were detained nearly five years ago following a series of deadly attacks in Arusha, a mainly Christian city in the north, but they have yet to go on trial. Security forces immediately took them to an isolation cell.

On 16 January 2018, local residents, mainly youths protested by waving placards and shouting at the Liwatoni dumpsite in Ganjoni (Nyali, Mombasa), against a county directive confining the dumping of garbage to only 3 dump sites. The group demanded the county government address the garbage problem.

On 17 January 2018, youths blocked both sides (unspecified means) of Mombasa Road at Mlolongo area on Wednesday morning to protest the delayed response of Machakos County fire fighters to put out a huge fire.

In west Hararge, Chiro city, there was a large protest that lasted for hours against the appointing of a man named Mamaya Yusef into the city administration. The protests were kicked off after rumours spread that he had killed two people during the crackdown in 2015. Police responded 'brutally' injuring almost 15 people, including 3 who were hospitalized in serious condition.
Protests against the TPLF government in Gondar, Woldia, Nekempte and Ambo. The protests were borne of Ethiopian Orthodox Epiphany celebrations.
Protests against the TPLF government in Gondar, Woldia, Nekempte and Ambo. The protests were borne of Ethiopian Orthodox Epiphany celebrations.
Protests against the TPLF government in Gondar, Woldia, Nekemt (Oromia) and Ambo. The protests were borne of Ethiopian Orthodox Epiphany celebrations.
Protests against the TPLF government in Gondar, Woldia, Nekempte and Ambo. The protests were borne of Ethiopian Orthodox Epiphany celebrations.

Demonstrations were reported in Cadaado against the agreement signed between Galmudug and ASWJ. The signing of the agreement sparked dissatisfaction from inter-clan interests between Cadado and Dhusamareb. Elders intervened and managed to resolve the issues.

On 19 January 2018, local residents, mainly family and friends, demonstrated by marching from the Aga Khan Hospital mortuary to Nyali Centre (Nyali, Mombasa), against the killing of a banker by night guards at the centre [coded separately]. The group demanded justice for the deceased.
20th January, PM, Cabdulasiis, Mogadishu: The Somali National Army (SNA) dispersed protesters that had assembled in support of Mogadishu Mayor, Thabit Abdi Mohamed.

Residents of Tog-wajale demonstrated against a town development plan by the local government perceived to negatively impact many businesses in Tog- wajale main market. The demonstration ended peacefully and there were no reports of arrests.
21/01, PM, Kismayo: SNA move out of Kismayo in protest of the IJA lack of action against al Shabaab.
Anti-TPLF protests in Kobo.
Two protesters are shot and killed by military forces on 22/01, bringing claimed total to 13 over the multiple day ordeal.

Hundreds of mostly female activists marched in Kenya's capital Nairobi on Monday to protest repeated failures to apply laws that women must hold at least a third of government seats. According to Kenya's 2010 constitution, women must have at least a third of seats in parliament and a third of appointed positions.

Hundreds of civilian villagers gathered in front of AMISOM KDF/Jubaland force base in Hosungo village to protest the arrest of a civilian male who was alleged to have connection with al Shabaab (c. 80 km south east of Dhobley town.) The demonstration occurred after the suspect was taken to AMISOM Dhobley base for further inquiry. There were no reports of security incidents during the period of the demonstration.
Anti-TPLF protests in Kobo. Reports of police making 'arbitrary arrests.'
TPLF security forces shot and killed three people in Alem Tena, East Shewa while holding a sit in protest at a flagpole to mourn the death of protesters in Woldia and Moyale in the weekend.

A massive anti-government protest took place in Welkite city, the administrative city of the Gurage Zone in southern regional state. Thousands came out to the streets protesting against the city administration's failure to deliver a promised hospital.

On 24 January 2018, regional commissioner Alexander Mnyeti was met by protesters in Simanjiro. The crowd waved placards and protested against the increasing land conflicts, including sale of land in their village.
On 24 January 2018, people in the town of Shewa Robit blocked roads (unspecified means) preventing the progress of TPLF Agazi soldiers.

Many demonstrators gathered at Kaaran market neighbourhood in Kaaran district against insecurity in the district. The demonstration spread across major roads in Kaaran market and surrounding areas hindering vehicle and pedestrian movement. The mayor requested that the protestors express their views against insecurity which existed in their village. The demonstration ended peacefully.
Residents of the Gurage Zone capital, Welkite [southern Ethiopia] went to the streets to protest against the killing of people by government security forces in Oromia and Amhara regional states.
On 24 January 2018, residents protested against the local administration in Kismayo town (Kismaayo, Lower Juba) after the police destroyed several illegally constructed houses in the town.
Approximately 100 civilians take the streets to protest against illegal extortion of money at SNAF checkpoints.

On 24 January 2018, residents of Mwingi Town Tuesday blocked (unspecified means) the Mwingi-Garissa highway and offloaded all the charcoal from a lorry ferrying the commodity to Nairobi in a bid to fight the illegal trade which is seen as a major threat to the ecosystem in the region.

On 25 January 2018, local residents, mainly women, demonstrated by singing, chanting and carrying twigs, as they marched at the Mutunguru shopping centre (Gatundu South, Kiambu), against the alleged child theft at Karatu subcounty health centre.

In East Shewa zone, Fantale woreda, Sara weba kebele, Matahara sugar cane factory reportedly dug up a cemetery, exposing diseased bones on the sidewalk and surface area. People gathered in the area in protest and security forces responded with gunfire. A young girl of 12 years old was killed and two more people were injured.
Students of Salale University protest 'for days' (coded as 2 days) for unknown reason. Government forces 'shot and killed' [the protesters]. Fatality numbers not provided.
Residents of Marta Ward in Taveta sub-county protest against the fencing off of a water source which was stationed on private property.
On 26 January 2018, Residents demonstration the TPLF government by blocking roads with logs and other materials in Kobo and Mersa on 26/01.
On 26 January 2018, Residents demonstration the TPLF government by blocking roads with logs and other materials in Kobo and Mersa on 26/01.
Students of Salale University protest 'for days' (coded as 2 days) for unknown reason. Government forces 'shot and killed' [the protesters]. Fatality numbers not provided.

Hundreds of butchers in Burao, mostly women, staged a peaceful demonstration in Burao against the privatization of the newly constructed slaughterhouse managed by Dayib company which resulted in an increase in the price of slaughtering animals. The protestors marched onto the streets and gathered in front of the local government office grieving their concerns.

Residents in Borama, mainly women and children, peacefully staged a demonstration in front of the local council office against no response to water scarcity in Borama town. The demonstrators demanded that the local council seeks potential water sources to supply water in Borama town.

Drivers of water tankers in Odweyne staged a demonstration against a road construction company that was contracted to rehabilitate Odweyne and Burao roads. The company was accused of excavating holes on the road barring vehicles movement without providing an alternative route. The protestors called to the government to unblock the road or explore alternative roads for use.

Lamu County health workers took to the streets of Lamu Island to demonstrate against recent allegations that they were complicit in Al Shabaab activities. The doctors, clinical officers, nurses and lab technicians from various hospitals, dispensaries and health centres across Lamu also marched to Lamu County Commissioner Gilbert Kitiyo's office.
Anti-government protests continue in Mersa. No reported violence or police interaction.

National Super Alliance (NASA) supporters took to the streets in western Kenya to celebrate Raila Odinga's swearing in as the 'people's president'. The peaceful celebrations were devoid of police presence and running battles, as has been the case whenever Opposition backers are on the streets to demonstrate.
