National Super Alliance (NASA) supporters on Tuesday took to the streets in western Kenya to celebrate Raila Odinga's swearing in as the 'people's president'. The peaceful celebrations were devoid of police presence and running battles, as has been the case whenever Opposition backers are on the streets to demonstrate.

An anti-government protest at Gondar University [north-western Ethiopia] has disrupted examinations. Three students who were badly beaten by police during the protest are admitted at Gondar Hospital and are said to be in a critical situation.
Thousands of National Super Alliance (NASA) supporters attended on Tuesday Raila Odinga's swearing in as the 'people's president'.
Police at Integrity Centre, Nairobi have used teargas to disperse a section of National Super Alliance (NASA) legislators who had gone to inquire about the arrest of Ruaraka MP TJ Kajwang

In Adama (aka Nazreth) city, Oromia region, the government demolished many people's houses claiming that had been built illegally. The security forces arrested many people for protesting against the demolition.

Residents report that violent attacks against anti-government protesters continued on 01/02 in Mersa, Weldiya and Kobo. The extent of injury not known. 700 youths arrested in Mersa. Any protest violence was not reported.

Residents report that violent attacks against anti-government protesters continued on 01/02 in Mersa, Weldiya and Kobo. The extent of injury not known. 700 youths arrested in Mersa. Any protest violence was not reported.

Residents report that violent attacks against anti-government protesters continued on 01/02 in Mersa, Weldiya and Kobo. The extent of injury not known. 700 youths arrested in Mersa. Any protest violence was not reported.

Burao local government, supported by police, demolished illegal temporary shops and other structures built on roads in 'October' neighbourhood. Residents resisted the operation and police were forced to fire warning shot. Two protestors were injured and an unspecified number of people were arrested.

People, mostly women hailing from Habar- Jeclo/Baho and Habar-Yonis/Sacad Yonis sub-clans, staged a peaceful demonstration in Dararweyne Village (c. 97 km south of Cerigabo) to protest of the recurrent and unsolved hostilities between the two clans. They appealed to the Somaliland government, with the support of traditional elders, to put an end to the recurrent clan hostilities in Elafweyn.
A group of youth in Mombasa, wanting Nasa leader Raila Odinga to appoint Governor Hassan Joho as his deputy, protest for his appointment.
On 4 February 2018, a militia group loyal to Ahmed Abdi Hassan (Tajir), a member of the Jubbaland regional parliament, has blocked roads in the city in protest against the MP's arrest.

Kibera residents in Nairobi demanded the release of Miguna Miguna on Sunday. In solidarity, the residents thronged the streets asking the Government to immediately free the National Resistance Movement (NRM), self-proclaimed general, Miguna.
Protests in Kibera for the release of Miguna Miguna.
Approximately 100 protest against the off-airing of 4 opposition leaning broadcast networks. Police used tear-gas to disperse the protesters.
Civilians protest against arrival of an oil exploration company at Gelo-Kor, without the knowledge of local authorities. Elders intervened, company left.
Residents and family of the step mother to the leader of the outlawed National Resistance Movement Miguna Miguna, protest against her possible political deportation.
Opposition NASA legislators were turned away by police when they sought to have their statements recorded over the protest swearing-in of their leader Raila Odinga as president.

Federal security forces killed a young man in Diredawa on the night of 07/02 for unknown reason. His funeral the following day turned into protest. The federal security forces are firing at the protesters. No confirmed number of death and injury reported.
Residents of Witu protest on 09/02 and 11/02 against the government appointment of an area chief.

A group of students demonstrated against increased tuition fees proposed by the Ministry of Education. The students marched onto the streets from their schools to the location of the Ministry of Education. Police dispersed the crowds.
Residents of Witu protest on 09/02 and 11/02 against the government appointment of an area chief.

Military-Agazi forces killed 10 Internally Displaced People [IDPs] at the Hamaresa [eastern Ethiopia] camp on 11/02 following a protest of a number of IDPs. The camp shelters people [ethnic Oromo] displaced from Somali Regional State. State television claimed 'clashes.'
Civilians protest against taxes levied by the Somaliland government at the clothes market. Somaliland Police disperse protesters. Event remained peaceful.
Several anti-government protests took place in Addis Ababa on 12/02. The protests took place in the subdivisions of Lege Tafo, Furi, Kara Kore, Burayu, Asko, Sebeta.
Several anti-government protests took place in Addis Ababa on 12/02. The protests took place in the subdivisions of Lege Tafo, Furi, Kara Kore, Burayu, Asko, Sebeta.
Anti-government protests in Asebot, Chiro, Gudar and Ambo. No reported violence.
Anti-government protests in Asebot, Chiro, Gudar and Ambo. No reported violence.
Anti-government protests in Asebot, Chiro, Gudar and Ambo (Asebe Teferi). No reported violence.
Anti-government protests in Asebot, Chiro, Gudar and Ambo. No reported violence.
Following a total trade and market boycott the previous day, protests took place in East Hararge Zone, Kombolcha woreda, Melka Raafu city.

Anti-government protests reported in Debark, Dabat and in other towns of Amhara Regional State (although they were not reported after internet and phone services were shut down). The protests were billed as a three-day event, though it is not clear if one or all of the protests continued for multiple days.

Anti-government protests reported in Debark, Dabat and in other towns (Bahir Dar) of Amhara Regional State (although they were not reported after internet and phone services were shut down). The protests were billed as a three-day event, though it is not clear if one or all of the protests continued for multiple days.

Anti-government protests reported in Debark, Dabat and in other towns of Amhara Regional State (although they were not reported after internet and phone services were shut down). The protests were billed as a three-day event, though it is not clear if one or all of the protests continued for multiple days.

On 12 February 2018, the UDPF laid siege to the Guardian Primary school in Jinja (Jinja, Eastern) under the claim that the institution was illegally using their land. Upon being surrounded, the principal called for students and parents to forcefully enter the school. The ensuing situation led to some of the people being injured by the police.
Anti-government protests reported in Durame, Shinshico and Hadro in Kembata.
Anti-government protests reported in Durame, Shinshico and Hadro in Kembata.
Anti-government protests reported in Durame, Shinshico and Hadro in Kembata.
Large anti-government protest in Bishoftu.
Youths held protests in Kisii Town against remarks by Embakasi East MP Babu Owino against Interior CS Fred Matiangi. The protesters threatened to disrupt a NASA rally.

In East Shewa zone, Bose woreda, Wolanchiti town, Ethiopian security forces killed one person and wounded 3 more. The victims were taking part in a protest/business boycott against the TPLF government.
A protest sparked 'last week' (source dated 21/02) when residents of Welkite learnt that the project to build a world class hospital in the town has been moved to the Tigray region.
In East Hararge zone, around Haramaya University, 4 people were killed in security forces shooting for supporting the students in boycott.

On 16 February 2018, an opposition rally (supporters of Chadema) took place in Dar es Salaam (Ilala, Dar es Salaam). Police tried to disperse it, but this resulted in a young 22-year old woman being killed by a stray bullet. Another 4 people were seriously hurt during the police intervention.

On 16 February 2018, a section of ODM youth under the NASA coalition demonstrated by waving placards outside the US Embassy in Gigiri (Westlands, Nairobi), against alleged political interference. The group demanded the international community to desist the alleged political interference.

On 17 February 2018, a section of Muslim faithful protested by carrying placards and chanted as they marched from Malindi municipal stadium to the deputy county commissioner's office in Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi), against the alleged grabbing of cemetery land by two tycoons. Joined by Haki Africa civil rights activists, the group demanded action against the two tycoons.
Bakaara Market remains closed as business owners protest against FGS decision to increase taxes.

On 18 February 2018, truck drivers in Berbera, managed by Towfiq association, staged a peaceful demonstration in Berbera against the Minister of Transport and Road Development who was accused of replacing their chairman without their knowledge. There were reports of arrests and casualties.

On 18 February 2018, unspecified groups of Borama business community staged a peaceful gathering against lack of hygiene and garbage on roads in Borama road and other public places. They accused the local government of not addressing the problems correctly. There were reports of arrests.
Protest against the state of emergency in Addis Ababa.
In Qellam wollega zone, Jima Horro woreda, Nunu town, people protested the state of emergency.

In north west Shewa, zone, Tole woreda, Bantu town, a student was shot by security forces and taken to hospital. He was shot during a protest that students were doing to oppose the state of emergency.

About a hundred residents demonstrated in Cerigabo to protest lack of public services include firefighting services in the area. The demonstration was triggered by the destruction of a local building by fire due to the absence of firefighters. The protestors marched on the streets chanting anti-Somaliland slogans. Police dispersed the demonstration.

Operations at the governor's office in Nyahururu Town were paralysed following protests against the County Public Service Board. Residents want the board removed over claims of incompetence, nepotism and corruption.

Dozens of IDP staged a demonstration at Ceel Jale IDP camp near the AMISOM protected area in Beletweyne. The IDPs complained of mismanagement of humanitarian aid by the local administration of Beletweyne. The protesters accused INGOs that operate in Beletweyne of mismanagement and reluctance to assist. The IDPs, through the local media, stated that their needs were food, and shelter and that there was a disease at the camps due to inadequate water. They requested the President of Hirshabelle to intervene.
Protests against restrictions on meetings with political dissidents begins on 24/02 and continues for at least four days (Nekemt, Oromia).

On 24 February 2018, presumed MCC supporters allied to a member of parliament demonstrated by waving placards, carrying twigs and singing songs of justice, as they marched to the constituency offices in Mpeketoni (Lamu West, Lamu), against the court's decision to nullify his election. The group demanded justice for their MP.
Residents protest the killing of an auto-rickshaw driver by state forces.
Day two: Protests against restrictions on meetings with political decedents begins on 24/02 and continues for at least four days (Nekemt, Oromia).
Protests have taken place in the western town of Eldoret after a court nullified the election of Nandi Hills Member of Parliament Alfred Keter. The election was sued over 'irregularities.'

On 1 March 2018, hundreds of tea farmers marched to the county assembly in Kericho town (Ainamoi, Kericho) against low pay from the Kenya tea development authority (KTDA). The farmers demanded an audience with the members of the county assembly.
Unrest in 'western Oromo' continues. (Likely in or around Dembi Dolo) One student reported killed and a second wounded. A number of local administrative officials were arrested.
On 1 March 2018, environmental protesters gather in Uhuru Park on Thursday to protest the passage of the Standard Gauge Railway through the Nairobi National Park (Nairobi - Westlands).

On 2 March 2018, hundreds of tea farmers protested by forcing themselves into Rorok tea factory while chanting and carrying twigs in Kaptebengwet (Konoin, Bomet) against the poor management of their parent factory Kapset. The farmers demanded that the Rorok tea factory be declared autonomous.
03 March. Anti-government protests in Ginchi on 03/03 and 04/03.
03 March. Anti-government protests in Guder on 03/03 and 04/03.
03 March. Anti-government protests in Ambo on 03/03 and 04/03. 3 people were reported killed.
03 March. Security forces kill six protesters in Kelem Wellega over 03/03 and 04/03 (Tarsimo). No reported violence from protesters.
04 March. Anti-government protests in Ambo on 03/03 and 04/03.
04 March. Anti-government protests in Ginchi on 03/03 and 04/03.
04 March. Anti-government protests in Guder on 03/03 and 04/03.
04 March. Security forces kill six protesters in Kelem Wellega (Tarsimo) over 03/03 and 04/03. No reported violence from protesters.
On 4 March 2018, c. 1000 hrs. A group of police took control of Qardho region bank over unpaid salaries. The situation ended peacefully.
05 March. Pupils protest an attempt by 'land grabbers' to confiscate school land.

On the week of 5 March, youth protested at the Kingdom headquarters in Bugembe, promising not to allow Minister Namuganza to go to Bugosa unless she apologised for her comments on Kyabazinga Wilberforce Gabula Nadiope IV and Speaker Rebecca Kadaga.
300 students of the Kabale Institute of Health Science marched in Kabale on March 5 protesting maladministration, mistreatment and poor services at the institute.
05 March. Security forces shot and killed three people (protesters). Two were killed in Jima, according to Oromo activists, while the third was killed in West Hararghe, in a locality called Chiro.

05 March. Security forces shot and killed three people (protesters). Two were killed in Jimma, according to Oromo activists, while the third was killed in West Hararghe, in Chiro. The victim in Chiro was not protesting at the time of attack.
05 March. Several student protesters and journalists are arrested during a demonstration against Kenyatta National Hospital management (Nairobi - Westlands).

Police had to intervene in a protest organised by Kyambogo University students on March 6th, when they protested the postponement of the voting for the student guilds. Police also arrested 2 guild members and an unspecified number of other students.

On 6 March 2018, health workers, mainly nurses, demonstrated by singing and marching within Kenyatta national hospital in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands), against the suspension of their colleagues following a surgery mix-up. The nurses demanded audience with the board of management.
08 March. Health workers in Lamu strike and protest alleged mistreatment from management on 08 March.

On 9 March 2018, Turkana university students demonstrated by blocking the Kitale-Lodwar highway, as they waved placards and carried twigs outside the institution in Lodwar (Turkana Central, Turkana), against the institution's mismanagement. The students demanded the principal to exit.
12 March. Protests in Dararweyn and Elafweyn to encourage locals to the support the reconciliation efforts made by the Somaliland government.
12 March. Protests in Dararweyn and Elafweyn to encourage locals to the support the reconciliation efforts made by the Somaliland government.

On 13 March 2018, Qeerro (Oromo youths) blocked (unspecified means) fuel tankers operating in southern Oromo State in demonstration against recent state violence. The blockade has created a severe fuel shortage in Addis Ababa. The blockade began on 13/03 and lasted at least until 14/03.
13 March. Residents of Scheme estate protest over insecurity after a child had gone missing several days earlier.
On 14 March 2018, a Oromo fuel blockade, largely affecting Addis Ababa, enters its second day. The demonstrators is believed to last a week, though there were no reports of specific instances.
14 March. University of Nairobi lecturers protest over salaries.

15 March. Hundreds of people staged demonstrations in Hargeisa, Burao, Berbera as well as 'other places in Somaliland.' The cause was to protest against the decisions made by the Somalia government to reject a company from operating in Berbera.

15 March. Hundreds of people staged demonstrations in Hargeisa, Burao, Berbera as well as 'other places in Somaliland.' The cause was to protest against the decisions made by the Somalia government to reject a company from operating in Berbera.
On 15 March 2018, residents protested against the Somalia federal government decision to ban DP world from operating in the country in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed).
16 March. Workers at a hospital demonstrated over funds.
On 17 March 2018, a group of over 70 people wielding pangas attached the Ishaka-Basajjabalaba Mosque protested in Bushenyi. The police arrested 3 protesters.

On 18 March 2018, a group of Muslim men wielding pangas attached the Ishaka-Basajjabalaba Mosque protested in Bushenyi. They were repelled by the police, with support from the army. This group is unhappy with the leadership of the district Kadhi.
19 March. Teachers from Wajir region staged protests at the Teachers Service Commission headquarters in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) over the state of insecurity in the region.
20 March. Sex workers demonstrate to promote awareness on the use of Pre-Exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) to curb HIV infections.
21 March. Students started demonstrating against the arrest of Oromo students at universities (Addis Ababa). Security forces responded by firing shots. No reports of injuries.
On 21 March 2018, students carried out a protest against the current motion against the Speaker of the House in Buur Hakaba town (Buur Xakaba, Bay).

25 March. A group of people gathered at Dajirka-Dahsoon monument, Bondhere District to protest against Kenyan Government on decision to build a wall between the border of Kenya and Somalia. Police forces dispersed the crowd and reportedly arrested several people.
On 26 March 2018, youth in Harar Woreda protested against the local militia.
On 26 March 2018, there was a peaceful demonstration at the Nakawa Chief Magistrates Court to protest the release of a professor accused of pouring acid on his lover.
On 26 March 2018, students at Kabale University marched to the office of the Resident District Commissioner to protest the expensive fees.
On 27 March 2018, subjects of the Busoga Kingdom staged a peaceful demonstration in Kamuli against the State Minister for Lands, whom they accuse of disrespecting the Busoga king.
28 March. Youths protest over the attempted deportation of an ODM/NRM leader in Kisumu.

On 29 March 2018, residents of Mulot area, mostly women, demonstrated along the Mulot-Narok highway near Narok (Narok Town, Narok North, Narok) calling on the government to intervene over the rampant donkey theft in the area. They camped beside the road for over three hours.
31 March. About 200 people protested at Heraale village against recent integration of Galmudug parliament in Dhusamareb. The demonstrators chanted slogans against the former ASWJ leader.
01 April. Personnel of the National Printing Agency in Hargeysa held a demonstration at the front office demanding for their salaries.
02 April. IDPs staged a demonstration at the Office of the Regional Governor in Burco to protest of lack of food and drinking water.
02 April. Protests in Borama over water scarcity.
04 April. Police teargassed public universities staff who were protesting at the Ministry of Education offices in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe). The staff was protesting over pay. No reported injury.

On 8 April 2018, local residents protested by waving twigs in Ngalla Estate of Malindi town (Malindi, Kilifi), against demolition of houses by National Housing Corporation (NHC). The group demanded the government and area member of parliament to help address the matter.
On 9 April protests were reported in Kobo after the killing of a pregnant woman by security forces the previous evening. The protesters gathered peacefully.
09 April. A group of traders in Wajale border town demonstrated due to new taxes levied by the Somaliland government.

Around 9 April 2018, 8 Oromo students were arrested from Haramaya university which led to a massive protest by the rest of the students. Reports of continued arrests in Habro and Miesso woredas, east and west Hararge zones respectively security forces.
11 April. Local contractors in Kathwana, Tharaka-Nithi County protest to demand unpaid salaries.
11 April. Nyeri KMTC students held demonstrations in protest of a planned transfer of the principal.
On 11 April 2018, In west Hararge zone, Doba woreda, Doba city, many people were injured when military forces opened fire on them as they were protesting for the release of people from prison.
On 11 April 2018, youth marched to the High Court in Mbale to protest the age limit bill. They were intercepted and prevented from marching by the police.
11 April. Students of Daystar University protest to demand the removal of the Vice Chancellor over mismanagement. Police used tear gas against the protesters; no reported injuries.
In east Hararge zone, Meyumuluke woreda, students protested following three of their teachers being detained. The school was closed but no one was injured.
11 April. Teachers staged a protest at the Knut headquarters in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) in a bid to eject Secretary General Wilson Sossio for 'acting in contravention of the law.'

On 15 April 2018, hundreds of supporters of Budalangi member of parliament (MP) Raphael Wanjala's (ODM), led by Bunyala South ward representative, demonstrated by carrying placards and marching from Mau Mau to Sigiri bridge [coded as Port Bunyala, Bunyala, Bunyala], against the arrest of the MP. Police intervened and dispersed the group (through unspecified means).

On 15 April 2018, residents of Bugomora village protested at an unspecified location along the road linking Nyabubare (Bushenyi district, coordinates used) to Kizinda, to highlight the very poor condition of the road. The source notes that demonstrators blocked the road, but does not specify how (actor 1 coded as protesters), and that police intervened to end the protest.

15 April. Residents from Hargeisa staged a peaceful demonstration in front of the Hargeisa local council to protest of the apparent lack of response to infrastructural damages and dirt caused by floods in the town.
15 April. University of Nairobi students protest the swearing-in of a newly elected student leader, calling the recent election a 'sham.'
On 15 April 2018, local residents protested against UN FAO for failing to pay food stipends in Afmadow town (Afmadow, Lower Juba).
On 16 April 2018, motorists in Tharaka South blocked (unspecified means) the Nkondi-Miomponi road to protest its poor state. The protesters blocked access to Meru.
17 April. Boda Boda riders hold a place card-carrying demonstration governor Ann Wairguru in Kutus.
On 17 April 2018, residents on William Street in Kampala gathered to protest the broken sewage system, however the police prevented them from marching.
On 17 April 2018, MP Paul Mwiru and his supporters demonstrated outside the Kira police station to protest against the arrest of opposition supporters. The police dispersed the protesters.
On 17 April 2018, over 100 tea farmers protested at Itumbe tea factory (South Mugirango, Kisii) against poor management. The farmers demanded the factory director address their grievances.
18 April. Residents of a Mombasa neighbourhood protest forced evictions.

On 19 April 2018, public service vehicle (PSV) operators, coded as taxi drivers, blocked the Kasarani-Mwiki road by parking buses on the road and also putting stones on it, in Mwiki (Nairobi - Kasarani, Nairobi), in demonstration against poor state of the road. Police restored calm (through unspecified means).
On 20 April 2018, people of Deder demonstrated after the death of a man at the hands of security forces to have the security forces brought to justice.
On 20 April 2018, protests erupted in the Jijiga zone of Somali region.

20 April. Residents of El-Afweyne demonstrated against the arrest of a prominent Somaliland traditional leader by Somaliland authorities. The demonstrators burnt tires and blocked roads in El-Afweyn. Demonstration were also reported in Ainabo town, but it is not known if these demos were violent.
On 21 April 2018, people in Hadew, 10km to the west of Jigjiga, on the main highway to Harar staged a massive demonstration against Abdi Iley.
On 21 April 2018, protests reported in Biki district of Shinille against Abdi Iley.
On 23 April in Ambo city, west Shewa zone, high school students demonstrated requesting the security forces to stop killing innocent people and arresting students.

Protests took place in five towns namely Afdem, Bike, Erer, Shinile and Hadhagala district, Sitti zone of the Somali region for four consecutive days (24-27 April). Protesters denounced the regional state's maladministration, accusing the president of the regional state Abdi Illey of endemic nepotism and corruption.

On 24 April 2018, Barbaarta, the youth leading the protests in the Shinile Zone (Harad), staged a massive protest in the Aysha District of the Zone.
On 24 April 2018, protests in Somali region spread to Degeh Bur.

24 April. While police perused a suspect in a Miritini building, a crowd gathered outside, claiming the man was the wrong person and mentally challenged. Police tried to disperse the group by shooting into the crowd, killing one and injuring three.

Protests took place in five towns namely Afdem, Bike, Erer, Shinile and Hadhagala district, Sitti zone of the Somali region for four consecutive days (24-27 April). Protesters denounced the regional state's maladministration, accusing the president of the regional state Abdi Illey of endemic nepotism and corruption.
25 April. Residents of Loruk protest over police insecurity following a spate of crime and cattle rustling.

On 25 April 2018, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Rwamucucu
On 25 April 2018, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Kashambya
On 25 April 2018, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Kamwezi
On 25 April 2018, demonstrators protested against poor service delivery and president Museveni in Muhanga

On 25 April 2018, residents of Nyagakenke village marched to the Kisoro District offices and protested. They demanded the release of the body of a man shot by Mgahinga National Park rangers on April 23rd. Following the protest, four suspects were arrested.
25 April. A group from milk and charcoal dealers demonstrated in front of local government offices against a new tax imposed by Borama local government.

Protests took place in five towns namely Afdem, Bike, Erer, Shinile and Hadhagala district, Sitti zone of the Somali region for four consecutive days (24-27 April). On 26 April 2018, a protest erupted at Ambo University Main campus. Students are demanding release of their classmates arrested by the command post. BBC reported police forces firing teargas. ORM reported Agazi units firing on students.

Protests took place in five towns namely Afdem, Bike, Erer, Shinile and Hadhagala district, Sitti zone of the Somali region for four consecutive days (24-27 April). Protesters denounced the regional state's maladministration, accusing the president of the regional state Abdi Illey of endemic nepotism and corruption.

On 26 April 2018, police arrested a group of 9 protesters in Dar es Salaam as soon as they gathered. Nationwide anti-government protests had been scheduled for the day but denounced as illegal by the government. The day before, several police bosses warned against the demonstrations, pledging to beat protesters 'like stray dogs'.
On 27 April 2018, Residents of Kagaene, Tigania West blocked (unspecified means) a road in protest of a construction delay.

On 27 April 2018, Youth blocked (means unspecified) the Nandi Hills-Chemelil road to protest surging crime in the area. The demos were spurred after two were discovered dead in a suspected bout of gangsterism.

Protests took place in five towns namely Afdem, Bike, Erer, Shinile and Hadhagala district, Sitti zone of the Somali region for four consecutive days (24-27 April). Protesters denounced the regional state's maladministration, accusing the president of the regional state Abdi Illey of endemic nepotism and corruption. On 27 April, over 50 protesters were arrested in Shinelle for wearing t-shirts with photos of the newly elected Prime Minister, Abiy Ahmed.

On 27 April 2018, residents joined protest against the administration of the regional president Abdi Illey in Jijiga. Businesses were closed and transportations disrupted in the Eastern commercial town.
On 27 April 2018, residents of Dire Dawa chanted slogans against the Iley administration following Friday prayers.

Protests took place in five towns namely Afdem, Bike, Erer, Shinile and Hadhagala district, Sitti zone of the Somali region for four consecutive days (24-27 April). Protesters denounced the regional state's maladministration, accusing the president of the regional state Abdi Illey of endemic nepotism and corruption.

27 April. Small business owners demonstrated in front of Borama local government against the destruction of their businesses along one of the main roads in Borama by Borama local government. The business owners demanded for more land to be provided to Borama local government. There were reports of arrests.
28 April, approximately. Protest against police road blocks in Witu 'at the weekend.'

On 28 April 2018, in Shinile zone, Somali region, people started protesting against Abdi Ily's administration. They have also called for market boycott. The protest has also spread to Awbare woreda, Jigjiga zone. One military van was burnt down by the protesters and one person was wounded by police.

On 28 April 2018, residents of Ceel Afweyn, mainly women and youth, took to the streets in Elafweyn against a prominent person by a Hargeisa regional court. The demonstrators demanded for his immediate release. There were reports of arrests.

On 28 April 2018, residents of Burco, mainly women and youth, took to the streets in Burco on protest of a ruling made by a Hargeisa regional court of a prominent person. The demonstrators demanded for his immediate release. There were reports of arrests.
30 April. Traders in Kisii town protest after their shops are dismantled.
On 30 April 2018, Protesters block (unspecified means) the Kisumu-Kakamage highway at Mamboleo junction (3.5km north of Kisumu) over the poor state of the road.
30 April - 1 May: In Welega university in Nekemt (Oromia), about 6,000 students protested following the renewal of work permission for MIDROC gold company.

On 30 April 2018, residents living in East and West Guji zone near a gold mine in Southern Ethiopia (Shakiso) took to the streets for in protest against the extension of a contract for MIDROC mining company for another ten years. The residents say the dangerous chemicals released from the mining project has resulted in birth defects, blindness and various ailments.

On 30 April 2018, the Hoima-Kaiso Tonya road was blocked (unspecified means) after striking workers demonstrated, placing stones and logs on to the road, in an area close to Bulemwa (Hoima district). The demonstrators (who worked for the Shandong Taikai Power Engineering Company) were protesting the absence of pay for the past week.

30 April. Drivers and co-drivers accessing Berbera port demonstrated at Berbera port after a private company managing the port imposed new regulations instructing truck drivers accessing the port to wear safety helmets and vests

On 1 May 2018, in Ambo University, hundreds of Oromo students protested the renewal of work permission for MIDROC gold company in Shakiso woreda, Guji zone. All the roads in east and west Guji zones have been closed by the Youths. Military forces have been arresting the people including local leaders.

On 1 May 2018, the renewal of a gold mining project for another ten years triggered street protests in five towns in Southern Ethiopia. Locals say the project, which has exploited their natural resources for over twenty years has not benefited the poor. Residents of Shakiso and Fincha towns in Guji zone in Southern Ethiopia (Yabelo) have taken to the streets after authorities extended contracts to MIDROC, a company owned by an Ethiopian born Saudi tycoon.

On 1 May 2018, the renewal of a gold mining project for another ten years triggered street protests in five towns in Southern Ethiopia. Locals say the project, which has exploited their natural resources for over twenty years has not benefited the poor. Residents of Shakiso and Fincha towns in Guji zone in Southern Ethiopia have taken to the streets after authorities extended contracts to MIDROC, a company owned by an Ethiopian born Saudi tycoon.

On 1 May 2018, the renewal of a gold mining project for another ten years triggered street protests in five towns in Southern Ethiopia (Nekemt, Oromia). Locals say the project, which has exploited their natural resources for over twenty years has not benefited the poor. Residents of Shakiso and Fincha towns in Guji zone in Southern Ethiopia have taken to the streets after authorities extended contracts to MIDROC, a company owned by an Ethiopian born Saudi tycoon.

On 1 May 2018, the renewal of a gold mining project for another ten years triggered street protests in five towns in Southern Ethiopia. Locals say the project, which has exploited their natural resources for over twenty years has not benefited the poor. Residents of Shakiso and Fincha towns in Guji zone in Southern Ethiopia have taken to the streets after authorities extended contracts to MIDROC, a company owned by an Ethiopian born Saudi tycoon.

01 May. Drivers stage a protest against a private company attempting to impose regulations on vehicles and personnel working at Berbera seaport. Somaliland Police dispersed the crowds peacefully. No arrests.

On 2 May 2018, people living near a gold mine in Southern Ethiopia (Shakiso) continued protests for the third day against the extension of contracts for MIDROC Gold, a company that has been extracting gold for the last two decades. Security forces use tear gas to disperse protesters and several students were reportedly beaten, arrested and taken to undisclosed locations.
On 3 May 2018, demonstrators blockaded (means unspecified) the roads in Shakiso to demonstrate against the licensing of MIDROC Gold mine.

On 3 May 2018, residents of Marigat took to the streets in Marigat (Marigat, Marigat, Baringo) demanding a government action following the death of four people in an alleged Pokot ambush (coded separately).
On the week from 1-7 May, protests to demand the license for the MIDROC Gold mine be cancelled spread to Ginchi town. The exact date was not specified.

On 4 May 2018, demonstrators blocked (means unspecified) the roads in Shakiso to demonstrate against the licensing of MIDROC Gold mine. Demonstrating students were beaten (likely by the police) while asking for their constitutional rights.
On 4 May 2018, Somali people in Diredawa and Jijiga continued to protest against Abdi Iley.
On 4 May 2018, Somali people in Dire Dawa and Jigjiga continued to protest against Abdi Iley.
On 5 May 2018, demonstrators blockaded (means unspecified) the roads in Shakiso to demonstrate against the licensing of MIDROC Gold mine.

On 5 May 2018, a group of people, mostly youths and women, peaceful demonstrated at Ceerigaabo and accused the Somaliland President and ministers who refused to meet with 120 prominent elders from Cerigabo in Hargeisa. SLP in Cerigabo dispersed the demonstrators and there were no reports of arrests.
On 6 May 2018, demonstrators blocked (means unspecified) the roads in Shakiso to demonstrate against the licensing of MIDROC Gold mine.
On 7 May 2018, a protest was reported in Shashamane against the MIDROC Goldmine company.
On 7 May 2018, demonstrators blocked (means unspecified) the roads in Shakiso to demonstrate against the licensing of MIDROC Gold mine.
On 7 May 2018, residents in Adola protested against the license of the MIDROC Gold mine.

On 7 May 2018, 200 students from Busoga Universoty (Iganga town) demonstrated against the University when they realised they were unlikely to be able to sit their final exams (the University had its license revoked, and was in the process of being taken over by the government). Eight students were arrested the following day, though no reason for the arrests is given in the source.

On 8 May 2018, two people were killed when shot by security forces in Adola town. They had been involved in a demonstration to the local police station to demand the release of detainees amidst protests against the MIDROC Gold mine.

On 8 May 2018, the Guji district witnessed several protests against the MIDROC Goldmine. Haruko, Shakiso, Sebou, Ansarra, Irvine and Lutta (Bore) were reported to have protests.General area coded as the specific areas not available.

On 8 May 2018, the Guji district witnessed several protests against the MIDROC Goldmine. Haruko, Shakiso, Sebou, Ansarra, Irvine and Lutta (Liben) were reported to have protests.General area coded as the specific areas not available.
On 8 May 2018, protests were held in the cities of Aisha, Harare, Biki, and Girloom against the Abdi Iley administration (Shinile).
On 8 May 2018, protests were held in the cities of Aysha, Harare, Biki, and Girloom against the Abdi Iley administration.
On 8 May 2018, the Guji district witnessed several protests against the MIDROC Goldmine. Haruko, Shakiso, Sebou, Ansarra, Irvine and Lutta were reported to have protests.

On 8 May 2018, the Guji district witnessed several protests against the MIDROC Goldmine. Haruko, Shakiso, Sebou, Ansarra, Irvine and Lutta (Mormora)were reported to have protests. General area coded as the specific areas not available.
On 8 May 2018, the Guji district witnessed several protests against the MIDROC Goldmine. Haruko, Shakiso, Sebou, Ansarra, Irvine and Lutta were reported to have protests (Negele).
On 8 May 2018, protests were held in the cities of Aisha, Harare, Biki, and Girloom against the Abdi Iley administration.

On 8 May 2018, the Guji district witnessed several protests against the MIDROC Goldmine. Haruko, Shakiso, Sebou, Ansarra, Irvine and Lutta (Dima) were reported to have protests.General area coded as the specific areas not available.
On 8 May 2018, three people were shot and killed by Liyu Police paramilitaries in Togochale town in Eastern Ethiopia supposedly while protesting against Abdi Illey.
On 8 May 2018, protests were held in the cities of Aisha, Harerge, Biki, and Girloom against the Abdi Iley administration.
On 9 May 2018, protests were reported to have taken place in the villages of Harare and Shadder, near Jijiga. Demonstrators are demanding the removal of Abdi's administration.
On 9 May 2018, residents of Abalo near Adola where some residents had been killed the day before, resumed in their protests.
Around 9 May 2018, in west Hararge zone, Burka Linxu woreda (Mieso), people of the area protested the killing of a teacher by an Oromo.
On 9 May 2018, around 2,000 people marched peacefully in Girja district of Guji zone (Buur) against the MIDROC gold mine and the health issues it is causing.
On 9 May 2018, protests were reported to have taken place in the villages of Harerge and Shadder, near Jijiga. Demonstrators are demanding the removal of Abdi's administration.

On 11 May 2018, protests continued in Kabri Dahar, Dire Dawa, Adigala, Bekie, Erer and other towns (Jijiga)against the administration of Illey, the regional president accused of corruption, nepotism and ties to corrupt army generals engaged in contraband trade. Protesters are calling Mr. Illey to step down.

On 11 May 2018, protests continued in Kabri Dahar, Dire Dawa, Adigala, Biki, Erer and other towns against the administration of Illey, the regional president accused of corruption, nepotism and ties to corrupt army generals engaged in contraband trade. Protesters are calling Mr. Illey to step down.

On 11 May 2018, protests continued in Kabri Dahar, Dire Dawa, Adigala, Bekie, Erer and other towns (Hadigale) against the administration of Illey, the regional president accused of corruption, nepotism and ties to corrupt army generals engaged in contraband trade. Protesters are calling Mr. Illey to step down.
On 11 May 2018, students from the health college in Jijiga joined protests against the Abdi Iley administration. Protesters were quickly dispersed by Liyu Police paramilitaries.
11 May. Protests in the Nairobi after the acquittal of a pastor charged with manslaughter.

On 11 May 2018, protests continued in Kabri Dahar, Dire Dawa, Adigala, Bekie, Erer and other towns (Harerge) against the administration of Illey, the regional president accused of corruption, nepotism and ties to corrupt army generals engaged in contraband trade. Protesters are calling Mr. Illey to step down.
14 May. Lawyers in Eldoret locked the High Court on Monday in a protest against a shortage of judges that has stalled hearings.

14 May. Pupils and parents of Rongo Primary School in Nyando, Kisumu County, on Monday protested over the transfer of the institution's head teacher Mr Patrick Odero, demanding his unconditional reinstatement.
On 14 May in Shambu town in Horo Guduru welega zone, a young man was killed by security forces which led the people of the town to protest.

On 14 May 2018, massive demonstrations were reported to be ongoing in several districts in the Somali region of Ethiopia after the Liyu police killed an 18-year-old Somali woman by hanging in Qabri Dahar district (Jijiga).
On 15 May 2018, Liyu Police paramilitaries and Somali militia shot 11 protesters dead in Busa and Lagahida in Fiik zone, Somali. Fatalities split between events.
On 15 May 2018, Liyu Police paramilitaries and Somali militia shot 11 protesters dead in Bussa and Lagahida in Fiik zone, Somali. Fatalities split between events.

On 15 May 2018, a section of women demonstrated by wearing white outfits and breastfeeding their babies while carrying banners and waving placards as they are marching from freedom corner to parliament buildings in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), against a move by a restaurant to refuse to allow a mom to breastfeed at one of their tables, directing her instead to the unsanitary lavatory. The group demanded businesses to provide conducive spaces mothers can use to breastfeed their babies.
17 May, or before. Residents chase a group of road contractors from their site in protest. The residents believed the workers were using substandard materials.
19 May. Police dispersed a group of youth who had gathered to hold a demonstration in Nairobi in support of a Sudanese girl who was sentenced to death for killing her husband.
21 May. Quarry workers in Mandera took to streets to protest against government closure of stone mines.
On 21 May 2018, in Mizan Teferi University, students protested against a recent sexual assault on the campus.

On 22 May 2018, residents of Mizan Teferi in Southwestern Ethiopia protested to denounce the unfair distribution of resources and to demand youth access to those resources to prevent growing unemployment. Students also joined the protests to denounce an attempted sexual assault at the MIzan-Tepi university. Federal and military forces beat and harassed the protesters.
On 24 May 2018, Liyu Police shot and killed three protesters in Dolo Odo town in the Somali region as protests against the regional administration intensified.
25 May. Victims of a collapsed dam protest in Nakuru.
25 May. Two members of an environmental group are arrested by an 'unlawful protest' in Lamu.
26 May. Residents of Ndia Constituency, Kirinyaga West Sub County, Kirinyaga County, held protests over bad roads in the area, specifically the Gacharu-Kiandai-Kianjang'a road.

26 May. Residents of Baki district demonstrated at the office of the Mayor appealing to the Somaliland government to support the victims of Cyclone Sagar which destroyed irrigated farms and livestock. The Mayor of Baki addressed the protestors stating that he would convey their demands to the Somaliland government.

28 May. Hundreds of people hailing from Jareerweyne clan staged a peaceful demonstration on the main road in front of Hotel Daresalam located east of Beletweyne. FGS Members of Parliament resided at the hotel. The motive behind the demonstration was in relation to two men, hailing from Jareerweyne clan, who were injured by the SNA in the previous week. The incident was not justified by the local administration. The local administration spoke to the demonstrators stating that their complaints would be considered.
Around 28 May 2018, public protests erupted in the Afar cemetery (Semera, Afar).

29 May. A peaceful demonstration was conducted at Dhahar town against the Somaliland government. The protestors waved the flag of Puntland and chanted anti-Somaliland slogans. The demonstration concluded peacefully.

29 May. Hundreds of residents of Buhoodle staged a demonstration in Buhodle town in protest of Somaliland presence in Sool, Sanag and Cayn regions. The protestors marched onto the streets chanting anti-Somaliland slogans and later gathered at Habado football grounds. The demonstration ended peacefully.

30 May. A demonstration of an estimated 100 individuals was conducted at the famous square known as 'Barxadda' in the centre of Garowe city. The purpose was to show support to the Puntland army at the frontline in the conflict against Somaliland.
31 May. Parents of students protest against a case of sexual abuse at their Ol Kalou school.
31 May. Nakuru residents protest against alleged corruption cases in the government along the streets of Nakuru town.

On 31 May 2018, sugarcane farmers protested in Muhoroni (Muhoroni, Kisumu) against the closure of Muhoroni sugar company by the Kenya revenue authority due to tax arrears. The farmers demanded the company reopened to support their livelihood.
31 May. Hundreds protest in Nairobi over alleged government corruption.
03 June. Students at a girl's boarding school in Muranga protest for unknown reasons.
On 3 June 2018, protests were reported in Hanna Mariam area of Addis Ababa by displaced residents.

03 June. Residents of Ceelbuh village, mainly youth and women, staged a demonstration in protest of Somaliland presence in Sanag and Sool regions and in support of the Puntland government. The protestors marched on the streets of the village chanting anti-Somaliland slogans.
04 June. Students of an Isiolo school protest the transfer of a teacher.
On 4 June 2018, truck drivers in Mbale protested against the municipality, because it had incorrectly awarded a tender for loading. The police attended the protest in case it turned violent.

On 4 June 2018, a section of old girls at Moi girls school demonstrated by chanting anti-rape slogans and camping at the institution near Kibera (Kibra, Nairobi), against the alleged rape of a student. The group demanded justice for the victim.
On 5 June 2018, a group of activists protested at the Police Headquarters in Kampala. Police arrested 5 of the protesters. The protesters were calling for police action against kidnapping in Uganda.
On 5 June 2018, rice farmers stormed the District HQ in Kalangala (Kalangala district), following a ban on rice farming in the district.
05 June. Police use tear gas on protesters who were demonstrating against the destruction of illegal structures in the area of the Moi Girl's School (Nairobi - Kibra).
On 6 June 2018, around 3,000 residents of the subdivision of Hanna Mariam took to the streets of Addis Ababa to protest the demolition of their homes to provide land for investors.
06 June. Environmental groups protest in Nairobi over the construction of a Chinese power plant in Lamu.
07 June. Residents of Githunguri, Kiambu County protest in Tatu City over rights to claimed land.

On 7 June 2018, in the Rahile woreda, Afar region (Berahle), a large number of people protested. They requested that Mr. Rashid Sali be released from prison. Rashid Sali is Samara University human resource director and was detained as he disagreed with Ethiopian military generals as they wanted to have total control over Samara university.

On 8 June 2018, residents in Irob in Tigray protested after Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed announced the government would adhere to the Algiers agreement with Eritrea. They claim the agreement puts Ethiopian nationalism in question.

On 8 June 2018, it was reported that residents of towns in the Afar region protested to demand the release of political prisoners and interference of the Tigray region in Afari affairs. Police fired shots at protesters but it was not clear if there were casualties. Protests reported in Semera, Aysaita, Barahle, Koneba and other towns (Awash).
Around 8 June 2018, reports of a protest in the northern zone of Addis Ababa, as a number of residents of the region were demanding change and justice.
Around 8 June 2018, there have been protests reported in Isea, Abella and various cities in the Afar region over interference of the Tigray region in Afari affairs (Badana).

On 8 June 2018, it was reported that residents of towns in the Afar region protested to demand the release of political prisoners and interference of the Tigray region in Afari affairs. Police fired shots at protesters but it was not clear if there were casualties. Protests reported in Semera, Aysaita, Berahle, Koneba and other towns.
Around 8 June 2018, there have been protests reported in Isea, Abella and various cities in the Afar region over interference of the Tigray region in Afari affairs (Dubti).

On 8 June 2018, it was reported that residents of towns in the Afar region protested to demand the release of political prisoners and interference of the Tigray region in Afari affairs. Police fired shots at protesters but it was not clear if there were casualties. Protests reported in Semera, Aysaita, Barahle, Koneba and other towns.

On 8 June 2018, it was reported that residents of towns in the Afar region protested to demand the release of political prisoners and interference of the Tigray region in Afari affairs. Police fired shots at protesters but it was not clear if there were casualties. Protests reported in Semera, Aysaita, Barahle, Koneba and other towns.

On 8 June 2018, it was reported that residents of towns in the Afar region protested to demand the release of political prisoners and interference of the Tigray region in Afari affairs. Police fired shots at protesters but it was not clear if there were casualties. Protests reported in Semera, Aysaita, Barahle, Koneba and other towns.
On 8 June 2018, in Tigray, the Woreda People's Committee held a demonstration calling for the implementation of the ALLA. They oppose the agreement because it pays Euro.
On 8 June 2018, truck drivers in Kabale stormed the Kabale mayor's office to demand the public goods in truck park.

On 8 June 2018, police dispersed protesters (comprising residents, boda boda drivers, and mechanics) who blocked a road in Mbale (Mbale district) in protest against its poor quality (note: the means through which it was blocked were unspecified, actor 1 coded as protesters). Two shopkeepers were wounded after being hit by a tear gas canister that penetrated the walls of the shop. Five people were arrested by police.
On 9 June 2018, Employees of a waste disposal service dump garbage along a Homa Bay road in protest of non-payment of salaries.

Around 9 June 2018, Oromo people in Harari demonstrated against the regional government's displacement from their land without compensation. Liyu Police paramilitaries reportedly shot and injured demonstrators.

09 June. About a hundred personnel of Somaliland National Printing agency demonstrated in front of the printing agency and later marched to the Presidential palace to claim 4 months arrears of their salaries. Police dispersed them.

10 June. Hundreds of Gudubi residents reportedly demonstrated peacefully against the arrest of their village cleric in Burao. Demonstrators marched to the main village mosque where they strongly condemned the Ministry of Religious Affair for their Sheikh arrest. The demonstration ended peacefully.
10 June. Auto-rickshaw drivers protest against road closures. SNPF peacefully dispersed the protesters.
10 June. Erigavo teachers staged a demonstration in front of the office of the regional Ministry of Education in Cerigabo to claim the many months arrears of their salaries. Police dispersed them.
11 June. A protest is being held around the KM4 junction in the [Somali] capital Mogadishu, where motorcar drivers in the region are protesting against the constant roadblocks in the city.

On 11 June 2018, workers at the Laico regency hotel protested by waving placards in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the failure by the management to honor a collective bargaining agreement as well as the summarily dismissal without reason of eight employees. The group demanded the workers to be reinstated with immediate effect.

11 June. Protesters, 'wanting justice to prevent similar incidents' protest in the central business district following an alleged case of sexual assault at a girl's school in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe).
11 or 12 June. Protests occurred in 'western Kenya' (likely around the Lake Victoria area) after three Kenyan security officials are arrested in Ugandan waters on 11 June.
Between 11-14 June, protests were reported in Bahir Dar University.
Between 11-14 June, protests were reported in Bahir Dar University.
Between 11-14 June, protests were reported in Bahir Dar University.
On 12 June 2018, around 700 girls from Maasai Girls School demonstrated in Narok (Narok Town, Narok North, Narok) over an alleged case of sexual harassment by a male teacher.
On 12 June 2018, 15 truck drivers under police detention for transporting banned timber demonstrated in Gulu town (Gulu district), claiming they were unfairly detained.
12 June. Workers protest at Nairobi city hall (Nairobi - Starehe) over an unfavourable pension bill.

On 13 June 2018, In east Hararge zone, Malka Balo woreda people demonstrated requesting the Prime Minister Dr. Abiy and Oromia regional president, Lema Megarsa, to stop the Somali regional President Abdi Illey from killing innocent people using Liyu police (Gimbi).

On 13 June 2018, police arrested Mukono MP, Betty Nambooze, in conjunction with the murder of MP Abirige the previous week. Her supporters protested outside the Jinja Road Police Station in Kampala, where she was held.
Between 11-14 June, protests were reported in Bahir Dar University. Liyu Police paramilitaries were reported to have beaten students and local residents.

On 14 June 2018, people gathered in Kisoro town with placards to protest the arrest of former police chief Kyihura the day before. Police was deployed throughout the town to prevent the protest from being held. The arrest came a few days after other senior police officers were arrested over unclear reasons.

16 June, on or about. Somaliland forces open fire on a group of anti-Somaliland demonstrators in Las Anod. The exact date of the event is not known - source dated 18 June, explaining that it took place 'a few days ago.'
On 17 June 2018, the TPLF organised a protest rally in Addis Ababa in an attempt to reportedly frustrate Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed.
On 17 June 2018, protests were reported in Mekele by natives of Irob against the decision by the federal government to accept and implement the boundary ruling with Eritrea.

17 June. A Group of Fiqi Fuliye (82km SE of Erigavo) residents, mainly youths and women staged a demonstration against Somaliland presence in Sool region and in support of Puntland government. The protestors reportedly marched in the village streets, chanting anti- Somaliland slogans.
18 June. Residents of Garowe town in the semi-autonomous Puntland region of Somalia held a large anti-Somaliland demonstration in the town on 18 June.

On 18 June 2018, local residents protested against Somaliland presence in Sool region in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal). Puntland police forces intervened and injured two women accused of supporting Somaliland.

On 20 June 2018, pupils of Oleico Primary School marched in Kumi town (Kumi district), demanding that six of their teachers (who had been arrested for allegedly damaging a car belonging to a woman involved in a land dispute with the school) be released.
21 June. Machakos Level Five Hospital workers demonstrate in Machakos town against a poor working environment.
On 21 June 2018, protests in the Afar region continue. In Koneba, Afar women were reported at front line of the protest. The protesters are calling for good governance and social justice.

On 21 June 2018, residents of Dire Dawa, a city in Eastern Ethiopia, protested for the president of the Somali region to step down, his administration of instigating conflict among different groups, and of corruption.
On 22 June 2018, security forces shot and killed a man who protested with other IDPs during an anti Al Shabaab arrest operation in an IDP camp at Kotulo (Tarbaj, Wajir), near the border with Somalia.
On 24 June 2018, protest rallies were staged in Gonder, Dire Dawa and Jijiga, Welo, Semera and Gambela to condemn the bombing in Addis Ababa on 23 June and to show support for the Prime Minister.
On 24 June 2018, protest rallies were staged in Gonder, Dire Dawa and Jijiga, Welo, Semera and Gambela to condemn the bombing in Addis Ababa on 23 June and to show support for the Prime Minister.
On 24 June 2018, protest rallies were staged in Gonder, Dire Dawa and Jijiga, Welo, Semera and Gambela to condemn the bombing in Addis Ababa on 23 June and to show support for the Prime Minister.
On 24 June 2018, protest rallies were staged in Gonder, Dire Dawa and Jijiga, Welo, Semera and Gambela to condemn the bombing in Addis Ababa on 23 June and to show support for the Prime Minister.

On 24 June 2018, protest rallies were staged in Gonder, Dire Dawa and Jijiga, Welo, Semera and Gambela (North Wollo, Amhara) to condemn the bombing in Addis Ababa on 23 June and to show support for the Prime Minister.
On 24 June 2018, protest rallies were staged in Gonder, Dire Dawa and Jijiga, Welo, Semera and Gambella to condemn the bombing in Addis Ababa on 23 June and to show support for the Prime Minister.

On 25 June 2018, sugarcane farmers marched in Awendo town (Awendo, Migori), against the importation of counterfeit sugar. The group demanded that the government prosecute millers involved in the importation of counterfeit sugar.
26 June. Residents of Ol Kalou protest over the poor state of an area road.
26 June. Local civilians protest against Rahanweyn traders operating in Ceerigaabo and ask Somalilander authorities to deport them due to their status as 'non-Somalilander'.

27 June. Turkana County residents blocked a road to stop five trucks from ferrying crude oil to Mombasa in protest of rising insecurity along the border with Baringo. The protest took place at Kalemngorok. The staff and suppliers working at the oil company left the oilfields for 50 days, shutting down the plant's production, until an agreement was found with the government on 23 August.

On or around 27 June, police shot and killed non-locals (Amhara/Oromo groups) who were holding a counter-protest against the attacks by the Bertas in Asosa, Benishangul region. A total of 14 people were reported killed in violence in Asosa over 25-27 June, including one on the first day and seven on the second. & remaining fatalities spread over two events on 27 June.

27 June. Erigavo residents demonstrated against the Rahanweyn traders (Rahanweyn are People from South West of Somalia namely Baidoa and Hudur) that occupy the strategic business centres in Erigavo town. They appealed to SL government to deport Rahanweyn traders from Erigavo (Back to Somalia) as they are not Somalilanders.

On 28 June 2018, a section of parents and students demonstrated by chanting and carrying twigs in Nyatike (Seme, Kisumu), against a police officer who sexually assaulted 13 students. The group demanded justice for the students.

On 30 June 2018, residents of Bahir Dar and other 20 towns in Ethiopia's northwestern Amhara Regional State were reported to hold peaceful rallies to show support for the reforms brought by Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed in the country.
On 30 June 2018, hundreds of protesters marched in Kampala to protest violence against women.
On 1 July 2018, a massive crowd was reported at a rally in the northwestern Ethiopian town of Bahir Dar in support of Prime Minister Abiy.
On 1 July 2018, a rally was reported in Shewa Robit in support of Prime Minister Abiy.

During the week between June 27th and July 3rd, protesters demonstrated against a police officer from Kibanda (Rakai district), following his role in an assault on a woman in Kakuuto sub-county of Kyotera district, resulting in the arrest of the officer. (Note that the source does not specify where the protests took place; coordinates for Kibanda used at precision 2. One event coded at time precision 2).
On 2 July 2018, researchers working on a project on climate change and agriculture stormed the district HQ in Moroto (Moroto district), following the non-payment of allowances.

On 2 July 2018, a section of drivers with taxi-hailing companies demonstrated by gathering at Uhuru Park and hooting, before driving to submit their petition to transport ministry officials in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands), against low fare rates charged by service providers. Led by their chairman, the group demanded the service providers to review the rates upwards.

03 July. Local communities from North and South Galkayo protested due to high inflation and the devaluation of Somali shilling. Protestors complained of high prices of commodities and urged the government administration to look into the issue.
On 3 July 2018, youths protested the poor state of a road in Binyenya (Tongaren, Bungoma). Police, who were dispersing the crowd, accidentally shot and killed a taxi rider.
03 July. Traders from Woodley and Jamhuri market protest at Nairobi city hall (Nairobi - Starehe) over alleged harassment by government agencies and destruction of their goods.

On 4 July 2018, students from Maliera Boys High School attempted to torch the school library in Yala (Yala Township, Gem, Siaya County) demanding for a new school bus and entertainment sessions every weekend. Police officers intervened and controlled the situation. The school was closed for a week.
05 July. Railway workers protest non-payment of salaries in Nairobi. The protest was peaceful.
On July 7 or 8, thousands of people demonstrated in support of PM Abiy's reform agenda and call for peace and forgiveness in Injibara, Dangila, Abrehajira, Raya, Ataye, and Arba Minch (Maychew).
On July 7 or 8, thousands of people demonstrated in support of PM Abiy's reform agenda and call for peace and forgiveness in Injibara, Dangila, Abrehajira, Raya, Ataye, and Arba Minch.
On July 7 or 8, thousands of people demonstrated in support of PM Abiy's reform agenda and call for peace and forgiveness in Injibara, Dangila, Abrehajira, Raya, Ataye, and Arba Minch.
On July 7 or 8, thousands of people demonstrated in support of PM Abiy's reform agenda and call for peace and forgiveness in Injibara, Dangila, Abrehajira, Raya, Ataye, and Arba Minch.
On July 7 or 8, thousands of people demonstrated in support of PM Abiy's reform agenda and call for peace and forgiveness in Injibara, Dangila, Abrehajira, Raya, Ataye, and Arba Minch.
On July 7 or 8, thousands of people demonstrated in support of PM Abiy's reform agenda and call for peace and forgiveness in Injibara, Dangila, Abrehajira, Raya, Ataye, and Arba Minch (Abderafi).
09 July. Transport was paralysed on the Nairobi-Mombasa highway in Emali after demonstrating residents blocked the busy road protesting water shortage in the area.
During the week of 11 July, mobile money operators in Katakwi held a protest against tariffs. 3 journalists covering the protest were arrested.
On 11 July 2018, 200 villagers who had been evicted from their land in Apaa began a sit-in protest outside the UN offices in Gulu.

Around 12 July 2018 (as reported), women demonstrated by carrying placards, twigs and singing songs of justice, as they marched from Kizingo to Gede chief's office ( Ganze, Kilifi), against the alleged unlawful appointment of a male sub-chief. The women demanded the revocation of the appointment of the male Sub-chief to pave way for a woman.

Around 14 July 2018 (as reported), local residents, mainly parents, demonstrated by marching to the Kinamba trading centre (Laikipia West, Laikipia), against increased insecurity. Led by their member of county assembly (MCA), the group demanded the area assistant commissioner to address the matter.

On 16 July 2018, Somali security officers were accused of deliberately shooting at civilians during a forceful eviction at Siinka Dheer neighbourhood in Mogadishu - Dharkenley (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle). Dozens of Somali forces were deployed to Al Biri village near Siinka locality to demolish houses illegally built in the area. The security officers deployed in the area were confronted by residents protesting over the demolition of their houses. Three unarmed civilians were killed and five others were injured.
Week of 16 July. Students of Munyeki primary school in Ol Kalou protest after donated clothes do not fit. Exact date of the protest is not known.
On 18 July 2018, a group of MPs and protesters marched with activist Bobi Wine, to protest his arrest. The police arrested a number of protesters.
19 July. Shop owners protest insecurity in Molo town.

During the week beginning July 16th, women have been marching in Mto wa Mbu (Arusha), in protest against a spate of gang-rapes (including a killing) in the area. The source says these protests have been taking place on a 'daily basis', though does not indicate when they began (two events at time precision 2 recorded).

On 19 July 2018, and following the detention of an independent candidate for the Bugiri parliamentary seat, supporters of the detained candidate blocked roads in Bugiri (Bugiri district). Police dispersed the demonstrators (coded as protesters, as the source doesn't specify the means used to block the road) with tear gas.
22 July. Approximately 70 NISA officers protested near Villa Somalia after they were fired on orders of FGS due to equipment issues.
23 July. Hundreds of Narok residents marched peacefully to protest calls by some politicians for Mau Forest evictions not to take place.

On 23 July 2018, a large number of protesters gathered in Jijiga city (Somali zone) demanding the resignation of the controversial regional president, Abdi Illey. Police violently broke up the protests, causing a number of injuries.

Around 23 July 2018 (as reported), residents carried twigs as they marched along the Isbania - Migori road [coded as Migori, Suna West, Migori] against increased insecurity in the area. The group demanded increased police patrols.

Around 23 July 2018 (as reported), shareholders of Wendano Matuu company protested by carrying twigs and waving placards in Wendano (Masinga, Machakos) against an alleged plot by a private developer to grab their land. The group demanded the president help address the matter.
On 26 July 2018, protests broke out in Gonder (Amhara zone), the home town of the murdered chief engineer of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam, Eng Simegnew.
On 26 July 2018, protesters filled the Mbale High Court to await the judgment on the age limit ruling.

On or before July 28th, police and UPDF soldiers used tear gas and live rounds to disperse FDC demonstrators outside of the tally station in Nebbi (Nebbi district), following allegations that the NRM had taken the parliamentary seat through foul play. (Note: actor 2 coded as protesters, as it is unclear whether they were engaged in violent activities).
On 29 July 2018, Ethiopian police fired teargas to disperse crowd in Addis Ababa calling for the arrest of culprits behind the death of the chief engineer of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam.
On 30 July 2018, there were demonstrations at the Kasese LC office to demand the creation of new sub-counties in Busongora.

On 30 July 2018, a section of students at Jomo Kenyatta university protested at the institution in Juja (Juja, Kiambu), against increased insecurity, following the murder of a fourth year student. The students demanded justice for the deceased.

On 1 August 2018, students at Nyakitoko Secondary School (Buhweju district) demonstrated against the headmaster of the school, demanding his resignation. Police officers shot dead an 18 year-old student, and wounded a 22 year-old student, as they attempted to suppress the protests. Two police officers have been arrested.

On 3 August 2018, hundreds of Somali youth reportedly protested in the main streets of Mogadishu against the deteriorating security situation in the country. The protests were reportedly prompted by the murder of Tanzanian-Somali entrepreneur Mohamed Sheikh Ali the evening before (event coded separately).
On 4 August 2018, supporters of the Somali region's president protested against the deployment of federal troops to Jijiga town.
On 4 August 2018, Ethiopian Somalis protested in Dire Dawa against the human rights violations by the regional government.
05 August. Amhara people protested at the door of ETV/EBC in Addis Ababa against land expropriation and persecution in Raya.

On 5 August 2018, unsatisfied worshippers at the African Independent Penecostal Church of Africa in Nyandarua blocked access to the Uiguano Rurii Church and verbally ejected the visiting bishop out of the church in a conflict over the legitimacy of the bishop.
On 5 August 2018, protesters gathered in Addis Ababa in response to the violence in Jijiga (capital of the Somali region), and concerns about the safety of their kin.

On 6 August 2018, business and transport was paralysed at Namanga border town as Kenyans blocked (means unspecified) the main road and deflated the tires of lorries to protest mistreatment by Tanzanian authorities after several milk traders were arrested and placed in custody in Tanzania. Traders on both sides of the border incurred big losses.
On 6 August 2018, Kenya National Union of Nurses (KNUN) demonstrated at the Bomet County HQs demanding to be paid their June and July salaries.
On 6 August 2018, residents of Kajiado blocked Namanga Highway at Ilbisil (Bissil) town, Kajiado county to protest alleged handing over of Kenyan criminal suspects to Tanzanian authorities.
On 6 August 2018, police used teargas to disperse striking staff of Kenyatta National Hospital in Nairobi - Kibra who protested over non-payment of their health service allowances.

On 7 August 2018, business and transport was paralysed at Namanga border town as Kenyans blocked (means unspecified) the main road and deflated the tires of lorries to protest mistreatment by Tanzanian authorities after several milk traders were arrested and placed in custody in Tanzania. Traders on both sides of the border incurred big losses.
In the week of 8 August, residents in Igayaza stormed the office of the district Internal Security Officer (DISO) to protest the arrest of 2 people accused of plotting a rebellion.
On 8 August 2018, people who were evicted from illegally constructed homes and civil society activists staged a protest in Nairobi against the recent governmental campaign to destroy illegal housing.
On 9 August 2018, residents protested in Rupa, against a plan to build a cement factory in the area.

On 9 August 2018, residents of Nyakahanga cell protested at the Electoral Commission offices in Makanga (Kabale district), storming the offices in order to express their disgruntlement at the lack of LC1 elections in the cell.
On 16 August 2018, protestors from the town of Tepi gathered in Addis Ababa to demonstrate against alleged abuses of power by the Tepi authorities.
On 16 August 2018, residents of Rupa protested against a land grab by a prominent businessman and some ministers.
On 18 August 2018, police fired live ammunition and teargas to disperse a crowd of protesters blocking the roads in Mukono. Protests had erupted in response to the arrest of Bobi Wine.

On 18 August 2018, merchants in Mombasa protested against the seizure of a consignment of sugar by the police, leading to a stand-off between the protesters and the police. The Somali Community Traders chairman reported that 50 shops had been raided by the police, and that the police were extorting shopkeepers.

On 19 August 2018, a group of people blocked (means unspecified) the highway in Mityana to protest the arrest of the Mityana MP, Zaake with Bobi Wine. Police dispersed the crowd using live ammunition. 1 person was shot dead and 5 people were injured.

On 20 August 2018, protesters gathered in Chebunyo (Bomet county) and blocked vehicles from leaving a nearby quarry. They were demonstrating against the marginalisation of Chebunyo and the poor state of the road running through the area (and the use of quarry materials in areas other than Chebunyo).

On 20 August 2018, police and military broke up a group of protesters marching from Katwe to Usafi Market against the arrest of Bobi Wine. The security forces fired live bullets into the crowd. 1 protester was shot dead.

On 22 August 2018, motorists of the Kenya Motorists Association staged a demonstration in Roysambu, Nairobi (Nairobi - Roysambu) against the proposed 16% Value Added Tax on petroleum. The protest was allegedly aborted soon after starting.
On 23 August 2018, dozens of protestors gathered in Nairobi's Uhuru park (Nairobi - Westlands), demanding the release of Ugandan MP Bobi Wine, who is in detention in Kampala.
23 August. Reports of demonstrations against the governing administration in Garbaharey town.

Around 24 August 2018 (as reported), hundreds of youth demonstrated in Isiolo (Bula Pesa, Isiolo, Isiolo) over poor service delivery from the county government and youth exclusion in awarding jobs. They barricaded (means unspecified) the Isiolo Meru highway before police officers put them off the road.
24 August. Protests in Garbahaarey continue for a second day.
25 August. Youths in Birrsheleko, Western Gojjam, Amahra region protested over lack of benefits from the large farmlands in the area (Bure).
26 August 2018: Protests against government interference in Jubaland and Gedo region took place in Dhobley.
26 August 2018: Protests against the Somali Federal Government were held in Afmadow town.
26 August 2018: Demonstrators gathered outside the Kooshin SNPF station took place after the killing of a Tuk-tuk driver. Main roads near the station were blocked.

On or before August 27th, around 300 protesters gathered in Chepkositonik (Bomet County) to demonstrate against a poor quality bridge that had been built by the government in the village, and an alleged misappropriation of funds surrounding the construction project.
On or before August 27th, protestors in Kiambere (Embu County, approximate coordinates used) demonstrated against KenGen's failure to supply the area with clean drinking water, and electricity.
27 August. Taxi drivers in Addis Ababa demonstrated outside Fana Broadcasting opposing the new Zonal allocation system.

On 27 August 2018, angry residents stormed the hospital in Malindi sub-county following the death of a man involved in a vehicle accident to protest alleged negligence on the part of the medical staff of the hospital. The staff denied.

27 August 2018: Protests by Hawadle sub-clan took place with civilians taking control of downtown Belet Weyne and blocking main roads. Negotiations between Hawadle and HiirShabelle took place to de-escalate the conflict.
28 August. Protests were held in Jijiga as bodies of Somali civilians killed in Baabile & Tulli Guled arrived at the hospital.

On 28 August 2018, protestors blocked (means unspecified) the road between Emali and Wote (Makueni sub-county, coordinates for Emali used). The demonstrators were angry about the substandard condition of the road, and the failure of the three MPs of the region to address their concerns.

On 28 August 2018, local residents, mainly boda boda taxi operators, protested outside the emergency wing of Malindi sub-county hospital (Malindi, Kilifi), against the death of a fellow boda boda taxi operator at the facility, citing neglect by medical personnel after he was knocked down by a Kilifi county inspectorate vehicle.

On 29 August 2018, local residents demonstrated by waving placards and banners as they marched from Mukuyu to the governor's office in Muranga (Kiharu, Muranga), against the alleged governor interference in the management of water resources. The residents demanded the governor to stop interfering in the management of water resources.
29 August 2018: Protesters blocked the streets in Karan, Mogadishu, denouncing the killing of a Tuk-tuk driver by a police officer earlier.
30 August. Supporters of former governor of the Ethiopian Somali Regional State are holding protests in the region's headquarters, Jijiga town, demanding the release of Abdi Mahamud Omar (Abdi Iley).

On 30 August 2018, a group of activists held a peaceful protest in Mombasa over the disappearance of a local youth. They also raised concerns over the rising number of forced disappearances in the region.
31 August. Residents of Telemt Woreda, North Gonder demonstrated calling for good governance and economic development issues to be resolved.

On 31 August 2018, more than 100 Kalangalala Secondary School students have organized a demonstration in front of the office of Geita District Commissioner, to protest lethal beating of their fellow student by a teacher of his school.
On or before 02 September. In west Wellaga, Mana Sibu woreda, large number of people demonstrated following the death of a young girl from Oromo tribe. She was killed by someone from Barta tribe.
On or before September 3rd, traders from the Maasai ethnic group demonstated against the demolition of their stalls in Uhuru market by authorities in Narok Town.

On 3 September 2018, around 120 youth from Makueni county blocked the Machakos-Wote road (means unspecified) in protests at unpaid wages for their work in upgrading work in the county (coordinates for Wote used).
On 3 September 2018, residents of Ngecha village (Kiambu county) demonstrated against a local gang known as the 'Gaza Boys'.
On 3 September 2018, drivers of taxis, matatus and boda bodas blocked (means unspecified) roads in Nakuru town, in protest at the increase in fuel tax which came into effect that day.
