On 3 September 2018, in Pajule Town Council (Aruu, Pader), youths staged a demonstration and blocked the Lacani protesting against its impassable state. They claim the road was last maintained by the district works and technical department in 2014.
On or before 03 September. Residents of Sheka, Tepi protested outside the Zonal city over recent clashes. They have asked for change of the local government.
04 September. People in Gonder under the name of 'Qemant's Identity Question coordinating committee members' protested to call for the release of detained members.

On 4 September 2018, drivers were reported to have blocked roads in the area of Mt. Kenya (locations not specified, coordinates for Nyeri town used). This was in protest at the introduction of a (long-delayed) fuel tax.

On 4 September 2018, drivers were reported to have blocked part of the Kisii-Bomet highway (location not specified, coordinates for Bomet used). This was in protest at the introduction of a (long-delayed) fuel tax.

On 4 September 2018, South Sudanese refugees based in the Bidi Bidi refugee camp (Yumbe district) organised a peaceful protests in response to a lack of food rations (which one refugee claimed had not been delivered for two months).
8 September 2018: Youth and women's groups in Garbaharay town protested against the Somali National Government's support of Ethiopian troops in the area.
8 September 2018: Residents of Lasanod staged a demonstration demanding the cessation of clashes in the area.

On 10 September 2018, matatu (minibus) operators blocked traffic on Murang'a - Kiriaini road in protest against the roads' dilapidated state. They demanded the road be re-carpeted instead of the government only investing in filling potholes.

On 10 September 2018, protesters of the village of Kigamba-Kasubi stormed the mayor's office at Masaka (Masaka district), following efforts by the state to evict them from disputed land, to build a hospital.

On 11 September 2018, vendors stormed the municipality offices in Kabale (Kabale district), following a ban on road-side selling of food. The vendors also accused security forces of assaulting them when the ban was first implemented.

On 11 September 2018, activists staged a protest in Nairobi against the murder of a Rongo University student who had been abducted together with the journalist Barrack Oduor. The protesters called on politicians to act upon the recent killing.
On 12 September 2018, informal traders staged a demonstration along Diani Beach Road in Kwale, protesting the ongoing demolition of their stalls ordered by the county government.
14 September. Residents of Maji-bero in Bench Maji Zone hold a protest accusing the government of neglect and unresponsiveness to their questions (Maji).

15 September 2018: A group of fishermen reportedly protested in Lawya Caddo against foreign vessels fishing in the area. Local police arrived and reassured the protesters that the vessels would not be allowed to remain.

15 September 2018: Protesters gathered outside of the Berbera Regional Police Headquarters after the death of the Police Commander of Abdaal district in a traffic accident. The protesters insisted that he had been assassinated.

16 September 2018: Local protesters protested in Dharkenley district against the killing of two soldiers by police forces at a checkpoint the day before. They accused the soldiers of setting up an illegal checkpoint.

17 September. Residents of Addis Abeba held massive protests condemning the killing of innocent civilians in the outskirts of the capital (Nifas Silk-Lafto) by Oromo youths. Protests were held in various subcities of Addis: Addis Ketema, Gullele, Kolfe Keran (Piazza and Jemo),Yeka (Lege Tafo), Nifas Silk, Addis (Meskel square). Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.

17 September. Residents of Addis Abeba held massive protests condemning the killing of innocent civilians in the outskirts of the capital by Oromo youths. Protests were held in various subcities of Addis: Addis Ketema, Gullele, Kolfe Keran (Piazza and Jemo),Yeka (Lege Tafo), Nifas Silk, Addis (Meskel square). Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.

17 September. Residents of Addis Abeba held massive protests condemning the killing of innocent civilians in the outskirts of the capital by Oromo youths. Protests were held in various subcities of Addis: Addis Ketema, Gullele, Kolfe Keran (Piazza and Jemo),Yeka (Lege Tafo), Nifas Silk, Addis (Meskel square). Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.

17 September. Residents of Addis Abeba held massive protests condemning the killing of innocent civilians in the outskirts of the capital by Oromo youths. Protests were held in various subcities of Addis: Addis Ketema, Gullele, Kolfe Keran (Piazza and Jemo),Yeka (Lege Tafo), Nifas Silk, Addis (Meskel square). Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.

17 September. Residents of Addis Abeba held massive protests condemning the killing of innocent civilians in the outskirts of the capital by Oromo youths. Protests were held in various subcities of Addis: Addis Ketema, Gullele, Kolfe Keran (Piazza and Jemo),Yeka (Lege Tafo), Nifas Silk, Addis (Meskel square). Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.
17 September. A protest in Alamata about the identity question of Raya people (a subgroup of the Oromo) was met by force from the local security forces. Several protesters were injured.
17 September. Residents of Burayu from the Oromo community held massive protests condemning the killing of innocent civilians in Burayu by Oromo youths (Asko).

17 September. Residents of Addis Abeba held massive protests condemning the killing of innocent civilians in the outskirts of the capital by Oromo youths. Protests were held in various subcities of Addis: Addis Ketema, Gullele, Kolfe Keran (Piazza and Jemo),Yeka (Lege Tafo), Nifas Silk, Addis (Meskel square). Five people were killed as police dispersed the demonstrations with force and 600 arrested. Five fatalities spread over six VAC events.

On 17 September 2018, protesters from the Jubilee Party marched in Nakuru, in the hope of changing the county-level leadership of the party. The protesters attempted to storm the HQ of the county branch of the party, but were unable to gain access to the premises, which was reported to be deserted.

17 September. Thousands of people protested in Armba Minch city condemning the attacks against Gamo people in Burayu (Arba Minch). The protest turned violent and police assaulted several protesters, some with life threatening injuries.

18 September. Scores of Amhara people displaced from the Somali region of Ethiopia held a protest in Bahir Dar asking the government to support them. Several protesters were attacked by the Region's police.
On 18 September 2018, residents from Mitahato village in Githunguri blocked the Kirigiti-Kwamaiko road in protest over poor workmanship carried out on the road by the contractor.

On 18 September 2018, activists demonstrated in Meru town demanding justice for Githongo law court magistrate's daughter who had been abducted and killed. The protesters also demanded an overhaul of local police units and better security.

On 19 September 2018, around 1,000 workers at the Mumias Sugar Company (Kakamega) blockaded roads around the factory, in protest at the non-payment of salaries for 17 months, and alleged mismanagement at the firm.

On 19 September 2018, the Mombasa/Nairobi highway was blocked by protesting Matatu drivers from Mikindani to the Central Business District, Jomvu, Mombasa. The drivers protested the lack of parking space within the city. At least one person was arrested. The protests come as the Mikindani stage was shut down the night before by police officers armed with batons and tear gas.

On 20 September 2018, soldiers beat protesters who had gathered to support the return of Bobi Wine MP in Kasangati (Wakiso) with long sticks, leaving two injured on the head. Similar incidents were reported to have occurred at an unspecified location(s) on Entebbe Road.

On 22 September 2018, local labourers of a Chinese company contracted to lay tarmac on Suguta-Maralal road staged a protest in front of Sino Hydro's office in Maralal town denouncing poor working conditions and non-payment of overtime.

On 23 September 2018, around 400 Maasai demonstrators protested against a planned eviction from farmland whose ownership is contested by members of the Maasai and Kikyu communities. The event occurred at Mai Mahiu
23 September. People protested in Gambella city. Protesters claimed Gambella has been neglected when changes were taking place in the other parts of the country.
23 September. A protest condemning anti-change forces and supporting Oromo Democratic Party was held in Adama (Nazreth).

From September 24th - 26th, students demonstrated against fee increases at the University of Machakos (Machokos). Police dispersed protesters with tear gas on Monday 24th; arrested a student leader on the 25th; and again dispersed protesters on the 26th (the source does not specify how). The University was indefinitely closed as of Sep 26th.
On 25 September 2018, refugees from the region gathered outside the headquarters of the UNHCR in Kampala, to protest against insecurity they have been facing in refugee camps.

From September 24th - 26th, students demonstrated against fee increases at the University of Machakos (Machokos). Police dispersed protesters with tear gas on Monday 24th; arrested a student leader on the 25th; and again dispersed protesters on the 26th (the source does not specify how). The University was indefinitely closed as of Sep 26th.

From September 24th - 26th, students demonstrated against fee increases at the University of Machakos (Machokos). Police dispersed protesters with tear gas on Monday 24th; arrested a student leader on the 25th; and again dispersed protesters on the 26th (the source does not specify how). The University was indefinitely closed as of Sep 26th.

On 27 September 2018, local Turkana residents stopped and blocked (through unspecified means) five trucks transporting oil from Ngamia 8 to Mombasa along the Lokichar-Kitale Highway [coded as Lokichar, Turkana South, Turkana]. The group demanded that the trucks return to Africa Camp Solutions.

On 27 September 2018, matutu (minibus) drivers and local merchants protested the alleged failure of the police to investigate reports of Mungiki activity in Nairobi, who they have say have been extorting matatu operators, and were behind the recent murder of a matatu driver who refused to pay protection fees. Police denied the claims, saying they arrested several gang members.
29 September 2018: A group of fishermen gathered to protest a land dispute. Police forces dispersed the protest peacefully.
On or before September 29th, protesters gathered at Jomvu (Mombasa) to demonstrate against land grabbing and the fraudlent sale of public land in the area.

30 September 2018: Protesters took to the streets of Diinsor town in protest of Muqtar Robow's possible candidacy for the upcoming South West State presidential election. Muqtar Rabow is a former member of Al-Shabaab.

On 2 October 2018, dozens of youth gathered at an unspecified location in Ibanda district (coordinates for Ibanda Town used) to protest what they deemed to be a misallocation of 50 million shillings donated by President Museveni to youth in the town.

On 2 October 2018, long distance truck drivers demonstrated by blocking the Malaba border (Teso North, Busia), against delays and alleged harassment by both customs and police officers. The group demanded to be involved as well as given able time before effecting any changes.
On 2 October 2018, around 2 000 workers from Karuturi Flower Farm demonstrated in Naivasha (Lake View, Naivasha, Nakuru) against Stanbic Bank failure in paying them their dues.
On 5 October 2018, dozens of local residents staged a protest in Kutus town, Kirinyaga demanding the arrest of Josephine Kabura for lying in NYS affidavit.
On 6 October 2018, students gathered at the University of Kabianga (Kericho county) to protest against the killing of a fellow student, who had been found with stab wounds earlier that day.

On 6 October 2018, protesters from Ruhjia sub-county, led by a local MP, demonstrated at the district headquarters of Rubanda county (Kabale) against the plan of building a secondary school in a neighbouring sub-county, a difficult place to access due to the geographical remoteness of the area.
07 October. Protesters took to the streets in Gambella to condemn the violence end September and call on the government to take action.
07 October. Residents of Lalibela held a peaceful demonstration urging the government to save ancient churches in the town.

On or around October 8th, around 1,000 protesters from Maji Moto bloked the Narok-Sikinani road, over a variety of disputes between the community and the Olarro Nature Conservancy, including the shooting of cattle and access to water sources. The Maasai community accused the conservancy of failing to constitute a proper management plan, to conduct elections of officials and a conservancy committee, and to review the land lease agreement.

On or before October 8th, residents of Siana ward protested following a dispute over grazing and access to water points with the Olarra Conservancy managing the game reserve. The protest took place at an unknown location (coordinates for Massai Mara Game Reserve used).

On 8 October 2018, 35 families of the late senior chief Wambugu Mathangani demonstrated by locking the gates leading to the Wambugu agricultural training centre in Nyeri (Nyeri Central, Nyeri), against the forceful acquisition of their land by the government. The group demanded the government to compensate them for the loss of their land.
On or before October 9th, the residents of Tunen in Trans Nzoia (approximate coordinates used closed to the border with Uasin) protested against land grabbing in the area.

9 October 2018: Clan militiamen gathered to stand and protest a man who lost his job with a private security company providing services to the UN in North Gaalkaco. Local authorities later came to resolve the issue.
9 October 2018: Residents of Wanla Weyne town protested the killing of a former Al-Shabaab member by military special forces. Protests were also held in Buur Weyne (coded separately).

9 October 2018: Police forces shot at demonstrators in the Burweyne village in Wanlaweyn district. Protesters were denouncing the killing of a well-known shiekh in the town by Somali security forces the day before. Two of the protesters were injured.
10 October. Several hundred soldiers marched on the prime minister's office to demand pay rises in Bete Mengist (East Shewa, Oromia). The PM met with them. Several arrested in the next days.
On 10 October 2018, students and workers of Dar es Salaam have blocked Rapid Bus Transport Road in the Business City to protest scarcity of buses.
On 11 October 2018, residents of Jumba Ruins in Mtwapa, Mombasa county held a protest in the locality over the alleged grabbing of a 127-acre land they claim to own.
On 11 October 2018, members of the disabled community of Kabale protested in Kabale town, drawing attention to the increasingly dilapated conditions of the rehabilitation centre of the town.

On 11 October 2018, hundreds of South Sudanese residents in Kenya and Kenyans protested in Nairobi against the political and military elite of South Sudan, and the alleged complicity of individuals and economic institutions in Kenya in the process of such accumulation.They called upon the Kenyan government to seize wealth and assets that South Sudanese elites had stored in the Kenyan banking system.
12 October. Residents of Agaro took to the streets calling for the removal of the City's officials. A person was killed when members of the Defence forces fired at the protesters.
12 October. Teachers in Takusa, Western Gonder staged protests due to disagreements with the local City Council over housing projects (Abyewalkaye).
12 October. Scores of people held a demonstration in Ambo against the abusing and insulting of mothers and women.

On 12 October 2018, students from the Mombasa branch of the University of Nairobi protested the killing of a UoN student and another man by a mob on 7 Oct. The student was lynched in an alleged case of mistaken identity.

On or before October 13th, around 2,000 market traders gathered in Jinja to protest their eviction from a UPDF-owned site in Mpumudde (Kimaka Division). An official at Kimaka Division claimed that the local authorities agreed a Memorandum of Understanding with the military dating back to 2001 for continued use of the site by the traders, which a UPDF spokesperson denied.
14 October. Protest held in Aysaita in Afar, opposing the regional government's abuse of power and calling for protest in 32 districts of Afar in the coming week.
On 14 October 2018, people from Baidoa staged a demonstration in support of the victims of the Al Shabaab suicide attack in the town the previous day.

On or before October 15th, students from a local technical college stormed the Hoima district headquarters in protest at the substandard facilities and inadequate teaching, calling for the Principal to be removed.

On 16 October 2018, police fired their weapons into the air to scatter a crowd of protesters in Kisiwani (Kilifi). This followed the arrest of 40 people (including a local politician) for invading an area of disputed land.

On 17 October 2018, students protested at the University of Machakos (Machakos), over a stipulation that they return to the University with their parents. The University closed indefinitely three weeks prior after student protests over an increase in fees. One person was arrested and later released.
17 October. The Afar special forces has attacked protesters in Afar region, Ethiopia (Aysaita). Protesters were demanding changes in governance and administrators of the region.

On 20 October 2018, Puntland security forces closed a road that links to the office of region's president in Garowe town of Nugaal region demanding for payment of their unpaid salaries for seven months.
20 October. Darawish security officers staged a demonstration because of non-payment of their salaries for two months.

On 21 October 2018, in Alamata town (Tigray), Tigray Regional State Special Force fired gunshots at Amhara activists protesting against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators. Tigray security forces killed 6 protestors and injured more than 20.

21 October. Local residents of Faxfaxdoon village staged a demonstration against AMISOM KDF contingent based in the village. Additional report indicated that locals denied the troops access to the water points located in the village.
On 22 October 2018, in Fiche town (North Shewa, Oromia), people staged a demonstration against the malfunction of the city administration.

On 22 October 2018, students protested at Kyambogo University (Kampala) over a decision by University management to increase a range of fees. Police used rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse the students.

On 22 October 2018, youth NRM supporters demonstrated in Lira over an apparent corruption case in the town. Police used teargas, and engaged in 'running battles' with the youth, dispersing the protest. 10 of the youth were arrested.
On or before October 22nd, teachers gathered in Mbita (Homa Bay) to protest the murder of a colleague on October 13th, and the failure of police to arrest any suspects.

23 October. A peaceful demonstration against the clan clash in Dhamay was organized by women in Lasanod. The demonstrators took to the streets and called the warring clans to have an immediate ceasefire and resolve issues in a peaceful manner.

On 23 October 2018, drivers associated with the company Taxify protested at the Taxify office in Kampala. The dispute relates to a system used to calculate passenger discounts and driver bonuses, which has resulted in a number of drivers being unable to access their accounts, as the company has accused them of fradulent activity.

On 24 October 2018, in Alamata town (Debubawi, Tigray), Amhara ethnic group activists continued to stage demonstrations against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.
On or before October 24th, demonstrators gathered in Machakos to protest against the poor condition of a road connecting Katangi to Matuu, and for the failure of local authorities to pave the road.

On or before October 24th, teachers gathered in Litein (Kericho) to protest the killing of a colleague in July, and specifically the lack of police response to the murder. The source mentions that the 'demonstration turned violent as police dispersed the teachers from the streets' (the demonstrators have been coded as protesters rather than rioters, since it is not specified whether they engaged in violent activity).

On 25 October 2018, in Alamata town (Debubawi, Tigray), Amhara ethnic group activists continued to stage demonstrations against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.

On 25 October 2018, in Kobo town (Semien Wollo, Ethiopia), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.
On 25 October 2018, in different parts of Afar region, people staged demonstrations protested against the failure of federal reforms to be brought down to the regional level (Semera, Afar).

On 25 October 2018, in Aweday woreda (East Hararghe, Oromia), people staged a demonstration demanding the release of several young men who were arrested last year. Security forces started shooting at the people.

On 25 October 2018, in Mohny town (North Wollo, Amhara), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.

On or before October 25th, residents from the Katimokor area of Chepchoina (Trans Nzoia) protested against the mining operations of a Chinese firm, and the role of local authorities in granting the company permission to mine the area. The source indicates that the company is embroiled in a pre-existing land dispute in the area.

On 26 October 2018, in Nekemt city (Oromia, Misraq Wellega), people staged demonstrations demanding attention of the government on the displacement of the Oromo people from on the border of Benishangul Gumuz region.

On 27 October 2018, in Nekemt city (Oromia, Misraq Wellega), people staged demonstrations demanding justice for attacks in Benishangul Gumuz State, asking the government take legal measures against forces who killed at least 50 people.
27 October. Demonstration in Adado over disagreement with the Constituent Assembly (particularly the president and Iskashiag newly elected MPs).

27 October. About 300 people protested against the conference of the Federal Member States held in Garowe on 23 October. The protesters chanted slogans against the agenda of the conference and pledged loyalty to the Federal Government.
27 October. A gathering of people from all parts of the community, as well as SSPF from Hudur town, staged a demonstration against the President of South West State.
On or around October 28, in Dallol woreda (Afar Zone 2, Afar), people staged protests against the local government demanding reforms and respect for human rights.
On or around October 28, in Erebti woreda (Afar Zone 2, Afar), people staged protests against the local government demanding reforms and respect for human rights.

On 28 October 2018, in Berahle town (Afar Zone 2, Afar), people staged protests against the local government demanding reforms and respect for human rights. People were lightly injured when security forces used tear gas and sticks to disperse demonstrators.

On 28 October 2018, in Semera town (Afar Zone 1, Afar), people staged protests against the local government demanding reforms and respect for human rights. People were lightly injured when security forces used tear gas and sticks to disperse demonstrators.
On 28 October 2018, in Bahir Dar town (Bahir Dar Special Zone, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.
On 28 October 2018, in Gonder town (Semen Gondar, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.
On 28 October 2018, in Debre Tabor town (Samara, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.
On 28 October 2018, in Dessie town (Debub Wollo, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.
On 28 October 2018, in Weldiya town (Semen Wello, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.
On 28 October 2018, in Debre Berhan town (North Shewa, Amhara), people staged protests demanding that a weed be removed from Tana Lake.

On 29 October 2018, in Kobo town (Semen Wello, Amhara), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.

On 30 October 2018, in Kobo town (Semen Wello, Amhara), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations for the second day against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.
On or before October 30th, approximately 100 teachers stormed an administrative office in Kitgum, to protest the non-payment of their salaries since July.
30 October. Residents of Bondhere district protested at Daljirka Dahsoon monument against the planned demolition of business kiosks in the district, disrupting transport. Police cleared the protest.

On 31 October 2018, in Kobo town (Semen Wello, Amhara), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations for the third day against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.
31 October. A group of construction laborers demonstrated peacefully against their employers over contracting foreigners. The demonstration took place in front of Sahil Governor Office.
On or before October 31st, approximately 100 students marched to Kakamega South police station (coordinates for Kakamega used), to protest the sexual assault at Bushianga Technical College.
During the week beginning October 29th, youth leaders in Bukomansimbi gathered to protest the arrest of around 20 youths, who had defaulted paying loans (coordinates for Bukomansimbi Town used).

On 1 November 2018, in Kobo town (Semen Wello, Amhara), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations for the fourth day against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.
On 1 November 2018, Clan militias who hail from Sa'ad sub-clan of Habargidir blocked the main road linking Galkayo and Adaado with stones demanding the release of Sa'ad Pirates in Garowe prison.

On 2 November 2018, in Kobo town (Semen Wello, Amhara), Amhara ethnic group activists staged demonstrations for the fifth day against the forceful takeover and remapping of their area boundaries by the Tigray region administrators.

On 2 November 2018, residents of Butere gathered at Butere (Kakamega) to protest against a spate of killings and mutilations which are said to be the work of a gang known as the Forty Two Brothers. The protesters accused the police of failing to tackle the gang.
03 November. Puntland military soldiers from Tukarak frontline briefly occupied the Garowe International Airport to protest unpaid salaries for several months.
Assumed on November 6, in Nekemt city (Misraq Wellega, Oromia), police fired on protestors, killing three activists.
On 6 November 2018, in Ambo town (Mirab Shewa, Oromia), people staged a protest demanding that the government take action on an armed group that has been killing and displacing people.

Around 6 November 2018 (as reported), residents of Kamasian (Kericho, coordinates for Kabirer used) blocked (means unspecified) the main road to protest against the presence of boulders, which the contracting company responsible for improving the road had not removed, and which are a potential danger to motorists. The demonstration was joined by a local politician.
On 7 November 2018, in Dessie city (Debub Wollo, Amhara), several people staged a protest demanding that suspected killer of a young girl be killed following the girl's death.
On 7 November 2018, in Afar region (Semera), several people staged a protest demanding reforms over an unknown issue.
On 10 November 2018, in Awash town (Afar Zone 3, Afar), people staged a protest demanding to reform Chinese foreign investment into the country.
On 10 November 2018, in Abala town in Abala woreda (Afar Zone 2, Afar), people staged a protest demanding to reform Chinese foreign investment into the country.
On or after November 11th, demonstrators gathered in Kusauni and Nyali (Mobassa), to protest a spate of killings by a new gang in the area.
On or after November 11th, demonstrators gathered in Kusauni and Nyali (Mobassa), to protest a spate of killings by a new gang in the area.

11 November. Residents of Garbaharrey town staged a demonstration against the visit of Jubaland State President. The cause is the tensions between the Jubbaland state and the Federal Government of Somalia.
12 November. About 100 people demonstrated against the arrest and demanding release of 'Abdirisak Hussein Tahliil' in South Galkayo, accused of having links with AS.

On 14 November 2018, police fired bullets and tear gas at youth in Kawempe (Kampala), to break apart an allegedly unauthorised meeting regarding missing money which had been promised by the government to the youth. According to the source, police 'violently arrested' a number of youth, but the police vehicle carrying the arrested crashed, and the arrested were released with the help of other youth. The source does not indicate that the youth were behaving violently.
15 November. Community members held a peaceful demo in Berdale district protesting FGS' intervention in the upcoming South West State presidential elections.

On 16 November 2018, workers from the water board at a location in Lyantonde stormed the headquarters of the board, to protest delays in the payment of their salaries, and against poor working conditions.

On 16 November 2018, boda boda (motorcycle) drivers in Isiolo town blocked roads (means unspecified) in protest against what they regarded as unfair targetting by police officers with respect to traffic law. Police fired teargas at the demonstrators.
16 November. Community members and supporters of Muqtar Robow held a peaceful demo in Hudur town protesting FGS' intervention in the upcoming South West State presidential elections.
17 November. Taxi drivers in Hargeisa held a demonstration against a recent travel ban by the Somaliland Ministry of Transport on the use of Toyota Vitz as taxis. Arrests reported.

On 17 November 2018, residents protested against the newly appointed District Commissioner during his arrival in Bardera (Bardheere, Gedo). The police escorting the Commissioner shot at the protesters, injuring four.

On or before November 19th, protesters gathered in Ayur-Alali (Kitgum, coordinates for Kal sub-county used) to protest the process surrounding the establishment of a sugar cane farm in the area, and alleged abuses by Ugandan security forces guarding the site.

On 19 November 2018, protesters - including politicians and businesspeople - gathered in Gulu town (Gulu district) following repeated power blackouts in the town and its environs. The protest was dispersed by police and UPDF soldiers, who fired tear gas and possibly live ammunition at the protesters. At least one person was injured, and at least three were arrested.

On 19 November 2018, in Addis Ababa city (Addis Ababa, Addis Ababa), hundreds of Ethiopian Jews staged a demonstration to protest the Israeli government's decision not to allow all of them to emigrate to Israel, leaving their families divided between the two countries.

On 21 November 2018, hundreds of farmers protested in Kitale town (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) in support of members of parliament championing for new maize prices. The group demanded the government to buy each 90kg bag of maize at Kenya shillings 3600.
21 November. Construction labourers demonstrated peacefully in front of the Office of the Governor of Sahil region against construction companies who employed foreign workers instead of the locals.

Around 22 November 2018 (as reported), a section of parents protested by carrying twigs and singing in St. Jude Luyekhe primary school (Kanduyi, Bungoma), against poor performance of the school. The parents demanded the headteacher to be transferred.
On 22 November 2018, women demonstrated in Wamba (Wamba East, Samburu East, Samburu) against the county government for alleged gender discrimination in the Kenya Defense Forces recruitment process.

On 22 November 2018, SNA soldiers blocked Buundaweyne South bridge and Liiqliiqato bridge disrupting movements of all vehicles in and out of Belet Weyne town over delay in payment of salaries. SNA commanders intervened.

24 November 2018: People in Himora town, Tigray region protested in support of a press release by Tigray regional president against PM Abiy and against identity issues raised by minorities in the Wolkait and Alamata areas.

24 November 2018: People in Adwa town, Tigray region protested in support of a press release by Tigray regional president against PM Abiy and against identity issues raised b minorities in the Wolkait and Alamata areas.

24 November 2018: People of Alamata town, Tigray region protested in support of a press release by the Tigray regional president. The press release accuses the prime minister Abiy for targeting only Tigrayans when arresting corruption suspects.

On 26 November 2018, motorbike taxi drivers blocked a road (unspecified means) and attempted to remove a police block in the area of Kiguchwa (Isiolo), to demonstrate against a concerted effort by police to improve safety standards. The demonstrators were joined by a local MP, who was later arrested.
27 November 2018: Ambo University students protested against some individuals seeking to cause conflict among students from different tribes.

27 November. SLP arrested an unspecified number of taxi drivers of specific saloon vehicles in Hargeisa after a peaceful demonstration against the banning of specific saloon vehicle taxis from transporting passengers and goods outside of Hargeisa.

On 27 November 2018, the Premier of Buganda - Charles Peter Mayiga - embarked on a visit to Masaka under heavy security, in a trip which had been delayed due to disputes over protocol. Protesters were reported to have taken place at or near Masaka by Kooki royalists, who were angered by the visit of the Premier. According to the source, the road was blocked by the demonstrators.

On 27 November 2018, about 200 Moi University students demonstrated in Eldoret (Kimumu, Moiben, Uasin Gishu) over missing marks and exclusion from the December graduation list. They blocked (means unspecified) Eldoret-Nakuru highway for at least three hours. Police officers fired live bullets to disperse the students. No details on the injuries.
28 November 2018: People protested against the displacement and killing of Oromo people by gunmen from Benishangul Gumuz (Nekemt, Oromia).
29 November 2018: People in Nekemt town, east welega zone protested for the second day against the displacement and killing of Oromo people by gunmen from Benishangul Gumuz.
29 November 2018: In East Welega zone, Sasiga woreda high school students protested against the displacement and killing of Oromo people by gunmen from Benishangul Gumuz.
29 November 2018: In East welega zone, Haro Limu woreda (Soghidda, Oromia) people protested the displacement and killing of Oromo people by gunmen from Benishangul Gumuz.
29 November 2018: In Horo Guduru Welega zone, Shambu town, people protested against the displacement and killing of Oromo people by gunmen from Benishangul Gumuz.

On 29 November 2018, over 300 people protested in Kambe Bondora near Mbungoni (Rabai, Kilifi), against an impending demolition of a mosque, following a land tussle. Joined by human rights activists, the group demanded the two families, fighting over the land, not interfere with the mosque.
On 29 November 2018, around 500 traders protested in Taveta (Taita Taveta) against the imposition of significantly higher taxes on produce in the county. The traders marched to the county offices.

On 29 November 2018, protesters stormed the police post at Madi-Opei (Kitgum), following an incident earlier in the day where a mother of a suspect had been shot by police. The police had already vacated the station, anticipating a demonstration.
29 November. Local residents of Garbahaarey town staged a peaceful demonstration. It was said to be related to the political differences between Jubbaland state and FGS.

On 30 November 2018, demonstrators gathered at the High Court in Fort Portal (Kabarole) to protest unpaid compensation by the Ugandan National Roads Authority, for the destruction of property and acquisition of land during the construction of a road nine years ago. The source says that over 600 residents were affected by the road, but does not specify how many attended the protest.
01 December 2018: In Illubabor zone, Metu woreda, Metu town, people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.

01 December 2018: In East Welega zone, Guto Gida woreda, in a town called Uke-Kersa, which is 32 KM from Nekemte City (Oromia), people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.

01 December. The mayor of Dar es Salaam led a demonstration in the city to launch a borehole. Later on police arrested the mayor for trying to take political gains (coded in a separate event). The project was inititiated by the government.
02 December 2018: people in Addis Ababa city demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.

03 December 2018: In Kelem Welega zone, Anfilo woreda, Mugi town, Military forces fired at protesters, injuring several. They were demonstrating against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.
03 December 2018: In Mirab shewa zone, Bako town people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.

03 December 2018: In Debub Mirab Shewa zone, Waliso woreda, waliso town people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz. They also chanted ' Oromia police should be well armed'.
03 December 2018: In jimma special zone, Jima city people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.

03 December 2018: In Bale zone, Bale woreda, Bale Robe town people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz. They also chanted that 'Oromia police should be well armed'.
03 December 2018: in west Hararge zone, chiro town people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.

03 December 2018: In west shewa zone, Ambo town, people from Ambo city and towns around Ambo demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz. They also chanted ' Oromia police should be well armed'.
03 December 2018: In Oromia-Finfine zone, Dukem town, which is about 33 KM from Addis Ababa, People demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.

03 December 2018: In Oromia special zone surrounding Addis Ababa, Holeta Genet town people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz. They also chanted 'Stop evicting Oromo Farmers' which was meant to refer to Addis Ababa city expansion.
04 December 2018: In east Hararge zone, haramaya (Alemaya) town people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.
04 December 2018: In Burayu town, which is just outside of Addis Ababa city, people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.
04 December 2018: In East Welega zone, Nekemte town (Oromia) security forces fired at protesters and injured some of them.
04 December 2018: In west Hararge zone, Daro Labu woreda, Mechara town people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.

04 December 2018: In Oromia-Finfine zone, Sebeta town people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz. They also asked that evicted Oromo farmers be taken care of.

04 December 2018: In west welega zone, Gimbi town people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz. They were also chanting ' Oromia police should be well armed'.
04 December 2018: In East Shewa zone, Guder town people staged demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.
04 December 2018: In west Hararge zone, Masalaha town people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.
04 December 2018: In west Welega zone (Dabbaso, Oromia), Nole kaba woreda people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.

On 4 December 2018, protesters from Kahengye village entered the offices of the Resident District Commission at Rukungiri, demanding compensation for delayed compensation payments for damages to property and crops which resulted from a government and World Bank-backed water project.

On 5 December 2018, residents took to the streets in Wamba (Wamba East, Samburu East, Samburu) calling on government to end bhang and other drug businesses in town. Religious leader Stephen Larmoko and Maendeleo ya Wanawake chairperson Rosal Lororwa participated in the demonstration.

At some time between December 3rd and 5th, protesters from Rukondwa entered the offices of the district council speaker for Masindi. The demonstrators were aggreived at the lack of quality roads serving their parish, which had limited their access to essential services, and compelled them to sell their goods to middlemen at a reduced price.
06 December 2018: In kelem welega zone, Dembi Dolo town, Ethiopian security forces killed two protesters and wounded others.
06 December 2018: In Adama (Nazreth) city people demonstrated against the killing of Oromo people by armed men from Benishangul Gumuz.
08 December 2018: In Tigray region, Mekele city, people demonstrated against lack of respect for their investment in the country.

10 December. Hundreds of demonstrators gathered in Bondhere district protesting the impeachment motion against the president. The demonstrators briefly closed the road and caused disruption of public transport.

10 December. Anti-president Farmaajo protest erupt calling for end to his tenure for treason in Mogadishu. Protesters ripping up president pictures shouting 'Somalia belongs to Somalis' and 'No to Treason'.
On or around December 11th, taxi drivers demonstrated in Rukungiri, over the company awarded a tender.

On 11 December 2018, LGBT refugees protested against homophobic attacks in the Kakuma Refugee camp (Turkana West, Turkana). The protesters were then beaten with sticks and iron bars (wounding 20), by both Kenyan citizens as well as fellow refugees (note that the nationality of the refugees is not provided; accordingly no associate actors are coded as IDPs/Refugees). The UNHCR has begun the process of permanently relocating LGBT refugees from the camp to Nairobi.

On 11 December 2018, a group of locals and refugees in Kakuma Refugee Camp (Turkana West, Turkana) beat up refugees accused of being gay with wooden sticks and iron bars when they were protesting outside the UNHCR office against rising homophobic attacks in recent months. About 20 refugees were injured.

12 December. A number of health stakeholders protested peacefully in Dar es Salaam to raise awareness for people who have no access to health services due to economic hardships. Protest took place as part of the Universal Health Coverage Day
13 December: In Borana zone, Moyale town, people held a demonstration asking the Government to stop Liyu police and other armed groups from attacking innocent people.

13 December. Protests held in Baidoa after Ethiopian forces arrested former Al Shabab deputy leader Mukhtar Robow and presidential candidate of South West Regional State in raid. Protests continued over the next two days. 200 arrested by police.
14 December: In Borana zone, Arero woreda people held demonstration asking the Government to stop Liyu police and other armed groups from killing innocent people.
14 December: In Borana zone, Moyale town people held demonstration for the second day asking the Government to stop Liyu police and other armed groups from killing innocent people.
14 December: In Borana zone, Teltele woreda people held demonstration asking the Government to stop Liyu police and other armed groups from killing innocent people.
14 December: In Guji zone, Nagele Borana woreda, Negele Borana town people held demonstration asking the Government to stop Liyu police and other armed groups from killing innocent people.
18 December: In Kayole, residents protested against the demolition of Nyama Villa estate.
19 December: In Borana zone, Dire woreda, Mega town people held demonstration asking the federal Government to bring permanent solution to the border conflict.
On 19 December 2018, residents of Katabi (Wakiso) protested at Garuga police station, against a police round-up of fisherman earlier that day, accusing police of engaging in arbitrary arrests.
19 December: Kayole residents protested for the second day as Nyama villa estate demolitions continued. Tens of families left homeless
20 December: In Amhara region, Bahir Dar city people held demonstration asking the woreda administrators to be removed from their places.
24 December: Hundreds of state owned commercial housing tenants protested against the recent steep rental fee increase in Addis Ababa.

On or before December 25th, fishers protested at Rock Landing site in Jinja municipality in Jinja against the failure of police to arrest a trades group who they allege is responsible for murdering their colleagues.
25 December. Residents of government-owned houses in Berbera peacefully demonstrated against a decision made by the Ministry of Housing for them to pay rent to the government.
26 December. An anti-al-Shabab protest was held in Burdhubo District, Gedo Region. The protesters expressed concern over a move by al-Shabab to set fire on residential houses.

On 27 December 2018, people in Bungoma (Kanduyi, Bungoma) protested against police brutality following the death of a man in custody of police officials. Police responded with live fire, injuring two.
On December 26th or 27th, police dispersed protesters demonstrating in support of Bobi Wine (who was prevented from performing a concert by the police on Dec 26th) in the Kamwokya suburb of Kampala.
27 December: In Kibera town, people demonstrated demanding justice for a student killed by a police officer. Police dispersed the protesters
30 December: In Debub Gonder zone, Wereta woreda people held a demonstration against the woreda administration malfunction.

On 31 December 2018, about 40 people protested along the main streets in Garowe against the perceived intervention of Federal Government of Somalia in the upcoming presidential elections in Puntland. The demonstrators were dispersed peacefully.
On 1 January 2019, residents demonstrated in Kendu Bay (Karachuonyo, Homa Bay) against a project that will harvest massive sand from the shores of the Lake Victoria.
01 January. Civilians in Baidoa protested in support of UN against the government following government decree against UNSRSG Haysom.

02 January (on or around): In Tigray region, Zela Ambesa residents blocked a convoy of soldiers withdrawing from the Zalambessa front. Ethiopian and Eritrean soldiers are withdrawing from border areas after a peace agreement improved relations between the two countries. Residents are asking for the trucks and weapons to stay in the area.
On 3 January 2019, residents demonstrated against abusive fares of the Matatu private minibus in Homa Bay town (Homa Bay, Homa Bay).
03 January. Civilian residents in Garbahaarey protested against the Jubaland Administration.

On 4 January 2019, local residents staged a demonstration against the Vice President of Jubbaland in Garbahaarey town who was visiting in the locality. The demonstrators entered Vice President's accommodation, but he was not in the building at the time of the incident. The protesters supported the Federal Government of Somalia.
On 5 January 2019, water vendors in Kajiado (Kajiado Central, Kajiado) protested against the new directive by the county administration to desalinate all salty water.
On 1 May 2019, on the occasion of International Workers' Day, a march was held in Arusha demanding a salary increase.
01 May. Residents held a peaceful protest in Borama protesting the killing of officers and demanding the government arrest the suspects. .
05 January. Supporters of Dr. Ali Isse who is running for President of Puntland held a rally in Las Anod to show their support.
On 5 January 2019, residents demonstrated over poor state road condition in Kahawa (Roysambu, Nairobi).
07 January: Ogaden National Liberation Front's supporters held demonstration in Jigjiga city, Ethiopian Somali region, in support of ONLF.

08 January: In Tigray region, Shire town, residents blocked a convoy of soldiers withdrawing from the Shire front. Ethiopian and Eritrean soldiers are withdrawing from border areas after a peace agreement improved relations between the two countries. Residents are asking for the trucks and weapons to stay in the area.
08 January: In Tigray region, Humera town people demonstrated against the ADP Chairman, Gedu Andergachew.
08 January: In Afar region , Argobba special woreda residents demonstrated against the Argobba people's Democratic Party.
Around 8 January 2019 (as reported), parents protested in Ndiruni primary school in Mwonge (Chuka, Tharaka-Nithi) against poor management. The parents demanded the headteacher be transfered.

08 January (on or around): In Amhara region, Metema town, Military forces shot and killed 8 demonstrators protesting on the road to block the way to construction company vehicles claiming that the vehicels had been transporting and supporting Qemant militias in the fight between Qemant and Amhara.

09 January: In Usasin Gisha county, millers in Eldoret city protested against the order to vacate NCPB (National Cereals and Produce Board) store. They had been using the store for 18 years prior to the order

09 January: In Makeuni county, Wote residents protested against the death of a 16 year old kid, claiming that he was bewitched by a woman. Protesters demanded the woman to ressurect the kid but they were dispersed by police.
09 January: In Amhara region, Metema town residents demonstrated against military action on the youth on the 8th of January.

On 10 January 2019, around 1,000 protesters from Bugonga village descended upon the office of the deputy Regional District Commissioner in Entebbe (Wakiso district), to protest against their contraversial eviction.
11 January: In Amhara region, Gonder town residents held a demonstration following the death of two civilians.
12 January: Narok residents held a demonstration against the authorities over increasing road accidents
13 January. Tuk-tuk drivers in Garowe staged a protest in the town centre over a tax increase that will impact their livelihoods.

14 January: Youths in Afara region blocked roads to demonstrate against the removal of the Afar regional police from areas of the region where there have been clashes between Afar and Somale Isa ethnic group.
On 14 January 2019, sugar cane farmers protested in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the the lack of representation in new sugar task force.

16 January: In Ethiopian Somali region, Sitti zone youths held demonstrations following the attack on Somali Isa ethnic group living in Afar region. The road connecting Dire Dawa to Djibouti was closed because of the demonstrations.

On 16 January 2019, around 200 protesters demonstrated in Sumbwe village (Mukono, coordinates for Mpunge used), following the non-payment of compensation for property lost as a result of the construction of a new water treatment plant.
21 January: Eldoret farmers protested over NCPB (National Cereals and Produce Board) failure to buy maize from them even though president Uhuru had ordered them to buy

On 22 January 2019, residents of Orom and Akurumo sub-counties in Kitgum protested against the arrival of pastoralists from Karamoja (location unclear; coordinates for Orom, Kitgum district, used). The protesters allege that the herders damage local ecosystems, and accuse the Karamojong of being behind thefts.

On 22 January 2019, demonstrators gathered on the Gulu-Kampala highway in or around Koro (Omoro district), following a series of traffic accidents that have resulted in several deaths. The protesters temporarily blocked (means unspecified) the road with stones.
22 January: In Nariobi, Kenya, University students held demonstration over increased extrajudicial killings of students by police.
23 January: In Kajiado sub-county, Nkatataek mixed secondary school students' parents protested against the school's adminstration
24 January: In SNNP region, Keffa zone people held demonstrations over the lack of Government's attention toward the Kambata farmers who were displaced and killed.

On or before January 28th, police prevented a march from protesters to the State House in Entebbe, arresting five. The protesters were attempting to stop their eviction from Namiiro wetlands (close to Entebbe Airport, Wakiso, coordinates used).

On 28 January 2019, street children protested their living conditions in front of the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs in Hargeysa city (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed). 28 children were arrested by the Police.

On 29 January 2019, a section of the Kenya civil aviation workers protested by singing solidarity song and waving placards at the Jomo Kenyatta international airport (JKIA) (Embakasi East, Nairobi), against the proposed takeover of the JKIA by Kenya Airways. The group demanded to be involved in the talks leading to the takeover .
On Jan 30th residents of Gitaru blocked the Gitaru-Wangige road, attempting to prevent Forest Service officers from seizing logs that they had cut from their farms.
On 30 January 2019, primary school teachers staged a protest over unpaid allowances in front of the Presidential mansion in in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed).
On Feb 1st 2019, residents of Eldoret protested against the accidental release of three men suspected to have killed a boda boda driver.
01 February: Eldoret residents protested against the killing of civilians by police officers.
01 February: Taita Taveta county nurses protested over poor medical equipmrnt and understaffing in public health centers
02 February: Residents around Kitale-Eldoret highway protested against land grabbing

On Feb 4th, five local MPs mobilised demonstrators in Gulu town (Gulu district), to protest the failure of the government to resolve violence associated with the Apaa land dispute. Police intervened immediately, and arrested the politicians in addition to a number of activists and youth.
05 February: Several merchants demonstrated over the closure of their store by city administration.

On 6 February 2019, boda boda and taxi drivers, together with members of the business community, blocked the Hoima-Fort Portal road using rocks, bricks and logs (coordinates for Hoima, Hoima district, used at precision 2). The protesters accused the Chinese company responsible for building the road of not taking sufficient action to prevent large amounts of dust from affecting residents of the area.

On Feb 8th, residents of Buhanika sub-county (who had been recently evicted as part of a land dispute) went to the residence of the MP for Bugahya (coordinates for Buhanika sub-county, Hoima, used at precision 2), and are now camping in his compound. The residents say that are left without the means of survival now they have been forcibly evicted.

On 8 February 2019, Ngara's Nyayo market traders demonstrated by marching and submitting a petition to the district commissioner's office in Kariokor (Starehe, Nairobi), against land grabbing of a section of the market's land. The traders demanded their political leaders to address the matter.

10 February. Water tanker drivers held a peaceful demonstration against the Wajale local authority and Ministry of water resources saying private water well owners denied them access to collect water.
12 February: Nairobi workers held a demonstration over the country's failure to increase their salary by 15%.
13 February. Local people staged a demonstration against the selection process of a district commissioner in Baardheere town.

On Feb 14th, demonstrators (including taxi and boda boda drivers) blocked the Hoima-Fort Portal road at Hoima (Hoima district) using logs and rocks, in protest against continued dust in the area resulting from road works. Police and soldiers dispersed the protesters (seemingly with gunfire), and arrested 30.
15 February. Residents of Ahmed-gurey demonstrated demanding the release of Sheikh Adan Sunaa. Police dispersed the protesters.
On Feb 18th, parents stormed a school in Jinja to protest the poor quality of the school buildings. Police arrived at the scene and tried to calm the protesters.
20 February: Litein residents protested over the rising insecurity. They expressed feelings of insecurity and their loss of trust in Kenyan police to protect them from the gangs

On Feb 20th, police dispersed Democratic Party protesters who had stormed the Central Police station at Jinja, using tear gas. When protesters reassembled and attempted to march through the town, police once again dispersed the protesters through 'caning' them. A local journalist covering events was also injured.
21 February: Hawasa city residents and people from around Hawasa held demonstration demanding regional self adminstration.

On or around Feb 21st, Ugandan truck drivers staged a protest in Elegu (Amuru district) at the Uganda-South Sudan border, following the killing of a colleague in Rumbek on Feb 20th, and refused to enter South Sudan given insecurity. The drivers demanded his body be repatriated, which appears to have happened on Feb 23rd.
22 February: Migori residents protested over the rising insecurity and the inability of Kenyan police to tackle criminality in Kenya
23 February. There was a peaceful protest by students of Haji Adan Secondary School, who protested because their Deputy Principal was leaving.
24 February: Trans Nzoia farmers held demonstration over the delays in purchase of their products by National Cereals and Produce Board due to lack of bags for storage
24 February. A peaceful demonstration was held by IDP residents in Beleteweyne against mismanagement of emergency food aid.
26 February. Following the rape of a 12 year old girl, the second one in a month, women have protested in Galkayoo.

Around 26 February 2019, residents protested the lack of funding for a local clinic between Kalabaydh and Gebiley towns (Gebiley, Woqooyi Galbeed). Protesters blocked the road linking the two towns. Somaliland police forces intervened and arrested scores of the protesters.

On or before Feb 27th, boda boda (motorcycle taxi) drivers stormed the courthouse at Bugiri town (Bugiri county), to demand that a merchant they accused of defrauding them faces justice, and refunds them money.
On or before Feb 27th, youth stormed municipal offices in Kitgum (Kitgum district), in protest at the non-payment of youth livelihood stipends. Authorities have acknowledged the problem.

27 February: Ethiopian police beat and injured protesters in Wolayita Sodo town. The protesters were protesting against the demolition of their houses. The city administration says that the houses were built without permission.
01 March: Bungoma High school students protested against school principal.

On 6 March 2019, a small protest took place in Kampala, by a group of people concerned at the apparent disapearnece of a street vendor arrested by police on February 12th. Police arrested four of the protesters, and denied that they are still detaining the previously arrested man.

On 6 March 2019, Kenya aviation workers union (KAWU) demonstrated by waving placards in Jomo Kenyatta International Airport (Embakasi, Nairobi), in demonstration against poor management of Kenya Airways (KQ). Police lobbed teargas canisters to disperse them. Six KQ staff members were injured.

07 March: Hundreds of people in Shashamane city protested after the Addis Ababa City Administration Savings & Houses Development Enterprise (AASHDE) handed over thousands of condominium houses located both in the city, and in Oromia regional state special zone. The protesters demanded that the condominium houses built in Oromia region should be given to displaced Oromo farmers.

07 March: Hundreds of people in Asela city protested after the Addis Ababa City Administration Savings & Houses Development Enterprise (AASHDE) handed over thousands of condominium houses located both in the city, and in Oromia regional state special zone. The protesters demanded that the condominium houses built in Oromia region should be given to displaced Oromo farmers.

07 March: Hundreds of people in Jima city protested after the Addis Ababa City Administration Savings & Houses Development Enterprise (AASHDE) handed over thousands of condominium houses located both in the city, and in Oromia regional state special zone. The protesters demanded that the condominium houses built in Oromia region should be given to displaced Oromo farmers.

07 March: Hundreds of people in Robe town, Bale woreda protested after the Addis Ababa City Administration Savings & Houses Development Enterprise (AASHDE) handed over thousands of condominium houses located both in the city, and in Oromia regional state special zone. The protesters demanded that the condominium houses built in Oromia region should be given to displaced Oromo farmers.

07 March: Hundreds of people in Arsi zone, Adaba town protested after the Addis Ababa City Administration Savings & Houses Development Enterprise (AASHDE) handed over thousands of condominium houses located both in the city, and in Oromia regional state special zone. The protesters demanded that the condominium houses built in Oromia region should be given to displaced Oromo farmers.

07 March: Hundreds of people in Oromia-Finfine zone, Holeta protested after the Addis Ababa City Administration Savings & Houses Development Enterprise (AASHDE) handed over thousands of condominium houses located both in the city, and in Oromia regional state special zone. The protesters demanded that the condominium houses built in Oromia region should be given to displaced Oromo farmers.

07 March: Hundreds of people in East Hararghe zone, Aweday town protested after the Addis Ababa City Administration Savings & Houses Development Enterprise (AASHDE) handed over thousands of condominium houses located both in the city, and in Oromia regional state special zone. The protesters demanded that the condominium houses built in Oromia region should be given to displaced Oromo farmers.

07 March: Hundreds of people in Nazreth (Adama) city protetested after the Addis Ababa City Administration Savings & Houses Development Enterprise (AASHDE) handed over thousands of condominium houses located both in the city, and in Oromia regional state special zone. The protesters demanded that the condominium houses built in Oromia region be given to displaced Oromo farmers.
07 March. A peaceful protest was held in Bosaso against the closure of the fish market located at the Bossaso Port.

08 March: Sidama people in Wendo Genet protested against the regional government leaders for delaying their refrundum request. They took down regional flag and put up the flag they said it represents Sidama people.

08 March: Sidama people in Hawasa protested against the regional government leaders for delaying the refrundum request. They took down regional flag and put up the flag they said it represents Sidama people.

On 8 March 2019, a section of parents demonstrated by carrying twigs as they marched to Ilmarba primary school (Kajiado Central, Kajiado), against poor management. The parents demanded the headteacher to be transferred.
08 March: Mombasa Women protested over the inequality of women and Men in Kenya.

On 10 March 2019, South Sudanese students studying at Nkumba University (Luamtundwe, Wakiso district) protested at the death of a colleague on the highway close to the University. They were subsequently joined by other students from the University, and prevented traffic from moving on the road. Police dispersed the protesters.
11 March: In South Gonder zone, people protested over lack of clean water.
On 11 March 2019, NHC project workers in Nygeri gathered at the site to protest over delayed payments and to demand improved working conditions.
11 March: In Hawasa city, Awassa undustrial park workers protested demanding salary raises.

On 12 March 2019, residents of Kaprelachkorol village (coded as Kapenguria with GP2 for unfound location) demonstrated against the Kapenguria-Makutano Sewage Treatment Plant, aimed at improving sanitation, accusing the provincial administration of implementing the project against their will.

Around 12 March 2019, (exact date not clear), transport workers held a peaceful demonstration in Nairobi, claiming that they had not been involved in the process of implementating the Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) system.

On 13 March 2019, protesters from Rupa village potested in the District HQ at Moroto (Moroto district), over unpaid compensation following the sale of their land to a mining company. A local politician has disputed their claims, saying those who were owed money have been paid.
13 March. Due to non-payment of salary, SNA soldiers peacefully demonstrated on the Main Street in Dayniile district.
On Mar 15th 2019, following episodes of criminal violence, protesters marched in Garissa to ask for peace. Residents committees and women took part in the march.

Around 15 March 2019 (as reported), boda boda taxi operators protested in Ruiru (Ruiru, Kiambu), against increase of insecurity in the area, following the killing of their colleague. Joined by their member of parliament (MP), the group demanded the police to bring to book killers of their colleague as well as enhance security surveillance.

On 16 March 2019, at least five people seriously injured by the police in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) as the latter tried to disperse several demonstrators who were protesting over the killing of a school teacher by the police.
18 March: Members of Ekeza Sacco held demonstration over the misuse of funds by Sacco officials. Police used tear gas to disperse the protesters.
On Mar 19th 2019, women from Plot 11 village in Kanjuiri protested over the poor condition of Njigaga road, calling for Nyandarua government to repair it.

On 19 March 2019, in Kaptoroi village, residents armed with crude weapons stormed the church of the Repentance and Holiness Ministry, accusnig the self-proclaimed Prophet Owuor, who runs the church, of radicalization and separation of families who didn't attend the same church. They forced the worshipers present to flea the premises.

Around 19 March 2019 (as reported), students protested by carrying twigs and singing, while marching at the Sango Salvation Army school near Kimilili (Kimilili, Bungoma), against land grabbing of the school land. Joined by the chairman of the school board, the group demanded the governor to help address the matter.
On 22 March 2019, taxi drivers protested the reinstatement of fees by authorities in Entebbe (Wakiso). Police dispersed the demonstrators with tear gas, and made three arrests.
22-23 March: Kibabi University students held demonstration after one of the students was injured by a car inside the school. Police used tear gas to disperse the protesters.
On 23 March 2019, in Marigat, farmers held a peaceful demonstration over the decision of Boresha Sacco to withhold Sh22 million to repay outstanding loans.
22-23 March: Kibabi University students held demonstration after one of the students was injured by a car inside the school. Police used tear gas to disperse the protesters.
On Mar 25th 2019, Githuri residents protested over poor condition of a road severely damaged by heavy rains.
26 March: Nairobi residents held demonstration over the slow pace of the road construction.
28 March. A peaceful protest was held by a group of internally displaced people demonstrated against the Mayor of Hargeisa in Hargeisa for not providing them land to settle.

On 28 March 2019, United States International University (USIU) -Africa students, mostly from the bachelor of pharmacy course demonstrated by carrying placards along the USIU road [coded as Kasarani, Kasarani, Nairobi], against the varsity's grading system. The students demanded a fair grading system.

On or before March 29th, residents of Kirundo and Nyamwishenya sub-counties protested in Kisoro District Council (Kisoro district), storming the building to demand the creation of a new constituency for their areas. The protesters accused local politicians of failing to do so, despite assurances from President Museveni that a new constituency may be established. Police dispersed the demonstrators, removing them from the building.
30 March: Matatu (14 seats taxi) operators held demonstration over the closing of their new stage by the county administration under unclear circumstances.
01 April. Rickshaw drivers held a protest after a municipal tax collector shot and killed one of their colleagues over a tax issue in Waberi district (coded separately).
02 April: In SNNP region, Silte zone, near Worabe (Silti, Southern Nations), hundreds of people held a demonstration over the lack of quality infrastructures.

On 3 April 2019, university students demonstrated at Kirinyaga University campus in Kerugoya (Kirinyaga Central, Kirinyaga), after the death of a student the same day who was stabbed by unknown individuals. Students complained about insecurity in the area.

On 3 April 2019, riot police and soldiers fired tear gas and water cannons at merchants protesting their eviction from several commercial buildings in Kampala. The traders say that they have already paid their rent to the deceased owner of the buildings they operate in, and that the new owners have been harassing them to pay this rent.

On 4 May 2019, demonstrators gathered in Gulu town (Gulu district), after police had abandoned a body outside Gulu hospital the previous day, demanding that the body be properly buried. The demonstrators threatened a local health official as well as police. Police arrived to retrieve the body with the use of detained suspects.
06 April: In Afar region, Gewane, hundreds of youths held a demonstration demanding the arrest of the soldier who killed a civilian days earlier.
06 April. Soldiers of the Somali military forces gathered and held a peaceful demonstration in Xudur in protest of payment issues .
On 8 April 2019, traders demonstrated at Nalule Arcade in Kampala, following a considerable rent increase. Police intervened, and made a number of arrests.
09 April: In Hawasa city, thousands of Sidama women demonstrated over the delayed Sidama regional referendum (over Sidama becoming a region).

On 9 April 2019, Moi university students blocked roads and marched to Eldoret central police station (Moiben , Uasin Gishu), against the hacking to death of their colleague by her alleged former lover. The students demanded to be addressed over the incident.
09 April. A group of disabled Somali military soldiers gathered peacefully at the entrance gate to Villa Somalia in Hamarweyne District to protest not being paid for more than four months.

Around 9 April 2019 (as reported), students from Nakyenyi secondary school (Lwengo district) protested against the lack of clean drinking water at the school, after three days of shortages. The headteacher fled the school; police have been deployed to prevent damage to school property.
10 Apri: In Illubabor zone, Metu town, Oromo people held demonstration over the attack on Oromo people in Amhara region.
10 April: In West Hararghe zone, Chiro town, Oromo people demonstrated over the attack on Oromo people in Amhara region.
11 April. Peaceful demonstration held in Garowe calling for justice and protection of the families of women who were victims of sexual violence.
14 April. Local population staged a peaceful demonstration against the local authority in Bardheere town about the lack of collaboration between the local administration members.

On 15 April 2019, local residents protested by carrying twigs and banners, as they marched to the offices of the county governor and county commissioner in Homa Bay (Homa Bay Town, Homa Bay), against over delayed compensation for the land taken by the Kenya airports authority for the expansion of Kabunde Airstrip. The group demanded the compensation of their land.
16 April: In South west Shewa zone, Waliso town people held demonstration after OLF soldiers in the military training camp were reported to have been poisoned.
16 April: In West Hararghe zone, Chiro town people held demonstration after OLF soldiers in the training camp were reported to have been poisoned.
16 April: In Amhara region, north Wolo zone youths (North Wollo, Amhara) held demonstration complaining that they have not been benefiting from the Opal mine in the region.
16 April. Youths held a peaceful demonstration in Garowe demanding increased protection from the local authorities to families of victims of sexual violence.

On Apr 17th 2019, squatters from 19 villages marched from Hindi town to Mokowe to protest against land harassment by tycoons and to demand that the government demarcate land and issue them with title deeds.
17 April: Medical students demonstrated over their practice intern schedule and how it has been affecting their performance. Police intervened, leaving some injured.
18 April. Thousands took to the streets opposing the current government of Somalia in Mogadishu. Somali military forces opened fire against the protesters.
18 April. A peaceful protest was held in Burao opposing the arrest of a journalist and a blogger.

On 19 April 2019, residents marched to the ADC farm premises in Sirikwa (Kuresoi North, Nakuru) against the closure of community water by ADC farm. The group demanded the management of the ADC farm allow them access to the water.
19 April: People protested in Afar over lack of good governance at the regional level in Afar. Police arrested more than 100 demonstrators.
19 April. Women and youths in Hargeysa protested the forcible acquisition of their land by the Somaliland government to build a new palace.
22 April: Tikur Anbesa specialized hospital and St. Paul General specialized hospital medical interns and students held demonstration against mistreatment, long working hours and low salary.
22 April: Medical interns and students held demonstration against mistreatment, Long working hours and low salary in Gonder, Amhara region.
23 April: Kibwezi residents held demonstration against Chinese company exhuming body parts from grave yard for road construction.

On 23 April 2019, over 15000 local residents protested in Mwangoloto trading centre (Kinango, Kwale) against delayed issuance of their title deeds. The group demanded to know why their title deeds have been withheld at the Kwale county Lands Registrar's office.
23 April: In Gurage Zone, SNNP region, Masken ethnic group held demonstration against the newly created east Meskan woreda. They do not want to be part of the newly created woreda.
25 April. Local residents of Guri Ceel have protested against militia and warlords operating in the state. .
26 April: Hospital and clinic employees held demonstration over salary raise, hospital safety and other issues in Bahir Dar, Amhara region.
On 26 April 2019, local residents protested against militias operating in Galmudug state in Guri-Ceel town (Dhuusamarreeb, Galgaduud).

On 27 April 2019, police and UPDF fired tear gas and live ammunition at FDC supporters who had gathered for a rally in Lira town (Lira district). Security forces had prevented the rally from taking place, alleging that permission had not been obtained (which has been disputed by the FDC), and briefly detained FDC politician Kiiza Besigye. Note that the source described the FDC supporters as a 'rowdy group of youth', though there is no mention of violent activity by the group, who have accordingly been coded as protesters.
On 28 April 2019, residents staged a protest against the death of a prisoner in Ceerigaabo town (Ceerigaabo, Sanaag).

On 30 April 2019, human rights activists under the Red Vest Movement demonstrated by singing, chanting, whistling, waving placards, carrying banners, wearing red outfits as they congregated at the freedom corner in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), against corruption in government. Police intervened by forming a blockade, lobbed tear gas and arrested one of the demonstrators.
On 1 May 2019, market vendors protested against high taxes in Kampala. Police arrested between two and four traders at the demonstration.

On 1 May 2019, a section of youth demonstrated by whistling and waving placards, as they marched and camped at the Kinyago police station in Dandora (Embakasi North, Nairobi), against extrajudicial killings. Led by their leader, the group demanded the government to empower the youth with jobs, as well as help them start up business enterprises.
02 May: In Amhara region, Bahir Dar city people held demonstration demanding the government to stop the killing and displacement of Amhara people in different places.
02 May. Widows of Somali military soldiers have protested in Hamar Jabab opposing non-payment of salaries. .

On 2 May 2019, women marched in Mombasa, in occasion of the campaign on Women's Labour, Decent Work and Gender Responsive Public Services stop harassment and all forms of violence targeted at women workers in the informal sector.

On 2 May 2019, the Kenya Paralympics team protested by blocking off (means unspecified) a section of Thika Superhighway at the garden city mall area in Nairobi (Nairobi - Kasarani), against delayed pay of their allowances. The team demanded their allowances.
On 3 May 2019, residents from Arumeru district protested against a move by district authorities to take over the Ngarenarok water source without consulting them.
