On 7 May 2019, local residents demonstrated by spewing waste on the streets in Bondeni slums of Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru), against poor sanitation in area. Police intervened and fired teargas to disperse the group.

On 7 May 2019, police and UPDF used tear gas to clear FDC supported in Lugazi town, after they refused to leave the area. Authorities were attempted to prevent FDC senior politician Dr Kizza Besigye from attending a party meeting in the town, and escorted him back to Kampala.
08 May : In Bahir Dar town, Amhara region, the youths held demonstration asking the ADP, Amhara Democratic Party to keep their words.
08 may: In Amhara region, Weldiya town people held demonstration asking the regional government to protect Amhara people in different regions from being dispalced.

On 8 May 2019, students from the Mbarara University of Science and Technology demonstrated in Mbarara town (Mbarara district), calling for local authorities to intervene in the ongoing strike by academics at the institute. Seven students were arrested by police for holding an unauthorised demonstration.

On 9 May 2019, demonstrators blocked (means unspecified) roads in Lokitelebu close to Kotido town (coordinates used at precision 2), following the arrest of 18 women in connection with the killing of a suspected witch. Police used tear gas and live ammunition against the demonstrators, with a stray bullet hitting and killing a woman.
On 10 May 2019, businessmen and residents blocked the Garissa-Nairobi road to protest over taxation by the Garissa County.
10 May. Condemning the arrest of their Party's Youths Chairman, members of Wadani Opposition Party members demonstrated in front of Hargeisa. .

On 10 May 2019, LGBT, Lesbian, Gays, Bisexual and Transgender who are refugees in Kenya held demonstration in Nairobi demanding more protection and financial support. Police used tear gas to disperse them.
On 11 May 2019, local residents protested in Mwihoko within Kahawa Sukari (Roysambu, Nairobi), against the poor road network. The group demanded the roads to be repaired.

On 11 May 2019, local residents demonstrated by singing, chanting and marching in South B estate of Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), against delayed completion of an unspecified road. The group demanded the contractor not to be paid until the road is completed.
On 13 May 2019, in Matare, St Teresa Primary school pupils protested over street accidents, demanding Governor to construct bumps along the road in front of the school.

On 13 May 2019, parents and students of St Teresa's primary school blocked (means not specified) a section of Juja Road [coded as Mathare, Ruaraka, Nairobi], against increased road accidents. The group demanded the authorities to take action.
On 14 May 2019, students of Kenya Medical Training College Nakuru campus protested over the grabbing of land supposed to be destined to sports facilities.

14 May: In Afar region, Aysaita woreda youths held demonstrations against the movement of military forces in the region for other purposes while the people are being attacked by ethnic militias. They blocked the higheway and prevented the militaries from passing through.
14 May. Students have protested in Mogadishu because their secondary examination was cancelled after alleged exam leaks. .
On 14 May 2019, students protesting were shot with live bullets by the police in Belet Weyene (Belet Weyne, Hiraan). Some were shot and injured.
14 May. Students have protested in Jowhar because their secondary examination was cancelled after alleged exam leaks. .
During the month of May 2019, miners protested in or near Ruhaama (Ntungamo district) against abuses by police in the area, and against low prices paid by a monopolistic mineral trading firm.

On 15 May 2019, demonstrators stormed the offices of the RDC in Kabale (Kabale district), following the arrest of a manager of a local NGO, who was accused of sexual abusing girls in his care. The demonstrators are parents of children who benefit from the NGO's services, and are protesting his innocence.

Around 15 May 2019 (month of), police officers at UNHCR headquarters in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) repressed a protest of a group of refugees mostly from the LGBTQI community. 21 protesters were injured and seven were arrested.
16 may: Medical interns and students held demonstration over the quality of work places and informimg the people that government is responsible for the low quality services in the hospitals.
16 may: Medical interns and students held demonstration over the quality of work places and informimg the people that government is responsible for the low quality services in the hospitals.
16 may: Medical interns and students held demonstration over the quality of work places and informimg the people that government is responsible for the low quality services in the hospitals.
16 may: Medical interns and students held demonstration over the quality of work places and informimg the people that government is responsible for the low quality services in the hospitals.

On 16 May 2019, taxi drivers demonstrated against police harassment in Kabale (Kabale district), briefly blocking a road with their vehicles before a meeting was arranged with the police commander to resolve the issues.
16 May: In SNNP region, Sodo town, Woleyta people held demonstration demanding to have their own zone and asking the government to stop the attack on Woleyta people in different areas.
17 May: A group of south Sudanese people in Ethiopia held demonstration demanding President Salvakiir to step down.
On 20 May 2019, members of the disabled society of Kenya took the streets of Machakos to protest the rape and killing of a disabled woman at her home in Kalama Sub County, Machakos.
On 22 May 2019, Ndongoro villagers blocked the road leading to the University of Nairobi's Kabete campus with logs and stones, to protest against car accidents.

On 23 May 2019, residents of Mbaruk blocked the Nakuru-Nairobi highway placing a coffin of a person died in a car accident, to urge the government to addresses the rising cases of accidents in Gilgil sub-county.

On 23 May 2019, in Mombasa, protesters held a demonstration in Machokos along the Nairobi-Mombasa highway at Devki in Athi River, demanding compensation for land acquired for the dual carriageway project.
23 May: In Debre Berhan town, Amhara people held demonstration demanding that Amhara people's voice may be heard. They also asked the government to stop internal displacements.

On 24 May 2019, youth demonstrated in Mbale town (Mbale district), after it was announced that the town would attain city status until 2021. Police arrested 11 leaders of the protests, and used tear gas to disperse them.

On 27 May 2019, an MP for Mbale led protesters (including NRM members) on a march in Mbale town (Mbale district), after it was announced that Mbale would not gain city status until 2021. Police intervened, and arrested the MP for organising a protest without approval.

On 28 May 2019, boda boda drivers in Lari blocked a street leading to Uplands Funeral Home to protest over the poor condition of the road. Two deep terraces were dug by protesters demanding the authorities repair the road.

On 28 May 2019, residents protested by blocking (means unspecified) the main Moi South Lake road in Kamere (Naivasha, Nakuru) against increased land-grabbing cases in the area. Led by their area member of the county assembly (ODM), the group demanded the cabinet secretary for lands to help address the matter.
28 May. Peaceful demonstrations, supporting Somaliland Army Officers who rejected the Army General's orders to attack Puntland Forces based in Badan, were held. .

On 29 May 2019, about 1000 health workers protested by waving placards, whistling, singing and marching in Kerugoya (Kirinyaga Central, Kirinyaga), against deplorable working conditions. The group demanded deployment of more staff.
31 May : In Amhara region, Bahir Dar town, teachers held demonstration demanding pay raise.
31 May: In Amhara region, Dessie town, teachers held demonstration demanding pay raise.
31 May. Somali journalists held a peaceful protest calling for the release of detained journalist Ali Mumin in Mogadishu. He was later released. .
08 June: In west Guji zone, Bule-Hora town people held demonstrations against the armed men who have beeen living in the bush and terrorizing the people around.
08 June: In West Guji zone, Negele town people held demonstration against the armed group that have been living in the bush and terrorizing the people around.

08 June: In Borena zone (Borena,Oromia) people held demonstrations against the armed people that have been living in the bush and terrorizing the people around. They demanded that they be hunted down and be brought before court.
08 June. In Nurhawad, a peaceful protest was held against the Hirshabelle administration opposing the replacement of the Regional Governor of Hiraan. .
10 June. Tricycle moto-taxi drivers protest near the Benjamin Mkapa Tower in Dar es Salaam. Police disperse the protest with tear gas.
11 June. Somaliland police forces left their posts and protested in Jowhar due to the non-payment of their salaries for six months. .
On 12 June 2019, In Belet Weyne, hundreds of demonstrators blocked (means unspecified) the road into the town, to prevent the arrival of Hirshabelle State President, Mohamed Abdi Ware.
On or around June 12th, medical students demonstrated at Makerere University, over the failure of the university to pay their allowances to undertake internships.

On 12 June 2019, a group of people took to the streets in Nairobi (Nairobi Central, Starehe, Nairobi) to protest against the project of a coal-fired power plant near the Lamu archipelago, over environmental concerns.

On Jun 17th 2019, parents of Makuka Primary school students barricaded the entrance of the school to prevent the resumption of classes the following week, after half term. Protesters call for the removal of the headteacher, accused of mismanaging the institute.

On 18 June 2019, Luruk residents blocked (means unspecified) the Marigat-Chemolingot in protest over frequent bandit attacks, occurring since the government withdrew guns from the National Police Reservists (NPR) a week before. Protesters also demanded their 200 goats stolen by bandits at Kagir in Baringo North.
On 19 June 2019, secondary school students demonstrated at the District HQ in Moyo town (Moyo district), citing a list of grievances against the headteacher of the school.
19 June: Mini-bus drivers protested against the police harassment in Dandora.
On 20 June 2019, in Nairobi, an anti-gay protest was held by the Catholic Justice and Peace Commission and the Kenya Christian Professional Forum.
On Jun 20th 2019, residents of Bula Salama village in Tana River county (coded as Galole with GP2) marched to protest the construction of the county assembly speaker's official residence.
On 22 June 2019, tea farmers gathered at Micimikuru facorty in Amugaa, demanding that a satellite factory be built.
24 June. In Balcad, several women who work as road cleaners, protested about lack of payment and food support..

25 June: Thousands of people in Gimbi town, West Wellega zone, held demonstration against a group of OLF soldiers that recently split from OLF and decided to remain armed . The people also asked that they may be unarmed and join the peaceful political arena.

25 June: Thousands of people in Bedele town, Buno bedele zone, held demonstrations against a group of OLF soldiers that recently split from OLF and decided to remain armed. They demanded that they be unarmed and join peaceful political arena.

During the week beginning June 24th, demonstrators gathered in Mbale town (Mbale district), protesting the leaking sewage in the town. Authorities pledged to address the issues raised by the protesters.

On 26 June 2019, health workers protested by marching to the office of the governor in Kutus in Kerugoya (Kirinyaga central, Kirinyaga), against County administration over their unmet demands. The police lobbed teargas to disperse the group, as well as clobbered the workers using clubs. At least 10 health workers were injured during the incident.

27 June: A protest led by Nairobi Governor, Mike Sonko (of the Jubilee party) was held in Machakos against Governor Alfred Mutua, machakos county Governor for intimidating and harassing small scale traders in Machakos county.

28 June: In Dembi Dolo town, West wellega zone, people held demonstrations against the a group of armed OLF soldiers that spilt from OLF recently and decided to remain armed. The people demanded that they may be unarmed and join a peaceful political arena.

On 1 July 2019, protesters gathered once more in Mbale (Mbale district), demonstrating against the failure of authorities to address the problems of leaking sewage in the town (note: demonstrators blocked the road, but unclear if intentional).
On 2 July 2019, NRM youth demonstrated in Jinja (Jinja district), expressing various grievances against senior NRM officials in the city.
On 2 July 2019, residents protested against the efforts to integrate Ahlu Sunna Wal Jamaa into the Galmudug Administration in Cadaado town (Cadaado, Galgaduud).
On Jul 3rd 2019, residents of Gede protested over the two-week-delay in restoring power after a blackout in the village.
On 3 July 2019, traders demonstrated against garbage collection fees in Kampala. Police arrested four traders, for staging an unauthorized demonstration.

On 4 July 2019, demonstrators blocked a road in Kigoro (Kasese district, coordinates for Rukoki used at prec2) using rocks, in a demonstration over the failure of the Chinese company undertaking road works to prevent large quantities of dust from affecting residents and shops. UPDF and police removed the rocks, and the road was cleaned.
Around Jul 4th 2019, residents of Sangailu protested after a man was allegedly burnt by military officers.
04 July. Women and children peacefully protested in Ceel Afweyn demanding the Somaliland government to take action about the armed conflict in the area. .
04 July. Puntland security forces left their defensive positions in Tuko Raq and protested unpaid salaries and incentives. .

06 July: In West Shewa zone, Meta Robi town, thousands of people held demonstration against OLF militant wing, Shane. They said that Shane has been killing, raping and robbing people. They demanded the government to put an end to their action.

On 6 July 2019, Chepchabas ward residents took to the streets in Konoin, near Bomet (Merigi, Bomet East, Bomet) over claims of pollution by Kipsigis Highlands Tea Factory. 3 factory guards allegedly attacked journalists who were covering the event, attempting to grab a camera and injuring them. One journalist was seriously injured.
On Jul 9th, civil servants in Laikipia held a peaceful demonstration over their delayed June salaries.
On 7 September 2019, FDC supporters were dispersed with tear gas and live rounds by police, at a rally in Mbale, Mbale district. Several arrests were also made.

On Jul 9th, in Narok, public transport drivers (matatu drivers) who operate using the Toyota Probox cars blocked the Narok -Mau- Nakuru road at Oloserian junction interrupting traffic flow for hours over alleged police harassment. Drivers accused police of erecting illegal roadblocks along the road and using it to harass the probox drivers into parting with bribes.
On Jul 10th 2019, Bungoma residents protested over the poor condition of the Pamus-Ndengelwa Road, by blocking the traffic and planting banana stems.

On Jul 10th 2019, in Embu village, boda boda and taxi drivers protested over a large and suspicious donation to a church from an MCA. Protesters also accused their representative of donating money to church instead of improving the living standards of the community.
On 10 July 2019, National Youth Service trainees lamented over lack of school fees, accommodation and food at the Riat Institute of Advanced Technology in Kisumu.

On 15 July 2019, demonstrators (predominantly female activists) protested in Lungujja (Kampala), following offensive remarks made by a controversial Pastor about his wife. Police arrested nine demonstrators.

On 15 July 2019, governors, senators and members of the county assembly (MCAs) demonstrated by chanting and walking to the supreme court in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), against the failed revenue sharing bill. The group demanded the supreme courts indulgence in the matter.
On 16 July 2019, supporters of a former journalist and pastor (who was recently arrested) demonstrated at the Special Investigations Unit in Kireka (Wakiso district), demanding his release.

19 July: Demonstrators marched towards the police station in Hula Woreda (no coordinates available, in the Hagere Selam area) to protest the killing of youth, police forces opened fire killing 14 demonstrators.
19 July: Security forces killed 12 protesters in Melga, Sidama (no coordinates available).

19 July: Three people were killed by military forces during protests held in Wendo Genet, Sidama zone. The demonstration was in support of the activists that were going to announce Sidama as a region.
19 July. A peaceful protest was held in Armo after local business people were arrested by local authorities. .
22 July. In Caynabo, a peaceful demonstration took place rejecting the parliament's approval to designate Caynabo District to Grade C level. .
On Jul 23rd 2019, a protest was held in Isiolo town by relatives and friends of the man beaten to death by police two weeks before.
On Jul 23rd, residents of Muhoroni held a demonstration to demand 4,000 acres of their land that had been taken by a sugar company a few years after Independence.
On Jul 23rd 2019, meat sellers protested against an eviction order by City Hall (Nairobi - Starehe).

On 24 June 2019, newly unemployed workers at Tembo Steels plant in Iganga town (Iganga district) demonstrated at the steel plant, preventing vehicles from entering or leaving. The dispute relates to the rapid dismissal of workers and salary arrears.
Around Jul 24th 2019 (no exact date reported) residents of Gatundu protested against the lack of police investigation into the killing of a villager by suspected drug peddlers.

On 25 July 2019, dozens protested by carrying banners and waving placards as they marched in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), against corruption and inflation of customer bills by the Kenya power and lighting company. Police intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the group. One man was arrested, and a journalist was injured after he was hit by a tear gas canister.

On 29 July 2019, health workers, mainly nurses under the KNUN, marched and camped outside Kisumu County headquarters (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the recent killing of the union's deputy secretary general. The group demanded justice for their deceased colleague.
30 July. Somali protesters mostly youth and women demonstrated in Xariirad opposing the way a road was being built. .
31 July. Following the arrest of dealers of Khat, a group of people demonstrated in Tuko raq. .

Around 1 August 2019 (as reported), residents in Naaro (Kandara, Muranga) blocked the footpath through which a corpse was being ferried by mourners. Protesters held the family of the deceased responsible for destroing their crops when, a few days before, they cut them with machetes to create more space for the coffin to pass. In retaliation, residents blocked the road. Police forces came and returned the body to the mortuary.

On 2 August 2019, residents of four sub-counties which adjoin Mt Elgon National Park protested at the District HQ in Mbale town (Mbale district), following alleged encorachment by Wildlife Authority rangers onto the land of the sub-counties, which residents fear pressages a withdrawal of their land rights.
03 August. Workers of the Berbera port held a protest. They demonstrated that their wages were being corrupted by officials. .
On Aug 4th 2019, Loborot residents (location coded as Kanankemer with GP2, for unfound Loborot) protested against evictions and land grabbing cases in the area.

On Aug 6th 2019, in Nuandarua, parents of Gikingi Primary School pupils rioted against the 'indiscriminate cutting down of trees' by the school. Parents had agreed with cutting only 5 trees, but more than 200 trees were cut.

On 7 August 2019, residents of the Karima ward in Nyeri protested over garbage dumping at the Gikeu dumpsite. Residents reported that they have been experiencing respiratory problems due to the amount of garbage disposed of at the site.
On Aug 8th 2019, boda boda drivers and members of Kapsoit Ward FC blocked the traffic in Kericho town to demand the resignation of of Kapsoit MCA Paul Chirchir Tarimbo.

On 9 August 2019, local residents demonstrated by chanting, shouting, carrying twigs as they marched in Naivasha (Naivasha, Naivasha), against their forceful eviction from their land. The group demanded the president and the local political leadership to help address the matter.

At an unspecified time after the death of a suspect in police custody on August 9th (and coded for August 10th at time prec2), protesters demonstrated at the police post in Kiwenda (Wakiso district), calling for justice for the victim of suspected police torture.

On 12 August 2019, residents of the Bardege suburb of Gulu demonstrated along the road running between Gulu town centre and Bardege, in protest at the very poor condition of the road, and planted crops along it. Demonstrators blocked the road with rocks and tires. Later, the protesters peacefully escorted a local MP along the road to show its poor quality.

On 12 August 2019, local residents demonstrated by carrying twigs as they marched along the Masongo- Menyinkwa road in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii), against the negligence at the Kisii teaching and referral hospital, following the death of a woman while giving birth at the facility. Led by family members, the group demanded justice for the deceased.
13 August. In Biyo Cadde, local people protested against Al Shabaab. They protested that militants are robbing them despite the people contributing taxes to the group. .
On Aug 15th, Kangemi residents stormed a census enumerators training centre to protest against alleged flawed hiring of outsiders. Police lobbed tear gas canisters to disperse the crowd.

16 Aug. Tour operators held a demonstration following the death of their colleague in a police station in Ndaragwa. Their colleague collapsed and died in the police station after being arrested for a traffic violation.

On 16 August 2019, Police intervened the demonstration held by South Wolo youths (South Wolo, Amhara). 4 people killed by bullets fired by the police. The government gave the land to government officials after compensating the farmers, which the demonstrators objected to.
On or before Aug 18th, landowners in Naikara staged a protest over the subdivision of a 10.000-acre ranch in Narok. The protesters alleged that the list of beneficiaries was manipulated.
18 August. The members of the Navy protested non-payment at Xamar Jaabjab. .
19 August. In Dhobley, several people held a peaceful demonstration calling for peace. .
20 August. Hundreds of people staged a demonstration in Laascanod Town Centre due to the killing of civilians by security forces.
On 20 August 2019, lorry drivers protested in Busia (Busia district), following the imposition of a new levy and parking fees in the town.

On 21 August 2019, demonstrators from the West Nile region protested at Arua Park in Kampala, against deaths of high-profile figures from their community in recent years, and calling for extra security for a minister who hails from the area.

On 22 August 2019, youth supporters of Bobi Wine MP gathered in Mpenja (Gomba district), upon hearing news that Bobi Wine was returning to the area for a funeral. Police used live rounds and tear gas against protesters, causing several injuries, and unsuccessfully attempted to detain Bobi Wine, who evaded their checkpoints.
22 August. In Garowe, people demonstrated supporting the elections and the outcomes of the election. .

On 22 August 2019, a group of women and boda boda taxi operators protested in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), against corruption in the judiciary. The group demanded the judicial service commission to fire corrupt judges.

On 26 August 2019, students demonstrated at Kabale University at Kitumba (Kabale district), following the decision by the University to considerably increase tuition fees, and to compel students to retake an academic year if they fail a module. Police used tear gas and live rounds to disperse the protesters.

On Aug 28th, protesters marched in front of the South African High Commission offices in Dar es Salaam to demand for the release of the Airbus 220-300 that was caught in a legal case dating back to 1980s.
28 August. Two peaceful protests were held in Dhuusamarreb with one group supporting the federal government and another opposing. .

28 August. In Yaaqla, the local population demonstrated against a move by Al Shabaab militants to relocate the town's hospital. A male demonstrator was killed and a female injured by an unidentified group (circumstances unclear). .

On 29 August 2019, demonstrators marched to the Bushenyi-Ishaka municipality offices (Beshenyi district) to protest against the sale of land which would see the closure of a pork market. The sale relates to a long-standing land dispute and legal case between local authorities and a businessman.
31 August. A large scale anti-government protest was held in Kismayo. .
01 September. In Dhobley, a demonstration was held opposing the Federal government for interfering in Jubaland affairs. .

On Sept 3rd 2019, in Athi River (also known as Mavoko) parents of of Eagles Emulators Academy held a deonstration to protest the closure of the school with no official communication from the ministry. Protesters demanded its immediate reopening.
03 September. In Laascaanood, children and women protested against the government's action of demolishing their houses. .
On Sept 6th, workers protested over 6-month delayed salaries at a Pipes-producing company in Limuru.
On 6 September 2019, a group of sex workers demonstrated in Machakos (Township, Machakos, Machakos) demanding free lubricants and condoms from governor Alfred Mutua.
07 September. Somali police officers have peacefully protested in Xamar Weyne against non-payment of salaries. .
On 7 September 2019, police intercepted an FDC rally in Mbale town (Mbale district), dispersing protesters with tear gas and live rounds, and arresting four (including a senior member).
09 Sep. Kangaru residents held demonstration after a police shot killed a mutatu driver saying that the driver was innocent.
09 Sep. Muranga residents held demonstration against the arrest of Ndindi Nyoro, member of a parliament.
On 9 September 2019, striking health workers staged a demonstration outside Governor Charity Ngilu's office in Kitui, demanding the payment of July and August salaries.

On Sept 9th, Kenya Union of Domestic, Hotels, Educational Institutions, Hospital and Allied Workers (KUDHEIHA) members staged a protest in Nairobi, over the failure to implement a State resolution that upgraded the hospital's parastatal status.

On or before September 10th, residents of Alim village in Pukor parish (Pader district, approximates coordinates based on online mapping service used at prec2) protested against the unexpected arrival of cattle and pastoralists in the area.
12 Sep. Gatundu County residents held demonstration against the rising the insecurity in the area.
12 Sep. Kigumo town residents held demonstration against Kirinyaga Governor for accusing members of County Assembly (MCA).

On Sept 12th 2019, in Ngeya village (coded as Mai Mahiu with GP2 for unfound Ngeya), following the death of a schoolchild hit by a car, the same day, residents protested over the frequency of car accidents in the area.
On or around Sept 12th, parents of Mathemba Secondary School students gathered to demand justice for their children who were beaten by police during a strike.
12 September. In Dhuusamarreb, motorists have protested against alleged money laundering by Galmudug administration. .

15 September 2019. Thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Belessa against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group.

On 15 September 2019, thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Nefas Mewcha against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group.

On 15 September 2019, thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Mekane Yesus against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group.

16 September 2019. Thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Debre Tabor against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group.

On 16 September 2019, protesters aligned to a candidate seeking to be elected as Bunyole cutural leader demonstrated at Butaleja town (Butaleja district), claiming that his opponent was not from the area, and was therefore ineligible to run.

17 September 2019. Thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Dessie against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group.
17 September. Residents of Bulambuli district protested the bad state of the Buyaga-Buluganya road.
17 September. In Cadaado, local people staged a peaceful demonstration against the Somali government. Amongst their demands was designation of Cadaado town as the seat of Galmudug parliament. .

18 September 2019. Thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Gonder against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group.
18 September (or around). Millers in Soroti protested the poor power supply at the UMEME office in town.

18 September. Police forces used live bullets and teargas to disperse FDC supporters in Hoima who protested the exclusion of their candidate from radio shows. No injuries reported from the protesters.
18 September. Students at Gulu University protested the bad state of the toilet facilities.
On Sept 18th 2019, Mombasa demonstrators protested against the assault of a human rights activist by an Immigration police officer the day before.

19 September 2019. Thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Kombolcha against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group.

20 September 2019. Thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Mekane Selam against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group.
On Sept 20th, thousands of students took the streets of Dar es Salaam to participate in a FridaysForFuture march against climate change.
20 September. Traders protested ongoing road construction works that cut off the access to a market in Kampala.
20 September. Students in Kampala participated in the global climate strike and staged a protest in town.
20 September. Demonstrators 2km off Palabek protested a demarcation exercise conducted by National Forestry Authority.
20 September. Residents of Apyeta Parish protested the re-opening of the Aswa River Forest Reserve land by National Forestry Authority.

Around 21 September 2019 (as reported), hundreds of residents from Burat ward marched in Isiolo town (Isiolo, Isiolo) against the quest to evict them by the Kenya defense forces. The group demanded a copy of the eviction notice from the county commissioner so that they can challenge it in court.
21 September (or around). Residents along the Kaliro-Kamuli road protested the bad state of the street.
21 September (or around). Residents of Mbarara protested the introduction of garbage fees.

22 September 2019. Thousands of Amharas held demonstration in Meket against what they called interference and blatant attack on Ethiopian Orthodox Church and its followers by Federal Government and influential individuals from the rival Oromo ethnic group.
On Sept 23rd 2019, residents of Ithamare held a demonstration against the decision of a Meru court to close the Mbaarua Primary School, as it did not meet the required standards.

On Sept 23rd, flower farm and Kengen company workers blocked the Moi South Lake Road in Naivasha demanding for its rehabilitation by the national government. Rioters lit bonfires and used boulders to block the road. Police used tear gas to disperse the crowd.
23 September. Uber taxi drivers protested poor working conditions at the companies HQ in Kampala.

23 Sep. Mombasa residents held demonstration against the plan by the state to build a dry port in Naivasha. Businessmen, long-distance truck drivers, Container Freight Station workers, clearing and forwarding agents, clerks and a section of port workers took part in the demonstration. They promised every day demonstration until the government responds to their request.
24 Sep. Parents of Ndakaini mixed day secondary school in Gatanga, Muranga county held demonstration after the students were sent home over unpaid bread fees.
24 September. Students of Bukalasa Agricultural College protested in Wobulenzi over poor sanitary conditions at the institute. Police forces used teargas to disperse the crowd.
24 September (or around). Police forces prevented FDC supporters and Bobi Wine from passing through Hoima town centre.
25 Sep. Mutatu drivers held demonstration in Kwale against private cars carrying passengers.
On 25 September 2019, in Naivasha, residents and workers protested, demanding the reabilitation of the Moi South Lake Road. Police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.

On 25 September 2019, vendors protested at the Central Market in Jinja (Jinja district), protesting alleged interference by political and security officials in the running of the market. They prevented the new chairperson from accessing the market.
26 September. In Luuq, a peaceful protest was held against the arrest of the Ministry of Security of Jubaland in Mogadishu as well as the interferences of the Federal government in Jubaland state. .

On 26 September 2019, Kisumu East residents took to the streets near Nyalenda (Kolwa Central, Kisumu East, Kisumu) over river Kibos pollution. They protested against Kibos Sugar factory contaminating the river.

26 September. In Buur Xaawo, a peaceful protest was held against the arrest of the Ministry of Security of Jubaland in Mogadishu as well as the interferences of the Federal government in Jubaland state. .

26 September. In Doolow, a peaceful protest was held against the arrest of the Ministry of Security of Jubaland in Mogadishu as well as the interferences of the Federal government in Jubaland state. .

On Sept 27th, a group of parents camped outside a Kibera court to demand the release of the owner of the Precious Talent Academy. A few days before, a part of the schook collapsed killing eight children. Held responsible for the poor conditions of the structure, the owner was arrested. Parents, however, defended him claiming he was only a teacher, not the architect of the structure and called for his release.
28 September. Residents of Railway village in Layibi protested the bad state of a local road.
29 September. Residents of Qalimow have protested against the decision by the Somali security forces decision that bans any farming activities within 1.5km on either side of Qalimow and Balcad. .
29 Sep. Gonder residents held demonstration against an attack on Amhara people and Amahara Liyu police. Amhara regional presiedency denied any attack in the region.

On 30 September 2019, medical students from Busitema University demonstrated in Mbale (Mbale district), at changes in the internship structure, and a lack of money. Police prevented the demonstrators from continuing their march, on the grounds that they did not have a permit.
On 30 September 2019, medical students demonstrated at Gulu University (Gulu district), in protest at changes in the structure of internships. Police dispersed the demonstrators with tear gas.

On 30 September 2019, Trans Mara women staged a demonstration in Kilgoris (Shankoe, Transmara West, Narok) demanding government intervention over clashes in Nkararo resulting in at least three deaths (coded separately). 30 women were arrested by police officers and detained at the Kilgoris police station.
On Oct 1st 2019, demonstrators blocked the Eldoret-Kitale road to protest the death of a college student, allegedly killed by her ex-boyfriend. Police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.

On 1 October 2019, a group of residents held a demonstration for the second day in Mombasa city (Mvita, Mombasa) against Government's directive to have all containers ferried to Nairobi's Inland Container Deport moved through the Standard Gauge Railway.

02 October. In Kismayo, a peaceful demonstration was held due to the continued flight rerouting to Mogadishu and the invite of Jubaland President Sheikh Madobe to Forum in Mogadishu only through media. .

On 3 October 2019, police fired tear gas to disperse students at Kyambogo Univerity (Kampala), as part of an intra-student protest which centred upon an attempt to impeach the president of the student guild. The details are unclear.
On 5 October 2019, taxi drivers drove from Kanungu to Kabale (Kabale district, coordinates used), in protest at the lack of security along the road.

07 October. Burundian refugees demonstrated before the Nduta camp administration, Kigoma, demanding improved refugee assistance. This comes as Tanzania and Burundi have agreed to repatriate all Burundian refugees by the end of the year.

On 7 October 2019, hundreds of women gathered in front of the administration buildings in Dire Dawa to conduct a peaceful demonstration against the government's lack of a final solution for conflicts in the areas of Dire Dawa, Ginchi Gara, and Amstagna. The protest lasted two days.

On Oct 7th, Kenyatta University students engaged in a violent demonstration against the suspension of students and student leaders on petty basis, the sacking of more than 700 casual workers without notice and the increment of graduation fee. Police forces intervened to disperse the crowd.

On Oct 7th, human rights activists and truckers demonstrated against a suspended government directive to have all imported cargo transported to the hinterland exclusively via the Standard Gauge Railway and not via trucks. Police officers fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.

On 7 October 2019, members of the Sengwer community protested by carrying banners, whistling and singing, as they marched to the office of the president at harambee house in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), against eviction from their ancestral land which lies inside Embobut Forest. Joined by defenders coalition, Amnesty International and other human rights organizations, the group demanded the government to formally recognize them as a tribe.
8 October 2019: A court decision to overrule police requests to postpone hearings sparked street demonstrations in Bahir Dar. Police later intervened, firing tear gas on protesters.

7th and 8th October 2019: Hundreds of women gathered in front of the administration buildings in Dire Dawa to conduct a peaceful demonstration against the government's lack of a final solution for conflicts in the areas of Dire Dawa, Ginchi Gara, and Amstagna. The protest lasted two days.
8 October 2019: Oromo community members in Dire Dawa city held a protest demonstration denouncing the wounding of a civilian by Somali regional security forces earlier (no details).

On Oct 8th, Kenyatta University students engaged in a violent demonstration against the suspension of students and student leaders on petty basis, the sacking of more than 700 casual workers without noticethe and the increment of graduation fee. Police forces intervened to disperse the crowd.

On Oct 8th, in Karen, a group of young people rioted outside Deputy President William Ruto's official residence after they were reportedly denied entry to a meeting he was having with some members of the Abagusii community. Police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.
9 October 2019: Members of the Somali Youth Federation gathered in Jijiga and demonstrated against what they saw discriminatory hiring practices by Ethiopian airlines.

9 October 2019: Residents of Adi Dearo town, located in upper Adiyabo of Western Tigray demonstrated against a local government official who was accused of engaging in serious sexual and financial crimes. Some news outlets have reported that demonstrators were shouting anti-TPLF slogans.
On 9 October 2019, young people in Nairobi marched to protest over unemployment.
On Oct 9th, refugees in Nairobi County marched to demand compensation for cases of violence after 2007 elections.

Around 10 October 2019 (as reported), local residents protested by carrying twigs as they marched in Nandi [coded as Nandi hills, Nandi East, Nandi], against the shooting and injuring of a man in the area by the police [coded separately]. The group demanded justice for the victim.
11 October 2019: A group of Oromo youth (Qeerroo) protested outside the office building of the Baldera organization as they held a press conference.
12 October 2019: Residents in Jima held a support demonstration after hearing prime minster Abiy Ahmed received a nobel prize.
12 October 2019: Residents of Sultulta held a support demonstration after hearing prime minster Abiy Ahmed received a nobel prize.

12 October 2019: Residents of Assosa town rallied in demonstration to show their support of President Abiy Ahmed, who had recently won the Nobel prize. Leaders of the rally spoke to fellow residents of the town, encouraging them to support the president and his reforms.

12 October 2019: Several people were arrested shortly after attempting to start a demonstration in Giorgis subcity, located in the capital, Addis Ababa. Those arrested were followers of the Baldares movement which opposes the current presidency and was planning a large rally in Meskal square the same day. The Addis Ababa city council had previously banned protests on the (12 October) citing security concerns. Additional small protest groups were reported in 4 Kilo, Markato, and French Embassy area.
12 October 2019: Locals gathered in Guji zone held a support demonstration after hearing prime minster Abiy Ahmed received a nobel prize.
On 12 October 2019, Borena zone residents held a support demonstration after hearing prime minister Abiy Ahmed received a nobel prize.
12 October 2019: Residents in Adama city (Nazret) held a support demonstration after hearing prime minster Abiy Ahmed received a nobel prize.

12 October 2019: Frustrated demonstrators attempting to reach Addis Ababa from Amhara region protested in Debre Birhan, north Shewa, claiming that Oromo Youth (Qeerroo) had closed the roads to block a planned protest by the Balderas movement. No information if any violence occurred.
On Oct 14th 2019, Baringo health workers marched in Kabarnet to protest over the nonpayment of salaries for 5 months.

On 14 October 2019, Pwani University students demonstrated in Kilifi (Sokoni, Kilifi North, Kilifi) over students suspension regarding fees arrears. Police officers fired gunshots in the air and lobbed teargas to disperse the students. Some students were allegedly assaulted by police officers. The university was later closed indefinitely.
15 October 2019: demonstrators condemning the killing of civilians by armed men from Djibouti the previous day demonstrated in Awash, Gawane, Afambo, Konnaba and Galalu cities in Afar region.
15 October 2019: demonstrators condemning the killing of civilians by armed men from Djibouti the previous day demonstrated in Awash, Gawane, Afambo, Konnaba and Galalu cities in Afar region.
15 October 2019: demonstrators condemning the killing of civilians by armed men from Djibouti the previous day demonstrated in Awash, Gawane, Afambo, Konnaba and Galalu cities in Afar region.
15 October 2019: demonstrators condemning the killing of civilians by armed men from Djibouti the previous day demonstrated in Awash, Gawane, Afambo, Konnaba and Galalu cities in Afar region.
15 October. A peaceful protest was held in Jowhar after scores of people were arrested in a security operation. .

On Oct 16th 2019, Green Peace Africa activists and local farmers staged a demonstration at the Makueni Agricultural Training Centre, Kwa Kathoka, where Celebrations for the World Food Day were being held. Protesters demanded the ban of chemical ingredients harmful to the environment, found in some pesticides.
On Oct 16th 2019, a group of women in Likuyani demonstrated against increased incidents of rape and other sexual assaults in the area.

On 16 October 2019, a group demonstrated throwing bloody pigs' heads inside the Delta Hotel in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), demanding the resignation of its owner, Kiambu Governor Waititu, accused of abuse of office charges. Riot police intervened, firing tear gas to disperse the crowd.
On Oct 17th 2019, residents of Kisii, protested in front of the immigration Department over delayed travel documents.
On or around October 17th, residents blocked the Busajjabwakuba road in Nakaloke (Mbale district), protesting the poor condition of the road.
On 17 October 2019, residents protested against the federal government in Maxaas town (Bulo Burto, Hiraan). This is after the former Mayor a former senior police officer appeared before the court.

19 October 2019: demonstrators from the 'Hadari Seb' student's group gathered in Mekelle town to demonstrate against ethnically Tigrayan students being sent for university studies to other parts of the country where they could face violence due to their ethnicity. Demonstrators were dispersed by police after being deemed illegal due to lack of pre-approval. No violence occurred.
On Oct 22nd 2019, census officials protested in Eldoret over the three-month delay in their payment.

On Oct 22nd 2019, members of the Ogiek and Ndorobo communities living around Chepkitale Forest in Mount Elgon protested over the decision to evict them from the area and relocate them from Chepkitale to Chepyuk.
On Oct 22nd 2019, census officials protested in Kakamega over the three-month delay in their payment.

On 22 October 2019, residents marched in Mumias town (Mumias West, Kakamega) in support of the takeover of the miller by the Kenya Commercial Bank (KCB) as an administrator. The group demanded the administrator be given a chance to turn things around at the firm.

22 October 2019: Thousands of people held a demonstration in Aweday, demanding ethnic clashes cease in Jigjiga. They also asked that the Oromo people who have been arrested in West and east Oromia region be released.

From October 22nd-24th, 2019, students demonstrated at Makerere University (Kampala), over the introduction of a cumulative tuition fee increase. UPDF and police used tear gas and live rounds against protests, with reports of beatings and arrests across the three days. Several students were also arrested as they attempted to march to President Museveni's state house.
On 22 October 2019, student protesters (led by women) demonstrated at Wandegeya police station (Kampala), following the arrest of student demonstrators that same day.
On Oct 22nd 2019, in Mombasa, cargo truck drivers protested a government directive to have importers move all containers headed to Nairobi by the Standard Gauge Railway (SGR).
On Oct 23rd 2019, in Ol Kalou, meat sellers protested the closure (since July) of the public slaughterhouse, which forced them to use a private abbattoir 4km from Ol Kalou.

23 October 2019: A popular Oromo activist living in Addis Ababa (Bole) issued a series of alerts on facebook during the night, claiming that the government had attempted to remove his guards and expose him to a potentially life-threatening situation. Within hours, hundreds of young men from the Qerroo Oromo youth group had surrounded his house, chanting slogans aimed at the prime minster.

From October 22nd-24th, 2019, students demonstrated at Makerere University (Kampala), over the introduction of a cumulative tuition fee increase. UPDF and police used tear gas and live rounds against protests, with 100 students arrested and beaten on the second day of protests.

From October 22nd-24th, 2019, students demonstrated at Makerere University (Kampala), over the introduction of a cumulative tuition fee increase. UPDF and police used tear gas and live rounds against protests, with reports of beatings and arrests across the three days.

On 25 October 2019, demonstrators gathered on Saaka road in Fort Portal (Kabarole district), in protest at the poor condition of the road. Demonstrators blocked the road with rocks, logs, and dug trenches.
26 October 2019. Anti-government protests were held in the streets of Mogadishu. .
27 October 2019. In Bosaso, a peaceful protest was held to oppose the closing down of a market. .
On Oct 28th 2019, residents of Kibundani staged a peaceful protest over the number of killings and disappearance of youths in the area.

On Oct 28th 2019, residents and drivers staged a demonstration over the bad condition of the Kikuyu-Dagoretti road, which was damaged by heavy rain. Traffic was blocked during the rush hour. Police intervened.

28 October 2019: Two protesters were wounded by bullets when security forces intervened in a protest/demonstration in Mojo town, East Shewa of Oromiya region. The demonstrators were asking for the people who were arrested last week to be released.

On 28 October 2019, local residents demonstrated by waving placards, chanting and burning an effigy of tourism cabinet secretary Najib Balala in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), against his remarks on rerouting all cargo via the Standard Gauge Railway (SGR). Led by Haki Africa executive director, the group demanded economic justice.
On 29 October 2019, students gathered at Markerere University (Kampala), as part of sustained demonstration against a cumulative fee increase. Police fired tear gas against demonstrators.

On 29 October 2019, over 100 village chairmen demonstrated at the District HQ in Budaka town (Budaka district), following the non-payment of money promised to them for their role in an immunisation campaign in the area.
Around Oct 30th 2019 (exact date not reported) traders protested in Engineer, over the condition of the market, worsened by heavy rains. Protesters called for Government assistance.
On Oct 30th 2019, Embu University Students staged a protest over proposed fees. The road in front of the school was blocked. Police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd.

On 30 October 2019, protesters gathered at Makerere Univeristy (Kampala) as part of continued protests against a cumulative fees increase. Police used tear gas and live rounds to disperse the students.
On 30 October 2019, pork vendors marched in Kabale (Kabale district), calling for a quarantine on pigs from the area (imposed due to an outbreak of swine fever) to be lifed.

Around Oct 31st 2019 (exaxt date not reported) cashew farmers raided a cashew board meeting, allegedly in Songea (exact location not mentioned) demanding the government to pay back their cashew money.

On 31 October 2019, private school owners, teachers, and parents protested by carrying placards and shouting in Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi), against the conduct of the sub county director of education for closing private schools and arresting teachers allegedly lacking documents. The group demanded the government to transfer the director.

31 October 2019: Qerro Oromo Youth protesters gathered on the main street of Ambo town as prime minister Abiy Ahmed and Defense Minister Lemma Megesa gathered to meet with local officials to discuss violence that had occurred in the city a week before. Witnesses claimed that demonstrators numbered over 10,000, all demanding that Qerroo youth representatives be included in the talks.

On October 30th or 31st, residents of Forest Ward on the outskirts of Gulu marched to the Resident District Commissioner's office in Gulu (Gulu district), to demand that two local politicians be released. The politicians are accused of mobilising a mob to clear a witch doctor off land in the area.
On 1 November 2019, police arrested student demonstrators at Gulu University (Gulu district) who were protesting in solidarity with colleagues at Makerere University.
On Nov 1st 2019, residents of Tsunza protested, claiming they were owed compensation for donating their land for construction of the Dongo highway.
On 4 November 2019, journalists demonstrated in Kampala against infringements against press freedom by Ugandan security organs. Police beat several journalists and arrested one.

On 4 November 2019, FDC supporters held a demonstration in Kireka (Wakiso district). Police used tear gas and water cannons against supporters. Video footage emerged of police smashing the vehicle of former FDC leader Dr Kizza Besigye and threatening its inhabitants with a firearm, before filling the vehicle with pepper spray. Dr Besigye was arrested, along with a number of his aides; eight FDC supporters were later arrested.

5 November 2019: hundreds of people gathered at the Bole international airport to receive the bodies of 7 dead Ethiopian domestic workers who had been killed in Lebanon. Greiving family members expressed their frusteration at the workers' treatment abroad, especially in Arab ccountries.

On 5 November 2019, supporters of Nairobi Governor Mike Sonko demonstrated outside of the Integrity Centre (in Kilimani, Nairobi), after he was summoned due to irregularities with paperwork he submitted when running for office. Police dispersed his supporters with tear gas.
9 November 2019: A peaceful protest was held by around 200 women in Mekele city, Tigray region, demonstrating against Gender-Based-violence.

On 9 November 2019, local residents demonstrated by carrying twigs, whistling waving placards as they marched in Tarbaj (Tarbaj, Wajir), against the census results, alleging that they were fraudulent. Led by their local leaders, the residents demanded the president to help address the matter.
Around 11 November 2019 (as reported), residents protested in Machakos town(Machakos, Machakos) against a donkey slaughter house. The group demanded the facility be closed down.

On 11 November 2019, students from Jomo Kenyatta University (Kiambu county) demonstrated against insecurity in the area around the university, and blocked traffic on the nearby highway (note: the sources do not mention how traffic was blocked; demonstrators accordingly coded as protesters). Police beat protesters, with footage emerging of five police officers severely beating a student whilst he was on the ground. Four police officers have been suspended.
On 11 November 2019. In Garbhaarey, residents held a peaceful protest against the Jubaland government and Ahmed Madobe's leadership. .
11 November 2019. A peaceful protest was held in Gaalkacyo calling for the government to release Somali youths accused of piracy. .

On 11 November 2019, business owners and truck drivers demonstrated by carrying placards, whistling and chanting in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), against the move by the government plan to have cargo from the port of Mombasa transported by the standard gauge railway (SGR). The group demanded the government to rescind decision.
On 12 November 2019, in Ziway, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University.
On 12 November 2019, in Hirna, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University.
On 12 November 2019, students protested at the central police office at Juja (Kiambu county), following a violent suppression of a student demonstration the previous day.
On 12 November 2019, in Asri Negele, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University.
On 12 November 2019, in Bulbula, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University.
On 12 November 2019, in Ginchi, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University.
On 12 November 2019, in Weldiya, demonstrators marched to denounce the killing of two university students in Woldiya Universtiy, Amhara region.
On 12 November 2019, in Ambo, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University.
On 12 November 2019, in Guder, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University.
On 12 November 2019, in Chiro, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University.
On 12 November 2019, in Shashamane, several people (mainly students) held a demonstration in Shashamane following the death of two Oromo students in Weldiya.
On 12 November 2019, in Haramaya, students and residents demonstrated against the killing of two Oromo students in Woldiya University.

On 13 November 2019, a section of members of the county assembly (MCA) demonstrated by blocking the entrance to the roads and infrastructure department headquarters using their vehicles in Kerugoya (Kirinyaga Central, Kirinyanga), against the lack of road projects in their wards. Police intervened (through unspecified means), to disperse the group.
On 13 November 2019, striking health workers demonstrated in Voi (Taita Taveta county), calling for 60m KSH of salary arrears to be paid, and for adquate provisioning of medical supplies.
On 13 November 2019, anti-abortion protesters gathered at the KICC in central Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), before being dispersed by police from the GSU.

On 16 November 2019, coffee farmers protested at a meeting of the coffee task forces in Kutus town (Kirinyaga county), after being excluded from participation in the meeting. The meeting was then cancelled.

On 16 November 2019, demonstrators blocked the road between Ambo and Addis Ababa using stones and logs after rumors circulated that Amhara ethnic students were being evacuated from the university in Ambo. Protesters blocking roads demanded that Oromo students be evacuated from Amhara region before any Amhara students were allowed to leave Oromiya region.
16 November 2019. In Mogadishu roads were closed when people protested the government of Somalia's refusal of the ex-president to fly across Somalia and taxation issues.
On 18 November 2019, cab drivers protested over a new order limiting their access to the roads in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed).
On 18 November 2019. Somali police blocked a gathering by the supporters of Waddani party in Hargeysa and gun fire was heard as police tried to disperse them. No fatalities reported. .

On 19 November 2019, striking workers at the Bidco industrial plant in Masese (Jinja district) demonstrated, against poor working conditions, unpaid overtime, arbitrary taxation from the company, and job insecurity.

On 19 November 2019, members of the Waddani opposition party staged a protest near the party's headquarter in Burco town (Burco, Togdheer) calling for the release of their leaders. Somaliland police forces fired live bullets and blocked the roads leading to the headquarters. No one was injured.
On 20 November 2019. A peaceful protest was held against the Jubaland administration. The delegation from Jubbaland administration led by vice president Mohamed Sayid Adan was in the region. .
On 21 November 2019, demonstrators marched in Lodwar (Turkana county), calling for the closure of a slaughterhouse in the area, which they say has decimated the number of donkeys in the area.
21 November 2019: University students who were beginning a protest were quickly arrested at the Sidist (6) Kilo entrance to Addis Ababa University. No further details.

On 21 November 2019, police dispersed Bobi Wine's People Power supporters with tear gas as they marched at the funeral of Human Rights Commissioner Haj Muhammad Kaggwa (known by his alias of Med Kaggwa) at Lufaka village on the outskirts of Mpigi town (Mpigi district, coordinates for Mpigi used at prec2).

On 22 November 2019. A peaceful protest was held in Mogadishu against visiting prominent Kenya-based cleric Sheikh Umal, whom Somali Sufi leaders accuse of being 'extremist.' After the protest, the Somali government called off the public lecture organised by the cleric. .

22 November 2019: Secondary school students demonstrated against recent violence targeting ethnically Amhara students across the country. Protesters began near the Dambacha university located in West Gojam zone, and marched to the police station after several students were arrested. Police fired bullets into the air to disperse the protesters, and at least one person was seriously injured and taken to the hospital.

On 23 November 2019, taxi drivers blocked roads with their vehicles in Nansana (Wakiso district) in protest at the presence of a rival group of taxi drivers who have recently been moved to a nearby taxi stage.
On 23 November 2019. Public bus drivers protested in Mogadishu. They protested recent tax increases by the Banadir Regional Administration and closure of the city's main roads. .

On 23 November 2019, Imenti youths reportedly blocked the Nkabune-Kathurine road that connects several schools in Nkabune, Meru county, with trees, to denounce the conditions of the impractical road. .
On 23 November 2019, several public minibus transportation drivers protested between four gardens and Fagah junction in Mogadishu - Yaqshid (Banadir) against illegal taxation.
On 23 November 2019, several public minibus transportation drivers protested between four garden in Mogadishu - Heliwa (Banadir) against illegal taxation.

On the 25th of November 2019, several students were arrested by Addis Ababa police following a protest rally on Addis Ababa campus. Protesters denounced violence facing Oromo students studying in Amhara region.

On 26 November 2019, protesters gathered in Kabowa (Kampala) to protest the closure of a footpath by a factor owner. A police officer fired several rounds at the protesters, shooting a demonstrator in the head, and killing him. The officer has been arrested.
On 26 November 2019, road workers protested at the local authority offices at Busia (Busia district), demanding salary arrears to be paid.
On 27 November 2019, unemployed men demonstrated in Kampala against corruption and unemployment. Police arrested one protester, who was reported to be in possession of a machete. .

On 27 November 2019. Clan leaders in Garowe held a peaceful protest against the administration accusing the authorities in Garowe of failing to abide by the agreement between clans which founded Puntland in 1998. .
On 3 December 2019, Hirshabelle administration police forces fired on protesters in Bulo Burto (Bulo Burto, Hiraan) and killed one of them.

On 4 December 2019, around 500 health workers who had recently been sacked by Vihiga county governor after alleged irrelugar hiring in May reportedly staged a protest to denounce the decision and demand unpaid salaries.

On 4 December 2019, businessmen who import goods in the area of Mombasa reportedly held a protest to denounce being forced to use the Standard Gauge Railway instead of trucks, which are cheaper, to transport their goods. Although the source reported the event has a weekly incident, the last such event recorded by ACLED took place on 22 October 2019 (KEN7025).

On 5 December 2019, protesters (including boda boda drivers) - who are reportedly aligned to the NRM (and coded as such) - demonstrated in Kisenyi (Kampala), against a petition to have Museveni indicted at the International Criminal Court. Police dispersed the protesters.

On 5 December 2019, casual labourers working for the Ugandan Road Authority protested at the HQ of the authority in Kabale (Kabale district), having been unpaid since May of 2019. The manager of the authority has agreed to pay the workers by the end of the week.

On 8 December 2019, local residents demonstrated by planting banana trees, chanting and waving twigs in Nyanduma area of Lari (Lari, Kiambu), against the poor state of roads. The residents demanded the county government to rehabilitate the road.

11 December 2019. Residents of Baligubadle protested in the district opposing the House of Representatives of Somaliland's Council for creating instability in the country by approving the District level from B to C level. .
On 12 December 2019, police fired tear gas at People Power activists demonstrating in Kamwokya (Kampala), and made a number of arrests.
12 December 2019: Residents of Sodo city, Wolayta city, Sodo, demonstrated in support of President Abiy Ahmed's receiving of the Nobel Peace Prize award.
On 13 December 2019, railroad workers reportedly marched in Mai Mahiu over unpaid wages. No further information was available.
On 13 December 2019, police arrested a number of People Power activists as they marched in Makindye (Kampala), and attempted to mobilise residents of the area to join the march.
On 15 December 2019, hundreds of members of 46 churches protested against the proliferation of bars in Kithirune (Central Imenti, Meru).
On 16 December 2019, in Borama, around two hundred people demonstrated against the arrest of Mohamed Abdurahman Duale, Chief of Borama town. .
16 December 2019: A woman-only rally was held in Wolayta zone (Sodo town), in support of Wolayta becoming a regional state.
On 16 December 2019, workers protested on the Makupa Causeway Road in Mombasa (Chaani, Mvita) over fears they would not be paid during the Christmas holiday.
On 17 December 2019, residents protested in Machakos against Deputy President William Ruto over threats he allegedly issued to Machakos Governor Alfred Mutua.
On 17 December 2019, residents protested in Kitui against Deputy President William Ruto over threats he allegedly issued to Machakos Governor Alfred Mutua.

On 17 December 2019, protesters demonstrated at Moroto and the nearby Kidepo barracks (Moroto district, one event coded), following the killing of an LCIII chairman earlier that day. Soldiers (coded as LDU) dispersed at least some of the demonstrators.

On 18 December 2019, residents of Hamurwa sub-county marched from Hamuko to Hamurwa (Rubanda district, coordinates used at geoprec2), in opposition to the very poor quality of the road in the area, and the absence of improvements despite the allocation of money for the road. Police prevented the demonstrators from proceeding, although allowed 11 chairpersons of villages to continue the march.
18 December 2019: Religious groups, trade union groups, and community groups rallied in Sodo, Wolayta, in support of a Wolayta regional state.
19 December 2019: Tuk Tuk drivers (bajaj) staged a protest in Sodo in favor of Wolayta becoming an Ethiopian state.
On 20 December 2019, men protested in Kapsabet (Emgwen, Nandi) after police had raided the venue for an upcoming celebration event and poured out traditional beer.
20 December 2019: Rallies were held in across Wolayta zone in Kondo Dodaye, Boditi, Boleso, Bombe, Hebcha, and Abala Abya, in support of a Wolayta regional state.
20 December 2019: Rallies were held in across Wolayta zone in Kondo Dodaye, Boditi, Boleso, Bombe, Hebcha, and Abala Abya, in support of a Wolayta regional state.
20 December 2019: Rallies were held in across Wolayta zone in Kondo Dodaye, Boditi, Boleso, Bombe, Hebcha, and Abala Abya, in support of a Wolayta regional state.
21 December 2019: Protest rallies were held in Jimma denouncing an attack on a mosque in Gojam zone the night before.
21 December 2019: Protest rallies were held in Shashamene denouncing an attack on a mosque in Gojam zone the night before.
21 December 2019: Muslim worshippers gathered near the Nur Masjid in Addis Ababa (Arada subcity), denouncing the burning of mosques in Motta, East Gojjam, the night before.
Around 21 December 2019, residents staged a protest over the body of a man shot by Somaliland police in Wajaale town (Gebiley, Waqooti Galbeed).
On 23 December 2019, members of the Maasai community protested along the Mai Mahiu-Narok Highway near Mai Mahiu (Narok) after 32 sheep were killed by a speeding truck.
On 24 December 2019, residents of Kapkwen (Bomet) protested after a pedestrian was killed by a motorist.

On 24 December 2019, in Kismayo, Jubaland security forces fired at protesters. Fatalities or injuries were not reported. The protesters blame the regional president of Jubaland administration for targeting politicians opposed to his administration. .

24 December 2019: Residents in Jigjiga protest against the burning of mosques in Amhara region, Ethiopia. Some reports claimed that police fired on protesters, leading to the death of one demonstrator, while other (more reliable) reports claimed that the demonstration took place without incident.

27 December 2019: Protest rallies were held in Dessie, Amhara region, denouncing the burning of several mosques and muslim-owned businesses in East Gondar the week before. Protests were peaceful and no police intervention was recorded.

27 December 2019: Muslim worshippers took to the streets in Addis Abeba, Hawassa, Assella, Illubabor, and Jima, demonstrating against the destruction of a mosque by angry mobs in Mota town, East Gojam the week before. All protests were peaceful and no arrests were made.

27 December 2019: Muslim worshippers took to the streets in Addis Abeba, Hawassa, Assella, Illubabor, and Jima, demonstrating against the destruction of a mosque by angry mobs in Mota town, East Gojam the week before. All protests were peaceful and no arrests were made.

27 December 2019: Muslim worshippers took to the streets in Addis Abeba, Hawassa, Assella, Illubabor, and Jima, demonstrating against the destruction of a mosque by angry mobs in Mota town, East Gojam the week before. All protests were peaceful and no arrests were made.

27 December 2019: Muslim worshippers took to the streets in Addis Abeba, Hawassa, Assella, Illubabor, and Jima, demonstrating against the destruction of a mosque by angry mobs in Mota town, East Gojam the week before. All protests were peaceful and no arrests were made.
On 28 December 2019, in Fiqi Ayuub, a peaceful demonstration was held. Protesters said the foreign mining company have not respected its promises to develop the infrastructure of the area. .
On 1 January 2020, parents protested at the Kwoyo Kodalo school near Rongo (Migori) to demand the dismissal of the principal due to poor test results.
On 1 January 2020, women leaders and residents protested in Ndhiwa (Homa Bay) against the rape and killing of a 12-year-old girl.
2 January 2020: A protest rally was held in Asosa town, denouncing the killing of a Benishangul State regional council member the day before.

On 2 January 2020, in Mogadishu (Banadir), a peaceful protest was held opposing Al Shabaab and condemning last week's attack. Some protesters were seen holding placards that supported the Turkish president.
On 2 January 2020, employees of the Guard Force Group protested outside their employer's office in Nyali area (Nyali, Mombasa) to demand payment.
On 2 January 2020, residents of Kathiani (Machakos County) protested over the poor state of a road.

On 2 January 2020, local residents demonstrated by whistling, waving placards, carrying twigs and chanting in Katani (Machakos, Machakos), against the poor state of roads in the area. The residents demanded those in authority to address the matter.
On 2 January 2020, residents of Kisumu stormed a hospital in Kisumu city (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) to demand the arrest of a police officer who had allegedly raped a 16-year-old girl.
3 January 2020: Heavy truck drivers in Gondor protested a lack of security on the roads, citing a number of recent ransom-motivated kidnapping of drivers in the region.
3 January 2020: Peaceful protests were held by Muslim protesters in Bahir Dar denouncing the burning of mosques and muslim-owned businesses in Mota town a week prior.
On 4 January 2020, youths supporting President Kenyatta disrupted the press briefing of Kandara MP Alice Wahome in Malindi town (Malindi, Kilifi).
On 5 January 2020, residents stormed the police station in Yamumbi near Eldoret town (Moiben, Uasin Gushu) to demand the arrest of gang members they said had been terrorizing them.
On 5 January 2020, angry residents blocked (means unspecified) the road into Kawangware (Nairobi - Dagoretti North, Nairobi County) over the poor state of roads.
On 6 January 2020, in Berbera (Berbera, Woqooyi Galbeed), families living in government housing peacefully demonstrated in front of the Mayor office against the high rent imposed on them.
On 6 January 2020, angry parents stormed the Kwenikab Ilet school in Ndarawetta (Bomet County) and ejected the principal due to poor exam results.

On 6 January 2020, People Power supporters gathered in Gayaza (Wakiso district) for a rally in support of the movement and of Bobi Wine MP's run for the presidency. Police arrested several protesters who refused to vacate the area, and fired tear gas upon the crowd.
On 6 January 2020, angry parents prevented the head teacher from accessing Suna primary school in Migori County due to poor test scores.

On or after 7 January 2020, boda boda drivers protested in Mukono town (Mukono district), carrying the body of a colleague (who had been killed after being hit by a commercial taxi) to the police station, and demanding the release of their colleagues who had earlier attempted to mobilise boda drivers for a demonstration.
On 8 January 2020, workers employed by Nairobi County protested outside city hall (Nairobi - Starehe) to demand payment. No further information was available.
On 9 January 2020, traders protested along the railway in Chaka and Karatina in Nyeri County due to being displaced for the revival of the railway.

10 January 2020: Security forces fired on protesting students at Bule Hora university, killing one and injuring at least 12 others. Protesters were demonstrating against action taken by military forces in West Wollega.

On 10 January 2020, pastoralists staged a demonstration in Lwemiyaga (Ssembabule district) in which they attempted to take their cattle to sale at the market, despite a ban due to an outbreak of foot and mouth disease. Police arrested a local MP who organised the demonstration.

On 10 January 2020, 400 miners marched to Ruhaama (Ntungamo district) from surrounding areas, in protest at alleged abuses by police officers directed towards them, and the low prices paid by a mineral trading firm in the area (which has a monopoly on trade).

On 10 January 2020, police used tear gas to disperse MPs who had gathered at the Kilimani police station in Nairobi County to demand the release of an MP that had been arrested following an assault claim against him.
On 12 January 2020, teachers protested in Nairobi against negligence after a teacher was murdered and accused of being involved in crime.

On 13 January 2020, human rights defenders (HRD's) led by Haki Africa demonstrated by carrying banners and waving placards as they marched in the streets of Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), against the move by the transport ministry to reroute port cargo from road to the standard gauge railway (SGR). Police intervened by firing teargas and attacked protesters using clubs to disperse the group. Four people were arrested, and a nation media journalist beaten up during the incident.
On 13 January 2020, anti-corruption activists marched in Kampala. Police intercepted the demonstrators, and arrested 13 organisers.

On 15 January 2020, demonstrators along the Mekelle/Samre road in Hintalo Woreda blocked roads and refused to allow traffic to pass for 4 days, protesting the creation of a new woreda administrative rearrangement that merged Hintalo Wereda with Hiwane wereda.

During the month of January 2020, taxi drivers protested at the Kampala Capital City Authority HQ, calling for authorities to enforce recent changes to taxi stands in the city. The drivers say that some taxi drivers are not respecting the changes, which is penalising those who have adhered to them.
On 15 January 2020, food vendors protested in Kerugoya, Kirinyaga county over harassment by public health workers.

On 16 January 2020, demonstrators along the Mekelle/Samre road in Hintalo Woreda blocked roads and refused to allow traffic to pass for 4 days, protesting the creation of a new woreda administrative rearrangement that merged Hintalo Wereda with Hiwane wereda.
16 January 2020: Protesters in Damobya woreda, Kembata zone marched in the street, demanding that road construction efforts link their district to the Halaba/Sheshamene road.
16 January 2020: Taxi drivers in Addis Ababa conducted a strike and protest, demonstrating against high traffic violation fees.
On 16 January 2020, people demonstrated in Nairobi after a youth was killed during a disagreement with a police officer.
On 16 January 2020, residents and workers protested in Kijabe, Nakuru County, over the Kijabe hospital's decision to fire 200 employees.

On 17 January 2020, members of the Maasai community blocked the Mai Mahiu-Narok road near Suswa town (Kajiado West, Kajiado) accusing the government of failing to resettle them due to construction of the dry port in Mai Mahiu.

On 17 January 2020, demonstrators along the Mekelle/Samre road in Hintalo Woreda blocked roads and refused to allow traffic to pass for 4 days, protesting the creation of a new woreda administrative rearrangement that merged Hintalo Wereda with Hiwane wereda.
On 17 January 2020, a march took place in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) to protest gender violence, taxation, and poverty levels.
On 17 January 2020, residents blocked (means unspecified) the Chebole-Chebango-Kipketii road over bad road conditions in Sotik, Bomet county.

15-18 January 2020: Demonstrators along the Mekelle/Samre road in Hintalo Woreda blocked roads and refused to allow traffic to pass for 4 days, protesting the creation of a new woreda administrative rearrangement that merged Hintalo Wereda with Hiwane wereda.

On 18 January 2020, a section of western leaders protested by staging a parallel rally in Bomani grounds, on the outskirts of Mumias town (Mumias West, Kakamega), against the building bridges initiative rally that was taking place in Bukhungu stadium. Police used teargas to disperse the group.
On 18 January 2020, residents blocked (means unspecified) the Chebole-Chebango-Kipketii road for the second day in a row over bad road conditions in Sotik, Bomet county.
On 19 January 2020, residents blocked (means unspecified) the Chebole-Chebango-Kipketii road for the third day in a row over bad road conditions in Sotik, Bomet county.
