On 20 January 2020, FDC supporters marched in Jinja (Jinja district), but were dispersed by police, who beat an unspecified number of supporters in Masese III slum.

On 20 January 2020, FDC supporters marched in Mbale town (Mbale district) in a belated celebration of the 15 year anniversary of the formation of the party, but were intercepted by police, who also arrested the FDC party chairman.

23 January 2020: Liyu police forces (Somali) opened fire on protesters in Dhobaweyn, Korahe district, Somali zone, killing one person and injuring several more. Protests were sparked after police arrested a prominate Shaykh.

25 January 2020: Students at Gondor university protested the kidnap and dissapearance of several ethnically Amhara students from Dembi Dolo several weeks ago. Police intervened and arrested several of the protesters.
On 26 January 2020, residents protested in Garissa over recent attacks against civilians.
On 27 January 2020, FDC supporters were prevented by riot police from holding a rally in Muhanga (Rukiga district).
On 27 January 2020, FDC supporters were prevented by riot police from holding a rally in Rubanda town (Rubanda district).

28 January 2020: Demonstrators gathered across Amhara region, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university. Protests took place in Debre Markos, Woldia, Debre Birhan, and Bahir Dar.

28 January 2020: hundreds of thousands of demonstrators gathered across Amhara region, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university. Protests took place in Debre Markos, Woldia, Debre Birhan, and Bahir Dar.

28 January 2020: Hundreds of thousands demonstrators gathered across Amhara region, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university. Protests took place in Debre Markos, Woldia, Debre Birhan, and Bahir Dar.
On 28 January 2020, protesters mounted banners along major highways in Nairobi to demand an end to corruption in the judicial system.

28 January 2020: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators gathered across Amhara region, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university. Protests took place in Debre Markos, Woldia, Debre Birhan, and Bahir Dar.
30 January 2020: Protesters in East Hararghe (city not specified) demonstrated against government violence against civilians in Wolegga, West Oromiya region.
On 30 January 2020, legislators marched in Kiambu to demand a judge complete the swearing in of the Kiambu governor.

1 February 2020: Protest rallies were held in Qobe, Shewa Robit, Durbete, Finote Selam, and Bure, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university.

1 February 2020: Protest rallies were held in Gondor, Debre Tabor, Sekaba, Kombolcha and Metema cities, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university.

1 February 2020: Protest rallies were held in Gondor, Debre Tabor, Sekaba, Kombolcha and Metema cities, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university.

1 February 2020: Protest rallies were held in Gondor, Debre Tabor, Sekaba, Kombolcha and Metema cities, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university.

1 February 2020: Protest rallies were held in Gondor, Debre Tabor, Sekaba, Kombolcha and Metema cities, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university.

1 February 2020: Protest rallies were held in Qobe, Gondor, Debre Tabor, Sekaba, Kombolcha and Metema cities, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university.

1 February 2020: Protest rallies were held in Qobe, Gondor, Debre Tabor, Sekaba, Kombolcha and Metema cities, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university.

1 February 2020: Protest rallies were held in Qobe, Gondor, Debre Tabor, Sekaba, Kombolcha and Metema cities, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university.

1 February 2020: Protest rallies were held in Qobe, Gondor, Debre Tabor, Sekaba, Kombolcha and Metema cities, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university.

1 February 2020: Protest rallies were held in Gondor, Debre Tabor, Sekaba, Kombolcha and Metema cities, denouncing the recent kidnap and government mismanagement of information in a case where 21 ethnically Amharic students were taken from a bus as they left Dembi Dolo university.

On 3 February 2020, residents of Odolo village in Morulem subcounty blocked (means unspecified) a road in Rackoko parish (no geographic information found, coordinates for Morulem town, Abim district, used at geoprec2), after their area was once again excluded from road improvement works, and amidst allegations that the engineer in charge of the project was profiting from selling materials required for the road. The demonstration lasted at least three days.
05 February 2020. In Dalsan (Kismaayo, Lower Juba) a peaceful demonstration was held against the clan clashes between the Majeerteen and Owramale clan militia.
5 February 2020: Police forces forcibly removed people campaining for a church to be built in an empty lot in 22 area of Addis Ababa, shooting and killing 2 in the process.
5 February 2020: Protesters gathered in 22 section of Addis Ababa, protesting the killing of 2 persons a few hours prior in a vacant lot. Police fired tear gas to disperse the protesters.

On 5 February 2020, over 800 teachers from several schools demonstrated during a training event at a school in Iganga town (Iganga district), in protest against unwelcome changes to the curriculum, and against a miserly stipend to cover transport to the school. Police intervened and arrested one teacher.

On 8 February 2020, truck drivers blocked the Kampala-Masaka road at Lukaya town (Kalungu district), calling for the release of a colleague of theirs who had been arrested for failing to pay a fine related to avoiding weighing station.

On 8 February 2020, taxi drivers demonstrated in Kabale town (Kabale district), following the decision of the Uganda Road Works Authority to prevent taxi drivers from using part of the road outside of their building.
9 February 2020: Tens of thousands of people took to the streets in Jimma, Oromia, protesting remarks made by the leader of the Oromo Federal Congress (OFC) in a recent conference.

On or before 11 February 2020, parents and students of a primary school in Kasongi in Lugusuulu subcounty (Mawogola, Ssembabule) protested following the unexpected movement of the schools' headteacher to Ntuusi subcounty, calling for authorities to leave the headmaster in place.

On 11 February 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held in Wajaale (Gebiley, Woqooyi Galbeed) after land that was given to be used as a public cemetery was allegedly sold to private property developers.

On 13 February 2020, locals, including the chairman of the business community, protested against the construction work at the city cemetery in Wajaale town (Gebiley, Woqooyi Galbeed). The police beat some protesters with baton sticks and at least 19 were arrested.

On 13 February 2020, taxi drivers demonstrated in Kabale town (Kabale district) following the decision of the Uganda Road Works Authority to prevent taxi drivers from using part of the road outside of their building. Police used tear gas and live rounds into the air to disperse the demonstrators, who had blocked the roads.

On 14 February 2020, over 500 casual workers from a tungsten mine in Karra parish (Rubanda district) demonstrated following the abrupt closure of the mine by its international owners, which has left many without an income. Police prevented the demonstrators from marching to Rubanda town to lodge their grievances.

On 14 February 2020, Democratic Party youth protested (and interrupted) at a party meeting which they believed would remove the Party Organising Secretary (supposedly on the grounds that he supported the People Power movement). The demonstration happened in the Mengo area of Kampala. Police were deployed, but did not become involved.
On 16 February 2020, traders who supplied goods to the Kenya Prisons Service protested in Nairobi over missing payments.
On 19 February 2020, over 100 residents of the Mount Elgon constituency marched in Bungoma (Khalaba, Kanduyi, Bungoma) to demand action regarding a rise in donkey theft.

On 20 February 2020, over 60 residents of rural areas around Njeru demonstrated in Njeru town (Buikwe district), calling for compensation after a private company damaged property and crops in their villages.

On 20 February 2020, thousands of people held a peaceful demonstration in Hargeysa (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed) to support the speech of 5th President of Somaliland, Muse Bihi Abdi's made in front of MPs.
On 20 February 2020, at least 200 contractors demonstrated in Mbale (Lugaga-Wamuluma, Vihiga) over unresolved debts.

On 20 February 2020, workers, drawn from various trade unions, demonstrated by holding hands and singing in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu), against delayed pay of their salaries. The workers demanded the governor to help them address the matter.

21 February 2020: Thousands of people gathered in Hawassa (Sidama, Southern Nations), demonstrating their support of PM Abiy Ahmed and his Prosperity Party in addition to the successful referrendum and creation of Sidama state.
On 23 February 2020, Christian protesters marched in Ngora (Ngora district), amidst a dispute over elections for the position of Bishop in the area. Police arrested over 30 demonstrators.
On 23 February 2020, Christian protesters marched in Kumi (Kumi district), amidst a dispute over elections for the position of Bishop in the area.

On 24 February 2020, 64 contracted workers protested by waving placards and whistling at Pumwani maternity hospital (Kamukunji, Nairobi), against delayed pay. The group demanded the hospital administration to pay their salaries.

On 24 February 2020, police fired tear gas and live rounds (assumed aerial fire) in Kabale town (Kabale district) at People Power supporters participating in a rally, held amidst student elections at the University in Kabale.
On 24 February 2020, over two hundred residents held a demonstration in Chepchoina (Endebess,Trans Nzoia) over police harassment and illegal evictions.
On 25 February 2020, residents protested over the poor state of roads between Homa Bay and Ndiwa (Homa Bay).

On 25 February 2020, a section of Kenya prison service suppliers demonstrated by carrying banners and chanting as they marched in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), against the delayed pay for their supplies. Police intervened and fired teargas to disperse the demonstrators.
On 26 February 2020, salt mine workers in Afar zone, Afdera woreda protested after a company executive recently accused of a violation was dropped from a prosecution list.

On 26 February 2020, residents of Kyagunda village in Bukulula subcounty (Kalungu district) blocked a road required by a Chinese infrastructure contractor, following complaints that the drivers of the company were damaging houses and crops in the area, and driving recklessly.

On 26 February 2020, FDC members protested in Jinja town (Jinja district), following the arrest of the former party leader earlier that day (he had been due to address a rally). There is no further information.

On 27 February 2020, several peaceful protests were held in Belet Xaawo (Belet Xaawo, Gedo) against the interference of Kenya and the reinforcements from the Jubaland Forces to support the rebelling Jubaland Minister of Security, Abdirashid Janan, who recently escaped from prison in Mogadishu.
On 27 February 2020, residents demonstrated in Chebunyo (Chepalungu, Bomet) against the county government's decision to stop the desilting of a major dam in the area.

On 28 February 2020, security forces opened fire on protesters in Tum town, Bench Maji woreda, killing 6. Protesters had flooded the streets, demonstrating against the recent arrest of woreda officials by federal troops.
On 29 February 2020, people who came to meet Oromo Federal Congress officials for a discussion in Adama city (Nazreth) protested after being denied entry to the venue by police forces.
Around 1 March 2020, or 29 February 2020, residents of Kasese town (Kasese district) demonstrated against a shortage of medicines at the local government health centre.
On 2 March 2020, over 200 hotel workers protested in Diani (Gombato Bongwe, Msambweni, Kwale) over salary demands.

On 2 March 2020, students and parents of Jamhuri primary school demonstrated by waving placards and twigs as they camped outside the office of the regional commissioner in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru), against devil worshipping and religious and tribal discrimination in the school. The group demanded the headteacher to be transferred.
On 3 March 2020, traders demonstrated in Kampala, following repeated electricity blackouts in Luwum street.
On 3 March 2020, students demonstrated in Moroto (Moroto district), due to a lack of clean water at the school.
On 5 March 2020, hundreds of residents protested at the Mokowe water office in Mokowe (Lamu West, Lamu) over a lack of water.
On 5 March 2020, police used tear gas to disrupt traders protesting in Eldoret (Kapsoya, Ainabkoi, Uasin Gishu) against extortion by police.

On 6 March 2020, striking Ugandan bus drivers demonstrated at the Elegu-Nimule border post (presumed to be in Elegu, Amuru district), after a group of South Sudanese money exchangers attacked and broke the arm of a Ugandan bus driver in Nimule.

On 6 March 2020, students demonstrated against poor conditions at a college in Bungoma town (Bungoma district). Police fired tear gas into dwellings, and were filmed beating students who appeared to have been forced to lie on the ground.
On 9 March 2020, taxi drivers protested at the Kampala Capital City Authority HQ, calling for authorities to enforce recent changes to taxi stands in the city, following a similar protest in January.

On 9 March 2020, hundreds of Kibos sugar company employees protested in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the closure of the sugar factory by the national environment management authority over pollution claims. The group demanded the governor help address the matter.

On 10 March 2020, lawyers marched in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega), following the killing of a colleague. The demonstrators accused police of being responsible for the surge in insecurity in the county.
On 14 March 2020, residents held a protest in Sokota town, Wag Hamra, denouncing the delay of the trial of an official accused of corruption.
On 14 March 2020 (or possibly on 15 March 2020), demonstrators gathered in Jinja (Jinja district) to protest against the poor quality of the roads in the area.

On 15 March 2020, People Power and FDC supporters demonstrated after police were deployed at student elections underway in Kyambogo University (Kampala). Police fired tear gas and live rounds (likely in the air) to disperse the demonstrators.
On 16 March 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held in Mogadishu (Mogadishu city, Banadir), over the recent killing of people in an explosion.

On 17 March 2020, butchers protested in Kabale (Kabale district), after the abattoir constructed by local authorities was deemed to have failed to meet basic safety standards due to a lack of running water.
On 19 March 2020, locals held a demonstration in Borana zone, Borbor woreda, demanding that the woreda administrator be removed from power.

On 19 March 2020, members of the Ciise Mohamoud sub clan blocked the Garowe municipality road (Garoowe, Nugaal), demonstrating in opposition to recent security activities and evictions of their clan elders from the municipal area.

On 21 March 2020, traders protested after the Kenyan government decided to charge an access fee to the stadium they were forcibly relocated to in Kisumu (Market Milimani, Kisumu Central, Kisumu). The traders were forcibly relocated as part of a greater effort to prevent the spread of coronavirus.
On 21 March 2020, the local population staged a peaceful protest in Baidoa town (Baydhaba, Bay), in support of the newly selected South West State Parliament members.

On 24 March 2020, around hundreds of IDPs staged a demonstration in front of the Burco municipality offices, complaining against the destruction of their homes by local authorities (Burco, Togdheer). Protesters were arrested by Somaliland police forces and some casualties reported.

On 26 March 2020, students from the Hawassa university's extension in Yirga Alem protested after university officials cancelled transportation assistance after the university was shut down due to coronavirus. As many as 50 students were treated for injuries after police forces intervened to break up the protest and at least one student was shot. No fatalities.
On 26 March 2020, Tuk Tuk drivers staged a demonstration and blocked main roads linking Dabka Junction and Benadir Junction in Mogadishu - Hawl Wadaag (Banadir).
Around 30 March 2020 (week of), residents demonstrated in Nakuru (Nakuru Town East, Nakuru) after a man was fatally assaulted by police. Police claimed it was a mob-related attack.

On 1 April 2020, protesters gathered in Mukono (Mukono district) to contest the delayed issue of travel permits. Bodyguards of the police commissioner attacked a journalist covering the protest, ostensible as part of coronavirus lockdown enforcement measures.

Around 2 April 2020, or 1 April 2020, market vendors demonstrated against the closure of the market in Kalerwe (Kampala), which had been closed on the grounds that it represented a public health risk and facilitated the spreading of coronavirus. Police dispersed the demonstrators through unspecified means.
On 3 April 2020, auto-rickshaws drivers staged a protest against illegal taxation in Afgooye town (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle). The event remained peaceful.

On 4 April 2020, 'big numbers' of residents blocked roads with large rocks in Koti, west of Kapchorwa town (Kapchorwa district), after authorities closed the Koti trading centre for not abiding by coronavirus social distancing measures. UPDF and LDU paramilitaries fired live rounds at the demonstrators, seriously wounding a teenage girl who was shot in the neck.

On 4 April 2020, villagers demonstrated in Nyahera in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) when police tried to remove a body of a young girl who was killed in a suspected ritual killing. Demonstrators demanded that police get to the bottom of the killing of girls in the area. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd.

On 4 April 2020, widows of deceased SNAF soldiers staged a small scale protest at the El Gab checkpoint near the entrance of Villa Somalia in Mogadishu - Wardhigley (Banadir). They protested against the absence of support from the FGS.

Around 5 April 2020 (as reported), villagers gathered at a farm in Kajiado (Kajiado Central, Kajiado), armed with sticks and rungus, and demanded that workers who arrived during the night leave due to coronavirus outbreak fears.

On 6 April 2020, health workers (including doctors and nurses) and medicine-delivery drivers demonstrated at the Ministry of Health HQ in Kampala, against the failure of authorities to distribute travel exemption stickers, without which workers have been unable to pass coronavirus security checkpoints.

On 10 April 2020, armed clan militiamen from the Bahortable sub-clan of Isse Mohamud protested at the mayor's office and blocked all the roads leading to the area in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal). They were demanding compensation after demolition of buildings next to the mayor's office.

On 10 April 2020, worshippers protested and chanted slogans like 'God is great' in Mogadishu - Hamar Weyne (Banadir) in support of an imam who refused a police request to close the mosque doors under coronavirus restrictions.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), residents of Nchooro near Tigania (Tigania West, Meru) demonstrated, accusing the chief of bias during the allocation of relief to those in need during the coronavirus curfew.

On 15 April 2020, vendors demonstrated in Busia town (Busia district), after police attempted to enforce coronavirus lockdown measures (which would have closed a number of stalls). Police dispersed the vendors with tear gas and live rounds (presumed to have been fired over the heads of the vendors).

On 17 April 2020, journalists working in Mogadishu staged a protest in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir), demanding the release of Goobjoog news editor who was arrested last week. The event remained peaceful.

On 20 April 2020, market vendors demonstrated at the RDC's office in Mbarara town (Mbarara district), in opposition to the ongoing closure of their market, which has been shut due to coronavirus lockdown measures.
On 20 April 2020, residents of Namungoona (Kampala) demonstrated, calling for the government to distribute coronavirus relief food. Police arrested two demonstrators.

On 22 April 2020, over twenty residents (including boda boda drivers) demonstrated at the LC1 chairperson's office in Kasese town (Kasese district), calling for the government to distribute food relief. The group comprises poor and disabled groups, who have been unable to obtain food due to coronavirus lockdown measures.

On 22 April 2020, two mothers and their eleven children camped outside the RDC office in Luwero (Luwero district) in protest at the lack of food and income engendered by the coronavirus lockdown measures. The protest lasted for two days, before the demonstrators were given food, and left the office.

On 23 April 2020, supporters of the RDC for Jinja demonstrated in Jinja town (Jinja district) upon hearing news that he had been arrested in connection with a murder case. Police dispersed the supporters with tear gas.

On 24 April 2020, local residents staged a demonstration and blocked a bus carrying passengers coming from a funeral from entering the village of Kalyet (Kipkelion West, Kericho), due to coronavirus fears.
On 24 April 2020, several local residents protested against growing insecurity in Mogadishu - Kaxda (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle).

On 25 April 2020, hundreds protested against the killing of 2 civilians by security personnel (police) during enforcing night-time curfew in Mogadishu - Bondhere (Banadir). The protesters blocked all road to Juba junction and demanded from the government to abolish the night curfew.
On 27 April 2020, people staged a protest against the government operations disarming the clan members of Habar Yonis and Habar Jeclo in Sanaag town (Ceerigaabo, Sanaag).

On 27 April 2020, women demonstrated over the theft of their underwear in Muranga county (Kiharu, Muranga). It is suspected that the theft was linked to the making of face masks during the coronavirus curfew.

On 28 April 2020, 20 youths demonstrated at the RDC's office in Luwero (Luwero district), after loosing their income due to coronavirus lockdown measures. Police arrested 2, and the remaining demonstrators fled.

On 29 April 2020, a section of residents of Samburu west constituency demonstrated by singing and waving twigs [coded to county HQ: Maralal, Samburu Central, Samburu], against the move by the government to evict them from the forests. The group demanded the area leaders to help address the matter.

Around 1 May 2020 (week of), about 60 refugees held a sit in demonstration at the United Nations High Commission for Refugees-run camp in Kakuma (Turkana West, Turkana), demanding to be relocated due to insecurity.
On 1 May 2020, public service vehicle operators, protested in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru), against poor sanitation at the bus terminal. Police cordoned off the terminal.
On 3 May 2020, local journalists held rallies in Mogadishu (Mogadishu City, Banadir) to protest against their working conditions.

On 4 May 2020, around 30 Ethiopian refugees and asylum seekers protested on the roadside between ministry of finance and the Presidential palace in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed). The refugees were complaining against an UN office for not providing support in terms of food and shelter for them.

On 4 May 2020, residents of Kasese district (including widows) demonstrated at the RDC's office in Kasese town (Kasese district), calling for food relief. The protesters claimed that food relief (distributed under coronavirus lockdown measures) was not reaching them, and was instead being sent to those who were less in need.

On 4 May 2020, about 500 residents of Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi) blocked police from taking the body of a man who was allegedly killed by police while enforcing the coronavirus curfew. The demonstrators then took the body to the police station, demanding justice. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd.

On 5 May 2020, a group of people mainly women and youth staged a protest in Dinsoor town in support of the release of the former district commissioner of Dinsoor who had been in Baidoa prison for months (Diinsoor, Bay). The protesters were chanting slogans in support of the former DC and appreciation of the South-West President.

On 6 May 2020, traders protested at Burma market in Nairobi (Nairobi - Kamukunji), against the arrest of one of their leaders (assistant chairman). The group demanded the police to produce their leader, whom they say they have been unable to trace since his arrest.
On 7 May 2020, public service vehicles (matatu) operators (coded as taxi drivers) blocked (through unspecified means) the outering road at Kariobangi (Ruaraka, Nairobi), for unknown reasons.
On 7 May 2020, hundreds of Eastleigh residents (Kamukunji, Nairobi) demonstrated following the implementation of a partial coronavirus lockdown in the area.

On 10 May 2020, over 100 families camped outside the house of Betty Aol Ocan (the Leader of the Opposition) in Gulu (Gulu district), in protest at the lack of food that has been provided under coronavirus relief measures.
On 11 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Eastleigh (Kamukunji, Nairobi), demanding mass testing and food relief during the coronavirus curfew.
On 11 May 2020, boda boda and taxi drivers protested at the office of the RDC in Wakiso town (Wakiso district), decrying the lack of food provided under coronavirus relief measures.
On 11 May 2020, over 80 health workers protested against a lack of pay owed to them at Kuluva hospital (Arua district), and announced they were on strike.

On 12 May 2020, local residents blocked the Kitale - Lowdwar highway using logs and stones while carrying woods at Kipsaina (Cherengany, Trans Nzoia), in demonstration against the area Chief who is alleged to be behind the unclear death of a suspect. The group demanded the minister for internal security and the inspector general of police to help address the matter.

On 13 May 2020, residents protested in Ngurubani town (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) against delayed implementation of development projects as well as delayed pay of health workers by the county government. Police intervened and arrested 30 protestors.

On 14 May 2020, a section of youth under the Kazi mtaani initiative stormed into the chief's office in Kosovo area of Mathare (Ruaraka, Nairobi), in demonstration against unpaid dues within the context of coronavirus help. The youth demanded those in charge to ensure transparency in the exercise.
On 14 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Eldoret (Ainabkoi, Uasin Gishu) after stray dogs attacked and killed a man. Following the demonstration, a group of youth went to kill 8 dogs.

On 14 May 2020, residents of Mukono district (including women, who are prominent in the source) blocked a vehicle carrying a local official at Wantoni (Mukono district) in protest at not receiving food under coronavirus relief measures. Police and LDUs arrived and allowed the official to complete his journey, though do not appear to have intervened directly.
On 14 May 2020, a section of health workers protested by singing solidarity song in Embu (Manyatta, Embu), against delayed salaries. The group demanded to be paid by May 18th, 2020.

On 15 May 2020, over 60 HIV positive residents of Gulu town (Gulu district) protested at the house of a local official in the town, decrying the lack of food provided under coronavirus relief measures.

On 16 May 2020, around thirty Hargeisa municipality employees protested in front of their office against unpaid salaries for the last five months in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed). Police dispersed them and there were no reports of causalities.

On 16 May 2020, residents of the Bureti sub-county, Chemosot ward, took to the streets in Chemosot, coded to Litiik (Tebesonik, Bureti, Kericho) to protest against the poor road network in the area. They lamented that the bad state of the road had hampered their business activities.

On 18 May 2020, protesters - including a prominent feminist critic of the President - gathered in Kampala to contest abuses by state security organs during the coronavirus lockdown and a lack of food being distributed to the public. Police forcefully arrested five (including the prominent critic).

Around 19 May 2020 (as reported), villagers of Lari (Lari, Kiambu) demonstrated after a newly opened dam in a nearby village flooded the village. The demonstrators accused residents of the nearby village of placing them in danger.
On 21 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Rongo (Rongo, Migori), accusing police of poor performance after a journalist was attacked with a heavy object by two unknown assailants.

On 21 May 2020, South Sudanese students held a demonstration outside of the South Sudanese embassy in Addis Ababa (Bole Subcity) after embassy staff failed to pay student stipends. Ethiopian police forces intervened to break up the demonstration, injuring at least 7 of the students.

On 21 May 2020, truck drivers barricaded the Bungoma-Malaba highway (Kanduyi, Bungoma) leading to Uganda. The demonstrators accused Ugandan authorities of harassment and discrimination. They were demanding the release of a truck driver detained in Uganda due to testing positive for the coronavirus and the release of their tests taken a week before.

On 25 May 2020, local residents took to the streets in Lukolis market in Teso (coded as Ochude, Amukura Central, Teso South, Busia) against police brutality and corruption. They barricaded (means unspecified) a road, demanding the transfer of police officers who allegedly caused two deaths the week before.
Around 26 May 2020 (week of), several protests were reported across the Tigray region (locations unspecified). Protesters denounced the lack of jobs, regional governance, and boundaries.
On 26 May 2020, residents demonstrated in Ukwala (Ugenya, Siaya) over the delayed completion of a bridge.

On 26 May 2020, over 200 boda boda drivers protested at District HQ in Kabale (Kabale district), calling for the government to provide them with food following the reduction of their income due to coronavirus lockdown measures.

On 27 May 2020, residents protested in Hintalo Awajirat district (Tigray) against the local governance and decisions to close roads and re-organize local governance boundaries. Protests were peaceful and no clashes or interventions were reported.

On 28 May 2020, journalists protested at the office of the Resident District Commissioner in Kabale (Kabale district), against harassment by authorities under the pretext of coronavirus lockdown measures.

On 29 May 2020, residents staged a public protest in Balcad town (Balcad, Middle Shabelle) against the killing of eight people in Gololey village. The protestors including elders demanded appropriate investigation and justice for the killing of the local youth.

On 30 May 2020, over a hundred residents staged a public protest in Balanbale village (Cabudwaaq, Galgaduud) against the Galmudug state president over resource allocation, from which the village had been left out. The protestors, including elders, demanded appropriate allocation of resources.

On 31 May 2020, members of the local community peacefully protested against a political party (known as KAAH Party) that wanted to open a new office in Godob Jiiran area in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal). Local authorities and elders intervened, and the office was subsequently opened without any incident.

Around 31 May 2020 (as reported), Konyu ward member of county assembly (MCA), backed by his fellow colleagues protested against the move by the police to block him from eulogizing his wife (in observance with coronavirus protocols) [coded as Ndimaini, Mathira East, Nyeri]. The group demanded the police to allow him pay tribute to his wife.

On 1 June 2020, over 200 Alur demonstrators marched towards Pakwach from Nwoya district, in protest at abuses inflicted upon Alur residents of the area by security forces in a violent land dispute. The demonstrators were stopped before they crossed Pakwach bridge between Nwoya and Pakwach districts by police and UPDF.

On 2 June 2020, over 200 workers from the water facility at Katosi (Mukono district) demonstrated upon discovering that parts of their salaries had been withheld, and without explanation. Police persuaded the protesters to leave (but did not intervene directly), after assuring the demonstrators they would investigate that the matter with the managers of the plant.

On 2 June 2020, a group of people from the Masaai community demonstrated in Masimba (Kenyawa-poka, Kajiado East, Kajiado) over increased attacks by wild animals. 9 GSU police officers shot at the crowd and killed 4 people.
Around 2 June 2020 (as reported), about 300 people demonstrated in Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi) after police fatally shot a homeless man who works at Marikiti market.

On 2 June 2020, about 20 demonstrators gathered outside the US Embassy in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) to demonstrated over the death of an African-American man in Minneapolis police custody, in support of the Black Lives Matter movement, as well as police brutality and extrajudicial killings in Kenya. Police intervened.
On 3 June 2020, residents demonstrated in Bomet (Bomet East, Bomet) after three people were attacked by people who pretended to be animals.
On 3 June 2020, women marched in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), calling for peace ahead of the polls.
On 8 June 2020, locals comprising of women, youths and elders in Caynabo town (Caynabo, Sool) staged a protestest supporting the President's last speech in parliament on elections matters.

On 8 June 2020, locals comprising of women, youths and elders in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari) staged a protestest supporting the President's last speech in parliament on elections matters. Puntland police dispersed the protesters. Two people were injured in the incident.
On 8 June 2020, the local administration organized a peaceful protest gathering in support of the FGS President's speech given at the Somali federal parliament in Doolow town (Doolow, Gedo).

On 8 June 2020, around 200 people demonstrated by waving placards, as they marched to Huruma police station (Ruaraka, Nairobi) against police brutality since the imposed national coronavirus curfew. Police intervened and fired teargas to disperse the group.

On 9 June 2020, hundreds of Badhan (Ceerigaabo, Sanaag) residents took the streets to show their support for the Somalia federal government, the rally was peaceful and the protestors left the streets voluntarily.

On 9 June 2020, the local administration organized a peaceful protest gathering in support of the FGS President's speech given at the Somali federal parliament in Belet Weyne town (Belet Weyne, Hiraan).
On 10 June 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held against the Prosperity Party and the regional president of the Somali region in Kebri Dehar (Somali), over dissatisfaction with the government.
On 10 June 2020, a peaceful demonstration against the Prosperity Party was held in Gawo Kebe (West Wellega), over dissatisfaction with the government.

On 10 June 2020, truck drivers demonstrated in Fort Portal (Kabarole district), denouncing the failure of local authorities to clean drainage ditches at their lorry park, which have filled with stagnant water.
On 11 June 2020, a peaceful demonstration was held against the Prosperity Party and the regional president of the Somali region in Jijiga (Somali), over dissatisfaction with the government.
On 11 June 2020, nearly 700 people demonstrated in Kutus (Mwea, Kirinyaga) to urge the senate to uphold the impeachment of Kirinyaga County governor.
On 11 June 2020, youth (including boda boda drivers) demonstrated in Arua (Arua district) against restrictions placed upon bodas under coronavirus guidelines.

On 13 June 2020, local people including women, youths and mosque leader staged a protest for opening a mosque which was closed for the spreading Al shabaab idealogies in Guri-Ceel town (Dhuusamarreeb, Galgaduud). Somali Armed Forces soldiers stopped the protest which was organized by local authorities and several protesters were arrested.

On 14 June 2020, residents in Nakuru (Nakuru Town East, Nakuru) demonstrated at the police station after a man who was arrested, committed suicide. The demonstrators accused police of murdering the man.
On 15 June 2020, Djiboutian citizens held a protest sit-in in Dire Dawa (Dire Dawa) to demand the end of Guelleh's Regime in Djibouti.
On 15 June 2020, residents marched in Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi) against police brutality during the national coronavirus curfew.

Around 15 June 2020 (as reported), community members demonstrated along the Marsabit-Isiolo highway near Marsabit (Saku, Marsabit) after four people from the Rendilles group were killed in a suspected tribal attack.

On 15 June 2020, matatu operators blocked the highway in Rironi (Limuru, Kiambu) with more than 300 vehicles. The demonstration was against the mounting of a roadblock which they say has interrupted their business.

On 15 June 2020, a peaceful protest took place in Buuhoodle town (Buuhoodle, Togdheer). The demonstrators were complaining that they were not represented nor included in the Somalia and Somaliland consultative summit in Djibouti.

On 16 June 2020, protestors took to the streets exhibiting their support for Somaliland president speech during the Somalia and Somaliland consultative summit in Caynabo town (Caynabo, Sool). The speech stated that Somalia and the international community should recognize Somaliland's sovereignty and Independence.

On 17 June 2020, residents protested against the committee for the preparedness and response of coronavirus over the mishandling of dead bodies in Heedho village (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed). They reiterated that the committee should be held liable for the cremation and dumping of suspected coronavirus dead bodies in a dry river in the village.

On 19 June 2020, around hundreds of residents protested new changes by local authorities in Bosaso town, by block the main roads in Lanta Hawada village (Bossaso, Bari). The protest was prompted by local authories appointing new officers from one clan only.

On 20 June 2020, local residents protested against the regional office and the office of Minister of Interior in Laag village (Bossaso, Bari) over recent appointments. Putland Police Force personnel shot at and beat protesters. One person was killed and several others injured.
On 21 June 2020, protesters demonstrated against the poor ambulance service in Orom sub-county, and an unspecified location within the Orom area (Kitgum district).

On 22 June 2020, about 50 youths whose application to join the NISA training was turned down protested against the decision in Belet Weyne town (Belet Weyne, Hiraan). The local elders intervened and reconciled with the protesters.

On 22 June 2020, demonstrators, led by the FDC party chairman for Buikwe district, protested by banding pots and pans at a market in Lugazi (Buikwe district), as part of a joint People Power and FDC initiative to broadcast levels of hunger in the country and highlight the failure of authorities to provide coronavirus relief food. A mob of market vendors assaulted the demonstrators, wounding three. Two other protesters were arrested by police.

On 23 June 2020, local residents protested against local government land allocation for public institution in Gabiley town (Gebiley, Woqooyi Galbeed). The protesters accused the officials of panning to sell the land. Police forces fired live bullets to disperse the crowd. Two police officers were injured (means unknown).

On 24 June 2020, over 100 protesters marched from Aboko village to Aduku (Kwania district), in opposition to the recent arrest of seven suspects relating to a lynch mob attack in December. Police dispersed the demonstrators with live rounds (presumed to be fired into the air).

On 24 June 2020, taxi drivers staged a peaceful protest against the local authorities over poor roads in Guri-Ceel town (Dhuusamarreeb, Galgaduud). The drivers stopped working and demanded the rehabilitation of the roads and vowed not to pay their taxes.
On 24 June 2020, hundreds of boda boda drivers demonstrated against the poor state of the Kitale-Endebess road in Endebess sub county (Endebess, Trans Nzoia).

On 26 June 2020, a legal officer with People Power mobilised protesters, including boda boda drivers, at Iganda (Iganda district), to criticise the government for failing to provide food under its coronavirus relief measures, whilst also calling for boda drivers to be permitted to work in the evenings (currently prohibited due to the partial lockdown). Police arrested the People Power mobiliser.
On 26 June 2020, journalists protested outside of the Radio Wa offices in Lira (Lira district), calling for the director of the station to be removed due to alleged mismanagement and nepotism.
On 26 June 2020, residents demonstrated in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) over a power outage which has lasted for one and a half months.

On 28 June 2020, over hundreds of local youths, women and Govt officials staged a peaceful protest at Daljir Dahsoon village in Mogadishu-Bondhere district (Bondhere, Banadir), supporting the decisions of the parliament of giving 13 elective seat to Banadir region to represent in the Upper house. This protest was organized by the local authorities.

On 29 June 2020, protesters demonstrated in Munyonyo (Kampala) against the demolition of a local market. Police from the Environment Protection unit arrested a protesting DP MP, who they accused of 'inciting violence'.

On 30 June 2020, federal police in Ambo city (Oromia) fired live rounds into crowds of demonstrators. Figures from a local hospital indicate at least 9 fatalities occurred as a result of the event, with 10 additional wounded in critical condition. Demonstrators demanded that the body of a popular Oromo musician, killed the day before, be buried in the capital city of Addis Ababa.

On 30 June 2020, at least 5 demonstrators were killed and 75 injured by federal police in Adama city (Nazreth), Oromia region, following the death of a popular Oromo musician. An additional 4 bodies were received by the hospital in Adama on the same day. Fatalities coded as 9.
On 30 June 2020, boda boda drivers demonstrated in Bududa town (Bududa district) against violent police behaviour towards them in the context of upholding the coronavirus lockdown.
On 30 June 2020, demonstrators gathered to protest outside of the US embassy (Gullele, Addis Ababa) during unrest over the killing of a popular Oromo artist.

On 30 June 2020, at least 2 protesters were killed by federal police in Chiro town, Oromia region, following the death of a popular Oromo musician. Additional details around the deaths of the protesters are unknown.

On 1 July 2020, an unknown number of protesters were killed when security forces opened fire on demonstrators in Iteya (Oromia), protesting in the aftermath of the killing of a popular Oromo musician. At least 70 were confirmed injured in the attack. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.
On 1 July 2020, security forces opened fire on protesters demanding that leaders of the Oromo Federalist Congress be released in Holeta town, Oromia. The source did not mention fatalities.

On 1 July 2020, male patients under quarantine (as a coronavirus precaution measure) in Masaka hospital (Masaka district) protested against a lack of food and the introduction of new patients with existing ones. The patients banged doors and windows, and were reported to have caused a stampede.
On 1 July 2020, security forces opened fire on protesters in Neqemt, demonstrating in the aftermath of the killing of a popular Oromo musician. 3 protesters were killed and several more injured.

On 1 July 2020, a section of youth demonstrated by marching to a member of parliament's office in Mathare (Ruaraka, Nairobi), against the selection process for the Kazi Mtaani initiative. The youth demanded the MP to address their grievances.

On 2 July 2020, at least 2 people were shot and killed by police forces in Ambo (West Shewa, Oromia) as they attempted to restricted demonstrators from attending the funeral of a popular Oromo musician who was killed in Addis Ababa a few days earlier. 7 others were injured in the event.
On 2 July 2020, local residents staged a protest in Sirisia (Malakisi, Sirisia, Bungoma) over the sentencing of the MP they supported who was jailed for 67 years.

On 3 July 2020, demonstrators blocked (means unspecified) a street in Fort Portal (Kabarole district) with rocks, to highlight the failure of the contractor undertaking roadworks to limit dust, coating the area in dust.

On 5 July 2020, hundreds of residents in gathered on Daljirka Dahsoon monument protesting against the Somali government and the leadership of the President in Mogadishu - Bondhere district (Banadir). Soldiers used live bullets to disperse the protesters.

On 7 July 2020, about 50 local youths protested in Belet Weyne town (Belet Weyne, Hiraan), against the decision of the parliament to transfer two elective seats to Jowhar. The seats were previously under Belet Weyne district.

On 7 July 2020, hundreds of activists staged the annual Saba Saba march in several areas in Nairobi, including Dandora (coded separately) and Kiamaiko (Nairobi - Ruaraka), Kayole (coded separately), and Mathare (coded separately) demanding an end to police brutality during the enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds and arrested 56.

On 7 July 2020, hundreds of activists staged the annual Saba Saba march in several areas in Nairobi, including Kayole (coded separately), Mathare (Nairobi - Mathare), Dandora (coded separately) and Kiamaiko (coded separately), demanding an end to police brutality during the enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds and arrested 56.

On 7 July 2020, hundreds of activists staged the annual Saba Saba march in several areas in Nairobi, including Kayole (coded separately), Mathare (coded separately), and Dandora (Nairobi - Embakasi North) and Kiamaiko (coded separately), demanding an end to police brutality during the enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds and arrested 56.

On 7 July 2020, hundreds of activists staged the annual Saba Saba march in several areas in Nairobi, including Kayole (Nairobi - Embakasi Central), Mathare (coded separately), Dandora (coded separately) and Kiamaiko (coded separately), demanding an end to police brutality during the enforcement of the national coronavirus curfew. Police used teargas to disperse the crowds and arrested 56.

Around 7 July 2020 (as reported), a group of elderly women demonstrated in Mundoro village (Gatundu South, Kiambu) after their tenants defaulted on rent, demanding the tenants to leave their property.

On 8 July 2020, about hundreds of people staged a protest after police arrested the district youth chairman at Afgooye police station in Xaawo-Cabdi village (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle). The police forces dispersed the protesters and arrested some of the protesters.

On 8 July 2020, demonstrators (including market vendors, and a prominent academic activist) protested against the effects of the coronavirus lockdown measures on the income of vendors in Nakasero (Kampala). Police arrested the prominent academic.

On 10 July 2020, around 200 FDC supporters gathered for a rally in the Kasokoso neighbourhood of Kampala (Wakiso district). Police fired tear gas and live rounds (presumed to have been fired into the air) to disperse the crowds and arrested 3, including the speaker of the FDC, ostensibly as part of coronavirus reinforcement measures.
On 10 July 2020, Puntland police forces protested in Qardho town (Qardho, Bari) over delayed salaries of several months.

On 11 July 2020, over hundreds of people protested in front of the Karan district office in Mogadishu-Karan district (Karan, Banadir), accusing Govt security forces of looting their land and other properties.
On 11 July 2020, more than 50 youths staged a rally in Arua (Arua district) in support of a local businessman seeking to run for political office in the city. Police dispersed the youth.
Around 13 July 2020 (as reported), residents demonstrated in Laikipia (Laikipia East, Laikipia) against insecurity in the area following the killing of a teacher by armed men.

On 13 July 2020, a prominent academic and at least two students from Makerere University demonstrated at the parliament building in Kampala, calling for a full investigation into an attack on a student in June (which ultimately killed the student). Police arrested the academic and one of the students.

On 14 July 2020, residents of Kaswanga village demonstrated at the Tom Mboya Level IV Hospital in Rusinga Islands (Homa Bay Town, Homa Bay) against the change of the hospital to a coronavirus isolation center.

On 15 July 2020, sugarcane drivers blocked a main road in Busia (Busia district) in protest at the recent ban on Ugandan sugarcane imports by Kenyan authorities. Police dispersed the drivers after three hours.

On 15 July 2020, local residents protested by waving twigs and chanting in Kijiwetanga area of Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi), against a three-month blackout. The residents demanded the Kenya power and lighting company (KPLC), to address the issue.

On 17 July 2020, five individuals who had been under quarantine under coronavirus protection measures in Entebbe (Wakiso district) protested against an extension of their quarantine period from 14 days.

On 18 July 2020, women's rights activists demonstrated in Sirende Location near Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia), demanded police action after a man battered his wife several times before leaving her for his partner.

On 19 July 2020, several rickshaw drivers protested in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool) against high license fees introduced by Somaliland authorities. Police (Somaliland) arrested several protesters.
On 20 July 2020, several rickshaw drivers protested in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool) against high license fees introduced by Somaliland authorities.
On 20 July 2020, several vendors demonstrated in Jinja (Jinja district), in opposition to street traders operating near the main market. Police used pepper spray against the protesting vendors.

On 21 July 2020, hundreds of demonstrators marched to the Kibos Sugar Factory in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) after three people were killed in an accident allegedly caused by a worker of the factory. Police dispersed the crowd.

On 23 July 2020, dozens of vendors demonstrated in several shopping arcades in Kampala, in protest at the decision by their landlords to charge them rent despite their shops being closed due to the coronavirus lockdown. Police dispersed traders in at least one area with tear gas.

On 23 July 2020, local residents, mainly boda boda drivers, took to the streets in Katelembo, near Machakos (Machakos, Machakos). They were protesting against the closure of a road that forced them to use alternative routes.
On 24 July 2020, taxi drivers demonstrated at the RDC's office in Mityana town (Mityana district), following the decision by the RDC to prevent elections among the labour group.

Around 24 July 2020 (as reported), residents demonstrated on the Eldoret - Kisumu road near Eldoret (Ainabkoi, Uasin Gishu), demanding the arrest of a man accused of assaulting women and children in the area. The accused was in custody but officers on duty allowed the suspect to go for a short call. He did not return.
On 25 July 2020, locals demonstrated in Garissa (Dujis, Garissa), demanding the release a murder suspect by police. 2 people were fatally shot by police repsonding to the demonstration.

On 28 July 2020, local traders staged a protest to voice concern over increased taxes imposed by the ministry of commerce and the fluctuation of the exchange rate in the Barxada area of Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal). Puntland Police forces fired gunshots to disperse the demonstrators, leaving one person dead and three others injured.

On 28 July 2020, local traders staged a protest in the Barxada area of Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal) to voice concerns over increased taxes imposed by the ministry of commerce and the fluctuation of the exchange rate. One person was killed and three others injured when Putland Police Force personnel fired gunshots to disperse them.

On 29 July 2020, government workers (Puntland office) staged a protest and locked down their office building in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal), demanding their unpaid salaries. Police fired gunshots to disperse the protesters. One person was injured and several people arrested.

On 29 July 2020, government workers (Puntland office) staged a protest and locked down the building, demanding their unpaid salaries in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal). Police fired gunshots to disperse the protesters. One person was injured and several people arrested.

Around 29 July 2020 (as reported), more than 200 residents of several villages in the Butuntumula area blocked (means unspecified) the main highway at Ndibulungi (Luwero district), to demonstrate against pollution caused by a chicken farm operating in the area.

On 30 July 2020, several rickshaw drivers blocked roads (through unspecified means) in protest against acts of violence by security forces at the Via Mohamud Harbi neighborhood in Mogadishu - Bondhere (Banadir).

On 1 August 2020, hundreds of armed youth from Ndeiya took to the streets in Kiambu (Riabai, Kiambu Town, Kiambu) following the attack the day before (coded separately). Kiambu governor and county commissioner convinced them not to retaliate.

On 3 August 2020, more than 50 people peacefully demonstrated and gathered around Daalo Stadium in Ceerigaabo town (Ceerigaabo, Sanaag), against the increasing cost of water in the local municipality.
Around 3 August 2020 (as reported), Matatu operators demonstrated against the recent relocation of a terminus in Nakuru (Nakuru Town East, Nakuru).
On 4 August 2020, local residents took to the streets in Emurua Dikirr (Iikerin, Trans Mara East, Narok), protesting against the conversion of a bridge project to a culvert.
On 4 August 2020, residents blocked (means unspecified) the Mirundi- Kevote road in Embu (Manyatta, Embu) to demonstrate against the slow construction of the road.

Around 4 August 2020 (as reported), over 3000 tea farmers marched to Chemusia centre in Nandi county [coded as Nandi hills, Nandi East, Nandi], against low tea prices. The farmers demanded the price be reverted to the original 30 shillings.
On 4 August 2020, patients in isolation due to the coronavirus demonstrated at the Kericho County Hospital (Ainamoi, Kericho) over a lack of food.

On 5 August 2020, over 70 ex-government soldiers gathered in front of the Jazeera Training facility-TURKSOM barracks in Mogadishu - Wadajir district (Banadir), to demonstrate against disciplinary action decisions, which separated them from the military service.
On 6 August 2020, residents of Hintalo Wajirat, Tigray regional state, staged a protest against local administration. Reason for the protest was unreported.

On 6 August 2020, local residents and activists demonstrated by carrying placards, blowing vuvuzelas and whistling as they marched to the Kenya power and lighting company (KPLC) station in Diani (Msambweni, Kwale), against the electrocution of a woman and a baby. Police intervened though dialogue to restrict the number of protestors to access the KPLC offices, in line with the coronavirus measures.
Around 8 August 2020 (as reported), residents demonstrated in Narok (Narok North, Narok) over the poor state of the roads connecting Olposimoru and Olkurto trading centres.
On 9 August 2020, federal troops opened fire at protesters in Areka Soddo (SNNPR) killing 1. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops.

On 9 August 2020, security forces fired on protesters in Sodo city of Woliayta (SNNPR), killing 4 and wounding 18. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops.
On 9 August 2020, over 40 workers from Aden Ade international airport protested in Mogadishu - Wadajir district (Banadir), over unpaid salaries.
On 9 August 2020, federal troops opened fire at protesters in Bodeti (Soddo, SNNPR), killing 6. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops.

Around 9 August 2020 (as reported), six relatives of an electrician who died in an accident began a sit-in protest at the offices of the electricity firm in Mukono (Mukono district) which had contracted him, demanding the company take responsibility for the death of the man and his co-worker, after the firm distanced themselves from the event.
On 10 August 2020, members of a Tawfik transportation association protested due to an disagreement over the election of a new chairman in Berbera town (Berbera, Woqooyi Galbeed).

On 10 August 2020, 2 people were killed when federal troops opened fire on protesters in Sodo city (Wolayta, SNNPR). Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops.
On 10 August 2020, locals demonstrated in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), demanding the release of a journalist detained in Ethiopia.

On 11 August 2020, about twenty-five Yemeni refugees and their children peacefully protested on the main road leading to the UNHCR office in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed), over a lack of support from the UNHCR office.

On 11 August 2020, security forces fired on protesters in Sodo city of Woliayta (SNNPR), resulting in three fatalities between 11-13 August. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. Fatalities split across three events.
On 12 August 2020, Federal troops shot protesters in Gacheno town (Wolayta, SNNPR), injuring 2. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops.

On 12 August 2020, security forces fired on protesters in Sodo city of Woliayta (SNNPR), resulting in three fatalities between 11-13 August. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. Fatalities split across three events.
On 12 August 2020, community members demonstrated in Mukong'a village in Kitui county (Kitui Central, Kitui) to protest against water shortages in the area.

On 13 August 2020, security forces fired on protesters in Sodo city of Woliayta (SNNPR), resulting in three fatalities between 11-13 August. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. Fatalities split across three events.

On 14 August 2020, security forces fired on protesters in Sodo city of Woliayta (SNNPR). Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. According to local medical officials, the total fatalities that occurred in Sodo region between August 9-14 was 21 persons. Fatalities split across events to specific reports of fatalities with that period.

On 16 August 2020, local residents demonstrated by carrying and waving banners, as they marched in Phenom park estate in Langata (Langata, Karen) against being duped by a developer. Joined by their member of parliament (Jubilee Party), the group demanded the developer to honor his promise on social amenities.
On 16 August 2020, local traders protested in Guri-Ceel village (Dhuusamarreeb, Galgaduud) over the new taxes imposed by the Galmudug Ministry of Finance.

On 16 August 2020, local people protested in Salaxley village (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed) against a lack of support from the government after heavy windy rains that caused destruction to their homes and other properties. Somaliland police forces arrested four youth members accused of being behind the protest.

On 17 August 2020, Ethiopian military forces opened fire on protesters in Shashemene town, killing an unspecified number across two days of demonstrations. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus. Unknown fatalities coded as 3 and spread across two days.

On 17 August 2020, Ethiopian security forces opened fire on protesters in Haro Maya (East Harerghe, Oromia), wounding 12 and killing 2. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention.
On 17 August 2020, protesters demonstrated in Ambo city (West Shewa, Oromia), denouncing the arrest of several Oromo leaders.

On 17 August 2020, demonstrators, mostly youth, gathered outside the Maralal police station (Samburu West, Samburu), demanding the release of the Semburu Senator who was arrested and questioned over rising insecurities in the Baragoi area.

On 17 August 2020, demonstrators gathered at the police station in Bungoma (Kanduyi, Bungoma) demanding the immediate transfer of all the senior police officers in the county, claiming that they helped the suspected murderers of a businessman to escape.

On 18 August 2020, Ethiopian military forces opened fire on protesters in Shashemene town, killing an unspecified number across two days of demonstrations. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted the coronavirus. The demonstration has been ongoing for the second day. Unknown fatalities coded as 3 and spread across two days.

On 18 August 2020, Oromia regional special forces forcibly dispersed demonstrators who were blocking roads (using unspecified means) in Bale Robe (Bale, Oromia), following reports that Oromo leaders had contracted coronavirus in detention. No injuries or fatalities reported.

On 18 August 2020, for the second day, Ethiopian security forces opened fire on protesters in Haro Maya (East Harerghe, Oromia), killing 1 and wounding 9 others. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention.

On 18 August 2020, Ethiopian security forces opened fire and assaulted protesters in Ciro (Chiro), killing 2 and wounding 24. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention.

On 18 August 2020, security forces opened fire on protesters in Dire Dawa city, killing at least 2 people (some sources claimed 4 fatalities, lowest estimate taken). Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention.

On 18 August 2020, Ethiopian military forces shot at protesters in Aweday, killing 8 people and injuring 18. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention.

On 18 August 2020, Oromia special forces shot at protesters in Kobo town (Harar), killing 2. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention.

On 18 August 2020, about 300 youths working for the Kitui County Textile Centre (KICOTEC) and the Kitui Youth Skills and Enterprise Centre (KIYOSEC) held a sit-in outside the county assembly of Kitui (Kitui Central, Kitui) over delayed salary payments. Police used teargas canisters to disperse the crowd.

On 18 August 2020, residents of Bugembe (Jinja district) converged on Health Centre IV to protest against the storing of dead bodies in the outpatients department, and calling for a morgue to be built.

On 18 August 2020, CCM party members from the Chang'ombe ward gathered outside the party's district headquarters in Dodoma (Dodoma Urban, Dodoma) in protest against the failure of the party's election committee to approve their elected nominee. Police intervened and arrested some of the protestors.

On 19 August 2020, for a third day, Ethiopian security forces opened fire on protesters in Haro Maya, killing 2 and wounding 26 others. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention.

On 19 August 2020, security forces opened fired at protesters in Dire Dawa city, killing 1 person. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention.
On 19 August 2020, residents of Lazebu parish demonstrated in Okavu village (Arua district), in opposition to efforts by the National Forest Authority to evict them from their land.

On 19 August 2020, local people, including women and children, staged a peaceful protest by marching through the main road of Baidoa town (Baydhaba, Bay). The protesters were chanting slogans against men that raped a child in the town.

On 20 August 2020, police used teargas canisters to disperse hundreds of youth in Nyabite and Kebirigo near Nyamira (West Mugirango, Nyamira), demonstrating against alleged corruption by the Nyamira administration. Police arrested the chair and secretary of the Nyamira ni Yetu Sisi Mayouth organisation.

On 21 August 2020, hundreds of youths, including members of the Kenya Tuitakayo Movement (KTM), demonstrated in Uhuru Park, Nairobi (Kilimani, Nairobi), demanding an investigation into the mismanagement of the coronavirus funds and the arrest of those involved. Police used teargas canisters to disperse the crowd and arrested 12 people.

On 21 August 2020, residents demonstrated in the Nessuit area (Njoro, Nakuru), demanding government intervention over ethnic clashes in the area. The demonstrators also accused police of brutalising them during a deployment to restore peace within the community.

On 23 August 2020, employees of a hardware business demonstrated (at the behest of the owner of the business) in Mbarara (Mbarara district) after the premises was cordoned off due to unpaid debt. Police arrested two, whilst private security forces fired upon the demonstrators, shattering the glass of nearby vehicles.

On 24 August 2020, about fifty small business owners (Illegal Kiosks owners) mainly women, demonstrated in front of Burao Local Council in Burco town (Burco, Togdheer) against the relocating of their kiosks and business from the town center to outskirts of Burao town by the Local Council.

On 24 August 2020, local residents demonstrated against rising insecurity in Kathageri town (Runyenjes, Embu), after armed men killed one guard and injured another one. The demonstrators blocked roads (means unspecified), police used teargas canisters to disperse the demonstrators.

On 24 August 2020, over hundreds residents and the human rights defenders demonstrated along the major streets of Nakuru town (Nakuru Town East, Nakuru), demanding for arrest and prosecution of those involved in the alleged theft and loss of billions of coronavirus fund. Police used teargas canisters to disperse the crowd. Four people were arrested.

On 24 August 2020, over hundreds residents and the human rights defenders demonstrated along the major streets of Kisumu town (Kisumu Central, Kisumu), demanding the arrest and prosecution of those involved in the alleged theft and loss of billions of coronavirus fund. Police used teargas canisters to disperse the crowd. Five people were arrested.

On 24 August 2020, around fifty residents and the human rights defenders demonstrated along major streets in Kakamega town (Lurambi, Kakamega). The demonstrators demanded the arrest and prosecution of those involved in the alleged theft and loss of billions of coronavirus fund. Two people were arrested.

On 25 August 2020, local residents, HAKI Africa, MUHURI and other human rights defenders demonstrated along the Madaraka street of Mombasa town (Mvita, Mombasa). The demonstrators demanding for arrest and prosecution of those involved in the alleged theft and loss of billions of coronavirus fund. Six people were arrested.
On 25 August 2020, truck drivers peacefully demonstrated in the streets of Mogadishu - Karan district (Banadir). They demonstrated against roads blocked by district officials.

On 25 August 2020, local residents and one human rights defenders demonstrated along the major streets of Kabarnet town (Baringo Central, Baringo). The demonstrators demanded the arrest and prosecution of those involved in the alleged theft and loss of billions of coronavirus fund.

On 27 August 2020, a protest took place in the Awdal region (Baki, Awdal), Awbare District between Somaliland and Ethiopia after the Somaliland Army ordered the Gadabursi clan chief not to cross the border between Somaliland and Ethiopia. At least one person was injured during the military's intervention and unspecified number of protesters were arrested.

On 28 August 2020, local business people demonstrated against the orders of ministry of livestock of Galmudug states in Guri-Ceel town (Dhuusamarreeb, Galgaduud) over an order closing the livestock market.
On 28 August 2020, a demonstration took place in Gebiley town (Gebiley, Waqooyi Galbeed), after the local council ordered the removal of livestock from the town.

On 31 August 2020, youth demonstrating against unemployment, blocked the Naivasha-Mai Mahiu road in Mai Mahiu town (Naivasha, Nakuru). They demanded for fairness in the recruitment. The police used teargas canisters to disperse the demonstrators. Three people were arrested.
On 31 August 2020, local residents peacefully protested over the ban on issuance of identity cards in Siaya town (Alego Usonga, Siaya).
On 31 August 2020, supporters of an NRM candidate detained by police demonstrated at the police station at Iganga (Iganga district). Police arrested the demonstrators.

On 31 August 2020, more than 20 people peacefully demonstrated and gathered around the municipality office in Ceerigaabo town (Ceerigaabo, Sanaag), against the local municipality for demolishing their small businesses. The Somaliland police arrested 10 protesters.

On 1 September 2020, dozens of bus drivers protested by blocking off the main road (through unspecified means) in Wanla Weyne town (Wanla Weyne, Lower Shabelle). This was in response to the growing number of illegal checkpoints and road blocks manned by clan militias in the area.

On 1 September 2020, hawkers and matatu drivers protested against the country government's decision to relocate matatu terminus and market out of the central business district in Nakuru town (Nakuru town, Nakuru). Police used teargas canisters to disperse the crowd.
On 2 September 2020, about 150 NRM supporters demonstrated in Kyenjojo (Kyenjojo district), after they discovered they were not on the ballot for NRM primaries.
On 3 September 2020, lawyers in Meru held a peaceful protest in Maua town (Igembe South, Meru) over the shooting of their colleague.

On 4 September 2020, NRM youth protested in Lalekan (Kitgum district) during NRM primaries, claiming that electoral fraud had taken place. Police used tear gas and live rounds (presumed to be fired in the air) to disperse the youth.

On 4 September 2020, Democratic Party supporters demonstrated at the police station in Entebbe (Wakiso district), after several party officials (including the deputy mayor of Entebbe) were arrested in relation to clashes with NRM supporters that week.

Around 5 September 2020 (between 4 - 7 September), protesters gathered at the Great Season Company HQ, presumed to be in or close to Kiryandongo town (Kiryandongo district), calling for the release of an activist who had been detained on 4 September after attempting to retrieve stolen goats from the company. Police fired tear gas and live rounds (presumed to have been fired into the air) and arrested seven, whilst police and private security guarding the building were reported to have beaten protesters.

On 6 September 2020, residents protested against Jubaland leadership in Garbahaarey town (Garbahaarey, Gedo), over the withdrawal of SNA forces from the region. The protest was organized by the local authority.

On 7 September 2020, Ugandan police forces used tear gas to disperse demonstrators who gathered in Rushenyi (Ntungamo district) to demonstrate against the detention of the State Minister for Labour Mwesigwa Rukutana.

On 7 September 2020, Village Health Team members from around Bududa stormed Bududa District Headquarters in Bududa (Bududa district) to demonstrate against the non-payment of allowances for their mosquito net distributions.
On 7 September 2020, junior staff at Ongino Hospital went on strike and demonstrated in front of the hospital in Kumi (Kumi) because of delays in the payment of salaries.

On 7 September 2020, hundreds of residents demonstrated by marching to the home of their member of parliament (MP) in Trans Mara (Transmara West, Narok) against the arrest of the MP. Police intervened and shot in the air to disperse the group.

On 7 September 2020, Ugandan police forces and Ugandan military forces blocked demonstrators attempting to access the National Resistance Movement office in Rubanda district. The demonstrators gathered because they felt that the NRM Party win in the election was not legitimate.

On 8 September 2020, Ugandan police forces used tear gas to disperse demonstrators in Hoima (Hoima district), who were demonstrating against the dispersal of a NUP political party meeting earlier that day.

On 9 September 2020, over fifty local residents, including women, protested in the main road of Gatundu town (Gatundu South, Kiambu). The protesters requested for apology from MP Ngeno and MP Sudi over their remarks against the mother of the current president.

Around 9 September 2020 (as reported), local residents, mainly KANU, supporters protested in Kapenguria (West Pokot, West Pokot), against the move by the party to sack four nominated female MCAs. The group demanded the immediate reinstatement of the MCAs.

On 10 September 2020, women, boda boda operators and matatu drivers staged demonstrations in the Narok town (Narok North, Narok). The demonstrators blocked (means unspecified) Narok-Nakuru road over the remarks of MP Ngeno and MP Sudi and demanded greater respect for the mother of the current president.

On 10 September 2020, National Resistance Movement (NRM) party supporters demonstrated the results of the primary elections and cut off traffic on the Kampala-Gulu highway near Wobulenzi Town (Luwero).

On 10 September 2020, over one hundred residents staged a peaceful protest by walking from KFA to the central business district in Nakuru town (Nakuru Town East, Nakuru). The protesters demanded respect for the mother of the current president and requested for apologies from MPs who made remarks about her.

On 10 September 2020, demonstrators camped outside the district headquarters in Butaleja (Butaleja district), after election officials announced an NRM party member as a winner instead of the candidate they voted for. Sources report that the demonstrators also had run-ins with police, but do not describe the nature of the interactions.

Around 11 September 2020 (as reported), dozens of teachers demonstrated outside the Anti Corruption Court in Kololo (Kampala) against the court granting bail to 4 suspects alleged to have embezzled funds that were intended to aid private school teachers who have lost income during coronavirus.

On 11 September 2020, Ugandan police forces fired tear gas to disperse demonstrators who gathered in Nabweru near Maganjo (Nansana Municipality) to demonstrate against not being allowed to vote because they were not in the party register.

On 11 September 2020, Kapsaret MP (Jubilee), youths and boda boda riders staged a peaceful protest in Eldoret town (Ainabkoi, Uasin Gishu). The protesters condemed the government for harassing MPs so they can shift KEMSA scandal.

On 13 September 2020, over 90 parents of Mbajone primary, stormed the learning institution near Kithirune (Imenti Central, Meru county), where they seized two bulls, slaughtered them and shared the meat. They accused the school management of lack of transparency at the institution.
On 14 September 2020, over one hundred local residents, mostly women, peacefully protested in the streets on Maralal town (Sanburu West, Samburu), demanding political tolerance in the country.

On 14 September 2020, health workers protested by waving placards, whistling and shouting as they camped outside city hall in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), against delays in promotion and disparity in job groups. The workers demanded their jobs groups reviewed upwards and their salaries increased.

On 15 September 2020, Ugandan police forces used tear gas to disperse demonstrators who gathered in Kamwokya (Kampala) to demonstrate against the failure of the police to apprehend a suspect connected to two shootings in Kampala.
On 15 September 2020, Ugandan police forces used tear gas to disperse protesters who gathered in Bugumba (Iganga) to protest a delay in announcing elections results, with at least 1 injury.

On 16 September 2020, 90 government security forces protested and briefly blocked the Main Street of Villa Somalia in Mogadishu - Wardhigley (Banadir). The soldiers were demanding for their salary for the last three months, they were stationed in the newly open Daynile airport.
