On 10 November 2021, local residents demonstrated against the thefts perpetrated by police forces in the area, in Kakindo (Bugahya, Hoima).
On 11 November 2021, local residents demonstrated against the absenteeism of health workers, accusing them of neglecting the coronavirus vaccination campaign, in Kasese (Western).
On 11 November 2021, local residents and parents demonstrated over the need for legal knowledge in the area, in order to avoid conflict in the community, in Mutungo (Makindye Ssabagabo, Wakiso).
On 12 November 2021, residents in Bonga (Kefa, SNNP) demonstrated against TPLF forces attacks. .

On 12 November 2021, NUP supporters demonstrated against the prohibition of access of Bobi Wine to a local radio station by security forces, in Mbale city (Eastern). Police forces intervened with teargas and bullets to suppress the demonstration. There were no fatalities nor injuries.

On 13 November 2021, NUP supporters demonstrated against an impeding access to a radio to the opposition figure, Bobi Wine, in Lira (Northern). Police forces shot live bullets and teargas against demonstrators, injuring one NUP supporter. There were no fatalities.
On 14 November 2021, local residents demonstrated against the killing of a resident by a private security guards, in Kireka (Kira, Wakiso).
On 15 November 2021, shop owners and traders demonstrated against the increased rent for obtaining license in the market, in Gulu (Northern).

On 15 November 2021, Kampala Capital City Authority employees demonstrated against the non-payment of their salaries for September and October and against the poor work conditions, in Kawempe (Kampala, Central).
On 16 November 2021, protest against TPLF and OLF-Shane was held in Gimbi town (West Wellega, Oromia).
On 16 November 2021, local residents marched to the county commissioner's office in Lamu town (Lamu West, Lamu) over rising machete attacks in the town. This is after a man was killed by a gang.

On 16 November 2021, more than 200 cereal traders, including women traders, protested against police harassment and accused top security officials of using junior officers to demand bribes in Garissa town (Garissa). The protest came after a multiagency team acting on intelligence intercepted and set ablaze a lorry carrying rice to Garissa in Modika.
On 17 November 2021, protesters gathered in Nejo town (West Wellega, Oromia) and denounced the TPLF and OLF-Shane alliance and demonstrated against recent gains made by the TPLF into Amhara region.

On 17 November 2021, local women denuded themselves and demonstrated against the increasing presence of elephants in the area, claiming that these were destroying the crop fields and demanding action to local authorities, in Lii (Nwoya, Northern).

On 17 November 2021, local residents and councilors demonstrated against the diversion of water supplies, claiming that this would deny access to clean water for local population, in Bududa (Bubulo, Manafwa).

On 17 November 2021, local residents protested against the rising insecurity in Migori county, demanding from the government to increase police patrols in Uriri town (Uriri, Migori) after two security guards were killed and a woman abducted.

On 17 November 2021, members from Munyo Yaya community protested at the Madogo trading center in Modogo town (Bura, Tana River), demanding recognition as a Kenyan ethnic group in order for them to get government jobs with ease.

On 18 November 2021, more than 400 local residents stormed the roads and demonstrated against the persistent cattle thefts perpetrated by Karamajong armed pastoralists, in Olilim (Otuke, Northern). This demonstration came after a few days that cattle rustlers looted 38 heads of cattle of a local resident (coded separately).

On 18 November 2021, local residents demonstrated, threatening to burn down a pub, against the torture of a civilian by a vigilante group of pub owners over a theft charge (coded separately), in Masaka city (Central). Police and military forces intervened to suppress the demonstration, and to avoid riotous acts. The demonstration lasted for two days, and there were no fatalities nor injuries.

On 18 November 2021, around 123 social workers in charge of collecting garbage and cleaning the streets demonstrated against the non-payment of their allowances for three months, in Gulu city (Northern).

On 19 November 2021, local residents demonstrated against the torture of a civilian by a vigilante group of pub owners over a theft charge (coded separately), in Masaka city (Central). Police and military forces intervened to suppress the demonstration, and to avoid riotous acts. The demonstration lasted for two days, and there were no fatalities nor injuries.

On 21 November 2021, NUP supporters gathered in front of a church, where Bobi Wine was talking in public, and demonstrated on the need to be politically listened by local government, in Masaka (Central). Police forces intervened to disperse demonstrators as they wanted to storm the church, shooting rubber bullets and teargas. There were no fatalities nor injuries.

On 22 November 2021, local residents blocked [through unspecified means] roads in Eastleigh (Kamukunji, Nairobi), in demonstration against the sentiments made by Kiambu Senator Kimani Wamatangi during a media interview. The residents demanded an apology from the senator.
On 22 November 2021, market vendors demonstrated against the increasing rent charge for stalls, demanding its reduction, in Entebbe (Wakiso).
On 24 November 2021, local residents demonstrated against the torture and the death of a local herdsman, after the victim's body was found, in Galiraya sub-county (Bbaale, Kayunga).

On 25 November 2021, around two thousand of Addis Ababa city residents gathered outside the US Embassy compound in Shiromeda/Gullele, Gulele (Region 14, Addis Ababa) in protest, accusing the US government of foreign intervention in Ethiopia and the spread of false information. The group also marched to the British Embassy. The protest was organized by the Coalition of Ethiopian Civil Societies Association.

On 26 November 2021, residents of Doba demonstrated against what they say 'TPLF and OLF Shane atrocities and foreign nations meddling in Ethiopia's internal affairs' in Doba town (West Hararge, Oromia).
On 26 November 2021, local residents demonstrated against the land expropriation perpetrated by a private oil company, demanding a compensation, in Hoima area (Western).
On 26 November 2021, local residents demonstrated against the decision to re-elect a new councilor in Mutungo (Makindye Ssabagabo, Wakiso). Police forces intervened to suppress the demonstration.
On 26 November 2021, local residents demonstrated against the attempts of local land owners in expropriating the lands, in Makulubita (Katikamu, Luwero).

On 28 November 2021, women demonstrated in Kebe town, Gawo Kebe (Kellem Wollega, Oromia), against what they say is 'TPLF and OLF Shane atrocities and foreign nations meddling in Ethiopia's internal affairs.'
On 29 November 2021, university students demonstrated against the delays on obtaining graduate papers and documents, in Mubende (Central).
On 29 November 2021, a protest against foreign countries' intervention in Ethiopia was held in Burayu (Finfine Special, Oromia).
On 29 November 2021, council candidates demonstrated against the delay in the start of elections, in Kayunga (Ntenjeru, Central).

On 29 November 2021, parents of Icangi primary school blocked (means unspecified) the Embu - Mwea highway [coded as Embu, Manyatta, Embu] using logs in demonstration against increased cases road accidents in the area. Police intervened using unspecified means to disperse the group.
On 30 November 2021, more than 20 employees of a private electric company demonstrated against the delay in the payment of their salaries, in Masafu (Samia-Bugwe, Busia).
On 30 November 2021, more than 100 miners demonstrated against the delay in their salary payment, in Harugongo (Burahya, Kabarole).

On 30 November 2021, locals in Haroo Qarsa kebele (coded to Fentale, East Shewa) reportedly stopped Oromia Regional Special forces by blocking roads after they attempted to arrest 5 young men. Police forces fired live ammunition in the air to disperse the crowd.

On 30 November 2021, more than 2,000 senior citizens, some with severe disabilities, protested against the delay in the Inua Jamii registration at the Magarini cultural center in Magarini town (Magarini, Kilifi).

On 1 December 2021, residents of Mieso town demonstrated against what they say is 'TPLF and OLF Shane atrocities and foreign nations meddling in Ethiopia's internal affairs' in Mieso (West Hararge, Oromia).

On 1 December 2021, residents of Gumbi Bordede demonstrated against what they say is 'TPLF and OLF Shane atrocities and foreign nations meddling in Ethiopia's internal affairs' in Bordode (West Hararge, Oromia).

On 2 December 2021, members of Addis Ababa University and students protested against foreign countries' intervention in Ethiopia. The protest began in Addis Ababa University (Gulele, Region 14, Addis Ababa) and protesters walked to the US embassy in Addis Ababa and protested in front of the embassy.

On 3 December 2021, shop owners demonstrated against the shortage of electricity, in Kirumira market in Kitintale (Kampala, Central). Police forces intervened to suppress the demonstration. There were no fatalities nor injuries.
On 3 December 2021, pupils and teachers protested against the foreign countries' intervention in Ethiopia in Bahir Dar town (West Gojam, Amhara).

On 5 December 2021, civil servants of Doba town demonstrated against what they say 'TPLF and OLF Shane atrocities and foreign nations meddling in Ethiopia's internal affairs' in Doba town (West Hararge, Oromia).
On 5 December 2021, traditional healers demonstrated against the imposition of a fee to practice their profession, in an unidentified location in Masaka district (Central).
On 5 December 2021, around 20 people demonstrated against the construction of a road by a private Chinese company, in Layibi (Gulu, Northern).
On 5 December 2021, Tigrayan ethnic group in Abebe Bikila Stadium (Addis Ketema, Region 14) in Addis Ababa protested against the TPLF.

On 5 December 2021, students from Obera boys secondary school protested after the death of their peer who was hit by a ball while they were playing football in the school in Ndhiwa town (Ndhiwa, Homa Bay).

On 6 December 2021, local residents demonstrated against the enforcement of curfew rules, after a mother was arrested on the road by police forces, in Pader (Aruu, Northern). The demonstration lasted for two days. Police forces intervened shooting live bullets in the air to disperse rioters. There were no fatalities nor injuries.
On 6 December 2021, over 300 local residents demonstrated against the high monthly bills of water services in Hamuhambo, near Rubanda (Western).

On 7 December 2021, a group of women protested and gathered in front of the governor's office in Burao town (Burco, Togdheer). The protesters were claiming the newly constructed slaughterhouse managed by Dayib company has increased the price of livestock slaughtering.
On 7 December 2021, local residents, including boda boda drivers, demonstrated along the Thiongo road against police brutality in Kabete (Kiambu).

On 7 December 2021, several people protested against the Somaliland administration in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool). The Somaliland police fired live bullets to disperse the crowd. There were no casualties.

On 8 December 2021, local residents and vendors demonstrated against the violence of police forces in enforcing the curfew, demanding an intervention from local authorities, in Pader (Aruu, Northern). Police forces intervened shooting bullets (unspecified) and teargas to suppress the demonstration. There were no fatalities nor injuries.
On 8 December 2021, truck drivers demonstrated against the imposition of a double import fee at the border, in Busia (Eastern).
On 9 December 2021, environmental activists demonstrated in front of the city court against the exploitation of the Bugoma forest by a private sugar company, in Hoima (Western).
On 9 December 2021, medicine and health sciences students demonstrated over a dispute about tuition fees in Makerere University (Kampala, Central).
On 10 December 2021, taxi and bus drivers demonstrated against the poor state of the bus and taxi parkings, demanding improvement from local authorities, in Mbarara (Western).

On 10 December 2021, local residents gathered in the local municipality offices in Busia (Eastern) and demonstrated against harassment perpetrated by URA officers, after the latter beat civilians the previous day (coded separately).

On 11 December 2021, Ethiopians and others in solidarity demonstrated at the Ethiopian Embassy in Kamapala city (Kampala, Central), launching a movement called 'NO More' which aimed at denouncing Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF) as well as western powers' meddling in the internal affairs of Ethiopia.
On 11 December 2021, local residents demonstrated against the water shortage in the area, demanding the construction of a water pipe, in Kiti village near Kalungu (Central).

On 11 December 2021, some Meru residents staged a protest in Meru (Municipality, Imenti North, Meru) against the planned visit of the Orange Democratic Movement presidential aspirant Jimmy Wanjigi. They urged him to stay away from Maru county until his case with DCI George Kinoti was resolved.

On 11 December 2021, a group of women belonging to the Catholic church staged a peaceful protest in Endo (Endo, Marakwet East, Elgeyo Marakwet County), demanding peace following continued attacks from 'bandits'.
On 12 December 2021, students demonstrated against the US sanctions on General Abel Kandiho, and delivered a petition against the US embassy, in Makerere University (Kampala, Central).
On 12 December 2021, local residents staged a peaceful demonstration near Nyawita settlement (Ndhiwa, Homa Bay). The residents demonstrated against the increased cases of cow killing in the area.

On 13 December 2021, local residents blocked a road in Padwot (Padyere, Nebbi) and demonstrated against the delay in compensation for the destruction of their lands, caused by a private engineering company.

On 13 December 2021, boda boda drivers and two allied chairpersons gathered into the local police station in Kagadi (Buyaga, Western) and demonstrated against the release of two people, who had been assaulted by a mob and then handed to police for a suspected theft (coded separately).

On 14 December 2021, women from different districts of Guraghe zone gathered in Welkite town, Welkite (Guraghe, SNNP) and demonstrated against 'attacks on women by TPLF and OLF Shane rebels and the intervention of foreign nations in Ethiopia's internal affairs'.

On 14 December 2021, local residents demonstrated against the heavy deployment of security forces around the Bobi Wine's house, in Magere (Kyadondo, Wakiso). Demonstrators were not affiliated with the NUP party.

On 14 December 2021, health workers from a national medical association demonstrated against the government measures regarding the national health sector, near the Parliament in Nakasero (Kampala, Central). Police forces intervened to suppress the demonstration, and arrested 27 doctors. There were no fatalities nor injuries.

On 14 December 2021, hundreds of NUP supporters demonstrated in favor of their leader, Bobi Wine, after he had been arrested at his house by security forces, in Kayunga (Ntenjeru, Central). Police forces shot teargas and live bullets against demonstrators, also arresting seven NUP supporters. Two people were injured, and there were no fatalities.
On 16 December 2021, protests against TPLF's attacks against women and children and Western countries' intervention in Ethiopia was held in Asosa town (Assosa, Benshangul/Gumuz).

On 16 December 2021, women in Gambela town peacefully demonstrated in Gambella (Agnewak, Gambela) against 'attacks on women by TPLF and OLF Shane rebels and foreign intervention in Ethiopia's internal affairs'. The protest was organized by the Regional Bureau of Women and Children's Affairs.

On 16 December 2021, 15,000 students from 15 elementary and high schools protested against US and some European countries' intervention in Ethiopia under a slogan 'No More' in Debre Markos town (East Gojam, Amhara region).

On 16 December 2021, local residents demonstrated against the suspected criminal activities of local authorities in boycotting the elections to favor the government party, in various locations in Kayunga district (Central).

On 17 December 2021, women in Samera Logiya town gathered at Semera Stadium (Awsi-Zone 1, Afar) and demonstrated against 'attacks on women by TPLF forces in Afar and foreign intervention in Ethiopia's internal affairs'. The protest was organized by Regional Bureau of Women and Children's Affairs'.
On 17 December 2021, market vendors demonstrated against the delay in the construction of market facilities, in Masaka city (Central).

On 17 December 2021, boda boda taxi riders staged a peaceful demonstration along the busy Kamagambo-Nyamarambe road, near Nyamarambe (South Mugirango, Kisii county), following the lynching of a 16-year-old minor, over claims of dating an eighth-grade pupil.

On 17 December 2021, hundreds of traders protested against the confiscation of their money by policemen of the Kampala Capital City Authority in Katwe, Nassar Road police station (Kampala, Central). Police intervened and arrested hundreds.

On 17 December 2021, women rallied in Bahir Dar (West Gojam, Amhara) and peacefully demonstrated against 'attacks on women by TPLF and OLF Shane rebels and foreign intervention in Ethiopia's internal affairs'. The protest was organized by the Regional Bureau of Women and Children's Affairs.

On 20 December 2021, Kyamahunga residents demonstrated by blocking construction works (apparently using their bodies) of a maternity ward at Swazi Health Center II in Kyamahunga town (Bushenyi, Western), over poor construction quality.
On 20 December 2021, Ngariam residents demonstrated at the barracks of UPDF soldiers with the casket containing the remains of a man allegedly killed by UPDF soldiers in Katakwi District (Eastern).

On 20 December 2021, workers at the postal corporation of Kenya (POSTA), demonstrated by waving placards in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), against salary delay and 'mistreatment' by management. The group demanded the removal of the postmaster general, as well as handing over management of the POSTA to the government.
On 20 December 2021, local residents, including boda boda drivers, demonstrated over unpaid Ksh.2 million promised by DP Ruto in Wote town (Makueni).

On 21 December 2021, residents and civl society leaders demonstrated against a decision by the National Forestry Authority (NFA) to give the Maracha County MP land in Barifa Forest to construct an eco- tourism site in Arua city (Arua, Northern).

On 22 December 2021, the clan members of an executed soldier demonstrated against the decision and action of the military court in Belet Xaawo town (Belet Xaawo, Gedo). This is after the court ordered the execution of the soldier. The local security forces (coded as military forces) opened gunfire to dispersed the crowd. Three people were injured in the shooting.
On 22 December 2021, parents demonstrated at Kebisoni School in Kebisoni (Rukungiri, Western), demanding the resignation of the Head Teachers.

On 22 December 2021, Makerere students protested the manner in which the election of the Guild President was being conducted at Makerere University Business School (MUBS), in Port Bell (Kampala, Central). Police and Military Forces used tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the students.

On 22 December 2021, about 350 Isiolo county government casual workers engaged in peaceful demonstrations in Isiolo (Isiolo, Isiolo County). The workers denounced the county government over nonpayment of their dues for the past one year.
On 24 December 2021, porters who worked at Bubungi Health Centre III demonstrated in Bushika (Bududa, Eastern), protesting the delayed payment of their wages.

On 25 December 2021, residents of Nono Benja woreda gathered in Algaa (coded to Cheri) in Nono Benja woreda (Jimma, Oromia) and protested against OLF Shane rebels and condemned the killings of innocent civilians. Location coded to district administrative town, Cheri.

On 25 December 2021, several people protested against the Kenya Defence Force (KDF) attempts to demarcate a disputed parcel of land, near Lamaiywet (Soy, Usian Ngishu). The Kenya Police used tear gas to disperse the crowd.

On 26 December 2021, several tuk tuk drivers organized a protest against police and military forces who are accused of killing drivers along the Maka Al Mukarama road, after a police killed a driver at the Dabka Junction, in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir).

On 27 December 2021, several people protested against the ongoing demolitions in Mukuru slums (Starehe, Nairobi County). The Kenya police fired live bullets to disperse the crowd. One person was killed and 2 injured during the demonstration.

On 29 December 2021, protest against Western countries' pressure on Ethiopia under a slogan 'no more' was held by students, and teachers of primary and secondary school of Gelego town in Quara woreda (West Goner, Amhara). Protesters also protested against CNN and BBC and asked them to stop 'fake news'.
On 29 December 2021, residents demonstrated by marching to the Resident City Commissionor's office in Kawempe (Kampala, Central), accusing a private bank of stealing their savings.

On 29 December 2021, several people protested against the suspension of the Prime Minister and in support of the elections at Saybiyano village neighborhood in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir). The protesters were chanting 'No coup, yes election'. Police forces dispersed the crowd.

On 30 December 2021, local residents staged a peaceful protest, near Alale (Pokot North, West Pokot County), accusing their area chief of grabbing some 500 acres of land and evacuating them from their homes.

On 31 December 2021, several people protested against the suspension of the Prime Minister and in support of the elections at Saybiyano village neighborhood in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir). They also rejected the attempted coup and called for elections.

On 1 January 2022, residents demonstrated by carrying placards demanding the resignation of police who killed a civilian and release of arrested residents at the Mbalala Police Station in Mukono District (Central). Police fired teargas to disperse the demonstrators. A demonstrator was arrested.

On 3 January 2022, residents of Biyu Duale town in Somali region (coded to Doale, Ayisha, Siti, Somali), blocked the main transport route (through unspecified means) between Dire Dawa and Djibouti and refused to allow trucks to pass after government water trucks failed to deliver promised water supplies.
On 3 January 2022, residents protested denouncing the use of force against the landlord in Kayunga sub-county (Kayunga, Central). A parcel of land was taken by force from civilians.

On 3 January 2022, truck taxi drivers protested and blocked the busy Malaba border point (Teso North, Busia County). The drivers were protesting against the mandatory coronavirus testing and the 'exorbitant' fee charged at the border by the Ugandan authorities. The strike lasted multiple days.

On 3 January 2022, a group of Pokot professionals staged a peaceful demonstration in Kapenguria town (West Pokot, West Pokot county). The group decried increased insecurity in their home area of Cheptulel, as a result of constant bandit attacks allegedly from the neighbouring Marakwet community.

On 4 January 2022, a group of demonstrators brought the bodies of 2 suspects who died in custody to the central police station in Bukedea (Bukedea, Eastern). Police fired teargas and bullets (unclear if live or rubber) to disperse the demonstrators.

Around 4 January 2022, boda boda drivers protested and paralyzed operations along the Embu - Kiritiri highway, near Kiritiri ( Mbeere South, Embu county), as they protested over increased road accidents in the area after 4 people were killed in an accident.
On 5 January 2022, residents peacefully protested in Kinoni village (Gomba, Central), demanding the replacement of the leader of their village.

On 5 January 2022, over 2000 agitated export processing zone (epz) workers staged a peaceful demonstration over alleged harassment by the company management in Athi River (Athi River, Machakos County).

On 6 January 2022, local residents staged a demonstration by blocking (through unspecified means) a road leading to the Geothermal Development Corporation (GDC) exploration site near Loruk (Tiaty, Baringo County). The residents accused GDC management of failure to honor their corporate social responsibility (CSR) pledges.

On 7 January 2022, for the second consecutive day, local residents staged a demonstration by blocking (through unspecified means) a road leading to Geothermal Development Corporation (GDC) exploration site near Loruk (Tiaty, Baringo County), accusing GDC management of failure to honor their corporate social responsibility (CSR) pledges.
On 7 January 2022, a section of Meru community elders (Njuri Ncheke) staged protests along the Maua Meru Highway over the increasing insecurity along Meru Isiolo border.

On 8 January 2022, parents held a peaceful protest at the gate of Makerere High Way College in Makerere [coded to the Makerere University] (Kampala, Kamapala), demanding the full reopening of the school. The school allowed only a certain category of students to start the courses after the reopening of schools by the government of Uganda. The schools were closed due to the coronavirus.
On 9 January 2022, local residents staged a protest against the ongoing transfer of their health care facility over land disputes in Ngoswe, near Marigat (Marigat, Baringo County).

On 10 January 2022, more than 1,000 students of Mountains of the Moon University took to the streets to protest the failure of their lecturers to show up in Fort Portal (Kabarole, Western). Police forces blocked the students from certain roads, fired teargas and live bullets to disperse the students. Three students including the guild president sustained injuries after being attacked by the police and 9 were arrested.

Around 10 January 2022 (as reported), hundreds of youth stormed the house of MP Marwa Kitayana in Kuria East (Gokeharaka, Kuria East, Migori) demanding to get paid for allegedly being hired for cheering DP William Ruto during his visit to the region. They chanted and blocked vehicles (means unreported) from accessing the home of the MP.

On 10 January 2022, a section of Meru community elders (Njuri Ncheke) together with local leaders staged a demonstration in Tigania (Tigania West, Meru County), decrying the increased insecurity along the Meru-Isiolo border.

On 10 January 2022, local women together with their leaders, staged a protest in Chesoi (Marakwet East, Elgeyo Marakwet county), denouncing the senior security and administration officials for failing to contain the security situation in the area.
On 11 January 2022, residents held a peaceful demonstration against the shooting of 12-year-old by the army in Kanu village, Abim District (Northern).

On 11 January 2022, students from a local medical training college staged a demonstration, by marching along the busy Kehancha- Migori highway, in Kihancha town (Kehancha) (Bukira East, Migori County). They accused the institution's management of high handedness and failure to address critical infrastructural inadequacies. The police stepped in to quell the tension.

On 11 January 2022, women rights defenders staged a protest along the streets of Isiolo town (Isiolo, Isiolo town), following the recent murder of Elizabeth Ekaru, a fellow activist, allegedly over a land dispute. They submitted a petition to the county commissioner's office, which sought for a speedy investigation into the incident.

On 11 January 2022, residents protested in Bondo town (Bondo, Siaya) against police brutality, following the recent killing of a suspect in police custody. The group demanded that their grievances be addressed.

On 11 January 2022, women and a section of human rights defenders in Nairobi central business district (Nairobi - Starehe county) went to the streets in protest against femicide, chanting 'justice for Elizabeth', the latest victim, over alleged land dispute with a neighbor.

On 12 January 2022, local residents protested against the Orpower power company in Narasha (Narok North, Narok county) for neglecting an agreement with the community relating to job opportunities. Their attempts to disrupt the company operations were thwarted by the police.

On 12 January 2022, for the second day, local residents took to the streets to demonstrate against increased dust, in the peripheral township of Kitengela (Kajiado East, Kajiado county), caused by a contractor on the Namanga road.

On 12 January 2022, women, led by UDA political leaders, staged a protest in Thika Town (Thika town, Kiambu County) over bishop Gakuyo's (aspiring member of parliament) comments about the former (and aspiring ) area MP Alice Ng'ang'a under the United Democratic Alliance (UDA).

On 13 January 2022, prisoners staged demosntrations inside their cells against the management and the 'oppressive' methods at Kamiti Prison (Roysambu, Nairobi) by attempting to break out of the highly guarded facility. Officers subdued them by firing teargas. At least 20 inmates were injured during the incident.

On 13 January 2022, a section of members of the Queer community, staged a protest in Nairobi Central Business District (CBD) (Nairobi - Starehe County), following the Education Cabinet Secretary's remarks that sought to ban lesbian, gay and queer students from attending boarding schools in Kenya.
On 15 January 2022, members of one family demonstrated and blocked a water project (assumed with their bodies) in Nakapiripirit town (Nakapiripirit, Northern), over lack of compensation.

On 15 January 2022, parents demonstrated at Kibedi Day and Boarding Primary School in Kawempe Division (Kampala, Central), demanding to see their children following a fire outbreak that destroyed the girl's dormitory.

On 16 January 2022, Katanga residents demonstrated in Wandegeya (Kampala, Central) for protection from threats of eviction by Makerere University. Four families were appealing to Makerere University and the Commissioner for land registration over cancellation of their land titles and ownership of the land by Makerere University.

Around 16 January 2022 (as reported), local residents staged a peaceful protest against the planned eviction from a piece of land by an insurance company in Kwa Bullo area, near Nyali (Nyali, Mombasa County), following the expiration of their land rates payment arrears notice. They called on the national and county government to intervene.

On 16 January 2022, ACK St. John Gichami church worshipers staged a protest against the firing of their church leader over his marital status, at the ACK St. John Gichami church in Othaya (Nyeri South, Nyeri County).

On 16 January 2022, parents with pupils staged a peaceful demonstration over the delayed renovation of two classroom blocks at Kaitandovu primary school, Buyengo sub-county, in Jinja District (Eastern). Heavy rains blew off the roof of the affected classroom blocks in April last year.

On 17 January 2022, residents protested against the arrest of a drug shop operator accused of procuring an abortion in Lyingo trading center, Kagulu sub county (Buyende, Eastern). Police officers opened fire to disperse residents, a bullet killing one lady.
On 17 January 2022, parents and students staged a protest against the government's closure of Murang'a road primary school near Ngara (Starehe, Nairobi county).

On 17 January 2022, traders from Karume Market protested against a 14-day layoff announced by the Regional Commissioner of Dar es Salaam in the region of Dar es Salaam (Ilala, Dar es Salaam). Protesters closed the road (through unspecified means) near the office of the Regional Commissioner and called on the authorities to allow them to continue working. Police fired teargas to disperse the protesters.

Around 18 January 2022 (as reported), local residents staged a peaceful demonstration after wild animals stray into their farms and destroyed crops in Longonot (Naivasha, Nakuru County), accusing the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS) of failing to compensate for their losses.

On 18 January 2022, supporters of business tycoon and presidential hopeful Jimi Wanjigi from ODM party, demonstrated and camped outside his office in Westlands (Westlands, Nairobi County) following a police raid on his office. Police fired tear gas to disperse the group.

On 19 January 2022, a section of market vendors demonstrated at the offices of KCCA to demand a meeting with the executive director in Kampala city (Kampala, Central), over endless challenges in Wandegeya, St Balikuddembe (Owino) and Nakasero markets.
On 19 January 2022, street food vendors in Usafi Market demonstrated against the arrest of six of their colleagues in Kamapala city (Kampala, Central).

On 19 January 2022, protestors matched to Milimani law courts right next to Uhuru Park (Dagoretti North, Nairobi county) to show support to business tycoon and presidential hopeful Jimi Wanjigi from ODM party, who was being arraigned following his arrest. Police used to fire tear gas to disperse the crowd.

On 21 January 2022, local residents protested against the Hirshabelle administration and in support of the clan militia (Abukar Haji Warsame Xuud) peace agreement with the federal government on 18 Jan 2022 in Belet Weyne town (Belet Weyne, Hiraan).
On 22 January 2022, local residents protested in Borama town (Borama, Awdal) to show their support to the British MP who proposed the recognition of Somaliland to the UK House of Commons.
On 22 January 2022, local residents protested in Burco town (Burco, Togdheer) to show their support to the British MP who proposed the recognition of Somaliland to the UK House of Commons.

On 22 January 2022, thousands of people protested in Hargeysa city (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed) to show their support to the British MP who proposed the recognition of Somaliland to the UK House of Commons.

On 23 January 2022, local residents staged a peaceful demonstration and blocked (through unspecified means) the Kitale-Lodwar highway near Lodwar town (Turkana Central, Turkana), following the killing of an 11-year-old boy and 31 sheep in a road accident. The protesters demanded compensation.

On 23 January 2022, sugarcane transporters and growers parked their trucks in Buikwe District (Central), in protest of unfair trade practices by the Sugar Corporation of Uganda Limited Lugazi-SCOUL. They claimed that the SCOUL who is supposed to buy the sugarcane from them started buying it directly from farmers using proxies to kick them out of business.

On 24 January 2022, Lwengo residents blocked Mbarara highway (through unclear means) in protest over power outage in Lwengo District (Central). The outage has gone up to two months, which residents say, has greatly affected their businesses. Police fired live bullets (assumed in the air given to casualties) to disperse the residents.

On 24 January 2022, a group of youths demonstrated at the district head office in Koboko (Kiboko, Northern), for allegedly being denied jobs after sitting for interviews. The demonstrators claimed they were denied jobs because they refused to bribe the district service commission officials.
On 24 January 2022, local residents protested in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool) to show their support to the British MP who proposed the recognition of Somaliland to the UK House of Commons.
On 24 January 2022, a group of government legislators demonstrated on bicycles at Parliament Avenue in Kampala (Kampala, Central) against high fuel prices in the country.

On 24 January 2022, Makerere University Business School students peacefully protested at Makerere University (Kampala, Central), over missing marks from the previous semester. The university halted the exams following protests.

On 25 January 2022, overnight, local residents, along with Nur Dheere militia protested against Hirshabelle administration in Belet Weyne town (Belet Weyne, Hiraan). This was due to the alleged visit of Hirshabelle president to the town. Police forces dispersed the protesters.

On 25 January 2022, private sponsored students demonstrated at the Senate building at Makerere University (Kampala, Central), after they failed to download their provisional admission letters. The university announced the release of admission letters and issued guidelines to private sponsored students to access their copies online, while government-sponsored students would pick up their forms physically.

On 25 January 2022, local residents protested in Buuhoodle town (Buuhoodle, Togdheer) against the British MP who proposed the recognition of Somaliland to the UK House of Commons. The protesters burned the flags of the UK and Somaliland.

On 26 January 2022, hundreds of boda boda drivers staged a peaceful demonstration in Chepareria (Pokot South,West Pokot County), over alleged unpaid dues for escorting Deputy President William Ruto during a recent United Democratic Alliance (UDA) rally.

On 26 January 2022, hundreds of sugar cane farmers protested by hooting motorbikes, waving placards and carrying sugarcane leaves, as they marched in Shianda market (Mumias East, Kakamega), against a case in court blocking the re-opening of the Mumias sugar company. The group demanded the company re-opened.

On 28 January 2022, boda boda drivers staged a peaceful demonstration in Bondo town (Ugenya, Siaya County) by blocking (through unspecified means) the Bondo-Siaya road, coercing passengers to participate in the ongoing voter registration process.
On 30 January 2022, protest against the TPLF attack on civilians in Kilbati Rasu-Zone 2 was held in Hayu town in Elidar woreda (Awsi-Zone 1, Afar).

On 30 January 2022, Galmudug and federal police forces demonstrated and took control of the district magistrate court, the police station, and the commissioner administrative center in Cabudwaaq town (Cabudwaaq, Galgaduud) over unpaid salaries.
On 30 January 2022, Makerere University students demonstrated at Makerere University (Kampala, Central), demanding the physical reopening of the university.
On 31 January 2022, protest against TPLF's attack on civilians in Kilbati Rasu-Zone 2 was held in Samera Logiya town (Logiya town, Awsi-Zone 1, Afar).

On 1 February 2022, health workers protested by singing solidarity songs in Kwale (Matuga, Kwale), against stagnation in job groups. The group demanded the finalization of the promotion list among others.

On 1 February 2022, residents of Owino Uhuru slum staged a peaceful protest along the Mombasa-Nairobi highway at Banglaa area, near Jomvu (Jomvu, Mombasa county), demanding their compensation awarded by court in 2020. The residents were awarded Sh1.3 billion payout after a successfully filing a class action suit over lead poisoning from a lead smelting factory.

On 3 February 2022, KCCA government councillors and street vendors demonstrated in Kampala on Wilson road (Kampala, Central), against criminalization of street traders. Police forces intervened, blocked them and arrested 14 KCCA councillors.

On 4 February 2022, a group of Batwa held a peaceful demonstration in Rubanda (Rubanda, Western), accusing the government of neglecting them after they were evicted from the forest in 1991 for the creation of a national parks and mountain gorillas reserve
On 4 February 2022, local residents staged a peaceful protest in Kiligoris (Transmara West Narok County), over the poor state of the Kilgoris sub-county hospital.

Around 7 February 2022 (as reported), a section of community-based organizations took to the streets, protesting against poor diaper disposals in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu county). The group called on the National Environment Management Authority (NEMA) to engage the manufacturers on the appropriate diaper disposal methods before allowing them into the market.
On 8 February 2022, residents held a peaceful protest at Bajo forest reserve (Kayunga, Central), over the sale of the Bajo central forest reserve .

On 8 February 2022, several opposition MPs, including NUP members, demonstrated at the office of the Parliament in Kampala (Kamapala, Central), demanding the police release an arrested opposition MPs. Police arrested Joyce Bagala, the Mityana District Woman Representative for allegedly sneaking in dozens of t-shirts for the opposition MPs to support their campaign against torture in the country. There were no causalities.

On 8 February 2022, students demonstrated for a second day at Makerere University (Kampala, Central) against online lectures. Police and military forces shot tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. A student lost his right hand in an explosion of a teargas canister.

On 8 February 2022, local residents took to the streets, protesting over an eight-month electricity outage by the Kenya Power and Lighting Company (KPLC) in Nyatieko village near Marani township (Kitutu Chache North, Kisii county).

On 8 February 2022, over 32 private security guards staged a demonstration by locking the gates to the county revenue offices in Kitale town (Saboti, Trans Nzoia County), to protest abuse by the newly posted enforcement director. The incident paralyzed operations for better part of the morning.

On 9 February 2022, business people staged a protest at a market in Kiambu (Kiambu town, Kiambu county), accusing a 70-year old woman for allegedly practicing witchcraft which negatively affects their businesses.

On 12 February 2022, hundreds of tuk tuk riders protested against the decision of local municipality to prohibit the use of tuk tuk's on the main tarmac road due to increased traffic congestion at the NECSOM area in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal).
On 13 February 2022, taxi drivers peacefully demonstrated against the increased fuel price in Hargeysa (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed).
On 13 February 2022, a group of Galmudug security forces blocked (through unspecified means) the main supply road in Gaalkacyo (Gaalkacyo, Mudug) due to unpaid salaries.

On 14 February 2022, dozens of torture survivors, likely affiliated to NUP, stormed the Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) on Kololo hill, Kampala city (Kampala, Central), protesting the silence of the Uganda Human Rights Commission on torture incidents by security operatives.

On 14 February 2022, local residents demonstrated demanding the release of journalist in Ceerigaabo town (Ceerigaabo, Sanaag). The journalist who was arrested in August 2021 for accusing Abaarso school of spreading Christianity and believed to be critical to the government of Somaliland. The Somaliland police fired teargas canisters and warning shots (live bullets not specified) to dispersed the crowd.

On 14 February 2022, over 400 students from Pemwai girls secondary school marched from the institution to Kabarnet town (Baringo central, Baringo county), following the death of two students. They accused the school principal of negligence and called on the county director of education to intervene.

On 15 February 2022, a section of students at Kyambogo University protested in Kyambogo (Central, Kampala), over missing coursework marks. They accused the management of failing to resolve the issue of missing marks in order to impose on them surcharges especially those in the final year.

On 15 February 2022, the Mayor of Kawempe, Emmanuel Sserunjogi, organized a rally in Kawempe (Kampala, Central), to protest the continued detention of Kawempe North MP Muhammed Ssegirinya. Police and army forces intervened, blocked Sserunjogi from accessing the venue, and foiled the rally.

On 16 February 2022, a section of Kyengera Town Council residents blocked the Kampala-Masaka road in Kyengera (Wakiso, Central), demanding the arrest of a policeman who killed a local. The demonstrators carried the coffin containing the remains of the deceased which they placed in the middle of the road. Police officers fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators and confiscated the coffin. There were no causalities.

On 16 February 2022, protest against recent abduction and killing of farmers in Shenkora Shesheng kebele in Wara Jarso woreda was held in front of Goha Tsion police station in Gohatsion in Wara Jarso woreda (North Shewa zone, Oromia. Demonstrators blocked (through unspecified means) the main road Abay Berha which connects Goha Tsion with Bahir Dar city for several hours.

On 17 February 2022, a section of councilors at Mityana Municipality Council, the majority from NUP, held placards and marched out of the council in Mityana (Mityana, Central), demanding the release of National Unity Platform (NUP) supporters.

On 17 February 2022, members from unidentified clan blocked (means unspecified) the Main Supply Road along the Gaalkayo-Garowe at Boone village near Garow town (Garoowe, Nugaal). The locals wanted the local authorities to release a female who was earlier arrested by the police over land dispute issues.

Around 17 February 2022 (as reported), local residents joined by a Member of Parliament (MP), staged a protest outside the sub-county birth and deaths registration office in Maragwa (Muranga South, Muranga county) over the delay in issuing birth certificates. No further information.

On 18 February 2022, residents in Abuna Gindeberet peacefully protested against OLF Shane rebels in Awara, Abuna Ginde Beret (West Shewa, Oromia) and demanded the militant group to stop, what they say, 'brutal attacks on civilians lives and property destruction in the name of the struggle for Oromos'.

On 19 February 2022, local residents protested opposing the construction of the telecommunication tower by SOMCABLE company in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed). Somaliland police dispersed the protesters.

On 20 February 2022, local residents demonstrated at the Kiptagich trading centre near Keringet (Kuresoi South, Nakuru County), calling for justice, following the deaths of three people allegedly at the hands of the police.

On 20 February 2022, Yemeni refugees protested at the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS) field office in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari) against the poor living conditions and lack of support from organizations.

On 20 February 2022, several local residents from the Banadiri clan protested against the Somalia Prime Minister in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir) accusing him of interfering in their electoral seats and rejected the electoral commission appointed by PM to oversee those seats.
Around 21 February 2022 (as reported), women staged a peaceful demonstration in Tiati (Tiaty, Baringo county), condemning the attack on a school bus ferrying students the week before.

On 21 February 2022, human rights activists including Muslims for Human Rights (MUHURI), staged a peaceful protest outside the law courts in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in solidarity with their colleagues who were found guilty of contravening coronavirus mitigation protocols. Singing freedom songs, the activists accused the courts of double standards and vowed not to be cowered into silence through intimidation.

On 21 February 2022, three protestors who claimed to be torture survivors demonstrated in Nakasero (Kampala, Central), against the attitude of the deputy speaker of mocking torture victims. Police forces blocked them from accessing the deputy speaker's home and dispersed them.

On 21 February 2022, parents demonstrated at the gate of Good Times Infant School, in Kawaala (Kampala, Central), after being blocked from accessing the school following reports that a pupil died in a fire.

On 21 February 2022, more than 40 teachers stormed the office of the Arua Chief Administrative Officer in Arua (Arua, Northern), protesting the delayed payment of their salaries. The teachers threatened to lay their tools, saying that they haven't received any pay since this financial year started in July.

On 21 February 2022, a section of Ethiopian nationals living in Kenya, joined by human rights activists from Haki Africa, staged a protest in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi county), petitioning the Cabinet Secretary (CS), on the whereabouts of businessman Samson Teklemichael, who was allegedly abducted by Kenyan security forces, three months ago.
On 22 February 2022, demonstrators held a protest at the gate of the deputy speaker In Nakasero (Kampala, Centra), over the attitude of the deputy speaker of mocking torture victims.

On 22 February 2022, a section of county government workers staged a peaceful protest by blocking (through unspecified means) the entrance to city hall in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe county). The workers demanded timely payment of their salaries and improvement of their working conditions.

On 23 February 2022, human rights activists, bearing anti-torture messages, demonstrated on Parliament Avenue in Kampala (Kampala, Central), against the attitude of the deputy speaker of mocking torture victims. Security operatives intervened and dispersed the demonstrators.

On 23 February 2022, boda boda taxi operators protested by blocking the Witu road (means unspecified) [coded as Witu, Lamu West, Lamu], against harassment by the police. The operators demanded the tranfer of the police officers.

On 24 February 2022, students from Kijomoro Secondary School burnt the food store and the office of the bursar, destroyed vital documents and the school gate among others in Kijomoro (Maracha, Northern), after the school administration rejected their demand to dance during the inauguration function for the new prefects. Police shot live bullets to calm the situation. There were no causalities.
On 24 February 2022, locals demonstrated in Entebbe (Wakiso, Central), over the killing of a local carpenter in unclear circumstances.

On 26 February 2022, two self-help groups and local residents staged a protest in Kinondo (Masambweni, Kwale county) over the alleged grabbing of their land by a private developer. The protestors called on the government to probe the land injustice.

On 26 February 2022, local protesters, including Russia and Ukraine nationals living in Kenya, staged a protest, by assembling and carrying banners outside the Russian embassy, in Kilimani (Dagoretti North, Nairobi county), demanding end of Russian invasion of Ukraine. The group was later dispersed by the police, citing lack of approval for their demonstration.

On 27 February 2022, over hundred local residents protested against the Jubaland state president in Belet Xaawo town (Belet Xaawo, Gedo). The protesters also accused the government of Kenya of interfering lower house elections of the Gedo region.

On 27 February 2022, hundreds of local residents staged a protest over the abandoned construction of Karatu stadium, near Gacarage (Gatundu South, Kiambu county). They called on the president to compel the contractor to finish the project.

On 27 February 2022, 13 truck drivers staged a demonstration against the trackdown operation by the Kenya National Highways Authority (KeNHA) on the Thika-Nairobi Highway, near Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu county), by abandoning their trucks on the highway. Police intervened and thwarted their efforts.

On 28 February 2022, hundreds of local residents protested against the increased cost of living and the current economic situation in Borama town (Borama, Awdal). The Somaliland police dispersed the protestors.

On 28 February 2022, local residents protested against police operation targeting illicit brew in Moi's bridge area, near Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia county), by barricading the Eldoret Kitale road using stones and lit fire along Mois Bridge. Police fired live bullets to disperse the crowd. One person was killed during the incident.
On 1 March 2022, residents protested in Kochia near Rangwe (Rangwe, Homa Bay) against the claimed poor workmanship of the Maugo bridge. The group demanded that authorities address the matter.

On 1 March 2022, a group of Muslims protested the new leadership of Kyazanga Central Mosque (Lwengo, Central). Kyazanga Central Mosque has developed rival factions over leadership. Police intervened to disperse the demonstration.
On 1 March 2022, over 400 Lokichoggio-Juba road construction workers, staged a protest in Lokichoggio (Turkana West, Turkana county), demanding better wages and allowances from their employer.
On 1 March 2022, students at Kitui Teachers Training College (TTC) marched to the sub-county education office in Kitui (Kitui), demanding a better learning environment. No further information.

On 1 March 2022, digital taxi operators under the digital taxi forum (dtf) to took to the streets of Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi county), to demonstrate the failure by the cabinet secretary (cs) of transport to gazette the digital hailing service regulations.

On 2 March 2022, local residents protested against the district commissioner, accusing him of stealing humanitarian aid in Raga Ceel village (Balcad, Middle Shabelle). Security forces fired live bullets to disperse the crowd. One person was killed.

On 2 March 2022, armed clan militias from Warsangeli sub-clan blocked the main road (through unspecified means) in Ceel Daahir town (Bossaso, Bari). The motive of the blockage is due to a dispute of a parliamentarian seat. Local clan elders intervened.

On 2 March 2022, a section of farmers took to the streets in Muranga (Kiharu, Muranga county), protesting against the massive importation of eggs from neighbouring Uganda. The protestors called on the government to regulate the importation of poultry products and the restore the market.

On 3 March 2022, members from Sheeqaal clan militia blocked the main roads (through unspecified means) in Gaalkacyo town (Gaalkacyo, Mudug), complaining about the seat number HOP#20 that was reserved for women and they requested that the seat be open for both, men and women.

On 3 March 2022, local residents staged a peaceful protest in Etago near Ikoba (South Mugirango, Kisii county), calling for justice, following the mysterious death of a middle aged man while in police custody.

On 3 March 2022, some aspirants of the jubilee party, protested the closure of their party offices in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru county), before some could present their nomination papers. No further information.

On 3 March 2022, a section of local residents staged a demonstration in Kitui (Kitui) by camping outside the county commissioner's office. The protestors demanded compensation after being displaced by the ongoing tarmacking of the Kibwezi-Migwani road project.
On 3 March 2022, health workers a staged a demonstration in Mbale town (Vihiga, Vihiga county), as they sought audience with the government health officials, over their seven month delayed pay.

On 3 March 2022, local residents demonstrated at Ariri village in Ndhiwa (Ndhiwa, Homa Bay county), following the knocking down of a boda boda taxi operator and killing of his pillion passenger by a truck driver from a local sugar miller. The demonstrators decried the increased rate of accidents in the area by the tuck drivers and carried the body of the victim to the millers main gate, demanding action to be taken.

On 4 March 2022, about 1000 Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs) of the 2007-8 post-election violence protested by walking to the Kiambu county assembly in Kiambu town (Kiambu Town, Kiambu). The protestors demanded the Members of County Assembly (MCAs) to address their resettlement issue.

Around 4 March 2022 (as reported), a group of around 100 county government cleaners took to the streets in Homa Bay (Homa Bay Central, Homa Bay Town, Homa Bay) demanding for the immediate payment of their seven-month salary arrears and threatening to take legal action against the county government.

On 5 March 2022, members from Gaaljecel clan militia blocked the Liiqliiqato bridge (through unspecified means) in Belet Weyne town (Belet Weyne, Hiraan), complaining about the seat number HOP# 30 that is only reserved for the MP who is currently occupying the seat. The militia were calling the seat to be open for all contesting candidates.

On 5 March 2022, Oromo students in Addis Ababa University gathered in sidist kilo campus and protested against what they say is 'hatred of Oromos' in the leaflets distributed in the university campus, (Gulele, Region 14, Addis Ababa).
On 5 March 2022, local pastoralists staged a peaceful protest in Mochongoi (Mogotio, Baringo county), decrying the increased rate of insecurity in the area. No further information.

On 7 March 2022, clinical interns from across the country, staged a peaceful demonstration, by marching while carrying placards from the General Post Office (GPO) within the Nairobi central business district (CBD) to the ministry of health offices near Uhuru Park (Dagoretti North; Nairobi county), demanding for their delayed 7 months stipend.

On 8 March 2022, several people, including students, protested against the fact finding committee appointed by the Prime Minister in Garbahaarey town (Garbahaarey, Gedo). The committee was tasked to solve the Gedo election dispute between the Gedo administration and Jubaland state.

On 8 March 2022, councillors in Busega led by Lubaga South MP of the NUP party, Aloysius Mukasa, celebrated Women's Day by marching in Busega (Kampala, Central), against the violation of their rights like early marriages, rape among others.

On 8 March 2022, National Unity Platform (NUP) supporters demonstrated in Luwero (Luwero, Central), accusing the police of blocking the venue that was meant for their celebrations. Police used tear gas to disperse the demonstrators.

On 8 March 2022, a section of women, joined by their local political leaders, staged a peaceful demonstration outside harambee house in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), condemning an incident where a woman motorist, was harassed by boda boda taxi operators (coded separately).

Around 9 March 2022 (as reported), residents, mainly farmers, protested in an unspecified location in Kochia East ward (coded to Ndiru, Rangwe, Homa Bay) against the construction of a culvert in the Maugo River, on Otolo-Ang'iro Road. The protestors demanded that the government remove the culverts and instead construct a bridge on the river.

On 9 March 2022, more than 400 students from Mbarara University of Science and Technology-MUST demonstrated at the Mbarara Resident City Commissioner in Mbarara (Mbarara, Western), demanding the release of their school practice allowances.
On 9 March 2022, over 50 students of Muni University peacefully demonstrated in Arua City (Arua, Northern), over unpaid living allowances meant for government sponsored students.

On 9 March 2022, several health workers staged a peaceful protest against the neglect of their welfare by the health department, by marching to the County Public Service Board (CPSB) offices in Voi (Voi, Taita Taveta county), where they submitted their petition.

On 10 March 2022, boda boda taxi operators demonstrated at Githurai (Nairobi - Roysambu, Nairobi countiy), by blocking a section of the Thika Superhighway using stones. The operators decried police harassment, following the nationwide crackdown.

On 10 March 2022, university students staged a protest in Nakuru town (Nakuru North, Nakuru county), over the alleged closure of industries, that has led to the increased unemployment rate of fresh graduates. No further information.

On 10 March 2022, boda boda taxi operators protested by storming into Kerugoya police station in Kerugoya (Kirinyaga Central, Kirinyaga), in solidarity with their colleagues who had been arrested, following the nationwide crackdown on the operators. Police intervened by firing tear gas to disperse them.
On 11 March 2022, over 1000 students from Mbarara university (both from the Main Campus and Kihumuro) demonstrated in Mbarara (Mbarara, Western), over poor living conditions.

On 11 March 2022, a group of visually impaired ethnic Oromo youths, who graduated from various universities, gathered in front of Addis Ababa Stadium, and marched to the office of the Oromia regional state president, at Mesqel Square, Kirkos (Region 14, Addis Ababa). The group protested against the recruitment policy of the regional government, claiming it is 'discriminatory and against their right to descent work'. The oromia regional special police dispersed them. No casualties.

On 14 March 2022, local residents staged a peaceful demonstration in Kiambu (Kiambu Town, Kiambu), against Deputy President William Ruto and his allies part of the Kenya Kwanza Alliance for allegedly hurling insults towards President Uhuru Kenyatta during a recently rally. The protestors demanded respect for the president and promised to follow his political direction to guard their community interests.

On 14 March 2022, local residents staged a peaceful demonstration in Kikuyu (Kikuyu, Kiambu), against the Deputy President William Ruto and his allies in Kenya Kwanza Alliance for allegedly hurling insults on President Uhuru Kenyatta during a recently held rally. The protestors demanded respect for the president and promised to follow his political direction to guard their community interests.

On 14 March 2022, local residents staged a peaceful demonstration in Githurai (Roysambu, Nairobi), against Deputy President William Ruto and his allies in Kenya Kwanza Alliance for allegedly hurling insults on President Uhuru Kenyatta during a recently held rally. The protestors demanded respect for the president and promised to follow his political direction to guard their community interests.

On 14 March 2022, workers at the university of Eldoret, staged a peaceful protest, by singing and chanting slogans outside the institution's gate in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu), over the delayed implementation of the 2017-2021 bargaining agreement and payment of their dues. The workers demanded audience with the university management.

On 14 March 2022, a group of workers staged a protest against the loss of employment in the Modern Railway Project between Mwanza to Isaka in the Shinyaga region. Protesters blocked (means unspecified) a bus holding the convoy of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Infrastructure in the Fela area of Misungwi district of Mwanza (Nyamagana, Mwanza). The protesters lamented that workers had arrived in the area, but only those who offered bribes were given employment.

On 14 March 2022, a group of citizens protested against the lack of payment of compensation of more than Sh800 million and the return for their lands taken for the construction of the Modern Railway Project between Mwanza to Isaka in the Shinyanga region. The protest took place in the Fela area of Misungwi district of Mwanza (Nyamagana, Mwanza). The district commission admitted in response that citizens had not been compensated.

On 14 March 2022, tens of local residents staged a peaceful demonstration in Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu), against Deputy President William Ruto and his allies in Kenya Kwanza Alliance for allegedly hurling insults on President Uhuru Kenyatta during a recently held rally. The protestors demanded respect for the president and promised to follow his political direction to guard their community interests.

On 15 March 2022, taxi drivers parked their vehicles, blocking Mbale-Soroti road in Mbale city (Mbale, Eastern), protesting a move by authorities to gazette a parking area for them, in a bid to stop roadside loading of passengers.
On 16 March 2022, local residents marched carrying placards in Kapchorwa (Kapchorwa, Eastern), over shortage of safe and clean water.

On 17 March 2022, residents of Debati woreda gathered in Barbara (Metekel, Benishangul/Gumuz) and peacefully demonstrated condemning what they say are 'increasing atrocities by the Amhara forces' and requested the withdrawal of Amhara special police and fanno youth militias from the region.

On 17 March 2022, protesters in Semera (Awsi-Zone 1, Afar), demonstrated against the TPLF invasion into Afar region and denounced the federal government's lack of response. Security forces consisting of the Afar regional special forces and city police violently dispersed the protesters, injuring 20 people.

On 17 March 2022, a group of youth from Kampala Ghetto Ambassadors association, in yellow NRM shirts, demonstrated at the State House in Entebbe (Wakiso, Central), seeking to meet President over undisclosed reasons. They were blocked by security at the main entrance.

On 17 March 2022, local residents took to the streets over the poor health services at the Nanyuki Referral Hospital in Nanyuki town (Thingithu, Laikipia). Carrying placards, the protestors marched to the county's secretary's office, demanding the reinstatement of doctors who were fired 3 years ago and to ensure the hospital has medicine to improve service delivery.
On 18 March 2022, around 400 scrap metal dealers staged a peaceful protest in Nakuru town (Nakuru North, Nakuru), demanding a lift on the ban on trade in scrap metals.

On 18 March 2022, a group of youth, presumed Jubilee Party and Azimio coalition supporters, disrupted a United Democratic Alliance (UDA) organized rally by shouting Jubilee Coalition and Azimio slogans in Kiamwangi (Githunguri, Kiambu). The Deputy President's security (believed to be police) dispersed the group.

On 18 March 2022, presumed supporters of Jubilee Coalition protested by carrying placards and blocking a road (though unspecified means) in Gatundu (Gatundu South, Kiambu), demonstrating against the Deputy President (DP) William Ruto, demanding that he respects the president. The DP's security (believed to be police) cleared the protestors.

On 19 March 2022, about 100 families displaced by the construction of the railway staged a peaceful protest in Mai Mahiu (Naivasha, Nakuru), demanding for compensation of their lost land. No further information.

On 21 March 2022, clinical interns staged a peaceful demonstration by marching while carrying placards to the ministry of health offices near Uhuru Park in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands), demanding their unpaid stipends.

On 22 March 2022, local residents took to the streets, by carrying placards and singing, as they decried the water shortage problem in the Nyayo Embakasi neighborhood of Embakasi divison (Embakasi South, Nairobi).

On 22 March 2022, local residents staged a demonstration by chanting slogans and blocking an unspecified road with logs and twigs in Fulugani, near Miritini (Kinango, Kwale), demanding equal job opportunities at the construction site of the Mwache multipurpose dam project.

On 22 March 2022, LGBTQ community members, joined by human rights activists, staged a peaceful protest by carrying placards and marching to the Ministry of Health offices in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) over the draft Sexual Reproductive Health (SRH) policy 2022-2032. The protestors demanded their rights to be included in the new policy.

On 22 March 2022, unknown number of Nubian community members, under the umbrella of 'Nubians Right Forum,' staged a protest by carrying placards while addressing the press in Kibera (Kibra, Nairobi), demanding recognition by the government, as one of the tribes in Kenya.
On 23 March 2022, a group of women protested in front of the governor's office complaining of shortage of water caused by droughts in Caynabo town (Caynabo, Sool).

Around 23 March 2022 (week of), members of the Yala Swamp Community staged a protest in Yala (Gem, Siaya) against claims that the Rai company has continued cultivating in the swamp, despite a court order prohibiting any activity.

On 24 March 2022, a group of women, joined by their local political leaders, staged a protest in Nairobi Central Business District (CBD) (Nairobi - Starehe), against insults directed at Mama Ngina Kenyatta by a foreign-based Kenyan man, who is also a Deputy President (DP) Ruto's supporter.

On 25 March 2022, youth staged a protest in Kom Durte (Merti, Isiolo) against the rising cases of insecurity in the area. The group demanded the government to remove armed herders and enhance security along the Losesia-Kom route.

On 25 March 2022, local residents blocked (through unspecified means) the Kenya Power company staff from taking down their transformer in Baraka area, Thingithu ward near Nanyuki (Laikipia East, Laikipia). No further information.

Around 25 March 2022 (as reported), a group of squatters staged a protest at Kapoto land, within the Chepchoina settlement scheme (Endebess, Trans Nzoia), against the conditions they have been living in without shelter. The group demanded the government to resettle them within a month.

On 26 March 2022, online apps taxi operators staged a protest, also placing placards on their cars in Kiambaa (Kiambaa, Kiambu), against the rising insecurity in the sector. The operators appealed to the government to protect their way of life.

On 26 March 2022, university students staged a protest by blocking the Busia-Kisumu road (through unspecified means) at Maseno (Kisumu West, Kisumu), against the increasing insecurity cases at the university. Police intervened by lobbing tear gas canisters to disperse the students.

On 26 March 2022, group of pro-life activists (Kenya Christians Professional Forum and Uhai Consortium), staged a protest by matching, while carrying banners and placards in the streets of Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against abortion.

On 27 March 2022, journalists staged a protest by marching and carrying placards in Lodwar town (Turkana Central, Turkana), against the alleged mistreatment by a section of employees in the governor's office.
Around 28 March 2022 (as reported), boda boda taxi operators staged a protest in Kakuma (Turkana West, Turkana) against fuel prices.

On 29 March 2022, donkey owners demonstrated by carrying carcasses to Kitengela police station (Kajiado East, Kajiado), against the rampant donkey theft. The protestors alleged that the donkey theft was affecting their businesses of supplying water to locals.

On 29 March 2022, a group of workers demonstrated and marched from Jivanjee gardens and presented a petition at parliament buildings in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe). The demonstration was against unstandardized forms of employment and continuous abuse of employment rights by employers.

Around 30 March 2022 (as reported), family members, joined by local residents, rights activists, civil society organizations including MUHURI, staged a protest in Kwale (Matuga, Kwale), against the disappearance of a man, Amani Mohammed Mwafujo also known as Saad (coded separately). They demanded that the government assist them locate him.

On 30 March 2022, locals, led by the councillor of Okungur, entered the office of the resident district commissioner (RDC) in Kapelebyong (Kapelebyong, Kapelebyong) with the body of a man shot by suspected Karimojong rustlers (coded separately), to express what they called their dissatisfaction over the security in the area.

Around 30 March 2022 (as reported), residents blocked the road with stones in demonstration urging the government to put zebra ridges and markers in Mwatulole (Geita, Geita), after a primary school student was hit by a truck and died while crossing the road.

On 30 March 2022, parents protested at Chingondi primary school (Bomet Central, Bomet), against the poor results posted in the 2021 Kenya certificate of primary examination (KCPE). The parents demanded for the transfer of the school head teacher.

On 31 March 2022, a section of Galmudug security forces stationed in Baxdo village blocked the main road (through unspecified means) in the vicinity of Cadaado town (Cadaado, Galgaduud), protesting against their unpaid salaries for three months.

On 31 March 2022, parents staged a protest for a second day by carrying twigs and chanting slogans at Kapchepsir Primary School near Kilibwoni Constituency (Emgwen, Nandi), against the poor results posted in the 2021 Kenya Certificate of Primary Examination (KCPE). The parents accused the teachers of laxity and absenteeism.

On 31 March 2022, a section of pro-Orange Democratic Movement (ODM) youth staged a protest by walking and chanting anti-Ongera slogans across the streets of Kisii town (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii), against the decision by the party to hand a direct ticket to the woman representative, Janet Ongera. The protestors supported Donya Toto.

On 1 April 2022, a group of residents from the Greater Kilembe Sub-county demonstrated at the municipal offices in Kasese (Kasese, Western), demanding the relocation of Kilembe Mines Hospital from Kasese town to Bulembia Division.

On 1 April 2022, a group of youth, presumed United Democratic Alliance (UDA) and Kenya Kwanza Alliance supporters, disrupted an Orange Democratic Movement (ODM) and Azimio la Umoja organized rally by shouting the name of their presidential candidate (opponent) in Iten (Keiyo North, Elgeyo Marakwet). The rally ended prematurely.

On 1 April 2022, a group of Orange Democratic Movement (ODM) supporters staged a protest by carrying placards and chanting slogans in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against claims that some aspirants will be given direct nominations ahead of the exercise.

On 1 April 2022, officials from the Kenya driving schools association (KDSA) and students staged a protest by carrying banners and singing, outside the general post office (GPO) in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against the prolonged closure of the examination portal by the national transport and safety authority (NTSA). The group was joined by MUHURI: Muslims for Human Rights.

On 1 April 2022, sand transporters under the Mogochendo transporters group banner staged a protest in Rachuonyo (Kasipul, Homa Bay), against alleged 'harassment by police and county revenue officials. The group presented their grievances to the assistant county commissioner (ACC).

On 3 April 2022, residents matched with placards to Sisuni sub county headquarters (Manafwa, Eastern), demanding the repair of broken boreholes in their areas. Residents have been walking long distances to Namisindwa district to access clean water.

On 5 April 2022, residents of Beltu town gathered in Beltu, Lege Hida woreda (East Bale, Oromia) in a demonstration against what they say is 'electric power disruption in their town'. Oromia regional special police force opened gunfire, beat, and wounded unknown number of protesters to disperse the gathering. Over 30 people, accused of organizing the protest, were also arrested. There were no fatalities.

On 5 April 2022, boda boda taxi operators staged a protest against alleged police harassment in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi). Police intervened and arrested at least 10 operators and seized twenty motorcycles.

On 5 April 2022, hundreds of women, affiliated to Azimio la Umoja One Kenya Coalition party and led by the Nairobi women representative dressed in blue outfits, waved placards as they marched from Agha Khan walk to parliament buildings in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against the recent attack on their presidential candidate Raila Odinga. The women handed over flowers to legislatures, urging them to preach peace during campaigns.

On 5 April 2022, health workers attached to Kitale County Referral Hospital staged a protest by carrying placards and marching in the streets of Kitale town (Saboti, Trans Nzoia), over the lack of medical supplies. The protesting workers were joined by students from the Kenya Medical Training College KMTC, Kitale campus and demanded for the restructuring of the health department.

On 5 April 2022, supporters of Democratic Action Party of Kenya (DAP-Kenya), an affiliate to Azimio la Umoja One Kenya Coalition party, staged a protest by carrying placards and banners in Kakamega town (Lurambi, Kakamega) against the recent attack on their presidential candidate Raila Odinga. The protestors were led by their deputy party leader.

On 6 April 2022, hundreds of supporters from the ODM party staged a protest by carrying twigs, chanting and blocked (through unspecified means) the Kisii-Kilgoris near Igembe (Bomachoge Borabu, Kisii), following the killing of their member of county aspirant (coded separately). The protesters demanded justice for the slain politician.

On 6 April 2022, local residents demonstrated by carrying banners, twigs and chanting slogans in Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi) against the government delay in compensating them, for their land, meant for the airport expansion. The protestors demanded a fresh evaluation of their properties since the cost of living has gone up.

On 7 April 2022, members of Mareko ethnic group from Gurage zone held a peaceful demonstration in front of SNNP regional president office in Hawasa (Sidama, Sidama) and demanded their right to self-govern under a new special woreda structure, separated from Gurage zone, and demarcation of 9 kebeles bordering Mareko with Mesken woreda.

On 7 April 2022, dozens of demonstrators, carrying placards, chanting, wailing, kneeling down and facing the sky, walked from Jeevanjee gardens to the office of the President on Harambee Avenue in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against the death of a 15-year-old girl who was also a form one student, who died mysteriously in school in 2019. The demonstrators were joined by family, friends (assumed fellow students), and primary school teachers and demanded justice.

On 8 April 2022, Muslim students held protests against 'government interference into religious matters' in several mosques in Addis Ababa after they accused schools of preventing students from holding prayers and other activities on school premises. Location coded to Addis Aba (Region 14).

On 8 April 2022, support staff at the Garissa teachers training college (TTC) demonstrated by carrying twigs and chanting outside the institution's gate in Garissa (Garissa, Garissa) against the delays in payment of their salary.
On 8 April 2022, a section of boda boda taxi operators demonstrated in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the detention of their colleagues in police custody.

On 8 April 2022, supporters of a parliamentary aspirant for the Orange Democratic Movement (ODM) party staged a protest by waving placards while marching in Katito and Sondu markets, near Nyakach (Nyakach, Kisumu), against the issuance of a direct nomination ticket to incumbent member of parliament (MP).

On 8 April 2022, supporters of ODM demonstrated by chanting slogans at Sir Ali Primary School, within Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi) against the move by the party's national elections board, to cancel the nomination exercise and award a direct ticket, to the sitting member of county assembly.

Around 9 April 2022 (as reported), Burundian refugees demonstrated and started a sit-in protest by camping in front of the office of the Ugandan government representative in Nakivale Refugee Camp (Isingiro, western), seeking asylum. The group organized a sit in for two weeks.

On 9 April 2022, youth employed by the Kenya youth employment and opportunity project (KYEOP) demonstrated by carrying twigs and marching in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii), against delayed pay of their wages.
