On 10 August 2022, DAP, Azimio supporters affiliated to a gubernatorial aspirant demonstrated by forcing themselves into the county tallying centre at St, Monica girls, Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against claims of electoral malpractices. Police officers intervened (through unspecified means) to restore order.

On 10 August 2022, UDA, Kenya kwanza supporters allied to a gubernatorial aspirant demonstrated by camping outside the tallying centre in Kapenguria (West Pokot, West Pokot), against delay in announcing the poll results. Police intervened and fired teargas to disperse the group.

On 10 August 2022, youth protested outside the Nyamache tallying centre (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against claims of voter rigging. Police intervened and charged batons at the group. One youth was injured during the incident.

On 11 August 2022, local residents demonstrated at Mbalambala tallying centre (Bura, Tana River), following the announcement of the member of the national assembly results. The police shot at the demonstrators. No details on the injuries.

On 11 August 2022, a group of supporters allied to an independent gubernatorial candidate demonstrated by waving placards and chanting outside the Gichugu tallying centre in Kiamutugu (Muranga South, Muranga), against claims of vote fraud. Police intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the group.

On 11 August 2022, several local residents and supporters of Wadani and Justice and Welfare Party of Somaliland party (UCID) demanded that the presidential elections should be held on time in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed). Police forces fired live bullets and teargas canisters to disperse the crowd. At least three demonstrators were killed, several others were injured and others were arrested.

On 11 August 2022, several local residents and supporters of Wadani and Justice and Welfare Party of Somaliland party (UCID) demanded that presidential elections should be held on time in Burco town (Burco, Togdheer). The police forces fired live bullets and teargas canisters to disperse the crowd. One demonstrator was killed, several others were injured and others were arrested.

On 11 August 2022, several local residents and supporters of Wadani and Justice and Welfare Party of Somaliland party (UCID) demanded that presidential elections should be held on time in Ceerigaabo town (Ceerigaabo, Sanaag). Police forces fired live bullets and teargas canisters to disperse the crowd. One demonstrator was killed, several others were injured and others were arrested.

On 11 August 2022, several local residents and supporters of Wadani and Justice and Welfare Party of Somaliland party (UCID) demanded that presidential elections should be held on time in Berbera town (Berbera, Woqooyi Galbeed). The police forces fired teargas canisters to disperse the crowd.

On 11 August 2022, several local residents and supporters of Wadani and Justice and Welfare Party of Somaliland party (UCID) demanded that presidential elections should be held on time in Borama town (Borama, Awdal). The police forces fired teargas canisters to disperse the crowd.

On 11 August 2022, several local residents and supporters of Wadani and Justice and Welfare Party of Somaliland party (UCID) demanded that presidential elections should be held on time in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool). The police forces fired teargas canisters to disperse the crowd.

On 12 August 2022, residents of Dano woreda, gathered in Seyo town (West Shewa, Oromia) and protested what they say is 'atrocities against civilians and lootings and property destruction by OLF Shane'.

On 12 August 2022, UDA, Kenya kwanza supporters allied to a governor candidate demonstrated by chanting and forcing their way into the vote tallying venue at Kangaru high school in Embu (Manyatta, Embu), against delay in declaration of results. Police intervened and forcefully pushed away the crowd from the venue leading to manhandling of those who resisted. Several people were injured during the incident.

On 12 August 2022, an ODM-Azimio governor candidate and his supporters demonstrated by storming the Kilgoris boys secondary school tallying centre (Transmara West, Narok), over claims of electoral irregularities. The group demanded a recount of the votes.

On 13 August 2022, ODM- Azimio supporters allied to a gubernatorial candidate blocked (through unspecified means), the Narok-Mahiu Highway in Narok town (Narok North, Narok), against alleged rigging and malpractices during the voting exercise.

On 13 August 2022, UDA-Kenya Kwanza supporters allied to a gubernatorial candidate blocked (through unspecified means), the Narok-Bomet road in Narok town (Narok North, Narok), against the move by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) to delay announcing the voting results. The group demanded IEBC to declare their preferred candidate as the winner of the race.

On 14 August 2022, local residents and traders demonstrated by marching in Lokichar town (Turkana South, Turkana), against increasing crime in the area. The traders demanded for enhanced security surveillance; the repair of vandalized street lights as well as immediate transfer of security officers.

On 14 August 2022, a section of youth, women leaders protested in Nyandarua (Kinangop, Nyandarua), against alleged electoral fraud in the gubernatorial contest. The group demanded a repeat of the elections.

On 14 August 2022, UDA- KKA supporters allied to a governor candidate protested in Narok town (Narok North, Narok), against the delay of announcement of gubernatorial results. Police intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the group as well as arrested some of the supporters.
On 14 August 2022, candidates of various elective positions protested in Kiambu (Kiambu Town, Kiambu), against vote rigging. The group demanded a recount of the votes.

On 14 August 2022, a section of youth, mainly Azimio supporters demonstrated by camping outside the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) national tallying center at the Bomas of Kenya in Langata (Langata, Nairobi), against the move by the commission to bar some leaders from getting into the tallying centre. Police used horses to disperse the group.

On 15 August 2022, about 120 refugees protested in front of UNSMS office due to unpaid cash substance allowance for August 2022, the poor living conditions, and lack of proper support in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari).

On 15 August 2022, Azimio supporters protested in Bondo (Bondo, Siaya) against the move by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) to declare William Ruto as the winner of the presidential race. The group demanded that the commission declare their preferred candidate as the winner of the election.
On 15 August 2022, residents blocked Adjumani Airstrip- Openzinzi -Amuru road with logs and old car tyres in Mgbere Cell in Adjumani town council (Adjumani, Uganda) demonstrating its poor state.

On 15 August 2022, local residents demonstrated at Arina estate in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu), following the announcement of the presidential election results. The police shot and injured one of the demonstrators.

On 17 August 2022, refugees protested in front of UNSMS office due to unpaid cash substance allowance for August 2022, the poor living conditions, and lack of proper support in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari).

On 18 August 2022, thousands of ODM- Azimio supporters demonstrated by singing, chanting and carrying placards, as they camped outside the independent electoral and boundaries commission (IEBC) offices in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), against the move by the commission to indefinitely postpone the gubernatorial elections for the 2nd time. The group demanded the elections to go on as planned.

On 18 August 2022, local residents, mainly ODM- Azimio supporters demonstrated by singing, chanting, carrying placards and banners as they marched in Kakakenga (Lurambi, Kakamega), against the move by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) to indefinitely postpone the gubernatorial elections for the 2nd time. The group demanded the elections to go on as planned.

Around 19 August 2022 (as reported), a section of women from the Somali ethnic group demonstrated by marching to the subcounty commander's office while carrying twigs in Maua town (Ingembe South, Meru), against a recent incident where a businesswoman was killed and her daughter sexually assaulted. The group demanded justice.

On 21 August 2022, boda boda drivers, traditional and religious leaders, including members of the Institute of Islamic Religion of Twariqatul Qadiriya and mamalishe, gathered in demonstration in Arusha (Arusha Urban, Arusha) to encourage people to participate in the census.

On 22 August 2022, Azimio supporters demonstrated by waving placards, chanting, blowing vuvuzelas as they camped outside the Milimani law courts in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands), in support of the coalition's presidential election petition challenging President-elect William Ruto's win. Police officers intervened (through unspecified means) to disperse the group.

Around 22 August 2022 (as reported), taxi divers protested in Dar es Salaam (Ilala, Dar es Salaam) against a company which has allegedly applied illegal fines and took their cars from the areas they used to work.

On 23 August 2022, youth from the 'Torture Survivors Movement Uganda' demonstrated in front of the Embassy of Saudi Arabia in Kololo (Kampala, Kampala) over the continued deaths and torture of migrant workers in Saudi Arabia and other Middle Eastern countries.

On 23 August 2022, tens of Makohokoho primary school parents demonstrated by carrying twigs and waving placards, as they marched to the institution in Makohokoho (Gatundu North, Kiambu], against alleged mismanagement and embezzlement of funds by the school head. Led by their chairman, the parents demanded the school head to leave.
On 23 August 2022, residents demonstrated in Bukomansimbi (Bukomansimbi, Central) against the court decision threatening to evict them from a 2 square miles land.

On 23 August 2022, Mumias sugar company workers demonstrated by chanting, waving placards and marching in Mumias (Mumias West, Kakamega) against poor working conditions and mismanagement at the miller. Led by the Mumias sugar factory workers union chairman, the group demanded the management firm to vacate the miller.

On 24 August 2022, several local residents protested the killing of the head of Ceeryaan village (coded separately) and demanded free and fair elections in Ceerigaabo town (Ceerigaabo, Sanaag). The police forces fired live bullets and tear gas canisters to disperse the crowd. Three demonstrators were injured.

On 24 August 2022, a section of the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) officials demonstrated by carrying banners, waving placards, and lighting candles, holding flowers on their hands as they marched in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), against the kidnapping and killing of their colleague [coded separately]. Joined by human rights defenders, the group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 25 August 2022, members of county assembly (MCA) allied to the Azimio coalition demonstrated by walking out of the governor's inauguration ceremony in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the presence of President-elect Dr William Ruto. The group demanded that the governor ought to have informed them of the presence of the president elect.

On 25 August 2022, a section of casual labourers who have been renovating Uhuru Park demonstrated by marching and camping outside the nation centre in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against delayed payment of their dues by the Nairobi metropolitan services (NMS).

On 27 August 2022, local residents, mainly ODM-Azimio supporters, demonstrated by marching to the home of their member of parliament (MP), while carrying crude weapons and shouting, as others attempted to set it a blaze in Komoro (Ugenya, Siaya), against the move by the MP to ditch the Azimio coalition for the Kenya Kwanza alliance. Police used unspecified means to disperse the group. No details on injuries.

On 29 August 2022, a section of voters believed to be ODM-Azimio supporters protested in Mumias township primary school (Mumias West, Kakamega), against the presence of former sports cabinet secretary Rashid Echesa during the gubernatorial elections. Police intervened through dialogue and managed to restore calm.

Around 30 August 2022 (as reported), some 71 families living in Patakwa settlement scheme demonstrated by carrying twigs and marching in Saboti constituency [coded as Kinyoro, Saboti, Trans Nzoia], against an eviction order by the Kitale lands and environment court. The group demanded their elected leaders to listen to their cries and give provide a lasting solution.

On 30 August 2022, Women Association in Hadiya zone gathered and held rallies in Hosaena town, Hosaena (Hadiya, SNNP) to condemn what they said is 'recruitment of child solidiers by TPLF and unwillingness to resolve the conflict peacefully'. The protesters also called for international community to condemn the TPLF aggressions.

On 30 August 2022, Mitero primary school parents demonstrated by carrying twigs and waving placards at the institution near Lamuria (Laikipia East, Laikipia), against mismanagement by the school's administration. The parents demanded the Ministry of Education to address their concerns.
Around 31 August 2022 (as reported), hundreds of youth demonstrated by storming into the county government offices in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) to demand jobs from the new county administration.

On 1 September 2022, ANC -Kenya kwanza supporters protested in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega), against the move by the police to raid the home of former senator and gubernatorial candidate. Joined by family members, the group demanded the police to stop political witch-hunt.

On 2 September 2022, members of the Borana and Garbra demonstrated by wearing white outfits and chanting peace messages as they marched along the Moyale-Marsabit highway [coded as Turbi, North Horr, Marsabit], in support of the peaceful coexistence between the two communities.
On 2 September 2022, more than 124 health workers from different facilities in Lira district demonstrated at the district headquarters in Lira (Lira, Northern) over unpaid salaries.

On 5 September 2022, four members of the Torture Survivors Movement marched in Kampala (Kampala, Central), to petition the Speaker of Parliament on the increasing torture cases of Ugandan migrant workers. Police forces intervened and arrested the demonstrators.

On 6 September 2022, local residents demonstrated by carrying twigs and waving placards as they marched in Kainuk town (Turkana south, Turkana), against increased insecurity. The group demanded the security agencies to enhance escorts and patrols.

Around 7 September 2022 (as reported), water consumers protested in Nanyuki (Laikipia East, Laikipia), against the move by the local supplier to increase charges by 100 percent. The group demanded the new county administration to intercede and have the water company revert to the old charges and penalties.

On 8 September 2022, thousands of residents staged a peaceful rally dubbed 'Peace for Ethiopia!' in Hawasa town, Hawasa (Sidama, Sidama), calling for an end, and a peaceful resolution, to the ongoing fighting in Ethiopia. The protesters echoed slogans that focused on the virtues of peace in the parade and waved white flags symbolizing their call for peace.

On 8 September 2022, several women organized by three women-centered Indigenous civil society organizations held peace rally in the capital, Mesqel Square, Kirkos sub city (Region 14, Addis Ababa), calling for an end, and a peaceful resolution, to the ongoing fighting in Ethiopia. The protesters showed banners with messages of peace, the role of women in peace, as well as condemning war-related rape and sexual assault against women.

On 10 September 2022, a group of people from Bukedea marched in Kolir sub county (Bukedea, Eastern) after their woman MP and Speaker of Parliament, Anita Among, revealed she was being trailed by suspected assassins.

On 10 September 2022, a section of traders demonstrated by singing and chanting, while carrying twigs in Kimilili town (Kimilili, Bungoma), against the destruction of their stalls by the county government. The traders demanded their political leaders to help address the matter.

On 13 September 2022, about 90 Yemeni refugees gathered and held a protest in front of UNSMS office due to poor living conditions, lack of proper support and demanding cash subsistence allowances in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari).
On 14 September 2022, residents of 'Welkait Tegede Setit Humera zone' held a rally in support of the Ethiopian government and allied armed forces in Humera (Setit Humera, Western Tigray, Tigray). .

On 14 September 2022, a section of persons with disabilities (PWDs) protested in Baringo county against marginalization in the member of county assembly (MCA) party nominations (coded as Kabarnet, Baringo Central, Baringo). The group demanded national and county stakeholders to address the matter.

On 14 September 2022, more than 200 youth demonstrated by waving twigs as they forced their way into the county commissioner's office in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu), against a recruitment agency that promised them World cup jobs in Qatar that did not materialize. The group demanded the government to help them get back their money.

On 15 September 2022, a group of youth led by the Bunyoro region NUP coordinator demonstrated in Hoima city (Hoima, Hoima) over the delayed completion of the area road. Police forces intervened and arrested the coordinator.

On 15 September 2022, more than 50 plastic collectors from different parts of the country held a peaceful protest in Namavundu (Wakiso, Central), protesting the 40 percent increment of tax imposed on imported polymer bags like polythene and sacks.

On 15 September 2022, a group under the Kazi mtaani initiative protested in Naivasha (Naivasha, Nakuru), against unpaid allowances after taking part of cleaning exercises. The group demanded the county government to address the matter.

On 16 September 2022, boda boda riders demonstrated in Bukwo town (Bukwo, Eastern) following the escape of ten suspects from Bukwo Central Police Station. According to the riders, some of the suspects were arrested for killing Boda boda riders in Bukwo district.

On 16 September 2022, Kenya county government workers union staged a protest by singing in unison in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), against the move by the new governors to terminate workers. The union demanded the governors to stop firing those hired by their predecessors.

On 16 September 2022, people living with disabilities demonstrated by chanting in Kilifi (Kilifi North, Kilifi), against the move by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC), to alienate them from the list of nominees to the county assembly. The group demanded the president to address the matter.

On 17 September 2022, residents of Kabtiya held a rally supporting the government forces in defending against TPLF forces' 'aggression.' Location not found, coded to Humera (Setit Humera, Western Tigray, Tigray).

On 17 September 2022, local residents demonstrated by marching along the Navakholo road [coded as Nambacha, Navakholo Central, Kakamega], against the poor state of the road. The group demanded the area leadership to rehabilitate the road.

Around 17 September 2022 (weekend of), residents led by the former minister of lands held a peaceful protest at the road between Tororo and Mbale (Mbale, Eastern) over poor rehabilitation of a bridge that was destroyed by heavy rain.

On 18 September 2022, members from Habar Gedir-Ayr sub-clan militia blocked (means unspecified) the main checkpoint in Gaalkacyo town (Gaalkacyo, Mudug). The blockage impeded the movement of commercial trucks, however, small cars are allowed to proceed.

On 19 September 2022, 32 traders demonstrated by marching to the county commissioner's office in Nanyuki (Laikipia East, Laikipia), against increased insecurity. Joined by their member of county assembly (MCA), the group demanded police officers to enhance surveillance.

On 19 September 2022, people living with disabilities (PLWDs) demonstrated by singing and chanting, as they marched and camped outside the Trans Nzoia county assembly in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia), against discrimination in job placement and other opportunities. The group demanded the human rights defenders to help address the matter.

Around 20 September 2022 (as reported), people living with disabilities (PLWDs) protested in Kwale (Matuga, Kwale), against underrepresentation in the county assembly. The group demanded to have one of their own nominated to the county assembly.

On 20 September 2022, a section of women demonstrated by waving placards and sing outside the Kajiado county assembly in Kajiado (Kajiado Central, Kajiado), against the nomination of a resident of Mandera County as a member of the Kajiado county assembly. The women demanded the governor to address the matter.

On 20 September 2022, a group of youth held a peaceful protest at the EU offices in Kampala (Kampala, Central), following the European Union Parliament's resolution to block Uganda's oil pipeline project. Police forces intervened and dispersed the demonstrators.

On 20 September 2022, a section of people living with disabilities (PLWDs) demonstrated by waving twigs and placards in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu), against exclusion from nomination into county assembly. The group demanded their rights to be respected.

On 20 September 2022, a section of the independent electoral and boundary commission (IEBC) clerks demonstrated by camping outside the commission's offices in Meru (Imenti North, Meru), against delayed payments. The group demanded their dues.

On 20 September 2022, vendors blocked the trucks of the city authorities from collecting garbage at the market in Mbale city (Mbale, Eastern) for failing to honor their contract. Vendors had appointed another company.

Around 20 September 2022 (as reported), people living with disabilities (PLWDs) protested in Kapenguria (West Pokot, West Pokot), against the move by political parties to exclude them in the nomination of members of county assembly positions, The group demanded the governor and other law makers to help address the matter.

On 21 September 2022, local residents, mainly UDA, Kenya Kwanza Alliance members, demonstrated during the swearing in of members of the county assembly (MCA), by singing and chanting, while waving placards in Isiolo (Isiolo, Isiolo), against the nomination of Kelvin Mbuthia Waruguru (a non-local) to the county assembly. Police intervened (through dialogue) and dispersed the group.
Around 21 September 2022 (as reported), local residents protested in Shamusinjiri (Ikolomani, Kakamega), against increased insecurity. The residents demanded the vice to be investigated.

On 22 September 2022, more than 40 traders protested at the office of the Mbeya Regional Commissioner in Mbeya (Mbeya Urban, Mbeya) against the demolition of their stalls. The traders were given a 90-day notice by the city Council to vacate the area.

On 22 September 2022, a section of local residents demonstrated by camping outside the Lamu county assembly buildings (Lamu West, Lamu), against being denied access to witness the election of the speaker.

On 22 September 2022, local residents demonstrated by carrying twigs and marching along the Nairobi-Nakuru highway at Kiambaa (Kiambaa, Kiambu), against increased accidents on the road. The residents demanded the Kenya national highways authority (KENHA) to erect speed bumps on the road.

On 23 September 2022, Kenya coast national polytechnic students demonstrated by shouting and carrying twigs against increased insecurity in Tononoka and Tudor areas [coded as Tudor, Mvita, Mombasa]. The group demanded the county government to provide security for the students.

On 24 September 2022, hundreds of youths demonstrated by wearing white outfits, carrying banners, waving placards, chanting and marching in the streets of Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), against climate change. The group demanded compensation from wealthy countries.

On 25 September 2022, local residents blocked with stones the Nairobi-Namanga road in Kumpa (Kajiado Central, Kajiado), in demonstration against killing of two brothers following a land feud. Police intervened through unspecified means and managed to restore calm.

On 26 September 2022, members from Habar Gedir-Ayr sub-clan militia blocked (means unspecified) the main checkpoint in Gaalkacyo town (Gaalkacyo, Mudug). The blockage impeded the movement of commercial trucks; however, small cars are allowed to proceed.

On 26 September 2022, Azimio la Umoja legislators and activists demonstrated by marching to the office of the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), against the interdiction of the IEBC deputy chief executive officer. Police intervened and lobbed tear-gas to disperse the group as well as arrested one man.

On 26 September 2022, parents at Kemeloi boys high school protested at the institution in Kemeloi (Aldai, Nandi), against the poor management of the institution. The parents demanded the transfer of the school principal.

On 27 September 2022, vendors protested in Fort Portal city (Kabarole, Western) against the presence of street vendors outside the market. The protesters claimed they no longer receive clients as customers prefer to purchase items outside the market. Police forces intervene to disperse the demonstration.

On 27 September 2022, local residents demonstrated by singing and chatting in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), against alleged grabbing of a road reserve around the Mombasa's Railways round-about. Led by human rights defenders, the group demanded the government to address the matter.

On 27 September 2022, a section of people living with disabilities (PLWD), demonstrated by singing and marching in Kajiado (Kajiado Central, Kajiado), against the move by political parties to delay nominating a PLWD representative. The group demanded to be included in the leadership to ensure their interest is represented.

On 27 September 2022, 32 members of the county assembly, barricaded (through unspecified means), the gate leading to Kenya wildlife service's (KWS) Tsavo conservation headquarters at Sophia Estate, Voi (Voi, Taita Taveta), in demonstration against increase in human-wildlife conflict in the area. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group and attacked a journalist during the incident.

Around 29 September 2022 (as reported), people living with disabilities (PLWDs) protested in Marsabit (Saku, Marsabit), against discrimination during nomination of members of county assembly positions. Led by their representatives, the group demanded the governor and as well as the speaker to help address the matter.
On 29 September 2022, Uganda National Students Union demonstrated in Kampala (Kampala, Central) against the EU Parliament resolution on the proposed East African Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP).
On 29 September 2022, a section of street traders protested in Kitengela (Kajiado East, Kajiado), against eviction by a private developer.

On 30 September 2022, Njumbi primary parents demonstrated by shouting and chanting, as they forced themselves into the institution in Karai near Kikuyu (Kikuyu, Kiambu), in demonstration against the school's poor performance. Joined by the students, the group demanded the teachers service commission (TSC), to post more teachers to the school.

On 30 September 2022, rice farmers demonstrated by camping outside the Bura irrigation scheme offices in Hola (Galole, Tana River), against skewed distribution of water. The group demanded for their fair share of the water.

On 30 September 2022, local residents demonstrated by waving placards in Athi river (Athi River, Machakos), against the presence of a hazardous hole. The group demanded the governor and other elected leaders to fill-up the hole.

On 30 September 2022, people living with disabilities (PLWDs) demonstrated by chanting and waving placards outside the City Hall in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), against alleged unfairness in the nomination of members of the county assembly. The group demanded respect for their rights to representation.

On 30 September 2022, Kemeloi high school students demonstrated by marching to the Aldai sub-county education offices in Aldai (Aldai, Nandi), against shortage of food. The school was closed indefinitely on 1 October 2022.

On 1 October 2022, a group of university students marched around Kampala (Kampala, Central) protesting a resolution by the European Parliament to delay the development of the East African Crude Oil pipeline.

Around 2 October 2022 (as reported), local residents demonstrated by singing and chanting, while carrying twigs in Kongowea (Nyali, Mombasa), against the destruction of storm water system by a private developer, who is said to constructing a building on the storm water chambers. The group demanded the construction works to be halted immediately.

On 3 October 2022, more than 50 taxi drivers staged a demonstration at the Koboko Municipal Council offices (Koboko, Northern) to protest the award of the taxi park tender to Hotel Delambiance Limited.

On 3 October 2022, hundreds of residents and iron ore miners demonstrated by marching from Kishushe to the governor's office in Mwatate (Mwatate, Taita Taveta), against the alleged move by a mining investor to shortchange them. The group demanded the investor replaced.

On 3 October 2022, a section of women protested outside the Loitokitok sub county deputy commissioner's office (Loitokitok, Kajiado), against discrimination in distribution of relief food. The women demanded the government to assist them with relief food as well as seeds and fertilizer.

Around 3 October 2022 (as reported), local residents protested in Muthwani (Mbooni, Makueni), against the increased incidences of human-wildlife conflict. The group demanded the Kenya wildlife service to address the matter.
On 4 October 2022, Tigrayan residents of Addis Ababa protested against TPLF in front of US and UK embassy in Addis Ababa (Lideta, Region 14, Addis Ababa).

On 4 October 2022, a group of university students marched to EU offices in Kampala (Kampala, Central) to deliver a petition in support of the EU Parliament resolution to halt the East African Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP) project. Police forces blocked the demonstrators and arrested nine of them.

On 4 October 2022, nurses demonstrated by chanting, waving placards and whistling at Jumia friends' hospital in Vihiga (Vihiga, Vihiga), against delayed pay and unfair dismissals. The nurses demanded to be given their pay.

On 4 October 2022, 52 Subordinate staff at the Garissa teachers college demonstrated by waving placards and carrying twigs outside the institution in Garissa (Garissa, Garissa), against delayed payment of their salaries. The group demanded local leaders to help address the matter

On 5 October 2022, a section of civil society representatives protested by singing and chanting in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the move by the government to lift the ban on Genetically modified organisms (GMOs). The group demanded that the government rescinds its decision and focus on farm-based research.

On 6 October 2022, public service vehicles (matatus) operators demonstrated by chanting slogans in Kagio town (Kirinyaga West, Kirinyaga), against the poor state of the bus stage. Joined by taxi drivers and boda boda taxi riders, the operators demanded the county government to repair the bus stage.

On 6 October 2022, drivers who ferried election material for the independent electoral and boundaries commission (IEBC) demonstrated by carrying twigs, whistling and chanting outside the commission's offices in Kilgoris (Transmara West, Narok), against delay in payment for services rendered. The group demanded the commission chairman to address the matter.

On 7 October 2022, local residents protested in Silanga area of Kibera (Kibra, Nairobi), against the move by a private developer to demolish their houses, schools and churches. The group demanded the government to help address the matter.

On 7 October 2022, drivers who ferried election material for the independent electoral and boundaries commission (IEBC) demonstrated for a second day, by carrying twigs, whistling and chanting outside the commission's offices in Kilgoris (Transmara West, Narok), against delay in payment for services rendered. The group demanded the commission chairman to address the matter.

On 7 October 2022, a section of minority communities, mainly of the Muslim faith, protested in Kapenguria (West Pokot, West Pokot) against exclusion from assembly, county government slots. The demanded the governor to consider them in the county job opportunities.

On 8 October 2022, South Sudan business community demonstrated by waving placards, chanting and carrying banners, as they marched in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), against the move by the Kenya ports authority (KPA) to disobey the presidential directive to revert all port clearing services to Mombasa. The group demanded the presidential directive to be implemented.

On 10 October 2022, local residents staged night demo by storming the home of a 'Bhang' peddler, while wailing and carrying twigs in Kaite village near Maili Nne (Laikipia West, Laikipia), in demonstration against selling 'bhang' to their children. The residents demanded the government to take action against the suspected peddler as well as transfer the security officers stationed at the local police post.

On 10 October 2022, local residents protested by shouting in Jogoo estate in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii), against the abrupt interment of a woman due to a prolonged land tussle. Police intervened through dialogue and called off the burial as well as ordered that the remains be returned to the mortuary.

On 11 October 2022, local residents demonstrated by carrying jerricans and twigs in Kieni near Endarasha (Kieni West, Nyeri), against the move by the government to close taps supplying them with water. The residents demanded the government to restore the water supply.

On 12 October 2022, hundreds of local residents, especially the elderly, demonstrated by carrying twigs as they marched along the Mubere-Endebess road [coded as Mubere, Endebess, Trans Nzoia], against the appointment of Sarah Kitiyo as their area chief. The group demanded for the revocation of her appointment letter and the recruitment process started a fresh.
On 12 October 2022, a group of people marched in Namungoona (Kampala, Central) in protest against bloggers who allegedly use online platforms to attack leaders in Uganda.

Around 12 October 2022 (as reported), residents marched in Kiwanja Ndege (Laikipia North, Laikipia) in protest against increased insecurity. The group demanded that the government deploy national police reservists to address the matter.

On 12 October 2022, a section of residents demonstrated by singing, chanting and carrying twigs as they camped outside Kabonge police station (Kirinyaga West, Kirinyaga), against increased incidences of cattle theft. The residents demanded the police officers to be transferred.

On 13 October 2022, a women's lobby movement, Amkeni Coast Movement, came together by chanting and holding their fists together in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), in support of the appointment of Aisha Jumwa as a cabinet secretary (CS).

On 13 October 2022, residents protested in Ajono (Arua, Northern) against the proposal by Arua district Ebola Taskforce to designate Kawuanzeti Health Centre III as an isolation center for suspected cases.

On 13 October 2022, Mumias sugar company workers demonstrated by chanting outside the miller in Mumias (Mumias West, Kakamega), against delays in payment of their salaries as well as against the move by the management to import workers from Uganda. The workers demanded the president to help address the matter.

On 13 October 2022, local residents demonstrated by chanting, whistling, carrying twigs and waving placards in Nyalenda (Kisumu East, Kisumu), against a weeklong power blackout after a transformer exploded. The group demanded the Kenya power and lighting company management to address the matter.

On 14 October 2022, Masai Lodge, Ole Kasasi, Tuala, Kandisi and Rimpa area residents demonstrated by carrying banners and twigs, while chanting as they marched in Ongata Rongai (Loitokitok, Kajiado), against the poor state of the road. The residents demanded the Kenya rural roads authority (KeRRA) to repair the road.

On 14 October 2022, local residents demonstrated by chanting, carrying twigs and waving placards in Shauri Moyo within Nairobi (Nairobi - Kamukunji), against the planned forceful eviction. The group demanded the governor and the president to help address the matter.

On 14 October 2022, residents marched while chanting, carrying twigs and waving placards in Musikoma (Kanduyi, Bungoma) in protest against prolonged power blackout. Led by their nyumba kumi chairman, the group demanded that the governor helps them get reconnected to the power grid.

On 15 October 2022, local residents protested in Mutha (Kitui South, Kitui), against the killing of a man by Somali herders [coded as separately]. The group demanded that the authorities to order the herders out of the region.

On 15 October 2022, Tigrayans who reside in Sodo held a protest against TPLF in Sodo town (Welayta, SNNP). They condemned the killing of civilians by TPLF and asked the international community to condemn the TPLF. They also supported the government's efforts to peace talks and ENDF.

On 15 October 2022, dozens of residents protested at Kamuli road, in the Northern division of Jinja (Jinja, Eastern) against the plan of establishing a sugarcane plantation in Jinja city . Residents are concerned as the area is surrounded by schools and homes and any attempt to establish a sugarcane plantation would make it a hub for criminals.

On 15 October 2022, public service vehicle operators (Matatu) [coded as taxi drivers], led by their chairman, demonstrated by waving placards, chanting and marching along the Makutano-Kacheliba-Alale road [Makutano, West Pokot, West Pokot], against police harassment. Joined by the area senator (Julius Murgo, UDA) and member of parliament (Peter Lokachapong, Jubilee Party) the group demanded the officers involved be investigated as well as transferred.

On 17 October 2022, a group of 13 persons made up of social activists, journalists and lawyers demonstrated at the Constitutional Court in Nakasero (Kampala, Central) to challenge the controversial Computer Misuse Act that was recently assented by President Museveni. The demonstrators claimed the Computer Misuse Act violated the Ugandan constitution and the right to freedom of expression.

On 17 October 2022, Egerton university lecturers protested by gathering together, singing, whistling and waving placards in the institution at Njoro (Njoro, Njoro), against delayed pay. Led by their UASU officials, the group demanded the government to dissolve the university management council.

On 18 October 2022, local residents demonstrated by holding placards and chanting slogans, as they marched from Tiaty to the sub-county headquarters in Tangulbei (Tiaty, Baringo), against delay in distribution of relief food by the deputy county commissioner (DCC). The group demanded that the DCC releases the food without further delay.

On 18 October 2022, several local residents protested against the Puntland election committee in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari). The security forces fired live bullets to disperse the crowd. No further information.

Around 18 October 2022 (as reported), a section of residents protested by camping at the director of criminal investigations offices in Athi River (Athi River, Machakos), against claims of land grabbing by 'powerful' government individuals. The group demanded the DCI to probe the claims.

On 18 October 2022, hundreds of UDA, Kenya Kwanza alliance members demonstrated by singing, waving placards, hooting motorbikes as they marched in Bungoma town (Kanduyi, Bungoma), against the move by their party to nominate non-locals to the Bungoma county assembly. Led by their county chairman, the group demanded the party to recede the decision.

Around 19 October 2022 (week of), residents from Musaijamukuru village led by their chief demonstrated at the office of the Resident District Commissioner in Kikuube town , coded as Kabwoya, Kikuube district (Western). The group was protesting due to a land dispute over the emergence of a fraudulently acquired title in their village. The chief of the village was attacked and killed the following day by unknown people (coded separately).

On 19 October 2022, a section of human rights defenders demonstrated by waving placards and singing, as they marched in the streets of Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), in support of the disbandment of the special service police unit, accused of engaging in extra-judicial killings. Joined by family members of the victims, the group demanded the new directorate of criminal investigations to take action against the implicated officers.

On 19 October 2022, members of the Alternative DigiTalk, an online video and journalistic platform, held placards outside the Constitutional Court in Nakasero (Kampala, Central) against the Computer Misuse Amendment recently approved by the government. The demonstrators claimed the Computer Misuse Amendment passed by the parliament of Uganda on September 9 and signed by the president on October 13, is an infringement of the principles of good governance.

On 19 October 2022, local residents, including boda boda taxi operators demonstrated by waving placards, chanting, whistling, blowing vuvuzelas and carrying billboards as they marched from Ihithe in Tetu to Nyeri town (Nyeri Central, Nyeri), against the stoppage of Mau Mau road construction tender. The group demanded the president to help address the matter.

Around 20 October 2022 (as reported), climate proponents demonstrated by carrying banners, waving placards, wearing white outfits and chanting as they marched in Machakos town (Machakos, Machakos), against the persecution of Ugandan students championing against the proposed East Africa crude oil pipeline. Joined by religious leaders, the group demanded justice for the Ugandan students as well as the government to hasten the transition from fossil fuels to clean energy.

On 20 October 2022, thousands of ethnic Tigray residents of Dessie town staged a protest against TPLF and rallied in Dessie (South Wello, Amhara). The protesters echoed slogans that condemn the TPLF for the 'several losses of life and property destruction' and displayed messages which calls for unity and peace on banners.

On 21 October 2022, students from Metu Secondary School demonstrated at the office of the District Education Officer -DEO in Moyo (Moyo, Northern) after the school administration failed to provide school uniforms to some students despite having paid for them.

On 21 October 2022, over 300 traders demonstrated by carrying twigs and marching in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia), against the demolition of their stalls to pave way for the expansion of the highway [coded separately]. The traders demanded the county and national government to allocate them an alternative working space.

On 21 October 2022, a section of farmers demonstrated by waving placards, chanting, whistling as they marched at the Wangui shopping centre [coded as Gatundu, Gatundu South, Kiambu], against the move by former directors to overthrow the current leadership of Kagwe tea factory. The group demanded the former directors to stop the infightings.

On 24 October 2022, several women street traders demonstrated by waving their wares, shouting and chanting in Dandora (Embakasi North, Nairobi), against the move by the area chief to demolish their stalls. The group demanded the president to protect small their businesses.

On 24 October 2022, local residents protested by marching to Mumias police station (Mumias West, Kakamega), against the alleged killing of a man by nyumba kumi officials. Joined by family members, the group demanded the police to arrest the suspects behind the killing.

Around 25 October 2022 (as reported), residents protested in Kitagwenda town (Kitagwenda, Western) over poor roads.

On 26 October 2022, a section of tea farmers demonstrated by carrying twigs, singing and marching in Ogembo (Bomachoge Chache, Kisii), against the reinstatement of former directors of the tea factory. The farmers demanded the president to help address the matter.

On 26 October 2022, local residents protested by waving twigs in Maina village, on the outskirts of Nyahururu town (Laikipia West, Laikipia), against increased insecurity. The residents demanded the government to enhance security in the area.

On 26 October 2022, local residents (presumed Jubilee-Azimio supporters) including boda boda taxi operators, demonstrated by carrying twigs, singing, and blocking the Chwele, Sirisia, Lwakhakha border road with stones in Sirisia (Sirisia, Bungoma), against the jailing of their area member of parliament [coded separately]. The operators demanded the ministry of transport and the national transport and safety authority (NTSA) to address their concerns.

On 27 October 2022, more than 200 NRM members who lost in the 2021 general election in Kampala demonstrated at the party offices in Kampala (Kampala, Central), demanding the refund of the money they used during the campaign and accusing their leaders of neglect.

On 27 October 2022, a section of digital taxi drivers demonstrated by waving placards, whistling, blowing vuvuzela's and chanting as they assembled at the greenpark terminus and marched to the national transport and safety authority (NTSA) offices in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands), against non-compliance by the transport network companies they operate under. The operators demanded the ministry of transport and NTSA to address their concerns.

On 14 November 2022, Nakasero market vendors peacefully protested in Nakasero (Kampala, Kampala) over daily market dues imposed on them.

On 5 December 2022, students from Cheleleki, Darge, and Catholic schools held a protest in Nekemte town, Nekemt (East Wellega, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'. The demonstrators threatened to mobilize the entire country to demonstrate against the unexplained arrest of Muslims. Mwanje was released after the demonstration.

The police, lobbed teargas to disperse the group, as well as shot and injured one of the student. The student later succumbed to the injuries while in hospital.

On 5 December 2022, tens of workers at Africa Spirits Ltd demonstrated by waving twigs, as they camped outside the liquor firm in Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu), against the move by the Kenya revenue authority to deny them entry into the facility, following the closure of the firm over alleged tax evasion claims. The group demanded the government (president), to help address the matter.

On 6 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students at Ambo University held a protest in the Main Campus, Ambo town, Ambo (West Shewa, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 6 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students at Metu University held a protest in the Main Campus, Metu town, Metu (Ilu Aba Bora, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 6 December 2022, more than 200 youths packed their bags and threatened to return to their home districts at the Presidential Skilling Centre in Zeu (Okoro, Zombo) in protest against harassment by their instructors. The protest came just two weeks before the pass out of the trainees following their enrolment in August this year. President Yoweri Museveni started the Presidential Initiative on Skilling the youth program in 2017 to help youths, especially school drops out to attain income-generating skills.

On 6 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students of Meda Welabu University and Bidire secondary school held a protest in Meda Welabu, Meda Welabu woreda (Bale, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'. Oromia regional special forces sprayed tear gas and dispersed the protesters.

On 6 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students of Adama ASTU staged a protest in Adama, Adama town (East Shewa, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'. Federal Police and Oromia regional special forces fired tear gas, beat, and injured several students after entering the university compound. There were no fatalities.

On 6 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students at General Wako Gutu High School staged a protest in in their school, around Jemo, Kolfe-Keran [Kolfe Keraniyo] (Region 14, Addis Ababa), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 6 December 2022, ethnic Oromo high school students staged a protest in Nekemt, Nekemte town, (East Wellega, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 6 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students staged a protest in Addis Ababa University, Gulele (Region 14, Addis Ababa), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 6 December 2022, over 3,500 workers from Bohemian Flower farm protested by chanting in Naivasha (Naivasha, Nakuru), against low wages and poor working conditions. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students staged a protest in Arsi University, Asela town, Asela (Arsi, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students staged a protest in Jima University, Jimma town (Jimma, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students staged a protest in Bule Hora University, Bule Hora town (West Guji, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo high school students staged a protest in Debre Zeyit, Bishoftu town (East Shewa, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo high school students staged a protest in Ginchi, Dendi woreda (West Shewa, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo university students demonstrated at Mizan Tepi university (in Mizan Teferi, Bench Sheko, South West) denouncing the killing of ethnic Oromo civilians by Amhara militiamen in Western Oromia. Police dispersed the protesters shortly after they had gathered.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students staged a protest in Jinka University, Jinka town, Jinka (South Omo, SNNP), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students staged a protest in Worabe University, Worabe town (Siltie, SNNP), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.
On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo and Amhara students staged separate protests in Dila University, Dila town (Gedeo, SNNP), denouncing ongoing violence in East Wollega zone.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo high school students staged a protest in Burayu town, Burayu (Finfine Special, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo high school students staged a protest in Meki, Dugda (East Shewa, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo high school students staged a protest in Waliso, Woliso town (South West Shewa, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students staged a protest in Gambella University, Gambela town (Agnewak, Gambela), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 7 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students staged a protest in Wachamo University, Hosaena town, Hosaena (Hadiya, SNNP), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 7 December 2022, Tuk tuk taxi operators demonstrated by carrying twigs, whistling, blowing vuvuzelas, chanting, singing as they marched in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu), against alleged harassment by the county government. The group demanded the president to help address the matter.

On 8 December 2022, ethnic Oromo high school students staged a protest in Holeta town, Genet (Finfine Special, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 8 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students staged a protest in Borena University, Yabelo town, Yabelo (Borena, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 8 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students staged a protest in Oda Bultum University, Chiro town, Chiro (West Hararge, Oromia), denouncing what they say is 'the arbitrary killings of Oromo civilians by ethnic Amhara militias and government forces'.

On 8 December 2022, market sellers demonstrated against the ill treatment by the market leaders in Usafi market located in Kampala (Kampala). The market sellers demanded that their leaders leave their office as the president had ordered.

On 8 December 2022, residents of Debre Markos staged a protest in Debre Markos town (East Gojam, Amhara) and rallied around Ras Teklehaimanot square after they learned 'one of the two drivers kidnapped by OLF Shane a month ago (coded separately), was killed by the group'. The protesters condemned what they say is 'violence against ethnic Amhara civilians by OLF Shane and inaction of government'. The residents also went on strikes by closing shops on the next day.

On 8 December 2022, a group of victims and activists protested by carrying placards and wearing red outfits as they camped outside Milimani law court in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands), in demonstration against the court's decision to defer the plea taking of police officer Ahmed Rashid to January 26. The group demanded the officer to be prosecuted for extra-Judicial killings.

On 9 December 2022, residents protested against the bad conditions of their roads in Njeru (Njeru, Buikwe). They claim the potholes have caused many deadly accidents. Police intervened using tear gas to disperse the demonstration.

On 9 December 2022, a section of health workers protested by waving placards, clapping, and singing in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombsa), against delay in payment of their salaries. The group demanded the governor to address the issue.

On 9 December 2022, environmental activists continued demonstrations against the East African Crude Oil Pipeline project in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala). Police intervened to disperse the demonstration.

Around 9 December 2022 (as reported), five students and their parents protested by marching at Ufanisi Saika Secondary school in Saika, within Nairobi (Nairobi - Kasarani), against the failure of the school to register them for the Kenya Certificate of Secondary Examinations (KCSE). The group demanded an explanation as to why they had not been registered.

On 9 December 2022, women's rights groups and survivors of sexual violence demonstrated by wearing orange outfits, carrying banners and waving placards along city hall way as they march to the Supreme Court in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), against a ruling that has seen the mandatory sentencing of sexual offenders removed. The group demanded the chief justice to reinstate fixed jail terms for sex offenders.

On 9 December 2022, hundreds of residents, whose land and property was acquired to pave way for the construction of the 84km Kenol-Marua dual carriageway protested by carrying placards and twigs as they marched to the deputy county commissioner's (DCC) office in Karatina (Mathira East, Nyeri), against delayed compensation by government. The group demanded the deputy president who hails from the area to help address the matter.

On 11 December 2022, food security, consumer rights and biodiversity groups protested by waving placards and chanting, as they marched in Nakuru town (Nakuru North, Nakuru), against the government's move to lift the ban on genetically modified organisms (GMOs) foods. The groups demanded the government to maintain the ban on GMOs.
On 12 December 2022, about 400 boda boda riders protested against the city authorities continued holding of suspended elections at the City council in Mbarara (Mbarara, Mbarara).

On 12 December 2022, market sellers demonstrated against the government's decision to relocate them to another market in Busega (Kampala, Kampala).They demanded clearance of swamps and construction of damaged roads around the market before relocating to it. Police intervened to disperse the demonstration.

On 12 December 2022, pork sellers protested demanding the expansion of the parking space for their customers on Gayaza road in Gayaza (Kyadondo, Wakiso). They claim that the small space can't accommodate all their customers.

On 13 December 2022, NUP activists protested against an NUP MP's unfair appearance before parliament disciplinary committee, in Kamwokya (Kampala, Kampala). They claim he was advocating for abducted NUP members.
On 13 December 2022, market sellers protested against ill treatment from their leaders in Bugolobi (Kampala, Kampala). They demanded that their leaders leave office as the president has ordered.

On 13 December 2022, local residents protested by riding on motorbikes, while waving twigs and wailing as they marched to Mahianyu (Laikipia West, Laikipia), against the disappearance of four vandalism suspects from a police cell. The group demanded the immediate re-arrest and prosecution of the suspects.
On 13 December 2022, a lobby group dubbed team Operation Linda Ugatuzi protested by waving placards in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), against calls to amend the constitution.

On 14 December 2022, local residents protested by waving placards and carrying banners as they marched from Matunga area to the county commissioner's office in Kwale town (Matunga, Kwale), against increased number of theft, burglary and house break-ins. Joined by the Human Rights Agenda [HURIA], the group demanded the commissioner to undertake and independent inquiry into police officers inaction and inadequate response.

On 14 December 2022, town councillors protested against abductions of the residents in their areas of responsibility in Nansana (Nansana, Wakiso). They claim that those abducted are mostly from the NUP opposition party.

On 14 December 2022, local residents demonstrated by carrying placards as they marched in Makina area of Kibera (Kibra, Nairobi), against increase of drug peddling. Led by Nubians right forum, the group demanded the police to stop protecting the peddlers.

On 14 December 2022, members of the county assembly (MCA) protested by singing, dancing and chanting, while wearing matching outfits, outside their chambers in Meru (Imenti Central, Meru), in support of the governor's impeachment for being arrogant.

On 15 December 2022, lawyers protested the decision of the director of public prosecution (DPP) to drop charges against businessmen involved in fraud in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala). They demanded that the DPP resumes investigations into the case.

On 15 December 2022, bar owners protested in Kutus (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) against the planned move by the county government to close down operations of all bars that defaulted in payment of tax arrears. The group demanded the president and the governor to allow them to keep their businesses open.
On 15 December 2022, a section of street traders protested in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia), against harassment by the county askaries. The group demanded the governor to address the matter. .

On 16 December 2022, residents protested against the way parliament is handling the censure motion for derogatory remarks and disrespectful conduct against the minister of State for Housing in Namataba (Nakifuma, Mukono). They claim it is conspiracy to take back the land she has been fighting for.

On 16 December 2022, a section of residents protested by chanting slogans and waving booklets in Meru (Imenti North, Meru), in support of the dissolution of the county assembly. The group demanded the county assembly dissolved.

Around 18 December 2022 (as reported), local residents protested by carrying twigs and marching and camped outside the Samruddha Resources Kenya Limited iron ore mining company in Kishushe (Wundanyi, Taita Taveta), against the move by an the miner to fail to adhere to the mining agreement. The residents demanded the governor and other politicians to help address the matter.

On 20 December 2022, Somali regional special forces shot into protesters who had gathered to oppose the drilling of a water well in a cattle grazing area near Shilabo, Korahe zone, Somali region. Two people were killed and seven others injured

On 20 December 2022, about 50 people from the Meru community protested by chanting, singing, carrying a banner, wearing black outfits and waving placards outside the senate chambers in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), in support of the impeachment of the Meru county governor. The group demanded the senate to uphold the impeachment of the governor.

On 21 December 2022, ethnic Oromo students demonstrated in Dilila town, Waliso woreda (South West Shewa, Oromia) denouncing the killing of ethnic Oromo civilians by Amhara militia in Western Oromia (coded separately). Regional Police dispersed the protesters after they gathered and arrested a school director after accusing him of organizing the demonstration.

On 21 December 2022, several local residents protested in front of the Mariineysa military camp in Mogadishu - Hamar Weyne (Banadir) accusing the government of trying to recruit by force their children.

On 22 December 2022, about 40 Ethiopian Refugees and asylum seekers peacefully demonstrated in front of the UNSMS office in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed) complaining against Somaliland Immigration authorities requesting them to evacuate their homes and leave the country during which some refugees were beaten by the authorities.

On 22 December 2022, cleaning staff protested by waving placards, chanting and shouting, while wearing their uniforms at the Embu Level 5 hospital (Manyatta, Embu), against delayed pay. The group demanded their pay. .

On 23 December 2022, local residents protested at Karisa Maitha grounds in Kilifi (Kilifi North, Kilifi), against the move by the county government to employ two brothers from Marsabit county. Staff from the county government (presumed police officers attached to the governor) injured three journalists covering the event and vandalized their equipment.

On 24 December 2022, local residents mainly women protested against the recruitment of their children by the government in Luuq town (Luuq, Gedo), after the government recruited hundreds of youths as soldiers.
On 24 December 2022, local residents protested against police brutality in Mogadishu - Karan (Banadir). The protesters demanded justice for a driver killed by the police (coded separately).

On 27 December 2022, several local residents demonstrated after the assassination of a local politician (coded separately) in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool). The demonstrators blocked [through unspecified means] the main road leading to Goolada and threw stones, glasses at Telesom and Dahabshill stores. The security forces (Both military and police - rapid reaction unit) fired live bullets to disperse the crowds. At least four protesters were killed and several others were injured.

On 28 December 2022, 20,000 residents of Tefki demonstrated against the new reorganization of Sheger Ketema under the Oromia region in Tefki town in Sebeta Hawas Woreda (Finfine Special, Oromia). They stated that this new reorganization 'isolated them' as the new reorganization, 'which aimed to benefit the farmers surrounding the capital city, did not include them.' The demonstrators were from 13 out of 24 kebeles of Sebeta Hawas woreda.

On 28 December 2022, local residents mostly women and children protested at Hass fuel station Center opposite in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugal) against the assassination of a local politician in Laascaanood (coded separately).

On 28 December 2022, several local residents protested after the assassination of a local politician (coded separately) in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool). The demonstrators blocked [through unspecified means] the roads and threw stones to the security forces. The security forces (Both military and police - rapid reaction unit) fired live bullets to disperse the crowds. At least protesters were killed and several others were injured.

On 28 December 2022, a section of members of Anglican churches of Kenya (ACK) protested by waving placards and twigs, while chanting at St. Mathew's Kiangima parish (Manyatta, Embu), against alleged embezzlement of funds by the church committee. The group demanded immediate dismissal of the whole committee.

On 28 December 2022, hundreds of Tuk-tuk drivers staged a protest at the Tarabuunka junction in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir). The protesters demanding for justice after soldier killed a driver. The Security forces fired live bullets in the air to disperse the crowd

On 29 December 2022, several local residents protested after the assassination of a local politician (coded separately) in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool). The protesters demanded justice, accusing Somaliland over extrajudicial killing. The security forces (Both military and police - rapid reaction unit) fired live bullets to disperse the crowds. At least five protesters were killed and several others were injured.

On 30 December 2022, a group of students protested vote rigging in Makerere Convocation Elections which happened at Makerere University (Kampala, Kampala). Police and military forces beat and arrested participants who were trying to protest.

On 30 December 2022, local residents protested after the assassination of a local politician (coded separately) in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool). The demonstrators threw stones and clash with security forces. The security forces (Both military and police - rapid reaction unit) fired live bullets to disperse the crowds. Five protesters were killed and several others were injured.

Around 30 December 2022 (as reported), over 60 cleaners protested by holding placards at the Thika level five hospital (Thika Town, Kiambu), against delayed salary. The cleaners demanded to know the progress of processing their dues.

On 1 January 2023, boda boda taxi operators protested by blocking (through unspecified means) the Mwea-Embu highway at Ngurubani (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) against the killing of their colleague by a vehicle. Police officers intervened (through unspecified means) and de-escalated the situation.

On 3 January 2023, residents marched along Kimintet road in Kimintet (Transmara West, Narok) against forceful demarcations. Joined by the area member of the county assembly, the group demanded the government suspend any further land subdivisions until all proper consultations are done.
On 3 January 2023, local residents, mostly women, protested against the abduction of civilians by Al Shabaab in Bulo Burto town (Bulo Burto, Hiraan).

On 3 January 2023, estate developers protested against the release on bail of a suspected land fraudster at the Entebbe Chief Magistrates Court in Entebbe (Entebbe, Wakiso). The estate developers mentioned several land disputes with the suspect who was arrested.

On 4 January 2023, a group of South Sudanese refugees (presumed to be Bor-Balanda Dinka), protested against the opening of a church in Nyumanzi refugee camp (East Moyo, Adjumani). Police shot and injured one refugee and arrested two others.

On 4 January 2023, representatives of the Kebena youth association gathered in front of government buildings in Hawasa (Hawasa town, Sidama) demanding that a request submitted 20 years ago for a special woreda for the Kebena ethnic group in the region not be ignored.

On 4 January 2023, thousands of residents protested in Kibiko (Kajiado West, Kajiado) against the subdivision of Kibiko prime land by the National Land Commission. The residents demanded the land subdivision to stop.

On 5 January 2023, residents of Bereh [Barek] woreda staged a protest in Barak town, Shewa (Finfine Special, Oromia), condemning their exclusion from the new Sheger city administration, now under formation. The protesters demanded the regional government to reconsider its plan which they say, 'will force them to travel over 200 kms to get government services'.

On 5 January 2023, local residents protested in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari) after the assassination of a local politician in Laascaanood town (coded separately). They welcomed the withdrawal of Somaliland troops from Laascaanood.

On 5 January 2023, local residents marched to the chief's office in Salama (Laikipia West, Laikipia) against increased insecurity. Demonstrators were joined by the area senator [UDA]. The group demanded the government to enhance security in the area.

On 5 January 2023, over 50 operators protested by forcing their way into the Thika's water distributing company (Thiwasco) with full lorry tankers ready to pour waste, and blocked part of Haile Selassie road in Thika town (Thika Town, Kiambu), against increased licensing fees and poor roads to the county's dumping site. Police intervened using unspecified means to disperse the group.
On 6 January 2023, hundreds of local residents, among them traders, marched to the Naiberi centre (Ainabkoi, Uasin Gishu) against increased cases of robbery in the area.
On 6 January 2023, several local residents protested in Garbaharey town (Garbahaarey, Gedo), rejecting the Jubaland president's aim to take over the region peacefully.

Around 7 January 2023 (as reported), a section of land buyers waved placards, while whistling as they forced their way into a real estate company called Lesedi Developers offices in Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu) against the move by the company to fail to honour land transactions. The group demanded their money back.

On 9 January 2023, a group of residents protested against the decision of the ministry of health to withdraw credit line for medical supplies at Kilembe Mines Hospital in Kilembe (Busongora, Kasese). Police used tear gas to disperse the protesters. Four people were arrested including government officers.

On 9 January 2023, 60 members of the county assembly (MCA),forced their way into the governor's office in Kiambu (Kiambu town, Kiambu), against delays in issuance of bursary funds. The group demanded the governor to address their concerns and provide clarity on the use of his foundation and county resources.

On 9 January 2023, hundreds of East African cargo truck drivers protested against being constantly extorted by security personnel in South Sudan, at Elegu border in Elegu town (Kilak, Amuru). They refused to enter into South Sudan and stationed at Elegu border, blocking traffic. Police intervened, firing tear gas and live bullets to get the drivers to unblock the road.

On 9 January 2023, a section of people living with disabilities (PWD) protested by waving placards and marching to the constituency development fund (CDF) office in Khwisero (Khwisero, Kakamega), against the irregular employment by the office set aside for the disabled.

On 10 January 2023, local residents protested by carrying twigs and chanting, as they marched in Gilai also known as Ngilai (Samburu North, Samburu) against increased insecurity, following the killing of animals and abduction of one of a police reservist [coded separately]. The group demanded the release of the reservist.

On 10 January 2023, hundreds of youth led by the mayor of Kashenshero Town Council protested against the statements passed to disqualify a presumed presidential candidate whom they support (Muhoozi Kainerugaba) in Motooma district, coded to Mitoma (Ruhinda, Mitooma). It is alleged that these statements were made by the current internal affairs minister (Kahinda Otafiire-former NRA soldier) saying Muhoozi is unfit for presidency.

On 10 January 2023, over 1,000 teachers grading the Christian religious education (CRE) paper protested by shouting and chanting at St. Francis girls school, Mang'u (Gatundu North, Kiambu), against poor working conditions as well as poor pay. Police and Kenya national examinations council (KNEC) intervened and asked the teachers to leave the center.

On 11 January 2023, a group of over twenty farmers protested against a Chinese sand mining company's activity in Kyennyange village coded as Bukulula (Bukulula,Kalungu). They claimed the company has caused water to flood their fields, causing crop losses. Some of them were armed with pistols, knives, and sticks. Police intervened to prevent the event from escalating into violence.

On 12 January 2023, a group of residents protested against the destruction of their corps by the Balaalo clan's cattle in Ongongoja (Katakwi, Katakwi). They later drove the herd to the district headquarters and demanded that the Balaalo quit the district with immediate effect. Police intervened by firing bullets to block the protesters.

On 12 January 2023, several people attended a demonstration call by the government against Al Shabaab 'Mogadishu Peoples Uprising' in Mogadishu - Abdiaziz (Banadir). The security forces blocked several roads in the town including Maka -Al Mukarama Road from Villa Somalia up to KM0 junction road, Seaport Road, blocked from Seaport to Lido Beach.

On 12 January 2023, the UASU Egerton chapter protested by singing and waving placards at the university in Njoro (Njoro, Nakuru), against the financial crisis affecting the institution. The group demanded the government to bring a new team of management to the university.

On 13 January 2023, local residents protested by carrying twigs as they marched in Kagumo (Kirinyaga Central, Kirinyaga) against the poor state of the Baricho-Getuya road. The group demanded the area member of parliament to help address the matter.
On 13 January 2023, several local residents protested in Baad Weyne town (Hobyo, Mudug) against Al Shabaab activities in the country. The protesters demanded the government support.

On 14 January 2023, overnight, a group of youths and women demonstrated in Tuko Raq town (Laas Caanood, Sool) against a potential visit of a Somaliland delegation scheduled to take place on 15 January. The demonstrators expressed their refusal to receive any delegations.
On 16 January 2023, about 10 Ugandan employees protested the failure of a Chinese company to pay their three-year salary arrears at the Chinese embassy in Kololo (Kampala, Kampala).

On 16 January 2023, local residents protested by waving twigs, blowing vuvuzelas, and chanting as they blocked (means unspecified) the Nakuru -Eldoret road at Eldama Ravine (Koibatek, Baringo) against increased insecurity, following the killing of one of their kin and his body dumped into the forest by unknown people. The group demanded justice for their slain kin.

On 16 January 2023, a section of shareholders, mostly traders forced their way into B-Smart sacco limited offices in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the move by the Sacco to deny them loans. The group demanded the Sacco to refund them, their savings.

On 17 January 2023, workers at James Finlay tea estate protested in Cheptabes (Konoin, Bomet) against the killing of a 9 year old boy by a tea plucking machine. Police intervened and thwarted the group.

On 17 January 2023, several local residents protested against Kaxda local administration in Mogadishu - Kaxda (Banadir). Police forces disperse the crowd and arrested a Kalsan Tv journalist while covering the protest.

Around 17 January 2023 (as reported), members of the Evangelical Lutheran Church marched in Kijitonyama (Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam) demanding to know the reasons that led the pastor of the church to be given a 60-day leave.

On 17 January 2023, local residents protested by blocking (means unspecified) the main gate leading to the Naivasha Level IV hospital (Naivasha, Nakuru) against health workers negligence, following the death of a woman who died from excessive bleeding hours after delivering.

On 18 January 2023, local residents protested by carrying placards and water containers in Kinango town (Kinango, Kwale) against water shortage. The group demanded the county and water authorities to address the matter.

On 19 January 2023, lawyers attached to the Law Society of Kenya (LSK) protested by waving placards in Machakos (Machakos, Machakos) against inefficiencies at the land registry offices. The lawyers demanded that the Lands registrar address their grievances.

On 20 January 2023, over 70 lawyers from Mt. Kenya and Rift valley regions attached to the Law Society of Kenya (LSK) protested by chanting, carrying banners, and waving placards as they marched in Nyandarua town (Kinangop, Nyandarua) against alleged corruption and redundancy in the work of the lands register. The group demanded the removal of the officer.

On 20 January 2023, members of a Ugandan civil society organization accompanied by farmers protested against Kenya's lifting of ban on genetically modified organisms (GMOs) at the East African Court of Justice Sub-registry in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala). They also filed a case in the East African Court of Justice against the Kenyan government. They claimed it was a violation of the treaty for the establishment of the East African Community which creates clear legal obligations to bar GMOs.

On 20 January 2023, lawyers attached to the Law Society of Kenya (LSK) protested by carrying banners and waving placards, as they marched from the supreme court of Kenya to the ministry of lands offices in ardhi house in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) against delays, inefficiencies and collapse of the national land information management system. The group demanded the ministry of lands to address the challenges.
