On 21 January 2023, dozens of local residents including drivers, protested in Bakaaro market in Mogadishu - Hawl Wadaag (Banadir) against police brutality, demanding for justice and calling for the immediate arrest and prosecution of the officer. The police forces fired live bullets to disperse the crowd. One protester was killed.
On 22 January 2023, about 100 Refugees protested at the front of UNSMS field office in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari) due to poor living conditions.

On 22 January 2023, hundreds of women protested by waving placards, screaming, and carrying twigs as they marched from Enosaen center to the regional headquarters in Trans Mara (Transmara West, Narok) against insecurity well as the illicit brew. The group demanded that the security agencies address the matter.

On 23 January 2023, a group of residents protested against the alleged continuous killing of innocent Ugandans by Rwandan security operatives in Karera village coded as Kabale (Bunyangabu, Rukiga). This followed an incident where Rwandan security operatives shot and killed a trader on 17/01/2023 on Ugandan land at the Mpororo border Village (coded separately). The Rwandan authorities insisted that the victim was shot dead by the Rwandan security operatives in self-defense inside Rwanda.

On 23 January 2023, a section of parents protested by chanting and carrying twigs and placards as they marched in Litiik primary school (Bureti, Kericho) against the school's poor exam performance. The parents demanded that the national and county government leaders transfer the head teacher.

On 24 January 2023, members of parliament (MP) protested for the second day by walking out of an induction meeting and camped at the Pride Inn hotel lobby in Mombasa (Mvita, Mvita) against the move by the government to delay releasing the constituency funds. The MPs demanded that the funds be deposited in their accounts.

On 24 January 2023, a section of Nyali primary school parents and stakeholders accompanied by Muhuri officers forced their way into the school while singing and waving placards in Nyali (Nyali, Mombasa) against the alleged unlawful recruitment of a new principal. The group demanded that the new acting principal be removed.

On 24 January 2023, Machakos university staff protested by chanting and waving placards as they marched in the institution at Machakos (Township, Machakos) against delayed promotions. Led by their UASU union officials, the group demanded the implementation of the comprehensive bargaining agreement (CBA).

On 24 January 2023, a section of traders protested by singing and chanting at Uhuru business park market in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the move by the county government to evict them. The traders demanded their elected leaders help address the matter.
On 24 January 2023, a section of women protested by waving twigs in Karatina village in Ruiru (Ruiru, Kiambu) against illicit brew. The group demanded that law enforcers address the problem.

On 24 January 2023, residents protested by carrying twigs and chanting outside the Thika water and sewerage company (Thiwasco) offices (Thika Town, Kiambu) against water shortage. The group demanded that company management address their concerns.
On 25 January 2023, a group of government sponsored students protested against the delayed payment of their first semester food and living allowance at Kyambogo University (Kampala, Kampala).

On 25 January 2023, a section of parents protested by shouting, carrying twigs and placards as they camped outside the Mogoiywet school gate (Bomet Central, Bomet) against poor examination performance. The group demanded that the ministry of education officials help address their concerns.

On 25 January 2023, a section of residents sang, chanted, whistled, and waved placards in Sobea (Rongai, Nakuru) against increased water scarcity. The group demanded that the area chief and the members of parliament address their grievances.

On 25 January 2023, a section of parents protested by blocking the state house road [through unspecified means] in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) against the school's alleged 'full fees payment' directive. The police intervened [through unspecified means] to disperse the group.

On 25 January 2023, a section of our lady of Victory Nyabiosi 'N' secondary school parents protested by waving placards, whistling, carrying twigs, and singing as they marched in Keroka (Nyaribari Masaba, Kisii) against poor examination results. The group demanded that the head teacher be transferred.

Around 26 January 2023 (as reported), over 500 sand loaders and transporters protested across Burat ward (Isiolo, Isiolo) against exploitation and discrimination at sites. The group demanded the county government to help address their grievances.

On 27 January 2023, residents protested in Lorngosua near Ilmarba (Kajiado Central, Kajiado) against the invasion of jumbos in their farms. The group demanded that the Kenya wildlife service (KWS) relocate the offending elephants into the national parks in Nairobi or Amboseli.

On 27 January 2023, NUP councillors staged a protest and demanded for proper medication for their jailed lawmaker Allan Ssewanyana at Makindye division council offices located in Makindye (Kampala, Kampala). Police and heavy military intervened to stop the protest from proceeding.

On 28 January 2023, more than 50 taxi operators protested by chanting in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against alleged harassment by the county askaris. The group demanded that the governor address the matter.

On 30 January 2023, boda boda taxi operators protested by waving placards and carrying twigs as they rode in Kisii town (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against the move by the county government to close down some of the stages in the city.

Around 30 January 2023 (as reported), a section of parents protested at Masimba high school (Nyaribari Masaba, Kisii) against the school's poor performance in the Kenya certificate of secondary examination. Police intervened and charged the parent before kicking them out of the school compound.
On 30 January 2023, Kenya Union of Clinical officials (health workers) protested at the union offices in Upper Hill area of Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) for unclear reasons.

On 30 January 2023, a section of human rights activists and members of civil society organizations protested carrying banners, waving placards, chanting, and whistling as they marched from Jeevanje gardens to the ministry of foreign affairs offices in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against the recent killing of a human rights lawyer in Eswatini. The group demanded that the Kenyan government forfeit working with the Eswatini government.

On 30 January 2023, more than 200 teachers protested by waving placards and marching to the teacher's service commission (TSC) offices in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against the delocalization transfer program. The teachers demanded to be transferred back to their home counties.
Around 31 January 2023 (month of), a group of teachers protested against delayed salaries at Pride Guest House in Koboko (Koboko, Koboko).

On 31 January 2023, a section of sand loaders protested by blocking [through unspecified means] the Isiolo-Moyale highway in Isiolo town (Isiolo, Isiolo) against alleged harassment by Burat sand loaders. The governor and the county security team intervened (using unspecified means) to calm the group.
On 31 January 2023, residents protested against electoral registration in Dhahar town (Sanaag, Laasqoray). Puntland police forces fired live bullets to disperse the crowd, killing a protestor.

Around 31 January 2023 (as reported), tea farmers protested by carrying twigs and chanting in Omokirondo near Ikonge (North Mugirango, Nyamira) against the delayed payment of their half-year tea bonus. The group demanded that the government help address their grievances.

On 31 January 2023, more than 70 street cleaners marched while carrying placards in Mwanza (Nyamagana, Mwanza) in protest against delayed payment of their salaries as well as statutory deductions. The group demanded that the district commissioner look into the matter.

On 2 February 2023, residents protested by waving placards, carrying twigs, and chanting in Jomvu (Jomvu, Mombasa) against the poor state of roads. The group demanded that the government address their grievance.

On 2 February 2023, members of the county assembly (MCAs) protested by chanting in Busia (Matayos, Busia) against the exclusion of the ward bursary in the supplementary budget. The group demanded an audience with the governor.
On 2 February 2023, several local residents protested in Garbaharey town (Garbahaarey, Gedo) rejecting the withdrawal of government security forces (Gorgor) from the Gedo region.

Around 2 February 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Siret (Kipkelion West, Kericho) against the upsurge of Alcohol dens in the area. The group demanded that the county commissioner address their grievance.

On 3 February 2023, several residents protested against ATMIS UPDF forces at the Ceel Gabta Market neighborhood in Mogadishu - Hamar Jabjab (Banadir) after the killing of a young boy (coded separately). The protesters demanded justice.

On 3 February 2023, former Nairobi metropolitan services (NMS) workers protested by waving placards and marching along Ngong road as they gathered at the Dagoretti training college ( Dagoretti, Nairobi) against the decision by the county government to terminate their contracts prematurely. The group demanded that the county rescind the decision.

On 3 February 2023, university students protested by singing, whistling, chanting, and waving placards outside the treasury building in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against the delay in releasing the higher education loan board funds. The group demanded immediate release of the funds and address from the treasury cabinet secretary.

On 3 February 2023, truck drivers protested by carrying banners, waving placards, and chanting as they marched in Meru (Imenti North, Meru) against the murder of their colleague along the Kenya-Tanzania border. Joined by the Imenti North member of parliament [coded as an independent candidate], the group demanded justice for the slain driver.

On 4 February 2023, followers of Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahido Christian (EOTC) gathered at Churches in Asela town, Asela (Arsi, Oromia) to demonstrate against 'the arrival of the newly appointed Bishop', and to 'protect the Church'. Government forces (assumed to be Oromia regional special forces) detained 'several followers' and forced a former Bishop to return to Addis Ababa and warned protesters who were gathered in the Church of 'using forces unless they leave the Church compound'.

On 5 February 2023, several local residents from Habar Jeclo-Baho protested against Somaliland administration in Ceel Afweyn town (Ceel Afweyn, Sanaag). The protesters demanded justice for person killed (coded separately). The Somaliland police forces fired teargas canisters to disperse the protesters.

On 6 February 2023, residents protested by hitting sufurias and spoons in Nyandarua (Kinangop, Nyandarua), against increased cost of living. Led by the jubilee party secretary general, the group demanded the government to address their grievances.

On 6 February 2023, about 150 families protested against the Resident District Commissioner's (RDC) order to vacate the government resettlement land in one week in Kata and Mabale villages coded to Bunambutye (Bulambuli, Bulambuli). Before the RDC's order was passed, an unidentified armed group burnt some of the grass thatched huts belonging to the settlers.
On 6 February 2023, hundreds of local residents protested against the ongoing voter registration exercise in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal).

Around 6 February 2023 (as reported), a section of residents protested by waving placards, singing and carrying twigs in Kikuyu (Kikuyu, Kiambu), against the sale of illicit brews. Joined by the area member of county assembly (MCA), the group demanded the relevant authorities address their grievances.
On 6 February 2023, residents protested along the Thika superhighway in Githurai (Roysambu, Nairobi), over unclear reasons.

Around 6 February 2023 (as reported), a section of residents protested by chanting, whistling and waving placards, as they marched in Makongeni (Makadara, Nairobi), against planned eviction without formal notice. The group demanded compensation before vacating their houses.

On 6 February 2023, a section of parents protested by blocking the gate with thorns and twigs at St Stephen Kirindo mixed secondary school (Mbita, Homa Bay), against poor exams performance. The group demanded the teachers service commission (TSC) to transfer the head teacher.

Around 6 February 2023 (as reported), parents protested at Tharuni primary school (Limuru, Kiambu), against the additional charges they're being compelled to pay yet not approved by the Ministry of Education. The parents demanded the ministry of education to address their grievances.

On 6 February 2023, followers of Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahido Christian (EOTC)s protested in Debark town (North Gondar, Amhara) against the government's involvement in religious matters and for providing protection and advice to 'the enemies' of the orthodox Tewahedo church and asked the government to stop meddling in religious issues.

On 7 February 2023, around 40 ethnic Oromo followers of Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahido Christian (EOTC) followers rallied in Jimma town, Jima (Jimma, Oromia) to protest what they say is 'hatred against Oromo and Oromo language under the cover of Orthodox Christian' and demonstrated their support to the 'newly formed Oromia Church Synod'.

On 7 February 2023, a group of parents protested against the incompetence of the school headmaster and poor performance of their children at Lwandubi primary school in Lwandubi village (Namabya, Bubulo, Namisindwa). They briefly locked the headmaster's office but later opened it.

Around 8 February 2023 (as reported), residents protested by waving placards as they blocked the entrance to a landfill in the Norkopir area of Kitengela (Kajiado East, Kajiado), against the increased health hazards caused by Kitengela dumpsite citing serious health complications. Armed police officers intervened and used unspecified meant to disperse the group.

Around 8 February 2023 (as reported), parents chased away a principal and closed Komosoko secondary school (Kuria West, Migori), in demonstration against poor performance. The parents demanded the principal transferred.

On 9 February 2023, four torture survivors (under the umbrella body: 'Torture Survivors Movement Uganda') staged a protest at the UHRC (Uganda Human Rights Commission) in Kololo (Kampala, Kampala), demanding the resignation of the commission's chairperson, whom they accuse of inaction against increasing cases of rights violation by state operatives. Police intervened and arrested the five protesters to prevent any further proceedings.

On 9 February 2023, Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahido Christian (EOTC) followers gathered at Ayer Tena Kidist Kidane Mihret and Welete St. Johannes Church in Kolfe Keranio, Kolfe-Keran sub city (Region 14, Addis Ababa) to demonstrate against 'the arrival of the newly appointed Bishops', as the dioceses rang the church bell and called residents to 'protect the Church'. Addis Ababa Police beat and dispersed the demonstrators who were marching to the Churches, holding 'noiseless weapons'. At least two demonstrators were wounded. The police said 'the calls were later found to be based on false information shared to the public to purposely create chaos'.

On 9 February 2023, residents protested by singing, chanting and waving twigs as they marched in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii), against alleged state harassment of former Interior Cabinet Secretary Dr Fred Matiang'i. The group demanded the state to stop witch-hunt of former government officials.

On 10 February 2023, a section of health workers marched to the county assembly and thereafter proceeded to Governor's office in Kiambu (Kiambu Town, Kiambu), against the move by the county government to change their medical scheme. Led by KMPDU, the group demanded the county to recede the decision.

On 10 February 2023, a section of residents allied to a member of parliament (MP) under the ODM, Azimio coalition protested by waving placards in Uriri (Uriri, Migori), in support of their MP's recent visit to statehouse to meet the president. Led by the local ODM chairperson, the group demanded leaders to focus on development of their regions.

Around 10 February 2023 (as reported), residents protested by carrying twigs, blowing vuvuzelas, shouting and hooting motorbikes as they marched in Rumuruti township (Laikipia West, Laikipia), against the failure of the current administration to listen to their cries, as well as being sidelined in the activities of the county. They demanded equality in the allocation of plots in the area.

On 10 February 2023, a section of academic staff protested by singing solidarity song and waving placards in Njoro (Njoro, Nakuru), against the move by the university to defy court orders such as full pay of lecturers. Led by the universities' academic staff union (UASU), the group demanded the government to address their grievances.

On 10 February 2023, Ndabibi illegal settlers protested at Uhuru park in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) against land grabbing in their area. The group demanded the president to address their grievances.

On 11 February 2023, local residents from Ahmed Kheyre, Nuh Muse and Hassan Ugaar sub clans of Majeerteen-Issa Mahmud protested against the ongoing local voter registration exercises in Dangoroyo village (Qardho, Bari) Budunbuto, Libaaxo, Baarweyn and Dasaan villages (coded separately).

On 11 February 2023, local residents from Ahmed Kheyre, Nuh Muse and Hassan Ugaar subclans of Majeerteen-Issa Mahmud protested against the ongoing local voter registration exercises in Budunbuto village (Eyl, Nugaal) Dangoroyo, Libaaxo, Baarweyn and Dasaan villages (coded separately).

On 11 February 2023, local residents from Ahmed Kheyre, Nuh Muse and Hassan Ugaar subclans of Majeerteen-Issa Mahmud protested against the ongoing local voter registration exercises in Libaaxo village (Garoowe, Nugaal) Dangoroyo, Budunbuto, Baarweyn and Dasaan villages (coded separately).

On 11 February 2023, local residents from Ahmed Kheyre, Nuh Muse and Hassan Ugaar subclans of Majeerteen-Issa Mahmud protested against the ongoing local voter registration exercises in Baarweyn village (Eyl, Nugaal) Dangoroyo, Libaaxo, Budunbuto and Dasaan villages (coded separately).

On 11 February 2023, local residents from Ahmed Kheyre, Nuh Muse and Hassan Ugaar subclans of Majeerteen-Issa Mahmud protested against the ongoing local voter registration exercises in Dasaan village (Qandala, Bari) Budunbuto, Libaaxo, Baarweyn and Dangoroyo villages (coded separately).

On 11 February 2023, friends and residents protested by carrying caskets of two brothers as they marched from Kiamanyeki village to Wang'uru police station (Mwea, Kiarinyaga), against their recent killing by a mob [coded separately]. Police intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the group.

Around 12 February 2023 (as reported), a section of residents protested blowing vuvuzelas, carrying twigs, as they marched in Ndiwa (Nyatike, Migori), in support of the appointment of former Nyatike member of parliament (MP) Edick Anyanga to the Kenya nuclear regulatory authority. The group demanded the government to expedite the compensation of locals who gave out their land for the lower Gucha irrigation scheme.

On 13 February 2023, overnight, over 500 students from Arnesen's high school protested by marching from the school to the sub-county offices in Kapsoya within Eldoret town (Moiben, Uasin Gishu), against absentee teachers, lack of water and toilets. The students demanded the sub-county commissioner to address their grievances.

On 13 February 2023, a section of health workers protested by singing solidarity song and waving placards as they picketed outside the governor's office in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against their medical covers plans. The group demanded a comprehensive medical cover.

On 13 February 2023, a section of sex workers protested by carrying banners and wearing ribbons, as they marched in unspecified location [coded as Nairobi, Starehe, Nairobi], against shortage of condoms.

On 13 February 2023, hundreds of Ugenya high school students protested by forcing their way out of the school, while carrying twigs and placards as they marched to Ugunja trading centre (Ugunja, Siaya), against the move by the teachers service commission (TSC) to transfer their principal. The principal and county director of education ordered the students back to school under the escort of anti-riot police officers.

On 14 February 2023, residents protested by waving placards, chanting as they marched in Magunga (Suba South, Homa Bay), against politicians playing divisive politics. The group demanded not to involve politics in the implementation of development projects.

On 14 February 2023, residents protested by chanting, while carrying twigs, as they marched in Salama (Mvita, Mombasa), against alleged violent evictions by a top politician. The group demanded the government to assure them of their security.
On 14 February 2023, a group of residents protested against the illegal survey and demarcation of the land at Wakiso Resident District Commissioner's office (Wakiso Town Council, Busiro).

On 14 February 2023, former Mumias sugar workers protested by camping at the sugar miller premises in Mumias (Mumias West, Kakamega), against delayed payment of their salary arrears. Led by the Mumias sugar branch workers secretary, the group demanded the president to help address the matter.
On 14 February 2023, Bamasaba clan members protested the planned coronation of a certain Mr. Amram Wagabyalile at the Office of Mbale Resident City Commissioner in Mbale (Mbale, Mbale).

On 15 February 2023, a group of Kyambogo University Bushenyi students protested at the Bushenyi district headquarters in Bushenyi ( Bushenyi, Bushenyi), following the mysterious death of their fellow students. The demonstrators demanded justice and asked authorities to explain the circumstances under which their colleagues were dying. They locked all three gates of the district office.

Around 15 February 2023 (as reported), a section of residents protested by carrying twigs in Mata (Taveta, Taita Taveta), against widescale land grabbing in the area. The group demanded both county and national political leaders to address the matter.

On 15 February 2023, youths staged a protest around Ferensay Gurara Kidane Miheret Church (Yeka, Region 14, Addis Ababa) near the border of Addis Ababa and Sululta, Oromia region, to condemn the demolition of their houses (found to be built illegally) by the government. Federal Police fired tear gas and arrested unknown number of protesters. Members of ENDF were also present.

On 15 February 2023, members of Naroosura-Ntuka group farm protested by waving placards, carrying twigs as they marched to the deputy county commissioner's (DCC) office in Olololunga (Narok South, Narok), against by the DCC to subdivide their land. The group demanded the governor help address their grievances as well as the transfer of the DCC.
On 15 February 2023, tuktuk drivers protested over shooting of colleague by security forces (coded separately) in VIa Tanzania neighborhood in Mogadishu - Hamar Jabjab (Banadir).

On 15 February 2023, a section of workers protested by forcefully closing the main gate at the Sparetech trading company limited yard in Athi River (Athi River, Machakos), against the company's unremitted statutory deductions. The group demanded the company to remit the statutory deductions.

On 15 February 2023, several scientists, lecturers, science students and farmers marched from Jevanjee gardens on Moi avenue to memorial park on Haille Selasie road in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), in support of government's decision to lift the ban on the importation, sale and consumption of genetically modified organisms (GMOs). Under the umbrella of RePlanet Africa, a communication and training outfit, the group demanded Kenyans, leaders and policymakers embrace GMOs for food security.

On 15 February 2023, several taxi operators protested by closing [unspecified means] the entrance of the standard gauge railway (SGR) terminus in Syokimau (Athi River, Machakos), against an alleged illegal increment in the parking fee. The group demanded Kenya railways attendants stop discrimination.

Around 16 February 2023 (as reported), 16 students who sat for the Kenya certificate of primary education (KCPE) last year protested by waving placards in Kajiado town (Kajiado Central, Kajiado), against lack of means for paying school fees. The students requested well wishers to support them with school fees.
On 16 February 2023, parents and students protested by waving placards and carrying twigs at ACK Canon Herbert primary school in Karurumo (Runyenjes, Embu), against the transfer of the head teacher.

Around 16 February 2023 (as reported), a section of parents protested at Got Kabok secondary school [coded as God Kabok, Rangwe, Homa Bay], against poor management as well as poor performance in exams. The group demanded the ministry of education officials to transfer the school principal.

On 16 February 2023, a section of private security guards protested by waving placards in Nairobi central business district (CBD) (Nairobi - Starehe), against poor pay and lack of work tools. Led by the Kenya national private security workers union (KNPSWU) union leaders, the group demanded the president to address their grievances.

On 17 February 2023, residents gathered at the county headquarters, while waving placards and clapping in Kilifi (Kilifi North, Kilifi), in support of the court's decision to uphold the election of governor Gideon Mung'aro.

On 17 February 2023, a group of women from South Kivu and North Kivu civil society (from Democratic Republic of Congo) staged a peaceful protest in front of African Union (AU) Head Quarter in Addis Ababa (Mesqel Square in Kirkos Sub City, Region 14, Addis Ababa), during the 36th AU Head of States Summit and called on African leaders to 'condemn, sanction and pressure the Rwandan government and M23 to immediately withdraw its troops from DRC'. The protesters echoed slogans such as, 'we need peace and nothing but only peace' and weaved national flag of DRC. The protest was organized by Collective of Women's Associations for Development (CAFED).
On 18 February 2023, a group of parents protested the increase in school fees at Kangulumira Public SS in Kangulumira (Ntenjeru, Kayunga).

On 18 February 2023, five workers protested by waving placards outside Sparetech trading company limited in Athi River (Athi River, Machakos), against alleged unlawful dismissal from work. The group demanded relevant government authorities to help address their grievances.

On 18 February 2023, a section of residents protested by congregating at Seme primary school gate in Katani (Athi River, Machakos), against the mismanagement of the school. The group demanded the disbandment of the school's board of management as well as transfer of the head teacher.

On 19 February 2023, Muslim residents of Kombolcha staged a protest in Kombolcha town (South Wello, Amhara), and condemned what they say is 'illegal take over of Mejlis/Ethiopian Islamic Affairs Council by the Wahabi sect'. The protesters chanted slogans such as 'Our leader is Sheik Omer Idris; Islam is not for sale, and Mejlis belongs to Muslims, not for Wahabis'.

Around 19 February 2023 (as reported), Juakali workers protested by blowing vuvuzelas, whistling, chanting, waving placards as they camped at the outside the Marmanet constituency industrial development center office in Oljabet town (Laikipia West, Laikipia), against alleged mistreatment from the leadership of the area. The group demanded the national government to help address their grievances.

On 19 February 2023, several local residents protested against police brutality in Baar-Ubax neighborhood in Mogadishu - Hawl Wadaag (Banadir), after a student was killed by the police (coded separately). The protesters demanded justice.

Around 20 February 2023 (as reported), a group of sand truck drivers gathered in demonstration at the mineral inspection center in Mbeya (Mbeya Urban, Mbeya) against the increase of a tax they need to pay per trip.

On 20 February 2023, a section of residents protested by carrying banners and waving placards, as they marched from Mathare, Austin's ground next to Kiboro primary school along Juja road CBD to the office of the deputy president (DP) in Nairobi (Nairobi - Kamukunji), against the increased cost of living as well as lack of school fees. The group demanded the dp to help address their grievances.

On 20 February 2023, a family of a deceased man protested by dropping his coffin at a restaurant in Bondeni area of Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru), against a debt owed by the restaurant owner to the deceased. The group demanded the restaurant owner make a commitment toward the debt settlement.

On 20 February 2023, a section of residents and parents of Ulumbi secondary school protested by waving placards and carrying twigs as they forced their way into the school near Yala (Gem, Siaya), against the move by the teachers service commission (TSC), to post a principal whom they described as a non-performer. Led by the chairman of the Ulumbi village United, the group demanded TSC to rescind the posting.

On 20 February 2023, a section of parents protested by carrying twigs, chanting, shouting and marching, before blocking [through unspecified means] the school gate at Dr Mbai mixed secondary school in Asego (Homa Bay Town, Homa Bay), against poor performance in national examination. The group demanded the transfer of the school principal.

On 20 February 2023, residents protested by forcing their way into the directorate of criminal investigations (DCI) offices in Mandera (Mandera East, Mandera) against the death of a community member who was allegedly stabbed to death by a Somali national. The group demanded justice for the victim.

Around 21 February 2023 (as reported), a section of parents protested at Longo primary school [coded to the county head quarter as Homa Bay, Homa Bay Town, Homa Bay], against poor performance. The group demanded the head teacher be transferred.

On 21 February 2023, a section of Yimbo residents, presumed farmers, protested by waving twigs, shouting, whistling and marching in Yimbo within Yala (Gem, Siaya), against destruction of their crops in the Texus area of Yala Swamp by an investor, Lake Agro Limited. The group demanded the governor to help address their grievances.
Around 21 February 2023 (as reported), a section of parents protested at Osure primary school (Ndhiwa, Homa Bay), against poor performance. The group demanded the head teacher to be transferred.

Around 21 February 2023 (as reported), a section of traders protested at the Laini Saba Market in Kibera (Kibra, Nairobi) against the move by the Kenya Railways to relocate them to another place. The group demanded their area leaders to look into the matter.

On 21 February 2023, a group of men, led by comedian and activist Eric Omondi, protested by blocking (means unspecified) parliament road by staging a sit-in, while singing and chanting and further attempted to force their way into the parliament building in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe), against the increased cost of living. Police intervened and hurled teargas to disperse the group. Omondi and a few other protesters were arrested.

On 21 February 2023, a section of residents protested by waving placards and marching to TAVEVO water and sewerage company in Samburu (Kinango, Kwale), against huge water bills. Joined by the area member of the county assembly (MCA) [ODM, Azimio], the group demanded that the water company address their grievance.

On 22 February 2023, a group of about thirty-three residents protested in Ker Kwaro Acholi (cultural palace) coded as Bar-Dege (Bungatira, Aswa, Gulu), against the new directive issued by the Office of the Prime Minister to leave their residences or face eviction. On 01/03/2023, the protesters vacated the area where they had camped for six days.

On 22 February 2023, a group of residents demonstrated against dusty roads in Kisozi zone of Kyengera (Busiro, Wakiso). They used tyres and tree trunks to block the road. Police and local leaders intervened to calm the demonstrators.

On 22 February 2023, residents protested by carrying twigs, singing and marching in Jomvu (Jomvu, Mombasa), against increased insecurity. The group demanded the police to address the insecurity in the area.

On 22 February 2023, a group of residents protested against the alleged continued torture, rape and killings of their relatives by UWA rangers at the Kween district headquarters located in Binyiny (Kween, Kween). The protesters carried empty coffins and posters. The protest comes days after one of the residents, Robert Musani, 45, was allegedly shot dead by rangers who found him collecting firewood in Mt Elgon forest on February 10, 2023 (coded separately).

On 22 February 2023, Azimio la umoja supporters, protested by carrying empty plates, spoons and 'sufurias' and holding them high in air during a rally in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi), against the high cost of living.

On 23 February 2023, residents, including boda boda taxi operators, protested in Matongo (Bonchari, Kisii), against the poor state of Nyakoe-Matongo road. The group demanded the national government complete the road construction.
On 23 February 2023, residents staged a peaceful protest in response to the death of a civilian detained by the security forces in Doolow town (Doolow, Gedo).

On 23 February 2023, Gatundu North residents protested by waving placards, carrying twigs and banners, blowing vuvuzelas, singing chanting as they marched to the deputy county commissioner's office in Kamwangi (Gatundu North, Kiambu), against the move by the government to construct a dam in the area. The group demanded the government to rescind the project.

On 23 February 2023, a section of residents protested in Loborngare (coded to county headquarters as Maralal, Samburu Central, Samburu), against sustained attacks by the raiders [coded separately]. The group demanded the government ensure the security operation meant to get rid of raiders was successful.

On 24 February 2023, a section of traders protested by singing, clapping, and shouting in Marimanti market (Tharaka South, Tharaka-Nithi), against poor working conditions. The group demanded the county government to address their grievances.

On 24 February 2023, a group of visually impaired contractors protested by waving placards, shouting and whistling as they camped at the Kiambu county headquarters (Kiambu Town, Kiambu), against lack of payment after completion of the works. The group demanded the county government to pay them their dues.

On 24 February 2023, a section of traders protested in Kagio market (Kirinyaga West, Kirinyaga), against the poor state of the market as well as harassment by the county askaris. The group demanded the county government to address their grievances.

On 24 February 2023, a section of Syoya high school parents protested by marching to the school and closing (means unspecified) the school principal's office in Syoya (Bumula, Bungoma), against allegations of poor leadership and performance in the school. The group demanded the principal be transferred.
On 24 February 2023, thousands of Muslims protested against homosexuality in Jinja (Jinja, Jinja). They were accompanied by primary and secondary school students as well as other religious leaders.
On 25 February 2023, members of the federal parliament protested over government police forces demanded to search female MPs in Mogadishu - Wardhigley (Banadir).

Around 26 February 2023 (as reported), Tuk Tuk taxi operators protested in Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu) against extortion by unlawful groups. The group demanded the county government officials help address the matter.

On 27 February 2023, residents protested in Poro (Samburu Central, Samburu) against increased insecurity following the killing of a chief and two national police reservists by suspected pastoral militia (coded separately). The group demanded that the government enhance security in the area.

On 27 February 2023, a group of Kampala City Street cleaners protested at the Kampala Capital City Authority (KCCA) offices in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), demanding audience with the KCCA Executive Director. The cleaners claimed they are subjected to deplorable conditions like working for long hours for very poor pay.

On 27 February 2023, a group of climate activists protested in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), for the cancellation of Uganda's external debt, and that of other global south countries on the pretext that these countries are suffering adverse effects of climate change majorly caused by the heavily industrialized global North countries in Europe and North America.

On 27 February 2023, a group of Wakiso and Kampala district councilors protested at the parliamentary avenue in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), demanding the release of all political prisoners. Police intervened to disperse the protesters.

On 27 February 2023, residents protested in Kambi Ya Simba Village in Marmanet Ward (coded as Marmanet, Laikipia West, Laikipia) against the diversion of river Ewaso Nyiro water to thousands of communities in the village by an investor. The group demanded their political leaders address their grievance.

On 27 February 2023, more than 20 teachers protested at Kitgum Municipality offices in Kitgum (Kitgum, Kitgum), demanding the removal of the Town Clerk for alleged incompetence while others stated their right to be paid their salary.

On 27 February 2023, staff protested outside the Meru University in Nchiru (Tigania West, Meru) against claimed mismanagement of the institution. The group, led by UASU and Kuddheiha Union officials, demanded that the education ministry dismiss the vice-chancellor.

On 27 February 2023, residents protested by blocking (using unspecified means) the Embu-Kanyoonyo road in Machanga (coded as Embu, Manyatta, Embu) against water shortage in the area following the alleged diversion of river Thiba to private farms. The group demanded the river be unblocked.

On 27 February 2023, Kisumu Polytechnic students converged outside the institution where they blocked the gate with stones in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in a demonstration against fee increment. Police engaged the student leadership and management in a dialogue to help break the impasse.

On 27 February 2023, a section of clinicians (health workers) protested and marched to the Ministry of Health offices and Parliament in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) against poor terms of employment. Led by the Kenya Union of Clinical officers (KUCO), the group demanded the posting of interns and the absorption of universal health coverage (UHC) staff.

On 28 February 2023, members of the Somali community protested in Burat ward [coded as Burat, Isiolo, Isiolo] against increased cases of insecurity in the area. Led by the Somali community grazing community chairperson, the group demanded that the county and national security authorities address their grievance.

On 28 February 2023, Hawadle-Yaber Dige sub clan militia blocked (through unspecified means) the main supply route and all other secondary roads that lead to the police station in Belet Weyne town (Belet Weyne, Hiraan). This is after a joint security forces killed a civilian from the clan (coded separately).

On 28 February 2023, residents of Bore town rallied in Bore town (Guji, Oromia) to condemn the new restructuring of Negele town under the newly established 'East Borena Zone' by Oromia regional council. Soldiers fired live bullets and killed 3 protesters, wounding 2.

On 28 February 2023, hundreds of traders protested and marched through the streets of Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against infiltration of the Kenyan market by Chinese business people. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 28 February 2023, several local residents, including tuktuk drivers, protested against police brutality in Zoobe junction neighborhood in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir), after the killing a driver (coded separately). The protesters demanded justice.

On 1 March 2023, a group of pastoralists protested in Kayanja I and Kayanja II, Kitswamba sub county (Busongora, Kasese). They blocked the team of officials from accessing the land and demanded a meeting with the Lands, Housing and Urban Development Minister. The land is being contested between cultivators and pastoralists.
On 1 March 2023, protesters condemned the new restructuring of Negele town under the newly established 'East Borena Zone' by the Oromia regional council in Bule Hora town (West Guji, Oromia).
On 1 March 2023, protesters condemned the new restructuring of Negele town under the newly established 'East Borena Zone' by the Oromia regional council in Shakiso town (Guji, Oromia).

On 1 March 2023, protesters condemned the new restructuring of Negele town under the newly established 'East Borena Zone' by the Oromia regional council in Adola (Guji, Oromia). Police beat protesters in an attempt to disperse the crowd, at least one person was hospitalized.

On 1 March 2023, a group of boda boda riders protested against the alleged extortion by traffic officers along Moyo-Yumbe road coded as Moyo (Moyo, Moyo). The cyclists accused traffic officers of impounding their motorcycles in the villages over not wearing reflector jackets. The traffic police are implementing directives on usage of reflector jackets for easy identification. The UPDF and local leaders intervened to calm down the boda boda riders who had blocked the road (means unspecified) for over an hour.

On 1 March 2023, several local residents, including tuktuk drivers, protested against police brutality, after the killing a driver (coded separately) in Juba junction neighborhood in Mogadishu - Bondhere (Banadir). The protesters demanded justice.

On 1 March 2023, a group of 25 women, whose children were allegedly killed by a police officer, protested by staging a vigil outside the Milimani law court in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) against the delayed prosecution of the officer. Police from the GSU unit intervened and dispersed the group by hitting them with rungus.

Around 1 March 2023 (week of), a group of parents protested at the PMM Girls School in Jinja (Jinja, Jinja), against the school administration's reluctance to handle complaints raised about homosexuality claims in the school, and the conduct of a female teacher whom they accuse of allegedly defiling their female children. In the following week, police arrested the alleged partner of the detained teacher.

On 1 March 2023, residents protested in Kahawa Sukari estate in Ruiru (Ruiru, Kiambu) against the construction of highrise buildings in their neighborhood. Led by a Member of County Assembly (MCA) (Government, Jubilee, Azimio), and their welfare association leaders, the group demanded the county government to demolish the upcoming structures.
Around 1 March 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Nyamauro (Nyamira North, Nyamira) against increased insecurity. The group demanded that the government heighten security in the area.

On 2 March 2023, for the second day, protesters condemned the new restructuring of Negele town under the newly established 'East Borena Zone' by the Oromia regional council in Bule Hora town (West Guji, Oromia).

On 2 March 2023, for the second day, protesters condemned the new restructuring of Negele town under the newly established 'East Borena Zone' by the Oromia regional council in Shakiso town (Guji, Oromia).
On 2 March 2023, for the second day, protesters condemned the new restructuring of Negele town under the newly established 'East Borena Zone' by the Oromia regional council in Adola (Guji, Oromia).

On 2 March 2023, about 100 lorry drivers ferrying quarry materials protested along the Lukenya and Joska road (coded as Joska, Matungulu, Machakos) against the road's poor condition. The group demanded that the government address the problem.

On 2 March 2023, residents protested by draping the body of a man in a national flag and prevented the police (using unspecified means) from collecting the body at Ilikoni village near Mtito Andei (Kibwezi East, Makueni) against increased human-wildlife conflict, following the killing of the man by an elephant. Police intervened by firing tear gas to disperse the group.

On 2 March 2023, residents blocked the Kericho-Kisumu highway with stones and pieces of timber in Kericho (Ainamoi, Kericho) in a demonstration against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of a security guard by unknown assailants. Joined by the county governor, the group demanded the police officers be transferred

On 2 March 2023, a group calling itself Movement for the Defense of Democracy - Nairobi chapter protested in the central business district of Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against the increased cost of living. Police intervened and arrested 40 protesters.

On 2 March 2023, public service vehicle drivers from City Hoppa and Double M Saccos protested by blocking the city hall way in Nairobi's central business district (CBD) with buses (Nairobi - Starehe) against the award of additional routes and pick-up points to a competing bus company (Super Metro).

On 3 March 2023, Kenyatta university students protested by gathering at the China square business complex near Kahawa (Roysambu, Nairobi) against the closure of the complex. The group demanded that the complex be reopened.
On 3 March 2023, Puntland security forces protested over several months of unpaid salaries in Balli-Khadar village (Bossaso, Bari). The troops withdrew from a base.

On 3 March 2023, Meru University students marched at the institution, in Nchiru (Tigania West, Meru) in protest against the removal of the vice-chancellor. Police used unspecified means to disperse the group.
On 5 March 2023, residents protested in Marti (Samburu North, Samburu) against the killing of two minors (coded separately). The group demanded security agencies address the matter.

On 5 March 2023, (overnight), students and residents protested at Chemase Secondary School (Tinderet, Nandi) against the mysterious death of a Form 1 student. The group demanded more explanation from the administration over the student's death. The school was later closed on 6 March 2023.

On 5 March 2023, Rastafarian community members protested in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against the ruling by the supreme court that allows the LGBTQ community to form unions. The group demanded the government protect the sanctity of traditional marriage.

On 6 March 2023, residents of Adola town continued to protest and condemned the new restructuring of Negele town under the newly established 'East Borena Zone' by the Oromia regional council in Adola (Guji, Oromia).

On 6 March 2023, residents of Bale zone (coded at the administration center of the zone, Robe town, Bale, Oromia), Borena zone (coded separately in Yabelo) and Guji zone (coded separately in Negele) protested the new administration arrangement of Negele town and the newly established East Borena zone announced by the Oromia regional government. They stated the new arrangement is not based on the will of the public and it only benefits the regional government. Specific locations of the demonstration not mentioned. However, one witness stated the demonstrations are being held in all woreda's of these zones. On 4 and 5 March 2023 (weekend), they held stay at home protest.

On 6 March 2023, residents of Borena zone (coded at the administration center of the zone, Yabelo town, Borena, Oromia), Guji zone (coded separately in Negele) and Bale zone (coded separately in Robe) protested the new administration arrangement of Negele town and the newly established East Borena zone announced by the Oromia regional government. They stated the new arrangement is not based on the will of the public and it only benefits the regional government. Specific locations of the demonstration not mentioned. However, one witness stated the demonstrations are being held in all woreda's of these zones. On 4 and 5 March 2023 (weekend), they held stay at home protest.

On 6 March 2023, residents of Guji zone (coded at the administration center of the zone, Negele town, Guji, Oromia), Borena zone (coded separately in Yabelo) and Bale zone (coded separately in Rober) protested the new administration arrangement of Negele town and the newly established East Borena zone announced by the Oromia regional government. However, one witness stated the demonstrations are being held in all woreda's of these zones. On 4 and 5 March 2023 (weekend), they held stay at home protest.

Around 6 March 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Kilifi (Kilifi North, Kilifi) against the cutting down and exporting of Baobab trees. The group demanded the county government address the matter.

On 7 March 2023, residents of Guji zone continued to protest the new administration arrangement announced by the Oromia regional government. They accused the government of making the new arrangement based on its benefit and with out public consultation. The exact locations of the protest not mentioned, coded at the administration center of the zone, Negele town (Guji, Oromia).

On 7 March 2023, supporters of the former interior cabinet secretary camped outside the directorate of criminal investigation (DCI) offices in Kiambu (Kiambu town, Kiambu) against his interrogation by the police.

On 7 March 2023, a group calling itself 'Bunge la Mwananchi' protested at the Jacaranda grounds in Embakasi (Embakasi South, Embakasi) against the cutting down of trees at the venue. The group demanded to know the reason why the trees had been cleared off.

On 7 March 2023, hundreds of demonstrators marched to the market stalls and then to the county assembly's gate and the county commissioner and the governor's office in Kisii town (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii), against the unfair treatment of a former interior minister.
On 7 March 2023, a large crowd of residents protested, supporting the Somaliland army operation against the Khatumo State in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed).

On 7 March 2023, a section of Gusii residents (coded as Kisii ethnic group) protested by marching from the DCI offices along Kiambu road towards Nairobi central business district (Nairobi - Starehe) against the move by the government to arraign one of the community members.

On 7 March 2023, a section of Upper Hill Secondary School parents protested by camping out at the school gate in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) against the outbreak of cholera at the school. The parents demanded to see their children

On 7 March 2023, thousands of Meru University students marched for more than 20 kilometers along the Meru-Maua highway (coded as Meru, Imenti North, Meru) in support of the reinstatement of their vice-chancellor.

Around 8 March 2023 (as reported), residents marched in the Losuk location, Malaso division Samburu west constituency (coded as Malaso, Samburu Central, Samburu), against the deteriorating security situation caused by suspected ethnic pastoral militias. On 8 March 2023, a group protested against delayed justice in Entebbe (Entebbe, Wakiso). The group demanded justice for one of the protesters who was allegedly hit by a speeding car from KIU (Kampala International University), and has not been compensated since 2016.

On 8 March 2023, a group of about ten women protested against the illegal detention of their husbands at the Market in Kalerwe (Kampala, Kampala). They demanded that their husbands be released. Police intervened, arrested the protesters and took them to the Wandegeya police station. The suspects allegedly planned for the demonstration from National Unity Platform (NUP) offices at Makerere Kavule. On 20/03/2023, the arrested women were released on bail (1 million UgShs for all- 265 USD).

On 9 March 2023, over four hundred residents protested against the boundary opening at Lukodi Central Forest Reserve in Lokodi (Aswa, Gulu). The area covers Lukodi Village, an area that is currently occupied by returnees, survivors, and victims of the Lord's Resistance Army (LRA) who either fled their homes or did not return back after the insurgency. Security forces fired live bullets and teargas to disperse the protesting residents.

On 9 March 2023, parents protested at Kiendege Primary School near Nyakeyo (South Mugirango, Kisii) against the misuse of funds by the head teacher as well as the lack of infrastructural progress at the institution. The parents demanded the teacher service commission transfer the headteacher
On 9 March 2023, residents protested against the Somaliland government and conflict in Laas Caanood in Burco town (Burco, Togdheer).

On 10 March 2023, residents of Acholi protested against the UPDF's opening of boundaries over a piece of land in Rupa (Matheniko, Moroto). In the land dispute, a woman protester was allegedly physically assaulted by some of the soldiers. The UPDF public liaison officer claimed it was the residents who attacked the soldiers and added that the plans to open boundaries will continue.

On 10 March 2023, a group of truck drivers protested against the police's failure to contain car theft issues at the Kayunga central police station in Kayunga (Ntenjeru, Kayunga). They accused some police officers of conspiring with car robbers. In response to this protest, on 12/03/2023 the police and the flying squad conducted an operation during which they arrested six suspects including a police officer.

On 10 March 2023, pro-Azimio supporters protested in Mbale town (Vihiga, Vihiga) against the competence-based curriculum as well as the increase in the cost of living. The group demanded that the government address their grievances.

On 10 March 2023, pro-Azimio supporters marched to Luanda town (Emuhaya, Vihiga) against the competence-based curriculum as well as the increased cost of living. The group demanded that the government address their grievances.

Around 10 March 2023 (as reported), members of the Wadani party protested in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed) against the conflict in Laascaanood. Somaliland police intervened and arrested two members of the party.

Around 10 March 2023 (as reported), residents protested by marching along the Kimbimbi-Kanjinji road (coded as Kimbimbi, Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) against the poor state of the road. The group demanded the national government look into the matter.

On 10 March 2023, Azimio supporters marched from Kondele to the office of the county commissioner in Kisumu (Kisumu Central Kisumu) against high cost of living and high taxes. The group demanded the government address their grievances.

Around 10 March 2023 (as reported), members of the county assembly (MCA) protested by forcing their way into the parking department of Nairobi county (Starehe, Nairobi) against the impoundment of their vehicles. The group demanded that the county executive provide them with a designated area for parking and disciplinary action taken against the officers involved.

On 10 March 2023, public service vehicle drivers, mainly from City Hoppa bus company, protested by blocking major roads within Nairobi's central business district (CBD) with buses (Nairobi - Starehe) against the award of additional routes and pick-up points to a competing bus company.

On 11 March 2023, residents and parents protested outside Namanjalala primary school (Kwanza, Trans Nzoia) against the death of a student following alleged corporal punishment by a teacher. The group demanded that the concerned teacher and the head teacher be dismissed from service.

Around 12 March 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Kitengela (Kajiado East Kajiado) against mechanics' invasion on the feeder road leading to the GK Athi River Prison. The group demanded that the governor address their grievances.

On 13 March 2023, Azimio supporters protested in Nyandarua (Kinangop, Nyandarua) against the Kenya Kwanza government. The group demanded the government lower the cost of living.

On 13 March 2023, Kenya ports authority (KPA) workers protested in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in support of the appointment of the new managing director (MD). The group demanded the MD remove the overtime cap of 30 percent, among other grievances.

On 13 March 2023, residents of Gutin town staged a protest in Gutin town, Gida Ayana woreda (East Wellega, Oromia) and condemned the 'attacks by Amhara militias against civilians', and called for the government to intervene and stop attacks.

On 13 March 2023, members of the Wadani party protested over the assault of one of its members (coded separately) in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed).

On 13 March 2023, residents protested outside an entertainer's apartment along Thika road in Nairobi (Nairobi - Kasarani) against the death of a man called Jeff Mwathi. The group demanded justice for the victim.

On 14 March 2023, presumed Azimio supporters protested in Savannah, Donholm and Kayole estates of Nairobi (coded as Kayole, Embakasi, Nairobi) against the high cost of living. The group demanded the government address their grievances.

On 14 March 2023, a group of Makerere University's government-sponsored students protested against the university's delayed payment of food and living allowances at Makerere University (Kampala, Kampala). Shortly after the protest, some of the students were able to get at least 33 percent of their mandatory allowances.

Around 14 March 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Kamiruri village near Bahati (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against the death of a man at a local bar under mysterious circumstances. The group demanded that the authorities state why they took long to respond to distress calls.

On 15 March 2023, residents blocked the Marimanti-Mati road with stones (coded as Marimanti, Tharaka South, Tharaka-Nithi) in a demonstration against the development of a technical institute in Kauthene area, following a land row. The protesters asked the court 'not to release' a fourteen-year-old female student in detention by police after being accused of 'hitting/hurting students with a spell at school'.
Around 15 March 2023 (week of), a group of teachers protested against delayed salaries at the Chief Administrative Officer (CAO) in Apac (Apac, Apac).

On 17 March 2023, the Muslim faithful protested in Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi) against the recent Supreme Court ruling allowing the registration of LGBTQI organizations. The group demanded that the court review its decision.

On 20 March 2023, about 30 Azimio supporters marched along Kenyatta avenue in Nakuru town (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against the increased cost of living. Police intervened and arrested a former county assembly speaker and the ODM chairperson.

On 20 March 2023, Azimio supporters marched to the state lodge, with some using motorbikes in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu), against the increased cost of living, among other concerns. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 20 March 2023, Azimio supporters gathered at the Serena hotel and then marched, led by their members of parliament (MPs), to the Kenyatta international conference center in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) and attempted to force their way in. The demonstration was against the increased cost of living, among other concerns. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group. The opposition leader claimed there were shots fired presumably by police officers against vehicles that were carrying him and the Wiper leader. Four MPs were arrested during the incident.

On 20 March 2023, Azimio supporters protested in the Congo area of Kawangware (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) against the increased cost of living. Police intervened and used unspecified means to disperse the protesters. Three protesters (other sources mention dozens) were arrested during the incident.

On 20 March 2023, a group of Azimio women supporters protested outside the city hall in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against the increased cost of living, among other grievances. The group demanded that the government lower the cost of essential commodities.

On 20 March 2023, Azimio supporters marched to the state lodge, with some using motorbikes near Kilimani (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) against the increased cost of living, among other concerns. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 20 March 2023, Azimio supporters marched along the Kisumu-Busia road in Ugunja (Ugunja, Siaya) against the arrest of their member of parliament (coded separately). The group demanded the immediate release of their MP.
On 20 March 2023, Azimio supporters marched in Kitale town (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against the high cost of living, among other concerns. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 20 March 2023, Azimio supporters protested in Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu) against the increased cost of living among other grievances. The group demanded the government to lower the prices of essential commodities.

On 20 March 2023, Azimio supporters marched in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) against the increased cost of living. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group and arrested about 50 youths.

On 20 March 2023, a group of youth allied to UDA-Kenya kwanza protested in Naivasha (Naivasha, Nakuru) against the Azimio-led nationwide demonstrations. The group demanded peace during the demonstrations.

Around 22 March 2023 (as reported), residents marched along the Nairobi-Mombasa highway in Ronge also called Rong'e (Mwatate, Taita Taveta) against the killing of over 300 livestock by wild animals. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 22 March 2023, about 300 boda boda riders protested against the police extorting money from them in Tete bridge in Arinyapi (East Moyo, Adjumani). They stormed the police station to claim their seized motorcycles. The Police intervened with teargas and rubber bullets to disperse the protesters who shortly re-organized and proceeded to the district headquarters to deliver their grievances to the district chairman. Police intervened again, and few protesters managed to access the district headquarters and met the chairman.

Around 22 March 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Voi town (Voi, Taita Taveta) against the killing of over 300 livestock by wild animals. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 23 March 2023, hundreds of women protested in Kerio Valley (coded as Keiyo Valley) against increased insecurity orchestrated by pastoral militia. The group demanded that the authorities address their grievance.

On 23 March 2023, a group of students from Maracha Secondary School protested at the Maracha district headquarters in Maracha (Maracha, Maracha), against the bad leadership of their head teacher. They demanded his resignation.

Around 23 March 2023 (as reported), a group of people protested at the Mulago hospital in Mulago (Kampala, Kampala), demanding to be handed over the body of their relative whom they claimed they wanted to bury in his extended family's homeland. The court had ruled that the deceased's body be buried at his mother's homeland. The protesters accused the mother of wanting to grab the properties of the deceased. Police intervened to disperse the protesters.

On 24 March 2023, teachers in Deka town, Gesha woreda (Kefa, South West Ethiopia) protested and condemned the regional government for a one-month salary cut without their consultations. The government security forces (coded as South West Ethiopia State Police) arrested organizers following the protest.

Around 25 March 2023 (as reported), residents protested in lorumbae and lmisigioi villages (coded as Archers Post, Samburu East, Samburu) against increased insecurity, following the killing of three people by suspected pastoral militia (coded separately). The group demanded the security authorities to address their grievance.
On 25 March 2023, (overnight), residents protested in Parklands (Westlands, Nairobi) against construction work at night. The group demanded the governor to address their grievance.

On 26 March 2023, residents of Aysha town closed Ethio-Djibouti highway and railway to demonstrate against what they say is the 'displacement of ethnic Somalis by ethnic Afar armed groups' in Ayisha woreda (Siti, Somali) and demanded the government to return IDPs to 'their places'. ENDF commanders peacefully discussed with communal elders to convince them to open the blocked highways, but the demonstrators refused and demanded the government to first 'return of Somalis to their land'. The demonstration continued the next day (coded separately).

On 27 March 2023, Azimio supporters led by the governor (ODM) marched to Nyamasaria (Kisumu East, Kisumu), against the increased cost of living among other concerns. The group demanded the government to lower the cost of essential commodities.

The demonstrators started to head to the ENDF camp after a rumor that ENDF captured members of regional forces traveling from Dessie to Kombolch was heard in the town. Members of the regional special forces were released later. A stone thrown by demonstrators injured the head of the ruling Prosperity Party office in Kombolcha.

On 11 April 2023, residents staged a rally in Kombolcha (South Wello, Amhara) and condemned the decision of Ethiopian government to 'reorganize and merge the regional special forces into federal and regional security forces'. On 11 April 2023, residents staged a rally in Wereta (South Gondar, Amhara) and condemned the decision of Ethiopian government to 'reorganize and merge the regional special forces in to federal and regional security forces'. ENDF members arbitrarily fired at protesters when someone 'tried to confront with the military' and dispersed the gathering. Casualties unknown.

On 11 April 2023, a group of pre-medical interns protested against the delayed commencement of their medical internship in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala). On 11 April 2023, residents staged a rally in Mer Awi (West Gojam, Amhara) and condemned the decision of Ethiopian government to 'reorganize and merge the regional special forces in to federal and regional security forces'. The demonstrators closed roads with stones and sticks and took to the street to voice their grievances. The roads were open on 20 April 2023.

The demonstrators closed roads with stones and sticks and took to the street to voice their grievances. The roads were open on 20 April 2023.

On 18 April 2023, public service vehicles (matatus) plying the city center to Kahawa West route protested by blocking the Thika superhighway at Lumumba drive (coded as Kahawa, Roysambu, Nairobi) against the registration of a new sacco (super metro) to the route.

Around 18 April 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Soweto area of Migori county (coded to the county headquarter as Migori, Suna West, Migori) against alleged intimidation and corruption by the area chief. The group demanded the president and the national security council to help address the matter.
On 18 April 2023, health workers drawn from various unions protested in Nairobi (stare he, Nairobi) against delayed payment of their salaries and statutory deductions in some selected counties.

On 18 April 2023, members of the Youth Fortress ACT-Wazalendo gathered in demonstration in Magomeni (Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam) against the misappropriation of public funds by the government but were stopped by the police (by unknown means).

On 19 April 2023, civil servants continued to demonstrate against the government in Shone town in Hadiya zone (SNNP), for a third day as the woreda administration failed to pay their salaries for the past three months. The demonstration began on 17 April 2023 (coded separately) and lasted until 19 April 2023. The demonstrators closed roads with stones and sticks and took to the street to voice their grievances. The roads were open on 20 April 2023.
On 19 April 2023, health workers protested in Nyamira (Nyamira, Nyamira) against delayed pay of their salaries. The group demanded a sit down with the county government representatives.
On 19 April 2023, health workers protested in Vihiga (Vihiga, Vihiga) against delayed pay of their salaries. The group demanded a sit down with the county government representatives.

On 20 April 2023, a group of residents accompanied by their local councilor, protested against damaged roads in Komambuga zone of Kawempe (Kampala, Kampala). They blocked the road demanding for its immediate reparation. The police intervened to disperse the protesters.

On 21 April 2023, residents protested in Kambi Waya village near Chepchoina (Endebess, Trans Nzoia) against the move by the Agricultural Development Corporation (ADC) to till a disputed 1,500-acre piece of land before a court matter is settled. Police shot and injured two people, before destroying unknown number of houses and property during the incident.

Around 22 April 2023 (as reported), residents protested by blocking the Igare-Matierio-Borangi-Nyacheki road with banana stems in Bobasi (Bobasi, Kisii) against the poor state of the road. The group demanded their leaders to address the matter.

On 23 April 2023, residents protested in Myland estate in Utawala near Embakasi (Embakasi South, Nairobi) against illegal quarry mining in the area due to noise and air pollution. Led by the resident's association chairman, the group demanded the government to close the quarry. The police visited the area and listened to the protesters, before asking them to disperse.

On 23 April 2023, rickshaw drivers protested over a new rule from the Banadir administration, that divided the drivers into two groups of A and B and commanded each group to function on alternate days and also that each had to repaint their rickshaws, in Mogadishu - Shangaani (Banadir). The police opened fire (unclear if live bullets were used) to disperse the protesters. There were no casualties.

On 23 April 2023, rickshaw drivers protested over a new rule from the Banadir administration, that divided the drivers into two groups of A and B and commanded each group to function on alternate days and also that each had to repaint their rickshaws, in Mogadishu - Hodan (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle). The police opened fire (unclear if live bullets were used) to disperse the protesters. There were no casualties.

On 24 April 2023, a group of doctor interns protested against their delayed internship deployment at parliament in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala). Police intervened and brutally arrested about a dozen protesters.
On 24 April 2023, a group of university students protested against unfair tuition fees and the non-payment of their allowance at Lira university in Lira (Lira, Lira).

On 24 April 2023, a group of students from the Karamoja sub-region, who belong to the opposition political party National Unity Platform (NUP) protested at the NUP offices in Kamwokya (Kampala, Kampala). They accused government of neglecting for a long time the problems affecting the sub-region. They noted escalating insecurity and recurrent raids, coupled with unmitigated poverty.

On 24 April 2023, residents of Kivou location marched to the directorate of criminal investigation in Mwingi (Mwingi Central, Kitui) against illegal sand harvesting in the area. The group demanded the local leaders to ensure that the illegal business does not continue.

Around 25 April 2023 (as reported), residents, including a group of women and akorinos, protested in Githakwa (Nyeri Central, Nyeri) against the move by the government to shut down bars in the area, following increased rate of drug and substance abuse. The group demanded the county government to open at least one bar in the area.

On 25 April 2023, residents, mainly farmers, protested in Nasewa (Matayos, Busia) against the development of an export processing zone (EPZ) by the government in the area. The group demanded the government to share a cost-benefit analysis of the project before rollout.
On 26 April 2023, residents protested over Governor Nuur Dheere's controversial takeover of the district's only hospital in Jalalaqsi town (Jalalaqsi, Hiraan).

On 26 April 2023, residents protested in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the move to construct a wastewater project in the area, citing fears of losing their ancestral lands. The group demanded the concerned authorities to rescind the move.

On 26 April 2023, residents, mainly university students, led by comedian and activist Eric Omondi, protested by blocking the Jomo Kenyatta highway, with some lying on mattresses, in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the increased cost of living, delay in disbursement of higher education loans board (HELB) funds, as well as unemployment. Police intervened and hurled teargas to disperse the group. Omondi and four other protesters were arrested.

On 26 April 2023, residents protested in Kileleshwa (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) against the location of the Jubilee party headquarters in their area, following the chaos among rival camps. The group demanded the offices moved.

On 26 April 2023, a group of youth protested in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against the lack of job opportunities from the county government. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 26 April 2023, boda boda taxi operators protested in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against alleged harassment by the employees of asset financing companies. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 27 April 2023, over 100 Pastors from Mombasa, Kilifi, Kwale and Taita Taveta counties gathered at the Mombasa Pentecostal church (Mvita, Mombasa) against the actions of one of their colleagues, accused of influencing his congregants to starve to death. The group demanded the government to prosecute pastors who preached outside the scripture.

On 27 April 2023, a group of women members of parliament protested in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), against police brutality. Police arrested at least eleven women from protesters as they led a procession to the Ministry of Internal Affairs to query why they had been banned from holding rallies across the country.

On 27 April 2023, Pastor Ezekiel Odero's followers protested at the New Life International church in Mavueni (Kilifi North, Kilifi) against the arrest of their pastor over alleged indoctrination. The group demanded for his release.

On 27 April 2023, a group of women's rights defenders protested outside the Milimani law courts in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) against the failure by a member of parliament (MP) to pay school fees for a child he is suspected to be the father. The group demanded the MP to fulfil his obligation to his children.

Around 27 April 2023 (as reported), the business community protested in Karatina (Mathira East, Nyeri) against the move by the county government to increase parking and mortuary fees as well as hospital charges. The group demanded the county to lower the fees.

On 28 April 2023, a section of residents protested against the opening of a community access road in their village of Amagoro (Tororo, Tororo). The protesters threatened to torch the grader if the local officials went ahead with the plan to open the road. The police intervened and stopped the government officials from opening the road.

On 30 April 2023, medical students at Kenyatta university protested outside the institutions gate in Kahawa (Roysambu, Nairobi) against the transfer of Kenyatta University Teaching, Referral & Research Hospital (KUTTRH) to the state. Led by the students association treasurer, the group demanded the state to revert the ownership of the hospital to the university, to facilitate their medical studies.

On 1 May 2023, Puntland security forces blocked (through unspecified means) the main road that links Gaalkacyo to Galdogob in Gaalkacyo town (Gaalkacyo, Mudug). The security forces were protesting against unpaid salaries.
On 1 May 2023, Puntland security forces protested and blocked a road over unpaid salaries, hiring issues, and unpaid voting card distribution salaries in Gaalkacyo North town (Gaalkacyo, Mudug).
On 1 May 2023, Puntland security forces protested and blocked a road over unpaid salaries, hiring issues, and unpaid voting card distribution salaries in Galdogob town (Galdogob, Mudug).
On 1 May 2023, Puntland security forces protested and blocked a road over unpaid salaries, hiring issues, and unpaid voting card distribution salaries in Jariiban village (Jariibaan, Mudug).
On 1 May 2023, a group of youth protested in Kibera (Kibra, Nairobi) against the planned Azimio led protests. The group demanded the Azimio leader Raila Odinga not to hold the protests in the area.

Around 2 May 2023 (as reported), traders protested in Sindo market (Suba, Homa Bay) against the poor state of the market, due to lack of garbage collection. Led by the market chairman, the group demanded the responsible department to undertake regular garbage collection.
On 2 May 2023, a group of Azimio supporters assembled in Siaya town (Alego Usonga, Siaya) against the increased cost of living, among other grievances.

On 2 May 2023, a group of students protested over missing marks at Kyambogo university in Kyambogo (Kampala, Kampala). The police intervened and used tear gas to disperse the protesters and arrested about fifteen.

On 2 May 2023, Pastor Ezekiel Odero's followers protested outside the Shanzu law courts (Kilifi South, Kilifi) against the arrest and arraignment of their pastor over alleged indoctrination. Joined by the pastor's lawyers, the group demanded for his release.

On 2 May 2023, Azimio supporters protested by in Rongo (Rongo, Migori) against the increased cost of living among other grievances. Running battles ensued as police used unspecified means to disperse the group.
On 2 May 2023, a group of Azimio supporters protested along the Kakamega-Kisimu Highway in Mbale town (Vihiga, Vihiga) against the increased cost of living, among other grievances.
On 2 May 2023, a group of Azimio supporters protested in Majengo town (Vihiga, Vihiga) against the increased cost of living among other grievances.
On 2 May 2023, a group of Azimio supporters assembled in Bondo town (Bondo, Siaya) against the increased cost of living among other grievances.

On 2 May 2023, a group of about 50 lawmakers allied to the Azimio coalition marched to the office of the president along Harambee avenue in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against the increased cost of living among other grievances. Police intervened and fired teargas to disperse the group.
On 2 May 2023, Azimio supporters protested by blocking (using unspecified means) the Kisumu-Busia highway in Ugunja (Ugunja, Siaya) against the increased cost of living, among other grievances.
