On 3 May 2023, demonstrators closed roads with stones in Shewa Robit (Shoa Robit, North Shewa, Amhara) and Debre Sina (coded separately) against ENDF movement in the area and the government's recent law enforcement operation in Amhara region following the killing of the head of Amhara Prosperity Party on 27 April 2023 (coded separately).
On 3 May 2023, a group of women demonstrated in Berbera district complaining about the increased electricity bills by the electricity companies in Berbera town (Berbera, Woqooyi Galbeed).

On 3 May 2023, a group of residents led by their local administrators protested in Kitagwenda (Kitagwenda, Kitagwenda), demanding that the president of Uganda solves the matter of land dispute between their district and the district of Kamwenge.

On 3 May 2023, a group of residents protested against the government's negligence of the state of their roads at Kajurugo coded to Bushenyi (Bushenyi, Bushenyi). Police intervened to prevent further escalation.

On 3 May 2023, demonstrators closed roads with stones in Debre Sina (Tarema Ber, North Shewa, Amhara) and Shewa Robit (coded separately) against ENDF movement in the area and the government's recent law enforcement operation in Amhara region following the killing of the head of Amhara Prosperity Party on 27 April 2023 (coded separately).

On 3 May 2023, demonstrators, including Fanos and youths, closed roads and shops (from Buluk to Azezo areas) with stones in Gonder town (Central Gondar, Amhara) against the government's decision to take action against 'extremists' in the region after the killing of the Head of Amhara Prosperity Party (coded separately). According to witnesses, the roads were closed after members of ENDF began to arrive in and around Gondar city. The group asked the military to leave their region and for the government to inform them about the TPLF forces' disarmament process status.

On 3 May 2023, a group of Azimio supporters protested in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the move by the coalition leaders to call off the planned nationwide protests slated for 4 May 2023. The group demanded the protests to proceed as planned.

On 3 May 2023, members of the county assembly, disrupted their inaugural meeting by scolding at the devolution permanent secretary (PS) in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) as they demanded a pay rise among other grievances. The meeting ended prematurely as the PS was forced to leave.

On 4 May 2023, demonstrators continued closing roads with stones in Shewa Robit (Shoa Robit, North Shewa, Amhara) and Debre Sina (coded separately) against ENDF movement in the area and the government's recent law enforcement operation in Amhara region following the killing of the head of Amhara Prosperity Party on 27 April 2023 (coded separately).

On 4 May 2023, local residents protested against Somaliland along the Dila and Borama road and blocked (through unspecified means) the road between Borama to Hargeisa in Borama town (Borama, Awdal). The protesters demanded justice for a police officer who was killed in Lawya Caddo (coded separately).

Around 4 May 2023 (as reported), Kyambogo government sponsored students protested against government's failure to release their food and living allowances at Kyambogo University in Kyambogo (Kampala, Kampala). As part of the protest, the students started using their lecture rooms as bedrooms claiming they are unable to pay their hostel fees.

On 4 May 2023, Pastor Ezekiel Odero's followers protested outside the Shanzu law courts (Kilifi South, Kilifi) against the arrest and arraignment of their pastor over alleged indoctrination. The group demanded for his release.

On 4 May 2023, demonstrators continued closing roads with stones in Debre Sina (Tarema Ber, North Shewa, Amhara) and Shewa Robit (coded separately) against ENDF movement in the area and the government's recent law enforcement operation in Amhara region following the killing of the head of Amhara Prosperity Party on 27 April 2023 (coded separately).

On 4 May 2023, demonstrators, including Fanos and youth, continued to close roads and shops (from Buluk to Azezo areas) with stones and also closed shops by staying at home in Gonder town (Central Gondar, Amhara) against the government's decision to take action against 'extremists' in the region after the killing of the Head of Amhara Prosperity Party (coded separately). According to witnesses, the roads were closed after members of ENDF began to arrive in and around Gondar city. The group asked the military to leave their region and for the government to inform them about the TPLF forces' disarmament process status. At least 3 people were killed by stray bullets fired by Amhara regional special forces.

On 5 May 2023, a group of residents protested the arrest of another resident in Kamina (Buyaga, Kagadi). It is alleged that Police backed by the UPDF soldier had gone to arrest a resident accused of malicious damage to property. As residents protested the arrest, the UPDF officer fired several bullets in the air to disperse the rowdy residents. A stray bullet hit one of the protesters killing her instantly and another stray bullet hit another resident on the left hand critically injuring him. The UPDF officer took off and is currently being hunted down.

On 5 May 2023, residents of Kalu Woreda and Habru town held a protest in Habru town (North Wello, Amhara) against the killing of the head of Amhara Prosperity party on 27 April 2023 (coded separately).

On 5 May 2023, protests against the killings of Amhara leaders were held in 21 woredas and towns of South Wello zone (coded at the administration center of the zone, Dessie town, South Wello, Amhara). The protesters condemned the killing of Amhara leaders and held slogans like 'Ideas can be built through ideas, not weapons; weapons will destroy the country; we want the government to continue the law enforcement operation, and we will assist; ENDF is our guarantee' etc.

On 7 May 2023, local residents protested against the government on the circumstances surrounding the death of a soldier (who was undergoing training in Uganda) who was recruited area in Hudur town (Xudur, Bakool). The protesters demanded a response from the government over the alleged missing vital organs of the deceased soldier, who was brought back to Somalia from Uganda by the Federal Government of Somalia.

On 7 May 2023, residents protested in Nduru (South Mugirango, Kisii) against the move by the county government to close down Nduru hospital after withdrawal of health staff. The group demanded the county to redeploy staff at the hospital.
On 7 May 2023, traders protested at Katito Market in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the non-collection of garbage. The group demanded cleaners to be stationed at the market.

On 8 May 2023, a protest against the killing of Amhara leaders and 'extremists' was held in Kemise town (Oromia, Amhara). In this protest, residents of Kemise town and Dewa Chefa woreda participated and held slogans like 'Respect the rule of law; the struggle will not stop by killing a leader; extremism is a current problem.'
Around 8 May 2023 (as reported), construction workers protested at Thwake dam (Mbooni, Makueni) against delayed pay.
On 8 May 2023, residents protested in Kangema (Kangema, Muranga) against the poor state of Mau Mau road. The group demanded the government to gravel the road.
On 8 May 2023, a group of four local leaders protested against the bad state of their roads in Tororo (Tororo, Tororo). The police intervened and arrested the protesters.

On 8 May 2023, residents, led by a DAP-K MP and an ODM leader, protested in Mumias (Mumias West, Kakamega) against the move by the government to change the management of Mumias sugar company. The group demanded the government to rescind the changes.

On 9 May 2023, Puntland police forces blocked (through unspecified means) the main road that links Garowe to Bosaso in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal). The police forces were protesting against unpaid salaries and accused Puntland president using their salaries for a campaign.
On 9 May 2023, a group of parents protested in Kiunguni primary school (Chuka, Tharaka-Nithi) against poor management of the school. The group demanded the headteacher to be transferred.

On 9 May 2023, students of Debre Markos University held a rally in their Campus, Debre Markos town (East Gojam, Amhara), following the death of a student (who was found hanged in a toilet). Government security forces (assumed to be Amhara Regional State Police) blocked and dispersed the protest by firing bullets in the air and tear gas.
On 9 May 2023, Puntland police forces protested and blocked a road over unpaid salaries in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari).

On 9 May 2023, 1200 workers at the export processing zone authority (EPZA) protested in Athi river (Athi River, Machakos) against poor working environment. The group demanded better working conditions as well as the management to prioritize workers safety.

On 9 May 2023, residents protested in Giachuma near Naro Moru (Kieni East, Nyeri) against increased cases of insecurity following the loss of more than 1000 livestock in the past one month. The group demanded the police officers to address the matter.
On 10 May 2023, a protest condemning 'extremists' forces was held in Sekota town (Wag Hamra, Amhara).
Around 10 May 2023 (as reported), a group of workers protested against a construction company's delay to pay their salaries in Nakifuma (Nakifuma, Mukono).

Around 10 May 2023 (as reported), a group of traders protested against the misuse of their funds by a local credit union (SACCO) in Nakawa (Kampala, Kampala). They demanded explanations why they could not access these funds.

On 10 May 2023, a group of timber traders marched towards the Ugandan parliament in a protest against the government's failure to pay them for the timber they had provided to different government institutions in Bwaise (Kampala, Kampala). Police intervened and cut off their protest and march to the Ugandan parliament.

Around 10 May 2023 (as reported), a group of NUP councillors protested in Kawempe (Kampala, Kampala), against the economic situation in the country and the hiking prices of items on the market. Police and the military intervened and arrested the protesters.

On 10 May 2023, residents protested in Kapchamo village (Kesses, Uasin Gishu) against the planned expansion of two rivers dam by the ministry of water and sanitation. The group demanded president to help address matter.

Around 10 May 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Kamanamsim near Litein (Bureti, Kericho) against the construction of poor-quality roads. The group demanded the president to address the matter.

On 11 May 2023, Jua Kali residents forced their way into the independent policing oversight authority (IPOA) offices in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the shooting of three people by police officers who were chasing a suspected public service vehicle (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the victims.

Around 12 May 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Kamtonga (Mwatate, Taita Taveta) against the planned move to displace them from their land. The group demanded both county and national government to address the matter.

On 12 May 2023, a group of residents supported by their local councillor protested against the attack of a fellow resident in Bulenga (Busiro, Wakiso), by a local pastor whom they accuse of attacking and seriously injuring the victim. They blocked the road going to the pastor's church. It is alleged that the land on which the church was built belongs to the victim and that has been the origin of the dispute and subsequent attack.

On 12 May 2023, several residents protested against Somaliland administration in Ceerigaabo village (Ceerigaabo, Sanaag). Somaliland police forces fired live bullets to disperse the crowd. There were no casualties.

Around 12 May 2023 (as reported), staff protested at Kabarnet special school (Baringo Central, Baringo) against delayed pay. The group demanded the cabinet secretary for education to address the matter. The institution was closed indefinitely.

Around 13 May 2023 (as reported), residents protested by blocking the Kapsoit-Soundu road with banana stems at Sigowet (Sigowet, Kericho) against the poor state of the road. The group demanded the government to address the matter.

On 14 May 2023, residents of Raya Alamata held a peaceful protest in Alamata town (Southern Tigray, Tigray). The protest was held after the National Election Board of Ethiopia announced its plan to hold the 6th general election in Tigray region next year. The protesters stated that this decision did not take their request for self-administration, and if their request is not addressed, they indicated their plan to boycott the election. They have also requested the government to release a budget and to reconstruct damaged public services during the northern Ethiopia conflict in the region.

On 14 May 2023, 1,300 household members protested in Sergoit, also known as Sirgoit or Kapsinende (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against threats of eviction from a private developer. The group demanded the government to help address the matter as well as the ethics and anti-corruption commission to investigate the authenticity of the private developer's title deed.
On 15 May 2023, a group of pre-medical interns protested against delayed deployment in Gulu (Gulu, Gulu). Police intervened and arrested the protesters as they tried to march towards state house.

On 15 May 2023, Nandi county residents protested in an unspecified location (coded to county headquarters as Kapsabet, Chesumei, Nandi) against increased cost of living. The group demanded the president to address the matter.

On 15 May 2023, Kipsuter boys high school students marched to the county headquarters in Bomet (Bomet East, Bomet) against the transfer of their school principal. The group demanded the transfer reversed.

On 15 May 2023, a group of pre-medical interns from the College of Health Sciences organizing a peaceful march to the president's office protesting their delayed deployment in Mulago (Kampala, Kampala) have been arrested by the police before they could set off.

On 15 May 2023, a group of pre-medical interns protested against delayed deployment in Kabale (Kabale, Kabale). Police intervened and arrested the protesters as they tried to march towards state house.
On 15 May 2023, presumed ODM-Azimio supporters disrupted a funeral service by scolding at lawyer Miguna Miguna in Oyugis (Kasipul, Homa Bay). The lawyer had to cut short his speech.

On 15 May 2023, hundreds of women marched from Makutano to Meru town (Imenti North, Meru) against the alleged derogatory remarks made by Tigania East member of parliament (MP) while faulting the governor style of leadership. Led by the chairperson of Maendeleo ya Wanawake Meru chapter, the group demanded the MP to issue a public apology within seven days.

Around 15 May 2023 (as reported), a group of youth protested in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against the move by the county government to chase away investors following alleged harassment and demolition of business establishments.
On 16 May 2023, causal workers protested in Migori (Suna West, Migori) against delayed salary payment. The group demanded the county government to pay their salaries.

Around 16 May 2023 (as reported), a group of youth protested in Chepchoina (Endebess, Trans Nzoia) against alleged unfair employment opportunities by the China state road construction company in the area. The group demanded both the county and national governments to help address the matter.

Around 16 May 2023 (as reported), 300 traders protested at Makongeni bus park in Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu) against a proposed plan by the county government to modernize the park. The group demanded the county not to demolish their kiosks.

On 16 May 2023, young farmers from Chenta Sost Kebele in Bahir Dar Zuria woreda protested the lack of fertilizers for their farmland in front of the Amhara regional administration office in Bahir Dar town (West Gojam, Amhara). They stated that the administrator at the local level requested for them to pay 500 birr instead of the agreed amount 300 birr, which according to the protesters, the 500 birr payment is for the local leader's 'pocket.'

On 17 May 2023, members of the Samburu council of elders protested in Samburu West (coded as Malaso, Samburu Central, Samburu) against increased insecurity following attacks by suspected pastoral militia. Led by the council secretary, group demanded government to address the matter.

On 17 May 2023, over 200 students protested in Ilmashariani primary school (Narok North, Narok) against the move by the teachers service commission (TSC) to transfer the institution's headteacher. Joined by their parents, the group demanded the education cabinet secretary to reverse the headteacher's transfer.

Around 17 May 2023 (as reported), parents protested at Muget primary school (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the lack of teachers as well as poor infrastructure for junior secondary school (JSS) students. The group demanded the ministry of education at both county and national government levels to address the matter.

On 17 May 2023, a group of mechanics protested to the Meru police station (Imenti North, Meru) against increased insecurity attributed to street children. The group demanded the police to enhance security in the area.

On 17 May 2023, over 3000 coffin traders and mechanics marched to the deputy county commissioners (DCC) office in Thika town (Thika Town, Kiambu) against the move by the Presbyterian church to eject them from their land. The group demanded the DCC to address the matter.

On 18 May 2023, youth protested in Kanankemer (Turkana Central, Turkana) against the planned move by the area member of parliament (MP) to construct a police post in their land. The group demanded the MP to relocate the police post.

On 18 May 2023, workers at the Maasai Mara university Kenya Staff Union (KUSU) protested in Narok (Narok North, Narok) against alleged mismanagement as well as mistreatment of workers. Led by the Kenya staff union (KUSU) officials, the group demanded the education cabinet secretary to help address their grievances.

On 20 May 2023, members of Wendano Matuu company Ltd, led by their chairperson, protested in Kisukioni shopping Centre in Matungulu, Machakos) against alleged against unfair treatment by the deputy county commissioner (DCC), following a land ownership dispute. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 22 May 2023, overnight, more than 50 primary school teachers protested outside the Tharaka Nithi county teachers' service commission (TSC) office in Chuka town (Chuka, Tharaka-Nithi) against the move by TSC to delay their transfer to their home counties following the abolishment of the delocalization policy. The group demanded their transfers effected.

On 22 May 2023, a group of people including, fishermen, gathered in demonstration at the Lake Manyara National Park (Monduli, Arusha) against an perpetrated by rangers from the Tanzania National Parks Agency who left thee fishermen injured (coded separately). Police officers and park rangers (Green Guards) intervened and shot people. One person was killed and others were injured. Fishermen claimed that two colleagues disappeared.

Around 22 May 2023 (as reported), more than a hundred parents from Nkubu primary school protested at the institution in Nkubu (Imenti South, Meru) against alleged misuse of funds by the headmistress. The group demanded the headmistress transferred.

On 22 May 2023, Kisumu polytechnic students protested outside the institution in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against fee increase. The group demanded the administration to revert to old prices of food.

On 23 May 2023, thousands of people displaced by the Northern conflict staged a protest in Abiy Adi, Tanqua Melashe (Central Tigray, Tigray) demanding their return to their residences, provision of aid, the implementation of the Pretoria agreement and the withdrawal of non-ENDF forces from the region. Similar demonstrations were held on the same day in other main towns of the region (coded separately).

On 23 May 2023, thousands of people displaced by the Northern conflict staged a protest in Adigrat, Adigrat town (Eastern Tigray, Tigray) demanding their return to their residences, provision of aid, the implementation of the Pretoria agreement and the withdrawal of non-ENDF forces from the region. Similar demonstrations were held on the same day in other main towns of the region (coded separately).

On 23 May 2023, thousands of people displaced by the Northern conflict staged a protest in Adwa town, Adwa (Central Tigray, Tigray) demanding their return to their residences, provision of aid, the implementation of the Pretoria agreement and the withdrawal of non-ENDF forces from the region. Similar demonstrations were held on the same day in other main towns of the region (coded separately).

On 23 May 2023, people displaced by the Northern conflict staged a protest in Aksum (Axum town, Central Tigray, Tigray) demanding their return to their residences, provision of aid, the implementation of the Preoria agreement and the withdrawal of non-ENDF forces from the region. Similar demonstrations were held on the same day in other main towns of the region (coded separately).

On 23 May 2023, thousands of people displaced by the Northern conflict staged a protest in Humera (Setit Humera, Western Tigray) and demanded the federal government to return home and called for the withdrawal of what they say is, 'foreign and invading forces' based on the peace deal. Protesters chanted and displayed banners that rea, 'return us quickly to our homelands!', 'invading forces should leave our land'. Similar protest rallies were held on the same day in other main towns of the region (coded separately).

On 23 May 2023, thousands of people displaced by the Northern conflict staged a protest in Mekele, Mekelle City (Mekelle Tigray/Central Tigray, Tigray) demanding their return to their residences, provision of aid, the implementation of the Pretoria agreement and the withdrawal of non-ENDF forces from the region. Similar demonstrations were held on the same day in other main towns of the region (coded separately).

On 23 May 2023, thousands of people displaced by the Northern conflict staged a protest in Shire, Tahtay Koraro, Mekelle City (North Western Tigray, Tigray) demanding their return to their residences, provision of aid, the implementation of the Pretoria agreement and the withdrawal of non-ENDF forces from the region. Similar demonstrations were held on the same day in other main towns of the region (coded separately).

On 23 May 2023, members of Acacia Estate Residents' Association (other sources mention Olekasasi), joined by boda boda taxi operators and business people, gathered in Ongata Rongai (Loitokitok, Kajiado) against the poor state of the Masai Lodge to Tuala-Rimpa road and to demand that the Kenya Rural Roads Authority (KeRRA) to allow the completion of the road work project by a Chinese contractor. Police used unspecified means to disperse the group.

Around 23 May 2023 (as reported), parents protested at a school in or around Kathonzweni subcounty (Makueni, Makueni) against embezzlement of funds by the teachers. The group demanded the ministry of education to investigate the teachers involved.

On 23 May 2023, residents protested in Kisimenyi (Voi, Taita Taveta) against the community land registration process led by the local administration. The group demanded for individual land registration.

On 23 May 2023, at least 178 Middle East jobs trainees marched to Kitengela police station (Kajiado East, Kajiado) against being deceived by their agents. The group demanded support from the police to go back to their homes as well retrieve their identity cards and birth certificates from the agents.

On 23 May 2023, parents of Iloodariak boys secondary school protested at the institution in Iloodariak (Kajiado West, Kajiado) against the alleged move by the school board of management to instigate the transfer of the school principal. The group demanded the principal reinstated.
On 23 May 2023, residents protested in Murubara near Wanguru (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) against increased livestock theft. The group demanded the government to address the matter.

On 24 May 2023, a group of market vendors protested against the absence of water and electricity in Soroti main market located in Soroti (Soroti, Soroti). The market remained closed after several vendors, some carrying placards demanding reconnection, took their goods to the street outside the market and conducted business there.
On 24 May 2023, a group of residents protested against the destruction of their crops by stray park animals in Kitagwenda (Kitagwenda, Kitagwenda).

On 24 May 2023, several tuk-tuk drivers and their owners gathered and protested in Ceelasha Biyaha village (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle). The reason for the protest was after the Government ordered to divide Tuk-tuks into two groups ('A' and 'B') and each group will work in turns on alternate days.

On 24 May 2023, supporters of former Mungiki leader protested outside the Nakuru law courts (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against the arrest and prosecution of their leader in connection to the recovery of two illegal guns and 90 rolls of bhang in his houses.

Around 24 May 2023 (week of), residents protested against the poor state of the Igare-Nyacheki road (coded as Igare, Bobasi, Kisii). The group demanded their area member of parliament (MP) to address the matter.

On 25 May 2023, students, teachers and board members protested at highway secondary school in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against attempts by a private developer to grab school land that hosts the teachers' quarters. The group demanded the government to issue title deeds to schools to safeguard the school land.

On 25 May 2023, supporters of former Mungiki leader protested outside the directorate of criminal investigations (DCI) offices along Kiambu road, in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the prosecution of their leader in connection to the recovery of two illegal guns and 90 rolls of bhang in his houses. Police lobbed teargas and deployed water cannons to disperse the group, as well as arrested 6 protestors. Four vehicles were damaged during the incident.

On 26 May 2023, following a Friday prayer, Muslims in Addis Ababa gathered at Grand Anwar Mosque in Addis Ketema, Addis Ketema (Region 14, Addis Ababa) and rallied to condemn the demolition of mosques by the government in the newly formed Sheger city. Federal Police, Republican Guards, and Addis Ababa city police entered the Mosque compound, fired tear gas and live bullets at the crowds, killed 3 and wounded unknown number of protesters. Addis Ababa police commission also claimed that around 30 police officers and 'supporters' were also injured. 114 people were arrested following the event. The death of one protester who was shot and died in hospital added to this event.

On 26 May 2023, following a Friday prayers, Muslims in Addis Ababa gathered at Al-Nur/Beni Mosque in Piazza (Menelik-II Square, Arada sub-city, Region 14, Addis Ababa) and rallied to condemn the demolition of mosques by the government in the newly formed Sheger city. Federal Police, Republican Guards, and Addis Ababa city police closed the Mosque compound, fired tear gas and live bullets on air and dispersed the crows.
Around 26 May 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Maweni, within Nyali (Nyali, Mombasa) against alleged grabbing of their land. The group demanded the government to help address the matter.

On 26 May 2023, parents and community members at Khasoko boys high school protested at the institution in Khasoko (Bumula, Bungoma) against poor management, following the death of a student. The group demanded the teachers service commission (TSC) to transfer the principal as well as the constituency development fund to build more classrooms blocks and dormitories to accommodate the increasing number of students.

On 27 May 2023, former TPLF fighters held a protest in Abiy Adi, Tanqua Melashe woreda (Central Tigray, Tigray) and demonstrated their discontent about lack of food and medication. TPLF detained the protest organizers in the military prison after accusing them of leading a strike and defaming the TPLF leaders.

On 27 May 2023, students from unregistered private school gathered in front of the Ministry of Education in Mogadishu - Wadajir (Banadir) to protest against the Ministry of Education's decision not to include their institution in final exams. Local security forces have responded to the situation (means not specified) and dispersed the protesters.
On 27 May 2023, residents gathered in front of the Ministry of Education in Mogadishu - Wadajir (Banadir) in a demonstration over procedures relating to exams.

On 27 May 2023, residents and mourners blocked the Meru-Maua highway with a casket near Maili Tatu market (coded as Maua, Igembe South, Meru) against increased insecurity, following a recent incident where a man was stabbed to death by unknown people.

On 27 May 2023, residents disrupted a funeral service by scolding at county senator in Navakholo (Navakholo, Kakamega) against the utterances he had made supporting the proposed finance bill. The senator had to cut short his speech.

On 29 May 2023, boda boda taxi operators blocked the Kawalathe bridge (using unspecified means) in Lodwar (Turkana Central, Turkana) against the killing of three colleagues by a Nyangtom assailant and other unidentified people (coded separately).

On 29 May 2023, residents led by A Voice of Mombasa, a lobby group, protested in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against delay in doctors and county workers salaries. The group demanded the governor to address the matter.

On 29 May 2023, Siaya governor supporters (ODM, Azimio) camped at the assembly premises in Siaya (Alego Usonga, Siaya) in support of the impeachment of the deputy governor by the members of the county assembly (MCAs).

On 29 May 2023, supporters of a former Mungiki leader protested in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against the arraignment of the former leader in court. Police lobbed teargas canisters to disperse the group.

On 29 May 2023, a group of street children carried a body of a street child and dumped it at the gate to Uasin Gishu county headquarters in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the murder allegedly by the county askaris (coded separately). Presumed county askaris (county inspectorate officers) intervened and dispersed the group (using unspecified means).

On 29 May 2023, medical interns protested outside the ministry of health offices in Nairobi (Nairobi - Westlands) against delayed pay as well as delayed posting. Joined by the KMPDU officials, the group demanded the ministry officials to address the matter.

On 29 May 2023, Nairobi county workers under the Kenya county government workers union (KCGWU) protested outside the city hall in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against the delay by the county to sign and register the collective bargaining agreement after completion of negotiations. Joined by the Sonko rescue team, the group demanded the governor to address their grievances.

On 29 May 2023, public Servants drawn from KNUT, KUSU, UASU, KMPDU, and Kudheiha, among others, assembled at the university of Nairobi chancellor's court before marching to the National assembly buildings in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against over taxation in the proposed finance bill.

On 30 May 2023, hundreds of parents protested at St James primary school Mgange (Mwatate, Taita Taveta) against poor management by the school head teacher. The group demanded the ministry of education officials to help address the matter.

On 30 May 2023, Puntland Darawish Soldiers protested and blocked vehicular access to the main entrance of the seaport (through unspecified means) for about one hour in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari). They demanded the payment of late six month salaries.

Around 30 May 2023 (as reported), civil servants in Misrak Badawacho woreda held a rally in their administrative town, Shone Town, Shone (Hadiya, SNNP) to condemn the government of delaying their salary payments for three consecutive months. SNNP regional state police arrested 40 protesters.

On 30 May 2023, a group of NUP councillors protested against the passing of the district budget at the district headquarters in Wakiso (Wakiso, Wakiso). They accused the district speaker of taking a bribe to pass the budget without their approval.

On 30 May 2023, and for the second day, tens of Nairobi county workers under the Kenya county government workers union (KCGWU) protested outside the city hall in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against the delay by the county to sign and register the collective bargaining agreement after completion of negotiations. The group demanded the governor to address their grievances.

On 31 May 2023, Puntland presidential security forces protested and blocked the road that connects the State House, uphill Ministerial buildings, and UN compounds through armored vehicles and stone road blockers means in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal). They demanded their monthly salaries.

On 31 May 2023, Kimugandura residents protested in Nanyuki town (Laikipia East, Laikipia) against the alleged unfair recruitment of a new chief. The group demanded the government to undertake afresh recruitment exercise.

On 31 May 2023, farmers staged a rally in front of the Amhara regional administration and agricultural offices in Bahir Dar town, Bahir Dar (West Gojam, Amhara), and condemned lack of willingness by local authorities to address their fertilizer needs and 'selling their quotas to private traders'. The farmers hanged whips on their shoulder to show that 'their farms are missing to sow the seeds in the planting season' due to the luck of fertilizer.

On 31 May 2023, residents protested by blocking the Igare-Nyacheki road with banana stems, as they marched from Matierio to Igare (Bobasi, Kisii) against the poor state of the road. The group demanded their area member of parliament (MP) to address the matter.

On 31 May 2023, Matatu operators protested in Naivasha (Naivasha, Nakuru) against over alleged interference of their business by members of the county assembly from Nakuru county. The group demanded the national government to help address the matter.

On 1 June 2023, a group of cleaners demonstrated the end of their contracts with UNHCR without prior notice in Odugonga (Aringa, Yumbe). The demonstrators blocked the road with stones, logs, and ladders and prevented anyone from accessing the offices. The police and local authorities spoke to the demonstrators and they removed the roadblocks.

On 1 June 2023, maize traders marched to the Customs office in Namanga (Longido, Arusha) on the border between Tanzania and Kenya as their cargo of maize was stopped at the border for unknown reasons.

On 1 June 2023, a group od of 10 Hirshabelle police forces protested over six unpaid months of salaries and blocked the roads through armored vehicles and stone road blockers means in Bulo Burto town (Bulo Burto, Hiraan).
Around 1 June 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi) against grabbing of riparian land. The group demanded the county and national governments to address the matter.

On 2 June 2023, following a Friday prayer, Muslims in Jimma town gathered in Fethi Mosque in Jima (Jimma, Oromia) and condemned what they say is 'the killings of Muslim protesters' in Addis Ababa (coded separately) and the demolition of mosques by the government in the newly formed Sheger city. Members of federal police and Oromia regional state police beat protesters, fired tear gas and live bullets and severely wounded two people. There were no fatalities. Hundreds were also arrested rounded up and detained in Jimma town police station.

On 2 June 2023, following a Friday prayer, Muslims in Harar gathered in their mosque in Harari, Abadir (Harari, Harari) and condemned what they say is 'the killings of Muslim protesters by the government forces' in Addis Ababa (coded separately) and the demolition of mosques by the government in the newly formed Sheger city. No further information is available.

On 2 June 2023, following a Friday prayer, Muslims in Robe Town gathered in their mosque in Robe (Bale, Oromia) and rallied to condemn what they say is 'the killings of Muslim protesters by the government forces' in Addis Ababa (coded separately) and the demolition of mosques by the government in the newly formed Sheger city. No further information is available.

On 2 June 2023, following a Friday prayer, Muslims in Shashemene town gathered in their mosque in Shashamane (West Arsi, Oromia) and condemned what they say is 'the killings of Muslim protesters by the government forces' in Addis Ababa (coded separately) and the demolition of mosques by the government in the newly formed Sheger city. No further information is available.

On 2 June 2023, coffee farmers protested in Nyakoe (Bonchari, Kisii) against the alleged mismanagement of the local coffee factory. The group demanded both the county and National government to help address the matter.

On 2 June 2023, following a Friday prayer, Muslims in Addis Ababa gathered at Grand Anwar Mosque in Addis Ketema, Addis Ketema (Region 14, Addis Ababa) and rallied to condemn the 'killings of Muslims by the government forces during the previous protests (coded separately) and the demolition of mosques by the government in the newly formed Sheger city. The protesters were saying 'Allahu Akbar' and echoed slogans, 'city development that demolishes Mosques, not a development'. Republican Guards, Federal Police, and Addis Ababa city police rounded up the mosque compound, blocked the gate, fired tear gas and live bullets at the crowd, killed 3 and wounded unknown number of protesters. Several were trapped in the mosques until the EIASC discussed with the Federal Police commission to allow those injured get treatments and others to safely go home. Addis Ababa police commission claimed that around 63 police officers and 'supporters' were also injured.

On 2 June 2023, a group of about three hundred sugar cane farmers protested at the Sugar and Allied Industries Limited (SAIL) company in Kaliro (Bulamogi, Kaliro), to demand for the payment of 1.5 billion Ugandan shillings which the company owes them. The police intervened, fired live bullets and teargas to disperse the protesters. The police arrested three protesters whom they later released. There were no casualties.

On 3 June 2023, public service vehicle (matatu) drivers plying the Kenyatta-Gatundu road protested in Gatundu (Gatundu South, Kiambu) against the alleged harassment and extortion by traffic police officers. The group demanded the relevant authorities to address the matter.
On 4 June 2023, protestors asked the government to answer their question of Amhara identity and release the budget in Adebay town (Kafta Humera, Western Tigray, Tigray).
On 4 June 2023, protestors asked the government to answer their question of Amhara identity and release the budget in Korarit town (Western Tigray, Tigray).
On 4 June 2023, protestors asked the government to answer their question of Amhara identity and release the budget in Makisegno Gebeya town in Tsegede Woreda (Western Tigray, Tigray).
On 4 June 2023, protestors asked the government to answer their question of Amhara identity and release the budget in Tsegede town (Western Tigray, Tigray).
On 4 June 2023, protestors asked the government to answer their question of Amhara identity and release the budget in Wef Argif (Welkait, Western Tigray, Tigray).
On 4 June 2023, protestors asked the government to answer their question of Amhara identity and release the budget in Welkait town (Kafta Humera, Western Tigray, Tigray).

On 4 June 2023, protestors asked the government to answer their question of Amhara identity and release the budget in Betemulu and Biaker towns (locations not found, coded at Welkait town, Kafta Humera, Western Tigray, Tigray).

On 4 June 2023, armed militias from Majeerteen clan blocked the roads leading to mayor's office (through unspecified means) in Burtinle town (Burtinle, Nugaal). The clan militias were against the local elections after missing their MP in Burtinle council.

On 4 June 2023, tens of thousands staged a protest rally in Adi Remets, Welkait woreda (Western Tigray, Tigray), to demand the federal government formally recognize their town as part of the Amhara regional state and release annual budget. Welkait in Western Tigray and Raya in Western Tigray have been contested between Amhara and Tigray regional states. The Tigray regional government said the people in this protest are 'those who were recently resettled by Amhara regional states and forcefully mobilized'.

On 4 June 2023, tens of thousands staged a protest rally in Dansha town, Dansha (Western Tigray, Tigray), to demand the federal government formally recognize their town as part of the Amhara regional state and release annual budget. Welkait in Western Tigray and Raya in Western Tigray have been contested between Amhara and Tigray regional states. The Tigray regional government said the people in this protest are 'those who were recently resettled by Amhara regional states and forcefully mobilized'.

On 4 June 2023, tens of thousands staged a protest rally in Humera, Setit Humera (Western Tigray, Tigray), to demand the federal government formally recognize their town as part of the Amhara regional state and release annual budget. Welkait in Western Tigray and Raya in Western Tigray have been contested between Amhara and Tigray regional states. The Tigray regional government said the people in this protest are 'those who were recently resettled by Amhara regional states and forcefully mobilized'.

On 4 June 2023, tens of thousands staged a protest rally in May Cadera, May Kadra woreda (Western Tigray, Tigray), to demand the federal government formally recognize their town as part of the Amhara regional state and release annual budget. Welkait in Western Tigray and Raya in Western Tigray have been contested between Amhara and Tigray regional states. The Tigray regional government said the people in this protest are 'those who were recently resettled by Amhara regional states and forcefully mobilized'.
On 5 June 2023, hundreds of former TPLF/TDF fighters held a demonstration in Mekele (Mekelle Tigray, Tigray) over a lack of medical care and food, demanding to be provided with basic services.

Around 5 June 2023 (as reported), parents at Mwangani primary school protested at the institution in Mwangani (Magarini, Kilifi) against the poor state of the classrooms as well as lack of toilets. The group demanded their area political leaders to address the matter.

On 5 June 2023, a group of parents protested at Isyukoni mixed day and boarding secondary school (Kathiani, Machakos) against poor management. It is not clear what were the groups demands. The school was closed until further notice.

Around 5 June 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Moyale (Moyale, Marsabit) against alleged invasion of community land by illegal miners as well as insecurity. Led by the village spokesman, the group demanded the government to address the matter.

On 5 June 2023, a group of parents protested at Dagoretti high school (Dagoretti South, Nairobi) against fee discrepancies as well lack of progress in the construction of a dormitory. The group demanded headmaster to address the matter.
On 5 June 2023, former county assembly staff workers protested in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against unpaid gratuity. The group demanded the county leadership to pay their gratuity.

On 6 June 2023, residents protested the government's decision to establish the East Borena zone in Shakiso town and other unidentified areas (coded at Shakiso, Guji, Oromia). The group stated that they could not receive essential services since the government had dismantled the old zones to establish the new zone and demanded the government to re-establish the dismantled zones. They also protested the chemicals released by MEDROC Gold mining company which is affecting the surrounding community's health. The demonstration continued the next day (coded separately). At least eight people were injured. It is not clear how they were injured. However, it is assumed that security forces injured them in an attempt to disperse the protestors.
On 6 June 2023, government security forces (SNA) protested by blocking Fagah intersection (through unspecified means) over unpaid salaries in Mogadishu - Yaqshid (Banadir).

On 6 June 2023, hundreds of youth protested in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against some sections of the finance bill, such as the requirement that all salaried employees pay a 3% housing levy. Police intervened and lobbed tear gas to disperse the group. Several protesters were arrested during the incident.

On 7 June 2023, residents continued to protest the government's decision to establish the East Borena zone in Shakiso town and other unidentified areas (coded at Shakiso, Guji, Oromia). The protestors stated that they could not receive essential services since the government had dismantled the old zones to establish the new zone, demanding the government to re-establish the dismantled zones. They also protested the chemicals released by MEDROC Gold mining company which is affecting the surrounding community's health. The demonstration began on 6 June 2023 (coded separately). At least eight people were injured. It is not clear how they were injured. However, it is assumed that security forces injured them in an attempt to disperse the protestors.

On 7 June 2023, pensioners in Mekelle town held a rally in Mekele (Mekelle Tigray, Tigray) to demand their retirement benefits, which have been withheld for nearly two years. Tigray regional interim government responded saying 'it is discussing with federal government to facilitate their payments'.

On 7 June 2023, over 900 truck drivers and clearing agents blocked the road connecting Kenya and Tanzania with more than 500 (other sources mention at least 200) trucks of maize at the Namanga border point (Kajiado Central, Kajiado) against the move by Tanzania authorities to bar their lorries from re-entering Kenya. The group demanded the government to ensure a seamless cross border trade.

On 7 June 2023, a group of market vendors protested against the lack of electricity in their workplace in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala). The vendors endured two days without electricity, prompting them to take action. They also voiced their opposition to the requirement of paying 800,000 Ugx in order to have their electricity restored. According to the authorities, the electricity was disconnected due to the vendors' alleged illegal usage.

On 7 June 2023, a group of pre-medical interns protested against their delayed deployment in front of the ministry of public health in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala). The protesters started their march in Mulago at Makerere university (Kampala) and proceeded to the ministry of health with police intercepting them along the way and arresting some.

On 7 June 2023, a former parliamentary aspirant (ANC, Kenya Kwanza), and his supporters, forced their way into Malinya police station (Ikolomani, Kakamega) in a demonstration against his arrest during last year's elections and to demand the cash bail, a motorbike and 1.6 million Kenya shillings that was lost during the incident.

On 7 June 2023, residents protested in Kashani area of Bamburi (Kisauni, Mombasa) against alleged land grabbing by a private developer. Joined by the member of county assembly (ODM, Azimio), the group demanded the government to address the matter.

On 7 June 2023, a group of parents protested at Kipchemwon primary school (Aldai, Nandi) against the transfer of teachers from the school by the teachers service commission (TSC). The group demanded TSC to rescind the move.

On 7 June 2023, a group of traders under the Chamber of Commerce and Industry protested in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against the suspension of the associations elections. The group demanded politicians from both Kenya kwanza and Azimio to stop interfering in the election and causing the division.

On 8 June 2023, residents of Gora Dola woreda gathered in Wadera (Guji, Oromia) and held a rally to oppose the government decision to re-structure their local administration. The protesters specially opposed the inclusion of Negele Borena to a newly formed 'East Borena' administrative zone.

On 8 June 2023, thousands of bar owners protested in Muranga town (Kiharu, Muranga) against alleged unfair vetting and licensing of bars by the county government. Led by bar hotel and liquor traders association chairman, the group demanded the process repeated.

On 9 June 2023, members of Turkana community living in Isiolo county protested at an undisclosed location within the county (coded to the county headquarters as Isiolo, Isiolo, Isiolo) against alleged derogatory remarks made by the chief excusive officer of Northlands rangelands trust against the community. The group demanded the officer to resign as well as the national cohesion and integration commission (NCIC) to interrogate the officer.

On 9 June 2023, boda boda taxi operators protested in Embu town (Manyatta, Embu) against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of their colleague by thugs. Led by the chairman of Kaa Ngumu boda boda association, the group demanded the police to enhance patrols at night.

On 11 June 2023, Wachamo University students staged a rally in their campus, blocked roads with stones and broken down chairs and tables in Hosaena town, Hosaena (Hadiya, SNNP), to oppose the government's new mandatory exit exam policy for all students graduating from Universities. Federal and SNNP regional state police forces entered the university campus, beat, and arrested an unknown number of students. There were no fatalities.

Around 12 June 2023 (as reported), thousands of residents led by area senator (ODM, Azimio) protested in Nyamira (Nyamira, Nyamira) against increased cost of living as well as the proposed finance bill that seeks to increase taxes.

Around 12 June 2023 (as reported), residents blocked the Mombasa-Malindi road (using unspecified means) in Shanzu (Kilifi South, Kilifi) against unfair distribution of job opportunities in the construction of the road. Joined by the area member of county assembly (ODM, Azimio), the group demanded for the jobs in the road construction. It is unclear whether the police dispersed the group.

Around 12 June 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Aterait (Teso South. Busia) against alleged police harassment. Joined by the area member of parliament (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded the ministry of internal security to help address the matter.

On 12 June 2023, about 40 mira/khat sellers protested in front of the ministerial building and blocked the road along the Argo Junction area in Kismayo town (Kismaayo, Lower Juba) in a demonstration against recent policies.

On 12 June 2023, youths blocked the main high way road (means unknown) connecting Bahir Dar to Addis Ababa in Finote Selam town (West Gojam, Amhara) to denounce what they say is 'the government's intervention in their religious affairs' and the entry of ENDF in their town. A police officer (coded as Amhara police) opened gun fire on the crowds, resulting in 1 protester getting killed and over 8 people wounded. ENDF did not enter Finote Selam.

On 12 June 2023, youths blocked the main highway road connecting Bahir Dar to the Addis Ababa (means unknown) in Jiga town, Jabi Tehnan woreda (West Gojam, Amhara), to denounce what they say is 'the government's intervention in their religious affairs' and the entry of ENDF in their town. No further information is available.

On 12 June 2023, residents protested in Voi town (Voi, Taita Taveta) against the government's move to increase taxes through the proposed finance bill. Joined by the county senator (ODM, Azimio), the group demanded the members of parliament to vote against the bill.

On 12 June 2023, tuk tuk taxi operators protested in Kisumu city (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the move by the county government to relocate their station. The group demanded the city manager to address the matter.

On 13 June 2023, residents protested in Malambisia market in Butula sub-county (coded to sub county headquarter as Butula, Butula, Busia) against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of a boda boda taxi operator who doubled up as a security guard at a filling station by unknown people. The group demanded a new police post is established in the area for enhanced police patrol.

On 13 June 2023, a group protested in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the President's proposed finance bill. Running battles ensued as police intervened and arrested some of the protesters. After the arrest, the group attempted to force their way into a police station located around the parliament buildings, demanding their colleague release. It is unclear whether the police dispersed the group.

On 13 June 2023, residents of Kanyenyaini ward, led by women parliamentarians under the banner of Kenya women parliamentary association (KEWOPA) protested outside the Murang'a county Assembly (Muranga, Kiharu, Muranga) against the move by the speaker of the county assembly to suspend Kanyenyaini member of county assembly from attending assembly sittings for four months. The group demanded the speaker to rescind the move.

Around 14 June 2023 (as reported), residents led by MUHURI-Muslim group protested in Kadzonzo (Kaloleni, Kilifi) against the killing of a 21-year-old businessman. The group demanded justice for the slain businessman.

Around 15 June 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Mutha (Kitui South, Kitui) against invasion of their farms by over 70 elephants. The group demanded the Kenya wildlife service to restrain the Elephants in the Tsavo game reserve.

Around 15 June 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Kashani area of Bamburi (Kisauni, Mombasa) against eviction threats by private developers. The group demanded the county and national government to address the matter by issuing title deeds to the residents.

Around 15 June 2023 (as reported), employees at Muruny - Siyoi water project protested in Karas (Kapenguria, West Pokot) against delayed pay. The group demanded area leaders to help address the matter.

On 15 June 2023, Macawisley clan militia protested and blocked roads (through unspecified means) in and around in Belet Weyne town (Belet Weyne, Hiraan). The clan militias accused Hirshabele leaders of failing to provide their rights.

Around 16 June 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Lokitaung trading Centre (Turkana North, Turkana) against the move by the teachers service commission (TSC) to revoke the transfer of two long serving teachers. The group demanded TSC to execute its duties without political interference.

Around 16 June 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Kaeris trading Centre (Turkana North, Turkana) against the move by the teachers service commission (TSC) to revoke the transfer of two long serving teachers. The group demanded TSC to execute its duties without political interference.

On 16 June 2023, a group closed roads (by unspecified means) connecting Awash Arba to Dire Dawa, Harar, and Adama in Awash Arba town (Awash town, Gabi-Zone 3, Afar) in demonstration against the killing of an Afar region police officer by a member of ENDF which sparked a clash between members of ENDF and police officers (coded separately).

On 16 June 2023, hundreds of residents protested against the federal government and Jubaland leader Ahmed Madobe over the political instability of the Gedo Region in Cabudwaaq town (Cabudwaaq, Galgaduud).

Around 16 June 2023 (as reported), 3000 employees of the Nairobi water sewerage company (NWSC) protested outside the county assembly in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against a new bill that seeks to change the company to be under the county executive. Led by the secretary-general of the Kenya union of water and sewerage employees (Kuwase), the group demanded NWSC to retain its semi-autonomous status devoid of political interference.

On 17 June 2023, residents and over 1000 pupils of Motony primary school protested in Enelerai (Narok West, Narok) against laxity and delay in justice by local administrators in addressing a land dispute with a private developer. Led by area local leaders, the group demanded both the national and county government to help address the matter.

On 17 June 2023, hundreds of disabled people whose business center had been demolished by government security forces closed a road in front of Simen Hotel in Arada K/K Addis Ababa (Region 14). Protesters denounced security forces, which had interrupted and stopped the press statement of one of their of representatives at the hotel. The disabled people called for a press briefing to indicate their intentions to hold a peaceful protest against the demolition of their business center in Keremela Factory area in Woreda 8 in Addis Ketema K/K in Addis Ababa. Security forces arrested the manager of the hotel. No further information on why the manager was arrested.
On 17 June 2023, hundreds of residents protested over the eviction and destruction of their shelters at Ex control Afgooye in Mogadishu - Hodan (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle).

On 18 June 2023, residents of staged a protest rally in May Tsebri town, May Tsemre, (North Western Tigray, Tigray), to demand the federal government to formally recognize their town as part of the Amhara regional state and release the annual budget. Some protesters raised banners that read, 'let our identity be respected' and 'we are ethnic Amhara'. Areas in North Western Tigray and Southern Tigray have been contested between Amhara and Tigray regional states.

On 18 June 2023, residents of staged a protest rally in Dima town, Dima woreda, (North Western Tigray, Tigray), to demand the federal government to formally recognize their town as part of the Amhara regional state and release the annual budget. Some protesters raised banners that read, 'let our identity be respected' and 'we are ethnic Amhara'. Areas in North Western Tigray and Southern Tigray have been contested between Amhara and Tigray regional states.

On 18 June 2023, Hawadle clan militia and local residents protested over the firing of the Hiiraan governor and blocked the roads through armored vehicles and stone road blockers in Belet Weyne town (Belet Weyne, Hiraan). Demonstrations also happened in Halgan, Bulo Burto, and Ceel Gaal village (coded separately).

On 18 June 2023, local residents from the Hawadle clan protested over the firing of the Hiiraan governor in Bulo Burto town (Bulo Burto, Hiraan), Belet Weyne town, Ceel Gaal, and Halgan village (coded separately).

On 18 June 2023, local residents from the Hawadle clan protested over the firing of the Hiiraan governor in Ceel Gaal village (Belet Weyne, Hiraan), Belet Weyne town, Bulo Burto, and Halgan village (coded separately).

On 18 June 2023, local residents from the Hawadle clan protested over the firing of the Hiiraan governor in Halgan village (Bulo Burto, Hiraan), Belet Weyne town, Bulo Burto, and Ceel Gaal village (coded separately).

Around 19 June 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Narok (Narok North, Narok) against alleged grabbing of 120-acre public utilities land. The group demanded the government to address the matter.

Around 19 June 2023 (as reported), hundreds of residents protested in Kaptebee (Turbo, Uasin Gishu) against alleged police laxity following the beheading of a woman by her companion. The group demanded the head of the woman before burial.

On 19 June 2023, residents of Amanuel town blocked the highway (means unspecified) linking Debre Markos town with Dembecha town at Amanuel, Michakel woreda (East Gojam, Amhara) to demand that the government deliver on its responsibility to protect civilians and mobilize its forces to release abducted truck drivers. Drivers had been abducted on 17 June by OLF Shane (coded separately). Amhara regional state police fired live bullets to disperse the crowds, killing 1 and wounding four demonstrators.

On 19 June 2023, Westlands traders protested outside the governor's office in Nairobi (Nairobi - Starehe) against the demolition of their businesses. The group demanded the governor to address the matter.

On 19 June 2023, a group of people gathered in demonstration in Dar es Salaam (Ilala, Dar es Salaam) to protest against a port operation agreement between Tanzania and a firm in Dubai called DP World but were dispersed by police officers who arrested 11 of them.

On 19 June 2023, farmers of West Gojam zone gathered in front of the Amhara regional administration and agricultural offices and staged a rally in Bahir Dar town, Bahir Dar (West Gojam, Amhara), condemning the lack of local authorities response to address their fertilizer needs and of 'diverting their quotas to private traders'. The farmers weaved flags and hanged whips on their shoulder to show that 'their farms are missing to sow the seeds in the planting season' due to the lack of fertilizer. The regional government authorities said 'they are waiting for the delivery of fertilizers being transported from the port of Djibouti'.
On 19 June 2023, residents staged a protest over ATMIS UPDF shelling and killing of civilians in Golweyn village (Marka, Lower Shabelle).

On 20 June 2023, residents protested in Maji Mazuri area of Mogotio (Mogotio, Baringo) against the proposal by the agriculture cabinet secretary to re-open a donkey slaughterhouse in area, arguing that the slaughterhouse will disadvantage them, as they use the animal for transportation.
On 20 June 2023, a group of journalists protested against acts of brutality against them at the Human Rights Commission Office in Soroti (Soroti, Soroti).

On 20 June 2023, Puntland security forces opposing the local elections protested and blocked major roads (through unspecified means) in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal). The motive was to prevent the State Assembly from convening.

On 20 June 2023, a group of youth protested by blocking the Nairobi-Mombasa highway (using unspecified means) at Mto wa Mawe bridge area in Athi River (Athi River, Machakos) against the demolitions of structures on the East African portland cement company's land. Police intervened (through unspecified means) and dispersed the group.

Around 21 June 2023 (as reported), St Athanas Kisaiwa mixed secondary students protested in Kissaiwa (Saboti, trans Nzoia) against alleged poor management. The group demanded the school principal transferred.

On 21 June 2023, residents of Alamata town staged a rally in Alamata town, Alamata (Southern Tigray, Tigray), to demand the federal government to formally recognize their town as part of the Amhara regional state and release the annual budget. Some protesters raised banners that read, 'we did not say let's be Amhara, we are ethnic Amhara'. Areas in North Western Tigray and Southern Tigray have been contested between Amhara and Tigray regional states.

On 21 June 2023, a group of medical interns protested against their delayed deployment in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala). Police intercepted them and only allowed a few of them to continue marching to parliament.

On 21 June 2023, a group of donkey owners in Bondo sub-county protested along the Migwena-Gombe road (coded to the sub-county headquarters as Bondo, Bondo, Siaya) against the plan for reopening of slaughterhouses by the ministry of agriculture. The group demanded the cabinet secretary to rescind the plan.

On 21 June 2023, Law society of Kenya (LSK) Nairobi branch members protested in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against alleged harassment by the executive through the police. The group demanded both the executive and the police to stop the harassment.

On 21 June 2023, hundreds of residents, led by a traditional healer, protested in Andula village near Maua (Igembe South, Maua) against the killing of a man by a chief and her assistant (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the victim.

On 22 June 2023, residents of Delanta woreda staged a rally in Wegeltena town (South Wello, Amhara) to condemn 'sexual violence by ENDF soldiers'. The protesters demanded justice for 'an eight-years-old girl victim of rape by government soldiers' in their district (coded separately) and asked ENDF to 'leave their town'.

On 22 June 2023, miners protested in Kishushe town (Wundanyi, Taita, Taveta) against the move by the government to suspend quartz mining activities in the area following rivalry claims over the mining zones. The group demanded the cabinet secretary for mining to help address the matter.

On 22 June 2023, illegal land grabbers blocked an unspecified road with tree branches and rocks in Kandara (Kandara, Muranga) in demonstration against the move by the county government to demarcate 1,400 acres land ceded by Del Monte company. The group demanded their share of the land. It is unclear whether the police dispersed the group.

On 22 June 2023, over 700 private security guards protested in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) against the move by the county government to dismiss them from work. The group demanded the governor to reinstate them.

On 23 June 2023, residents marched before attempting to force their way into a land selling company's office in Thika town (Thika Town, Kiambu) against alleged fraud claims by the company. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 24 June 2023, the first day of a two-day protest, a group of students protested in Nyabikoni (Ndorwa, Kabale) against mismanagement and ill treatment from the school administration. The anti-riot police were later deployed at the school to prevent further escalation.

On 25 June 2023, a group of mourners protested against the former minister addressing them at the burial of their mayor in Kitimbwa (Bbaale, Uganda). The SFC Guards (police officers) who guard the minister, beat the protesters and shot in the air to disperse them.

Around 25 June 2023 (as reported), hundreds of protested in Moiben Kuserwo near Tunyo (Marakwert West, Elgeyo Marakwet) against alleged highhandedness of the Eldoret water and sanitation company chief executive officer (CEO). The group demanded the immediate removal of the CEO.

On 25 June 2023, the second day of a two-day protest, a group of students protested in Nyabikoni (Ndorwa, Kabale) against mismanagement and ill treatment from the school administration. The anti-riot police were deployed at the school to prevent further escalation.
On 25 June 2023, residents staged a protest against the Puntland Maritime Police Force trained by the United Arab Emirates over its participation in conflict in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal).

On 26 June 2023, miners protested (for the second week) in Kishushe town (Wundanyi, Taita, Taveta) against the move by the government to suspend quartz mining activities in the area following rivalry claims over the mining zones. The group demanded the cabinet secretary for mining to help address the matter.

On 28 June 2023, over 500 health workers protested at the Nakuru county referral and teaching hospital in Nakuru city (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against unfair dismissal as well as corruption in the recruitment procedure. The group demanded the governor to keep her election pledge of employing the workers permanently.

On 28 June 2023, hundreds of residents protested by forcing their way into Githiga police station (Githunguri, Kiambu) against alleged sexually assaulted a form 3 student by the officer commanding station (coded separately). Led by the area member of parliament (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded justice for the minor as well as the transfer of all police officers from the station.
On 28 June 2023, milk farmers protested in Kabiyet (Mosop, Nandi) against reduced milk prices as well as delayed pay. The group demanded the government to help address the issues.

On 29 June 2023, over 400 residents from Machakos and Kitui counties marched from Kitui to Kithyoko (Masinga, Machakos) against the planned reopening of the donkey abattoir. The group demanded that the leadership at both county and national government levels ensures that the abattoir is not opened.

On 29 June 2023, public service vehicle (matatu) operators and drivers protested Bissil (Kajiado Central, Kajiado) against increased road accidents along Nairobi-Namanga road especially caused by lorries coming from Tanzania. The operators demanded the police to take action against those breaking traffic rules.

On 29 June 2023, commercial and public service vehicle drivers protested in Busia (Matayos, Busia) against the move by the national transport and safety authority (NTSA) to re-test and charge drivers. Led by the chairpersons of long-distance driver's and conductors association (LODDCA) and the Kenya diver's association (KDA), the group demanded the government to halt the NTSA process and call for dialogue.
On 29 June 2023, 4 councilors protested against the non-payment of their allowance in Lira (Lira, Lira). They locked the district offices, until police intervened and arrested them.

Around 29 June 2023 (as reported), residents protested in Nambale (Nambale, Busia) against the alleged discharge of waste by Nambale secondary school into the nearby river. The group demanded the ministry of health officials together with other concerned auth to help address the matter.

Around 29 June 2023 (as reported), Ngong residents (other sources mention upper Matasia) including boda boda taxi operators blocked the Maasai-Silanga road with stones in Ngong (Kajiado North, Kajiado) in demonstration against the poor state of the road. The group demanded county government to address the matter.

On 29 June 2023, about 250 employees of Malindi water and sewerage company protested by blocking the entrance to the company's offices using trucks before gathering outside the compound in Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi) against late disbursement of salaries and poor management. Police fired in the air and lobbed teargas to disperse the group. One of the employees sustained injuries after being hit by a teargas canister.

On 30 June 2023, farmers of Sodo woreda staged a protest rally in Bue town (Guraghe, SNNP), to demand the government to timely provide fertilizers. The protesters condemned that fertilizers are now being sold at high price in the hands of private traders and some quintals are being held in government stores while the sowing season is passing them.

On 30 June 2023, members of the law society of Kenya (LSK) from southwest branch marched and gathered outside the land registrar's office in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against the move by the registrar to accuse them of forging records as well as declining to receive their petition. The group demanded that the registrar to follow the law in service delivery.

On 30 June 2023, residents, joined by two members of county assembly (MCAs) (Wiper, Azimio; Independent) protested by blocking the Mombasa highway (using unspecified means) in Mtito Andei (Kibwezi East, Makueni) against increased human-wildlife conflict in the area. Police intervened and arrested the two MCAs.

On 30 June 2023, over 600 residents of Ugatuzi protested in Kiembeni (coded to the nearest known location as Kisauni, Kisauni, Mombasa) against the planned move by a private developer to evict them from their 100-acre piece of land, following a land dispute. The group demanded the government to help address the matter.

On 3 July 2023, thousands of Protestant religion followers staged a protest rally in Hawasa town (Sidama, Sidama) to condemn what they say is 'same-sex marriage and abortion'. The protest rally was organized by Protestant churches in Hawasa.
On 3 July 2023, ACK chief Makau secondary school parents protested in Mutomo Kitui (Kitui South, Kitui) against poor management. The group demanded the headteacher transferred.

On 4 July 2023, residents blocked the Kenol-Mariwa road with stones (coded as Kenol, Muranga South, Muranga) in demonstration against delayed disbursement of their compensation by the government, following the road construction. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 4 July 2023, hundreds of tuk tuk taxi operators protested in Thika (Thika town, Kiambu) against harassment by their boda boda counterparts and other organized gangs. Led by their chairman, the group demanded the government to increase patrols, and provide better working conditions for the operators.

On 5 July 2023, a group of residents protested at the police post in Kasambira (Buzaaya, Kamuli), against the sudden mysterious death of an 18-year-old young man inside the police cell. Police intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the protesters.

On 5 July 2023, more than a hundred Kenya power and lighting company workers protested in Kitengela (Kajiado East, Kajiado) against alleged assault by Kitui East member of parliament on one of their colleague who was seeking to disconnect an illegal power line. Led by their union leaders, the group demanded justice for their colleague.

On 5 July 2023, more than 200 residents of Muhuji Estate protested in Dodoma (Dodoma Urban, Dodoma) against the move by the city authorities to demolish their houses, following a land ownership dispute. The group demanded that their grievances be addressed.

On 6 July 2023, a group of women protested in Limuru (Limuru, Kiambu) against alleged mistreatment of female workers at Brown's cheese limited company following a shaming incident within the company premises.

On 6 July 2023, a group of lawyers protested in Kisii town (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against the changes effected at the regional lands office. The police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 6 July 2023, health workers union officials sang solidarity songs in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against the move by the county government to dismiss a section of health workers. The group demanded the dismissed workers to be reinstated.
On 6 July 2023, residents protested in Nene village near Kinangop (Kinangop, Nyandarua) against the poor state of road in the area. The group demanded the governor to help address the matter.

On 7 July 2023, Azimio supporters led by their leaders gathered along Kisumu Nairobi highway before marching towards Nyamasaria (Kisumu East, Kisumu) against the high cost of living as well as new tax measures set by the government. The group demanded the government to lower the cost of living.

On 7 July 2023, Azimio supporters protested in Rangwe (Rangwe, Homa Bay) against the high cost of living as well as new tax measures set by the government. The group demanded that the government lower the cost of living.

On 7 July 2023, Azimio supporters and human rights defenders protested in Lodwar (Turkana Central, Turkana) against the high cost of living as well as new tax measures set by the government. Police intervened and arrested three protestors (other sources mention several).

On 7 July 2023, Azimio supporters protested in Obunga slums (Kisumu West, Kisumu) against the high cost of living as well as new tax measures set by the government. Police used live bullets to disperse the group. One person was shot dead during the incident.

On 7 July 2023, Azimio supporters gathered in Jacaranda grounds in Embakasi (Embakasi South, Nairobi) against the high cost of living as well as new tax measures set by the government. The group demanded the government to lower the cost of living.

On 7 July 2023, Azimio supporters protested in Luanda (Emuhaya, Vihiga) against the high cost of living as well as new tax measures set by the government. Led by Azimio leaders from ODM and DAP, the group demanded the government to lower the cost of living.

On 7 July 2023, Azimio supporters protested in Nyahururu (Laikipia West, Laikipia) against the high cost of living as well as new tax measures set by the government. Police intervened and arrested some of the protestors, including the immediate former governor.

On 7 July 2023, more than 300 parents, along with their children, protested in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against alleged fraud in the Finland education program ran by the county government. The group demanded the president to help address the matter as well as refund of their money.

On 7 July 2023, Azimio supporters protested in Embu town (Manyatta, Embu) against the high cost of living as well as new tax measures set by the government. The group demanded the government to lower the cost of living.

Police intervened using live bullets, teargas and water cannons to disperse the group. Several vehicles belonging to Azimio leaders were vandalized and Police arrested more than 73 people (other sources mention 35, others 70)

On 7 July 2023, Azimio supporters protested in Meru town (Imenti North, Meru) against the high cost of living as well as new tax measures set by the government. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 7 July 2023, Azimio supporters, including traders, protested in Kitale town (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against the high cost of living as well as new tax measures set by the government. Police intervened and lobbed tear gas to disperse the group.

On 8 July 2023, hundreds of residents of Mbeti village, that borders Meru and Tharaka Nithi counties (coded as Mitunguu Imenti South, Meru), protested against increased insecurity following a boundary dispute. The group demanded the interior cabinet secretary to address the matter.
