On 31 January 2024, workers at the Migori water department protested in Migori (Suna West, Migori) against delayed pay. The group demanded the county government and Migori Water and Sanitation Company (MIWASCO) to address the matter.

On 31 January 2024, teachers and parents pretested at Kaptumo primary school (Baringo Central, Baringo) against the failure by the ministry of education to establish a section for Junior Secondary School (JSS) students in the school. The group demanded the ministry to address the matter.

On 31 January 2024, hundreds of boda boda taxi operators from Kagumo marched to Kiamiciri police station (Kirinyaga East, Kirinyaga) against increased incidents of motorbike theft. The group demanded the police to help address the matter.

On 31 January 2024, hundreds of traders from Nyamlori market and Garissa Lodge plus motorists from the Kisumu bus park, barricaded the Kisumu boys school roundabout with bonfires, while others marched in the Kisumu city streets (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in demonstration against the move by the city management to relocate them to alternative places. Led by a civil activist, the group demanded for the removal of Kisumu city manager from office.
On 31 January 2024, hundreds of passport applicants protested at the at the immigration service offices in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against delayed processing passports.

On 1 February 2024, former Tigray fighters who have sustained different bodily injuries during the Northern Ethiopia conflict staged a protest in front of the office of Tigray Interim Administration in Mekele (Mekelle Tigray, Tigray). The demonstrators expressed concerns over neglect by the regional administration including lack of adequate medical support and embezzlement of the budget allocated for them. The regional deputy president promised to visit their residence to assess and address the concern.

On 1 February 2024, residents protested in at Kihumbuini market (Gatanga, Muranga) against the proposal by Gatanga Water and Sanitation Company (Gatawasco) to raise water tariffs. Led by their area member of county assembly (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded the company to suspend the proposal the economic environment will allow residents to pay more.

On 1 February 2024, a group of butchers protested an imposed animal Foot-and-mouth disease quarantine in Mbarara (Mbarara, Mbarara). The protesters claimed that the quarantine is selective since milk dealers allegedly continue operating unrestricted.

On 1 February 2024, (for the second time in less than a week) hundreds of residents protested at Esoit (Narok West, Narok) against alleged grabbing of their land by unknown people. The group demanded the ministry of security as well as county political leaders to help address the matter.

On 1 February 2024, hundreds of students at Gianchere mixed boarding secondary school marched to the education office in Keumbu (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against the transfer of their school principal. The group demanded the principal reinstated.

On 1 February 2024, healthcare workers (mostly nurses) marched and camped outside the governor's office in Kericho (Ainamoi, Kericho) against poor pay and poor working conditions among other grievances. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 2 February 2024, residents gathered in Kiano neighborhoods of Nyahururu town (Laikipia West, Laikipia) against power outage, following the move the Kenya Power to disconnect power supply due to overdue bills. The group demanded the agency to restore power as well as stop blanket victimization.
On 2 February 2024, county casual workers from Isebania marched to the county headquarters in Migori (Suna West, Migori) against unfair dismissal. The group demanded their unpaid dues.
On 2 February 2024, women protested and blocked (means unspecified) the KM4 Junction in Mogadishu - Hodan (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle). No further information.

Around 2 February 2024 (as reported), members of the Union of Public Servants of Kenya (UKSC) gathered and sang solidarity songs in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) against alleged misuse of funds and poor leadership at the union's national office.

On 2 February 2024, family, relatives and members of the public staged a protest at the Naivasha sub-county hospital (Naivasha, Nakuru) against alleged negligence by the hospital management, following the death of an eight-month-old child. Several journalists were assaulted and injured by anti-riot police, who used unspecified methods to disperse the group.

On 3 February 2024, a group of Puntland Police Forces (Goodir Unit) protested and took over the Eastern checkpoint on the Garowe-Bosasso main tarmac road and blocked vehicular access to the main road by unspecified means in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal). They demanded the payment of salaries.

On 3 February 2024, local residents protested in Ceel Buur town (Ceel Buur, Galgaduud). The protesters rejected the recent MoU agreement between Somaliland and Ethiopia for access to the Red Sea coast.

Around 3 February 2024 (as reported), 5000 workers of Ashton EPZ drawn from Changamwe constituency and Jomvu constituency, joined by the Mombasa women representative (ODM, Azimio), protested in an undisclosed location (coded to the nearest known location as Jomvu, Jomvu, Mombasa) against the sacking of their colleagues and alleged poor working conditions. The group demanded the company management address the matter.

On 4 February 2024, hundreds of local residents protested in Buqda Caqable village (Bulo Burto, Hiraan). The protesters rejected the recent MoU agreement between Somaliland and Ethiopia for access to the Red Sea coast.

On 4 February 2024, hundreds of local residents protested in Ceel Cali village (Belet Weyne, Hiraan). The protesters rejected the recent MoU agreement between Somaliland and Ethiopia for access to the Red Sea coast.

On 5 February 2024, ethnic Agaw residents of Tsana held a peaceful rally in Tsana sub woreda (location coded to admin center, Nirak) in Abergele woreda (Wag Hamra, Amhara) to demand their constitutional rights to self-determination and the ability to govern themselves as a separate regional state. The protesters chanted slogans urging the federal government to address the demands of the Agaw ethnic group.

On 5 February 2024, hundreds of residents protested in Chelelmetio near Tembelio (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the alleged grabbing of road reserve land. The group demanded the president to help address the matter.

On 5 February 2024, a group of parents staged a protest against poor academic performance at Bulekeyi Primary School in Bulekeyi (Samia-Bugwe, Busia) and demanded the immediate transfer of the head teacher.
On 5 February 2024, a group of teachers protested the non-payment of their salaries at the administrator's office in Kibatsi (Kajara, Ntungamo).

On 5 February 2024, Mwakamba\Mvumoni residents protested in Diani (Msambweni, Kwale) against alleged land injustices, following the move by private developers to claim ownership of the Mwakamba/Mvumoni and Diani Complex land, that is not fully adjudicated. Led by the area committee chairman of land adjudication, the group demanded both the county and the national governments to help address the matter and ensure that justice prevails.

Around 5 February 2024 (as reported), hundreds of residents marched in Kiambu town (Kiambu town, Kiambu) against the renewal of the lease for the 75-acre piece of land belonging to Kiambu Golf Club. Led by their ward representatives, the group demanded the allocation of 25 acres of land for the construction of a market, school, and public toilet.

On 5 February 2024, hundreds of residents from Mororo, Madogo, and KBC areas, joined by a former Chewele ward member of the county assembly and human rights defenders, marched along the Bura-Hola road (coded to one of the areas as Madogo, Bura, Tana River) against the move by the county government to start a cluster program in the Moya Buya area aimed at mitigating the effects of flooding. The group demanded for public participation.

Around 5 February 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly traders, protested in Maragwa (Muranga South, Muranga) against the lack of essential services. The group demanded the county governor help address their grievances.
On 5 February 2024, casual workers gathered outside the Isebania sub-county hospital (Kuria West, Migori) against alleged unfair dismissal. The group demanded for their salary arrears.

On 6 February 2024, hundreds of residents protested in Mwea town (Kirinyaga West, Kirinyaga) against a recent court ruling that declared their occupation of a 29-acre piece of land illegal. The group demanded justice.

On 6 February 2024, teachers from Mogusii mixed secondary school marched to the teacher's service commission offices in Nyamira (Nyamira, Nyamira) against community hostility, following a recent event where residents stormed the school and frog-matched the teachers (coded separately). Led by the Kenya Union of Post-Primary Education Teachers (KUPPET) officials, the group demanded the transfer of the teachers.

Around 6 February 2024 (as reported), women, joined by human rights defenders, including representatives from Action Aid, gathered and conducted a vigil by lighting candles in Eastleigh neighborhoods of Nairobi - Kamukunji (Kamukunji, Nairobi) against increased femicide cases, following the recent killing of a woman in the area. The group demanded the government guarantee security for the women.

On 6 February 2024, residents protested outside the Nakuru Memorial War Hospital (Nakuru North, Nakuru) in support of the move by the county government to take over the management of the private hospital, following a land dispute between the county and the hospital management.

Around 6 February 2024 (as reported), residents protested by blocking the Nyansakia to Omosocho road (coded to Omosocho, Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) with banana stems against the poor state of the road. The group demanded the member of parliament to address the matter.
On 6 February 2024, residents protested in Belet Xaawo town (Belet Xaawo, Gedo) over a curfew imposed by Ethiopian forces following the killings of Ethiopian citizens (coded separately).

On 6 February 2024, human rights defenders marched in the Enchoro-Emuny area of Ngong (Kajiado North, Kajiado) against female genital mutilation (FGM). The march marked the International Day of Zero Tolerance for FGM.

On 6 February 2024, more than 40 Ogiek and the Endorois community representatives marched to the Office of the Attorney General in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against government evictions from the Mau Complex. The group demanded justice and reparations.

On 6 February 2024, the Kenya National Union of Teachers (KNUT) gathered and sang solidarity songs in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the alleged failure of the teacher's service commission to engage them in drafting the new teachers' law. The group demanded a special engagement with the commission.

On 6 February 2024, 21 Gikuyu elders protested inside the courtroom in Muranga (Kiharu, Muranga) against the alleged government move to target the Kikuyu culture, following their arrest over suspicion of being members of the outlawed Mungiki (coded separately). The group demanded freedom and solidarity.

Around 6 February 2024 (as reported), public service vehicle owners, tuk-tuk taxi operators, and lorry owners protested and chased away county enforcement officers in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) against increased county fees. The group demanded to be consulted before the increment. No violent interactions reported.

Around 7 February 2024 (as reported), tenants gathered outside the Buxton apartments in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against the alleged high amount of money demanded by the developer for them to occupy the houses. The group demanded the governor to help address the matter.

On 7 February 2024, Sixty Puntland Maritime Police Force officer staged a protest by blocking the airport road near Mashallah restaurant by unspecified means in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari). The protest aimed at demanding payment of their unpaid salaries.

On 7 February 2024, residents of Mutomo gathered outside the Thika law courts (Thika Town, Kiambu) during a demonstration in support of the court's decision to refer the case challenging the compulsory acquisition of their land for Mama Ngina University College to a Land Acquisition Tribunal (LAT).

On 8 February 2024, residents protested in Buruburu City carton neighborhood of Nairobi - Makadara (Makadara, Nairobi) against an alleged plan by the government to evict them for the construction of affordable houses. The group demanded the governor and national government officials issue them with land title deeds as well as to be allowed to pay the land rates.
On 8 February 2024, about two hundred (200) fish sellers staged a protest against the impounding of their fish at the office of the Resident City Commissioner in Arua (Arua, Arua).

On 8 February 2024, residents protested in Muthurwa (other sources mention Jogooo road) in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the move by a business owner to rebuild an oil recycling plant, citing that the chemicals from the plant allegedly exacerbated the fire that recently burnt down businesses along the area. The group demanded the government to have the plant relocated from the area.

On 9 February 2024, hundreds of fishermen, joined by advocacy groups like 'Save Lamu' and Katiba Institute, held a demonstration by slaughtering a goat on the streets of Lamu town (Lamu West, Lamu) against delayed compensation from Kenya Ports Authority (KPA), following the construction of Lamu port, which took over their fishing grounds. The group demanded justice from KPA.

On 9 February 2024, IDPs held a rally and blocked the main road connecting Chibra with Weldiya at Jara IDPs site (Habru, North Wello, Amhara), opposing the non-distribution of food aid for two consecutive months. The road was briefly closed as the IDPs demonstrated on the main road.

On 9 February 2024, a family and friends marched to Garissa police station (Garissa, Garissa) against the alleged abduction of their kin by police officers on 7 January (coded separately). The group demanded the government locate and ensure the safety of their kidnapped relative.

On 10 February 2024, traders protested at Gatukuyu market (Gatundu North, Kiambu) against the move by the county government to send contractors to reconstruct the market. The group demanded to be informed on the reconstruction process as well as meet with the county government officials together with the contractors to gauge the authenticity of the project.

Around 10 February 2024 (as reported), drivers of United Nations vehicles heading to Juba in South Sudan protested at an unspecified location along the Nairobi-Mombasa highway (coded to the nearest known location as Mtito Andei, Kibwezi East, Makueni) against the move by government officials and the police to seize their vehicles before they cleared the arrears. Police used batons to disperse the group. One person sustained injuries, while three people others were arrested during the incident. Extent of injuries unknown/not reported.

Around 10 February 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Kanamai (Kilifi South, Kilifi) against the alleged move by a private developer to use police officers to evict them from their ancestral land. The group demanded the president to help address the matter.

On 11 February 2024, hundreds of fishermen marched along the streets of Lamu Old Town (Lamu West, Lamu) against delayed compensation from Kenya Ports Authority (KPA), following the construction of Lamu Port, which took over their fishing grounds. The group demanded the county government sign the compensation agreements between individual fishermen and KPA.

Around 12 February 2024 (as reported), Katamanak and Lopii residents, joined by area professionals, protested against increased insecurity (location coded to one of the affected villages as Lopii, Turkana East, Turkana), following frequent attacks by suspected pastoral militia believed to be from neighboring West Pokot County. The group demanded the Cabinet secretary to address the matter by deploying enough officers.

On 12 February 2024, student leaders from Multimedia University gathered at the institution in Ongata Rongai (Loitokitok, Kajiado) against the delayed confirmation of the current acting Vice-Chancellor (VC) as the substantive VC. The group demanded the education cabinet secretary to address the matter.

Around 12 February 2024 (as reported), residents gathered in an unspecified location within the Kinna ward (coded to the nearest known location as Kinna, Garbatulla, Isiolo) against the alleged torture and killing of a community health worker by the police (coded separately). Led by the area Senator (Jubilee, Azimio), the group demanded the Independent Policing Oversight Authority (IPOA) to investigate the matter as well as the police to be transferred.
On 12 February 2024, Puntland Dervish force members protested in the Golis Mountains area near Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari). The protest aimed at demanding payment of their unpaid salaries.

Around 12 February 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Kosare near Dago (Kisumu West, Kisumu) against the poor state of the roads. The group demanded their political leaders help address the matter.

On 12 February 2024, hundreds of residents of Turkana and West Pokot counties camped outside the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) offices in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) in support of their leaders, as they were questioned over insecurity as a result of pastoral militia attacks.

Around 12 February 2024 (as reported), residents gathered in Ruai within the Nairobi - Kasarani neighborhoods (Kasarani, Nairobi) against the move by private developers to grab their land and turn it into quarry mining fields. The group demanded the government to help them regain their land.

On 12 February 2024, graduate medical students, joined by medical students from the University of Nairobi marched and camped outside the Ministry of Health headquarters at Afya House in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against delayed internship placements. The group demanded an audience with the Health Cabinet Secretary (CS) over the matter.

Around 12 February 2024 (as reported), youth under the Kenya Youth organization banner marched in Kakamega town (Lurambi, Kakamega) against alleged increased political incitement and intolerance in the county. The group demanded the National Cohesion and Integration Commission (NCIC) investigate and address the matter.
On 13 February 2024, hundreds of residents marched to the County assembly building in Kiambu Town (Kiambu Town, Kiambu) against the law on freehold land rates. The group demanded the law be repealed.

On 13 February 2024, members of the Maasai community, mainly youth, protested in Kedong' (Naivasha, Nakuru) against an alleged planned move by private developers to grab their land. The group demanded national government help address the matter.

On 13 February 2024, boda boda taxi operators forced their way into Othoro police station (Kabondo Kasipul, Homa Bay) against the recent attack against two students perpetrated by police officers (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the students.

On 14 February 2024, parents protested at St. Philips Rateti Secondary School (Nyamira, Nyamira) against the transfer of the school principal. The group demanded the education cabinet secretary to help address the matter.

On 14 February 2024, women gathered and conducted a vigil by lighting candles in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against increased femicide cases. The group demanded the judiciary to fast-track femicide cases.

On 14 February 2024, women under the End Femicide Kenya Movement gathered and conducted a vigil by lighting candles in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against increased femicide cases. The group demanded both the county and national governments implement necessary changes to end femicide.

On 14 February 2024, hundreds of women under the End Femicide Kenya Movement gathered and conducted a vigil by lighting candles at the University of Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against increased femicide cases. On 15 February 2024, for the second day, residents and teachers led by KNUT and KUPPET marched along the Marigat-Chemoligot road in Marigat town (Marigat, Baringo) against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of a head teacher by suspected pastoral militia (coded separately). On 16 February 2024, seafarers protested in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against the alleged flawed election of their leaders, arguing that the laws and regulations were not adhered to. The group demanded the election be repeated.

On 16 February 2024, residents and community members gathered around Ting'ang'a police station (Kiambu Town, Kiambu) against the death of a detainee by suicide, accusing the officers of foul play. The group demanded justice.

The group demanded the cabinet secretary for interior to help address the matter.

On 16 February 2024, members of the Kenya National Union of Nurses (KNUN) Trans Nzoia branch gathered and sang solidarity songs in an unspecified location (coded to the county headquarters as Kitale, Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against lack of alleged understaffing and lack of promotions. The group demanded the county government address their grievances.

On 16 February 2024, family members, education association of Mogadishu, and teachers protested the recent killing of a teacher at his school in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir). Around 18 February 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Tampalal, also known as Tambalal (West Pokot, West Pokot), against the torching of their houses, following a land dispute (coded separately). On 20 February 2024, members of Chadema, including the Vice Chairman of the party, marched in Mbeya (Mbeya Urban, Mbeya) opposing proposed changes to electoral laws, particularly three bills recently presented in Parliament, seen as protection measures to the ruling party. On 20 February 2024, health workers gathered and sang solidarity songs at the Busia referral hospital (Matayos, Busia) against delayed remittance of statutory deductions. Led by the Busia KMPDU's Secretary General, the group demanded the county government address their grievances.

On 21 February 2024, youth marched in Kiambu town (Kiambu Town, Kiambu) against increased femicide cases. The group demanded the government to declare femicide a national emergency among others.

Around 22 February 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Marigat town (Marigat, Baringo) against increased insecurity as a result of pastoral militia attacks. The group demanded the government address the matter.

Around 22 February 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Kabarnet town (Baringo Central, Baringo) against increased insecurity as a result of pastoral militia attacks. The group demanded the government address the matter.

Around 22 February 2024 (as reported), students from Ramogi Institute of Advanced Technology protested in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the transfer of their principal. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group. One student was injured and taken to hospital during the incident.

On 26 February 2024, Chadema supporters marched in Mbeya (Mbeya Urban, Mbeya), Dar es Salaam, Mwanza, and Arusha (coded separately), opposing proposed changes to electoral laws, particularly three bills recently presented in Parliament, seen as protection measures to the ruling party. On 26 February 2024, Chadema supporters marched in Mwanza (Nyamagana, Mwanza), Dar es Salaam, Mbeya, and Arusha (coded separately), opposing proposed changes to electoral laws, particularly three bills recently presented in Parliament, seen as protection measures to the ruling party. On 6 March 2024, residents of Miyo woreda held a protest rally in Hidilola town (Borena, Oromia) to condemn the killing of a youth by government security forces a day before (coded separately). The protesters condemned the militia behavior in the Oromia region, including accusations of excessive force, intimidation, and corruption.

On 6 March 2024, teachers from the Early Childhood and Development Education (ECDE) program protested in Homa Bay town (Homa Bay Town, Homa Bay) against poor pay as well as poor employment terms. The group demanded the county government to address the matter.

Around 6 March 2024 (week of), residents protested in Isiolo town (Isiolo, Isiolo) against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of 3 people in Mulango area by pastoral militia (coded separately).

On 6 March 2024, officials of the KMPDU gathered and sang solidarity songs in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the delay in posting and payment of medical interns, among other grievances. The group demanded the Ministry of Health to address their grievances.

Around 6 March 2024 (as reported), a group of musicians protested in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against an alleged move by the Kenya Copyright Board (Kecobo) to interfere in the management of the Kenya music copyright society. The group demanded Kecobo's help in law enforcement.

Around 6 March 2024 (as reported), Moi University workers and lecturers led by KUDHEIHA, UASU, and KUSU protested at the Kesses campus (Kesses, Uasin Gishu) against delayed pay. The group demanded the university management address the matter.

Around 7 March 2024 (as reported), members of the Maa pastoral community (coded Maasai) protested in Rombo (Loitokitok, Kajiado) against the move by a rival group to oppose the subdivision of the Rombo group ranch on the border of Kajiado and Taita Taveta counties. The group demanded the aggrieved parties raise their grievances with the ranch chairperson.
On 7 March 2024, residents protested in Ganda (Malindi, Kilifi) against the alleged move by a private developer to serve them with eviction orders following a land dispute.

Around 7 March 2024 (as reported), members of the Meru community council of elders gathered at an unspecified location in Meru County (coded to the county headquarters as Meru, Imenti North, Meru) in support of the government's fight against illicit alcohol.
On 8 March 2024, a group of women protested against police brutality compensation delay at the police station in Naguru (Kampala, Kampala). The police intervened and arrested three of the protesters.

Around 9 March 2024 (as reported), over 7000 dairy farmers in the Murang'a South region (including Kandara, Gatanga, and Kigumo) gathered outside the Kenya Cooperative Creameries (KCC) cooling plant in Githumu (Kandara, Muranga) against delayed payment for milk deliveries. Led by a nominated member of county assembly, the group demanded the deputy president to help address the matter.

On 10 March 2024, members of the Anglican Church of Kenya (ACK) protested in Mwihoko (Ruiru, Kiambu) against the move by the church elders to transfer their Reverend. The group demanded the archbishop to help address the matter.

On 11 March 2024, a group of parents, accompanied by pupils, protested against the embezzlement of school funds by the headteacher at Nakatuli Primary School located in Nakatuli (Bbaale, Kayunga). The parents arrested the headteacher and handed her over to the police.

On 11 March 2024, students of Kaimosi University marched at the institution in Kaimosi (Hamisi, Vihiga) against the poor state of the road leading to the university, following the recent death of student after being knocked down by a boda boda taxi operator. The group demanded that the county and national governments erect bumps, expand and tarmac the road.

Around 12 March 2024 (as reported), maize farmers protested at the cereals board in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against shortage of subsidized fertilizer. The group demanded the government to address the matter.

Around 13 March 2024 (week of), around 2,000 IDPs hosted in the 'Turk IDP camp' staged a peaceful demonstration before Thehulederie woreda administration in Hayk (Thehulederie, South Wello, Amhara), protesting negligence by the government and non-provision of aid services for many months.

Around 14 March 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Kiorimba (Tigania West, Meru) against alleged move by a bishop's wife and her family to assault and wound a 17-year-old boy for having a relationship with their 15-year-old daughter (sister). The group demanded justice for the victim.

On 15 March 2024, health workers (doctors) marched from Lodwar town to the office of the Public Service Board and Ministry of Health in Lodwar (Turkana Central, Turkana) against lack of promotions among other grievances. Led by the KMPDU liaison officer, the group demanded the government to address healthcare deficiencies and engage them in dialogue.

On 15 March 2024, residents protested in Sereolipi (Samburu East, Samburu) against increased insecurity, following the killing of two people by suspected pastoral militia (coded separately). The group demanded measures to address the security challenge.

Around 15 March 2024 (as reported), KNUT officials gathered and sang solidarity songs at an unspecified location (coded to the country headquarters as Nairobi, Starehe, Nairobi) against delayed disbursement of school capitation funds. The group demanded the government to address the matter.

On 15 March 2024, hundreds of residents from Igembe region marched to Meru County headquarters (Imenti North, Meru) against lack of development in their region. The group demanded development initiatives from the county government.
On 16 March 2024, residents forced their way into the governor's office in Bomet (Bomet East, Bomet) against alleged lack of development in the county. The group demanded the governor to resign.

On 16 March 2024, workers protested at the Mwache dam project (Kinango, Kwale) against underemployment as well as non-remittance of National Health Insurance Fund (NHIF) and National Social Security Fund (NSSF). The group demanded the company management to address their grievances.

On 17 March 2024, residents of Abergele woreda staged a protest rally in different kebeles (location coded to Abergele) in Abergele woreda (Wag Hamera, Amhara), to condemn ethnically targeted attacks against ethnic Agaw civilians and demand their right to self-administer as an autonomous regional state.

On 18 March 2024, a crowd gathered and protested at Fagax main road in Mogadishu - Yaqshid (Banadir) against a private businessman who set up storage for cooking gas near the residential area. The residents feared that malicious activity could cause an explosion, destroying the residential buildings and generating human casualties.

On 18 March 2024, residents of Kampi Sumari and Kamukwa marched to Ol Joro Orok police station (Oljoroorok, Nyandarua) against the sale of illicit brew. The group demanded the security officers to address the matter.
On 18 March 2024, business owners protested in Mogadishu - Hamar Jabjab (Banadir) against a new fee imposed by the Mogadishu seaport management.

On 18 March 2024, officials of the KMPDU gathered and sang solidarity songs in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in support of the ongoing doctors' strike. The group demanded the government address the doctor's grievances.

On 19 March 2024, residents protested in Umoja II neighborhoods of Nairobi - Embakasi West (Embakasi West, Nairobi) against alleged harassment and arbitrary arrests by county government enforcement, following the demolition of a car wash operated by the youth in the area. Led by their Member of County Assembly (MCA), (ODM, Azimio), the group demanded justice for the youth.

On 19 March 2024, residents forced their way into the Malakisi cotton ginnery (Sirisia, Bungoma) against the alleged sale of scrap metal by the facility manager. Led by their area Member of Parliament (Jubilee, Azimio), the group demanded the facility's manager to resign.

On 19 March 2024, for the second day, residents of Kampi Sumari and Kamukwa forcefully closed down a bar in Kampi Sumari near Ol Joro Orok (Oljoroorok, Nyandarua) against the sale of illicit brew. Led by a nominated Member of the County Assembly (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) and the area chief, the group demanded their voices to be heard.

On 19 March 2024, students of Wasio Secondary School marched from the school to the Suna East Sub-County Education Director in Migori (Suna West, Migori) against poor meals and poor state of learning, alleging that they aren't allowed to conduct practicals. The group demanded the school principal to resign.
On 19 March 2024, a group of residents protested in the village of Busamba (Busiro, Wakiso), after the police blocked their meeting to solve land dispute issues.

On 20 March 2024, health workers (doctors) gathered and sang solidarity songs at the Kenyatta University Teaching, Referral and Research Hospital in Nairobi - Roysambu (Roysambu, Nairobi) in support of the ongoing nationwide KMPDU strike. Led by KMPDU officials, the group demanded the government address their grievances.

Around 20 March 2024 (as reported), squatters protested in Laikipia West (coded to the nearest known location as Rumuruti, Laikipia West, Laikipia) against the alleged move by a private developer to subdivide the land they have been residing on. The group demanded their political leaders help address the matter.

Around 20 March 2024 (as reported), traders marched and camped outside the Busia county assembly (Matayos, Busia) against the move by a select committee meant to investigate two County executive committee (CEC) members over malpractices to hold sessions in Kisumu. Led by their chairman, protesters demanded the sessions to be held in Busia.

Around 20 March 2024 (as reported), residents forced their way into a factory in Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu) against air pollution from the factory which allegedly emits poisonous gases. The group demanded the factory be closed.

Around 20 March 2024 (as reported), residents protested at the Chepchoina Settlement scheme along the Trans Nzoia-West Pokot County (Endebess, Trans Nzoia) against land grabbing, allegedly facilitated by brokers and Ministry of Land officials. Led by Kapenguria Member of Parliament (UDA-Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded the Trans Nzoia governor to help address the matter.

On 21 March 2024, residents of Bacho Bore kebele gathered and blocked the road (through unspecified means) and prevented the passage of Jimma town officials in Becho Bore kebele/Welda, in Jimma town, Jima (Jimma, Oromia), to demonstrate against the demolition of homes without compensation.

On 21 March 2024, surveyors and residents marched to the Ugenya Deputy County Commissioner's office in Ukwala (Ugenya, Siaya) against poor service delivery at the land registry office. The group demanded the land registrar be transferred.

On 21 March 2024, a group of traders protested in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), against the decision by the Uganda Revenue Authority leaders to evict journalists from their meeting. A scuffle erupted between security operatives and traders when the former intervened to prevent further escalation.

On 21 March 2024, health workers (doctors) from the North Rift region marched from the entrance of the Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital through the Eldoret-Nairobi highway, with some attempting to force their way into the county government offices, before accessing the Eldoret town's central business district (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against poor pay as well as government's delayed posting of the medical interns among other grievances. Led by KMPDU officials, the group demanded the government address their grievances.

On 21 March 2024, a group of residents protested at Jinja Hospital in Jinja city (Jinja, Jinja), against the land minister's decision to give their land to the Uganda Muslim Supreme Council. The protesters blocked the hospital for over thirty minutes. The police intervened and dispersed the protesters.

Around 21 March 2024 (as reported), residents gathered in Tumoiyot near Sigowet (Sigowet, Kericho) against the move by the county government to excavate a road in the area and leave it impassable. The group demanded the area Member of the County Assembly (MCA) to help address the matter.

On 22 March 2024, public service vehicle (matatu) operators blocked an unspecified road using their buses in Huruma neighborhoods of Nairobi - Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi) against alleged harassment and misappropriation of funds by their Savings and Credit Cooperative Organization (SACCO) as well as divisions within the SACCO leadership. The group demanded the chairperson of the SACCO to resign.

Around 22 March 2024 (as reported), residents protested at Kijipwa (Kilifi South, Kilifi) against an eviction court order of 160 families, following the move by a tycoon to claim ownership of their land. The group demanded the government to help address the matter.

On 22 March 2024, vendors of palm wine (Mnazi-local brew) from Kisauni and Nyali sub-counties, joined by Jubilee deputy party leader and five Members of County Assembly (MCAs) (including ODM, Azimio; UDA, Kenya Kwanza) marched in Frere Town near Mwandoni (Nyali, Mombasa) against alleged harassment by police officers, following the deputy president's directive on drugs and illicit brew. The group demanded the MCAs to develop a county law which extends the hours for drinking as well as the security officers to help address the matter.

Around 22 March 2024 (as reported), nurses under the Nurses Association of Kenya gathered and sang solidarity songs in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in support of the doctors' strike. Led by the association's president, the group demanded the government address the doctors' grievances as well as the intern doctors carefully read their deployment letters before signing.

On 22 March 2024, hundreds of health workers (doctors) marched and camped outside the Ministry of Health offices in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against alleged delayed poor pay and delayed posting of medical interns, among other grievances. Led by KMPDU officials, the group demanded the cabinet secretary for health to address their grievances.

On 22 March 2024, boda boda taxi operators and residents marched in Muranga town and later outside the university gate, before proceeding to Kabati village near Muranga town (Kiharu, Muranga) against the killing of a boda boda taxi operator colleague by university students through mob justice (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the victim.
On 23 March 2024, squatters protested in Ngeria (Kapseret, Uasin Ngishu) against the invasion of their land by an unnamed politician. The group demanded the president to help address the matter.

On 23 March 2024, residents, mainly traders, protested at Abom near Rarieda (Rarieda, Siaya) against prolonged power outage. The group demanded the Kenya Power and Lighting Company to address the matter.

Around 23 March 2024 (weekend of), residents, mainly women, marched in Kaliani (Yatta, Machakos) against increased cases of femicide. Led by the Coalition for Grassroots Human Rights Defenders Convener, the groups demanded religious leaders to help address the vice.

Around 23 March 2024 (as reported), farmers camped outside the National Cereals and Produce Board (NCPB) depot in Ishiara (Mbeere North, Embu) against delayed disbursement of subsidized fertilizer. Led by the area Member of Parliament (DP), the group demanded the NCPB national office to help address the matter.

Around 24 March 2024 (as reported), residents protested within Moa sub-locality (coded to the nearest known location as Gamba, Lamu West, Lamu) against the appointment process of a new Chief, alleging bias and lack of transparency. The group demanded the position to be re-advertised.

On 24 March 2024, thousands of people, including civil servants and Governor of Banadir Region and the Mayor of Mogadishu, protested at the Daljirka Dahson field square in Mogadishu - Bondhere (Banadir) to express their appreciation and support for the amendment of the Somali Constitution which was being tabled in the parliament session.

On 24 March 2024, traders protested in Nyamakima and Gikomba markets within Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the holding of their container ports at the Port of Mombasa. The group demanded the relevant authorities to address the matter.

On 25 March 2024, dozens of friends and family members held a candle-lighting vigil in Utawala neighborhoods of Nairobi - Embakasi East (Embakasi East, Nairobi) against the attack and eventual death of a police officer in an alleged road rage incident. The group demanded justice for the murdered officer.

Around 25 March 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Rumuruti (Laikipia West, Laikipia) against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of two cousins by unknown people. Th group demanded the police officers to address the matter.

On 25 March 2024, Nyandarua county workers gathered at the sports ground before marching to the office of the governor in Ol Kalou (Olkalou, Nyandarua) against the move by the county to deduct their salaries as well as poor and unhealthy working conditions. The group demanded the governor to address their grievances

On 25 March 2024, members of the Kenya National Private Security Workers Union (KNPSWU) gathered and sang solidarity songs in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the lack of implementation of the proposed new reforms for security guards by security firms. Led by the secretary general, the group demanded implementation of minimum wages.

On 25 March 2024, residents, mainly families of the IED explosion victims (coded separately) protested outside the Mandera referral hospital (Mandera East, Mandera) against alleged discrimination, following the move by authorities to airlift only two police officers to Nairobi for advanced medical care. The group demanded the county commissioner and the county government to airlift all the injured to Nairobi.

On 25 March 2024, contract health workers (described as medics) marched in Meru town (Imenti North, Meru) against the proposal by the council of governors to extend their contracts. The group demanded to be hired on permanent and pensionable terms.

On 25 March 2024, Kiandutu market traders marched to the Deputy County Commissioner's office in Thika town (Thika Town, Kiambu) against derailed construction of the market, alleging poor politics pitying the governor and the Member of Parliament over who lobbied for the construction of the market. The group demanded the row settled.

On 26 March 2024, Arsi University Dinsho campus students staged a public demonstration in Asela (Asela town, Arsi, Oromia), opposing the killings of Wello Oromos in the Oromo special zone of the Amhara region (coded separately).
On 26 March 2024, a group of residents protested against a minister's attempt to campaign for the MP of Buyende coded near Irundu (Budiope, Buyende).

Around 26 March 2024 (as reported), hundreds of Maa women (likely Maasai ethnic group, as Maasai are the majority in Kajiado county) closed more than 10 bars (no further information, no mention of interactions) in Enkorika town (Kajiado Central, Kajiado) against drugs and substance abuse, that has contributed to myriad of miseries in the region. The group demanded relevant agencies to address the matter.
On 26 March 2024, a group of city cleaners protested late salary payments at the city hall in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala).

On 26 March 2024, hundreds of health workers (doctors) from the south rift region marched from the Rift Valley provincial general hospital to the Central Business District through Kenyatta Avenue and ended at the county government headquarters in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against delayed posting of medical interns, fair pay for interns and medical doctors and comprehensive medical cover all as outlined in the 2017 collective bargaining agreement among others. Led by the KMPDU officials, the group demanded the government to address their grievances.

On 26 March 2024, Kenya National Union of Medical Laboratory Officers (KNUMLO) officials gathered and sang solidarity songs in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the delay by both the national and county governments to establish a recognition agreement to guarantee the inclusion of all Universal Health Coverage (UHC) employees. The group demanded the government to confirm UHC workers, UHC interns, Coronavirus Health Emergency Response Program (CHERP) participants, National TB and Lung Diseases Program (NTLD-P) Global Fund Employees contracts to be engaged on permanent and pensionable terms.

On 26 March 2024, health workers (mainly medical interns) marched in Meru town (Imenti North, Meru) against the government's proposed move to post medical interns from April 1 after reducing their stipends by over 90% among other grievances. Led by the KMPDU eastern region officials, the group demanded the President, the Council of Governors and the Health Ministry to implement the 2017 Collective Bargaining Agreement.

Around 27 March 2024 (as reported), pastoral communities living on the Isiolo and Samburu County border marched to Sereolipi (Samburu East, Samburu) in support of peace, following a recent spate of insecurity as a result of pastoral militia. Led by the Samburu women representative (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) the group demanded the state and non-state actors to invest more in peace.

On 28 March 2024, health workers (doctors) marched in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against alleged delayed posting of medical interns, better remuneration of interns, postgraduate training, employment of more doctors and comprehensive health coverage for the doctors. Led by KMPDU coast region officials, the group demanded the government to address their grievances.
On 28 March 2024, a group of farmers protested corruption by their woman MP in Rubanda (Rubanda, Rubanda). They demanded that the woman MP resign from her position as a parliament commission member.

Around 28 March 2024 (as reported), Miraa (Khat) famers gathered in Athiru (coded as Athiru Gaiti, Igembe South, Meru) against poor returns from the crop allegedly as a result of middlemen. The group demanded the president to help address the matter.
On 28 March 2024, business owners protested in Kiganjo (Gatundu South, Kiambu) against alleged multiple taxation by the county government. The group demanded the county to address the matter.

On 28 March 2024, activists from Grassroots Trust marched from Taifa Park and to Kisumu high court in Kisumu town (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the challenges facing Kenyans. The group demanded the government to give Kenyans hope and move decisively to addressing their grievances.

Around 29 March 2024 (as reported), Hethi residents marched to the Deputy County Commissioner's (DCC) office in Nanyuki (Laikipia East, Laikipia) against increased insecurity. The group demanded the president, through the ministry of interior, to deploy more police officers in the area.

On 29 March 2024, representatives of tea farmers from Kericho, Bomet, Nyamira and Kisii marched to Korara tea factory offices in Kebenet (Sigowet, Kericho) against delayed payment of their dues. The group demanded the factory to settle their debts in two weeks.

On 30 March 2024, women leaders from the Kenya Muslim Women Alliance, Maendelea ya Wanawake, Ukombozi wa Haki and Friends Women Movement marched along the Moi avenue in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against the move by a bank to ask a widow and businesswoman to pay a strange bank loan. The group demanded the judiciary expedite the case.

On 30 March 2024, residents, under the umbrella of Oloolua Community Forest Association, joined by Kajiado County Senator (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) and Former Nandi Hills Member of Parliament (MP) (Independent), protested in Oloolua, also known as Ololua (Kajiado West, Kajiado) against the alleged grabbing of 66 (other sources mention 50) acres of forest land, following the move by an unknown people to dig up trenches with the intension of fencing off the piece of land. The group demanded the government to ensure that the forest is not invaded as well as those responsible for the grabbing are held accountable.

On 30 March 2024, hundreds of residents blocked unspecified roads using unspecified means in Kinangop constituency (coded to the nearest known location as Githabai, Kinangop, Nyandarua) against increased insecurity, following rampant livestock theft allegedly involving the police officers. The group demanded immediate resignation and arrest of the police officers involved.

On 31 March 2024, residents, mainly ethnic Amhara, staged a protest in Korem town (South Tigray, Tigray), demanding the federal government to prevent the clashes between Amhara and Tigray forces in the disputed Raya Alamata and Ofla woredas from escalating. The protestors also requested the federal government to address the Amhara identity and self-administration questions and to allocate a budget for the disputed territories.

On 1 April 2024, hundreds of farmers staged a protest in Mehoni (Mekhoni town, Southern Tigray, Tigray), protesting the practice of giving land to investors who could not develop it and demanding redistribution of the lands to unemployed youths.

On 1 April 2024, residents blocked a road with logs and sacks of charcoal in demonstration in the area of Kibindu (Bagamoyo, Pwani) demanding the construction of embankments on the road after a fourth-grade student was hit by a car and died on the spot.
Around 1 April 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Ramula (Gem, Siaya) against the move the police to cancel a public forum meant to discuss gold prospects in the area.

On 2 April 2024, hundreds of residents, mainly beach operators and fishers, protested at Bidi Badu beach (Msambweni, Kwale) against the government's proposed Diani-Chale marine reserve project, alleging it would render many people jobless. The group demanded the government to immediately de-gazette the project.

On 2 April 2024, parents protested at the Jonathan Gloag Academy in Lang'ata neighborhoods of Nairobi - Langata (Langata, Nairobi), against alleged irregular creation of the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) position that has usurped the headteacher's powers. The group demanded the removal of the CEO as well as the creation of a Parent Teacher Association (PTA) among other demands.

On 2 April 2024, health workers, mainly doctors and medical interns, marched from the Jaramogi Oginga Odinga Sports Ground, before proceeding to Oginga Odinga Street and then State House road towards Prosperity Building in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against the government failure to honor the 2017 Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA). The group demanded a comprehensive implementation of the CBA including provision of medical cover and posting of medical interns.

On 2 April 2024, health workers, mainly nursing interns, marched along Parliament road and Harambee avenue to the Parliament building in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against their late posting and delayed payment. The group demanded the government to address their grievances.

On 2 April 2024, health workers, mainly doctors, medical interns and medical students, assembled at the Rugby Football Union of East Africa (RFUEA) grounds Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against issues affecting their welfare. Led by the Kenya Medical Practitioners Pharmacists and Dentists Union (KMPDU) officials, the group demanded the government to address the myriad of issues affecting the healthcare workers.

On 3 April 2024, traders marched to Njabini shopping Centre (Kinangop, Nyandarua) against the move by the county government to increase the trading fees. The group demanded the governor to address the matter.

On 3 April 2024, various residents of Korem, Zata, and Wofla staged a public demonstration in Korem (Korem town, Southern Tigray, Tigray) demanding a response to their identity questions. They raised their voices stating that the identity question is a human rights issue that needs immediate response. They also stated that they identify themselves as Wakshum not as Tigraway. The area is among the disputed location between Amhara and Tigray region and currently occuppied by Amhara forces.
On 4 April 2024, secondary school teachers protested the non-payment of their salaries at the district headquarters in Ngora (Ngora, Ngora). The protesters demanded the payments of all arrears.
On 4 April 2024, a group of science tutors protested in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), over removal from new pay scale.

On 5 April 2024, hundreds of Mekele University main campus students whose graduation was delayed by two years due to the northern Ethiopia conflict staged a protest in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray) against the university's decision to postpone their graduation to the next year. Police intervened and dispersed the gathering by firing warning shots and beating students (extent of injuries not reported). An unspecified number of students sustained slight injuries. At least 10 students were arrested.

On 5 April 2024, a group of parents and students protested at St Augustine Senior Secondary School in Nakifuma (Nakifuma, Mukono), over withheld 2023 national examinations results. The protesters held placards demanding the release of the results.

On 5 April 2024, residents blocked the Ol Kalou-Engineer road using unspecified means at Ndunyu Njeru (Kinangop, Nyandarua) against increased taxes by the county. as well as the poor state of roads, as a result of alleged poor governance by the county leadership. The group demanded the governor to address the matter.
Around 5 April 2024 (as reported), residents gathered in Molo (Molo, Nakuru) against the invasion of their farms by unknown people. The group demanded the government to help address the matter.

Around 5 April 2024 (as reported), sugarcane farmers from Kameloi and Maraba gathered in Aldai (Aldai, Nandi) against the poor state of the Miwani-Kipkorok road, following the move by a sugarcane processing firm to halt the reconstruction of the road.

On 6 April 2024, hundreds of Miraa (Khat) farmers protested at Maili Tatu in Igembe (Igembe South, Meru) against alleged exploitation by people described as cartels. The group demanded the government to license more transporters.

On 6 April 2024, residents protested in Kibagare slums in Westlands neighborhoods of Nairobi - Westlands (Westlands, Nairobi) against an alleged move by a group of individuals to grab their land. The group demanded the county government to help address the matter.

On 6 April 2024, family and friends, joined by human rights defenders, protested in Cheptiret (Keses, Uasin Gishu) against the abduction of their kin in Langata, allegedly by officers from the directorate of criminal investigations (DCI) (coded separately). The group demanded their kin released.

On 7 April 2024, residents, mainly ethnic Amhara, staged a demonstration in May Tsemre, May Tsebri town (Northwestern Tigray, Tigray). They called upon the parties to the Pretoria agreement to respect the agreement by prioritizing dialogue over clashes. They also requested the government to address their question about self-administration and the recognition of their Amhara identity. Ethnic Tigrayans complained of being forced by local administration to join the demonstration.
On 7 April 2024, cleaners protested at the Thika Level 5 hospital (Thika Town, Kiambu) against delayed pay. The group demanded the governor to help address the matter.

On 8 April 2024, more than 20 armed ex-combatants of GPDM encircled Dibate Woreda's administration building, in Dibate town (Debati, Metekel, Benshangul/Gumuz)) and blocked at least 800 employees from exiting the building for more than two hours. The group sought woreda officials to satisfy some of their unmet demands. They allowed the employees to leave after warning them not to go to work until their demands were met.

On 8 April 2024, hundreds of healthcare workers under the universal healthcare program, joined by the Kenya Union of Clinical Officers (KUCO) secretary general, converge at Green park terminus before marching in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the government failure to employ them on permanent and pensionable terms. The group demanded the government to address their grievances.

On 8 April 2024, worshippers from Pentecostal Assemblies of God (PAG) church marched in Ngara neighborhood of Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) against alleged move by a private developer to grab church land. Led by their bishop, the group demanded the relevant government agencies to help address the matter.

Around 9 April 2024 (as reported), sugarcane farmers from Mosop, Tinderet, Chesumei and Aldai gathered in Kapsabet (Chesumei, Nandi) against zoning of sugar catchment areas as proposed in a bill that is before the Senate. Led by Nandi County women representative (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded to sell their cane to millers of their choice.

On 9 April 2024, supporters of the current speaker of the Ugandan parliament (NRM members) protested in the town of Kamuli (Kamuli, Kamuli), over the alleged insubordination and sabotage by the former speaker of parliament.

On 9 April 2024, hundreds to thousands of health workers, mainly doctors under the KMPDU, medical interns and nurses marched from Kenyatta National Hospital to the ministry of health offices, before proceeding to parliament in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the government failure to honor the 2017 Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA) as well as delayed posting of interns, better remuneration of interns, postgraduate training, hiring of more doctors and comprehensive health coverage for health workers among other grievances. Rowdy youth riding on boda boda taxis pelted stones to disperse the group, police used unspecified means to restore normalcy and no details on the injuries.

On 9 April 2024, ODM-Azimio Members of County Assembly blocked, using unspecified means, the entrance to the assembly room in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) against alleged biasness of the assembly speaker. The group demanded the speaker to effect the house leadership changes as communicated by the party secretary general.

Around 10 April 2024 (as reported), four students from Bujwang'a secondary school, joined by their parents, camped outside the Samia sub-county education offices in Alema (Samia, Busia) against failure by the school administration to register the students for the Kenya Certificate of Secondary Education (KCSE) examination over demonstration fines. The group demanded the government to help address the matter.

On 10 April 2024, students of Addis Ababa University in Sidist Kilo staged a protest in Sidist Kilo Campus, Gulele, Addis Ababa (Region 14, Addis Ababa) to condemn the killing of an OLF politician by an unknown armed group (coded separately). The government security forces (coded as Federal Police) intervened (means not mentioned/specified) and dispersed the protesters.

On 10 April 2024, tea farmers gathered in Munyu-ini, also known as Munyuini (Gatundu South, Kiambu), against plans to pay millions of shillings to lawyers in Kenya Tea Development Agency (KTDA) suits. Led by Gatundu South Member of Parliament (MP) (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded the president to help cushion the farmers from exploitation.

Around 11 April 2024 (as reported), squatters from the Samburu community living in the 50000 hectares EX-P&D settlement scheme gathered at Mouwarak (Laikipia North, Laikipia) against the alleged move by people described as cartels to grab their land. Led by their chairman, the group demanded government to subdivide the land.

Around 11 April 2024 (as reported), UDA supporters from Teso North marched to the party sub-county offices in Angurai (Teso North, Busia) against presence of cartels allegedly handpicking leaders ahead of party elections. The group demanded the party leader, President William Ruto, to address the matter.

On 11 April 2024, members of Kenya Union of Clinical Officers from Kisumu County, gathered in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in support of the ongoing nationwide strike. Led by the national deputy secretary, the group demanded the government address their grievances.

Around 12 April 2024 (as reported), residents of Tsegede woreda staged a peaceful demonstration in Tsegede (Western Tigray, Tigray), asking the government to respond to their identity question and recognize them as Amharas.

On 12 April 2024, members of the Dupoto/Dafur settlement scheme in Embakasi gathered outside the Milimani court in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against alleged failure to receive compensation payment after the Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) was developed on their land. Led by their lawyer, the group demanded the Kenya Railways Corporation to address the matter as well as the Directorate of Criminal Investigations to investigate the matter.

On 12 April 2024, health care workers (doctors) protested outside the Kakamega county headquarters (Lurambi, Kakamega) against the move by the governor to threaten to laid them off for participating in the on-going nationwide strike. Led by their KMPDU officials, the group demanded the government to address their grievances.

On 13 April 2024, IDPs displaced from the Southern Tigray zone and hosted in Mehoni town staged a peaceful demonstration in Mehoni (Mekhoni town, Southern Tigray, Tigray), requesting a return to their homes and implementation of the Pretoria agreement.

On 13 April 2024, members of the Linda Mnazi organization and other stakeholders, including traders, marched from Kiwandani, Kibaoni, Kwa charo mae, up to Karisa Maitha grounds within Kilifi county (coded to the county headquarters as Kilifi, Kilifi North, Kilifi) in support of the traditional palm wine (extracted from palm tree), following the ongoing crackdown on illicit liquor. The group demanded the government to create a palm tree directorate to regulate the sale of palm wine.

Around 13 April 2024 (as reported), milk farmers protested in an unspecified location within Trans Nzoia county (coded to the county headquarters as Kitale, Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against delayed payment of their dues by the New Kenya Cooperative Creameries company. The group demanded the government, through the relevant ministry to help address the matter.

On 14 April 2024, ethnic Tigrayan IDPs currently living in Maychew staged a peaceful demonstration by marching towards unspecified ENDF checkpoints around Maychew town (location coded to Maychew, Maichew town, Southern Tigray, Tigray). The IDPs demanded the implementation of the Pretoria agreement. Protesters also gathered in Mehoni on 13 April (coded separately).
On 15 April 2024, 150 Ethiopian refugees protested around the UNHCR office in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed) against deductions in their SA (subsistence allowance).

On 15 April 2024, Boda Boda riders protested at the city council offices in the city of Mbarara (Mbarara, Mbarara), against how the election of their leaders scheduled for the next day was being organized.

On 15 April 2024, a group of landowners marched in protest to the High Court in the city of Hoima (Hoima, Hoima) over a land dispute. The group demanded action against a court order ejecting them from their land for the Tilenga oil project.

On 15 April 2024, residents, mainly health workers (doctors) under the KMPDU, joined by clinical officers, nurses, and nursing students protested in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the delayed implementation of the 2017 Collective Bargain Agreement (CBA), among other grievances. Another group of residents, mainly matatu (public service vehicle) operators launched a counter-protest at the same location and accused the doctors of not returning to their workstations.
On 15 April 2024, a group of Christians protested the demolishing of Blood of Jesus Ministries International Church in Mukono (Mukono, Mukono).

On 15 April 2024, health workers staged a protest at the Jinja Regional Referral Hospital in Jinja (Jinja, Jinja), following reports that a Muslim group in the city had grabbed the hospital's land. As they tried to march to the city center, the police intervened and fired tear gas to disperse them.

On 15 April 2024, residents joined by local leaders, including Masige West (UPA, Azimio) and Masige East (Independent) Members of the County Assembly (MCAs) and the deputy governor (ODM, Azimio), protested in Nyamache (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against delayed repairs to a dilapidated bridge, following alleged negligence by the area Member of Parliament (MP). Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

Around 16 April 2024 (as reported), residents living along the Angata Barrikoi and Gwetembe border protested against the move by unknown people to raid and destroy a 10-acre piece of maize field (coded as Gwitembe, Kuria East, Migori) following a border dispute (coded separately). The group demanded the Cabinet Secretary for Interior to help address the matter.
On 16 April 2024, residents marched in Bokimai (South Mugirango, Kisii) against a prolonged power outage. The group demanded the Kenya Power and Lighting Company (KPLC) to address the matter.

Around 16 April 2024 (as reported), residents forced their way into the agricultural training center in Chebororwa (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the death of a man who allegedly succumbed to injuries after being attacked by the county law-enforcement officers manning the facility (coded separately). Led by Charengany-Chebororwa Member of County Assembly (MCA) (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) and human rights defenders, the group demanded justice for the deceased victim.

On 16 April 2024, a group of residents including boda boda riders protested in the town of Rwahi (Rushenyi, Ntungamo), against unfulfilled presidential pledges. The police intervened and arrested about five protesters after they had blocked (through unclear means) the Ntungamo-Kabale road.

On 16 April 2024, hundreds of health workers (doctors and other medical practitioners) marched to the Council of Governors' offices in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the delayed implementation of the 2017 Collective Bargain Agreement (CBA), among other grievances. Led by the KMPDU officials, the group demanded the government to address their grievances.

Around 17 April 2024 (as reported), sugarcane farmers protested in Kipsitet (Sigowet, Kericho) against the proposed Sugarcane Bill 2022, specifically its provisions on pricing, zoning, and the constitution of the sugar directorate. The group demanded the president to not to assent the bill into law, in case it is passed by parliament.

Around 17 April 2024 (as reported), family members protested in Burnt Forest (Ainabkoi, Uasin Gishu) against the disappearance of their son under unclear circumstances. The group demanded the government through the cabinet secretary for interior to help address the matter.
On 17 April 2024, locals protested at the Saybiano neighborhood in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir) against the orders from the police to vacate land formerly used by firefighters.

Around 18 April 2024 (as reported), sugarcane farmers protested in Maraba (Aldai, Nandi) against the proposed zoning bill for the sugarcane growing areas. The group demanded the bill amended as well as farmers to be represented in the sugarcane pricing committee.

Around 18 April 2024 (as reported), members of the ODM-Azimio gathered at the Kisii agricultural training center (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against alleged harassment and intimidation of the governor by national security agencies. Led by the county party chairman, the group demanded the security agencies accord the governor ample time to serve the residents.

On 18 April 2024, parents forced their way into Upper Hill Secondary School in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against high fees charged as well as poor academic performance. The group demanded the school principal be transferred.

On 19 April 2024, residents protested in Mbuyu wa Chapa (Jomvu, Mombasa) against the alleged move by unnamed individuals to grab their land, following the revocation of their title deeds by the county government.

On 19 April 2024, dozens of climate activists marched in the streets of Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against fossil fuel industries in their region. The group demanded changes to prevent the water nearby and the ecosystems of those bodies of water from being impacted by global warming.

On 20 April 2024, members of the Nakuru Workers Cooperative Society marched and camped outside the governor's office in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against the alleged move by high-profile individuals to grab their land. The group demanded the governor and the senator to help address the matter.
On 20 April 2024, more than 100 young climate change activists marched in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against fossil fuel financing. The group demanded action to halt financing for fossil fuels.

Around 21 April 2024 (as reported), hundreds of Rarieda (other sources mention Ramba) residents marched to the Siaya law courts (Alego Usonga, Siaya) against gold mining activities of a Chinese firm in the area, following the death of four local workers. The group demanded the company halt its gold extraction activities.

Around 22 April 2024 (as reported), residents, joined by Safina party leader, Jubilee party secretary general, former cabinet assistant secretary and area Member of County Assembly (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) gathered in Ndabibi (Naivasha, Nakuru) against the president's alleged move to grab their land. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 22 April 2024, residents marched in Marimanti Shopping Center (Tharaka South, Tharaka-Nithi) against the move by the government, through the State Department for Housing and Urban Development, to cancel a tender meant for constructing a modern market. Led by the women's county representative (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded the president to help address the matter.

On 23 April 2024, for the second day, hundreds of refugees from Burundi, DR Congo, Uganda, Ethiopia, Somalia, Eritrea, Sudan, and Djibouti blocked the Kakuma, Kalobeyei, and Lokichoggio road using unspecified means in the Kakuma refugee camp (Turkana West, Turkana) against the move by the United Nations High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR) to reduce their food ratio. The group demanded the UNHCR to rescind the decision.

On 23 April 2024, a group of high school students protested after the suspension of their mate at Apac Seed Secondary School in Apac (Apac, Apac). The police intervened and fired live bullets to prevent further escalation. A stray bullet caught and seriously injured a student who was trying to leave the school during the scuffle.

On 23 April 2024, thousands of Sudanese refugees demonstrated in Awlala Akushara (Awlala Akushara, Metema, West Gondar) against poor security conditions after a young man was robbed and shot a day prior by militiamen (coded separately). Several thousand refugees left the camp in the days following the demonstration.

On 23 April 2024, thousands of Sudanese refugees demonstrated in Kumer (Metema, West Gondar) against poor security conditions after a young man was robbed and shot a day prior by militiamen (coded separately). Several thousand refugees left the camp in the days following the demonstration.

On 23 April 2024, health workers (nurses, other sources mention doctors) marched to the office of the governor and the county public service board in Busia (Matayos, Busia) against lack of promotion as well as delayed pay. The group demanded the county government to address their grievances.

On 23 April 2024, health workers (clinical officers) gathered at the Green Park, before marching and camping outside the Ministry of Health offices, in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the alleged lack of commitment by the government, following unresolved negotiations over a new Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA) and other important needs. Around 23 April 2024 (as reported), members of the Muranga county assembly marched to the Murang'a police station before proceeding to the county assembly in Muranga (Kiharu, Muranga) in support of their six colleagues who the police had summoned in connection with the recent chaos witnessed in the assembly (coded separately). Around 23 April 2024 (as reported), residents of Gatitu, Sulmak, Karathi, and Kagiraini protested within the Kinangop subcounty (location coded in Kinangop, Kinangop, Nyandarua) against the poor state of feeder roads in the area. On 24 April 2024, residents blocked the Thika highway with rocks at the Githurai 45 neighborhood of Nairobi - Roysambu (Roysambu, Nairobi) in a demonstration against the alleged failure of the government to resolve the flooding problem in the area. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

Around 24 April 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly women, marched in Migori town (Suna West, Migori) in support of the Migori county women representative against verbal attacks by the Suna West Member of Parliament (MP). Around 26 April 2024 (as reported), residents marched in Kalokol (Turkana Central, Turkana) against police brutality. The group demanded all the police to be transferred.

The group demanded the government through the Teachers' Service Commission (TSC) to comply with a recent court order to grant them permanent and pensionable employment terms as well as compensation for the period worked while underpaid.

Police force opened gunfire to disperse the crowd. One protester was killed while two others sustained minor injuries.
