On 30 May 2024, religious leaders (likely Christians and Muslims-the main religious groups in the country), human rights defenders and women, marched in Malindi town (Malindi, Kilifi) against the move by the president to reverse the ban on the sale, consumption and distribution of muguka within the coastal counties. The group demanded the president to listen to their grievances.
On 31 May 2024, division councilors protested against the deliberate withholding of their allowance at a meeting in Masaka (Masaka, Masaka).
On 31 May 2024, residents marched on the streets of Mombasa town (Mvita, Mombasa) in support of the county government's move to ban Muguka. The group demanded the sale of Muguka stopped.

On 31 May 2024, a group of Junior Secondary School (JSS) intern teachers marched to the education offices in Chiakagira (Tharaka South, Tharaka-Nithi) against their employment terms. The group demanded the government, through the Teachers' Service Commission (TSC), to grant them permanent and pensionable employment terms.

On 31 May 2024, NUP supporters protested against the police's orders to their party leader Bobi Wine to use an alternative route to the venue of his mobilization rally at Kako Junction coded as Kako (Bukoto, Masaka). The police fired tear gas and live bullets to disperse the protesters. No fatalities were recorded.

Around 31 May 2024 (as reported), a group of maize famers from the north rift region protested outside the National Cereals and Produce Board (NCPB) stores in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the move by NCPB to delay purchasing their produce. The group demanded the government to allocate enough money in the budget for purchasing the produce.

On 31 May 2024, health workers, mainly members of the KUCO, marched towards the governor's office in Eldoret town (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against their employment terms. Led by the union officials, the group demanded both the county and national government to confirm the Universal health coverage (UHC) staff on permanent and pensionable terms as well as provision of comprehensive medical cover among others.

On 31 May 2024, public service vehicles (matatus) and taxis blocked roads (means unspecified) within Meru town (Igembe North, Meru) in demonstration against alleged harassment by county officials. Police officers used tear gas to disperse the group.
On 31 May 2024, residents marched on the streets of Malindi town (Malindi, Kilifi) in support of the county government's move to ban Muguka. The group demanded the sale of Muguka stopped.

Around 1 June 2024 (as reported), tea farmers protested at the Kianjagi tea buying Centre near Gatwe (Kirinyaga Central, Kirinyaga) against Mununga tea factory management, following the suspension of their committee representatives. The group demanded the representatives reinstated.

On 1 June 2024, health workers, mainly members of the KUCO, marched towards the county assembly and county government headquarters in Kericho (Ainamoi, Kericho) against their employment terms. Led by the union officials, the group demanded the county government to confirm the Universal health coverage (UHC) staff on permanent and pensionable terms.

On 1 June 2024, tens of activists under 'The Concerned Citizens Kenya' and 'Linda Jamii' initiatives, among them a lawyer and a businessman, marched from Kaloleni social hall to the Treasury building in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the government's proposed tax measures. Police intervened and dispersed them by arresting four people. Two motorcycles were also impounded by the police during the incident.

On 2 June 2024, residents, mainly family members, protested outside the Kiamaciri (also known as Kiamachiri) police station (Kirinyaga North, Kirinyaga) against the alleged escape from police custody of a farmhand suspected of killing his employer. The group demanded justice and the suspect rearrested.

On 3 June 2024, residents marched in Kapsengere (Aldai, Nandi) against poor medical services, following the delayed completion of a local hospital as well as poor road network. The group demanded the county government to help address their grievances.

On 3 June 2024, a group of Junior Secondary School (JSS) intern teachers from Nyamira County protested in Nyamira (Nyamira, Nyamira) against the recent return to work formula signed by the Kenya Union of Post Primary Education Teachers (KUPPET) officials on their behalf. The group demanded the government, through the Teachers' Service Commission (TSC), to grant them permanent and pensionable terms.

On 3 June 2024, residents forced their way (means unspecified) into Machakos police station (Machakos, Machakos) against the death of a public service vehicle (matatu) driver, moments after being arrested by county enforcement officers. The group demanded answers from the county officers.

On 3 June 2024, over 3000 members of the Ntulele adjudication section protested in Ntulele also known as Ntulelei (Narok East, Narok) against a recent a court verdict to subdivide their 56,000-acre land to 2,222 members, alleging it may trigger interclan fighting among the Purko, ildamat and Keekonyokie clans. Led by the area member of county assembly (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded the court verdict overturned.

On 3 June 2024, health workers, mainly members of the KUCO from Kilifi county, marched to the county government offices in Kilifi (Kilifi North, Kilifi) against their employment terms. Led by the union officials, the group demanded better pay and improved working conditions.

On 3 June 2024, residents, mainly women traders, gathered in Voi (Voi, Taita, Taveta) in support of the ban on the sale, distribution and consumption of muguka by the governors of the Coastal counties. The group demanded other political leaders to support the ban.

On 3 June 2024, over 1200 Junior Secondary School (JSS) intern teachers protested in Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi) against the move by the Kenya Union of Post Primary Education Teachers (KUPPET) to call off their strike, alleging that their representatives were not involved. The group demanded the government, through the Teachers' Service Commission (TSC), to address their grievances by granting them permanent and pensionable employment terms, among others.

On 3 June 2024, health workers, mainly members of the KUCO from Machakos, Kitui, and Makueni counties, marched from Wote Green Park to the governor's office in Wote (Makueni, Makueni) against their employment terms. Led by the union officials, the group demanded the better terms of service.

On 4 June 2024, a group of KCCA cleaners protested against delayed salary payment at the KCCA offices in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala). The police intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the protesters and an unspecified number of them was arrested.

On 4 June 2024, residents of Alamata town staged a peaceful demonstration in Alamata (Alamata town, Southern Tigray, Tigray), requesting the withdrawal of TPLF forces from the city. The demonstrators rounded the main road of Alamata and shouted their slogans before ENDF and federal police camps.

On 4 June 2024, health workers, mainly members of the KUCO from Elgeyo Marakwet county, marched in an unspecified location (coded to the county headquarters as Iten, Keiyo North, Elgeyo Marakwet) against their employment terms. Led by the union officials, the group demanded the county government to grant them permanent and pensionable terms.

On 4 June 2024, hundreds of residents protested in Maparasha (Kajiado Central, Kajiado) against the introduction of water tariffs in the area. The group demanded both the national and county government to help address the matter.

On 4 June 2024, about 200 women vegetable vendors, led by activist and comedian Eric Omondi, protested outside parliament building in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the government's proposed tax measures. Police intervened and arrested the comedian.

On 4 June 2024, health workers, mainly members of the KUCO, marched in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against their employment terms. Led by the union officials, the group demanded the county governments to confirm the Universal health coverage (UHC) staff on permanent and pensionable terms among others.

On 4 June 2024, human rights defenders, mainly members of the Sauti ya Wanawake- a civil society organization, protested in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against alleged assault of a domestic worker by two civil servants. The group demanded the inspector general of police to order for the arrest of the two civil servants.

Around 5 June 2024 (as reported), over 400 Junior Secondary School (JSS) intern teachers protested in Lodwar (Lodwar Central, Lodwar) against their employment terms. The group demanded better pay as well as employment on permanent and pensionable terms.

Around 5 June 2024 (as reported), residents gathered in Uyombo (Kilifi North, Kilifi) against police brutality witnessed during a recent demonstration against the proposed nuclear project (coded separately). Joined by human rights defenders, the group demanded the Kenya National Human Rights Commission (KNHRC) to investigate the matter as well as the Independent Policing Oversight Authority (IPOA) to help address the matter.

On 6 June 2024, hundreds of residents, mainly women, marched at Garage market near Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against increased alcoholism. The group demanded the county government to close down all bars in the area.

Around 6 June 2024 (as reported), coffee farmers under the Mutira farmers' cooperative society, protested in Mutitu (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) against alleged low-rate payment of their produce. Led by their member of county assembly (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded factory management to address the issue as well as the board and Savings and Credit Cooperative Organization (SACCO) books audited.

On 6 June 2024, members of the civil society protested outside the parliament building in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the government's proposed tax measures. Led by Bunge la Mwananchi, the group demanded the proposals, amended.
On 7 June 2024, a group of farmers uprooted 150 acres of tea gardens in protest over reduced prices of tea leaves at the processing factories in Mpugu sub county coded to Kanungu (Kinkizi, Knungu).

Around 7 June 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Ngomano (Kitui South, Kitui) against alleged illegal land grabbing by unknown people. The group demanded their political leaders to help address the matter.

On 7 June 2024, more than 200 residents of Maroro and Bulla Baraka floods displacement camp marched to the office of the deputy county commissioner (DCC) in Bangale (Bura, Tana River) against alleged move by political leaders to oppose their relocation to safer ground. Led by human rights defenders, the group demanded the DCC to help address the matter.
On 7 June 2024, residents blocked (through unspecified means) the road from Mazimbu to Lukobe (Morogoro Urban, Morogoro) to demand road repairs, complaining about its poor condition.

Around 7 June 2024 (as reported), UDA supporters gathered in Busia town (Matayos, Busia) against alleged interference in the running of the party affairs in the county, by the party national secretary general and a permanent secretary, ahead of party elections in August. The group demanded the two officials stopped.

On 7 June 2024, a group of Junior Secondary School (JSS) intern teachers marched and camped outside the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) offices in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against their employment terms. The group demanded the government, through the TSC, to grant them permanent and pensionable employment terms.

Around 7 June 2024 (as reported), Moi University lecturers gathered and sang solidarity songs at the university in Kesses (Kesses, Uasin Gishu) against delayed pay. The group demanded the university management address the matter.

On 8 June 2024, and for two days, thousands of ethnic Amhara residents staged a demonstration in Alamata (Alamata town, Southern Tigray, Tigray) to denounce killings and abuses by Tigray forces. The demonstrations were triggered by the killing of a worker of Ethiopian Electric Utility in the town (coded separately).

On 8 June 2024, several residents, including civil servants and the Governor of Banadir Region and the Mayor of Mogadishu, protested in Mogadishu - Abdiaziz (Banadir) to express their appreciation and support for the Somalia admission to the UN security council.
On 8 June 2024, a group of residents protested in Oyam county headquarters, coded to Abok (Oyam, Oyam), demanding compensation for relatives killed during LRA insurgency.

Around 8 June 2024 (as reported), traders, joined by human rights defenders, marched from the market to the county assembly in Kericho town (Ainamoi, Kericho) against the move by the county government to increase levies. The group demanded the governor and members of the county assembly to help address the matter.

On 9 June 2024, for a second day, thousands of residents of Alamata town protested in Alamata (Southern Tigray, Tigray), against the presence of TPLF forces and the alleged killing of an electricity worker by the TPLF militants (coded separately). The protesters called for their withdrawal from Alamata and its surrounding areas. The TPLF forces who were camped in a nearby school opened fire and killed a protester and wounded another.

On 9 June 2024, UDA -Kenya Kwanza delegates allied to the Embakasi Member of Parliament (MP) gathered in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the postponement and occasioned delays in the party city elections. The group demanded a speedy resolution of the matter.

On 10 June 2024, a group of youth protested in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), against US sanctions against the Speaker of the Ugandan Parliament, Ms. Anita Amongi. She and several other former and current government officials were barred from traveling to the US over involvement in 'significant corruption' tied to their leadership and 'gross human rights abuse.
On 10 June 2024, parents protested at Ithimani primary school (Kitui Central, Kitui) against alleged poor leadership by the head teacher. The group demanded the headteacher transferred.
On 10 June 2024, long distant truck drivers gathered in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against poor working conditions and delayed pay. The group demanded for a return-to-work formula with the employer.

Around 10 June 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly boda boda taxi operators, protested in Ndhiwa (Ndhiwa, Homa Bay) against the poor state of Otochogo Gina road. The group demanded their political leaders to address the matter.

On 10 June 2024, human rights defenders gathered in Bungoma town (Kanduyi, Bungoma) against increased cases of gender-based violence in the county. The group demanded the chief justice to ensure justice for the victims.

Around 10 June 2024 (as reported), residents of Embakasi North marched to the Milimani law courts in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against unfair distribution of National Government Constituencies Development Fund (NG-CDF) by their area Member of Parliament (MP). The group which joined the judiciary open day celebrations, demanded the MP to be investigated.

On 11 June 2024, students of Achiya Echakara Kamuriai secondary, joined by Alumni members, marched from the school to the deputy county commissioner's offices in Amagoro (Teso North, Busia) against the nullification of their football victory by the Kenya Secondary Schools Sports Association (KSSSA). The group demanded their victory upheld.
Around 11 June 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Katumba (Kitui Rural, Kitui) against the planned move to construct a police station in the area. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

Around 11 June 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly members of the Samburu pastoral community, marched to Rumuruti police station (Laikipia West, Laikipia) against the killing of their kin by a police reservist (coded separately). Led by the area member of county assembly, the group demanded the police to investigate the matter.

On 11 June 2024, Kilifi county Members of County Assembly (MCAs) gathered outside the assembly chambers in Kilifi (Kilifi North, Kilifi) against the arrest of their colleague, following a land conflict that led to the death of a resident (coded separately). Led by Ganze and Marikani wards MCAs, the group demanded the police to release their colleague.

On 11 June 2024, hundreds of farmers protested in Garissa (Garissa, Garissa) against alleged government neglect of their agricultural concerns, following the recent flooding. The group demanded for compensation as well as the government to develop a sustainable solution to flooding.

On 12 June 2024, residents (likely supporters of Isiolo county senator-Jubilee, Azimio- since they are defending her) marched in Isiolo town (Isiolo, Isiolo) against alleged gross misconduct of the county governor, after he insulted the senator. The group demanded the governor to respect all the leaders as well as the members of the county assembly to impeach the governor.

On 12 June 2024, residents, mainly farmers, protested in Kahura area of Nanyuki (Laikipia East, Laikipia) against alleged unfair eviction from the forest by Kenya Forest Association (KFA) officials. The group demanded the Kenya Forest Service to allow them into the forest to harvest their crops.

Around 12 June 2024 (as reported), more than 4000 farmers from Kanagoni, Garite and Bundasaga gathered and chanted in Mkono wa Jongoo (coded to the nearest known location as Magarini, Magarini, Kilifi) against alleged land seizure in the salt belt by the rich. The group demanded the government to help address the matter.

On 12 June 2024, a group of residents accompanied by their MP protested in Jinja (Jinja, Jinja), against the move by the Uganda National Farmers' Federation-UNFFE, to relocate the national students' agricultural exhibition to Bukalasa agricultural college in Luwero district instead of Jinja.

On 12 June 2024, residents, joined by local leaders, including a former Mwea member of parliament and a former deputy governor, blocked the Kutus - Kimbimbi - Togonye - road with stones at Murinduko (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) in demonstration against the move by the national budget committee to re-allocate of funds meant for its tarmacking. The group demanded the committee to re-assign the money meant for the road's completion and the contractor to embark on the tarmacking.

On 13 June 2024, a group of musicians protested in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the proposal by the Kenya Copyright Board (KECOBO) to appoint Kenya's performing and audio-visual rights society (PAVRISK) to collect their royalties. The group demanded for the resignation of the KECOBO chairman.

Around 13 June 2024 (as reported), a group of young leaders gathered and chanted in an unspecified location within the Mt Kenya region (coded to the nearest known location as Thika, Thika Town, Thika) against alleged move by politicians to humiliate and undermine the Deputy President (DP). The group demanded the DP to be respected by all.

On 14 June 2024, students from various universities in Uganda protested against the EACOP (East African Crude Oil Pipeline) project at the Ugandan Human Rights Commission in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala).

On 14 June 2024, residents of Timuga staged a peaceful demonstration in Timuga (Raya Alamata, Southern Tigray, Tigray), opposing the occupation of Raya by TPLF forces, reconfirming their identities as Amhara, and asking the federal government to honor the Pretoria agreement.

On 14 June 2024, residents of Waja town staged a peaceful demonstration in Waja (Raya Alamata, Southern Tigray, Tigray), opposing the occupation of Raya by TPLF forces, reconfirming their identities as Amhara, and asking the federal government to honor the Pretoria agreement.

On 14 June 2024, health workers, mainly members of the KUCO, protested in Kiambu town (Kiambu town, Kiambu) against their employment terms. Led by the union officials, the group demanded better pay among others.

On 14 June 2024, human rights activists marched to the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions (ODPP) in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against alleged assault of a domestic worker by two civil servants. The group demanded the ODPP to take action against the two civil servants.

On 15 June 2024, a group of residents protested in Kole (Kole, Kole), against the arrest of their own. The police fired live bullets to disperse the crowd. A stray bullet hit and killed a resident who was not part of the protest. This enraged the protesters further causing them to threaten to lynch the policeman who shot the victim.
On 16 June 2024, a group of NRM youth protested in the city of Gulu (Gulu, Gulu), against corrupt leaders.
Around 16 June 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Ole Serini near Gilgil (Gilgil, Nakuru) against the poor state of the roads. The group demanded the county government to fix the roads.

Around 16 June 2024 (as reported), judges, magistrates and judiciary staff members, gathered at the doorstep of the Nairobi's Milimani courts (Starehe, Nairobi) against poor working conditions, following the recent killing of their colleague (coded separately). The group demanded for a better working environment.

On 16 June 2024, residents of Banissa constituency protested in an unspecified location (coded to the nearest known location as Banissa, Banissa, Mandera) against their lack of representation in parliament, following the death of their member of parliament. Led by Banissa ward member of county assembly (UDM, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded the government to set-up the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) to organize for the election of a new representative.

On 16 June 2024, members of KNUT from West Pokot county gathered and sang solidarity songs in Kapenguria (West Pokot, West Pokot) against the shortage of teachers in the county. The group demanded the Teachers' Service Commission (TSC) to address the matter.

On 17 June 2024, residents protested in Kiunga village near Kagio town (Kirinyaga West, Kirinyaga) against prolonged power outage. The group demanded the Kenya power and lighting company to restore power in the area.

On 17 June 2024, residents gathered in Kibwaga village near Tiwi (Matuga, Kwale) against alleged grabbing of community land by a private developer. The group demanded the authorities to help address the matter.

On 17 June 2024, Sudanese refugees in Kumer closed a road outside their camp (means unspecified) in Metema woreda (West Gondar, Amhara), and protested the refusal of Ethiopian authorities to hand over the body of the deceased woman shot and killed by unidentified gunmen a day ago (coded separately). The protesters demanded authorities address problems with security and the delivery of essential services and called on the international community to return them to their country. The Ethiopian Refugees and Returnees Service (RRS) responded by announcing plans to relocate Sudanese refugees in the Amhara region.

On 17 June 2024, dozens of residents blocked the main feeder road in the Acacia neighborhoods in Kitengela (Kajiado East, Kajiado) against poor workmanship by the contractor, alleging embezzlement of funds. The group demanded the road to be re-done.

On 17 June 2024, residents protested in Lunerere village near Bushiangala (Ikolomani, Kakamega) against the planned move by a mining company to displace them, to pave way for mining. The group demanded the company to suspend its activities in the area.

Around 18 June 2024 (as reported), UDA delegates from Embakasi East constituency gathered in an unspecified location (coded as Nairobi - Embakasi East; Embakasi East; Nairobi) against the party's move to call for a rerun of the previous party election. Led by the party's Chairperson in the area, the group demanded the president to help address their grievances.

On 18 June 2024, roadside traders protested at the Transami stage within Nairobi - Embakasi South (Embakasi South, Nairobi) against the demolition of their stalls by the city council. The group demanded their area member of county assembly and the governor to help address the matter.

On 18 June 2024, residents gathered at the Railways terminus in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against the government's proposed tax measures. The group demanded members of parliament to reject the proposals.

On 18 June 2024, judges, magistrates, lawyers and other judiciary staff marched in Eldoret town (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the against the recent killing of their colleague (coded separately). The group demanded the judicial service commission to provide protection for judicial officers.

On 18 June 2024, judicial officers and advocates, joined by the Law Society of Kenya (LSK) Chairman Embu chapter, walked from the Embu Law Courts along Embu-Meru Highway to Embu town and back to the law courts in Embu (Manyatta, Embu) against the against the recent killing of their colleague (coded separately). The group demanded the judicial service commission to provide protection for judicial officers.

On 18 June 2024, hundreds of residents, mainly youth organized under the 'Occupy Parliament,' banner, joined by human rights activists and celebrities, protested in Nairobi Central Business District (Starehe, Nairobi) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. Police lobbed teargas canisters, used water cannons, and live bullets to disperse the group and arrested more than 210 people, including journalists and observers. Several police officers and protesters sustained injuries (one police officer was severely injured after he detonated a tear gas canister and delayed releasing it).

On 18 June 2024, a group of women protested along parliament road in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the ongoing demolitions, following a government directive to demolish properties in the city center. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group. Some protestors sustained injuries.

On 18 June 2024, a dozen lawyers forced their way into the Nairobi central police station (Starehe, Nairobi) against the move by the police to arrest demonstrators during the protests against the government's proposed tax measures (coded separately). Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 19 June 2024, hundreds of residents, joined by MUHURI representatives, gathered and marched in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. Police lobbed teargas canisters (including into the nearby Coast girls high school) to disperse the group.

On 19 June 2024, around 150 lawyers and law students marched to the office of the county commissioner in Kisii town (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against the low levels of security accorded to courts and judicial officers, following the recent killing of a magistrate (coded separately). The group demanded the government to provide adequate security as well as release funds meant for the development of the regional courts.

On 19 June 2024, health workers, mainly members of the KUCO, protested in Eldoret town (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against their employment terms. Led by the union officials, the group demanded the county governments to confirm the Universal health coverage (UHC) staff on permanent and pensionable terms, among others.
On 19 June 2024, health workers gathered at the Cheptais hospital (Cheptais, Bungoma) against delayed pay. The group demanded the hospital board to address the matter.

On 20 June 2024, for the second day, hundreds of residents, mainly youth, joined by human rights activists from Muhuri, gathered at the Mapembeni area along Moi Avenue, before marching to the Mombasa county assembly, the governor's offices and later camped outside the Coast provincial headquarters in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded members of parliament to reject the proposals.

On 20 June 2024, residents, mainly youth, blocked a road with stones in Narok town (Narok North, Narok) in demonstration against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. Police used unspecified means to disperse the group, and attempted to arrest some of the demonstrators.

On 20 June 2024, residents, mainly youth, marched in Kisii town (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded members of parliament to reject the proposals.

On 20 June 2024, residents gathered in Kiambaa (Kiambaa, Kiambu) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded their member of parliament to reject the proposals.

On 20 June 2024, hundreds of civilians protested in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed), demanding the release of a prominent member of the political opposition Wadani National Party, arrested by police upon his arrival at Hargeisa airport. Somaliland police forces fired several shots in the air to disperse the demonstrators. No injuries were reported.
On 20 June 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Mbale town (Vihiga, Vihiga) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. Police intervened and arrested four people.

On 20 June 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Isiolo (Isiolo, Isiolo) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded members of parliament to reject the proposals.

On 20 June 2024, residents, mainly the youth, marched in Nanyuki town (Laikipia East, Laikipia) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded members of parliament to reject the proposals.

On 2 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, blocked the Homa Bay-Rongo road with stones in Homa Bay (Homa Bay Town, Homa Bay) in demonstration against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded the president to resign.
On 2 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, marched in Kilifi (Kilifi North, Kilifi) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded the president to resign.

On 2 July 2024, scores of residents, mainly youth, gathered near Eldoret shuttle bus stage (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded the president to resign. They were dispersed by police (means not specified).

On 2 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Nyeri town (Nyeri Central, Nyeri) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 2 July 2024, hundreds of residents gathered at different locations including Kondele, Nyamasaria, Juakali, Otonglo, and Buspark before marching to the city Centre and Kisumu state lodge (Kisumu Central. Kisumu) in solidarity with persons killed as a result of police actions during the recent anti-finance bill unrest as well as against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded the president to resign.

On 2 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Kanduyi (Kanduyi, Bungoma) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded that the government address their grievances. Protesters engaged with police (no further information).

On 2 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, blocked (means unspecified) the Mombasa Malindi Highway at an unspecified location (coded as Malindi, Malindi, Kilifi) in demonstration against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded the president to resign.

On 2 July 2024, thousands of residents, mainly youth, protested in Wote town (Makueni, Makueni) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded the government to address their grievances.

On 3 July 2024, residents of Boku Shenen sub-city/Torban Obo woreda blocked roads with stones and woods in Adama town, Adama town (East Shewa, Oromia), blocked bulldozers from passing, and demonstrated against the demolition of 1500 houses that were considered 'illegal' by the city administration. Federal police, Oromia regional state police, and Kebele militias fired live ammunition to clear the blockade, resulting in at least one individual being killed (some sources mentioned 3 or 7) and seven others being injured and hospitalized.

On 3 July 2024, Ilkiremisho community members protested at Tipis town near Ilmashariani (Narok North, Narok) against alleged mismanagement of resources at the Purko group ranch by the Purko development trust board. The group demanded the board disbanded, among others.

On 3 July 2024, mini-van and tuk-tuk drivers protested in Gaalkacyo town (Gaalkacyo, Mudug) against the increased tax from the local administrations. Police disperse the protesters with gunfire, no further information.
On 3 July 2024, a group of about a hundred residents protested against the mismanagement of funds to maintain roads in Amolatar (Kioga, Amolatar). The Police intervened and foiled the protest.
On 3 July 2024, a group of residents protested against the bad state of roads in Banda (Kampala, Kampala). No further details.

On 3 July 2024, supporters of the UDA-Kenya Kwanza party marched while waving placards in Kericho (Ainamoi, Kericho) in support of the re-erection of their party symbol (a wheelbarrow on a pole) that was vandalized during the recent anti-finance bill protests. The group demanded the anti-government protestors to respect the government.

Around 4 July 2024 (as reported), a group of fishers protested at Kokwa island (Marigat, Baringo) against the move by the government fishery officials to regulate the type of net for fishing. The group demanded the fishery officer transferred.

Around 4 July 2024 (as reported), mourners interrupted a memorial service by chanting slogans at the St. Stephen's Cathedral Church, Jogoo Road in Nairobi - Makadara (Makadara, Nairobi) in solidarity with their kin, who was recently killed as a result of police actions during the recent anti-finance bill unrest (further details unknown/not reported). The group demanded justice for the deceased.
On 4 July 2024, a group of residents protested eviction threats in Bar-Dege (Aswa, Gulu) by the Uganda Railways Corporation (URC).

On 4 July 2024, Standard Group Media journalists, including presenters from Radio Maisha, Spice FM, Berur FM and Vybez Radio, staged a walk- out, before gathering at the staff cafeteria in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against delayed pay. The group demanded the company management to obey their contractual agreements.

Around 4 July 2024 (as reported), a group of parents protested at Rwanyange Primary School (Imenti North, Meru) against poor management, following the drowning of a grade 7 pupil in a water tank. The group demanded the head teacher be transferred.

Around 5 July 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Kakuzi near Muti (Gatanga, Muranga) against the alleged move by their area Member of Parliament (MP) to neglect them development-wise, following the poor state of roads in the area among others. The group demanded the MP to resign as well as the constituency to be split into two.

Around 5 July 2024 (as reported), hundreds of residents, marched, while singing and chanting in Mbita (Mbita, Homa Bay) in solidarity with a victim, who was recently killed as a result of police actions during the recent anti-finance bill unrest (further details unknown/not reported). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

Around 5 July 2024 (as reported), persons living with disabilities, gathered and lit candles in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) in solidarity with their colleague, who was recently killed as a result of police actions during the recent anti-finance bill unrest.

On 5 July 2024, residents disrupted a funeral service by chanting anti-president slogans at a Cabinet Secretary (CS) in Kianjoya (Nyeri Central, Nyeri). It is unclear whether the chants are related to the ongoing protests against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The CS had to cut short his speech.

Around 5 July 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly youth, gathered, while waving the country flag in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) against alleged move by politicians to hire 'goons' to infiltrate their ongoing anti-tax protests. The group demanded politicians to stop using anti-tax protests to settle political scores.

On 6 July 2024, Sudanese refugees demonstrated in Awlala Akushara, Metema woreda (West Gondar, Amhara) and demanded the release of a refugee who was abducted by unidentified gunmen (coded separately). The protesters criticized the Ethiopian government and international organizations for failing to protect them and hold kidnappers accountable.
Around 6 July 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Mikindani (Jomvu, Mombasa) against water shortage. The group demanded the county government to address the matter.

On 6 July 2024, truck drivers and other transporters blocked the Malindi-Garsen highway with their vehicles at Sabaki bridge (Magarini, Kilifi) against the recent county directive to implement a dusk-to-dawn collection of cess. The group demanded the governor to revise the directive.
On 7 July 2024, a group of residents protested in Karengyere (Rubanda, Rubanda), against the possibility of Naro evicting them.

On 7 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Ongata Rongai (Loitokitok, Kajiado) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. Two unidentified men (likely police officers who have been suspected of being involved in similar abductions during demonstrations) abducted a 19-year-old young male. No further information on the abductee's whereabouts.

On 7 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Kitengela (Kajiado East, Kajiado) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. Police intervened and fired live bullets to disperse the group. At least 1 person was shot dead during the incident.

On 7 July 2024, youth disrupted a church service by chanting anti-president slogans at the holy family basilica in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi). It is unclear whether the chants are related to the ongoing protests against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024.
On 8 July 2024, demobilized TDF soldiers staged a demonstration in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), demanding the payment of their salaries overdue for over a year.

On 8 July 2024, over 2,000 residents of Timobo, Siwo, Chepkunyuk, and Kapchorua, including causal workers, protested in an unspecified location within Kapchorua ward (coded to the nearest known location as Kapchorua, Nandi East, Nandi) against labor exploitation by the Kapchorua tea factory. The group demanded the factory management to respect the rights of residents and workers.

On 8 July 2024, hundreds of residents, mainly youth, marched in Kakuma (Turkana West, Turkana) against the move by non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and other development agencies to discriminate youth in their operations. The group demanded transparency and equity in job opportunities.

On 8 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, marched to their Member of Parliament (MP) constituency office in Nyamarambe (South Mugirango, Kisii) against the recent move by the MP to vote in favor of the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. Youth allied to the MP (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) confronted and injured some of the protestors while the police lobbed teargas to disperse the protestors.

On 8 July 2024, hundreds of medical, dental, and pharmacy interns, joined by other youth, gathered and camped outside the Ministry of Health headquarters in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against delayed posting. The group then demanded immediate posting and payments as well as the resignation of the health cabinet secretary.

On 8 July 2024, traders and farmers of the Simu2000 market closed their business and blocked a road (means unspecified) in Ubungo (Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam), demanding the Ubungo Municipality to cancel its decision to pass an area of the market to the Bus Rapid Transit Agency (DART) so the Bus Agency can build a garage.

Around 9 July 2024 (as reported), protesters disrupted a bursary distribution exercise by chanting anti-president slogans at a member of parliament in the Soweto neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi East (Embakasi East, Nairobi) against the government's proposed tax measures in the finance bill 2024. The group demanded their grievances addressed including the resignation of the president.

On 9 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, including boda boda taxi operators and college students, blocked the Kapsabet-Eldoret highway using unspecified means, as they marched to and camped outside the office of the governor in Kapsabet town (Chesumei, Nandi) against delayed implementation of projects, shortage of drugs in hospitals, impassable roads, irregularities in employment of county staff among other grievances. The group demanded the governor to address their grievances.
On 9 July 2024, a group of Kampala city cleaners protested delayed salary payment in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala).

On 9 July 2024, students protested in Buuhoodle town (Buuhoodle, Togdheer) against the 8th-grade examinations. Police fired shots in the air to disperse the crowd and injured a female protestor (through unspecified means).

On 9 July 2024, parents protested at the Mwamunga comprehensive school in Voi (Voi, Taita Taveta) against the mismanagement of funds by the school's head teacher and the board of management. The group demanded the head teacher to resign.

On 9 July 2024, for the second day, medical, dental, and pharmacy interns, joined by other youth, gathered and camped outside the Ministry of Health headquarters in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against delayed posting. The group the demanded for immediate posting and payments as well as the resignation of the health cabinet secretary.

On 9 July 2024, a prison warder and his supporters demonstrated at the senate gate in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the recent killings as a result of police actions during the recent anti-finance bill unrest. Police intervened and arrested the warder.

Around 9 July 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly youth, camped outside the Sirende ward Member of County Assembly (MCA)'s office in Sirende (Kiminini, Trans Nzoia) against increased unemployment, accusing the MCA of failed leadership. The group demanded the MCA to address their grievances.

On 10 July 2024, youth (likely Wiper- Azimio party supporters, since some of them were wearing the party's scarfs) forced their way (means unknown/not reported) into the party's offices in the Karen neighborhoods of Nairobi - Langata (Langata, Nairobi) against the recent comment by one of the party Members of Parliament (MP) on handling of anti-government tax protests, where he alluded that he would have engaged in mass killings to punish the protesters. The group demanded the MP to resign as well as to be expelled from the party.

On 10 July 2024, youth (described as volunteers) protested outside the offices of the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection in Kangundo (Kangundo, Machakos) against delayed pay of their allowances. Protesters did not engage with the police.

On 10 July 2024, parents protested at the Rev. Canon Kuri Memorial Secondary School near Mazeras (Rabai, Kilifi) against poor education standards. The group demanded the school principal be transferred.
On 10 July 2024, a group of residents protested in Nakuwadde (Busiro, Wakiso), against the marking of their houses for demolition by the National Environment Management Authority (NEMA).

On 11 July 2024, residents, mainly internally displaced persons from the recent flooding forced their way into Gachie police station (Kiambaa, Kiambu) against the move by their political leaders to delay the distribution of humanitarian food. The group demanded for the food.

On 11 July 2024, a group of residents protested marching to the Chairperson's office in Ganda (Bukomansimbi, Bukomansimbi), against officials from the National Environment Management Authority (NEMA) who had marked their houses for demolition. The police intervened firing teargas to disperse the protesters.

Around 11 July 2024 (as reported), Kapsimbiri secondary school parents and students protested outside the office of the County Director of Education in Bomet (Bomet East, Bomet) against the disqualification of the school football team and a ban from future competitions, for fielding ineligible players. The group demanded the decision be reversed.

On 11 July 2024, students protested at the Borabu Technical Training Institute (Borabu, Nyamira) against increased insecurity, following the recent incident where three of their female colleagues were sexually assaulted. The group demanded the security agencies to address their grievances.

On 11 July 2024, parents and Board of Management (BOM) representatives, blocked the principal's office using timber at Isiolo boys' high school (Isiolo, Isiolo) in demonstration against the move by the Teachers' Service Commission (TSC) to post a new principal, accused of poor performance in his previous stations. Led by the BOM chairman and Parents and Teachers' Association chairman, the group demanded the commission to address the matter.

On 11 July 2024, more than 800 traders blocked a road (means unspecified) close to CCM Headquarters in Dar es Salaam (Ilala, Dar es Salaam), demanding the leadership of the Karikaoo market to include their names in a list published by the market managers containing the names of traders who could return to the market. The traders were removed from the market following a fire that destroyed it in July 2021.

On 11 July 2024, more than 50 workers allied to a sunflower oil and cottonseed oil factory marched and camped outside the regional commissioner's office in Shinyanga (Shinyanga Urban, Shinyanga) in protest against delayed pay. The group demanded that the commissioner help address the matter.

On 12 July 2024, hundreds of students at Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology blocked a section of the Thika highway using unspecified means, as they marched from the institution towards Juja police station (Juja, Kiambu) in solidarity with their colleague, who was recently abducted and killed as a result of police actions during the recent anti-finance bill unrest (further details unknown/not reported). The group demanded justice and accountability.

On 12 July 2024, residents forced their way into a police station (means unspecified) within the Kware neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi South (Embakasi South, Nairobi) against the killing and dumping of at least nine bodies at a dumpsite. Police lobbed teargas and fired in the air to disperse the group.

On 12 July 2024, a group of residents protested the arrest of their fellow in Tebu coded to Apac (Apac, Apac). During the resistance, the police officer shot and seriously injured, in alleged self-defense, a protester who was allegedly trying to disarm him. The two officers have been arrested for excessive use of force, as well as some of the protesters who allegedly obstructed justice.
On 12 July 2024, a group of residents protested against the threat of eviction from their land in Mpunge (Mukono, Mukono), to develop a project called ''Akon City' funded by the USA musician Akon.

On 12 July 2024, students protested outside the Kenya school of law offices at the Karen office park in the Nairobi - Langata neighborhood (Langata, Nairobi) against grade irregularities and corruption among officials. The group demanded to meet the chief executive officer as well as the disbandment of the council for legal education.

On 12 July 2024, residents, with placards, protested outside the Parliament in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala) to present a petition against an MP whom they accused of different irregularities. They were ushered into Parliament with their placards (means unclear).

Around 12 July 2024 (as reported), Suna East constituency residents, including boda boda taxi operators, blocked an unspecified road within the constituency by planting unknown plants (coded to the nearest known location as Got-Jope, Suna East, Migori) against the poor state of Migori-Ngege, Uyoma road and Mabera-Got Jobe road. The group demanded their area member of parliament to fix the roads.

On 12 July 2024, youth, mainly students from technical training institutes, marched to and camped at the governor's office, with some attempting to force their way into the governor's office (means unspecified), in Mbale (Vihiga, Vihiga) against mismanaging county funds. The group demanded the governor to address their grievances. Protesters engaged with security officers (no further information).

On 12 July 2024, residents of Taveta constituency, including traders and MUHURI representatives, protested in an undisclosed location (coded to the nearest known location as Taveta, Taveta, Taita Taveta) against poor service delivery. The group demanded their area member of parliament to address their grievances.

Around 12 July 2024 (as reported), grain traders blocked the Holili-Moshi highway (means unspecified) at the border of Holili (Rombo, Kilimanjaro), demanding the Rombo District Council to remove a tax imposed for cars transporting corn that access the Holili grain market. The road was closed by the traders for more than two hours. The Head of Rombo District talked to the traders and agreed to reduce the tax.

On 13 July 2024, residents and parents protested at Kapsamich primary school, Kipsamich (Keiyo South, Elgeyo Marakwet) against the move by a private developer to grab school land. The group demanded the political leaders and the government to help address the matter.

On 13 July 2024, residents, mainly internally displaced persons from the recent flooding, attempted to force their way into Kihara police station (Kiambaa, Kiambu) against the move by their political leaders to delay the distribution of humanitarian food. The group demanded for the food.

On 13 July 2024, thousands of residents, mainly boda boda taxi operators, joined by the Kikumbulyu south member of county assembly (Muungano, Azimio) and marched from Kibwezi to Makindu (Kibwezi West, Makueni) against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of over 5 (other sources mention over 10) youth by criminal. The group demanded justice for the victims as well as transfer of the police officers.
Around 13 July 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Nyandwir village near Sifuyo (Ugenya, Siaya) against poor road network. The group demanded the relevant authorities to address the matter.

Around 13 July 2024 (as reported), public service commission interns gathered in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the move by the commission to deny them jobs at the end of their internship. The group demanded the commission and the government to offer them job opportunities.

On 13 July 2024, student leaders marched at the university of Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the new funding model, as well as poor leadership, following an ongoing leadership dispute. The group demanded the president to help address their grievances.

On 14 July 2024, residents protested in Jidali village (Ceerigaabo, Sanaag) to support Sool, Sanaag and Cayn - Khatumo state administration. Somaliland forces fired shots in the air to disperse the crowd. No injuries were reported.

On 14 July 2024, digital taxi drivers gathered and sang solidarity songs in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against unfair pricing by the application company. The group demanded the government to help address the matter.

On 14 July 2024, residents marched while chanting anti-government slogans from the Kware area of Mukuru slums up to the city mortuary in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the president Wiliam Ruto government, following the discovery of dead bodies dumped at a dumpsite in their area (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the victims.

On 14 July 2024, a group of teachers protested in front of the Ministry of Education, Culture, and Higher Education, in Mogadishu - Hodan (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle) against their dismissal from government schools and claimed that the government replaced them with other teachers.

On 14 July 2024, students protested outside the classrooms at Ragana girls' secondary school near Suna (Suna West, Migori) against lack of clean water, food, poor dormitory conditions and worship hours. The group demanded the school administration to address the matter. The school was later closed indefinitely.

On 15 July 2024, residents, including boda boda taxi operators, protested in Mwania Kaharo area of Ithanga near Gatanga (Gatanga, Muranga) against poor road network. The group demanded their elected leaders to address the matter.

On 15 July 2024, residents, with placards, protested outside the Parliament in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala) to present a petition against an MP whom they accused of different irregularities. The residents were ushered into Parliament with their placards (means unclear).

On 15 July 2024, Ruai girls' secondary school students, chanted during morning assembly, at the institution, within the Nairobi - Kasarani neighborhoods (Kasarani, Nairobi) in protest against poor management. The group demanded the school administration to address their grievances.

On 15 July 2024, youth allied to UDA-Kenya Kwanza gathered in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in support of the Principal Secretary (PS) for interior and national security Raymond Omollo. The group demanded the president to promote the PS to a full cabinet secretary position.

On 15 July 2024, teachers under KUPPET, forced their way into Minet insurance company offices, before ejecting the staff and locking the doors in Kakamega town (Lurambi, Kakamega) against negligence of the insurance broker, following the death of two of their colleagues. Led by the union branch executive secretary, the group demanded for improved health services.

On 16 July 2024, hundreds of residents, mainly youth, gathered at the Kanamkemer junction in Lodwar (Turkana Central, Turkana) against bad governance, corruption and lack of police accountability over their actions, including killings, abductions, and torture during the recent anti-finance bill unrest. An anti-protest group (other sources mention goons) attacked and injured one of the protestors. They were disperse by the police (means unspecified).

On 16 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, gathered at the Roysambu neighborhood of Nairobi - Roysambu (Roysambu, Nairobi) against bad governance, corruption and lack of police accountability over their actions including killings, abductions, and torture during the recent anti-finance bill unrest. The group demanded the president to resign.

On 16 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, marched to the governor's office in Kitui (Kitui Central, Kitui) against bad governance, corruption, both at the county and national levels, and lack of police accountability over their actions including killings, abductions, and torture during the recent anti-finance bill unrest. The group demanded the county government to address their grievances as well as the president to resign.

On 16 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, gathered along Kenyatta avenue in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against bad governance, corruption and lack of police accountability over their actions, including killings, abductions, and torture during the recent anti-finance bill unrest. Police lobbed teargas as well as used live bullets (other sources mention rubber bullets) to disperse the group. Three people (other sources mention ten), including a journalist working for Kameme radio, sustained gunshot wounds.

On 16 July 2024, 1,372 community health promoters from Nyandarua County, marched in an unspecified location (coded to the county headquarters as Ol Kalou, OlKalou, Nyandarua) against delayed pay. The group demanded both the national and county government to address the matter.

On 16 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, gathered at the central business district of an unspecified town (coded to the county headquarters as Ol Kalou (Olkalou, Nyandarua) against bad governance, corruption, both at the county and national levels, and lack of police accountability over their actions including killings, abductions, and torture during the recent anti-finance bill unrest. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 16 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, gathered in Nanyuki (Laikipia East, Laikipia) against police actions including abductions during the recent anti-finance bill unrest. The group demanded Independent Policing Oversight Authority (IPOA) to address the matter.

On 16 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, gathered in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against bad governance, corruption and lack of police accountability over their actions including killings, abductions, and torture during the recent anti-finance bill unrest. Police intervened and arrested one (other sources mention several) youth.

On 16 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Kilifi (Kilifi North, Kilifi) against bad governance, corruption, both at the county and national levels, and lack of police accountability over their actions including killings, abductions, and torture during the recent anti-finance bill unrest. The group demanded the president to resign.

On 16 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Voi (Voi, Taita Taveta) against bad governance, corruption and lack of police accountability over their actions including killings, abductions, and torture during the recent anti-finance bill unrest. The group demanded the president to resign.

Around 16 July 2024 (as reported), a group of youth gathered in an unspecified location in Nairobi (coded to the country headquarters as Nairobi, Starehe, Nairobi) in support of Dadaab member of parliament, following the recent accusation that the MP would have engaged in mass killings to punish the anti-government protesters.

On 16 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Meru (Imenti North, Meru) against the move by members of the county assembly to harass the governor. The group demanded for accountability at the legislative and executive levels, both at the county and national levels.

On 17 July 2024, residents staged a demonstration in Alamata (Alamata town, Southern Tigray, Tigray), opposing the return of displaced persons from various parts of Tigray. The protesters claimed that the returnees were not IDPs, but TPLF soldiers. The residents of Alamata town protested when the returnees entered the city in multiple trucks waving the flag of the Tigray region and chanting the protest songs of TPLF.

Around 17 July 2024 (as reported), a group of youth gathered in an unspecified location within Tharaka Nithi County (coded to the county headquarters as Kathwana, Tharaka South, Tharaka-Nithi) against claims that youth are being paid to engage in anti-government protests.

On 17 July 2024, a group of people protested in Burao town (Burco, Awdal) opposing the rise of electricity prices by a private company. The police intervened by unspecified means and dispersed the crowd.

On 17 July 2024, police forces dispersed with tear gas a meeting-turned-protest by residents of Kasokoso (Kira, Wakiso) who had initially gathered to discuss with MPs plans for eviction in the area. Several protesters were arrested and one of the MPs was taken home by police. Four journalists suffered serious injuries after being struck by teargas canisters.

On 17 July 2024, activists, mostly women, who identified with or as persons with disabilities staged a protest at a magistrate's court in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala) to call for action against a senior university lecturer accused of raping an underage blind student and infecting her with AIDS.

On 17 July 2024, journalists marched to the central police station in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against the recent shooting and injury of their colleague as a result of police actions during protests (coded separately). The group demanded for accountability and justice for the victim as well as police to respect journalists.

On 17 July 2024, a group of youth marched along Kisumu road towards Eldoret town Centre (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in support of former roads and transport Cabinet Secretary (CS), following the recent dissolution of cabinet. The group demanded the president to re-appoint the former CS

On 17 July 2024, Standard media group journalists protested by visiting every office and removing their colleagues from their workstations in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against delayed pay. The group demanded the media house to settle all their salary arrears.

Around 17 July 2024 (as reported), residents protested outside the Kenya Power and Lighting Company (KPLC) offices in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against frequent power outages and billing issues. The group demanded KPLC to address their grievances.

On 17 July 2024, journalists protested in Thika town (Thika Town, Kiambu) against the recent shooting and injury of their colleague as a result of police actions during protests (coded separately). The group demanded accountability and investigation into the matter.
On 17 July 2024, a large number of residents protested after ATMIS UPDF killed three civilians (coded separately) in Bulo Mareer town (Marka, Lower Shabelle).
On 17 July 2024, parents stormed Mbande Primary School (Temeke, Dar es Salaam) in protest against the recent disappearance of a student from the school. The group demanded justice for the victim.

On 18 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Kibwezi (Kibwezi West, Makueni) in demonstration against bad governance, corruption and lack of police accountability over their actions including killings, abductions, and torture during the recent anti-finance bill unrest. The group demanded the president to resign. They were dispersed by police (means not specified).

On 18 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, marched in the streets of Siaya town (Alego Usonga, Siaya) against embezzlement of funds by the county government as well as the use of goons to disrupt their planned protests. The group demanded audience with the governor.

On 18 July 2024, more than 3,000 miners marched to a mining company's office in Kanyambiga in the district of Bunda (location coded to Bunda, Bunda, Mara), demanding the return of their gold mining areas, given to an investor. Police officers intervened with tear gas. A miner claimed they were given a seven-day notice to vacate the area without preparation. The Regional Mining Officer for Mala claimed the government halted mining operations at the mine to prevent conflict between miners and investors.

On 18 July 2024, hundreds of residents in wetlands in the Kampala metropolitan area affected by eviction orders staged a protest in the premises of the National Environment Management Authority in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala) over its plans and actions.

On 18 July 2024, for the second day, residents staged a demonstration in Alamata (Alamata town, Southern Tigray, Tigray), opposing the return of displaced persons from various parts of Tigray. The protesters claimed that the returnees were not IDPs, but TPLF soldiers. The residents of Alamata town started protesting on 17 July 2024 (coded separately) when the returnees entered the city in multiple trucks waving the flag of the Tigray region and chanting the protest songs of TPLF.

On 18 July 2024, health workers, mainly clinical apprentices, gathered, chanted and sang solidarity songs in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against low pay as well as poor working conditions. Led by KUCO officials, the group demanded the county government and the ministry of health to address their grievances.

Around 18 July 2024 (as reported), more than 3000 residents of seven villages at the border of Ganze and Kaloleni sub-counties marched (coded to the nearest known location as Kaloleni, Kaloleni, Kilifi) against the move by an area national government administrator to grab and sell their land. The group demanded both the county government and the national land commission to help address the matter.

On 18 July 2024, the business community protested in Kitengela (Kajiado East, Kajiado) against looting and vandalism of property during the recent anti-government protests by the youth. The group demanded the youth to maintain peace.

On 18 July 2024, residents of Kapsisiywa and Kebulonik, mainly famers, blocked the Kapsisiywa-Kaiboi road with banana seedlings (coded to the nearest known location as Kapsisisywa, Chesumei, Nandi) against the poor state of the road. The group demanded the government to fix the road.

Around 19 July 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly youth and UDA-Kenya Kwanza supporters, gathered in Iten town (Keiyo North, Elgeyo Marakwet) in support of the re-erection of their party symbol (a wheelbarrow on a pole) that was vandalized during the recent anti-finance bill protests (coded separately) as well as against the ongoing anti-government protests. The group demanded the youth not to engage in the protests.

On 19 July 2024, residents blocked (means unspecified) the Chepkober-Kebulonik-Kaiboi-Turbo road with a fence at Kebulonik (Mosop, Nandi) against the poor state of the road. The group demanded the area member of parliament to address the matter as well as a meeting with Sang'alo tea factory managers.

On 19 July 2024, residents neighboring Murchison Falls National Park held placards in protest in Buliisa (Buliisa, Buliisa) against the invasion of elephants and buffaloes who devoured their plantations. The protesters demanded that UWA erect an electric fence around the Park to prevent further invasion of the animals into the community.

On 20 July 2024, for the second day, residents blocked (means unspecified) the Chepkober-Kebulonik-Kaiboi-Turbo road with a fence at Kebulonik (Mosop, Nandi) against the poor state of the road. The group demanded the area member of parliament to address the matter as well as a meeting with Sang'alo tea factory managers.

On 20 July 2024, thousands of people gathered and protested in Borama town (Borama, Awdal) to express support for Somaliland Lower House representatives and demand that Somaliland drop the charges against their representative.

On 21 July 2024, residents blocked the Kibwezi-Kitui road with tree stumps, stones, and twigs at the Kyandula shopping center (Kitui South, Kitui) in demonstration against the killing of a nine-year-old child by a speeding motorist. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.
On 21 July 2024, a group of women in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed) protested against online harassment targeting women and demanded the authorities to intervene.
On 22 July 2024, a group protested at the Taj mall area of Embakasi in Utawala neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi East (Embakasi East, Nairobi). Motivation unknown/not reported.
On 22 July 2024, a group of people protested in Bulo Burto town (Bulo Burto, Hiraan) against the city mayor after the local authority stopped partners from visiting locals.
On 22 July 2024, a group of NUP members protested over corruption in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala). The police intervened and arrested 9 protesters. The protest had been themed #march2parliament.

On 22 July 2024, students from the Jomo Kenyatta University of Agriculture and Technology (JKUAT), sang and chanted, during a funeral service, in Kanjira (Karachuonyo, Homa Bay) in solidarity with their colleague, who was recently abducted and killed as a result of police actions during the recent anti-finance bill unrest (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 22 July 2024, environmental defenders gathered and chanted, while carrying placards, at the Dunga beach area of Lake Victoria in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against pollution of the Lake. The group demanded leaders put to use the policies governing the Lake.

On 22 July 2024, residents protested in Kaptien (Kiminini, Sirende) against a prolonged land dispute. The group demanded the assistant county commissioner, county commissioner and president to help address their grievances.
On 23 July 2024, residents marched in Kiunga (Lamu East, Lamu) against prolonged power outage. The group demanded the Kenya Power and Lighting Company to address the matter.

On 23 July 2024, residents protested in Ndabibi (Naivasha, Nakuru) against plans by a group of youth to invade president William Ruto's farm in the area following a land dispute. The group demanded the youth to maintain peace.

On 23 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, joined by a human rights defender, protested in Diani (other sources mention Ukunda) (Msambweni, Kwale) against corruption, bad governance, mismanagement of public funds at the county government. Police intervened and arrested three protestors.

On 23 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, joined by MUHURI representatives, protested in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against corruption, bad governance, mismanagement of public funds as well as the arrest of their colleagues during the recent anti-government protests (coded separately). Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group, and a prison officer assaulted a MUHURI representative. One person (a deaf) was injured (other sources mention two people, while others mention several people sustained injuries).

On 23 July 2024, 40 women and children protested by blocking vehicular road access to the main road by unspecified means in the Carta area in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari). The protesters were dissatisfied with the undelivered medicines earlier sent by the Ministry of Health to MCH (Maternal and Child Health) in Cart
On 23 July 2024, a group of local beneficiaries protested at the mayor's office in Bulo Burto town (Bulo Burto, Hiraan), demanding that local partners resume food distribution.

On 23 July 2024, residents, mainly youth with placards, including NUP members and students, marched along Parliamentary Avenue and near Oasis Mall Nakumatt in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala) to present a petition to the speaker of parliament against corruption, particularly among government officials and legislators. They had several demands, including the resignation of the speaker of parliament and four commissioners, a reduction in the number of MPs, their salaries, and a lifestyle audit of all legislators. Security forces, comprising police and army forces, denied the protestors access to parliament premises and several were bundled up and beaten up in the process (no further details). At least 54 people, including one journalist, were arrested and detained at various police stations in Kampala before appearing in multiple courts and charged with common nuisance. They were remanded to Luzira prison without securing bail until July 31, August 5 and August 6. An unknown number of protesters remained under police custody.
On 23 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, gathered in Siaya (Alego Usonga, Siaya) against corruption, bad governance, mismanagement of public funds. The group demanded the president to resign.

On 23 July 2024, eight residents, mainly youth, demonstrated along Kenyatta avenue in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against corruption, bad governance, mismanagement of public funds. Police intervened and arrested the eight protestors.

On 23 July 2024, residents protested in Nyahururu (Laikipia West, Laikipia) against corruption, bad governance and mismanagement of public funds. Police fired rubber bullets to disperse the group. A fifteen-year-old student (on her way home from school), sustained injuries during the incident.

On 23 July 2024, thousands of residents blocked a funeral motorcade (using unspecified means), removed the casket and forcefully entered a police station, with some running to the deceased's home, filled up the grave with soil, before planting a banana tree at Kiawara near Githakwa (Nyeri Central, Nyeri). The group accused the wife of being a suspect and claimed the police was not investigating the matter. The group demanded the wife to be detained and investigated, while the police to be transferred from the station.

On 23 July 2024, residents, mainly youth, marched in the streets, while chanting anti-government slogans in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against corruption, bad governance, mismanagement of public funds. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group as well as arrested a human rights defender.

On 24 July 2024, tens of journalists gathered at the Mapembeni area, before marching through Moi Avenue, Nkurumah Road, and Mama Ngina Drive to the County Commissioners office at Uhuru na Kazi in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against harassment, intimidation, attacks and injury by the police and government authorities for their coverage of the anti-government protests. The group demanded a free and safe working environment for media practitioners, among others.

On 28 July 2024, a group of students demonstrated against the punishment given to their peers at Ruhaama Secondary School in Ruhaama (Ruhaama, Ntungamo). The police intervened and while trying to disperse the demonstrators, shot, and seriously injured two students.

Around 29 July 2024 (as reported), milk vendors camped outside Samburu governor's office in Maralal (Samburu Central, Samburu) against harassment by Kenya Dairy Board (KDB) officers. The group demanded the governor to help address the matter.

On 30 July 2024, residents blocked the Waiyaki way with stones at the Kangemi neighborhood of Nairobi - Westlands (Westlands, Nairobi) in demonstration against the killing and dumping of a body at the Kangemi dam, as well as the slow pace by police officers to attend to the scene. Around 31 July 2024 (as reported), traders protested at the Naiberi trading Centre (Ainabkoi, Uasin Gishu) against increased insecurity, following the recent spate of robberies. The group demanded for the transfer of all the police officers.

On 31 July 2024, residents barricaded the Maili nne road with stones and crops in Kiplombe (Turbo, Uasin Gishu) against the poor state of the road. The group demanded the relevant authorities to fix the road.
On 31 July 2024, tens of health workers marched in Embu (Manyatta, Embu) against unfair remuneration and poor working conditions. The group demanded the county government to address their grievances.

On 31 July 2024, a handful supporters of Embakasi North and Embakasi Central Members of Parliament (MPs, UDA and Kwanza Alliance), gathered outside the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) headquarters on Kiambu road in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the arrest and questioning of the two MPs over their role sponsoring the anti-government protests. On 1 August 2024, hundreds of squatters protested in Kisiriri (Laikipia West, Laikipia) against delayed resettlement. The group demanded audience with the governor to help address the matter.

On 1 August 2024, Sankuri ward residents and human rights defenders camped outside the Garissa police station (Garissa, Garissa) against increased cases of abductions and disappearances, following the recent disappearance of four men (coded separately). Led by their Member of County Assembly (MCA) (UDM, Kenya Kwanza), who was accompanied by four other MCAs, the group demanded the government to produce the four men.

Around 2 August 2024 (as reported), residents blocked an unspecified road with stones in Kipkegenda (Aldai, Nandi) in demonstration against the move by a politician living in the area to block a road for public use. The group demanded the re-opening of the road.
On 2 August 2024, hundreds of residents, including Mosques imams protested in Mogadishu (Banadir) against the assassination of the Hamas chief in solidarity with Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.

On 2 August 2024, hundreds of butchers protested at Daljirka Daahsoon area in Mogadishu - Bondhere (Banadir) against the government for closing the fish market in Abdiaziz district, they demanded that the government stop demolishing the market.

On 2 August 2024, students protested at the university of Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against mismanagement and poor service delivery. The group demanded the vice-chancellor to be ousted.
