On 7 August 2024, coffee farmers allied to Baricho Coffee Society protested in Karatina town (Mathira East, Nyeri) against poor pay. The group demanded the marketer to review the coffee rates.

Around 8 August 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Msumarini (Kilifi South, Kilifi) against the move by a private developer to disinherit them their land. The group demanded the governor to help address the matter.

On 8 August 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Kisii town (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against the government's incompetence, wastage of public resources and corruption. The group demanded the president to resign.

On 8 August 2024, residents, mainly youth, protested in Emali town (Kibwezi West, Makueni) against the government's incompetence, wastage of public resources and corruption. Police intervened and arrested 26 protestors.

On 8 August 2024, residents marched from Kalundu market to the town center in Kitui (Kitui Central, Kitui) against the recent move by the president to form a broad-based government by incorporating members of Orange Democratic Movement (ODM), among other grievances. The group demanded the president to appoint another Cabinet Secretary (CS) from Kitui County. The group also mentioned 'President Ruto's calculated move to marginalize the Kamba community.'

On 8 August 2024, residents, mainly youth, gathered in Nakuru town (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against the government's incompetence, wastage of public resources and corruption. Police intervened and arrested unknown number of protestors. One protestor (described as a person living with disability), sustained injuries as he was being bundled into a police vehicle.

Around 8 August 2024 (as reported), a group of Junior Secondary School (JSS) teachers gathered and chanted in Kilifi (Kilifi North, Kilifi) against slow reposting process. The group demanded the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) to address the matter.

On 8 August 2024, a handful to dozens of residents, mainly youth, protested in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the government's incompetence, wastage of public resources and corruption. Police lobbed teargas and fired live ammunition to disperse the group as well as arrested 126 protestors. Over 30 people sustained injuries, including at least three journalists. Police officers also beat up and injured a private security guard (unarmed) along the Mfangano street for filming the police action during the anti-government riots. The victim was taken to hospital.

On 9 August 2024, a group of students protested at the Ugandan parliament in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), against the construction of the East African Crude Oil Pipeline. The police intervened and arrested about 57.

On 9 August 2024, a group of residents protested against power outage in the town of Kabale (Kabale, Kabale). The police intervened to stop the protesters from marching to the office of UMEME, the Ugandan power distributor.
On 9 August 2024, resident gathered and camped at the Mathioya constituency offices in Mathioya (Kiharu, Muranga) against delayed pay, after attending a rally. The group demanded their dues.

Around 9 August 2024 (as reported), hundreds of youth waved flags and sang anti-president songs outside Nairobi law courts (Starehe, Nairobi) in support of the court's decision to release them unconditionally following their arrest and arraignment for engaging in anti-government protests. The group demanded for social justice.

On 9 August 2024, hundreds of residents and family members of a murdered businessman protested at the Suuqa Bakaraha neighborhood in Mogadishu - Hawl Wadaag (Banadir) against police brutality, they demanded justice for the victim who was killed in Ceelasha Biyaha (coded separately).

On 14 August 2024, a group of civil servants demonstrated in Hobicha (Hobicha Abaya, Welayta, South Ethiopia Region), opposing the non-payment of their salary for three months. The demonstrators went to the administration office in groups, found the head of the administration office at the gate as he was leaving the compound, forced him to step out of his car (means not reported), returned him to his office, and asked him to make an order for the payment of their salary. They blocked him from leaving the office until 8:00 p.m. The Central Ethiopia region police arrived, disbursed the demonstrators and took the head of the administration office to Welayta Sodo town (likely for his safety based on the context).

On 18 August 2024, hundreds of Maasai members including men, women, and children blocked (means unspecified) Ngorongoro-Serengeti Road (location coded to Ngorongoro, Ngorongoro, Arusha) against the lack of basic rights, discrimination, and the loss of their ancestral land. Maasai complained about the government's discriminatory practices, including special permits to enter and leave Ngorongoro and the withdrawal of education and healthcare, with funding diverted to Msomera. The Tanzanian government has a relocation plan aimed at moving 110,000 Maasai from Ngorongoro to Msomera, Sauni, and Kitwai (over 200 kilometers from their homes). The government claimed the relocation aims to preserve the Ngorongoro Conservation Area. 8,364 residents have moved since July 2022.

Protesters also called for police forces to improve the monitoring of incidents involving child abductions, disappearances, and murders. The march follows the rape and murder of a six-month-old in Dodoma region and the kidnapping and killing of a two-year-old with albinism in Kagera region. The march began at St Peter's grounds in Oysterbay and finished at Leaders Club grounds.

The group demanded the regional office to replace the reverend who was later whisked away by the police.

On 30 September 2024, a group of residents protested in Nyantaboma parish, also spelt Nyantabwoma, Kijura Town Council (Burahya, Kabarole), over the alleged delayed release of Parish Development Model (PDM) funds. The PDM is a government strategy to reduce poverty by moving 39% of households from subsistence to money economy.

On 30 September 2024, residents blocked the Ruaka-Ndenderu road with stones, in Ruaka (Kiambaa, Kiambu) in protest against increased road accidents, following the recent killing of a pedestrian by a speeding truck. The group demanded motorists to drive with care as well as the Kenya national highways authority to erect speed bumps on the road.

Around 30 September 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly youths, gathered while carrying placards in Kilifi town (Kilifi North, Kilifi) in protest against the move by a private developer to grab public land. The group demanded both the county and national government to restore the land to the public.

On 30 September 2024, human rights defenders and lawyers, chanted songs of freedom outside the Nairobi regional police headquarters (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the arrest and detention of their colleague. Police intervened and lobbed teargas canisters to disperse the group.

On 30 September 2024, parents of St. Monica's Girls' High School protested in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against declining academic performance, among other grievances. The group demanded the head teacher transferred.

On 30 September 2024, lecturers protested at Moi university main campus in Kesses (Kesses, Uasin Gishu) against delayed pay among other concerns. The group demanded the university administration to address their grievances.

On 1 October 2024, medical doctors, mainly members of KMPDU, marched to the governor's office in Kapsabet Referral Hospital (Chesumei, Nandi) in protest against delayed pay, among other grievances. Led by the KMPDU south rift region officials, the group demanded the governor to address their grievances.

On 1 October 2024, students at Tharaka boys' high school, protested at the institution, in Marimanti (Tharaka South, Tharaka Nithi) against the move by the school administration to administer internal exams ahead of the Kenya certificate of secondary education (KCSE) examinations. Police intervened and arrested two students for interrogation. The school was closed indefinitely.
On 1 October 2024, a group of street vendors protested in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala) against the decision by KCCA (Kampala Capital City Authority) officials to confiscate their merchandise.

On 1 October 2024, ethnic Amhara residents and students staged a protest against the start of students' registration based on Tigray regional state's curriculum, around Midre Genet Elementary School, in Alamata (Alamata town, Southern Tigray, Tigray). The protestors demanded the schools in the town use Amharic as a language of instruction. Conflicting reports mentioned that protesters argued that schools should remain closed until the conflicts in the Amhara region are resolved. Tigray forces affiliated with TPLF (coded as Tigray Police Force) intervened and killed 2 protestors. 7 - 8 other protestors were injured. Officials from the Tigray regional state claimed that the protesters were armed (uncorroborated).

On 1 October 2024, for the second day, human rights defenders and lawyers sang and chanted outside the Milimani law courts, in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the arrest and detention of their colleague. Police lobbed teargas canisters to disperse the group.

On 1 October 2024, university of Nairobi students protested in the Nairobi city center (Starehe, Nairobi) in support the proposed impeachment of the deputy president from office. The group demanded the president not to interfere with the impeachment process.

On 2 October 2024, for the second day, health workers, mainly members of KMPDU, joined by members of KUCO and other hospital staff, gathered and sang solidarity songs at the Kapsabet referral hospital (Chesumei, Nandi) in protest against delayed pay. The group demanded the county government to address the matter.

On 2 October 2024, residents and traders marched to the office of the county commissioner in Lodwar town (Turkana Central, Turkana) in protest against frequent power outages. The group demanded the Kenya power and lighting company to address the matter.

On 2 October 2024, a group of residents protested in the city of Mbarara (Mbarara, Mbarara) against the prolonged delay in constructing Katete Bridge. The bridge has allegedly been in poor condition for seven months, causing significant losses to local businesses. The protesters blocked the bridge (through unspecified means), demanding immediate action from authorities. The police intervened and used teargas to disperse the crowd.

On 2 October 2024, about 50 residents protested in Kasoli Parish coded to Tororo (Tororo, Tororo), over delayed compensation for their homes, which were allegedly demolished to make way for the Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) project.

On 2 October 2024, over 4000 Moi university lecturers, mainly UASU members and other workers, marched to the Uasin Gishu county assembly in Eldoret town (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against delayed pay among other concerns. The group demanded the president to help address their grievances.

On 2 October 2024, Uasin Gishu residents, mainly youth, lured by First Choice Recruitment Agency into a job scam, marched to the office of the director of public prosecutions (ODPP) in Eldoret town (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against delayed refund of their money. The group demanded the ODDP to charge the main suspect in the case.

Around 3 October 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly miners, chanted while carrying placards in Macalder (Nyatike, Migori) in protest against the move by the county government to close down the Kopa mines. The group demanded the county to reopen the mines.

On 3 October 2024, Murang'a teachers' college students marched along the Murang'a-Kenol highway while chanting in Muranga (Kiharu, Muranga) in protest against bad governance and poor management by the college principal. The group demanded the principal be dismissed.
On 4 October 2024, residents carried placards in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in support of the impeachment motion against the deputy president. The group demanded the deputy president to leave office.
On 4 October 2024, a group of people protested against the EACOP (East African Crude Oil Pipeline) march in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala). The police intervened and arrested the protesters.

On 4 October 2024, youth allied to a lawyer and political activist, disrupted a public participation exercise at the Bomas of Kenya auditorium within Nairobi - Langata (Langata, Nairobi) on the impeachment motion against the deputy president by chanting anti-government slogans in protest against the impeachment of the deputy president. A group intervened and hurled chairs and other objects to disperse the protestors. The activist sustained injuries during the incident before being whisked to safety. Police officers used unspecified means to restore normalcy and the event proceeded as planned. The activist was later arrested on 8 October in connection with the incident.
On 4 October 2024, residents protested in Njabini (Kinangop, Nyandarua) against the proposed impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded the lawmakers to reject the proposal.

On 4 October 2024, residents joined by their member of parliament (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) protested in Kipipiri (Kinangop, Nyandarua) against the proposed impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded that the lawmakers reject the proposal.

On 4 October 2024, youth forced their way into Madogo police station (Bura, Tana River) in protest against increased insecurity, following renewed interclan clashes. The group demanded justice for the killings. Police used (unspecified means) to calm down the group.

On 4 October 2024, residents burnt posters of their member of parliament while chanting anti-government slogans, in Kiambaa (Kiambaa, Kiambu) in demonstration against the proposed impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded the law makers to reject the proposal.

On 4 October 2024, residents disrupted a public participation exercise on the impeachment motion against the deputy president by storming out of the venue with some tearing the impeachment forms in Nyahururu town (Laikipia West, Laikipia) in demonstration against the impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded the president to be included in the ouster motion. It is unclear whether the event proceeded as planned.

On 4 October 2024, residents disrupted a public participation exerciseon the impeachment motion against the deputy president by singing and chanting anti-government slogans, at the Ol Kalou NG-CDF hall (Olkalou, Nyandarua) in protest against the impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded the president to be included in the ouster motion. Police used unspecified means to restore normalcy and the event proceeded as planned.

On 4 October 2024, residents disrupted a public participation exercise on the impeachment motion against the deputy president by singing songs and carrying placards, in Nanyuki (Laikipia East, Laikipia) in protest against the impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded the president to be included in the ouster motion.

On 4 October 2024, residents disrupted a public participation exercise on the impeachment motion against the deputy president by protesting at the Kabarnet rehabilitation center (Baringo Central, Baringo) against the impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded the president to be included in the ouster motion.

On 4 October 2024, residents disrupted a public participation exercise on the impeachment motion against the deputy president by chanting anti-government slogans, at the Talent academy in Embu town (Manyatta, Embu) in protest against the impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded the president to be included in the ouster motion. It is unclear whether the event proceeded as planned.

On 4 October 2024, residents disrupted a public participation exercise on the impeachment motion against the deputy president by protesting at the Kirinyaga Central National Government Constituency Development Fund (NG-CDF) office in Kerugoya town (Kirinyaga Central, Kirinyaga) against the impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded the president to be included in the ouster motion.

On 4 October 2024, residents chanted slogans in Kanduyi town (Kanduyi, Bungoma) in support of the impeachment motion against the deputy president. The group demanded that the deputy president leave office.

On 4 October 2024, residents carried placards in Kericho town (Ainamoi, Kericho) in support of the impeachment motion against the deputy president. The group demanded the deputy president to leave office.

On 4 October 2024, residents disrupted a public participation exercise on the impeachment motion against the deputy president by tearing forms and chanting anti-government slogans, in Muranga (Kiharu, Muranga) in demonstration against the impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded the president to be included in the ouster motion. It is unclear whether the event proceeded as planned.

On 4 October 2024, residents protested in Karatina town (Mathira East, Nyeri) against the motion on the impeachment of the deputy president. Police intervened and lobbed teargas canisters to disperse the group.

On 4 October 2024, residents, mainly traders, disrupted a public participation exercise on the impeachment motion against the deputy president by chanting anti-government slogans, at Magharibi hall in Kakamega town (Lurambi, Kakamega) in protest against the impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded the president to be included in the ouster motion. It is unclear whether the event proceeded as planned.

Around 5 October 2024 (as reported), members of the association of online taxi drivers gathered and sang in solidarity at an unknown location (coded to the country headquarters as Nairobi, Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against lack of safety measures by the application companies. The group demanded the government not to renew the licenses of the current application companies.

On 6 October 2024, Presbyterian Church of East Africa (PCEA) members, protested at Igoki south parish (Imenti South, Meru) against mistreatment, intimidations, and misuse of resources by the reverend. The group demanded the moderator of the general assembly to help address their grievances.

On 6 October 2024, over 500 members of the joy holy trinity ministry, protested in Gakungu near Thiba (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) against threats to their church leader by unknown people. The group demanded the security officers to investigate the matter.

On 7 October 2024, members of the Mailwa group ranch marched in Maili Tisa (Kajiado Central, Kajiado) in protest against the move by the courts to dismiss the case challenging the election of new ranch officials. The group demanded the courts to listen to their plea

On 7 October 2024, residents marched while chanting in Oljorai (Gilgil, Nakuru) against a planned move by individuals in government to evict them from their ancestral land. Led by a former member of county assembly, the group demanded the government to help address the matter as well as ensure justice is served.

On 7 October 2024, Bungoma national polytechnic students marched along the Kanduyi - Bungoma highway, in Bungoma (Kanduyi, Bungoma) in protest against poor leadership of the institution's principal, following the recent dismissal of their deputy principal. The group demanded the deputy principal reinstated. The police used unspecified means to control the group.

On 7 October 2024, religious leaders mainly from the Christian faith, gathered and chanted while carrying placards in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the proposed impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded that the president pardon the deputy president for any wrong doing committed.

On 8 October 2024, a group of students protested at their school, Ishaka Adventist College, located in Ishaka (Bushenyi, Bushenyi), against the administration's decision preventing them to celebrate Uganda's independence as they planned. When the students started destroying school property, the police intervened to disperse the protesters and control the situation.

On 8 October 2024, residents, protested in Nyeri town (Nyeri Central, Nyeri) against the move by the members of parliament to impeach the deputy president. The group demanded for the senate to reverse the impeachment.

On 9 October 2024, supporters of political activist Morara Kebaso, chanted slogans outside the hardy police station within the Nairobi - Langata (Langata, Nairobi) in support of the move by the police to release the activist, following his arrest for disrupting a public participation exercise on the impeachment motion against the deputy president (coded separately).

On 9 October 2024, health workers marched while carrying banners and blowing vuvuzelas, in Kapsabet (Chesumei, Nandi) in protest against the move by the county government to sack over 600 of their colleagues (other sources mention poor working conditions and lack of medical supplies). The group demanded that the county government to address their grievances.

Around 9 October 2024 (as reported), residents and parents protested at Kwa Ndonga primary school (Kitui West, Kitui) against poor performance as well as mismanagement. The group demanded for the head teacher to be transferred.

On 9 October 2024, e-hailing taxi operators protested at the Tononoka grounds in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against lack of protection and poor workplace safety, following the recent murder of their colleague during the theft of her vehicle. The group demanded the government to address their grievances.

On 9 October 2024, intern clinical officers, joined by KUCO officials protested outside the ministry of health headquarters in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against delayed pay, poor working conditions and lack of medical cover. The group demanded the ministry to address their grievances.

Around 10 October 2024 (as reported), patrons shouted in unison at the Texas bar, Kikuyu town (Kikuyu, Kiambu) in protest against their area member of parliament's leadership. Police intervened and shut down the bar before arresting unknown number of patrons.

On 10 October 2024, residents, mainly relatives and family members, marched while carrying placards and chanting to Garsen police station (Garsen, Tana River) in protest against the recent abduction of one of their own by suspected police officers (coded separately). The group demanded that the police to disclose the whereabouts of the victim.

On 10 October 2024, Puntland Dervish forces staged a protest by blocking the main road (means not specified) in Gaalkacyo town (Gaalkacyo, Mudug). The protest aimed at demanding payment of their unpaid salaries.

Around 10 October 2024 (as reported), a group of residents protested near Ibambiro (Buhaguzi, Kikuube), by planting banana suckers on poorly maintained roads, particularly the Kisambo-Bujugu-Ruguse Road. This action is in response to the alleged failure of local leaders to rehabilitate roads.

On 10 October 2024, a group of environmental activists from the Weka Afri Sustainable Biodiversity and Food Security Foundation protested at Kitgum house located near Jinja road in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), against Chinese operations in the Lwera wetlands near Masaka. The protesters were found with placards condemning environmental destruction. The police intervened and arrested five protesters.

On 11 October 2024, students vandalized property of unknown value at Kaptebeswet secondary school (Ainamoi, Kericho) in demonstration against the transfer of the deputy principal. Police officers used unspecified means to disperse the group and the school was closed indefinitely.

On 11 October 2024, residents disrupted a funeral ceremony by chanting anti-president slogans during the governor's speech in Bibilioni, also known as Bibirioni (Nakuru North, Nakuru). It is unclear whether the chants are related to the ongoing opposition to the impeachment of the deputy president. The governor had to cut short his speech.

Around 11 October 2024 (as reported), members of the Ogiek community gathered in Mariashoni (Molo, Nakuru) to protest against a planned move to evict them following a recent court ruling. Led by the council of elders' national secretary general, the group demanded that the relevant government authorities respect and uphold the rights of the Ogiek community as well as ensure justice and fairness in the implementation of the court ruling.

On 11 October 2024, hundreds of residents, joined by environmental activists marched to the office of the governor in Kilifi town (Kilifi North, Kilifi) in protest against the planned construction of a nuclear plant in Uyombo area. The group demanded that theproject be suspended.

On 12 October 2024, residents disrupted a function by chanting anti-president slogans during the President's economic advisor's speech, within the Githurai 44 neighborhood of Nairobi - Roysambu (Roysambu, Nairobi). It is unclear whether the chants are related to the ongoing opposition to the impeachment of the deputy president. The advisor had to cut short his speech.

On 12 October 2024, hundreds to thousands of Lari Nyakinyua group blocked the Nairobi-Nakuru highway using stones, with some carrying placards and chanting slogans, in Gilgil (Gilgil, Nakuru) in protest against the recent move by squatters to settle on their land. The group demanded the government through the cabinet secretary interior to help address the matter.

On 12 October 2024, youth disrupted a public service vehicle (matatu) culture event by chanting anti-government slogans, in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against increasing economic pressures. The group demanded accountability from the political class.

Around 14 October 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly family members from the Muslim faith, camped outside the Hola hospital mortuary (Galole, Tana River) in protest against the move by the government to withhold four bodies of the victims of the recent interclan clashes in the area (coded separately). The group demanded the bodies released for burial according to the Muslim faith.

On 14 October 2024, locals protested in Hudur town (Xudur, Bakool) to show support for the former district commissioner, who was replaced by the Southwest administration. The protesters expressed their concerns about his replacement.

On 14 October 2024, parents, mainly family members, camped outside the St. Angela's Girls' school in Kitui (Kitui Central, Kitui) in protest against the recent death of a student at the school, under unclear circumstances. The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 15 October 2024, residents of Mekele City who participated in a government-backed housing scheme gathered in front of the office of the president of the Tigray Interim Administration in Mekelle (Mekelle Tigray, Tigray) and protested over claims of a sudden change in the housing project. The protesters claimed that this decision undermines their years of savings and breaches a longstanding agreement.

Around 15 October 2024 (as reported), parents protested at Kianjogu primary school (Laikipia West, Laikipia) against poor school performance and safety risks among other grievances. The group demanded for the transfer of the headteacher.

On 15 October 2024, residents of Buxton, Khadija, Mzizima, Changamwe, Malandini, Tudor, and Likoni, led by representatives of Haki Yetu Organization (a civil society group), gathered while carrying placards at the Elephant Tusks monument on Moi Avenue in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against the failed promises of the affordable housing project. Police dispersed the group by arresting nine protestors.

On 15 October 2024, youth protested outside the Nyamira county assembly (Nyamira, Nyamira) against the move by the county speaker to resume duty. Police used batons to disperse the group as well as arrested several protestors.

On 15 October 2024, hundreds of women gathered and sang songs in Kutus (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) in support of the county governor to succeed the outgoing deputy president (DP), following the ongoing impeachment process. The group demanded the president to return the DP position to Mt Kenya as well as nominate a woman as a replacement.

Around 15 October 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Sira Nyawita village near Ugunja (Ugunja, Siaya) against the move by a medical officer in the area to disinherit orphans their land. The group demanded the government and well-wishers to help address the matter.

Around 15 October 2024 (month of), students protested at Larmudiac Mixed Secondary School in Kihingo (Njoro, Nakuru) against poor management by the school principal. The group demanded that the principal be transferred. The boys involved in the demonstration were suspended indefinitely.

On 15 October 2024, online taxi drivers protested outside the company offices in the Morocco area of Dar es Salaam (Ilala, Dar es Salaam) against poor pay, among other grievances. The group demanded that the company management address the matter.

Around 16 October 2024 (as reported), women gathered and sang songs in Juja (Juja, Kiambu) in support of the Kirinyaga county governor to succeed the outgoing deputy president (DP), following the ongoing impeachment process. The group demanded the president to nominate a woman as a deputy president.

On 16 October 2024, residents blocked the Kutus-Sagana highway (means unspecified), with some chanting slogans in Kagio town (Kirinyaga West, Kirinyaga) in protest against the ongoing deputy president's impeachment trial at the senate. The group demanded the senators to dismiss the motion.

Around 16 October 2024 (as reported), residents marched while carrying placards in the in the Kware neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi South (Embakasi South, Nairobi) in protest against the move by a private developer to grab part of a school land. The group demanded the relevant authorities to address the matter.

On 16 October 2024, residents marched and camped outside the deputy county commissioner's office in Garbatulla (Garbatulla, Isiolo) in protest against unfair recruitment and compensation plans by the Horn of Africa gateway road project. The group demanded for an audit of the employees working on the road project.

On 16 October 2024, intern clinical officers protested outside the ministry of health headquarters in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against delayed pay. The group demanded the ministry to address their grievances.

On 17 October 2024, residents marched while carrying placards in Chebilat also known as Chepilat (Sotik, Bomet) in protest against increased cases of sexual assault targeting children. Led by women and church leaders, the group demanded justice for the victims.

Around 17 October 2024 (as reported), residents gathered and spoke in unison in Mpeketoni (Lamu West, Lamu) in protest against the impeachment of the deputy president. The group demanded the president to be included in the ouster motion.

On 17 October 2024, residents, mainly youth, led by the area ward representative (ODM, Azimio) marched while carrying placards and blowing vuvuzelas in the Nairobi West neighborhood of Nairobi - Langata (Langata, Nairobi) in protest against the move by a private developer to grab public land. Police used batons to disperse the group.
On 17 October 2024, a group of butchers protested in the town of Hoima (Hoima, Hoima), following the arrest of their chairman.

On 18 October 2024, a group of residents protested against eviction in the wetland of Lubigi (Busiro, Wakiso). The residents had been evicted in June 2024 but slowly returned to inhabit the area. The police started an operation to evict the residents, which led to the protest. At least 30 people were arrested.

On 20 October 2024, residents, mainly relatives to Dela ward representative (UDM, Kenya Kwanza), protested in Wajir (Wajir East, Wajir) against the recent abduction and disappearance of the ward representative (coded separately). The group demanded the security agencies to address the matter. Police officers used unspecified means to disperse the group. The protest took place in the context of the discovery of a mutilated body in Lake Yahud area (Deoxyribonucleic acid-DNA results revealed that the body was not for the abducted ward representative).

On 20 October 2024, residents disrupted the Mashujaa (heroes) day celebrations by chanting anti-president slogans during the deputy county commissioner (DCC) speech in Juja (Juja, Kiambu). It is unclear whether the chants are related to the ongoing opposition to the impeachment of the deputy president. The DCC had to cut short his speech.

On 20 October 2024, hundreds of youth, joined by human rights defenders, including Haki Africa representatives, gathered in the city Centre, before attempting to march to Uhuru park grounds in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in solidarity with the victims of police brutality during the recent anti-government protests (coded separately). Police intervened and lobbed teargas canisters as well as fired live ammunitions to disperse the group. One person sustained gunshot wounds and dozens were arrested during the incident.

On 22 October 2024, over 150 employees of Mesfin Industrial Engineering staged a public demonstration in front of the Tigray Reconstruction head office in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), complaining low wages for employees of the company.

On 22 October 2024, students marched to the Nairobi technical training institute administration within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against increased school fees. Police intervened and arrested 108 students. The college was closed indefinitely following the incident.

Around 22 October 2024 (as reported), hundreds of residents protested in Cheptonon (Mosop, Nandi) against the recent move by the area assistant chief (under the influence of alcohol) to attack and injure one of the residents using a machete. The group demanded justice for the victim.
On 23 October 2024, traders protested at Kiganjo market (Gatundu South, Kiambu) against harassment by the county enforcement officers. The group demanded the county government to address the matter.

On 23 October 2024, Nairobi technical training institute students, joined by their parents, blocked highways using unspecified means, before marching while carrying twigs and placards, and camping outside the Pangani police station, within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the move by the police to arrest 108 of their colleagues. Police intervened and lobbed teargas canisters to disperse the group.

Around 23 October 2024 (as reported), nurses protested outside the county assembly in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against poor working conditions as well as delayed promotion. The group demanded the county to address their grievances.

On 23 October 2024, residents of Kwachocha stormed the Malindi law courts (Malindi, Kilifi) in protest against proposed takeover of the airport by a new investor. The group demanded for compensation before the investor takeover, following their eviction.
On 23 October 2024, residents protested in Gothoka near Githunguri (Githunguri, Kiambu) against increased attacks by hippopotamus. The group demanded the Kenya wildlife service to address the matter.

Around 24 October 2024 (as reported), lorry operators protested in Rongo (Rongo, Migori) against the conduct of county enforcement officers, following the recent assault and injury on one of their colleague (coded separately). Led by the Rongo lorries transporters savings and credit cooperative (SACCO) chairperson, the group demanded the county government to ensure that the officer is arrested and charged.

On 24 October 2024, hundreds of residents, mainly members of the business community, joined by the area member of parliament (Jubilee, Azimio) and senator (ODM, Azimio), blocked roads (means unspecified) in the Eastleigh neighborhood of Nairobi - Kamukunji (Kamukunji, Nairobi) in protest against the recent killing of three women from the Somali community (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased victims.

On 24 October 2024, residents, mainly relatives to Dela ward representative (UDM, Kenya Kwanza), protested in Wajir (Wajir East, Wajir) against the recent abduction and disappearance of the ward representative (coded separately). Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group. The protest took place in the context of the discovery of a mutilated body in Lake Yahud area (Deoxyribonucleic acid-DNA results revealed that the body was not for the abducted ward representative).

On 24 October 2024, residents stormed into Lugulu primary school (Butula, Busia) in protest against irregularities in the school's tendering process. Students intervened by confronting and ejecting the group out of the school.

On 24 October 2024, residents, mainly women cancer victims, gathered and sang in solidarity songs in Nanyuki (Laikipia East, Laikipia) in protest against lack of medication. The group demanded the relevant agencies to address the matter.

Around 25 October 2024 (as reported), residents of Tabu Hotel Village blocked (means unspecified) the Dodoma-Morogoro highway (location coded to Morogoro, Morogoro Urban, Morogoro) to call the attention of the Morogoro Regional Governor after a Cruzer government vehicle hit a student on the pedestrian crossing, killing him/her. Protesters demanded ridges and claimed accidents in the area involving government vehicles running over citizens, including students, were frequent.

On 25 October 2024, residents blocked an unspecified road with stones in Siembeni (Kibwezi West, Makueni) in protest against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of a private security guard by unknown assailants. The group demanded for the transfer of the police officers in the area.
On 27 October 2024, thousands of squatters protested in Mwatate (Mwatate, Taita Taveta) against delayed issuance of their title deeds. The group demanded the government to address the matter.
On 27 October 2024, local residents protested in Mogadishu (Banadir) against the recent killing of a soldier. The protesters demanded justice for the victim.

On 27 October 2024, residents from Mkiwa blocked (means unspecified) the Dodoma-Singida-Mwanza highway (location coded to Mkiwa, Ikungi, Singida) to demand the government remove a herd of elephants that invaded the area, causing damage to homes and food supplies. The road was blocked for over two hours. The elephants have wreaked crops and, in some instances, caused fatalities as they move through the area en route to the Rungwa Game Reserve located in Itigi District.

On 27 October 2024, residents marched while carrying twigs in Bondeni village near Karandi (Laikipia West, Laikipia) in protest against the sale and consumption of illicit alcohol, following the recent death of two (other sources mention three) people. The group demanded the government to help address the matter.

Around 28 October 2024 (as reported), residents of Funto town conducted a public demonstration in Funto (Damboya, Kembata Tibaro, Central Ethiopia), opposing the power blackout in the town for weeks. There is no further information concerning the reason for the blackout. The ENDF fired live bullets to disperse protesters, wounding an unspecified number of protesters.

On 28 October 2024, truck drivers blocked the Eldoret-Malaba road with trucks, at Amagoro (Teso North, Busia) in protest against the move by the county government of Busia to introduce a road levy charge. The group demanded the cabinet secretary for transport to address the matter.

On 28 October 2024, a group of students from Kayambogo University protested at the university senate building in Kyambogo (Kampala, Kampala), against the move by the management to put in place a guild caretaker government as they wait for the 2024/25 polls which were suspended last week. The police intervened and arrested several students.

Around 28 October 2024 (as reported), more than 1000 residents of Ntulili and Tirigwi villages gathered in an unspecified location (coded to one of the villages as Ntulili, Tigania West, Meru) in protest against the destruction of their properties by military officers (coded separately). The group demanded that the government to help address the matter.

On 28 October 2024, residents, mainly family members, protested in Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi) against increased police brutality following the recent killing of a grade six student by the police (coded separately). The group demanded the independent policing oversight authority (IPOA) to investigate the matter.

On 28 October 2024, residents, mainly members of the Mara Lemek conservancy protested in Lemek (Narok West, Narok) against the move by a private developer to grab their land. The group demanded the government to help address the land dispute.

On 29 October 2024, lecturers, mainly UASU members protested at the Bomet university (Bomet East, Bomet) against the government's failure to implement agreed-upon salary increases. The group demanded the government to honor the negotiated return-to-work formula.

On 29 October 2024, for the second day, truck drivers blocked the Eldoret-Malaba road with trucks, at Amagoro (Teso North, Busia) in protest against the move by the county government of Busia to introduce a road levy charge. The group demanded the cabinet secretary for transport to address the matter.

The police forces blocked the gates to prevent the protesters from leaving their campus, some students were reportedly injured by security forces that dispersed the protest. Extent of injuries unknown/not reported.
