The group demanded the president to disband the SHA board.

On 5 December 2024, intern doctors camped while waving placards and blowing vuvuzelas outside the Ministry of health headquarters, at Afya house in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against delayed pay. The group demanded for implementation of the collective bargaining agreement.

On 5 December 2024, supporters of Kiambu senator (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) carried placards as they camped outside the directorate of criminal investigations headquarters in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against claimed police intimidation, following the move by the police to summon the Kiambu senator for grilling over the recent chaos at a funeral service (coded separately). The group demanded the police to follow the constitution.

On 5 December 2024, residents gathered and chanted in Malindi town (Malindi , Kilifi) in protest against a claimed move by politicians to incite public service vehicle (matatu) operators to stage protests (coded separately). The group demanded security officers to investigate the matter.

On 6 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders, marched while carrying placards in Nturumeti primary school (Narok East, Narok) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded state and non-state actors to engage youth in addressing the vice. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 6 December 2024, residents, mainly women rights defenders and joined by the deputy governor (ODM, Azimio), gathered in Busia (Matayos, Busia) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for streamlined efforts in addressing the vice. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 6 December 2024, residents, mainly women rights defenders, gathered in Nyeri (Nyeri Central, Nyeri) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded everyone to be involved in addressing the vice. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 6 December 2024, residents, mainly women rights defenders, gathered in an undisclosed location within Kuria (coded to the nearest known location as Isibania, Kuria West, Migori) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for concerted efforts by both the county and national government leaders including non-state actors in addressing the vice. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 7 December 2024, over 1000 traders protested at the Fedha bus stage within Nairobi - Embakasi East (Embakasi East, Nairobi) against abrupt eviction notice (24-hour eviction notice) ahead of planned demolitions of their businesses, following the sell of their public land to a private developer. The group demanded sufficient time to relocate

Around 7 December 2024 (as reported), women, mainly widows and joined by women rights defenders, gathered and marched while carrying a banner and singing in Ukwala (Ugunja, Siaya) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for the county to dedicate resources to protect women and widows in particular. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 7 December 2024, a section of Meru community elders (Njuri Ncheke) gathered and chanted at their shrine in Ncheru also known as Nchiru (Tigania West, Meru) in protest against a proposal to form Gikuyu, Embu, Meru and Akamba (GEMA) political party, ahead of the 2027 general elections. Led by the chairman, the group demanded their rival faction (described as the urged Linus Kathera's group) to stop engaging in Njuri Ncheke affairs.

On 7 December 2024, residents disrupted an entertainment festival by shouting and chanting during the sports Cabinet Secretary's (CS) speech in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu). It is unclear whether the incident is related to the ongoing opposition to the recent impeachment of the deputy president as well as dissatisfaction with the government development agenda. The CS had to cut short his speech.

On 8 December 2024, hundreds of residents protested in Belet Xaawo town (Belet Xaawo, Gedo) opposing the re-election of Jubaland president and the entry of Ethiopian troops into the Gedo region (coded separately).

On 8 December 2024, members of the salvation army church protested in Nairobi city Centre (Starehe, Nairobi) against the poor management of the Nairobi central temple complex. The group demanded to sign a new contract for the management of the facility.

On 9 December 2024, residents, mainly members of the Ogiek community, gathered while carrying placards, twigs and chanting in Mariashoni (Molo, Nakuru) in protest against the plan by the government to subdivide the Mau summit land, arguing that the move amounts to violation of their rights as indigenous community. The group demanded that the government implement the earlier court ruling on the matter.

On 9 December 2024, hundreds of residents marched while carrying twigs and chanting in Olempirita near Ndabibi (Naivasha, Nakuru) in protest against the move by a high-ranking government official to grab their land (coded separately). The group demanded that the president help address the matter.

On 9 December 2024, youth and women protested in Ceerigaabo town (Ceerigaabo, Sanaag) against the recurring hostilities in the area. They marched on the streets chanting slogans and holding banners to support peace negotiations and the end of violence.
On 9 December 2024, Banadir university students protested at the main gate of the university in Mogadishu - Hodan (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle) rejecting one year extension to their academic years.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders, marched while carrying banners and placards to the office of the county commissioner in Busia town (Matayos, Busia) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by government officers and the director of children services, gathered in Homa Bay town (Homa Bay Town, Homa Bay) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders gathered and marched while carrying a banner and chanting in Rombo (Loitokitok, Kajiado) in protest against increased cases of femicide, following the recent incident where a woman was sexually assaulted before being killed in the area. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women protested in Kiambu (Kiambu Town, Kiambu) against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women protested in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders and county government officials protested in Sori (Nyatike, Migori) against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women, marched while carrying banners, placards and singing in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders, marched while carrying placards and banners in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders marched while carrying banners and placards in Kapsabet (Chesumei, Nandi) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women protested in Lodwar (Turkana Central, Turkana) against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, disabled former Tigray Defence Forces (TDF) members staged public demonstrations in Agula (Agulae, Eastern Tigray, Tigray) to oppose their discharge from the hospital where they were receiving medical treatment as a part of DDR (Disarmament, Demobilization, and Rehabilitation) process. The protesters complained that the officials enforcing DDR considered wounded former TDF members equal to non-wounded members and demanded treatment tailored to their context. They blocked (with stones) the main road connecting Mekelle with Wukro and Adigrat. After discussing it with the Tigray Interim Administration security and political leaders, the protesters opened the road in the afternoon.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders marched while carrying banners, placards and singing in Kilifi (Kilifi North, Kilifi) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders including a lawyer, gathered while carrying a banner in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women, the deaf, university students and parents of children living with disabilities and joined by women rights defenders, marched (under police escort) to the deputy county commissioner's office in Nyeri town (Nyeri Central, Nyeri) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders protested in Garissa (Garissa, Garissa) against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, doctors gathered and sang solidarity songs at the Nairobi hospital (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against mismanagement at the facility. Led by KMPDU officials, the group demanded for the resignation of the entire board of directors including the chief executive officer.

On 10 December 2024, hundreds of residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders, gathered at the Jeevanjee gardens and marched while chanting, carrying placards and blowing whistles within the Nairobi central business district (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against increased cases of femicide. Police intervened and lobbed teargas as well as arrested at least three (other sources mention five, while others 10) people. Several people, including journalists sustained injuries during the incident. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence. Top police officers were transferred as well as placed under investigation by the Internal Affairs Unit (IAU) of the police, for mishandling the protest.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women representative (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) gathered in Meru town (Imenti North, Meru) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders gathered in Webuye (Webuye West, Bungoma) against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 10 December 2024, residents, mainly women protested in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.

On 11 December 2024, doctors joined by KMPDU officials, gathered and held hand in solidarity, at the Kiambu level V hospital (Kiambu Town, Kiambu) in protest against delayed salaries among other grievances. The group demanded that the government honor the collective bargaining agreement.

Around 11 December 2024 (as reported), over 5000 residents of Kaya Fungo and Mwanamwinga wards, marched while carrying twigs and chanting, in an unspecified location (coded to the nearest known location as Kayafungo, Kaloleni, Kilifi) against an attempt to grab their ancestral land. The group demanded the county governor to address the matter.

On 11 December 2024, doctors joined by KMPDU officials, gathered at the Machakos level 5 hospital (Machakos, Machakos) in protest against delayed salaries among other grievances. The group demanded that the government honor the collective bargaining agreement.
On 11 December 2024, about 50 women from the Somali national women organization protested in Mogadishu (Banadir) against the plans to re-locate the Guriga Hooyooyink to the ministry of women.
Around 11 December 2024 (as reported), a group of residents protested in Dima Sub- County coded to district seat Kiryandongo (Kibanda, Kiryandongo), against the bad state of their road.

On 11 December 2024, locals protested in Kismayo town (Kismaayo, Lower Juba) in support of the victory of Jubaland security forces over the government security forces (SNA) in Ras Kamboni (coded separately).
On 11 December 2024, county workers protested in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) against delayed pay. The group demanded audience with the governor.
Around 11 December 2024 (as reported), health workers including nurses, protested at the Bungoma county referral hospital (Kanduyi, Bungoma) against delayed pay. The group demanded their dues.
Around 11 December 2024 (as reported), health workers including nurses, protested at the Kimilili sub-county referral hospital (Kimilili, Bungoma) against delayed pay. The group demanded their dues.

On 11 December 2024, intern doctors, joined by KMPDU officials, marched from Kenyatta national hospital while carrying placards and a coffin, before camping outside the Ministry of health headquarters, at Afya house in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against delayed pay. The group demanded for the implementation of the collective bargaining agreement.

On 11 December 2024, P1 grade teachers gathered in an unspecified location within Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against delayed employment by the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) among other grievances. The group demanded the government through TSC to address their grievances.

On 11 December 2024, university students protested in Witeithie (Juja, Kiambu) over claims of incompetence by the students' leadership as well as frustration by lecturers, following the death of their colleague via suicide. The group demanded the responsible lecturer to resign.

On 12 December 2024, residents held a peaceful protest in Lalibela (Lalibela town, North Wello, Amhara), calling for an end to the ongoing armed conflict in the Amhara region. The residents emphasized the socio-economic impact of the conflict including the potential damage caused by the sound of heavy weapons to the historic churches in the town.

On 12 December 2024, over 200 - 400 fourth-year students protested at the of the university of Nairobi lower Kabete campus (Kabete, Kiambu) against the exclusion of their names from the graduation list. The group demanded that the dean address the matter.

On 12 December 2024, residents disrupted the Jamhuri (independence) day celebrations by chanting anti-president slogans during the county commissioner's speech at the Engineer's ground (Kinangop, Nyandarua) in protest against unfulfilled government promises. The commissioner proceeded with his speech as planned.

On 12 December 2024, tens of residents, mainly boda boda taxi operators, blocked the Total-Sabaki road with stones in Athi River (Athi River, Machakos) in protest against the poor state of the road. The group demanded a that private investor selling murrum from the quarries to fix the road.

Around 12 December 2024 (as reported), workers protested at the Nzoia sugar company (Kanduyi, Bungoma) against the company's move to sack their union's secretary general. The group demanded that the union official be reinstated and for the dissolution of the board of directors.

Around 12 December 2024 (as reported), lawyers protested at the Maua law courts (Igembe South, Meru) in protest against shortage of judges and magistrates. The group demanded the chief justice to address the matter.

On 12 December 2024, patrons sang solidarity song and chanted anti-government slogans at club VSpot in Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu) in protest against unfulfilled government promises. The group demanded for change.
On 13 December 2024, a group of residents from the Baruuli clan protested in the town of Nakasongola (Buruli, Nakasongola), against the Baganda's installations and celebrations on their land.

Around 13 December 2024 (as reported), donkey farmers gathered and spoke in unison in Kipsis (Cheptais, Bungoma) in protest against the slaughter of donkeys for meat. The group demanded the government to develop laws to address the matter.
On 13 December 2024, residents protested in Nyamache (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against delayed repair of a collapsed bridge. The group demanded their area member of parliament to address the matter.

Around 13 December 2024 (as reported), P1 grade teachers gathered while carrying placards in Kapenguria (West Pokot, West Pokot) in protest against discrimination in hiring and job overstay. The group demanded the government through Teachers Service Commission (TSC) to address their grievances.

On 14 December 2024, a multitude of residents, raised their hands in a sign of rejection while chanting anti-president slogans during a football tournament in Machakos (Machakos, Machakos) in protest against unfulfilled government promises. Led by the Wiper-Azimio party leader, the group demanded the president to focus on empowering the youth.

On 15 December 2024, residents staged a protest in Gatira, Setema (Jimma, Oromia) to denounce the attack by Kebele militias in the market (coded separately). The protesters also chanted during the protest.

Around 15 December 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly elders from the Kwabwai ward gathered at Got Kojowi market (Ndhiwa, Homa Bay) in protest against increased insecurity, following a recent incident where a mother and her daughter were sexually assaulted by three gang members. Led by two senior retired chiefs among others, the group demanded the police to hasten investigations and bring to book the suspects.

Around 15 December 2024 (week of), hundreds of people protested in the town of Kikuube (Buhaguzi, Kikuube), against the EACOP (East African Crude Oil Pipeline) project calling for an immediate halt to the project. The protesters were carrying placards with messages like 'No to land grabs,' 'No to eviction,' 'No to environmental harm,' and 'Stop EACOP.'

On 15 December 2024, members of the salvation army church protested in Nairobi central business district (Starehe, Nairobi) against the poor management of the Nairobi central temple complex. The group demanded to sign a new contract for the management of the facility.

On 16 December 2024, a group of teachers from Teticha wereda staged a peaceful demonstration in Teticha (Sidama), opposing their salary deduction (amount unknown/not reported) for the Prosperity Party's fifth-year anniversary celebration. The Sidama state police assaulted the protesters (means unknown/not reported) and arrested an unspecified number of teachers.

On 16 December 2024, health workers, mainly members of the KMPDU marched while blowing vuvuzelas from the Kenyatta national hospital to Nairobi hospital, before proceeding to the ministry of health headquarters at Afya house, within Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the government failure to implement their 2017 and 2021 Collective Bargaining Agreements (CBA), among other grievances. The group demanded for the implementation of their CBAs as well as the disbandment of the Nairobi hospital board.

On 16 December 2024, health workers, mainly KUCO members gathered at the green park terminus, before marching to the ministry of health headquarters at the Afya house, then to the Social Health Authority (SHA) offices, in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against claimed corruption and discrimination by the SHA board in the registration of healthcare facilities operated by clinicians. The group demanded the right to do pre-authorization reinstated.

Around 17 December 2024 (as reported), residents of Silale and Uaso Narok gathered while carrying twigs in Mutitu near Uaso Narok (Laikipia North, Laikipia) in protest against the invasion and destruction of their farmlands by Elephants. The group demanded the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS) to help restrict the animals by erecting a fence.

Around 17 December 2024 (as reported), residents, mainly athletics stakeholders including current and former professional athletes, civil society representatives, footballers, and opinion leaders, protested in Kapsabet (Chesumei, Nandi) against the proposed move by the county government to convert the Kipchoge Keino stadium into a modern market. The group demanded the stadium to be upgraded to international standards.

On 17 December 2024, residents, joined by political leaders allied to the immediate past deputy president (mainly UDA-Kenya Kwanza members), protested in Engineer town (Kinangop, Nyandarua) against the move by security officers to arrest two Members of County Assembly (MCAs), accused of mobilizing youths to reject the president's speech during the recent Jamhuri day celebrations (coded separately). The group demanded for the release of the MCA's as well as the president to stop intimidating their leaders.

Around 17 December 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Kilimo neighborhood of Nanyuki town (Laikipia East, Laikipia) against poor waste management by the county government. The group demanded the county government to address the matter.

On 17 December 2024, residents of Difathas and nearby areas, including parts of Gichugu and Mwea constituencies blocked the Mwea-Embu highway (means unspecified) in Difathas (Kirinyaga East, Kirinyaga) in protest against increased road accidents, following the recent killing of a boda boda taxi operator and his pillion passenger by a speeding vehicle transporting miraa (khat). The group demanded accountability from the owners of the vehicles. Police intervened (means unspecified) and restored calm.

On 17 December 2024, residents, mainly women and joined by women rights defenders gathered in Magarini (Magarini, Kilifi) in protest against increased cases of femicide. The group demanded for urgent action to end the killing of women. The event happened in the context of 16 days of activism against gender-based violence.
Around 17 December 2024 (as reported), retrenched government workers gathered while singing in Voi (Voi, Taita Taveta) in protest against delayed pay. The group demanded their dues.

On 18 December 2024, residents staged a peaceful demonstration in Alala (Eferatana Gidem, North Shewa, Amhara) to oppose the government's military operation in the Amhara region. According to the Fano representative from the area, the protesters demanded the withdrawal of ENDF from the region.

On 18 December 2024, residents staged a peaceful demonstration in Tere (Kewet, North Shewa, Amhara) to oppose the government's military operation in the Amhara region. According to the Fano representative from the area, the protesters demanded the withdrawal of ENDF from the region.

On 18 December 2024, residents staged a peaceful demonstration in Wegere (Menze Lalo Midir, North Shewa, Amhara) to oppose the government's military operation in the Amhara region. According to the Fano representative from the area, the protesters demanded the withdrawal of ENDF from the region and featured various slogans criticizing the government.

On 18 December 2024, residents staged a peaceful demonstration in Mezezo (Tarema Ber, North Shewa) featuring posters and slogans opposing the government's military operation in the Amhara region. The protesters demanded the withdrawal of ENDF from the Amhara region and called for the international community to pay attention to the conflict in the region.

On 18 December 2024, over 1000 members of the Oldonyio Sampu conservancy, marched while chanting in Linti market (Kajiado Central, Kajiado) in protest against a planned carbon project in the conservancy by unknown people, claiming lack of community participation. The group demanded the government to help address the matter.
On 18 December 2024, nurses protested in Kiambu (Kiambu Town, Kiambu) against delayed pay. Led by the KNUN branch secretary general, the group demanded the county government to address the matter.

On 18 December 2024, residents gathered while carrying twigs and chanting in Maili Saba (Laikipia West, Laikipia) in protest against the road closure by an investor. The group demanded their area leaders to help re-open the road.

On 18 December 2024, a group of people protested against the arrest of a suspected thief in downtown Kampala City (Kampala, Kampala). To disperse the crowd, one policeman grabbed a gun from a colleague and in an attempt to shoot in the air, he shot towards a tall building nearby, killing a worker who was at a balcony.

Around 18 December 2024 (as reported), residents protested in Kimuri near Makutano (Mbeere South, Embu) against delayed completion of the rural electrification project. The group demanded the area member of parliament to help address the matter.

On 18 December 2024, workers protested at the Nzoia sugar company (Kanduyi, Bungoma) against delayed pay. Led by Kenya union of sugarcane workers officials, the group demanded the company management to address the matter.

Other: On 18 December 2024, residents held government-led rallies in Gonder, Weldiya, Kemise, Dessie, Sekota and Bahir Dar (coded to Bahir Dar town, West Gojam, Amhara), calling for an end to the ongoing armed conflict in the Amhara region. Some participants/reports indicated that the government/authorities coerced residents and public servants to join the rallies, threatening them with arrest and salary cuts. An unidentified armed group carried out a grenade attack during the rally (coded separately).

On 19 December 2024, Maasai herders gathered in Kajiado (Kajiado Central, Kajiado) in protest against the plans by the government move to vaccinate livestock. The group demanded the government to focus on the challenges of animal feeds.

On 19 December 2024, students of Debark University staged a public demonstration on the premises of Debark University in Debark (Debark town, North Gondar, Amhara), protesting the low budget for student meals. The police shot and killed 1 and wounded 2 other students (fatalities uncorroborated). The police also arrested many students and released them on the following day, 20 December 2024.

On 19 December 2024, people living with disabilities marched in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) in protest against challenges in accessing health services, following the transition from the National Health Insurance Fund (NHIF) to Social Health Authority (SHA). The group demanded the government to provide civic education on the matter.

On 20 December 2024, employees of Mesfin Industrial Engineering staged a public demonstration in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), complaining about low wages and poor employment conditions. The employees complained that no improvement had been made since they conducted the first demonstration on 22 October 2024 (coded separately). The employees staged a strike from 20 to 25 December 2024, and the organization suspended 250 employees from their jobs and salaries for one month.

On 20 December 2024, a group of KUPPET and junior secondary school (JSS) teachers disrupted the KUPPET's annual delegates' conference by singing and chanting at the Sosa hotel in Gisambai (Hamisi, Vihiga) in protest against a plan to increase the union's top executives' retirement age from the current 60 to 65. Police officers and some youth wearing KUPPET uniforms intervened and ejected the protestors from the conference.

On 20 December 2024, residents, joined by the area member of parliament (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) marched while carrying placards and hooting motorcycles in Nyeri (Nyeri Central, Nyeri) in support of the recent move by the president to nominate a cabinet secretary from the area. The group demanded the rest of Kenyans to give the government time to deliver on the promises.

Around 21 December 2024 (as reported), parents protested at Kasodo mixed secondary school near Rongo (Rongo, Migori) against misuse of school funds. The group demanded accountability from the school management.

On 21 December 2024, locals from Waxaracade area protested at the Daljirka Dahsoon neighborhood in Mogadishu - Bondhere (Banadir) against eviction from lands that they claimed to have occupied for a long time by the government.

Around 22 December 2024 (as reported), family members, joined by Tom Mboya university students gathered in Homa Bay (Homa Bay Town, Homa Bay) in protest against the recent killing of a university student (with mental challenges) by hotel workers (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased victim.

On 22 December 2024, worshipers locked all entrances to the sanctuary with some carrying placards, at the Presbyterian Church of East Africa (PCEA) Elim in Kenol (Muranga South, Muranga) to protest against mismanagement of the church by the reverend, following the recent move by the reverend to deny politicians an opportunity to address the congregants. The group demanded for the transfer of the reverend.

On 23 December 2024, pharmacists gathered and held hands in solidarity in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) to protest against the failure by the county government to recognize their labor union. The group demanded the county to address their grievances.

On 23 December 2024, hundreds to thousands of residents gathered while carrying twigs, waving placards, and displaying their land title deeds at Kondoo farm 3 (Kesses, Uasin Gishu) in protest against a planned move by a private developer to evict them from their land. The group demanded the president to help stop the planned eviction.

On 23 December 2024, hundreds of workers blocked the main gate of the East African Portland Cement Company (EAPCC) using tractors in Athi River (Athi River, Machakos) in protest against the appointment of a new managing director. The group demanded the company board to release each candidate's interview results for the position.

On 23 December 2024, nurses gathered and sang solidarity songs in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against failure to sign collective bargaining agreement (CBA) as well as lack of promotions among other grievances. Led by KNUN officials, the group demanded the county government as well as national government through the ministry of health, to address their grievances.

On 23 December 2024, former workers at the Mumias sugar company, protested in Mumias (Mumias West, Kakamega) against delayed payment of their arrears. Led by their union chairman, the group demanded both the government and the current company investor to address their grievances.

On 24 December 2024, for the second day, nurses gathered and sang solidarity songs in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against failure to sign collective bargaining agreement (CBA) as well as lack of promotions among other grievances. Led by KNUN officials, the group demanded the county government as well as national government through the ministry of health, to address their grievances.

On 24 December 2024, tens of residents marched and blocked the Maralal-Baragoi road with branches in Lpartuk (Samburu Central, Samburu) to protest against lack of development in the area as well as against the planned evictions from their land by unidentified individuals, following a land dispute. The group demanded the county government to help address the matter.

Around 24 December 2024 (as reported), residents chanted while carrying twigs in Chepchoina (Endebess, Trans Nzoia) in protest against increased insecurity. The group demanded the security officers to address the matter.

On 26 December 2024, civilians protested long the main road in Dhobley village (Afmadow, Lower Juba) against the federal government. The protesters criticized the suspension of local and international flights and highlighted the growing concerns over the ongoing conflicts in the Gedo region (coded separately).

On 26 December 2024, civilians protested at the Wamo Football Stadium in Farjano village (Kismaayo, Lower Juba) against the federal government. The protesters criticized the suspension of local and international flights and highlighted the growing concerns over the ongoing conflicts in the Gedo region (coded separately).

On 26 December 2024, community health workers gathered in Kericho (Ainamoi, Kericho) to protest against delayed pay. The protest involved some clapping and ululating by the protesters who also demanded that the county government address the matter.

On 27 December 2024, hundreds of Christians, Muslims and traditional believers from the GEMA community gathered at the Samson Corner (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) to protest against the ongoing abductions and enforced disappearances. Led by the director of the Gikuyu and Mumbi cultural museum, the group demanded the government to address the matter. The event happened in the context of their annual prayer session.

On 27 December 2024, nurses marched in the streets before staging a sit-in at the county headquarters in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) to protest against failure to sign collective bargaining agreement (CBA) as well as lack of promotions among other grievances. Led by KNUN officials, the group demanded the county government as well as national government through the ministry of health, to address their grievances.

On 28 December 2024, residents protested outside the Nyando law courts (Nyando, Kisumu) in support of the arrest and arraignment of a man (described as a serial assault suspect). The group demanded the suspect detained.

On 28 December 2024, residents, joined by the county women representative (WDM, Azimio) protested in Kalamba Muyo (Mwingi North, Kitui) against the ongoing abductions and enforced disappearances targeting the youth, following the recent abduction of one of a resident in Ngong (coded separately). The group demanded for the release of the abducted youth.

On 28 December 2024, residents protested in Utange (Kisauni, Mombasa) against intimidation by an absentee landlord on a government owned land. The group demanded the government to hand them the possession of the land.

On 28 December 2024, youth gathered while carrying placards in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against the ongoing abductions and enforced disappearances targeting the youth. The group demanded for the release of the abducted youths.

On 28 December 2024, Early Childhood Development Education (ECDE) teachers protested in Nyamira (Nyamira, Nyamira) against the move by the county government to terminate their contracts. The group demanded the labor unions and human rights defenders to help address the matter.

On 28 December 2024, residents blocked the Meru-Nairobi road (means unspecified) in Chuka (Chuka, Tharaka-Nithi) in protest against the ongoing abductions and enforced disappearances targeting the youth, following the recent abduction of one of their own in Uthiru (coded separately). The group demanded for the release of the victims.

On 28 December 2024, residents protested in Limtidi village (coded to the subcounty headquarters as Muhoroni, Muhoroni, Kisumu) against poor state of roads in the area. The group demanded their elected leaders to address the matter.

Around 29 December 2024 (as reported), UDA-Kenya Kwanza supporters gathered in Gongo village (Rangwe, Homa Bay) in protest against poor leadership at the ward level, as well as the failure to adhere to party rules. The group demanded the party's executive organ at the headquarters to suspend the current office holders.

On 29 December 2024, locals from Waxaracade area protested at the Daljirka Dahsoon neighborhood in Mogadishu - Bondhere (Banadir) against eviction from lands that they claimed to have occupied for a long time by the government.

On 29 December 2024, youth protested in Nanyuki (Laikipia East, Laikipia) against the ongoing abductions and enforced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). The group demanded for the release of the victims.

On 30 December 2024, residents, mainly youth joined by human rights defenders including the representatives from Haki Africa gathered at Uhuru gardens in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against ongoing abductions and forced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). Police intervened and arrested 13 protestors.

On 30 December 2024, locals protested in Miisaanka neighborhood in Mogadishu - Yaqshid (Banadir) against eviction from lands that they occupied for a long time by the government. Police opened gunfire to disperse the crowd and injured two people.
On 30 December 2024, locals protested in Jalalaqsi town (Jalalaqsi, Hiraan) against the killing of the seven soldiers (coded separately) and demanded justice for the families.

On 30 December 2024, a group of teachers protested the arrest of their Sacco secretary in Kira (Kira, Wakiso). The secretary was accused of mismanaging funds offered to the Sacco by President Museveni.

On 30 December 2024, residents, mainly youth joined by a former presidential aspirant (independent) protested in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against ongoing abductions and forced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). Police intervened and arrested the former presidential aspirant as well as confiscated their placards.

On 30 December 2024, hundreds of residents, mainly youth joined by human rights defenders, lobby groups and a Busia senator (Independent) among others, protested in the Nairobi central business district (Starehe, Nairobi) against ongoing abductions and forced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). Police intervened lobbed teargas to disperse the group, arrested and arraigned 23 protestors.

On 31 December 2024, 13 detained human rights defenders chanted liberation songs inside Mombasa court (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against ongoing abductions and enforced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). The group demanded an end to the abductions as well as release of the victims.

On 31 December 2024, hundreds of residents marched in the streets, while waving banners and chanting anti-president slogans at the Githurai neighborhood of Nairobi - Roysambu (Roysambu, Nairobi) in protest against rising living costs, high taxes, and unmet expectations. The group demanded the government to address their grievances.

On 31 December 2024, 23 anti-abduction protesters including Busia senator (independent) who were arrested, sang solidarity songs at the Milimani law courts in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against ongoing abductions and enforced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). The group demanded an end to the abductions as well as release of the victims.
On 31 December 2024, residents protested in Ruiru (Ruiru, Kiambu) against rising living costs, high taxes, and unmet expectations. The group demanded the government to address their grievances.

On 1 January 2025, around 1000 protesters (most of them youths) staged a peaceful demonstration in front of Mekele town municipal administration in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray). The demonstrators opposed the closure of the Mekele town mayor's office, which was sealed off by security forces a month ago due to the disagreement between the TPLF and the Interim Regional Administration of Tigray over the appointment of the mayor of Mekelle town. The demonstrators asked for the reinstatement of the Mekele mayor appointed by the Tigray region's interim administration and requested that the Tigray region security forces remain neutral in the disagreement between the Tigray Region Interim Administration and the TPLF. The Tigray state police heavily presented at the demonstration site and blocked (means unknown/not reported) some individuals before they arrived at the demonstration area.

On 2 January 2025, former TPLF fighters who were wounded in the northern Ethiopia conflict staged a protest in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), requesting the authorities to speed up the disarmament, rehabilitation and reintegration process of the former TPLF fighters. The protestors blocked the road from Mekele town to Alula Aba Nega airport for two hours. A government representative appeared and confirmed to the protestors that talks with the federal government are underway to resume the process.

On 2 January 2025, locals protested in Qoryooley town (Qoryooley, Lower Shabelle) against the local administration over poor services. Police opened gunfire to disperse the crowd and injured three people.

On 2 January 2025, hundreds of residents, mainly sugarcane farmers and boda boda taxi operators from Tangakona and Nambale, protested outside West Kenya sugar factory in Olepito (Teso South, Busia) against claimed bias in decision making by the sugar board, following the move by the board to only allow Mumias sugar to resume milling. The group demanded for the decision cancelled and all factories to be re-opened.

On 2 January 2025, residents, mainly parents and students gathered and sang in unison in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against fraud in the Finland education program ran by the county government. The group demanded justice for the victims.

On 2 January 2025, a group of Kikuyu elders living in the North rift and western regions gathered while carrying placards in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against claimed divisive politics by the immediate former Deputy President (DP). The group demanded the former DP to keep off from the politics of the region for development and stability. The event happened in the context of a consultative meeting of the group.

Around 3 January 2025 (as reported), youth gathered and chanted in Busia (Matayos, Busia) in protest against ongoing abductions and forced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). The group demanded for the release of the abducted victims.

On 3 January 2025, members of the Coast Parliamentary Group (CPG) marched to the coast region Kenya Wildlife Services (KWS) offices in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against increasing human-wildlife conflict, following the recent killing of an elder by a KWS personnel (coded separately). The group demanded the ministry of tourism and wildlife to hasten the creation of a grazing corridor in Yakaliche village, to help resolve the conflict.

On 3 January 2025, women from Githunguri, Gichumbu and Kirumi villages marched while carrying placards and twigs, at an unspecified location (coded to the subcounty headquarters as Gatanga, Gatanga, Muranga) in protest against the increased sale of illicit brews, following the recent death of a man in the area. The group demanded the area leaders to address the matter as well as justice for the deceased victim.

Around 3 January 2025 (as reported), residents protested in the South B neighborhood of Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) against land grabbing. The group demanded the relevant authorities to address the matter.

On 4 January 2025, technical university students gathered and chanted in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against ongoing abductions and forced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). The group demanded for the release of the abducted youths.

On 4 January 2025, residents, mainly youths protested in Busia (Matayos, Busia) against ongoing abductions and forced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). The group demanded for the release of the abducted youths.

On 4 January 2025, more than 100 bishops from various denominations protested in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against increased cases of land grabbing targeting churches and other places of worship, following the recent move by unknown people who raided and demolished Logos church (coded separately). The group demanded the National Land Commission (NLC) to investigate the matter.

Around 4 January 2025 (as reported), traders protested at Mogonga market (Bomachoge Borabu, Kisii) against the poor state of the market including lack of sanitation facilities and street lighting. The group demanded the county governor to address the matter.
On 5 January 2025, local business owners protested in Mogadishu - Hamar Weyne (Banadir) against the local administration for evicting them from the business area.

On 5 January 2025, members of the Salvation Army Church protested in Nairobi city Centre (Starehe, Nairobi) against poor management of church properties and investments. The group demanded that the international headquarters send auditors to help address the matter.

On 5 January 2025, residents gathered in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) in protest against ongoing abductions and forced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately) and against the recent move by the Kikuyu member of parliament to castigate the leadership of the Trans Nzoia governor. The group demanded for the release of the abducted youths and respect for the governor's leadership.

On 6 January 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against ongoing abductions and forced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). The group demanded for the release of the abducted youths. Police used unspecified means to disperse the group.

On 6 January 2025, human rights defenders protested at the Gatoto community primary school in Mukuru kwa Reuben neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi South (Embakasi South, Nairobi) against the ownership and management of the school. Parents intervened and evicted the protestors through unspecified means.

On 6 January 2025, residents of Asa and Kone marched while carrying placards and twigs, to an unspecified location (coded to the nearest known location as Asa, Garsen, Tana River) in protest against harassment by Kenya wildlife rangers, following the recent killing of one of the residents (coded separately). The group demanded the president to help address the matter.

On 6 January 2025, residents of villages along the Meru-Isiolo border, including Kiwanja, Attan, Chumviere, Tractor, Epiding, and Attir, gathered while carrying placards at an unspecified location (coded to one of the affected villages as Attan, Isiolo, Isiolo) in protest against harassment and illegal demolitions by the military (coded separately), following a land ownership dispute. The group demanded for the president to help address the matter.

On 6 January 2025, public service vehicle (matatu) operators protested at the Keveye bus park (Sabatia, Vihiga) against increased taxation by the county government. The group demanded the county to address the matter.

Around 6 January 2025 (as reported), parents protested at Kamotyo primary school (Chepalungu, Bomet) against poor state of the school infrastructure. The group demanded the authorities to address the matter.

Around 6 January 2025 (as reported), residents protested in Kilera (Igembe North, Meru) in protest against the invasion and destruction of their farmlands by Elephants. The group demanded that the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS) compensate them.

On 6 January 2025, dozens of residents marched in Mtwapa (Kilifi South, Kilifi) in protest against ongoing abductions and forced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). The group demanded for the release of the abducted youths.

On 6 January 2025, parents blocked (means unspecified) the entrance to Yago primary school (Ndhiwa, Homa Bay) in protest against mismanagement. Led by the board of management vice chairman, the group demanded for the transfer of the head teacher.

On 6 January 2025, human rights defenders under the banner 'gen Z movement' Kisumu chapter, other sources mention civil society groups, attempted to gather at the Jaramogi Oginga Odinga sports ground in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in protest against ongoing abductions and enforced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately. The group demanded for the release of the abducted youths among others. Police intervened and cordoned off the grounds.

On 6 January 2025, residents, mainly women, joined by human rights defenders gathered, chanted, sang hymns and freedom songs, with some chasing away plain cloth police officers, within the Nairobi central business district (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against ongoing abductions and forced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). Police intervened and arrested several human rights defenders.

On 6 January 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) against ongoing abductions and forced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). Police intervened and arrested a few protestors.

On 7 January 2025, scores of residents, mainly women, blocked (means unspecified) the Isinya-Kiserian road (other sources mention Kikuria-Kajiado road) (coded to the nearest known location as Isinya, Kajiado East, Kajiado) in protest against the poor state of the road. The group demanded the authorities to fix the road.

On 7 January 2025, residents marched while carrying placards in Mtwapa (Kilifi South, Kilifi) in protest against the criticism of the senate speaker by the Narc Kenya leader, following his recent remarks on the ongoing abduction of youth by state agents (coded separately). The group demanded other leaders to show respect to the senate speaker.

On 7 January 2025, residents, mainly youth, marched while carrying placards in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) in protest against the recent move by Kenya Kwanza leaders led by the leader of majority in parliament to castigate the leadership of the Trans Nzoia governor. The group demanded respect for the governor's leadership.
On 7 January 2025, health workers from a private hospital protested in Murinduko (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) against delayed pay. The group demanded their pay.

On 7 January 2025, residents marched while carrying twigs in Nyakwerema (Borabu, Nyamira) in protest against the move by one of the residents to block off a public road by erecting a fence. The group demanded the road re-opened.

On 8 January 2025, residents, mainly farmers, marched while carrying twigs in Banita (Rongai, Nakuru) in protest against the invasion of their farms by illegal herders (coded separately). The group demanded the government to heighten security in the area.

On 8 January 2025, parents, joined by human rights defenders and politicians including area member of parliament (ODM, Azimio) protested at the St. Anne's girls' school in Nairobi - Makadara (Makadara, Nairobi) against the recent move by the school principal to lock out students at night for failing to pay school fees. The group demanded the principal to resign.

Around 8 January 2025 (as reported), parents protested at Amariba mixed secondary school (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against the incompetence of the headteacher. The group demanded for management overhaul, including the transfer of the head teacher.

Around 8 January 2025 (as reported), hundreds of Somali herders marched to the county commissioner's office in Isiolo (Isiolo, Isiolo) in protest against the recent move by the government to disarm national police reservists. The group demanded the county commissioner to address their grievances.

On 8 January 2025, public service vehicle drivers protested at the Lindi main bus stage (Liwale, Lindi) against the move by authorities to suspend their licenses and increased road fines. The group demanded that their grievances be addressed.

On 9 January 2025, a group of Lawyers and human rights activists protested in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), against the arrest of their fellow who was representing a prominent opposition figure (Kiiza Besigye) in court and was detained. The police intervened and arrested seven protesters.

On 10 January 2025, residents including transport operators blocked the Junction-Ruiri road with stones, branches and planting banana stems in Kithoka (Imenti North, Meru) in protest against the poor state of the road. The group demanded that the area member of parliament fix the road.

On 10 January 2025, street traders waved placards, blew whistles, ululated and punched fists in the air while chanting slogans as they marched around round City Hall building in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the governor's recent directive to keep off from the main streets within the city centre. The group demanded that the directive be reversed.

On 11 January 2025, residents protested at the Argada Number 4 area in Mogadishu - Hodan (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle) to oppose their eviction from lands that they had occupied for a long time by the government.

On 12 January 2025, residents protested in the Dalxiiska area of Farjano neighborhood in Kismayo town (Kismaayo, Lower Juba), supporting the Jubaland cabinet's recent communique and expressing vehement opposition to the federal government.

On 12 January 2025, residents of Asgede woreda protested in Kisad Gaba, also known as May Seye, Asgede (North Western Tigray, Tigray), against the use of toxic chemicals by illegal miners. The protest, led by young people, was held in front of the local administration office, where they voiced their grievances against local authorities and Chinese mining companies operating in the area. The protesters demanded an end to illegal mining and the unauthorized use of harmful chemicals, chanting slogans such as 'Stop illegal mining', 'Stop the unlawful use of chemicals,' and 'Justice for the youth'. More than 20 protesters were arrested by local security forces (coded as Tigray Regional Police) for two days and released after being warned to remain silent.

On 13 January 2025, IDPs (mainly displaced from western Tigray and other weredas along the Ethio-Eritrea border) staged a public demonstration in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), requesting the Interim Regional Administration of Tigray, the federal government, and the international community to return them to their homes and ensure the full implementation of the Pretoria cessation of hostilities agreement signed between the Government of Ethiopia and the TPLF. The demonstration led to the closure of main traffic roads and the deployment of many police officers in the town. The interim administration issued a statement supporting the cause of the IDPs and requested the federal government to return IDPs to their homes by removing non-ENDF forces from Western Tigray and Ethio-Eritrea borders. Tsilal Civil Society of Western Tigray coordinated the peaceful demonstration.

On 13 January 2025, over 800 health workers, mainly members of KNUN and the National Nurses Association of Kenya (NNAK), protested in Homa Bay (Homa Bay Town, Homa Bay) against poor working conditions. The group that demanded the county government address their grievances.

On 13 January 2025, health workers, mainly members of KNUN and the National Nurses Association of Kenya (NNAK) protested in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against poor working conditions. The group demanded that the county government address their grievances.

On 13 January 2025, residents of Magongo joined by KUPPET representatives marched while carrying placards to Changamwe police station (Changamwe, Mombasa) in protest against the disappearance of a three-year-old child, belonging to one of the teachers in the area. The group demanded that the police to address the matter.

On 13 January 2025, street traders, mainly women protested in the Posta area of Busia town (Matayos, Busia) against claimed harassment by county enforcement officers. The group demanded the governor to help address the matter.

On 13 January 2025, health workers, mainly members of KNUN and the National Nurses Association of Kenya (NNAK), protested in Migori (Suna West, Migori) against poor working conditions. The group demanded that the county government address their grievances.

On 13 January 2025, Universal Health Converge (UHC) workers marched while carrying placards and chanting, in Maralal (Samburu Central, Samburu) in protest against unfair salaries. The group demanded for permanent and pensionable terms of employment.

On 13 January 2025, residents, mainly youth gathered while carrying placards in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in protest against ongoing abductions and enforced disappearances targeting the youth (coded separately). The group demanded for the government to accept accountability as well as form the new Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC).

On 13 January 2025, health workers, mainly members of KNUN and the National Nurses Association of Kenya (NNAK), protested in Bungoma (Kanduyi, Bungoma) against poor working conditions. The group demanded that the county government address their grievances.

On 13 January 2025, teaching and non-teaching staff at Moi University gathered and sang solidarity songs at the main campus in Kesses (Kesses, Uasin Gishu) in protest against delayed pay. Led by UASU leaders, the group demanded for their pay as well as well as full implementation of return-to-work formula by the university management.

On 13 January 2025, residents blocked Thika road (means unspecified) at Ruiru (Ruiru, Kiambu) in protest against ongoing abductions and enforced disappearances targeting the youth (further details unknown/not reported), following the discovery of a body in a nearby river. The group demanded for greater transparency and accountability from law enforcement officers.

On 13 January 2025, and for a second day, residents of Asgede woreda protested in Kisad Gaba, also known as May Seye, Asgede (North Western Tigray, Tigray), against the use of toxic chemicals by illegal miners. The protest, led by young people, was held in front of the local administration office, where they voiced their grievances against local authorities and Chinese mining companies operating in the area. The protesters demanded an end to illegal mining and the unauthorized use of harmful chemicals, chanting slogans such as 'Stop illegal mining', 'Stop the unlawful use of chemicals,' and 'Justice for the youth'. More than 20 protesters were arrested by local security forces (coded as Tigray Regional Police) for two days and released after being warned to remain silent.

On 14 January 2025, for the second day, IDPs (mainly displaced from western Tigray and other weredas along the Ethio-Eritrea border) continued protesting at Romanat Square in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray). They started the peaceful demonstration on 13 January 2025 (coded separately) to request the signatories of the Pretoria agreement and mediators to ensure the full implementation of the agreement and return IDPs to their homes. Tsilal Civil Society of Western Tigray coordinated the peaceful demonstration.

On 14 January 2025, residents, mainly boda boda taxi operators, blocked the Nakuru-Marigat road with stones in London estate (Nakuru West, Nakuru) in protest against police harassment, following the recent shooting and injury of their colleague by the police (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the victim.

Around 14 January 2025 (as reported), parents protested at Kwang'amor mixed secondary school (Teso South, Busia) against poor performance in the recently released Kenya Certificate of Secondary Education (KCSE) examination results, accusing the principal of school poor management and embezzlement of school funds. The group demanded that the principal be transferred.

On 14 January 2025, parents and students protested at Lmisigiyoi primary school (Samburu Central, Samburu) against delayed reopening of the school due to lack of teachers. The group demanded for the transfer of all the teachers.

On 14 January 2025, dozens of health workers mainly members of KNUN, marched in the streets of Kisumu town (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in protest against poor working conditions. The group demanded that the county government address their grievances.

On 14 January 2025, Technical University of Kenya (TUK) teaching and non-teaching staff, mainly members of UASU,KUSU and KUDHEIHA, marched while singing patriotic songs and chanting slogans in the Nairobi central business district (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against delayed pay. The group demanded the government through the ministry of education and the university council to address their grievances.

On 15 January 2025, for the third day, IDPs (mainly displaced from western Tigray and other weredas along the Ethio-Eritrea border) staged a public demonstration in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), requesting the Interim Regional Administration of Tigray, the federal government, and the international community to return them to their homes and ensure the full implementation of the Pretoria agreement. After finalizing their three-day protest, the protesters submitted their written demands to the interim regional administration and the head of the TPLF party. They asked that the regional administration leaders should resign if they were unable to return the IDPs to their homes. Tsilal Civil Society of Western Tigray coordinated the peaceful demonstration.

On 15 January 2025, pyrethrum company employees, gathered and chanted in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) in protest against poor management of the company as well as misuse of office by the company's chief executive officer. Led by their union branch chairman, the group demanded the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (EACC) to probe the company's operations.

Around 15 January 2025 (as reported), parents and students, protested at Gaketha primary school (Muthambi, Tharaka-Nithi) against the transfer of the school head teacher. The group demanded the school board disbanded.

On 15 January 2025, tens of residents mainly players, gathered at the Afraha stadium in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) in protest against delayed completion of the renovation of the stadium by the county government. The group demanded that the stadium be reopened.
On 15 January 2025, residents protested in Ndiru (Rangwe, Homa Bay) against the move by a Bishop to engage in incest with his daughter. The group demanded authorities to address the matter.

On 15 January 2025, squatters gathered while holding placards and chanting, outside the governor's office in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against a planned eviction. The group demanded that the governor address the matter.

Around 15 January 2025 (as reported), a group of councilors protested in Busabi (Bunyole, Butaleja), and locked the office of the town clerk, over accusations of abuse of office and failure to provide financial accountability.
On 15 January 2025, a group of residents protested in Kiwanga Lwanda (Mukono, Mukono), against frequent power outages.

Around 15 January 2025 (week of), parents protested at Teremi boys' high school (Kabuchai, Bungoma) against the school's academic integrity and learning environment, following the disqualification of some of the students in the recently released Kenya Certificate of Secondary Education (KCSE) examination results. The group demanded that the school administration address the matter.

Around 15 January 2025 (as reported), traders including public service vehicle operators gathered outside the Migori county revenue authority offices in Migori (Suna West, Migori) in protest against increased taxation. The group demanded the county government to address the matter.

On 15 January 2025, several patients protested at the ministry of health offices at Afya house in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the poor quality of health services under the Social Health Authority (SHA). The group demanded answers over bureaucracies and uncertainties on the usage of the Social Health Insurance Fund (SHIF). Police from the Directorate of Criminal Investigation (DCI) later tracked down one of the protestors and apprehended her while she was seeking medical care from a medical facility in the Eastleigh neighborhood on 23 January (coded separately).

Around 15 January 2025 (month of), students protested at Larmudiac Mixed Secondary School in Kihingo (Njoro, Nakuru) over unclear reasons. The boys involved in the demonstration were suspended indefinitely.

On 16 January 2025, residents protested in Changamwe (Changamwe, Mombasa) against delayed completion of a section of the Mombasa-Nairobi highway (Makupa Bridge to Changamwe interchange). Led by Haki Africa representative, the group demanded that the Kenya National Highways Authority (KeNHA) address the matter.

On 16 January 2025, 600 health workers, mainly members of KNUN gathered and sang solidarity songs outside the Coast general hospital in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against lack of promotions among other grievances. The group demanded the county government to address their grievances.

On 16 January 2025, miraa (Khat) traders protested in the Pumwani neighborhood of Nairobi - Kamukunji (Kamukunji, Nairobi) against the planned move by a private developer to grab their market. The group demanded the county governor to help address the matter. Police used unspecified means to disperse the group.

On 16 January 2025, Bumala B secondary school teachers joined by a KUPPET representative, gathered and sang solidarity songs outside the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) offices in Butula (Butula, Busia) in protest against their safety, following the recent move by parents and students to storm the school over poor performance (coded separately). The group demanded TSC to transfer them to other schools.

Around 16 January 2025 (as reported), parents protested at Kenneth Marende primary school in Munungo (Luanda, Vihiga) against the recent government's directive for the school to relocate following the discovery of gold in the area. The group demanded answers as to why they were not involved.
On 16 January 2025, mira/khat traders protested at the KM4 road in Mogadishu (Banadir) rejecting the importation of mira/khat by a single company.

On 16 January 2025, a group of human rights activists protested at the Supreme Court in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), in an attempt to access court premises to deliver their petition to the Chief Justice, over the trial of civilians in the General Court Martial. The police officers intervened blocking the protesters from having access.

On 16 January 2025, residents, mainly family members gathered in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against the abduction of their relative by Al Shabaab following a raid on a Kenya military camp in El Adde, Somalia in 2016 (coded separately). The group demanded the government to facilitate the release of the victim.

On 16 January 2025, health workers, mainly members of KNUN protested in Bungoma (Kanduyi, Bungoma) against poor working conditions. The group demanded the county government to address their grievances.

On 17 January 2025, health workers, mainly members of KUCO marched while blowing vuvuzelas in Lamu (Lamu West, Lamu) in protest against delayed pay, intimidation, among other grievances. The group demanded that the county government address their grievances.

On 18 January 2025, residents marched along the Kitale-Eldoret road while carrying banners in Chemoset (Soy, Uasin Gishu) in protest against increased road accidents. The group demanded the government to expand the road.

On 18 January 2025, health workers, mainly members of KNUN and the National Nurses Association of Kenya (NNAK) protested in Bungoma (Kanduyi, Bungoma) against poor working conditions among other grievances. The group demanded that the county government implement the collective bargaining agreement.

On 19 January 2025, tens to hundreds of residents including women and traders blocked Jogoo road by laying mats across the tarmac at the Mbotela neighborhood of in Nairobi - Makadara (Makadara, Nairobi) in protest against the demolition of their homes and businesses by a private developer following a land ownership dispute (coded separately). The group demanded for justice and that the authorities help to resolve the matter.

On 19 January 2025, residents, mainly family members gathered while carrying placards in Mambrui (Magarini, Kilifi) in protest against the disappearance of their relative under unclear circumstances. The group demanded authorities to help resolve the matter.

On 19 January 2025, residents, mainly family members and community leaders gathered while carrying placards in Wajir (Wajir East, Wajir) in protest against the abduction of their relative by Al Shabaab following a raid on a Kenya military camp in El Adde, Somalia in 2016 (coded separately). The group demanded that the government facilitate the release of the victim.

On 20 January 2025, health workers mainly members of KNUN protested in Lamu (Lamu West, Lamu) against delayed pay, lack of opportunities for growth and promotions. The group demanded the county government to address the matter.

Around 20 January 2025 (as reported), pyrethrum company employees gathered and chanted in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) in protest against poor management by the company's chief executive officer, among other grievances. The group demanded their grievances addressed. The company was closed indefinitely.

On 20 January 2025, residents protested in Manguu (other sources mention Manguo) slums at the outskirts of Nyahururu town (Laikipia West, Laikipia) against delayed arrival of fire fighters after fire broke out in the area. The group demanded the county government to seek another fire truck and station it in the area for a prompt and efficient reaction in the event of similar situations in future.

Around 20 January 2025 (as reported), women members of beach management associations protested in Shella (Lamu West Lamu) against gender discrimination in representation in those associations following the recent changes in electoral laws which they claim favors men leadership. Led by chairpersons of 20 parties, the group demanded the department of fisheries and marine economy help ensure there is an integrated election process.

On 20 January 2025, residents chased and blocked police officers (means unspecified) from collecting a dead body, in the Mathare 4A neighborhood of Nairobi - Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi) in demonstration against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of a man by suspected thieves. The group demanded the government to restore security in the area.

On 20 January 2025, residents, mainly involving women and children, protested in Wadaamago village (Caynabo, Sool). The protesters demanded the government to complete the main road connecting Wadaamago and Buhoodle.

On 20 January 2025, residents protested in Kolbiyow village (Badhaadhe, Lower Juba) in support of the Jubaland administration and opposed the federal government recent decision to suspend flights and condemned the politicization of humanitarian aid meant for Jubaland.

On 21 January 2025, over 10,000 Muslim students, parents and other residents staged a peaceful demonstration at Romanat Square in Mekele (Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), opposing the banning of hijab-wearing female Muslim students from 5 schools in Axum. The 5 schools prevented 159 female Muslim students from classes because of wearing headscarves. The Ethiopian Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs and Tigray Region Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs protested the schools' decision and requested the schools' leadership to stop interfering in religious affairs at various points. The Tigray Region Education Bureau previously wrote a letter instructing the schools to refrain from adding new directives and instructed them to continue teaching with the school regulations that were in action before the ban. Likewise, the court suspended the schools' protocols. According to the protesters, the schools refused to obey the court's order and the education bureau's instruction and continued prohibiting the female students from accessing the schools' compound.

On 21 January 2025, parents camped outside the Moi Girls School within the Nairobi - Kibra (Kibra, Nairobi) in protest against the move by the school administration to deny them entry into the school to enquire about their children's safety, following a fire outbreak in one of the dormitories. The group demanded the administration to address their concerns.
On 21 January 2025, residents protested at the Carowda Qaranka in Mogadishu - Hodan (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle) against their eviction from lands that they occupied long time ago.

On 22 January 2025, health workers, mainly members of KMPDU gathered and sang solidarity songs, at the Siaya county referral hospital (Alego Usonga, Siaya) in protest against the failure by the county government to implement the Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA).
