The protesters called for the dissolution and restructuring of the region's interim administration and chanted slogans rejecting the ongoing efforts of disarmament of the TPLF fighters. They also demanded that the TPLF's legal entity be restored and the Pretoria peace deal be fully implemented.

On 27 January 2025, residents and members of the matatu owners' association gathered at the Kisumu bus park (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in protest against the recent move by the county government to increase parking fees. The group demanded the county to rescind the decision.

On 27 January 2025, Technical University of Kenya (TUK) teaching staff, mainly members of UASU, protested at the institution, within the Nairobi central business district (Starehe, Nairobi) against delayed pay among other grievances. Led by their union officials, the group demanded all their grievances to be fulfilled and the agreed Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA) reached.

Around 27 January 2025 (as reported), residents marched while chanting in Dekaburei, on the outskirts of Garissa town (Garissa, Garissa) in protest against poor road network in the area. The group demanded that their elected leaders address the matter.

On 27 January 2025, residents staged a protest in Enticho, Enticho town, (Central Tigray, Tigray), supporting the decision adopted by sTigray security force leaders on 23 January 2025. The resolution underscored the security force's support for the TPLF's faction led by the TPLF Chairperson (Dr. Debretsion Gebremichael) to take over the interim regional administration of Tigray, with the party's 50 + 1 power. The protesters called for the dissolution and restructuring of the region's interim administration and chanted slogans rejecting the ongoing efforts of disarmament of the TPLF fighters. They also demanded that the TPLF's legal entity be restored and the Pretoria peace deal be fully implemented.

Around 28 January 2025 (as reported), over 300 workers protested at an affordable housing project site in Alema (Samia, Busia) against poor pay and poor working conditions among other grievances. The group demanded that the area member of parliament help address their concerns.

On 28 January 2025, hundreds of warehouse workers gathered and chanted in Changamwe (Changamwe, Mombasa) in protest against poor pay. The group demanded for the full implementation of a pending collective bargaining agreement.

On 28 January 2025, residents marched while carrying placards in Isiolo town (Isiolo, Isiolo) in protest against the court's recent decision to halt the operations of the Northern rangelands trust conservancy operations at Biliqo Bulesa and Cherab community conservancies. The group demanded that the court's decision be appealed.

On 28 January 2025, residents protested in Kianduma near Ngariama (Kirinyaga East, Kirinyaga) against poor state of road in the area. The group demanded the County Executive Committee (CEC) member in-charge of roads to address the matter.

On 28 January 2025, residents, drawn from over 10000 families and nine villages gathered and marched in Oljorai also known as Olenjorai (Gilgil, Nakuru) in protest against a planned move by members of the Lari Nyakinywa women's group to take over their land, following a land dispute. The group demanded that the government issue them with title deeds and compensate the Lari Nyakinywa group.

On 28 January 2025, overnight, Cheplaskei secondary school students marched to Uasin Gishu County Commissioner's office, in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against poor school management and inadequate teaching among other grievances. The group demanded that their concerns be addressed.

Around 28 January 2025 (as reported), residents protested in Nyamache (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against the delayed repair of a collapsed bridge. The group demanded that their area member of parliament address the matter.

On 29 January 2025, members of the business community protested in Kapsabet town (Chesumei, Nandi) against increased insecurity. Led by the chairman, the group demanded security agencies to increase patrols as well as improve street lighting among others.

On 29 January 2025, for the second day, residents marched in Oljorai (Gilgil, Nakuru) in protest against a planned move by members of the Lari Nyakinywa women's group to take over their land, following a land dispute. The group demanded the government to issue them with title deeds as well as compensate the Lari Nyakinywa group.

On 29 January 2025, Technical university of Kenya non-teaching staff members, mainly members of KUSU, gathered while carrying placards at the institution, in the Nairobi central business district (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against delayed pay among other grievances. The group demanded the ministry of education, parliament and treasury to address their grievances.

On 30 January 2025, long distance drivers protested outside the Mombasa port (Mvita, Mombasa) against exorbitant fees for the arming of the Regional Electronic Cargo Tracking System (RECTS) seals. The group demanded that the government stop all unauthorized charges.

On 30 January 2025, residents protested in Kivumbini (Nakuru East, Nakuru) against the recent disappearance of a fisherman while in the custody of the wildlife rangers (coded separately). Police officers lobbed teargas to disperse the group. A girl (who was not part of the protestors) inhaled teargas (other sources mention that a teargas canister hit her) and later died while in hospital.

On 30 January 2025, sugarcane farmers marched while chanting in Shianda (Mumias East, Kakamega) in protest against the management of the Ethanol production unit at the Mumias sugar factory. The group demanded that the government address the matter.

On 30 January 2025, residents protested in Mutomo (Gatundu South, Kiambu) against increased insecurity, accusing security officers of laxity. The group demanded that security officers address the matter.

On 31 January 2025, traders, mainly Persons with Disabilities (PWDs), gathered and chanted, while carrying placards, at the Mama Ngina waterfront park of Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against the recent move by the National Museums of Kenya (NMK) to chase them away from the park. The group demanded that 10% of the business spaces in the park be allocated to PWDs.

On 31 January 2025, small traders and vegetable sellers blocked (means unspecified) roads at Samunge Market in Arusha (Monduli, Arusha), demanding an end to harassment by rangers, the return of their confiscated goods, a suitable market space with better infrastructure, and transparency in enforcement actions.

On 31 January 2025, workers on Muyembe - Nakapiripirit Road protested in a march from the town of Chepsikunya (Kween, Kween), against non-payment of wages for the past five months by their contractor. Security officers intervened by blocking the workers' efforts to reach the administration offices at the contractor's main campsite.

On 31 January 2025, a group marched while carrying twigs and placards to the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) headquarters, along Kiambu road in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the disappearance of their relative, following a recent fire incident at a furniture warehouse (coded separately). The group demanded that the DCI investigate the matter.

On 1 February 2025, sugarcane farmers, alongside political leaders drawn from Mumias West, Mumias East, and Matungu (ODM, Azimio) constituencies, marched while carrying placards into Mumias sugar company in Mumias town (Mumias West, Kakamega) in protest against the recent move by the government to allocate ethanol distillery and co-generation (co-gen) plants at Mumias sugar company to a rival company. The group demanded the decision be revoked.

Around 2 February 2025 (as reported), Toronto girls' school students marched from the school to the sub-county education offices in Eldama Ravine (Koibatek, Baringo) in protest against the transfer of their head principal to another school. The group demanded their principal be retained. The school was closed indefinitely.

On 2 February 2025, University of Nairobi students gathered and chanted in the institution within the Nairobi Central Business District (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the delayed disbursement of the Higher Education Loans Board (HELB) loans. The group demanded that the authorities address the matter.

On 2 February 2025, the staff of Tibebe Ghion Specialized Hospital held a demonstration in Bahir Dar (Bahir Dar town, West Gojam, Amhara), requesting the government to protect health workers from attacks. The demonstration came following the killing of Dr. Andualem Dagne (coded separately).

On 2 February 2025, tea farmers from various buying centers, including Ramba, Nyakemincha, Bosiango, and Omwaro, among others, protested in Kebirigo (Nyamira, Nyamira) against the mismanagement of funds by the directors of the Kebirigo tea factory. The group demanded that the Ministry of Agriculture and the Office of the President address the matter.

On 3 February 2025, tens of Kenyatta university students blocked the Thika highway (means unspecified) outside the institution within the neighborhood of Nairobi - Roysambu (Roysambu, Nairobi) in protest against delayed disbursement of the Higher Education Loans Board (HELB) loans. The group demanded the authorities to address the matter. Police used unspecified means to disperse the group.

On 3 February 2025, journalists marched to the office of the county commissioner in Lodwar (Turkana Central, Turkana) in protest against increased harassment, intimidation, and death threats by county government officials. The group that demanded their grievances be addressed.
On 3 February 2025, residents protested in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari) to support the Puntland administration operation against Islamic State Somalia Province in Bari region (coded separately).
On 3 February 2025, relatives of a tuktuk driver protested in Mogadishu - Wadajir (Banadir) demanding justice for the driver that was shot and injured by a police officer (coded separately).

On 3 February 2025, residents marched for 15 kilometers in Ngoben, also known as Nkoben (Narok South, Narok), in protest against poor roads, education, and administration services, among other grievances. The group demanded that the president help address their grievances.

On 3 February 2025, a group of youth protested at the Bunyoro Kitara Kingdom premises in the city of Hoima (Hoima, Hoima), demanding the resignation of the Kingdom prime minister. An official of the Kingdom grabbed a journalist who was filming the protest and pulled him by his neck and damaged his camera. Extent of injuries not known/reported.

On 3 February 2025, teachers, mainly KUPPET and KNUT officials, protested at the Minet insurance company offices at Daima towers in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against poor medical services. The group demanded that their concerns be addressed.

On 3 February 2025, Technical university of Kenya teaching and non-teaching staff members, mainly members of UASU and KUSU, joined by students, gathered and marched while chanting slogans outside the institution in the Nairobi central business district (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against delayed pay, among other grievances. The group demanded their grievances be addressed. The university was later closed indefinitely.

On 3 February 2025, for the second day, tea farmers from various buying centers, including Ramba, Nyakemincha, Bosiango, and Omwaro, among others, protested in Kebirigo (Nyamira, Nyamira) against the mismanagement of funds by the directors of the Kebirigo tea factory. The group demanded that the Ministry of Agriculture and the Office of the President address the matter.

The group demanded that the ministry address their grievances.

On 4 February 2025, for the third day, tea farmers from various buying centers, including Ramba, Nyakemincha, Bosiango, and Omwaro, among others, protested in Kebirigo (Nyamira, Nyamira) against the mismanagement of funds by the directors of the Kebirigo tea factory. The group demanded that the Ministry of Agriculture and the Office of the President address the matter.

On 5 February 2025, residents protested in the Mukuru Maasai slums of Nairobi - Embakasi South (Embakasi South, Nairobi) against the demolition of their houses to make room for riparian land. The group demanded that the president to address the matter.

On 5 February 2025, teachers, mainly KUPPET and KNUT officials, protested at the Minet insurance company offices at Daima towers in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against poor medical services. The group demanded that their concerns be addressed.

On 6 February 2025, some ethnic Tigrayan residents of Addis Ababa staged a peaceful demonstration in Addis Ababa (Lideta, Region 14, Addis Ababa). The demonstrators denounced any possibility of conflict in the Tigray region and called for the two factions of the TPLF to amicably address their disagreement. The demonstrators chanted various slogans, including 'Stop War' and 'The first choice of the Tigray people is peace.'

Around 6 February 2025 (as reported), residents marched while carrying twigs in Kipkoibet near Taboino (Konoin, Bomet) in protest against the increased sale of illicit brews and insecurity in the area. The group demanded that security agencies address their grievances.

On 6 February 2025, hundreds of people comprising of youth and women protested in Oog village (Caynabo, Sool). The protesters expressed their disaffection and frustration about the protected clan militiamen conflict in Buuhoodle district (coded separately).

On 6 February 2025, residents, mainly family members, friends, and human rights defenders, protested at the Nakuru law courts (Nakuru North, Nakuru) against the court ruling that there was no evidence showing that the Kenya wildlife rangers were holding their relative (a fisherman) after the claimed abduction (coded separately). On 6 February 2025, hundreds of youth protested outside the Eldoret polytechnic (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the failure of an international job recruitment exercise by the Ministry of Labor to take off. The group demanded that the president address the matter.

The parents demanded transparency from the school regarding the events that led to this tragedy

On 6 February 2025, residents gathered while carrying a banner in Kisii village of South B within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) to protest against the disappearance of a man in the area. The group demanded that the government help address the matter.

On 6 February 2025, residents gathered in Moi's Bridge (Soy, Uasin Gishu) in protest against the recent chaos witnessed at a fundraiser for fire victims (coded separately). The group demanded that their political leaders work together in unity.

On 7 February 2025, supporters of the Bomet governor (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) marched while singing in Bomet (Bomet East, Bomet) in solidarity with the governor, following his recent arrest by officers from the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission over the claimed missing of Sh1.4 billion county funds.

On 7 February 2025, a group of lawyers from the Uganda Law Society (ULS) protested in a walkout during the 2025 New Law Year event in Kampala (Kampala, Kampala), over tensions with the judiciary. The protest was triggered by the exclusion of the ULS President's speech from the event's program.

On 8 February 2025, parents protested at Nyakianga primary school (Mathioya, Muranga) against incidents of bullying and sexual assault at the institution by a grade 7 student. On 8 February 2025, some of the West Nile Kony War Victims staged a protest in Onduparaka (Northern Division, Arua). The protesters displayed placards and demanded for compensation from the government.

On 9 February 2025, worshippers at the Citadel Salvation Army Church protested in Machakos (Machakos, Machakos) against mismanagement and embezzlement of church funds by church leaders. The group demanded accountability from the church leaders.

On 11 February 2025, residents of Chole town staged a peaceful protest in Chole (Arsi, Oromia), opposing the killing and abductions of civilians perpetrated by OLF-OLA members on 7 February 2025 (coded separately).

Around 12 February 2025 (as reported), residents gathered while holding placards in Busia town (Matayos, Busia) in support of the former prime minister's election for the Africa Union Commission (AUC) Chairmanship's position. On 12 February 2025, residents marched while carrying placards and twigs in Kongowea (Nyali, Mombasa) in protest against a recent move by a private developer to demolish their homes, following a land dispute (coded separately). The group demanded that the government address the matter.

On 18 February 2025, political leaders, mainly those allied to the immediate former deputy president (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) gathered and sang solidarity songs outside the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) offices in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the arrest of the Juja Member of Parliament (MP). The group demanded that the MP be released.

On 18 February 2025, Technical University of Kenya (TUK) teaching and non-teaching staff gathered while carrying placards at the institution, within the Nairobi central business district (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against delayed pay among other grievances. Led by UASU union officials, the group demanded that the parliament address their grievances.

On 19 February 2025, employees (medical and supportive staff) of Yirga Cheffe Hospital staged a peaceful demonstration before a police station in Yirga Chefe (Yirgachefe, Gedeo, South Ethiopia Region) opposing the arrest of 9 management and medical staff of the hospital by south Ethiopian police. The demonstration and arrest were preceded by a strike by the hospital's employees on 17 February 2025 opposing the non-payment of salary increments for 4 months.

On 19 February 2025, for the second day, over 2000 traders protested in Londiani town (Kipkelion East, Kericho) against poor service delivery as well as high license fees. The group demanded that the governor address their grievances.

On 19 February 2025, parents of four students at the Dr. Aggrey boys' high school protested at the institution in Wundanyi (Wundanyi, Taita Taveta) against the payment of a Sh5 million fine for burnt dormitories following recent student unrest (coded separately). The group demanded that the Board of Management (BOM) address the matter.

On 19 February 2025, a group of market traders from Kitunzi Market in the Rwebikona business hub of Mbarara city (Mbarara, Mbarara) protested against unfair tax administration and the unfavorable opening hours for the weekly market, which operates every Wednesday.
On 19 February 2025, a group of activists protested in Mbarara city (Mbarara, Mbarara), demanding the release of Dr. Kizza Besigye.

On 19 February 2025, for the second day, residents and family members of Somali youths sentenced to death by Saudi Arabia protested at the Daljika Dahsoon neighborhood in Mogadishu - Bondhere (Banadir). The protesters demanded that the Somali government intervene and return the youths to the country.

On 19 February 2025, residents stormed Kerugoya police station (Kirinyaga Central, Kirinyaga) in protest against increased insecurity. Led by their area member of parliament (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded that the security officers address the matter.

The group demanded that parliament help reopen the institution.

On 19 February 2025, residents (likely supporters of the FORD-Kenya, Kenya Kwanza based on similar events in other nearby towns) gathered while waving placards in an unspecified location within Trans Nzoia County (coded to the county headquarters as Kitale, Saboti, Trans Nzoia) in protest against a planned move by opposition Members of Parliament (MPs) to impeach the national assembly speaker, who is also their party leader. The group demanded that the president protect the speaker.

On 19 February 2025, hundreds of squatters from the agricultural development corporation (ADC) farm (other sources mention Kiboroa) gathered and marched in Kitale town (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) in protest against delayed resettlement. The group demanded that the government address their grievance.

On 19 February 2025, residents (likely supporters of the FORD-Kenya, Kenya Kwanza based on similar events other nearby towns) marched while waving placards and hooting motorbikes in Kakamega town (Lurambi, Kakamega) in protest against a planned move by opposition Members of Parliament (MPs) to impeach the national assembly speaker, who is also their party leader. On 20 February 2025, supporters of FORD-Kenya, Kenya Kwanza marched while waving placards along the Kisumu-Busia highway in Busia town (Matayos, Busia) in protest against a planned move by opposition Members of Parliament (MPs) to impeach the national assembly speaker who is also their party leader. On 20 February 2025, a group of truck drivers protested at the Hass Fuel Station along Kinubi Road in Hoima City (Hoima, Hoima), against the non-payment of wages by Nexius Company, which was contracted to transport marram for the construction of Hoima City Stadium.

On 21 February 2025, residents blocked unspecified roads leading to a quarry with stones in Gatong'ora (Ruiru, Kiambu) in protest against the poor state of the area's roads. The group demanded that the governor address the matter.

Around 23 February 2025 (as reported), human rights defenders protested in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against the transfer of the Kisii Polytechnic principal, who is under investigation for financial misappropriation. The group demanded that the president help address the matter.

On 23 February 2025, clinical officers gathered and chanted solidarity songs in Bungoma (Kanduyi, Bungoma) in protest against the failure by the county government to implement a Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA). The group demanded that the county address their grievance.

Around 24 February 2025 (as reported), residents protested in Msikiti Nuru village near Diani (Msambweni, Kwale) against the killing of a student by a mob in a claimed case of mistaken identity (coded separately). Around 24 February 2025 (as reported), a group of residents and local leaders from Kyebikube and neighboring villages protested in town of Kikagate (Isingiro, Isingiro) against the local leaders and parish chiefs, accusing them of extorting bribes in exchange for access to Parish Development Model (PDM) funds. On 10 March 2025, health workers, mainly members of KMPDU, gathered at the Gevanjee gardens before marching while carrying placards to the county governor's office at City Hall within the Nairobi city center (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against illegal salary stoppages, dismissals, and frequent salary delays. On 10 March 2025, more than 300 members of the Dupoto Darfur settlement scheme, mainly from the Maasai community, gathered while carrying placards outside the Milimani law courts before marching to various government offices in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against misappropriation of funds meant for their compensation, following the acquisition of their land for the development of the Standard Gauge Railway (SGR). The group demanded accountability from the land's principal secretary.

On 11 March 2025, protesters gathered in Adi Gudem town (South Eastern Tigray, Adigudom, Tigray) to oppose security forces' took over the town's administration offices. The protesters were shot at by at least 44 members of Tigray security forces affiliated with the TPLF faction led by Debretsion Gebremichael (coded as TPLF). The gunmen abducted at least seven cabinet members of the town's administration, including the administrator and his deputy. 4 protesters were beat, shot and injured by the security forces. .

On 11 March 2025, parents and community leaders of Kanyakine and Ntharene secondary schools protested at the sub-county headquarters in Kanyakine (Imenti South, Meru) against mismanagement and poor performance of the schools. The group demanded that the school principals be transferred.

On 11 March 2025, Members of County Assembly (MCAs) evicted three county executive committee members from their offices within the county assembly building and shut the assembly gates in Nyamira (Nyamira, Nyamira) in protest against the failure by the CECs to relocate, following the dispute between the MCAs and the executive. The group demanded the county senator help address the matter.

On 11 March 2025, boda boda taxi operators protested in Migori town (Suna West, Mogori) against claimed mistreatment by county authorities. The group demanded that the county governor address their grievances.

On 11 March 2025, boda boda taxi operators protested in Awendo town (Awendo, Mogori) against claimed mistreatment by county authorities. The group demanded the county governor address their grievances.

Around 11 March 2025 (as reported), residents marched while carrying twigs in Katsangani (Magarini, Kilifi) in protest against the move by a private developer to grab their land. The group demanded that the president help address the matter.

On 12 March 2025, in the afternoon, an unspecified number of residents gathered in Adi Gudem (Southeastern Tigray, Adigudom, Tigray), protesting attacks and abductions by security forces in the town (coded separately). On 3 April 2025, students chanted anti-president slogans at the Karatina University (Mathira East, Nyeri) in protest against unfulfilled government promises. The group demanded that the country leadership listen and exercise accountability and dignity.

On 4 April 2025, residents held a protest in Rira, Goba (Bale, Oromia), condemning the government's decision to relocate them from their homes in the Bale Mountains National Park and resettle them in other areas. The protesters marched through their village, demanding that the forced displacement be halted and expressing their refusal to accept compensation or agree to resettle. They chanted, 'Our Land is Our Bones.'

On 4 April 2025, Moi University medical students protested in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the failure by the institution to provide dental equipment for clinical practical sessions. The group demanded that the vice-chancellor address the matter.

Around 4 April 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly women, protested in Kianda (Rongai, Nakuru) against the recent killing of a woman by a mob (coded separately). The group demanded that the area chief and the Nyumba Kumi officials be held accountable.

On 4 April 2025, residents gathered while carrying placards in Juja (Juja, Kiambu) in protest against the construction of a factory inside the residential area. The group demanded that the factory be relocated.

On 10 April 2025, residents gathered while carrying placards and chanting in Bungoma (Kanduyi, Bungoma) to protest the arrest of the Butere girls school drama students' playwright, who previously served as the secretary general of the ruling United Democratic Alliance (UDA) party and also as a former Kakamega senator. On 24 April 2025, hundreds of CHADEMA members and supporters protested in front of a court conducting the treason trial of leader Tundu Lissu, and police arrested 13 of them, tied them up and beat them, and left at least 9 in remote areas approximately 25 to 40 kilometers away from the Kisutu Magistrate's Court in Dar es Salaam (Mchafukoge, Ilala, Dar es Salaam). Police also arrested several party members en route to the court, barred journalists from following the trial, and detained or dispersed others (unspecified means) in front of the venue. Police had over 10 dogs, 4 horses, guns and batons and the unrest lasted for over 10 hours. At least 8 people were injured with others unaccounted for; 1 source claimed 1 man was killed and 1 party leader was arrested on 22 April. Sources differ on how many arrests occurred before or during the demonstration, and whether journalists were included in the arrests of CHADEMA officials. Fatalities coded as 1.

The group demanded that the government explores alternative sources of energy. On 2 May 2025, for the second day, residents protested in Timboroa market (Koibatek, Baringo) against the recent killing of a scrap metal dealer via mob injustice (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased as well as arrest and prosecution of those behind the killing.

Around 2 May 2025 (as reported), residents gathered and held hand in solidarity at the Alaskan grounds in Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi) in protest against moves by some leaders to incite tribal and political tensions. The group demanded that the county governor and the area member of parliament unite the community ahead of the 2027 elections.

On 2 May 2025, flower farm workers gathered in Naivasha (Naivasha, Nakuru) in protest against the claimed failure by the Central Organization of Trade Unions (COTU) Secretary General (SG) to fight for their rights and better renumeration. The group demanded the SG to retire from the union.

Around 3 May 2025 (as reported), a number of residents with a plastic jerry can staged a public demonstration at an unspecified place in Mehal Sayint Wereda (location coded to admin center Densa, South Wello, Amhara), denouncing the destruction of the drinking water services/infrastructures by Fano militia.

On 3 May 2025, health workers, mainly members of KMPDU from the south rift region, gathered and sang solidarity songs in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) in protest against the failure by the county governments to honor their Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA). The group demanded that their grievances be addressed.

On 3 May 2025, residents blocked an unspecified road by planting banana stems at Kapkugerwet (Ainamoi, Kericho) in protest against the poor state of the road. The group demanded that the Member of County Assembly (MCA) and the county government fix the road.

On 3 May 2025, at least 64 members of the CHADEMA party, including leaders, marched to the regional police office in Mbeya (Mbeya Urban, Mbeya) in protest against the recent abduction of their colleague by suspected police officers (coded separately). On 16 May 2025, parents protested at the Garden of Hope in Ngong (Kajiado North, Kajiado) against the move by the ministry of education to close down the school, citing wrangles among the school management. The group demanded that the decision be rescinded.

Around 16 May 2025 (as reported), residents protested in an unspecified location within Mahiakalo ward (coded as Duka Moja, Lurambi, Kakamega) against claimed poor road construction by a contractor. The group demanded that the governor address the matter.

On 16 May 2025, residents, mainly women and youth, and supporters of the Kilifi governor (ODM, Azimio) marched while carrying placards in Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi) in protest against the move by a former public service Cabinet Secretary (CS) to incite women against the county governor. The group demanded that the president call the former CS to order.

On 17 May 2025, residents of six woredas of Southern Tigray staged a protest at an unspecified location (coded to the zonal admin center, Alamata town, Alamata, Southern Tigray, Tigray), opposing the TPLF's plan to dismantle the local administrators appointed by the former interim administrator of Tigray in the administrative structures of Southern Tigray. The protesters also called for the new interim administration of Tigray to be inclusive and participatory and chanted slogans such as 'We do not accept authoritarianism', 'Respect law and order', and 'The right to self-governance should be respected', among others.

On 17 May 2025, hundreds of residents staged a protest in Mekhoni town, Mehoni (Southern Tigray, Tigray), opposing the TPLF leader's plan to dismantle the local administrators appointed by the former interim administrator of Tigray in the administrative structures of Southern Tigray.
On 17 May 2025, residents protested in Korem town, Korem (Southern Tigray, Tigray), calling for peace and opposing 'forces' pushing the Tigray region to another round of conflict.
On 17 May 2025, residents protested in Chercher (Southern Tigray, Tigray), calling for peace and opposing 'forces' pushing the Tigray region to another round of conflict.
On 17 May 2025, residents protested in Ambalage, Emba Alaje (Southern Tigray, Tigray), calling for peace and opposing 'forces' pushing the Tigray region to another round of conflict.

On 18 May 2025, People's Liberation Party supporters carried banners and chanted at the Jomo Kenyatta International Airport in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the move by the Tanzanian authorities to detain and deport their party leader alongside other human rights defenders who were visiting the country ahead of the court hearing of a case involving the detained Tanzanian opposition leader Tundu Lissu. The group demanded for an end to restrictions on movement within the East African Community (EAC).

Around 18 May 2025 (as reported), residents gathered in Mbosie (Ugunja, Siaya) in protest against the delayed completion of a health facility in the area. The group demanded that the governor, through the county government, address the matter.

Around 18 May 2025 (as reported), more than 100 farmers marched to the Maili Saba market (Cherangany, Trans Nzoia) in protest against increased incidents of cattle theft. Led by the former Sengwer ward member of the county assembly, the group demanded that the suspects be arrested and prosecuted.

On 18 May 2025, residents, mainly supporters of Soy Member of Parliament (MP) (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), blocked the Eldoret-Ziwa road (means unspecified) in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against claimed threats to the life of the MP by unknown people using leaflets (coded separately). The group demanded that the police provide the MP with enough security and arrest the suspects behind the leaflets.

On 19 May 2025, patients and their families gathered in front of the Tikur Anbesa Specialized Hospital administration office in Lideta (Region 14, Addis Ababa) to demand a solution for the lack of medical services as health workers abandoned their duties amid the ongoing strikes (coded separately).

On 19 May 2025, hundreds of students from Kapsowar High School marched from the institution while chanting slogans and carrying placards to Kapsowar town (Marakwet East, Elgeyo Marakwet) in protest against poor leadership by the school principal among other grievances. The group demanded that the principal be transferred. Education officers and security personnel intervened (means unspecified) and escorted the students back to school.

Around 19 May 2025 (as reported), over 400 students and parents protested at Vikutsa Primary School (Shinyalu, Kakamega) against the recent closure of the school by health officials, citing infrastructure concerns. The group demanded that the area member of parliament address the matter.

Around 19 May 2025 (as reported), residents of Ndhiwa and Dipu gathered while carrying placards and twigs in an unknown location within Witu ward (coded as Witu, Lamu West, Lamu) in protest against a planned move by a private developer to evict them from their land. The group demanded that both the county and national governments address the matter.

Around 19 May 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly UDA-Kenya Kwanza supporters, gathered while clapping hands in Matungulu (Matungulu, Machakos) in protest against poor infrastructure development. The group demanded that the president help develop the Ondonyo Sabuk bridge.

On 19 May 2025, human rights defenders marched to the Tanzanian Embassy at Reinsurance Plaza in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the Tanzanian authorities' move to detain and deport their colleagues who were visiting the country ahead of the trial of the detained Tanzanian opposition leader Tundu Lissu. The group demanded accountability from the Tanzanian government.

Around 19 May 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly members of the Muslim community, gathered and spoke in unison in Kalaule near Hola (Galole, Tana River) in protest against an escalation of a land dispute pitting them against a Christian group. The group demanded that their elected leaders address the matter.

On 19 May 2025, students protested at the Kitale National Polytechnic (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against claimed financial misconduct and the misuse of institutional funds by the principal. Police intervened and assaulted the students to disperse the group.

On 19 May 2025, a group of vendors from the Kabale central Market staged a protest at Kabale Municipal Council in Kabale town (Northern Division, Kabale, Kabale) to demand rent fee reduction and to pay rent directly to the council and not landlords.

On 20 May 2025, supporters of the former Deputy President (DCP) protested in Kitengela (Kajiado East, Kajiado) against claimed harassment of the former DP by the state. The group demanded justice for the former DP.

On 20 May 2025, residents gathered in the Githurai neighborhood of Nairobi - Roysambu (Roysambu, Nairobi) in protest against prolonged power outages. The group demanded that the Kenya Power and Lighting Company (KPLC) address the matter.

On 20 May 2025, hundreds to thousands of health workers under the Universal Health (UHC) program, protested outside the ministry of health headquarters at Afya House in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the government's failure to employ them on permanent and pensionable terms, among other grievances. Police officers lobbed tear gas as well as fired rubber bullets to disperse the group. Several protesters were injured during the incident. Extent of injuries unknown/not reported.

On 20 May 2025, supporters of the former Deputy President (DCP) protested in Mukurweini (Mukurweini, Nyeri) against claimed harassment of the former DP by the state. The group demanded justice for the former DP.

On 20 May 2025, supporters of the former Deputy President (DCP) protested in Othaya (Nyeri South, Nyeri) against claimed harassment of the former DP by the state. The group demanded justice for the former DP.

On 20 May 2025, supporters of the Trans Nzoia governor (DAP, Azimio) protested in Kiminini (Kiminini, Trans Nzoia) against the move by the officers from the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (EACC) to raid, arrest, and detain the governor over claims of procurement irregularities. The group demanded that the governor be released.

Around 20 May 2025 (as reported), farmers protested in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the agreement to change between two differing carbon credit companies. The group demanded that the second agreement be revoked.

On 20 May 2025, human rights defenders, including Haki Africa and MUHURI representatives, protested outside the Tanzanian consulate offices in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against the move by the Tanzanian authorities to detain and deport their colleagues who were visiting the country ahead of the trial of the detained Tanzanian opposition leader Tundu Lissu. The group demanded that the Tanzanian government respect the rights of human rights defenders.

On 20 May 2025, for the second day, supporters of the Trans Nzoia governor (DAP, Azimio) protested in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against the move by the officers from the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (EACC) to raid, arrest, and detain the governor over claims of procurement irregularities. The group demanded that the governor be released.

On 20 May 2025, supporters of the Trans Nzoia governor (DAP, Azimio) gathered outside the Milimani law courts in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the move by the officers from the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (EACC) to raid, arrest, and arraign the governor over claims of procurement irregularities (coded separately). The group demanded that the governor be released.

On 20 May 2025, hundreds of supporters of the former Deputy President (DCP) protested in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) against claimed harassment of the former DP by the state. The group demanded justice for the former DP.

On 21 May 2025, residents, mainly women, gathered while carrying placards and banners in Makutano town (Imenti North, Meru) in protest against claimed police harassment of the former Meru governor (coded separately). The group demanded that police address the matter.

On 21 May 2025, residents protested at the Villa police station in the Mukuru Kwa Reuben neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi South (Embakasi South, Nairobi) against the criteria used by the government in allocating houses under the affordable housing program as well as the planned move by the government to evict residents from another section of the neighborhood for the development of more houses. Led by Mukuru Community Justice Centre (MCJC) representatives, the group demanded a fresh process of vetting beneficiaries of the program.

On 21 May 2025, human rights defenders and family members, protested at the Tanzanian Embassy at Reinsurance Plaza in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the Tanzanian authorities' move to detain and deport their colleagues who were visiting the country ahead of the trial of the detained Tanzanian opposition leader Tundu Lissu. The group demanded that the human rights defenders be released.

On 21 May 2025, locals protested at the Livestock Market neighborhood in Mogadishu - Heliwa (Banadir) against the government's move to evict them from the land. They demanded justice and to return to their land. The police force opened fire to disperse the crowd. 1 protester was injured.
On 21 May 2025, residents of Ntoroko staged a protest at Kanaara/Kanara town (Kanara, Ntoroko, Ntoroko) over deteriorating conditions of the road that links Karugutu to Ntoroko Port.

On 21 May 2025, on the second day, health workers under the Universal Health (UHC) program protested outside the Ministry of Health headquarters at Afya House in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against the government's failure to employ them on permanent and pensionable terms, among other grievances. The group demanded that the authorities address their grievances.

Around 21 May 2025 (as reported), teachers, mainly members of KNUT, gathered and sang solidarity songs in Kapenguria (West Pokot, West Pokot) in protest against claimed authoritarian leadership and mismanagement by the county director of education. The group demanded that the director be transferred.

On 21 May 2025, a group of students staged a protest at KCB Bank in Kampala (Central Division, Kampala) to demand the bank to stop its plan of supporting financially the East African Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP). The police intervened and arrested nine protesters.

On 22 May 2025, residents protested in Masalani (Ijara, Garissa) against the recent move by the government to declare via a gazette notice that the area is restricted under the National Intelligence Service (NIS), citing lack of public participation. The group demanded that the gazette notice be revoked.

On 22 May 2025, human rights defenders and family members gathered and sang solidarity songs in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against the Tanzanian authorities' move to detain, torture, and deport their colleagues who were visiting the country ahead of the trial of the detained Tanzanian opposition leader Tundu Lissu (coded separately). The group demanded that the responsible Tanzanian officials be arrested.

On 22 May 2025, hundreds of farmers from Trans Nzoia and West Pokot counties including Turkwel, Orutum, Chepareria, Kapenguria, Kitale gathered and marched while chanting and carrying placards in Makutano (West Pokot, West Pokot) in protest against delayed compensation by the Kenya Electricity Transmission Company (KETRACO), following the move by the firm to acquire their land for the development of power lines. The group demanded that KETRACO address the matter.

On 23 May 2025, residents who had previously organized themselves into various associations to obtain land from the government to build residential houses held a peaceful rally in front of the office of the Tigray Interim Administration President in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), protesting a decision made by the regional government to give them lands to build apartment houses instead of giving a separate 70 m2 land for each member, as per the relevant regulation. The residents formed associations and waited for six years without obtaining the land.
On 23 May 2025, residents protested in Chebukutumi (Sirisia, Bungoma) against a stalled road project in the area. The group demanded that the area ward representative address the matter.

On 23 May 2025, residents gathered in Athi River (also known as Movoko) in protest against the pollution of River Athi by nearby companies. The group demanded that the county government address the matter.

Around 23 May 2025 (as reported), tens of residents marched while carrying twigs in Tot (Marakwet East, Elgeyo Marakwet) in protest against the recent killing of a Catholic priest in the area by suspected pastoral militia (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased priest.

On 24 May 2025, residents gathered at Juja Farm (Juja, Kiambu) in protest against the disappearance of the Juja Member of Parliament (MP) after being chased by suspected security agents. The group demanded that the government disclose the whereabouts of their MP.

On 24 May 2025, a group of drivers protested in front of the regional governor's office in Burco town (Burco, Togdheer). The protesters claimed that a member of the Somaliland Parliament of misappropriating and tampering with their salaries.

On 26 May 2025, traders protested in Malaba town (Teso North, Busia) against the politicization of a market construction project. The group demanded that the county government proceed with the construction.

On 26 May 2025, teachers, mainly members of KUPPET and KNUT, gathered while clapping in Isiolo (Isiolo, Isiolo) against delayed promotions. The group demanded that the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) address their concerns.

On 27 May 2025, residents, mainly boda boda taxi operators blocked the Kiambu road using their vehicles in Kiambu town (Kiambu Town, Kiambu) in protest against the recent abduction of 1 of their colleagues by 3 unknown individuals. The group demanded security agencies to investigate the matter. Police intervened (means unspecified) and dispersed the group.

On 27 May 2025, health workers under the Universal Health (UHC) program marched from the ministry of health headquarters to the parliament building in Nairobi city center (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the government's failure to employ them on permanent and pensionable terms, among other grievances. The group demanded that the government address their grievances.

On 27 May 2025, residents, including traders, gathered in the Milimani area of Maralal town (Samburu Central, Samburu) in protest against increased insecurity following the recent incident where unknown armed individuals invaded and looted a shop associated with the area chief. The group demanded that the government provide a firearm to the chief.
On 28 May 2025, more than 200 contractors gathered in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in protest against delayed pay. The group demanded that the president help address the matter.

On 28 May 2025, youth, including footballers, protested in Khayega (Shinyalu, Kakamega) against the planned move by the county government to convert a stadium in the area into a market. The group demanded that the county look for an alternative site for development of the market.

On 28 May 2025, residents of Woodley and 8 other neighborhoods protested outside the Nairobi County offices at City Hall in the Nairobi city center (Starehe, Nairobi) against ongoing county-sanctioned evictions. The group demanded the return of all evicted tenants and the removal of the county chief housing officer from the office.

On 28 May 2025, residents protested in Lamu (Lamu West, Lamu) against a planned move by the government to construct a coal power plant in the area. The group demanded the development of safe power generation methods.

On 28 May 2025, traders protested at the Kwa Jiwa market in Malindi town (Malindi, Kilifi) against the unfair election of new market committee officials, citing the infiltration of outsiders. The group demanded that the election be postponed.

On 28 May 2025, health workers, mainly members of KMPDU, protested at the Kakamega referral hospital (Lurambi, Kakamega) against the lack of promotions and the failure by the county government to remit their statutory deductions, among other concerns. Youth and county enforcement officers (other sources mention the police) confronted the group and locked the hospital gate, preventing the protestors from marching to the governor's office.

On 28 May 2025, a group of fishermen operating on Lake Victoria staged a protest at the Masaka Resident District Commissioner in Masaka (Kimaanya-Kyabakuza Division, Masaka) to denounce harassment inflicted on them by Tanzanian fishermen and demand the intervention of authorities.

On 29 May 2025, more than 700 members of the Tawakal farmers society protested in Gambela (Tigania East, Meru) against a claimed move by some of their officials to conspire with private developers and sell parts of the land. The group demanded that the government help address the matter.

On 29 May 2025, residents, including construction workers, gathered while chanting and carrying twigs and placards in the Parklands neighborhood of Nairobi - Westlands (Westlands, Nairobi) in protest against harassment and intimidation by the Parklands Residents Association. The group demanded that authorities address the matter.

On 29 May 2025, residents, mainly members of the pastoral Maasai and Samburu communities, protested in Kisargei (Laikipia North, Laikipia) against claimed harassment by the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS) officers. The group demanded that their elected leaders, including the president, help address the matter.

On 29 May 2025, residents protested in the Uhuru neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi West (Embakasi West, Nairobi) against the move by the county government to evict them from their houses after failing to pay rent. The group demanded that the governor allocate them more time.
On 30 May 2025, parents protested at the Arabuko Sokoke primary school (Ganze, Kilifi) against poor management. The group demanded that the head teacher be transferred.

Around 30 May 2025 (as reported), environmentalists and human rights defenders, including representatives from MUHURI, protested in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against the move by unknown people to cut down trees at Uhuru Gardens. The group demanded that the county government address the matter.

On 30 May 2025, Kenya Utalii College students blocked the Thika highway using unspecified means within Nairobi - Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi) in protest against the recent death of their colleague under unclear circumstances. The group demanded that the administration institute reforms in the management of the well-being of the students, among others. Police used unspecified means to disperse the group.

On 30 May 2025, teachers, mainly members of KUPPET, gathered outside their offices in Maralal (Samburu Central, Samburu) in protest against the move by the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) to demote 158 of its members as well as against plans to the remove hardship allowance from their salaries. The group demanded that TSC address their concerns.

On 30 May 2025, women's groups protested in Ol Kalou town (OlKalou, Nyandarua) against increased incidents of gender-based violence. The group demanded that security agencies increase patrols as well as the county government erect security masts along the streets.

On 31 May 2025, residents, including human rights defenders, chanted and carried banners and placards as they marched from Mtangawanda to Faza town (Lamu East, Lamu) in protest against increased incidents of gender-based violence. Led by the area member of parliament (Jubilee, Azimio), the group demanded an end to the vice.

On 31 May 2025, a group of prisoners at the central prison launched a strike to protest unspecified issues in Borama town (Borama, Awdal). Police forces opened fire at the prisoners, and 1 prisoner was killed and 3 others were injured.
On 31 May 2025, mira/khat traders, mostly women, protested in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir) district, demanding that the government allow all business owners to transport mira/khat from Kenya.

On 31 May 2025, traders marched while carrying placards and blowing vuvuzelas in Kakamega town (Lurambi, Kakamega) in protest against recurring losses during political rallies, following the recent clash between DCP party supporters and the police (coded separately). The group demanded that political leaders use designated venues for their rallies.

On 1 June 2025, Catholic faithful marched while carrying a banner on the streets of Eldoret town (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against the recent killing of a priest by suspected pastoral militia (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased priest.

On 1 June 2025, dozens of human rights defenders, joined by family members, gathered and sang solidarity songs outside the Pangani police station in Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the move by the police to arrest one of their colleagues over the accusation of developing an online site meant to mobilize public opposition to the Finance Bill 2025 (coded separately). The group demanded her release.

On 1 June 2025, youth disrupted a national holiday celebration (Madaraka) by chanting anti-president slogans, with some throwing bottles in the air during the county commissioner's moment for reading the president's speech in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) in protest against unfulfilled government promises. The group demanded that the president deliver on his campaign promises. The county commissioner proceeded with reading the speech as planned.

On 1 June 2025, hundreds of Christian church members blocked a road (unspecified means) and sang songs in Ubungo (Ubungo, Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam) as police fired tear gas against them and arrested 86 of them at the Ofufuo na Uzima Church. They were demonstrating against the police presence in search of their Bishop who the government claimed was inciting 'public discord' through discussions about recent abductions (coded separately), and the government's deregistration and closure of the Church. The Bishop, a member of ruling party Chama Cha Mapinduzi, had conducted a press conference on 24 May and remarked about abductions in a sermon on 1 June. The Church was cordoned off with yellow tape with over 20 police officers in full tactical gear in a security perimeter to limit site access. 84 of the arrested were released.

On 1 June 2025, families of killed and injured prisoners protested at the main entrance of a regional hospital in Borama town (Awadal, Borama). The families demanded to see the body of the deceased and refused blood compensation after their family members were targeted with gunfire during a protest at the central prison on 31 May (coded separately). They requested justice from the Somaliland government.
On 1 June 2025, residents in Bule Wikey protested in Mogadishu - Hamar Jabjab (Banadir) against land evictions, demanding that the government legalize their land.

On 2 June 2025, residents of Alamata town and neighboring Weredas staged a peaceful demonstration in Alamata (Alamata town, Southern Tigray, Tigray), protesting the pressure by the TPLF and 'its allies' to return the six contested provinces of North Wello (Alamata, Raya Alamata, Raya Abla, Korem, Wefla and Zata) to Tigray region. During the demonstration, the demonstrators chanted 'Rayas are Amharas' and other slogans.

On 2 June 2025, developers, mainly construction company workers gathered while carrying banners in the Parklands neighborhood of Nairobi - Westlands (Westlands, Nairobi) to protest against harassment and intimidation by the Parklands Residents Association. The group demanded that authorities address the matter.

On 2 June 2025, more than 1000 residents (likely supporters of the area Member of Parliament-MP-Wiper, Azimio, as they were defending him) marched while carrying placards and chanting slogans in Athi River (Athi River, Machakos) in protest against claimed interference in their county politics, following recent remarks made by a former deputy president that appeared critical of their area MP. The group demanded that non-local politicians respect their elected leaders and stop influencing their county political issues.

Around 2 June 2025 (as reported), hundreds of environmental defenders protested in Lamu (Lamu West, Lamu) against the delayed ruling on the proposed coal power plant project case in the area. Led by representatives of Save Lamu, the group demanded that the government provide safe methods of generating power.

On 2 June 2025, hundreds of residents, mainly members of the Uduru Makoa Cooperative, marched while carrying placards in an unspecified location within the Hai district (coded to the district headquarters as Hai Mjini, Hai, Kilimanjaro) in protest against the lease and usage of the cooperative land by a private investor (Elizabeth Stegmaier). The group demanded that the lease be terminated. The area member of parliament and the district commissioner used dialogue to disperse the group.

On 3 June 2025, health workers under the Universal Health (UHC) program gathered while carrying banners and blowing vuvuzelas at the Green Park terminus within the Nairobi city center (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the government's failure to employ them on permanent and pensionable terms, among other grievances. The group demanded that the government address their grievances.

On 3 June 2025, human rights defenders gathered and sang solidarity songs outside the Milimani law courts in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the move by the police to arrest one of their colleagues over the accusation of developing an online site meant to mobilize public opposition to the Finance Bill 2025 (coded separately). The group demanded her release. Security officers used unspecified means to disperse the group.

On 3 June 2025, residents protested in Wakor (other sources mention Onoch) (Pokot Central, West Pokot) against the poor state of the Wakor-Onoch (other sources mention Wakor-Kokwotendwo) road. The group demanded that the Kenya Rural Roads Authority (KeRRA) and the Constituency Development Fund (CDF) fix the road.

Around 4 June 2025 (as reported), approximately 300 members of the Maasai Siria clan stormed the Angama Conservancy in Lolkuruk village near Kimintet (Transmara West, Narok) in protest against claimed illegal acquisition of the conservancy by a former politician. Police officers from the General Service Unit (GSU) fired in the air to disperse the group.

On 4 June 2025, residents confronted police officers before blocking the Turbo-Soy road with sisal plants, with some carrying placards in Seregeya (Likuyani, Kakamega) in protest against increased insecurity following the recent killing of a private security guard (unarmed) by unknown assailants. The group demanded that the police officers be transferred from the area.

On 4 June 2025, hundreds of residents disrupted a function attended by the deputy president by chanting and waving placards in Othaya (Nyeri South, Nyeri) in protest against unfulfilled government promises. The group demanded that the president deliver on his campaign promises. It is unclear whether the function proceeded as planned.
On 4 June 2025, 40 Puntland Dervish soldiers erected an illegal checkpoint and protested in Laag village (Bossaso, Bari) over unpaid salaries for five months.
On 4 June 2025, vendors from Gulu main market staged a protest in Gulu Town (Pece Division, Gulu, Gulu) to denounce the failure of local authorities to stop vending on the street outside the market.

On 4 June 2025, a group of activists from 'Weka Afri Sustainable Biodiversity and Food Security Foundation' staged a protest outside the National Environment Management Authority (NEMA) on Jinja Road in Kampala town (Central Division, Kampala, Kampala) to denounce the degradation of the Wetlands of Lwera. The police intervened and arrested two activists.

Around 4 June 2025 (as reported), around 15 business owners protested against extra taxes imposed by government security forces (NISA) in the Bakara market in Mogadishu - Hawl Wadaag (Banadir). The NISA closed the business after the owners refused to pay the additional taxes.

On 4 June 2025, Puntland Dervish soldiers erected an unauthorized checkpoint and protested in Karin village (Bossaso, Bari) over unpaid salaries for five months. The forces were paid in the Bali Khadar area, fighting with Islamic State militants. The local administration intervened (means unspecified) and promised to address their grievance.

On 4 June 2025, Puntland Dervish soldiers erected an unauthorized checkpoint and protested in Ceel Daahir village (Bossaso, Bari) over unpaid salaries for five months. The forces were paid in the Bali Khadar area, fighting with Islamic State militants. The local administration intervened (means unspecified) and promised to address their grievance.

Around 5 June 2025 (as reported), health workers, mainly members of KUCO, gathered and sang solidarity songs outside the Kilifi County Referral Hospital (Kilifi North, Kilifi) in protest against the failure by the county government to effect their 2024 return-to-work agreement. The group demanded that the county address their grievances.

Around 5 June 2025 (as reported), students from the Eastern Africa region gathered and marched while carrying placards and chanting at the University of Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the ongoing war in Sudan. The group demanded that the war come to an end.

On 5 June 2025, residents gathered in Obunga (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in protest against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of a man in the area by unknown assailants. The group demanded that the security officers serving in the area be transferred.

On 5 June 2025, residents marched while carrying placards and twigs in Kipsiwon (Bomet Central, Bomet) in protest against the poor state of the Sachangwa-Kipsiwon road. The group demanded that the county government fix the road.

Around 5 June 2025 (as reported), residents protested within the Mukuru Kwa Njenga neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi South (Embakasi South, Nairobi) against the move to belittle the president's leadership by his opponents through ethnic slurs and mockery. The group demanded that the president be respected.

On 5 June 2025, residents gathered while carrying twigs at the Kibokoni Baharini squatter settlement scheme (Magarini, Kilifi) in protest against the unfair land adjudication process. The group demanded that authorities address the matter.
On 5 June 2025, Puntland Dervish soldiers erected an illegal checkpoint and protested in Karin village (Bossaso, Bari) over unpaid salaries for five months.
On 5 June 2025, Puntland Dervish soldiers erected an illegal checkpoint and protested in Laag village (Bossaso, Bari) over unpaid salaries for five months.

On 5 June 2025, residents protested inside the district's local administration in Mogadishu - Kaxda (Banadir). They rejected voting in other districts and asked the new Banadir mayor and governor to address their grievances.

On 5 June 2025, families of killed and injured prisoners protested protested at the main entrance of a regional hospital in Borama town (Awadal, Borama). They requested justice from the Somaliland government after their family members were targeted with gunfire during a protest at the central prison on 31 May (coded separately).

On 5 June 2025, overnight, families of killed and injured prisoners protested in Buuhoodle town (Buuhoodle, Togdheer), refused to proceed with the burial, citing unresolved grievances after their family members were targeted with gunfire during a protest at the central prison on 31 May (coded separately).

On 5 June 2025, youth, women, and clan elders protested against the ongoing recruitment of the Federal Electoral Commission in Dhuusamarreeb town (Dhuusamarreeb, Galgaduud). They accused the commission of inciting clan disputes and demanded that the current commission workers be replaced with people from outside the Galmudug region.

On 5 June 2025, residents and environmental defenders protested in Lamu (Lamu West, Lamu) against the development of harmful projects in the county. The group demanded that authorities protect marine ecosystems. The event happened in the context of World Environment Day.

On 6 June 2025, human rights defenders, including representatives from HAKI Africa, protested in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against the move by government officials to conduct a participation process on the finance bill during a public holiday (Eid-al-Adha). Police intervened and arrested 2 human rights defenders.

Around 6 June 2025 (as reported), hundreds of residents, mainly Pokot community gold miners, protested in Kambi Karaya (Pokot Central, West Pokot) against a proposal to close down the mines over environmental concerns and illegal mining. The group demanded that the proposal be rescinded.

On 6 June 2025, hundreds of residents marched while carrying placards in Angata Barikoi (Transmara West, Narok) in protest against police brutality, following the recent killing of at least nine people in Angata and Angama areas (coded separately). The group demanded that the Deputy County Commissioner (DCC) be transferred.

On 6 June 2025, residents, mainly mourners, blocked the Migori-Isebania road using unspecified means at an unspecified location (coded as Isebania, Kuria West, Migori) in protest against the recent killing of their relative via mob violence (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 6 June 2025, parents and students gathered while carrying placards and banners in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against claimed fraud in the Finland scholarship program that was managed by the county government. The group demanded that the president help address the matter.
On 7 June 2025, overnight, residents protested in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal) in support of the Puntland administration's fight against the Islamic State.

On 7 June 2025, residents stormed the venue of a budget forum at an unspecified location within Chuka Igambang'ombe Constituency (coded to the constituency headquarters as Chuka, Chuka, Tharaka-Nithi) in protest against mismanagement of public funds by the county government. The group demanded that county finances be audited and officials implicated be arrested.

On 7 June 2025, residents stormed the venue of a budget forum at an unspecified location within Tharaka Constituency (coded to the constituency headquarters as Marimanti, Tharaka South, Tharaka-Nithi) in protest against mismanagement of public funds by the county government. The group demanded that county the finances be audited and officials implicated be arrested.

On 8 June 2025, residents, mainly friends, camped at the Nairobi Central Police Station (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the death of a teacher who was also a blogger while in police custody (coded separately). The group demanded an explanation for the incident.

On 8 June 2025, residents chanted anti-government slogans in Embu Stadium (Manyatta, Embu) in protest against unfulfilled government promises. The group demanded that the president deliver on his campaign promises.

On 9 June 2025, for the second day, dozens of residents, including human rights defenders and representatives from the People's Liberation Party, verbally confronted a plain clothes police officer as they marched from the Nairobi funeral home (City Mortuary) and camped outside the Nairobi Central Police Station, Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the death of a blogger who also served as a teacher while in police custody (coded separately). Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 9 June 2025, dozens of residents, including human rights defenders and representatives from the People's Liberation Party, protested outside the Nairobi funeral home (City Mortuary) within the Nairobi - Kibra (Kibra, Nairobi) in protest against the death of a blogger who also served as a teacher while in police custody (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 9 June 2025, residents, including traders, protested in Khayega (Shinyalu, Kakamega) against the planned move by the county government to relocate their market to a playground. The group demanded that the authorities reconsider the plan. Police officers used unspecified means to disperse the group.

On 9 June 2025, residents protested in Mosocho (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against claimed police negligence or collusion, following the release of a sexual assault suspect from police custody. The group demanded that the suspect be re-arrested.

Around 9 June 2025 (as reported), residents protested in Kamae (other sources mention Karinga) (Lari, Kiambu) against the poor state of roads in the area. The group demanded that the area leaders, including the ward representative, fix the roads.

Around 9 June 2025 (as reported), Muslim leaders gathered and chanted in an unspecified location within the North Rift region (coded to Eldoret, Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against the recent sentiments by a senator linking the Islamic faith to gender-based violence. The group demanded an apology from the senator.

On 9 June 2025, Yemit Girls' Secondary School marched while chanting from the school to Kapsowar town (Marakwet East, Elgeyo Marakwet) against the school administration. The group demanded that the school administration change.

On 10 June 2025, residents, mainly human rights defenders, marched from the Nairobi Funeral Home to the police headquarters at Vigilant House before proceeding to Jogoo House within the Nairobi City Center, Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the death of a blogger who also served as a teacher while in police custody (coded separately). Police officers (in plain clothes) intervened and dispersed the group using batons.

On 10 June 2025, residents, including human rights defenders, gathered, with some verbally confronting the Homa Bay women representatives outside the Nairobi funeral home (City Mortuary) within Nairobi - Kibra (Kibra, Nairobi) in protest against the death of a blogger who also served as a teacher while in police custody (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 10 June 2025, residents protested at the Livestock market neighborhood in Mogadishu - Heliwa (Banadir) against the government's move to confiscate their land. They demanded justice for their seized land. The police force opened fire to disperse the crowd. 1 civilian was injured.

On 11 June 2025, ethnic Tigrayan IDPs who were displaced from their homes in Western Tigray and other areas bordering Eritrea demonstrated at the office of the President of the Tigray Interim Administration, in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), demanding an immediate return to their areas of origin, before a fifth rainy season in tents. The IDPs carried and chanted different slogans such as 'the government has forgotten us', 'enough', 'return us to our homes', and 'we won't be a tool for political forces'. They decried the government's failure to return them to their homes despite several promises. In the afternoon, the demonstrators forcibly entered the compound of the president's office by surpassing the security forces and refused to leave without a solution, prompting the deployment of several police forces to the area. Around 100 IDPs' representatives met and discussed the matter with the Deputy President of the Interim Administration, Amanuel Assefa, who promised to give them a solution soon. The representatives rejected the answer and vowed to continue their demand.

On 11 June 2025, human rights defenders gathered and sang solidarity songs at the Kenya Human Rights Commission(KHRC) head office in the Lavington neighborhood of Nairobi - Dagoretti North (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) in protest against the death of a blogger who also served as a teacher while in police custody (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

Around 11 June 2025 (as reported), over 100 scrap metal dealers, mainly women, protested in Kitengela (Kajiado East, Kajiado) against the authorities' move to fence off an area where they have been operating. The group demanded a resolution to the matter.

On 11 June 2025, family members of a killed woman protested at Madina Hospital in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir), demanding justice after their family member was targeted by a police officer in in Jabad-geele neighborhood in Ceelasha Biyaha village earlier that day (coded separately).

Around 11 June 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly boda boda taxi operators, blocked Pamus-Ndengelwa by planting banana stems in Bukembe (Kanduyi, Bungoma) in protest against the poor state of the road. The group demanded that the county government rehabilitate the road.

On 11 June 2025, for the second day, residents marched while carrying placards to the Machakos County Assembly (Machakos Town, Machakos) in protest against the deteriorating state of political affairs. The group demanded that the Members of the county assembly address the matter. It is unclear whether the police dispersed the group.

On 11 June 2025, human rights defenders gathered while carrying placards in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against the death of a blogger who also served as a teacher while in police custody (coded separately). The group demanded that the Deputy Inspector General (DIG) of police resign.

On 11 June 2025, residents camped outside the Rwanyambo Police Post (Kinangop, Nyandarua) in protest against the police conduct towards a remandee, following a recent incident where a woman miscarried while in custody. The group demanded justice for the woman.
On 11 June 2025, residents protested in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir). Residents were against what they described as looting and illegal confiscation of their homes and land.

On 12 June 2025, protestors blocked the main asphalt road between Mekele and Degua Temben at Enda Mariam (Degua Temben, Southeastern Tigray, Tigray), claiming that the current administration wants to seize land previously given to them, accusing them of supporting the reform. Police forces fired guns and arrested the people they accused of coordinating the protest, after the youths refused to open the road.

On 12 June 2025, residents, mainly family members and human rights defenders, protested at the Eldoret High Court (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) against the delayed hearing of a murder case, following the disappearance of the suspect. The group demanded that the police arrest the suspect.

On 12 June 2025, thirty four journalists protested at the Nkubu Law Courts (Imenti South, Meru) against the recent assault of their 2 colleagues by a headteacher (coded separately), during the arraignment of the suspect. Led by Meru press club chairperson, the group demanded justice for their colleagues.

Around 12 June 2025 (as reported), residents protested in Sirongo (Bondo, Siaya) against a prolonged power outage, among other concerns. The group demanded that the area member of parliament and the energy cabinet secretary help address the matter.

On 13 June 2025, teachers, mainly members of KUPPET, protested in Malindi (Malindi, Kilifi) against the death of a blogger who also served as a teacher while in police custody (coded separately). Led by the union assistant secretary, the group demanded that the Deputy Inspector General (DIG) of police resign.

Around 13 June 2025 (as reported), residents protested in Mawego (Wang'chieng, Karachuonyo, Homa Bay) against the recent death of a blogger who also served as a teacher while in police custody (coded separately). Police officers lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 13 June 2025, residents blocked the Eldoret-Nairobi Highway with stones in Megun (Kapseret, Uasin Gishu) in protest against the recent abduction of a medical laboratory technologist by suspected security officers (coded separately). The group demanded that the victim be produced.

On 13 June 2025, members of the Patriotic League of Uganda (PLU) staged a protest at the German Embassy in Kololo Quarter (Central Division, Kampala, Kampala) to denounce German's involvement in local politics.

On 13 June 2025, teachers, mainly members of KUPPET, gathered while carrying placards in Embu (Manyatta, Embu) in protest against the recent death of their colleague, who also served as a blogger while in police custody (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 13 June 2025, teachers, mainly members of KUPPET, gathered while carrying placards in Garissa (Garissa, Garissa) in protest against the recent death of their colleague, who also served as a blogger while in police custody (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 13 June 2025, teachers, mainly members of KUPPET, marched while chanting in Isinya town (Kajiado East, Kajiado) in protest against the recent death of their colleague, who also served as a blogger while in police custody (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 13 June 2025, Kituma secondary school students and teachers, mainly members of KUPPET, gathered while carrying placards in Mwatate (Mwatate, Taita Taveta) in protest against the recent death of their colleague, who also served as a blogger while in police custody (coded separately).
