Around 14 June 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly representatives from the Somali, Gabra, and Samburu council of elders, gathered in Isiolo (Isiolo, Isiolo) in protest against a planned motion by Members of the County Assembly (MCAs) to impeach the county governor. The group demanded that the motion be withdrawn.

Around 14 June 2025 (as reported), private security workers marched to the ministry of labor headquarters in Nairobi - Dagoretti North (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) in protest against poor pay. The group demanded that the ministry effect the minimum wage hike.

Around 14 June 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly tea farmers, gathered and marched while chanting slogans and waving twigs in Kapkembu (Kuresoi South, Nakuru) in protest against the poor state of the Kapkembu road. The group demanded that the government rehabilitate the road.
On 14 June 2025, IDPs from the Madhiban clan protested in Jiqafbiir in Cabudwaaq town (Cabudwaaq, Galgaduud). They accused the local administration of clan discrimination.
On 14 June 2025, local youths protest in Qansax Dheere town (Qansax Dheere, Bay) against the district commissioner, demanding his resignation.

On 14 June 2025, for the second day, residents protested in the Baba Ndogo neighborhood of Nairobi - Ruaraka (Ruaraka, Nairobi) in protest against a claimed move by a private company to grab land meant for a public playground. The group demanded that authorities address the matter.

Around 15 June 2025 (as reported), community health promoters gathered and sang solidarity songs in Bomet (Bomet East, Bomet) in protest against delayed pay. The group demanded that the county government address the matter.

On 15 June 2025, members of the Glory of Christ Tanzania Church (Ufufuo na Uzima), with signs and posters, gathered outside the church premises in Ubungo (Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam), following the deregistration of the church on June 2, after its main leader denounced abductions in the country. They called for freedom of worship and denounced the abductions. Police officers used tear gas and arrested an unspecified number of members.

On 15 June 2025, for the third day, residents protested in the Baba Ndogo neighborhood of Nairobi - Ruaraka (Ruaraka, Nairobi) in protest against a claimed move by a private company to grab land meant for a public playground. The group demanded that authorities address the matter.

On 16 June 2025, residents, including traders, protested in Muthitwa village near Chiakagira (Tharaka South, Tharaka-Nithi) against the delayed rollout of the electricity project in the area. The group demanded that the area Member of Parliament address the matter.

On 16 June 2025, residents marched while carrying twigs and placards in Uthiru (Kabete, Kiambu) in protest against the increased sale and consumption of illicit alcohol, following the recent death of 4 people in the area. The group demanded that the relevant authorities address the matter.

Around 16 June 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly youth, gathered with some clapping hands in Witu (Lamu West, Lamu) in protest against delayed National Youth Council (NYC) elections. The group demanded that the Cabinet Secretary for Sports and Youth Affairs address the matter.
On 16 June 2025, locals, including youths, protested in Hiilweyne village (Balcad, Middle Shabelle) over the killing of people in the area due to land dispute (coded separately).

Around 16 June 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly family members and human rights defenders, gathered at the Kakamega law courts (Lurambi, Kakamega) in protest against the killing of their relative (a girl) by her boyfriend. The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 17 June 2025, residents, mainly human rights defenders and Pwani university students marched from Mkoroshoni market to Karisa Maitha grounds in Kilifi town (Kilifi North, Kilifi) in protest against the recent death of a blogger who also served as a teacher while in police custody (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 17 June 2025, hundreds of residents including human rights defenders gathered at the coastal city's elephant tusks monument in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against the recent death of a blogger who also served as a teacher while in police custody (coded separately). Police officers intervened and arrested 4 protestors.

Around 17 June 2025 (as reported), residents gathered with some clapping hands in Isiolo (Isiolo, Isiolo) in support of the planned move by Members of the County Assembly (MCAs) to impeach the governor. The group demanded that the MCAs go ahead with the impeachment without intimidation.

On 17 June 2025, less than 10 to a handful of youth under the Kenyans Against Extra-Judicial Killings and State-Sponsored Violence and Repression umbrella, and human rights defenders marched from Kondele to the Independent Policing Oversight Authority (IPOA) office at Central Square Building in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in protest against the recent death of a blogger who also served as a teacher while in police custody (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.
Around 17 June 2025 (as reported), parents protested at the Ruiri Rwa Rera primary school (Buuri, Meru) against the head teacher's drinking habits. The group demanded that the teacher be transferred.

On 17 June 2025, residents marched while carrying placards and chanting slogans in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) in protest against a planned move by the county government to use part of the Afraha land stadium for the affordable housing project. The group demanded that Members of the County Assembly (MCAs) look into the matter. Police officers used unspecified means to block the group.

On 17 June 2025, more than 230 students from Kuru Secondary School demonstrated from their school to the District Education Officer, via Yumbe police station, in Yumbe (Yumbe Town Council, Aringa, Yumbe) to request improvements in quality and increase in quantity of school food.

On 17 June 2025, residents, mainly the youth and the elderly, chanted justice songs and waved twigs as they marched in Kipkaren (Mosop, Nandi) in support of the Deputy Inspector General (DIG) of police, following his recent move to step aside for investigation into the murder of a blogger who died while in police custody (coded separately), a day after his arrest over the accusation of tarnishing the name of the DIG on social media. The group demanded justice for the DIG.

On 17 June 2025, residents protested against corruption and favoritism in Qansax Dheere town (Qansax Dheere, Bay). There were injuries among protestors (likely as result of Southwest Special Police Forces opening fire at demonstrators).
On 17 June 2025, residents, mainly women, protested against a power blackout in several areas in Berbera town (Berbera, Woqooyi Galbeed). They demanded the removal of the mayor and other officials.

Around 18 June 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly women, gathered while singing and carrying placards in the Vatican estate of Ol Kalou town (OlKalou, Nyandarua) against increased incidents of femicide cases. The group demanded justice for the deceased.

Around 18 June 2025 (as reported), residents blocked the road (means unspecified) leading to the Geothermal Development Company (GDC) drilling sites in Paka Hills (Tiaty, Baringo) in protest against claimed theft of compensation money for their communal land used for steam exploration. The group demanded that their lands committee chairman be ousted.

On 18 June 2025, nearly a hundred residents camped at the Kenyatta National Hospital within Nairobi - Kibra (Kibra, Nairobi) in protest against the move by the supporters of the Nairobi governor to attack protestors during a recent protest in the city center (coded separately). The group demanded that the governor resign and justice for the victims.

On 18 June 2025, thousands of IDPs from Western Tigray (Kafta Humera, Setit Humera, Tsegede, Dansha, May-Kadra, Welkayit, Qorarit, and May-Gaba) held a peaceful demonstration in Aksum stadium during the celebration of the 37th Anniversary of the Martyrs' Memorial. (Axum town, Central Tigray, Tigray), carrying slogans including 'Return us to our home before summer ', 'Respect the dignity of Western Zone people', 'The world's silence is costing lives', 'Restore Tigray territorial integrity'. The event was attended by senior officials, including Tigray Regional Administration's President Tadesse Werede, TPLF Chairperson Debretsion Gebremichael, TDF top commanders, the mayor of Axum town, and religious/community leaders, as it coincided with the celebration of the 37th Anniversary of the Martyrs' Memorial. The demonstration was titled 'enough' and it was part of coordinated demonstrations organized by Tsilal - an advocacy group supporting the return of the IDPs from Western Tigray.

On 18 June 2025, farmers protested against AUSSOM BNDF troops in Buurane village (Jowhar, Middle Shabelle). They accused BNDF of disrupting farming activities and demanded the withdrawal of the forces from their farmland.

On 18 June 2025, traders protested against an additional tax imposed by the local administration at the Tabelaha market in Mogadishu - Garasbaaley (Banadir). They closed the markets and blocked the roads within the market with stones.

On 18 June 2025, residents protested against AUSSOM UPDF in Arabiiska village (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle). They accused UPDF of misusing the tarmacked Afgooye-Mogadishu road. They blocked the road with vehicles and stones.
On 18 June 2025, locals protested against a gang rape incident in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool). They demanded justice for the victims.
On 18 June 2025, residents protested against insecurity in Qardho town (Qardho, Bari).

On 18 June 2025, hundreds of Tigray IDPs protested at Romanat Adebabay, Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), for three days (18, 19, and 20 June 2025, coded separately), calling for an urgent return to their places of origin. The main slogan for the three-day protests was 'Let's not spend the fifth rainy season in tents.' They also chanted slogans such as 'Return us to our homes,' 'Give attention to IDPs in Sudan,' and 'Living in tents is enough.' The IDPs vowed to take their own action if the government failed to provide an immediate and concrete solution.

On 18 June 2025, Kenyatta University students gathered and chanted anti-government slogans at the Kenyatta National Hospital within Nairobi - Kibra (Kibra, Nairobi), to protest against the move by the police to shoot and injure their colleague during the recent youth-led protests in the city center (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the victim.

Around 19 June 2025 (as reported), members of the Oldonyonyuki group ranch marched while carrying placards to the Kajiado West Sub-County offices in Olepolos (Kajiado West, Kajiado) in protest against the demarcation of the land. The group demanded the area list, used in the subdivision of the land, among others.

Around 19 June 2025 (as reported), residents gathered in Angata Barikoi (Transmara West, Narok) to protest against delayed compensation following the recent killing of five people in the area by suspected security officers over a land dispute (coded separately). The group demanded that the government address the matter.

On 19 June 2025, for a second day, thousands of Tigray IDPs continued a peaceful protest at Romanat Adebabay in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), calling for an urgent return to their places of origin. The main slogan for the three-day protests was 'Let's not spend the fifth rainy season in tents.' They also chanted slogans such as 'Return us to our homes,' 'Give attention to IDPs in Sudan,' and 'Living in tents is enough.' The IDPs vowed to take their own action if the government failed to provide an immediate and concrete solution.

On 20 June 2025, 25 families whose relatives were among the victims that were killed by security officers during the 2024 anti-finance bill protests gathered while carrying placards in Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) against claimed biasness by the government in offering justice. The group demanded justice for the deceased victims.

On 20 June 2025, residents blocked roads (means unspecified) in the London estate (Nakuru West, Nakuru) in protest against the recent killing of a man by the police during an operation against drug trafficking. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

On 20 June 2025, a group of young women and activists from 'the Sisterhood Chain' staged a protest on Sir Apollo Kaggwa Road in Kampala town (Central Division, Kampala, Kampala) to denounce the arrests of opposition members who spoke out online, and to call for the arrest of Gnl Muhoozi Kainerugaba. The police intervened and arrested them.

On 20 June 2025, for a third day, thousands of Tigray IDPs continued a peaceful protest at Romanat Adebabay in Mekele (Mekelle, Mekelle Tigray, Tigray), calling for an urgent return to their places of origin. The main slogan for the three-day protests was 'Let's not spend the fifth rainy season in tents.' They also chanted slogans such as 'Return us to our homes,' 'Give attention to IDPs in Sudan,' and 'Living in tents is enough.' The IDPs vowed to take their own action if the government failed to provide an immediate and concrete solution. On the third day of the protest, government offices were closed, and thousands of people, including government employees, residents, civil society organizations, and government officials, attended the demonstrations, expressing their solidarity. The Deputy President of the Tigray Interim Administration attended the protest and reiterated his administration's commitment to returning the IDPs to their homes. He accused the federal government of not doing enough to return the IDPS, using the Pretoria Peace Agreement to divide Tigray and to implement demographic changes in the occupied territories. The Federal government, on its part, accused TPLF of continuously obstructing the effort to return the IDPs for political benefits.

Around 21 June 2025 (as reported), parents gathered at Malukiloriti Primary School (Taveta, Taita Taveta) to protest against a claimed move by a private developer to grab public land. The group demanded that the government address the matter.

On 21 June 2025, residents, mainly family and friends, gathered while carrying placards at the Kenyatta National Hospital within Nairobi - Kibra (Kibra, Nairobi), to protest against the move by the police to shoot and injure their relative (a mask vendor) during the recent youth-led protests in the city center (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the victim.

On 22 June 2025, residents of Addis Kidame and its surroundings staged a peaceful protest in Addis Kidame (Fagta Lakoma, Awi, Amhara), condemning 'extremism' and calling upon rebels to silence the guns.
On 22 June 2025, residents of Ankasha Wereda staged a peaceful protest in Ambala (Ankasha, Awi, Amhara), condemning 'extremism' and calling upon rebels to silence the guns.

On 24 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, marched carrying banners in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) in protest against the move by 2 foreign nationals to sell off a children's orphanage home. The group demanded that the government investigate the matter.

On 24 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, gathered in Kondele (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in protest against the planned nationwide June 25 protests against police brutality as well as to demand justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government demonstrations (coded separately). On 24 June 2025, residents, mainly youth under the Vijana Ni Nguvu movement, gathered in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against the planned nationwide June 25 protests against police brutality as well as to demand justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government demonstrations (coded separately). Led by their constituency representatives, the group demanded that the protest participants avoid political influence.

On 24 June 2025, residents, mainly youth under the One Kenya One Tribe movement, gathered in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against the planned nationwide June 25 protests against police brutality as well as to demand justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government demonstrations (coded separately). The group demanded that youth unite and expel criminals who might take advantage of the protests.

On 24 June 2025, 60 members of the Puntland Dervish Force protested in Balade village (Bossaso, Bari) over unpaid salaries. The protest was in anticipation of high-level government patrol teams passing through their area to hear their grievances, which include several months of unpaid wages.
On 24 June 2025, Puntland dervish soldiers protested over a three-month salary delay in Sabow village near Balade village (Bossaso, Bari). They enacted an illegal checkpoint.

Around 24 June 2025 (as reported), more than 70 residents of Katomaini, Mzingamo, Magema, and Ikumbayaga marched and camped outside the Regional Commissioner's office in Geita (Geita, Gaita) in protest against delayed compensation, following the planned mining activities in the area. The group demanded that the commissioner address the matter.

On 25 June 2025, thousands of residents, mainly youth, gathered in Chwele market (Kabuchai, Bungoma) in protest against police brutality. The group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests.

On 25 June 2025, a handful of residents, mainly youth and human rights defenders, gathered at the Jamhuri Park in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in protest against police brutality. The group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests. The group was chased away by a rival group on motorcycles as police watched from a distance (no mention of interaction).

On 25 June 2025, thousands of residents, mainly youth, marched while carrying banners and blowing vuvuzelas in Meru (Imenti North, Meru) in protest against police brutality. The group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests.

On 25 June 2025, thousands of residents, mainly youth, marched while blowing vuvuzelas in Kiambu town (Kiambu Town, Kiambu) in protest against police brutality. The group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests.

On 25 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, marched carrying placards in Kagio (Kirinyaga West, Kirinyaga) in protest against police brutality. Led by the Kirinyaga women representative (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests.

On 25 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, marched chanting in Busia town (Matayos, Busia) in protest against police brutality. The group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests.

On 25 June 2025, scores of residents, mainly youth, marched from Muranga town to Makuyu center (Muranga South, Muranga) in protest against police brutality. The group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government demonstrations.

On 25 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in Kibwezi (Kibwezi West, Makueni) against police brutality. The group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests.

On 25 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in Sultan Hamud (Kajiado East, Kajiado) against police brutality. The group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests.

On 25 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in Matisi (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) to demand justice for police brutality and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government demonstrations. Police fired live bullets to disperse the group. A bystander high school student sustained gunshot wounds during the incident.

On 25 June 2025, hundreds of residents, mainly youth, breached police barricades along Thika Road in the Roysambu area of Nairobi - Roysambu (Roysambu, Nairobi) in protest against police brutality as well as to demand justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests. Police lobbed tear teargas to disperse the group. A journalist sustained injuries during the incident.

On 25 June 2025, a group of Balaalo people staged a protest at the Uganda Parliament, and Ministry of Justice in Kampala (Central Division, Kampala) to denounce an eviction notice by the president which ordered them to leave Northern Uganda.

On 25 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in the Shauri Moyo neighborhood of Nairobi - Kamukunji (Kamukunji, Nairobi), to demand justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government demonstrations. Police fired live bullets to disperse the group. At least 1 person (a 14-year-old girl, assumed to be a bystander) sustained gunshot wounds during the incident. The victim later died as a result of the injuries.

On 25 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested at an unspecified location along Ngong Road within Nairobi - Kibra (Kibra, Nairobi) in protest against police brutality as well as to demand justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government demonstrations. Police officers fired live bullets to disperse the group. 1 protestor was killed after sustaining gunshot wounds during the incident and later died in the hospital.

On 25 June 2025, dozens of women protested in Wundanyi (Wundanyi, Taita Taveta) against increased incidences of incest, defilement, and other sexual gender-based violence (GBVs) in the region, following the recent defilement and murder of a grade two girl. Led by the County National Government Affirmative Action Fund (Ngaaf) County Coordinator, the group demanded that authorities address the matter.

On 25 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in Chuka (Chuka, Tharaka-Nithi) against police brutality. The group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests. Police used dialogue to disperse the group.

On 25 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, marched in Lamu town (Lamu West, Lamu), to protest against police brutality. The group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests.

On 25 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, gathered in Voi (Voi, Taita Taveta), to protest against police brutality. The group demanded justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests. Police used dialogue to disperse the group.

On 25 June 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in the Zimmerman neighborhood of Nairobi - Roysambu (Roysambu, Nairobi) against police brutality as well as to demand justice and accountability for those killed during last year's anti-government protests. Police fired live bullets to disperse the group. A high school student was shot dead during the incident.
On 26 June 2025, thousands of residents protested in Berbera town (Berbera, Woqooyi Galbeed). They demanded recognition of Somaliland as a sovereign state from the UN and other countries.
On 26 June 2025, thousands of residents protested in Borama town (Borama, Awdal). They demanded recognition of Somaliland as a sovereign state from the UN and other countries.
On 26 June 2025, thousands of residents protested in Ceel Afweyn town (Ceel Afweyn, Sanaag). They demanded recognition of Somaliland as a sovereign state from the UN and other countries.
On 26 June 2025, thousands of residents protested in Gabiley town (Gebiley, Woqooyi Galbeed). They demanded recognition of Somaliland as a sovereign state from the UN and other countries.
On 26 June 2025, thousands of residents protested in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed). They demanded recognition of Somaliland as a sovereign state from the UN and other countries.

On 26 June 2025, residents protested against private land developers Al Bayrak and Doccol in Warshiikh town (Balcad, Middle Shabelle) after the government leased the land to them. They demanded the removal of the building material.

Around 27 June 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly members of the Wardei community, gathered while carrying twigs in an unspecified location within Galma location in Garsen sub-county (coded to the sub-county headquarters Garsen, Garsen, Tana River), to protest against the government's planned move to develop new villages known as clusters. The group demanded that the president and other national leaders help address the matter.

On 27 June 2025, CHADEMA supporters demonstrated at the High Court in Kivukoni in Dar es Salaam (Mchafukoge, Ilala, Dar es Salaam) in support of CHADEMA political opposition chairman Tundu Lissu who was asking the court to review a previous decision to listen to evidence from secret witnesses without his knowledge.

Around 28 June 2025 (as reported), residents marched carrying placards in the Chokaa neighborhood of Nairobi - Kasarani (Kasarani, Nairobi) in protest against the move by a private developer to grab public land. Unknown people (coded as rioters) attacked and injured 2 journalists covering the event and confiscated their equipment.

Around 28 June 2025 (as reported), Early Childhood Development and Education (ECDE) teachers gathered and sang solidarity songs in Muranga (Kiharu, Muranga) in protest against claimed poor pay and neglect. The group demanded that the county government address their grievances.

Around 28 June 2025 (as reported), residents and human rights defenders carried placards and camped outside the Kapsabet County Referral Hospital gate (Chesumei, Nandi), to protest against the disappearance of a 4-day-old baby from a hospital under unclear circumstances. The group demanded an explanation from the hospital management.

Around 28 June 2025 (as reported), residents from 16 villages, including Ol'Rongai, Marigo, and Rigogo, gathered in an unspecified location (coded to Rongai, also known as Ol'Rongai, Rongai, Nakuru), to protest against the planned move by the Geothermal Development Company to evict them from their land for energy drilling operations, citing lack of consultation. Led by their chairman, the group demanded that the government address the matter.
On 28 June 2025, over hundreds of Muslim scholars protested in Cabudwaaq town (Cabudwaaq, Galgaduud) demanding the end of fighting between the police and the clan.
On 28 June 2025, residents, mainly youths and women, protested in Agabar village (Gebiley, Woqooyi Galbeed) against a mining company in the area. They demanded compensation from one of the companies.
On 28 June 2025, women traders protested in Gaalkacyo North (Gaalkacyo, Mudug), rejecting the order by the local government to relocate their businesses from the Puntland region.

On 29 June 2025, residents blocked the Thika-Garissa highway using stones, boulders, and logs of trees at Kavaini market (Mwingi West, Kitui), to protest against the recent killing of a businesswoman in the area by unknown people. Police fired in the air and lobbed tear gas to disperse the group.

Around 29 June 2025 (as reported), residents blocked Kangundo Road using unspecified means and marched while carrying twigs and placards to the Assistant County Commissioner's and Chief's offices in the Njiru neighborhood of Nairobi - Kasarani (Kasarani, Nairobi), to protest against corruption and harassment by local officials. The group demanded that the area administration resign.

On 29 June 2025, 75 members of the Puntland Dervish Force protested in front of the main hospital in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari) over inadequate government facilitation of the injured veterans in the hospital. The soldiers demanded support from the Puntland government.
On 29 June 2025, residents, including elders and youths, protested in Cabudwaaq town (Cabudwaaq, Galgaduud), demanding an end to the fighting between the police and the clan.

On 29 June 2025, more than 200 Christian worshippers demonstrated with posters outside of a church in Kibo/Ubungo (Ubungo, Kinondoni, Dar es Salaam). Police used tear gas and batons to beat them before arresting 52. The protesters were calling for freedom of worship after the deregistration of their church (Glory of Christ Tanzania Church/Ufufuo na Uzima) and denouncing abductions occurring in the country.

On 29 June 2025, Catholic faithful protested at the Nyarugusu Refugee Camp (Kasulu, Kigoma) against the lack of respect and insensitivity of their priest, following the priest's call for voluntary repatriation during a sermon. The group demanded that the diocese help address the matter.

On 30 June 2025, truck drivers, mainly members of the Long-Distance Drivers and Conductors Association (LoDCA), carried placards and blocked (means unspecified) all entry and exit points to the Kenya Pipeline Company (KPC) hub in Eldoret (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against claimed harassment and unlawful levies by the customs officials within the facility. The group demanded that the customs authorities address the matter. Police officers attempted to disperse the group (means unspecified) to no avail.

Around 30 June 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly miners and members of the Kishushe group ranch, protested in Kishushe (Wundanyi, Taita Taveta) against the move by the Ministry of Mining to license a private mining company without community consultation. The group demanded that the ministry address the matter. Police used unspecified means to disperse the group.

Around 30 June 2025 (as reported), residents of Imbirikani and Isara protested in an undisclosed location (coded to Imbirikani, Loitokitok, Kajiado) against water scarcity. The group demanded that both the county and national governments help address the matter.

On 30 June 2025, members of the Oldonyonyokie group ranch blocked Magadi Road with stones and branches, with some carrying placards and chanting in Kamukuru market (Kajiado West, Kajiado) to protest against a planned move by a private developer to grab their land. The group demanded that officers from the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) and the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (EACC) investigate the matter.

On 30 June 2025, human rights defenders protested at the Milimani law courts within Nairobi - Dagoretti North (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) against the arrest and arraignment of their colleagues in connection with the recent protest in the City Centre (coded separately). The group demanded that their colleagues be released. Security officers attempted to deny the group access to the courtroom by locking the court doors.

On 30 June 2025, human rights defenders gathered at the Kibra law courts within Nairobi - Kibra (Kibra, Nairobi), to protest against the arrest and arraignment of their colleagues in connection with the recent protest in the city center (coded separately). The group demanded that their colleagues be released.

On 30 June 2025, Students from Bumasifwa Seed School staged a protest and marched to the district headquarters in Sironko (Sironko Town Council, Budadiri, Sironko) to demand a transfer of their head teacher. The latter is accused of absenteeism, and inadequate relations with the school board.

Around 30 June 2025 (as reported), squatters, mainly members of the Maasai community, protested in Rumuruti (Laikipia West, Laikipia) against delayed redistribution of land. The group demanded an audience with the county governor.

Around 1 July 2025 (as reported), residents and taxi drivers blocked an unspecified road by planting banana stems in Sitikho (Webuye West, Bungoma), to protest against the poor state of roads in the area. The group demanded that the Member of Parliament fix the roads.

Around 1 July 2025 (as reported), hundreds of residents chanted and marched from Nomotio to the Samburu County government offices, carrying placards, in Maralal (Samburu Central, Samburu) in protest against the move by 2 county employees to grab public land. The group demanded that the county government address the matter.

On 1 July 2025, human rights defenders gathered in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), to protest against a claimed state-led crackdown targeting them, following the recent nationwide protests. The group demanded that the government guarantee their safety and protect their right to protest.

On 1 July 2025, residents, mainly family members of the recent victims of the youth-led protests, camped outside the Nairobi funeral home (City Mortuary) within Nairobi - Kibra (Kibra, Nairobi), to protest against the failure by the government pathologist to conduct an autopsy on their deceased relatives. The group demanded that their grievance be addressed.

Around 1 July 2025 (as reported), workers camped at a vanilla processing company in Moshi (Moshi Urban, Kilimanjaro) in protest against delayed pay, following the recent termination of their contracts. The group demanded that the government help address the matter.

On 2 July 2025, doctors and medical staff of the Tibebe Ghion Specialized Hospital staged a peaceful demonstration inside the hospital's premises in Bahir Dar (Bahir Dar town, West Gojam, Amhara), protesting the arrest of Dr. Daniel Fentaneh (also known Dr. Debol) by Amhara state police in Bahir Dar (coded separately). The protesters demanded the immediate release of Dr. Daniel from police custody.

On 2 July 2025, health workers, mainly members of KMPDU, gathered at the Msambweni County Referral Hospital (Msambweni, Kwale), to protest against delayed salaries and poor working conditions. A group of rioters allied to the county government and working under the watch of the police, armed with clubs and riding on motorcycles, stormed the venue and dispersed the health workers before locking the hospital gates.

Around 2 July 2025 (as reported), workers, including health workers, protested at the St. Mary's Mission Hospital in Mumias (Mumias West, Mumias) against delayed pay. The group demanded that the hospital management address the matter.

Around 2 July 2025 (as reported), Muslim leaders from the coast region gathered in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa), to protest against the recent Supreme Court ruling on inheritance rights for children born out of wedlock. The group demanded that the government and legal institutions help address the matter.

On 2 July 2025, hundreds of tuk-tuk drivers and residents demonstrated in KM4 Junction in Mogadishu - Waaberi (Banadir) to reject the additional tax on their vehicles imposed by the government. They demanded justice regarding their licenses. The police forces opened fire to disperse the crowd. 3 people were injured.
On 2 July 2025, locals protested against land grabbings by private companies in Lambar 50 village (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle).

Around 2 July 2025 (as reported), for the second day, workers camped at a vanilla processing company in Moshi (Moshi Urban, Kilimanjaro) in protest against delayed pay, following the recent termination of their contracts. The group demanded that the government help address the matter.

Around 3 July 2025 (as reported), coffee farmers from 76 factories protested in Kerugoya town (Kirinyaga Central, Kirinyaga) against the move by the court to extend a conservatory order halting the rollout of new coffee exchange fees. The group demanded that the government abandon the proposed exchange fees.

On 3 July 2025, students from Sot Technical Institute marched to the county commissioner's office in Bomet (Bomet East, Bomet) to protest against increased insecurity, while accusing police officers of laxity. Led by their student leaders, the protesters also demanded that the county commissioner address the matter.

Around 3 July 2025 (as reported), boat operators protested at the Mulwanda River border crossing point (coded to Mulwanda A, Bunyala, Busia) against claimed unlawful fees levied by Ugandan authorities upon entering their country. The group demanded that both the Kenyan and the Ugandan governments address the matter.

On 3 July 2025, residents of Huruma and Kiamaiko stormed and dumped uncollected garbage at the Nairobi County office in the Huruma neighborhood of Nairobi - Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi), to protest against the poor waste management. The group demanded that the county officials address the matter.

On 3 July 2025, a section of clan militias from the Habar Awal clan protested against illegal mining activities on the southern outskirts of Berbera town (Berbera, Woqooyi Galbeed). They vowed to take arms and defend their land.
On 3 July 2025, some residents and workers at the mayor's office protested against the impeachment of the Saylac mayor in Saylac town (Zeylac, Awdal).
On 3 July 2025, residents protested against the killing of two civilians earlier that day (coded separately) in Agabar village (Gebiley, Woqooyi Galbeed).

On 3 July 2025, a massive number of residents protested against the killings of two civilians in Agabar village by the Somaliland police earlier that day (coded separately) in Arabsiyo (Gebiley, Waqooyi Galbeed).

Around 3 July 2025 (as reported), the Meru community council of elders (Njuri Ncheke) marched to their shrine in Nchiru (Tigania West, Meru), to protest against violence witnessed during the recent youth-led protests in the country (coded separately). The group demanded that the youth respect the president.

On 4 July 2025, youth allied to the DCP party camped and chanted outside the Kiambu police station (Kiambu Town, Kiambu) in protest against the move by the police to re-arrest one of their youth leaders moments after the court released her on bond over the accusation of organizing the recent countrywide protests against police brutality (coded separately). The group demanded that the youth leader be released.

On 4 July 2025, Muslim leaders from the coast region gathered while carrying placards in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in support of the president's planned move to construct a church at the state house. The group demanded that the president promote religious inclusivity by also constructing a mosque.

On 5 July 2025, residents stormed Archers Post police station (Samburu East, Samburu) in protest against the killing of a woman by a speeding police vehicle. Police fired in the air to disperse the group.

On 5 July 2025, residents, mainly family and friends, marched chanting anti-government slogans in Kagumo (Kirinyaga Central, Kirinyaga), to protest against the killing of their relative during the recent anti-government protests in the city center (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 5 July 2025, hundreds of residents blocked the Kapenguria-Lodwar highway using stones and timber at Bendera (West Pokot, West Pokot), to protest against the increased abduction, killing, and eating of several children in the area, following the arrest of 12 suspects. The group demanded that the security officers hand over the suspects.
On 5 July 2025, locals protested in Bula Weki neighborhood in Mogadishu - Hamar Weyne (Banadir) against forced land evictions, demanding that the government protect them from private developers.

On 6 July 2025, members of the Nyinam Nairobi County Network carried placards, sang songs, and marched along Parliament Road in Nairobi City Center within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) to protest against the destruction of property during the ongoing youth-led protests. The group demanded that youth conduct peaceful protests.

On 6 July 2025, Special police forces (Harmacaad) opened gunfire into the air and protested at the ex-control Afgooye junction in Mogadishu (Banadir) over unpaid salaries. The officer demanded salary payments.

On 7 July 2025, residents, mainly youths, protested in Gilgil (Gilgil, Nakuru) against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption, among other grievances. Police fired live bullets to disperse the group and arrested 17 protesters. At least 4 rioters sustained gunshot wounds, out of which 1 later died as a result of the injuries while in hospital. The event happened in the context of the commemoration of the pro-democracy resistance (Saba Saba).

On 7 July 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in Kiritiri (Mbeere South, Embu) against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption, among other grievances. Police fired live bullets to disperse the group. 1 protester (described as a student, a minor) was shot dead (other sources mention he was beaten to death) during the incident. The event happened in the context of the commemoration of the pro-democracy resistance (Saba Saba).

On 7 July 2025, residents, mainly youths, protested in Kutus (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption, among other grievances. Police fired live bullets to disperse the group. At least 2 protesters were shot and killed during the incident. The event happened in the context of the commemoration of the pro-democracy resistance (Saba Saba).

On 7 July 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in the Kawangware neighborhood of Nairobi - Dagoretti North (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption, among other grievances. Police fired in the air and lobbed teargas to disperse the group. The event happened in the context of the commemoration of the pro-democracy resistance (Saba Saba).

On 7 July 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in the Mathare neighborhood of Nairobi - Mathare (Mathare, Nairobi) against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption, among other grievances. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group. The event happened in the context of the commemoration of the pro-democracy resistance (Saba Saba).

On 7 July 2025, residents, mainly youth, gathered at the Ruaraka Junction on Thika road within Nairobi - Ruaraka (Ruaraka, Nairobi) to protest against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption, among other grievances. Police lobbed teargas and fired in the air to disperse the group. The event happened in the context of the commemoration of the pro-democracy resistance (Saba Saba).

On 7 July 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in Nairobi city center within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption. Police lobbed tear gas to disperse the group, as well as arrested at least 10 youths. The officers also beat up and arrested an unknown number of boda boda taxi operators and confiscated their motorcycles over the accusation of attempting to transport protestors into the city center. The event happened in the context of the commemoration of the pro-democracy resistance (Saba Saba).

On 7 July 2025, residents, mainly youths, protested in Thika town (Thika Town, Kiambu) against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption, among other grievances. Police fired live bullets to disperse the group. At least 1 protester was shot and killed during the incident. The event happened in the context of the commemoration of the pro-democracy resistance (Saba Saba).

On 7 July 2025, residents, mainly youth, marched along the Jomo Kenyatta highway carrying banners in Kisumu city (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in protest against the ongoing nationwide protests against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption. The group demanded that youth remain calm.

On 7 July 2025, hundreds of residents, mainly youth, erected blockades (means unspecified) and extorted fees from motorists at Sagana (Kirinyaga West, Kirinyaga) in protest against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption, among other grievances. The group demanded that the government address their grievances.

On 7 July 2025, residents, mainly youth, barricaded roads with bonfires and stones in Thindigua (Kiambu Town, Kiambu) in demonstration against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption, among other grievances. Police fired live bullets to disperse the group. At least 2 people (1 was an uninvolved laborer) sustained gunshot wounds during the incident. The event happened in the context of the commemoration of the pro-democracy resistance (Saba Saba).

On 7 July 2025, the Kalenjin Myoot Council of Elders, 3 Members of the County Assembly (MCAs), and UDA-Kenya Kwanza-affiliated youth groups gathered and re-erected the ruling party wheelbarrow along the Kericho-Kisumu highway in Kericho town (Ainamoi, Kericho) in support of the president and the party. The group demanded the protestors stay away from the party symbol during protests. The event happened in the context of the commemoration of the pro-democracy resistance (Saba Saba).

On 7 July 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in Subukia (Subukia, Nakuru) against police brutality, state abductions, and corruption, among other grievances. Police intervened and arrested 10 protestors.

On 8 July 2025, residents marched while carrying placards in Garissa (Garissa, Garissa) in protest against prolonged power outages, poor road networks, and lack of other important services. The group demanded that the power supplier and the county government address their grievances.

On 8 July 2025, a group of taxi drivers protested near Entebbe Taxi Park in Entebbe town (Division A, Entebbe, Wakiso) to denounce preferential treatments that enjoy the fly over express services. The police blocked their way and fired teargases to disperse them leading to a confrontation. A number of protesters were injured. The extent of injuries is unknown. No arrests were made.

On 9 July 2025, residents, mainly youth, gathered at Imenti House, along Mondlane Street in Nairobi city center within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the recent killing of a hawker by the police during the youth-led protests in the Nairobi city center (coded separately). Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

Around 9 July 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly farmers, gathered in the Ngusiru area of Bissil (Kajiado Central, Kajiado), to protest against the invasion by elephants on their farms. The group demanded that the government, through the Kenya Wildlife Service (KWS), address the matter.

On 9 July 2025, about 100 supporters of the former Mungiki leader gathered and marched chanting from the Makadara law courts through Jogoo Road to the Nairobi city center within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in support of the former leader, following the mention of a case that the former leader had at the court.

Around 9 July 2025 (as reported), residents abandoned a casket at Baricho police station (Kirinyaga West, Kirinyaga) in protest against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of a boda boda taxi operator in the area. The group demanded that the police arrest the suspects.

On 9 July 2025, livestock traders protested in Jowhar town (Jowhar, Middle Shabelle) after the Jowhar administration ordered them to relocate from the old market to a new location near Moyko village. The livestock traders resisted this order. Hirshabelle police forces opened fire to disperse the crowd. 1 civilian was injured.

On 9 July 2025, around 10 residents and traders protested against the rise of insecurity in the Halwadaag area of Belet Weyne town (Belet Weyne, Hiraan). They demanded that local forces and the administration address the high number of robbery cases in the town.

On 10 July 2025, a section of the SSC-Khatumo protested and seized the Jidbaale Hotel in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool). The hotel was the area where the Khatumo Administration Completion Conference was scheduled to open on that date. The section supported some opposition candidates of SSC-Khatumo.

On 10 July 2025, hundreds of residents under the Kililana Farmers Association marched while carrying placards in Lamu Island (Lamu West, Lamu) in protest against the move by the government to grab and evict them from their ancestral land for the expansion of the Manda Bay airfield. Led by representatives from the Save Lamu organization, the group demanded compensation.

On 10 July 2025, students chanted slogans at the Giakanja Boys High School (Nyeri Central, Nyeri) in protest against their school principal. The group demanded change in leadership. The school was later closed temporarily.

On 10 July 2025, former Alliance Girls High School students protested outside the school gate in Thogoto (Kikuyu, Kaimbu) against the acclaimed sexual harassment of students by a male teacher at the institution. The group demanded that the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) interdict the suspect and investigate the matter.
On 10 July 2025, Puntland Dervish soldiers blocked road (means unspecified) in Wardheer Bari village (Bossaso, Bari) in protest over unpaid salaries.

Around 10 July 2025 (as reported), more than 200 health workers under the Universal Health (UHC) program gathered and chanted in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) in protest against the government's failure to employ them on permanent and pensionable terms. The group demanded that the authorities address the matter.

On 11 July 2025, residents, mainly mourners, gathered and held flags at the Kanda grounds in Kangema (Kangema, Muranga) in protest against the recent killing of a hawker by the police during the youth-led protests in the Nairobi city center (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased victim.

On 11 July 2025, several residents gathered and held a sit-in protest in Dore Bafano Kebele (Hawassa Zuria Woreda, Northern Sidama Zone, Sidama), demanding an explanation from the woreda administration regarding the government's plan to incorporate some of the kebeles in the woreda into Hawassa city. The residents claimed that the plan to annex the kebele would weaken the woreda. No government officials appeared to speak with the residents. The residents later went to the woreda administration office, where they were told to wait until the officials discussed the issue and provided a response. The residents refused to go home before getting a response from the government and continued the protest until nighttime without a response.

On 11 July 2025, Maasai community members, mainly members of the Maasai Stock Farmers Cooperative drawn from Kajiado and Narok counties, gathered in an unspecified location within Kajiado County (coded to the county headquarters as Kajiado, Kajiado Central, Kajiado) in protest against the recent court ruling on the subdivision of 3000 acres of land. The group demanded that the Chief Justice help address the matter.

On 11 July 2025, residents of Ndome, Ndii and Mbulia, mainly members of the Mbulia community land shareholders gathered in Mbulia (other sources mention Manga) (Voi, Taita Taveta) in protest against the move by their land management committee to subdivide and sell parcels of land without consultation, among other grievances. The group demanded that the management stop the sale and subdivision of their land.

On 12 July 2025, students from Maumbe Mukhwana Vocational Institute staged a protest in Wampewo village, Bungokho sub-county, coded to the sub-county seat, Bungokho (Bungokho, Mbale) over lack of school practicals, water, and power.

On 12 July 2025, residents, mainly family members and mourners, protested in Tabani (Tongaren, Bungoma) against the burial of a private security guard who was killed in Nairobi during the recent youth-led demonstrations (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 12 July 2025, motorbike drivers protested in Afgooye town (Afgooye, Lower Shabelle) against the increased illegal checkpoints by SNA soldiers. The drivers demanded that the government address the matter.

On 12 July 2025, business owners and civilians protested in Jowhar town (Jowhar, Middle Shabelle), demanding justice for a businessman who was injured by the Hirshabelle police forces (coded separately).

On 13 July 2025, members of the African Independent Pentecostal Church of Africa (AIPCA) protested in the Kayole neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi Central (Embakasi Central, Nairobi) against mismanagement by the current church leadership. The group demanded for election to establish a fresh leadership.

Around 13 July 2025 (as reported), parents protested at Maikona Secondary School (North Horr, Marsabit) against corporal punishment, following the recent move by teachers to beat up and injure 36 girls. The group demanded that the matter be investigated and the teachers be transferred.

Around 13 July 2025 (as reported), residents gathered in Giacai (Kirinyaga Central, Kirinyaga) in protest against the recent move by police officers to stormed a bar, assaulted patrons and took away some alcohol. The group demanded action against the officers involved.

On 13 July 2025, hundreds of residents from Maykenetal, Keyhi Tekli, and Tembien held a protest at an unspecified location in Central Tigray Zone (unspecified location coded to the admin center of Keyhi Tekli Woreda, Werkamba, Central Tigray, Tigray), accusing a gold mining company of using dangerous chemicals and releasing them into Wari River, causing health complications to people and animals. The protestors chanted slogans, such as 'we don't give our lands', 'we will sacrifice for our lands', 'our rivers cannot be contaminated with dangerous chemicals.' The protestors also closed roads. Local administrators suspended the operation of the company following the protest.

Around 14 July 2025 (as reported), residents carried twigs and placards in Karanjee (Limuru Central, Limuru) in protest against the delayed arrest of an assistant chief accused of killing a man in the area. The group demanded that police officers arrest the suspect.

On 14 July 2025, teachers, mainly members of KUPPET, protested at the Kindu Secondary School (Kisumu East, Kisumu) against harassment of their colleagues by the area's Member of Parliament (MP). Residents, rioters who were mainly supporters of the MP (Independent), intervened and pelted stones as well as beat up the teachers using canes to disperse the group. 4 teachers sustained injuries and were taken to the hospital following the incident.
On 14 July 2025, several minibus drivers protested in Mogadishu (Banadir) over the poor state of the roads. They demanded that the Banadir regional administration repair the streets.

On 14 July 2025, students chanted slogans at Kibendo Secondary School (Keiyo North, Elgeyo Marakwet) in protest against the school leadership. The group demanded that the school principal be transferred. The school was later closed indefinitely.

On 14 July 2025, Magegele Primary School parents protested at the Makambako Town Council offices (Makambako Township Authority, Njombe) against a claimed move by the teachers to steal students' food. The group demanded legal action from the authorities.

Around 15 July 2025 (as reported), tea farmers gathered while carrying placards outside the Kisii High Court (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) in protest against the claimed unlawful election of new Kenya Tea Development Agency (KTDA) directors. The group demanded that the directors convene a special general meeting so that they could air their concerns.

Around 15 July 2025 (as reported), students protested at Kipsigis Girls' High School in Kericho (Ainamoi, Kericho) against the scheduled end-term examinations. The group demanded that the school administration postpone the examinations. The school was later closed indefinitely.

Around 15 July 2025 (as reported), students protested at Senior Chief Koinange Girls High School in Kiambaa (Kiambaa, Kiambu) against the scheduled end-term examinations. The group demanded that the school administration postpone the examinations. The school was later closed indefinitely.

On 16 July 2025, residents, mainly farmers, protested in Booster Uhuru (Olkalou, Nyandarua) against claimed poor workmanship by a road contractor in the area. The group demanded that the contractor repeat the work using the right materials.

On 16 July 2025, health workers, mainly members of KUCO, protested in Nairobi city center within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) against the failure by the county government to implement the 2024 career guidelines. The group demanded that their grievances be addressed.

On 16 July 2025, members of the KNPSWU and family representatives protested outside the headquarters of Hatari, a private security company along Rapta Road within Nairobi - Westlands (Westlands, Nairobi), against the recent death of their colleague, who was shot dead during the youth-led protests (coded separately). The group demanded compensation for the deceased. The Assistant County Commissioner used dialogue to disperse the group.

Around 16 July 2025 (as reported), Alung'oli primary and junior secondary school students, joined by their parents, protested in Alung'oli (Matayos, Busia) against claimed mismanagement of the school by their head teacher. The group demanded that the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) transfer the headteacher.

On 16 July 2025, family and friends camped outside the Thika Law Courts (Thika Town, Kiambu) in protest against claimed excessive bail terms for the youth arrested during the recent Saba Saba protests (coded separately). The group demanded that the judiciary lower the bail and guarantee justice for the affected youth. Police officers restrained the group and blocked (means unspecified) access to some areas of the court.

Around 16 July 2025 (as reported), parents gathered while carrying placards at Nyataragi Primary School (Limuru, Kiambu) in protest against absenteeism and claimed alcohol abuse by the school head teacher. The group demanded that the headteacher be transferred.

Around 16 July 2025 (week of), students marched from Simat high school to the Director of Education's office in Eldoret town (Moiben, Uasin Gishu) in protest against poor leadership. The group demanded that the school head teacher be transferred.

Around 17 July 2025 (as reported), Public Service Vehicle Operators (PSVs) blocked the Kilgoris-Nyangusu road using their vehicles in Kilgoris town (Transmara West, Narok) in protest against the lack of a designated terminus. The group demanded that the county governor address the matter.

On 18 July 2025, a group of NRM women staged a protest at NRM headquarters in Kampala city (Central Division, Kampala, Kampala) to demand immediate release of election results. Police forces attempted to disperse the protesters in vain as the latter resisted.

On 18 July 2025, supporters of Naivasha Member of Parliament (MP) (UDA, Kenya Kwanza) gathered and chanted anti-government slogans at the Milimani law courts within Nairobi - Dagoretti North (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) in protest against the move by the police to arrest and arraign the MP over incitement claims (coded separately). The group demanded that the MP be released.
On 18 July 2025, hundreds of civilians protested in Dhahar town (Laasqoray, Sanaag). They demanded peaceful coexistence between the administrations.
On 18 July 2025, students protested at Jera Mixed Secondary School (Ugenya, Siaya) against claimed mismanagement by the school head teacher. The group demanded that the head teacher be transferred.

On 18 July 2025, students protested at Kondabilet Mixed Secondary School in Chebara (Marakwet West, Elgeyo Marakwet) against insufficient food. The group demanded that the school administration address the matter. The school was later closed indefinitely.

On 18 July 2025, scores of residents marched as they carried twigs in Kobila Komuoyo (Karachuonyo, Homa Bay) in protest against claimed illegal evictions by the Kenya Electricity Transmission Company (KETRACO). The group demanded for compensation.

On 19 July 2025, a group of approximately 150 to 200 NRM supporters staged a protest and marched on the main street of Matany town (Matany, Bokora, Napak) to show their dissatisfaction with the results of the recent NMR primary elections in which MP aspirant Namoe Stella was defeated. The police intervened, and protesters dispersed upon the former's arrival. The police arrested 3 protesters.

On 19 July 2025, hundreds of NRM supporters staged a protest in Kapchorwa town ( Central Division, Kapchorwa, Kapchorwa) to demand the nullification of the NRM party primaries and the arrest of the registrar due to results manipulation allegations. Protests erupted after Twalla Fadil and Evelyn Chemutai were declared winners for Tingey County and Kapchorwa woman MP respectively.

On 19 July 2025, residents and NRM supporters staged a protest in Karenga town (Karenga Town Council, Dodoth, Karenga) to decry the delays of NRM party primaries results for Kaabang district women MP elections. Protesters alleged that withholding the results intends to manipulate the results in favor of Rose Akello who is suspected to have lost the race to Loe Doreen Imen.

On 19 July 2025, Chebisaas Boys High School students marched along the Kisumu-Eldoret highway while chanting in Eldoret (Moiben, Usain Gishu) in protest against a claimed concert that failed to meet their expectations. The group demanded that the school administration address the matter.

Around 19 July 2025 (weekend of), residents marched while carrying twigs in Gahaleni B (Malindi, Kilifi) in protest against prolonged power outages. The group demanded that the Kenya Power and Lighting Company (KPLC) address the matter.
On 19 July 2025, several residents protested in Bareeda town (Caluula, Bari) against the shipment of illegal weapons. They demanded the looted weapons to be returned.

On 20 July 2025, a group of NRM supporters staged a protest in Jinja City (Central Division, Jinja, Jinja) to contest the NRM primaries electoral results and reclaim their victory. The protests were organized after Daniel Kanu lost to MP Moses Grace Balyeku.

On 20 July 2025, human rights defenders gathered while chanting outside the Pangani police station within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the arrest of their colleague by the police over claims that he facilitating the recent youth-led protests in the country (coded separately). The group demanded that their colleague be released.

On 20 July 2025, youth marched while chanting in the Nairobi city center within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the proposed all-inclusive intergenerational dialogue meant to address the grievances from the recent youth-led protests. Led by the president of Bunge la Mwananchi, the group demanded justice for the victims of the protests.

On 20 July 2025, for the second day, residents blocked (means unspecified) the Mararianda-Lolgorian road at Engos (Transmara West, Narok) in protest against the poor state of the road. The group demanded that both the national and county governments fix the road.

On 20 July 2025, overnight, students protested at Our Lady of Mercy Girls Secondary School in the Shauri Moyo neighborhood of Nairobi - Kamukunji (Kamukunji, Nairobi) against the claimed sexual assault of their colleague in a dormitory toilet by a night watchman from a neighboring school. The group demanded that the school management address the matter. The school was later closed indefinitely.

On 21 July 2025, a group of NRM supporters staged a protest in Kasese municipality (Nyamwamba Division, Kasese) to decry electoral injustice and to demand a vote recount in recent women MP primary vote. Supporters of Margaret Kabugho, who lost the election to Sarah Balege, accused the NRM chairperson of results manipulation.

On 21 July 2025, Tambach Boys High School students marched to the county education offices in Iten town (Keiyo North, Elgeyo Marakwet) in protest against the ongoing end-term examinations. The group demanded that the education officials help address the matter. The school was later closed indefinitely.

On 21 July 2025, University of Nairobi student leaders marched to the Ministry of Education offices at Jogoo House in Nairobi City Centre within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against high accommodation fees. The group demanded that the permanent secretary of education address the matter.

On 21 July 2025, parents and students carried placards and chanted slogans at Nyakwerema Secondary School (Borabu, Nyamira) in protest against the recent transfer of the school head teacher. The group demanded that the former head teacher be reinstated.

Around 21 July 2025 (as reported), Mayenje Primary School students marched to the headteacher's home while carrying twigs and chanting in Mayenje (Matayos, Busia), in protest against a claimed move by the headteacher to sabotage a football competition in which they were participating. The group demanded the head teacher address the matter.
On 21 July 2025, parents gathered at Simat High School (Kapseret, Uasin Gishu) in protest against poor leadership. The group demanded that the school head teacher be transferred.

On 21 July 2025, hundreds of human rights defenders and supporters gathered, while waving flags at the Kahawa law courts within Nairobi - Roysambu (Roysambu, Nairobi), in protest against the arrest and arraignment of their colleague by the police over claims of facilitating the recent youth-led protests in the country (coded separately). The group demanded that their colleague be released.

On 21 July 2025, for the third day, residents blocked (means unspecified) the Mararianda-Lolgorian road at Engos (Transmara West, Narok) in protest against the poor state of the road. The group demanded that both the national and county governments fix the road.
On 21 July 2025, residents protested in Biyo Cadde village (Jowhar, Middle Shabelle) to show support for Al Shabaab activities and rejected the government operations.

Around 21 July 2025 (as reported), residents protested in Elburgon (Molo, Nakuru) against the government's move to allocate part of a school's land for the affordable housing development program. The group demanded accountability and transparency in the use of public land for the project. Police officers from the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) later questioned a former State House official in connection with the protest.

On 22 July 2025, some residents of Arba Minch town staged a peaceful demonstration in Arba Minch (Gamo, South Ethiopia Region), demanding justice for the former Ethiopian national team and Bahir Dar City football team player (Alelign Azene) who was killed by his wife and another collaborator on 26 March 2025. The Gamo Zone High Court sentenced the perpetrators to 16 and 15 years' imprisonment consecutively, but protesters rejected the punishment as disproportionate to the seriousness of the committed crime.

Around 22 July 2025 (as reported), university workers, mainly members of KUSU, UASU, and KUDHEIHA, protested at the Jaramogi Oginga Odinga University of Science and Technology (JOOUST) in Bondo (Bondo, Siaya) against a poor medical scheme. The group demanded that the university administration terminate the scheme.

Around 22 July 2025 (as reported), students protested at Santa Maria Cheptulon Girls Secondary School (Marakwet West, Elgeyo Marakwet) against the school deputy, accusing her of being strict. The group demanded that the deputy be transferred. The school was later closed indefinitely.

On 22 July 2025, for the fourth day, residents blocked (means unspecified) the Mararianda-Lolgorian road at Engos (Transmara West, Narok) in protest against the poor state of the road. The group demanded that both the national and county governments fix the road.
On 22 July 2025, traders protested at the Suuqa Xoolaha market in Mogadishu - Heliwa (Banadir) against land eviction. They demanded the local government to protect them from private developers.

On 22 July 2025, civilians protested in the Silga Towfiiq neighborhood in Mogadishu - Yaqshid (Banadir), against the forced eviction and property destruction by the security forces. This protest comes after the forces started destroying houses on the government-owned land. They demanded compensation.

Around 23 July 2025 (as reported), over 200 Kalenjin elders and youth from Mutara marched to Rumuruti police station (Laikipia West, Laikipia) in protest against increased insecurity, following the recent incident where unknown people raided and made away with livestock from their area. The group demanded that the security officers address the matter. The group later marched to Wiyumiririe police post (coded separately).

Around 23 July 2025 (as reported), over 200 Kalenjin elders and youth from Mutara marched to Wiyumiririe police post (Laikipia East, Laikipia) in protest against increased insecurity, following the recent incident where unknown people raided and made away with livestock from their area. The group demanded that the security officers address the matter.

Around 23 July 2025 (as reported), students protested at Saseta Girls High School (Konoin, Bomet) against the recent death of their colleague under unclear circumstances. The group demanded answers and transparency from the school administration. The school was later closed indefinitely.

On 23 July 2025, human rights defenders marched while singing solidarity songs and carrying the national flag in Kisumu City (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in support of the move by the courts to dismiss incitement charges leveled against their colleague, following his arrest during the 2024 youth-led protests in the city (coded separately). The group demanded that the state stop using state apparatus to silence dissenting voices.

On 23 July 2025, for the fifth day, residents blocked (means unspecified) the Mararianda-Lolgorian road at Engos (Transmara West, Narok) in protest against the poor state of the road. The group demanded that both the national and county governments fix the road.
On 23 July 2025, residents protested against the arrest of Sultan Qabile in Sheikh town (Sheikh, Togdheer).

Around 24 July 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly farmers, gathered and spoke in unison in Osasimwa near Olorropil (Narok North, Narok) in protest against the poor state of the Osasimwa-Olorropil road. The group demanded that the county governor fix the road.

On 24 July 2025, health workers, mainly members of KMPDU, gathered at the Kiambu Level V Hospital before marching while carrying banners and placards to the County Assembly and then the Governor's office within Kiambu town (Kiambu Town, Kiambu), in protest against poor pay and working conditions, among other grievances. The group demanded that the county government implement the return-to-work formula.

Around 24 July 2025 (as reported), hundreds of youth, mainly boda boda taxi operators, protested in Masewani (Kangundo, Machakos) against the burial rites of their colleague. The group demanded that they bury their colleague in a manner that depicted their generational identity.

Around 24 July 2025 (as reported), Muminji ward residents, mainly members of the UDA-Kenya Kwanza party, gathered in Karambari (Mbeere North, Embu) in protest against marginalization. The group demanded that the party pick its candidate from the ward, ahead of the constituency by-election.

On 24 July 2025, residents, including women traders, gathered while carrying twigs and chanting in Nyambera (Kitutu Chache South, Kisii) in protest against the poor road network in the area. The group demanded that their elected leaders fix the road.

On 24 July 2025, residents protested outside the Kakuzi company offices in Makuyu (Muranga South, Muranga) against historical injustices and oppression. The group demanded an audience with the firm's managing director.

Around 24 July 2025 (as reported), hundreds of residents protested in the Mihango neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi East (Embakasi East, Nairobi) in protest against the move by unknown individuals to grab their land (previously owned by the military). The group demanded that the government help them resettle on the land.
On 24 July 2025, residents protested against forced land evictions in Mogadishu (Banadir). They demanded justice and compensation from the government.

On 25 July 2025, police forces clashed with hundreds of NRM supporters at Arua city (Arua Hill Division, Arua, Arua) after the latter protested and rejected some of the primary NRM election results due to irregularities. Some protesters were beaten by the police forces. The extent of injuries is unknown.

On 25 July 2025, residents held a protest in Maichew town, Maychew (Southern Tigray, Tigray), opposing the Tigray Interim Administration's (TIA) decision to remove authorities from their office. The protesters expressed their concerns and accused the TIA of forcefully controlling the areas. TIA recently announced detailed, significant leadership changes in the Southern Tigray Zone, particularly in the towns of Raya, Maichew, Mohoni, and Chercher.

On 26 July 2025, around 30-50 women protested at the front gate of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Mogadishu (Banadir), demanding that the government process the return of youths who were held in prisons in Mali.

Around 26 July 2025 (as reported), residents and Kat leaf traders protested in Dalo (location coded to admin center, Gelemso) in Habro woreda (West Hararge, Oromia), condemning the authorities' order to move the Kat (Chat) trading center to Bedessa. Oromia regional police arrested several protesters.

On 27 July 2025, thousands of residents chanted slogans during a presidential tour of the Kariobangi neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi North (Embakasi North, Nairobi) in protest against unfulfilled government promises and poor living conditions. The group demanded that the president address their grievances. Security officers from the Presidential Escort Unit used unspecified means to control the situation.

On 27 July 2025, more than 800 families gathered while carrying placards in Mkokoni (Matuga, Kwale) in protest against land injustice following the invasion of their land by private developers. Led by their land committee chairperson, the group demanded that the government stop the ongoing intimidation and planned evictions.

On 27 July 2025, residents of Yabelo town staged a protest in Yabelo (Borena, Oromia), accusing the Somali regional government of 'territorial expansion' under the pretense of administrative restructuring. They condemned the Somali regional council's decision to create 14 new woredas, four zonal administrations, and 25 municipal leadership offices by redrawing several villages from the Oromia region under its new administration. The protesters also voiced their dissatisfaction with the silence of the Oromia regional state. Similar protests took place in Negele Borena, Liben, Wachile, Dhas, and Guchi woredas (coded separately).

On 27 July 2025, residents and traditional elders of Hargele staged a protest in Hargele town (Afder, Somali), condemning the recent administrative restructuring of new Woredas by the Somali regional state, following the Somali regional council's approval to establish 14 new woredas, four zonal administrations, and 25 municipal leadership offices. These protesters also called for an immediate reversal of this decision by the regional government. They claimed that the new restructuring would rather favor the leadership's clan fiefdoms, without proper local consultations and legal due process. Similar protests were also held in Shilaabo, Dhooba-Weyn, and Gabagabo (coded separately).
