On 27 July 2025, residents of Wejerat 20 Adi protested in Adi Gudem town, Adigudom (Southern Tigray, Tigray) against the detention of their administrator and the two journalists on the same day (coded separately). Protesters voiced slogans such as 'We will be governed by whom we have elected'. 'A force that represses the media does not represent us' and 'Justice for the People of Tigray.' Tigray regional security forces (coded as Tigray regional police) fired and killed 1 protester.

On 27 July 2025, a large number of residents protested in Mekhoni town, Mehoni (Southern Tigray, Tigray), opposing the TIA's decision to reshuffle the local administration in Southern Tigray. The protesters carried slogans such as 'Peace is our choice' and 'We shall be governed by whom we have elected.' Similar protests were also held in other parts of the region (coded separately).

On 27 July 2025, residents of Emba Alaje woreda staged a protest in Ambalage town (Southern Tigray, Tigray), opposing the administrative reshuffling of local officials by the Tigray Interim Regional Administration. The protest continued the next day (coded separately).

On 27 July 2025, residents of Dhas woreda protested in Dhas, also called Sogiya (Borena, Oromia), condemning the attacks by Somali regional forces (coded separately) and opposing the recent administrative restructuring of new Woredas by the Somali regional state. The protest followed the Somali regional council's approval to establish 14 new woredas, four zonal administrations, and 25 municipal leadership offices by including several villages from the Oromia region under the newly structured administration. The demonstrators expressed their anger over the Oromia government's failure to protect the Oromia borders and the invasion of Oromo land, demanding that the Oromia region border be restored immediately and that the Oromia government fulfill its role in protecting the Oromia border.

On 28 July 2025, students protested at Nairobi Road secondary school in the Pipeline neighborhood (Nakuru East, Nakuru) against the recent death of their colleague, who was bullied by learners from another school and later struck by a speeding vehicle. The group demanded justice for their deceased colleague. The school was closed indefinitely following the incident.

Around 28 July 2025 (as reported), residents marched while carrying twigs in Lagdera (Balambala, Garissa) in protest against lack of electricity in the area. The group demanded that the Kenya Power and Lighting Company (KPLC) address the matter.

On 28 July 2025, friends and relatives protested outside the Milimani law courts within Nairobi - Dagoretti North (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) against the impartiality of a judge in a case where a police officer is claimed to have killed their relative (a mask vendor) during the recent youth-led protests (coded separately). The group demanded that the suspect unmask while in court and not be released on bail or bond.

On 28 July 2025, residents protested in Doolow town (Doolow, Gedo) against the recent clashes between ENDF and NISA (coded separately). The local security forces dispersed the protesters (means unspecified).

On 28 July 2025, for a second day, residents of Dhas woreda, mainly women, protested in Dhas, also called Sogiya (Borena, Oromia), condemning the attacks by Somali regional forces (coded separately) and opposing the recent administrative restructuring of new Woredas by the Somali regional state. The protest followed the Somali regional council's approval to establish 14 new woredas, four zonal administrations, and 25 municipal leadership offices by including several villages from the Oromia region under the newly structured administration. The demonstrators expressed their anger over the Oromia government's failure to protect the Oromia borders and the invasion of Oromo land, demanding that the Oromia region border be restored immediately and that the Oromia government fulfill its role in protecting the Oromia border.

On 28 July 2025, for a second day, residents of Arero staged a protest in Arero town (Borena, Oromia), accusing the Somali regional government of 'territorial expansion' under the pretense of administrative restructuring. They condemned the Somali regional council's decision to create 14 new woredas, four zonal administrations, and 25 municipal leadership offices by redrawing several villages from the Oromia region under its new administration. The protesters also voiced their dissatisfaction with the silence of the Oromia regional state. Similar protests took place in Negele Borena, Liben, Wachile, Dhas, Dubuluk, and Guchi woredas (coded separately).

On 30 July 2025, locals protested in Bardera town (Baardheere, Gedo), against the ongoing clash in Belet Xaawo (coded separately) and rejected Jubaland administrations in Gedo region. They demanded for withdrawal of Jubaland forces from Gedo region.

Police and military forces were deployed, but they didn't interact with the protesters.

Around 31 July 2025 (as reported), health workers, mainly members of KNUMLO, gathered and sang solidarity songs in Machakos (Machakos, Machakos) in protest against lack of promotions and job misplacement. The group demanded that the county government address their grievances.

Around 31 July 2025 (as reported), residents marched while carrying twigs and placards in Kipini (Garsen, Tana River) in protest against the invasion of their ancestral land by private developers, following the discovery of titanium deposits in the area. The group demanded that the president help address the matter.

On 31 July 2025, parents sang solidarity songs while carrying placards outside the Mbale High School gate (Vihiga, Vihiga) in protest against mismanagement, following the recent student unrest that led to the indefinite closure of the school (coded separately). The group demanded that the board of management address the matter.

Around 31 July 2025 (as reported), youth disrupted a deputy president's function by singing and chanting anti-government slogans in Irunduni (Tharaka North, Tharaka-Nithi) in protest against unfulfilled government promises. The group demanded that the president deliver on his campaign promises ahead of the 2027 elections.
On 31 July 2025, several displaced persons protested in Saylac town (Zeylac, Awdal). They demanded food aid distribution amid the ongoing drought in the Awdal region.
On 31 July 2025, locals, including women, protested in Lughaye town (Lughaye, Awdal). They demanded food aid distribution amid the ongoing drought in the Awdal region.

On 31 July 2025, representatives of Wajarat woreda gathered in front of the Tigray regional administration building in Mekele (Mekelle, Tigray) to demand justice for a man killed in a protest on 27 July in Adi Gudem town (coded separately).

On 31 July 2025, hundreds of civilians protested near the former Metallic Factory along the main industrial road in Mogadishu - Daynile (Banadir) against the government-led operations that demolished their homes. They chanted anti-government slogans.

On 1 August 2025, a group of students staged a protest at Stanbic Bank in Kampala (Central Division, Kampala) to demand the bank to stop its continued funding of the East African Crude Oil Pipeline (EACOP). The police intervened and arrested 10 protesters.

Around 1 August 2025 (as reported), ruling party UDA-Kenya Kwanza supporters, mainly women, marched while carrying banners and blowing vuvuzelas along Moi Avenue (Mvita, Mombasa) in support of the president's re-election in 2027. Led by the Mombasa County UDA coordinator, they demanded inclusion in the president's political strategy.

On 1 August 2025, nursing interns gathered, chanted and sang solidarity songs outside the Ministry of Health headquarters in Nairobi - Dagoretti North (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) in protest against the recent move by the ministry to revoke their internship. The group demanded justice from the ministry.

Around 1 August 2025 (as reported), residents gathered while chanting and carrying twigs in Ebuyangu, also known as Buyangu (Emuhaya, Vihiga) in protest against increased insecurity. The group demanded that their elected leaders help address the matter.

On 2 August 2025, tuk-tuk divers blocked the main road with their vehicles in Guri-Ceel town (Dhuusamarreeb, Galgaduud), after a soldier shot and injured a driver in town. The group demanded justice from the local administration.
On 2 August 2025, civilians protested in Siinay market in Mogadishu - Wardhigley (Banadir) against government land eviction. The group demanded compensation from the government.

On 2 August 2025, residents camped outside the Gatoto community primary school in the Mukuru Kwa Reuben neighborhood of Nairobi - Embakasi South (Embakasi South, Nairobi) in protest against the ownership and management of the school, following a recent court ruling that ordered the school to be returned to the original community management. The group demanded the enforcement of the court order. Youth and politicians intervened and blocked the school's gate using unspecified means.

On 3 August 2025, locals, including women, protested in Siinay market in Mogadishu - Wardhigley (Banadir) against government land eviction. The protesters claimed that the government and private developers are demanding the payment of 80,000 USD for them to stay on the government land. The group demanded compensation from the government.

On 3 August 2025, over hundreds of civilians protested at the Argada neighborhood in Mogadishu - Daynile (Banadir) against the recent land eviction from the Warshada Biirta. The protesters demanded the relocation and compensation from the government.

On 3 August 2025, parents, allied to the area Member of County Assembly (MCA) (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), protested at the Upper Sagana primary school (Kirinyaga West, Kirinyaga) against the move by the members of the National Government Constituency Development Fund (NGCDF) to construct a police post and chief's camp within the school compound. Led by the Parent Teacher Association (PTA) chairman, the group demanded that the construction be halted.

On 3 August 2025, residents, mainly members of CCM, gathered while carrying placards in an unspecified location within Kitangiri ward (coded to Kitangiri, Ilemela, Mwanza) in protest against the move by the party organs to disqualify a former councilor from the internal party primaries. The group demanded that the former councilor be reinstated.

Around 4 August 2025 (as reported), teachers, mainly members of KUPPET, gathered and sang solidarity songs at the Tononoka grounds in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) to protest against the new Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA), citing negligible pay increases and unexplained deductions. The group demanded that the union national officials be changed.

On 4 August 2025, nursing interns gathered, chanted, and sang solidarity songs outside the Ministry of Health headquarters at Afya House in Nairobi - Dagoretti North (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) in protest against the recent move by the ministry to revoke their internship. The group demanded reinstatement from the ministry.

On 4 August 2025, Eldoret Polytechnic students blocked the Eldoret-Kisumu highway using unspecified means, with some camping at the Langas police station, within Eldoret town (Moiben, Uasin Gishu), in protest against increased insecurity in the area, following a recent incident where their colleague was robbed and killed by unknown people. The group demanded that security officers address the matter. Police officers used dialogue to disperse the group.

On 4 August 2025, teachers, mainly members of KUPPET, gathered while singing solidarity songs and carrying placards in Muranga (Kiharu, Muranga) to protest against the new Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA), citing negligible pay increases and unexplained deductions. The group demanded that the union national officials be changed.

Around 4 August 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly members of CCM, protested at an unspecified location within Kisesa Constituency (coded to the nearest known location as Kisesa, Meatu, Simiyu) against the move by the party organs to disqualify their former Member of Parliament (MP) from the internal party primaries. The group demanded that the MP be reinstated.

Around 4 August 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly members of CCM, protested in Mbulu (Mbulu, Manyara) against the move by the party organs to disqualify their former Member of Parliament (MP) from the internal party primaries. The group demanded that the MP be reinstated.

On 4 August 2025, residents marched while carrying placards, flags, and twigs in Isiolo's Central Business District before heading to the County Assembly in Isiolo (Isiolo, Isiolo) in protest against lack of public participation in the budget. The group demanded accountability in the expenditure of public funds.

On 4 August 2025, residents carried placards during a funeral service in Weruini Matanya (Laikipia East, Laikipia) in protest against the killing of their relative by suspected security officers during the recent youth-led protests (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 5 August 2025, young people from 'End Fossil Occupy Uganda' movement staged a protest in Kampala city (Central Division, Kampala) to express their dissatisfaction over the government's silence on their request to stop the EACOP project, and to demand financial institutions to stop funding the project.

On 5 August 2025, for the second day, nursing interns gathered, chanted, and sang solidarity songs outside the Ministry of Health headquarters at Afya House in Nairobi - Dagoretti North (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) in protest against the recent move by the ministry to revoke their internship. On 5 August 2025, residents of Bihawana village, mainly CCM supporters, gathered outside the party's district offices in Dodoma (Dodoma Urban, Dodoma) in protest against their ward nominee, following the recently concluded party internal primaries, claiming that he has not achieved any development during the 10 years he has been in office. The protesters chanted slogans like 'We will not hand over our land, We condemn border plunder, Moyale shall not be ruled under two regional flags, Moyale is our land and bones.' On 13 August 2025, locals gathered and protested at the mining site in Agabar village (Gebiley, Woqooyi Galbeed). The locals rejected the mining activities.

On 13 August 2025, several locals and business owners protested against increased electricity prices in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari). They demanded that the Golis company decrease the electricity rates.

On 13 August 2025, for the second day, a group of Puntland Police Force members protested over unpaid salaries and set up a roadblock (means unspecified) at the former Eastern Checkpoint in Laanta Hawada village (Garoowe, Nugaal).
On 14 August 2025, residents protested against an increased rate of killing in the Ahmed Dhagah village (Hargeysa, Waqooti Glabeed).
On 14 August 2025, Puntland police forces protested over a lack of salaries in Carmo village (Bossaso, Bari). They demanded immediate payments.
On 14 August 2025, tuk-tuk drivers and family members protested in Garowe town (Garoowe, Nugaal). They demanded justice for a driver killed by gangs on the outskirts of the city.
On 14 August 2025, local women gathered at a market area to protest against the high rate of criminal cases in Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool).

On 14 August 2025, health workers, mainly members of KNUN, carried placards and chanted as they marched to the Machakos county assembly (Machakos, Machakos) in protest against staff shortages, delayed promotions, and delayed payment of statutory deductions, among other grievances. Led by their union officials, the group demanded that the county government address their grievances.

Around 14 August 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly members of the Kiambu business community, protested in Kiambu (Kiambu Town, Kiambu) against claimed harassment and intimidation by county enforcement officers. The group demanded that the county governor help address the matter.

Around 15 August 2025 (as reported), residents gathered and spoke in unison in Kipsongo (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) in protest against prolonged power outages as well as increased insecurity. The group demanded that the power supplier and the security agents address their grievances.

On 15 August 2025, residents protested in the Mwembe Tayari area of Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) against the move by a contractor allied to the Mombasa Water Supply and Sanitation Company (MOWASSCO) to dig up trenches in the area without their consent or from the local administration. Led by a human rights defender, the group demanded that the works be halted until the due process is followed.

Around 15 August 2025 (as reported), human rights defenders, including representatives from the Mijikenda community, gathered while chanting and carrying banners and placards in Mombasa (Mvita, Mombasa) in protest against a move by some politicians to tarnish the name of the Kenya Ports Authority (KPA) Managing Director (MD) over claims of involvement in corruption. The group demanded that the president extend the MD's term in office.

On 15 August 2025, unemployed teachers of grade P1 gathered while carrying placards in an unspecified location within Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against delayed employment by the Teachers Service Commission (TSC). The group demanded that the commission undertake mass recruitment of teachers.

Around 15 August 2025 (as reported), residents gathered and spoke in unison in Nturukuma (Laikipia East, Laikipia) in protest against increased insecurity, following recent incidents of livestock theft. The group demanded that security agents address the matter.

On 16 August 2025, 40 Puntland Dervish Force erected an illegal checkpoint and protested in front of the main hospital in Bosaso town (Bossaso, Bari). The protest was due to delayed and unpaid salaries.
On 16 August 2025, Somaliland soldiers protested outside the parliament in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed) over delayed and insufficient salary payments.

Around 16 August 2025 (as reported), health workers, mainly members of KNUN, gathered and protested in Kilifi (Kilifi North, Kilifi) against staff shortages, delayed promotions, and delayed payment of statutory deductions, among other grievances. Led by their union officials, the group demanded that the county government address their grievances.

On 16 August 2025, residents gathered and spoke in unison in Kericho (Ainamoi, Kericho) in support of the recent impeachment of the governor by the county assembly. The group demanded that the Senate uphold the impeachment.

On 17 August 2025, over 50 women protested in Mogadishu (Banadir), demanding resettlement from the federal government. The protesters were evicted from the Dabdamiska area by the government, and they were promised compensation.

On 17 August 2025, residents, mainly boda boda taxi operators, protested in Kapsabet (Chesumei, Nandi) against the poor state of the roads. The group demanded that the county government rehabilitate the roads.

Around 17 August 2025 (as reported), health workers, mainly members of KNUN, gathered in Migori (Suna West, Migori) in protest against staff shortages, delayed promotions, and delayed payment of statutory deductions, among other grievances. Suspected youth allied to the county governor (ODM, Azimio) intervened and hijacked the union officials, locked them in a hotel, and attempted to force them to call off the strike.

On 17 August 2025, CCM party members from the Mbalizi Road location gathered while carrying placards and singing solidarity songs in Mbeya (Mbeya Urban, Mbeya) in protest against the party ward nominee. The group demanded that the party organs address the matter.

On 17 August 2025, more than 50 CCM party members from the Minepa location gathered outside the party's provincial headquarters in Morogoro (Morogoro Urban, Morogoro) in protest against the failure by the party's election committee to approve their elected nominee. The group demanded that their grievance be addressed.

Around 18 August 2025 (as reported), health workers, mainly members of KNUN, gathered while carrying twigs in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) in protest against claimed tribalism in the running of the union in the county. The group demanded that the national secretary help address the matter.

On 18 August 2025, in the afternoon, thousands of residents protested in Mekhoni town, Mehoni (Southern Tigray, Tigray), condemning the civilian injuries, chanting slogans such as: 'Stop killing civilians, We won't accept forceful decisions, and Respect our quest for self-administration.' The protest was erupted after 6 civilians were injured during an exchange of fire between TDF and local militias on the same day (coded separately). The protesters also demanded that the Tigray Defense Force (TDF) leave their city.

On 18 August 2025, Galmudug security forces protested in Cabudwaaq town (Cabudwaaq, Galgaduud) over unpaid salaries. The soldiers seized registration logistics belonging to the National Identification and Registration Authority NIRA) from the municipality office.

On 18 August 2025, residents, mainly members of the Bondeni Maili Saba jua kali association, gathered while carrying placards and chanting in the Njiru neighborhood of Nairobi - Kasarani (Kasarani, Nairobi) in protest against the move by the county government to allow a private developer to commence construction on a disputed piece of land. The group demanded that the county government respect court orders.

On 18 August 2025, residents (likely DCP supporters, as they are defending the DCP leader) gathered and spoke in unison in an unspecified location within Trans Nzoia County (coded to the county headquarters as Kitale, Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against a claimed planned move by the government to arrest the DCP leader upon arrival from the United States (US), over his sentiments while in the US. The group demanded that the DCP leader be respected.

On 18 August 2025, residents blocked the Kilifi-Malindi highway with stones in Chumani (Kilifi North, Kilifi) in protest against the poor state of the road. Led by the area Member of County Assembly (MCA) (PAA, Kenya Kwanza), the group demanded that the contractor fix the road.

On 18 August 2025, youth gathered while carrying banners and singing solidarity songs in an unspecified location within Nairobi (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against claimed poor leadership in the country. The group demanded alternative accountability, leadership, and respect for the constitution.

On 19 August 2025, traders staged a protest in Kampala city (Central Division, Kampala) to denounce unfair taxes imposed by the Uganda Revenue Authority and stringent business policies. The police forces intervened and arrested an unspecified number of protesters.

On 19 August 2025, a group of NRM supporters from Kisoko sub-county staged a protest at Kisoko (Kisoko, West Budama (Kisolo), Tororo) to denounce the manipulation of electoral results by the NMR EC chairperson in favor of Osinde, and to demand the re-run of the elections.

Around 19 August 2025 (as reported), CCM party members from the Likobe location gathered outside the party's provincial headquarters in Mtwara (Mtwara Urban, Morogoro) in protest against the failure by the party's election committee to approve their elected nominee. On 19 August 2025, hundreds of health workers, mainly members of KNUN, protested in Kisii (Nyaribari Chache, Kisii) against staff shortages, delayed promotions, and delayed payment of statutory deductions, among other grievances. On 19 August 2025, residents blocked the Suswa-Narok road with stones and twigs at an unspecified location along the road (coded to Narok town, Narok North) in protest against increased cases of road accidents. On 19 August 2025, Northeastern security forces (formerly SSC/Khatumo forces) erected an illegal checkpoint and blocked a key corridor connecting LaasCanood and Garowe (means unspecified), in the vicinity of Laascaanood town (Laas Caanood, Sool). On 19 August 2025, a group of Puntland police officers blocked the custom checkpoint (means unspecified) along the Galkayo-Garowe main supply route in the vicinity of Xarfa village (Gaalkacyo, Mudug) during a demonstration over unpaid salaries.
On 19 August 2025, locals protested against the increased electricity rates in Burco town (Burco, Togdheer). The rate went up from 0.5 per unit to 0.8.

On 20 August 2025, a group of young people from NRM party staged a protest at the party office in Ntungamo municipality (Western Division, Ntungamo) to denounce local officials malpractice and bias during the primary elections, and to demand the First lady's intervention over the electoral disagreements. On 20 August 2025, a group of traders from Kampala staged a protest at Buganda Road Court in Kampala City (Central Division, Kampala) to demand the release of 17 of their colleagues who were arrested on the 19 August (coded separately).

Around 20 August 2025 (as reported), health workers, mainly members of KNUN, gathered and sang solidarity songs in Mpeketoni (Lamu West, Lamu) in protest against staff shortages, delayed promotions, and delayed payment of statutory deductions, among other grievances. On 20 August 2025, more than 1,200 workers protested at the New Knitwear Manufacturing company in the Export Processing Zone (EPZ) within Athi River (Athi River, Machakos) in protest against intimidation of workers by the company management as well as delayed pay. On 20 August 2025, workers gathered while singing and chanting at the Chemelil Sugar Company (Muhoroni, Kisumu) in protest against delayed pay. The group demanded that the president help address the matter.

On 20 August 2025, residents marched while chanting, carrying twigs and placards in Kadenge (Alego Usonga, Siaya) in protest against the claimed unjust leasing of the Yala Swamp land to a private investor. On 20 August 2025, Kadenge residents marched while carrying twigs and placards to the Lands office and the county commissioner's office in Siaya (Alego Usonga, Siaya) in protest against the claimed unjust leasing of the Yala Swamp land to a private investor. On 20 August 2025, DCP supporters, mainly women, gathered and sang solidarity songs in Embu (Manyatta, Embu) in protest against a claimed planned move by the government to arrest the DCP leader upon arrival from the United States (US), over his anti-government sentiments while in the US. On 20 August 2025, residents of the Maichew town protested in Maychew (Southern Tigray, Tigray), opposing the civilian injuries in Mekhoni during an armed confrontation between TDF and local militias on 18 August (coded separately).

Around 21 August 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly human rights defenders, gathered and sang solidarity songs in Busia (Matayos, Busia) in protest against the claimed move by lawyers at the Busia courts to intimidate a magistrate, following her stance against corruption, among other vices, at the courts. On 22 August 2025, residents, mainly youth, protested in Nyalenda (Kisumu East, Kisumu) against prolonged power outages. The group demanded that the Kenya Power and Lighting Company (KPLC) address the matter.

On 25 August 2025, parents and students camped outside the ABC Muvuti Girls Secondary School (also known as Mavuti) (Machakos, Machakos) in protest against poor management. The group demanded that education authorities help address the matter.

Around 25 August 2025 (as reported), CCM supporters marched to the party's district office in Tarime (Tarime, Mara) in protest against the claimed disregard for the democratic process by the party, following the disqualification and replacement of the winner for the Tarime Urban constituency in the recent primary elections. Around 26 August 2025 (as reported), health workers, mainly members of KNUN, carried banners and sang solidarity songs as they marched and camped outside the county service board offices in Lamu (Lamu West, Lamu) in protest against staff shortages, delayed promotions, and delayed payment of statutory deductions, among other grievances. On 26 August 2025, health workers, mainly members of KNUN, carried placards as they marched in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) in protest against staff shortages, delayed promotions, and delayed payment of statutory deductions, among other grievances. On 26 August 2025, students protested outside the St. Stephen's Usingo Secondary School (Alego Usonga, Siaya) against poor leadership by the school management. The group demanded that the school principal be transferred.

The regional security forces (coded as Tigray Regional State Police) opened fire and killed 1 protester and injured 2 others.

On 2 September 2025, residents, mainly youth, gathered while carrying banners and placards in Kisumu (Kisumu Central, Kisumu) in protest against the recent killing of a man by boda boda taxi operators via mob justice (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 2 September 2025, residents of the Machinjoni, Matisi, Tuwan, and Kipsongo neighborhoods protested on the outskirts of Kitale town (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) against increased insecurity. The group demanded that the security agencies enhance the patrols in the town.

On 2 September 2025, teachers, mainly members of KUPPET, gathered and chanted solidarity songs in Kutus (Kirinyaga South, Kirinyaga) in protest against delayed promotions and poor medical cover, among other grievances. The group demanded that their union leadership be changed.

On 2 September 2025, health workers, including members of KUCO, marched while carrying banners and placards in Lamu (Lamu West, Lamu) in protest against poor pay, among other grievances. The group demanded that the authorities address their concerns.

On 2 September 2025, hundreds of residents, mainly members of the Border Point One (BP1) area, gathered while carrying placards and posters in Mandera town (Mandera East, Mandera) in protest against the presence of Jubaland forces in the town, which has led to the displacement of hundreds of families (coded separately). The group demanded that the government address the matter.

On 2 September 2025, health workers under the Universal Health (UHC) program gathered and spoke in unison in Meru (Imenti North, Meru) in protest against the government's failure to employ them on permanent and pensionable terms. The group demanded that the authorities address the matter.

On 3 September 2025, health workers gathered in Kitale (Saboti, Trans Nzoia) in protest against a recent incident where their colleague was attacked and injured by a member of the public at a Sitatunga hospital. The group demanded that the county improve security in the facilities.
Around 3 September 2025 (as reported), health workers protested in Bungoma town (Kanduyi, Bungoma) against delayed pay. The group demanded that the county government address the matter.

On 3 September 2025, supporters of the Kilifi governor (ODM, Azimio) gathered outside the Malindi law court (Malindi, Kilifi) in support of 3 youth sued by the governor's 2022 opponent and current chairperson of the Kenya Roads Board regarding a contentious 2016 audio recording that purportedly showed her disparaging one of the defendants. The group demanded that the chairperson stop using the courts to muzzle her critics.

Around 3 September 2025 (as reported), residents of Ramana village, including a Nyumba kumi representative, marched while chanting and carrying twigs to Mirangine police station (Olkalou, Nyandarua) in protest against the recent killing of a 17-year-old boy via mob justice (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the deceased.

On 3 September 2025, University of Nairobi medical students gathered while chanting and blowing vuvuzelas near the Central Police Station along University Way, within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the delayed release of their examination results, citing a dispute between the university administration and lecturers. Police lobbed teargas to disperse the group.

Around 3 September 2025 (as reported), more than 150 teachers, mainly KNUT members, gathered and chanted at the KNUT offices in Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest of the recent move by the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) to transfer teachers out of Nairobi. The group demanded that the move be halted.

On 4 September 2025, a group of NRM supporters staged a protest at Kisiita town (Kisiita Town Council, Bugangaizi, Kakumiro) to demand the release of NRM MP flag bearer who as detained over assault grounds. The police intervened and dispersed the protesters.

On 4 September 2025, residents protested in Wajaale town (Gebiley, Woqooyi Galbeed). Protestors blocked the roads with fire, and police opened fire. 2 people were killed. The civilians were protesting for justice for the killing of the day before by unknown people. The protest spread on both sides of the town.

On 4 September 2025, civilians and some business owners protested near the Telesom building in Hargeysa town (Hargeysa, Woqooyi Galbeed). The protesters were against a fraud case involving an Aagah forex trader, following the shutdown of the apps. They requested the Somaliland administration to intervene.

On 4 September 2025, civilians protested near Burco town (Burco, Togdheer). The protesters were against a fraud case involving an Aagah forex trader, following the shutdown of the apps. They requested the Somaliland administration to intervene.

On 4 September 2025, parents chanted slogans while carrying placards outside the Kithyoko Primary School in Machakos (Masinga, Machakos) in protest against the move by the Teachers Service Commission (TSC) to transfer the head teacher. The group demanded that the transfer be revoked.

On 4 September 2025, traders protested at the Uhuru market within Nairobi - Makadara (Makadara, Nairobi) against the planned move by unknown individuals to grab public land meant for their stalls. The group demanded that authorities include them in redevelopment plans.

On 4 September 2025, overnight, students protested at Kabaa High School (Mwala, Machakos) over claims of a prolonged school term. The group demanded that the school management address the matter. The school was later closed indefinitely.

On 5 September 2025, youth from Nyamira County marched while carrying placards to the Ethics and Anti-Corruption Commission (EACC) headquarters at Integrity Centre, within Nairobi - Dagoretti North (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) in protest against corruption in Nyamira County. The group demanded that the commission arrest and charge the county governor.

Around 5 September 2025 (as reported), members of the Samburu council of elders (pastoralists) drawn from Laikipia, Marsabit, Isiolo, and Samburu gathered and chanted at Kisima (also known as Lekisima) (Samburu Central, Samburu), demanding that political leaders address security, land, and development challenges.

On 5 September 2025, members of the Muslim faith marched while carrying placards to the office of the Registrar of Societies at Sheria House in the city center within Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the delayed elections of the Supreme Council of Kenya Muslims (SUPKEM). The group demanded the election of new leaders.

On 5 September 2025, tuk-tuk drivers and residents protested at the Banadir Junction in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir) against the government's decision to impose an additional tax on motorcycles. They demanded justice regarding their licenses. Police Force opened fire to disperse the crowd. 1 person was injured.

Around 6 September 2025 (as reported), University of Nairobi students gathered and chanted at the institution's gate at the Kikuyu campus (Kikuyu, Kiambu) in protest against increased insecurity, following the recent killing of their colleague by a fellow student. The group demanded that the administration enhance security as well as justice for their deceased colleague.

Around 6 September 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly women, protested in Kamangu (Kikuyu, Kiambu) over claims of an increased consumption and sale of drugs to minors. The group demanded security agencies address the matter.

On 6 September 2025, hundreds of residents, including farmers, blocked the Kapkiara-Bakuot (other sources mention Kapkisiara-Bakoiyot) road with rocks while carrying placards and chanting slogans in Tebesonik (Bureti, Kericho) in protest against the poor state of the road. The group demanded that both the county and national government address the matter.

On 6 September 2025, DCP members protested outside the party offices in Meru (Imenti North, Meru) against abrupt changes in the party's leadership in the county, citing lack of integrity. The group demanded that the party leader address the matter.

On 6 September 2025, ACT supporters marched in Lindi (Liwale, Lindi) in support of the party's vice chairperson's candidature for the Lindi Urban parliamentary seat. Police intervened and lobbed teargas to disperse the group as well as arrested 7 members, including the vice chairperson.

On 6 September 2025, residents marched while carrying placards and twigs in Egu Kalinga (Kinango, Kwale) to protest against the ownership of the ranch, following a claimed move by a former area chief to grab the land. The group demanded that the government, through the National Land Commission, address the matter.

Around 6 September 2025 (as reported), Kamba community members protested in Madogo (Bura, Tana River) against claimed targeting by criminal gangs, following the recent intercommunal clashes (coded separately). The group demanded justice for the victims.

On 7 September 2025, boda boda taxi operators protested in Thika (Thika Town, Kiambu) over claims of impunity and heavy-handedness by police officers, following an incident where a police officer opened fire after knocking down their colleague and his pillion passenger (coded separately). The group demanded accountability in the matter.

On 7 September 2025, CHADEMA members gathered in Serengeti (Bunda, Mara) in protest against state brutality against opposition members. Police intervened and arrested an unknown number of protestors, including party officials. The event happened in the context of regional Mashujaa Day celebrations.

On 7 September 2025, CHADEMA members gathered at a church compound in Mwanza (Nyamagana, Mwanza) in protest against state brutality against opposition members. Police intervened and arrested over 20 members. The event happened in the context of regional Mashujaa Day celebrations.

On 7 September 2025, CHADEMA members gathered while carrying placards in Ndaga (Rungwe, Mbeya) in protest against state brutality against opposition members. Police intervened and arrested at least 6 members. The event happened in the context of regional Mashujaa Day celebrations.

On 8 September 2025, North Galkayo municipal police forces protested in Gaalkacyo North (Gaalkacyo, Mudug) over unpaid salaries and took control of the municipal headquarters, denying staff and administration access to the premises.

On 8 September 2025, CHADEMA party members chanted inside the courtroom in Dar es Salaam (Ilala, Dar es Salaam) in protest against the postponement of the hearing of a case against their party leader, who is facing treason charges. The group demanded that the courts release their party leader.
On 9 September 2025, locals protested in Cabudwaaq town (Cabudwaaq, Galgaduud) against the Federal Government's voter registration program, which recently commenced in areas of Galmudug State.

On 9 September 2025, small scale traders gathered in Meru (Imenti North, Meru) in protest against claimed strict tobacco regulations in a senate bill. The group demanded that the bill be withdrawn and consider public participation.

On 10 September 2025, 30 Puntland Darwish Forces protested in Qandala town (Qandala, Bari) over unpaid salaries for more than five months. The soldiers accused some military commanders of blocking their salaries and demanded the immediate release of their money.

Around 10 September 2025 (as reported), residents and ODM and Azimio la Umoja One Kenya Coalition Party supporters protested in Kakamega (Lurambi, Kakamega) against the recent derogatory remarks by the senator against the county woman representative. On 10 September 2025, overnight, students protested at Ndarawetta Girls High School (Bomet Central, Bomet) against the planned transfer of one of their teachers. Police officers and the school administration used unspecified means to disperse the group.
Around 10 September 2025 (as reported), parents protested at Kangaita Primary School (Buuri, Meru) against claimed mismanagement by the head teacher. The group demanded the teacher be transferred.

On 11 September 2025, residents protested at the Jamaacada Gaheer in Mogadishu - Hodan (Banadir). Protestors were against the land eviction by the federal government, and rejected the demolition of the houses and residents in the area.

On 11 September 2025, 30 Puntland Darwish Forces protested in Qandala town (Qandala, Bari) over unpaid salaries for more than five months. The soldiers accused some military commanders of blocking their salaries and demanded the immediate release of their money.

On 11 September 2025, ACT Wazalendo party members chanted outside the high courts in Dodoma (Dodoma Urban, Dodoma) in support of the court decision to overturn the disqualification of their party's presidential candidate, citing unconstitutional disqualification by the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC).

Around 11 September 2025 (as reported), health workers, including members of KUCO, marched while carrying banners and blowing vuvuzelas in Lamu (Lamu West, Lamu) to protest against poor pay, among other grievances. The group demanded that the authorities address their concerns.

On 11 September 2025, elders from the Kikuyu community gathered at the Lands Disputes office within Nairobi - Dagoretti North (Dagoretti North, Nairobi) in protest against delayed compensation, following historical land injustice. The group demanded that the government address the matter.

On 11 September 2025, traders gathered and chanted in Nakuru (Nakuru North, Nakuru) in protest against claimed strict tobacco regulations. The group demanded that the senators consider amending the tobacco bill that is before the senate.

On 11 September 2025, traders gathered in Nyeri (Nyeri Central, Nyeri) in protest against claimed strict tobacco regulations. The group demanded that the senators consider amending the tobacco bill that is before the senate.

On 11 September 2025, boda boda taxi operators protested in Nanyuki (Laikipia East, Laikipia) against a claimed move by a motorcycle supplier to supply them with defective electric motorcycles. The group demanded a refund and compensation.

Around 11 September 2025 (as reported), parents gathered while carrying twigs and placards at Kiptergekian Primary School (Sotik, Bomet) in protest against mismanagement by the school administration. The group demanded that the Ministry of Education officials help address the matter.

Around 11 September 2025 (as reported), residents protested in Mangelete (Kibwezi East, Makueni) against claimed illegal quarrying activities in the area. The group demanded that their elected leaders help address the matter.

Around 12 September 2025 (as reported), hundreds of residents gathered while carrying placards and twigs in Kinoo (Kikuyu, Kiambu) to protest against increased sale and consumption of illicit alcohol. The group demanded that both the county and national government address the matter.

On 29 September 2025, farmers chanted slogans and carried placards as they marched to the offices of Nyakoe Farmers' Co-operative Society (Bonchari, Kisii) in protest against claimed mismanagement and corruption by the society's officials. The group demanded that the officials be removed.

On 30 September 2025, hundreds of Orkierieine residents carried placards as they marched to the Deputy County Commissioner's (DCC) office in Olololunga (Narok South, Narok) in protest against a claimed move by an influential person in government to grab their land. The group demanded that the DCC address the matter.

Around 30 September 2025 (as reported), residents of Damaja and Matagala villages, led by their area member of parliament (UPIA, Azimio), gathered in an unspecified location (coded to one of the mentioned villages as Matagala, Bura, Tana River) in protest against investor entry into the Bura irrigation scheme. The group demanded that the National Irrigation Authority (NIA) address the matter.

Around 30 September 2025 (as reported), teachers, mainly Junior Secondary School (JSS) teachers under KUPPET, protested in Marsabit (Saku, Marsabit) against intimidation, mistreatment, and poor working conditions under primary school heads. Led by the union officials, the group demanded that the national government and the National Assembly enact legislation granting them full autonomy from primary schools.

Around 30 September 2025 (as reported), teachers, mainly Junior Secondary School (JSS) teachers under KUPPET, protested in Maralal (Samburu Central, Samburu) against intimidation, mistreatment, and poor working conditions under primary school heads. Led by the union officials, the group demanded that the national government and the National Assembly enact legislation granting them full autonomy from primary schools.

Around 30 September 2025 (as reported), coffee farmers gathered at Komothai (Githunguri, Kiambu) in protest against the government's Direct Settlement System (DSS) mode of payment and increased insecurity. The group demanded that government agencies and local authorities enhance security and address gaps in the coffee value chain. The event happened in the context of the farmers' annual general meeting.

On 30 September 2025, residents protested in Lamu (Lamu West, Lamu) against increased insecurity, following the recent abduction of a fisherman and businessman, who had traveled to Kiunga (coded separately). Led by human rights defenders, the group demanded that security agencies address the matter.

Around 30 September 2025 (as reported), residents, mainly women traders allied to the Kapenguria member of parliament (UDA, Kenya Kwanza), gathered while carrying placards in Kapenguria ( West Pokot) in protest against the move by the county governor to oppose an empowerment project in the area. The group demanded that the governor put an end to the opposition, as the program has uplifted many small-scale traders in the county.

Around 30 September 2025 (as reported), dozens of poultry farmers gathered outside the Machakos County offices (Machakos, Machakos) in protest against the county's move to impose a fee on the movement of chickens into the county. The group demanded the repeal of the new fee.

On 30 September 2025, health workers, mainly members of KNUN, marched and camped outside the county headquarters in Siaya (Alego Usonga, Siaya) in protest against failure by the county government to implement the Salaries and Remuneration Commission (SRC) circular, non-remittance of statutory deductions, and delays in honoring their Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA). Suspected supporters of the governor (ODM, Azimio) intervened and used clubs to disperse the group. At least 20 protestors sustained injuries, and 5 mobile phones were stolen during the incident.

On 30 September 2025, passengers on a public service vehicle chanted anti-government slogans in an unspecified location within Dar es Salaam City (Ilala, Dar es Salaam) in protest against the shortage of buses for transport. The group demanded the government address the matter.

Around 1 October 2025 (as reported), teachers, mainly Junior Secondary School (JSS) teachers under KUPPET, protested in Voi (Voi, Taita Taveta) against intimidation, mistreatment, and poor working conditions under primary school heads. Led by the union officials, the group demanded that the national government and the National Assembly enact legislation granting them full autonomy from primary schools.

On 1 October 2025, residents gathered in Thome (Laikipia West, Laikipia) in protest against the delayed completion of a bridge in the area. The group demanded that the area member of parliament address the matter.

On 1 October 2025, university teaching and non-teaching staff, mainly members of UASU, and KUSU, gathered and sang solidarity songs at the Technical University of Kenya, in Nairobi - Starehe (Starehe, Nairobi) in protest against the government's failure to honor 2 Collective Bargaining Agreements (CBAs). The group demanded the full implementation of the 2021-2025 CBA, payment of salary arrears, and remittance of statutory deductions.

On 1 October 2025, Kirinya zone residents staged a protest at the Balungi's office in Kampala city (Central Division, Kampala, Kampala) to demand the release of their chairperson who was arrested by the Anti-corruption unit for his mediation in a land dispute.
